Q44_R1_C1: Mark DeGarmo and Dancers / Dynamic Forms
Q46_1:
2017-2018 was an exciting year of art at PS 15. With support from our generous partners and Lowes Toolbox for Education we built a Makerspace and students are "Making", every day. Students also enjoyed showing their original art work, for the 2nd time, at the District 1 Art Fair.

Through implementation of the School-Wide Enrichment Model, our faculty have played an integral part in providing sustainable arts programming based on student-interest. They offer art inspired clusters such as “Dance N Beats," Dive Into Ocean Art.” “Photography and Beyond,” “The PS 15 Paper Co. and Press,” “Comic Creators,” “Sewing for a Cause,” and “Let’s Make a Movie”. 

We continued our nine-year relationship with Arts for All, Inc, providing our kindergarten through second grade students with opportunities to integrate theater and visual arts into literacy. Other opportunities for expression through dance, music, and theater came through our partnerships with Mark DeGarmo Dance, Third Street Music School, Rosie’s Theater Kids, Children's Museum of the Arts, and puppetry with Arts Connection. In addition, all our students visited arts museums, films and performances to supplement and extend arts learning objectives grown out of classroom curriculum. 

Finally, through our Technology Arts class and Makerspace, students study mentor artists, learn coding, graphic design, animation and work with electronics, robotics, and “making” in all its manifestations!

We strongly believe that the arts should be an important part of a school's academic program. We have participated in and developed a wide variety of educational programs and activities to support the inclusion of the arts (music, art, movement and drama) in daily curriculum offerings to our students. Many community agencies support us; including Third Street Music School, Rosie's Broadway Kids and the Beacon after school program. Visitors to PS 19 often comment on the extent to which the students are engaged with their work. We are particularly proud of our school's warm and sociable atmosphere and productive learning environment.

Every student at PS 20 is engaged in the arts in a variety of ways. Our current partnerships have allowed us to provide dance and movement instruction to all of our students in grades K-5. Turtle Bay Music School continues to provide world music classes to our students in grades 1st and 2nd.  Our classroom teachers, cluster teachers, and arts partners work closely to integrate the arts into our units of study. In addition to our many partnerships, we have a school based visual arts teacher and music teacher who meet with all classes once a week. Both arts teachers try to coordinate their curriculum with the literacy and social studies curriculum.  Our Fourth graders dance all year with teachers from the National Dance Institute and have 2 performances for families and the school. In addition, our 5th graders get to be part of Rosie's Broadway Kids; this program gives them the opportunity to take weekly dancer classes for half a year, and attend a Broadway show. Our 3rd graders experience Bollywood Dance with Anja Dance Company, educating the students on the geography, history, and heritage of Indian Dance.  Our Music and Art teachers are active all year teaching all our students to play instruments and different fine arts techniques. This year they will have a Arts Festival Day where they will incorporate all our students work.

Our school currently offers visual arts by a certified full-time visual arts teacher. The curriculum taught is aligned to the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Our school participates in the District 1 Arts Festival at Arbron Arts Center. Our students attend trips that explore the arts and music of different cultures. We are expanding our music program next year to include vocal and instrumental instruction. We will be offering music lessons after school through  NYU.

Q44_R3: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: At P.S. 63, our commitment to the arts is always growing. Since the 2010-2011 school year, full-time music and visual arts instruction by certified arts teachers has been offered to all grades. In visual art classes students explore a variety of 2 and 3 dimensional media and techniques. Additionally, they are exposed to a wide variety of artists both contemporary and from art history, as well as careers in the arts. In music, all K-5 students are given keyboard instruction as well as instruction in reading music and singing. As students move into the upper grades they learn additional instruments such as the recorder, ukulele and bucket drums. To enhance our arts program we continue our partnership with the dance education organization Notes in Motion and theater partnership with Script to Stage-Young Storytellers in 5th grade.

The P.S. 64 Arts programming is growing stronger every Year and is a core element of the school’s vision and mission statements.  This year visual arts programming has been provided to all students in grades preK-5. A new fulltime music teacher has Joined the school community and is providing high quality music education to every student in the school.  These arts educators have extensive experience in their designated professions and bring their passion for the arts to all of the school community. All arts facilities are well suited for Visual art and Music curriculum. The benchmarks designated through the Blue Print for the Arts is followed by all the art educators. The school is continuing its dedication to quality arts programming with future plans of building a theater/dance studio. Additional arts programing occurs with special theater and dance organizations such as The New York City Ballet and Rosie’s Theater Kids.

Q44_R2: Paul Taylor's American Modern Dance Theatre
Q46_1:
The school Leadership Team at PS 110 believes that arts connections can be made within all areas of curriculum and those connections
can help enhance student learning in all content areas. The team also believes in cultivating the many gifts and talents our students
possess in the various arts disciplines and interest areas that students identify. We are currently working towards a more integrated
approach to teaching the arts in which we directly tie newly acquired art techniques and media to our curriculum units of study.

The students, staff and parents are fully committed to the integration of all art forms across all grades. Our licensed Dance teacher collaborates with teachers to align her program with the science and social studies curriculum. Our licensed music teacher integrates her work with developing social emotional growth of our students. The Studio-In-A-School artist-in-residence works closely with classroom teachers to guide our students toward rich explorations of visual art as an extension of mathematical and analytical thinking. Our students' arts products have been recently displayed at the Metropolitan Museum of NY, City Museum of NY, Asia Society of NY as well as various city agencies.

Q44_R2: Mark DeGarmo and Dancers / Dynamic Forms
Q44_R3: Mark DeGarmo and Dancers / Dynamic Forms
Q44_R4: Mark DeGarmo and Dancers / Dynamic Forms
Q46_1: P.S. 140's goals for our schools' art programs focus on coordinating the planning between the classroom teachers, the music teacher, part-time visual arts teacher and visiting artists in order to integrate the arts and curriculum to have a more positive impact on student learning. We look forward to building on the addition of the visual arts program through the Arts Matters initiative this past year. We expect that this initiative will inspire and encourage students to gain skills and confidence through art and gallery visits. In addition, we will continue to enhance our school environment and culture by encouraging performances and displays that not only celebrate the talents of our students but also create more of a connection and understanding of the various units of study in different curriculum areas. We currently and consistently have student work on display throughout our school building. This enables students to support each other and gain respect for each others work and skills. In addition, we have a middle school art gallery and photography wall which showcases the art work and photography created by our middle school students in collaboration with our community based arts organizations.

PS 142 is known for its arts programs, including sequential art and music during the school day. A comprehensive extended-day arts program in partnership with the Educational Alliance takes place from 2:40-5:30 PM daily: this program includes musical theater, dance, art, photography, filmmaking, mask making and storytelling. The program culminates in two showcases and an annual original school musical. Third grade students studied songwriting with Broadway Playhouse (at the Kaufman Center), including attending 3 performances there. Rosie's Kids provided musical theater for students in grade 5, Studio in a School brought visual art to grades Pre-K and K, and Story Pirates brought theater and storytelling to grades K-3. A new partnership with Ballet Hispanico offered dance to students in grades 3 and 4.  In art classes, students studied artists, techniques and processes, elements and principles of art, and major works of the different periods. In addition to weekly music classes, students can elect to participate in chorus after school.

Shuang Wen School has always prided itself on academic performance in mathematics, literacy, science, social studies, and arts.  We provide music, dance, and visual arts instruction for all students across the grades.  In addition to classroom instruction, students visit various cultural and community organizations throughout the year.  Students also had many opportunities to showcase their talent in arts either via school wide events, concerts, art festival, or outside of school performances or exhibitions.
Q47_1: We are a Chinese English Dual Language School.  Therefore, our students also learn arts and culture through Chinese songs, Chinese folk dance, and Chinese Arts and Crafts, etc. to enhance their language and cultural knowledge throughout the Dual Language Curriculum.

Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R5: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
PS/MS 188 is dedicated to identifying and nurturing each student's talents. To accomplish this, we strive to secure funding for arts resources and opportunities for our students. Our 2017-18  CBO arts partners include LEAP, Marquis Studios, Rosie's Theatre Kids, Disney Musicals in School, SEA during the day, and teaching artists from The Educational Alliance during our extended day program.  

We believe the arts provide a unique entry point into academics. Given this,  we collaborate with our CBOs to implement arts-infused curricula in core subject areas, as well as providing skills-based arts instruction. PS/MS 188 is designated a NYC DOE Showcase School.  Our Technology/Media Arts program has been highlighted at our regularly held Open Houses for NYC DOE educators and administrators, and commended by Chancellor Farina.  In addition to providing musical theatre programs during our regular school day, we offer an intensive theatre program during after school.

We believe that the arts provide meaningful pathways for success to and in high school, and beyond. Using Renzulli's School-wide Enrichment/Talent Development Model, we provide students with a comprehensive range of experiences in the Arts: Type I (Exposure & Exploration); Type II (Skills Development); Type III (Application of Skills to Real-Life Situations). The arts at PS/MS 188 greatly enrich our student's lives, and provide inspiration and pathways for our students when they move on to secondary school,as well as contributing greatly to our vibrant school culture.
Q47_1:
Our school offers a three. year sequence in Media Technology.   This program has been highlighted at our NYCDOE Showcase Open Houses (we are a NYCDOE Showcase School) and has received high praise from former Chancellor Farina.   
This program integrates film-making, animation, podcasting, PSAs with music, Maker Space Technology, and t-shirt design.   

We would like to find out if we can get 'credit' for this sequence.  Currently, the choices for 3-year sequences include only:  Music, Dance, Moving Image, Theatre, Visual Arts. 

Please let us know how we can pursue this. 

Thank you!

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: In 2017-2018 TASS provided arts instruction in visual arts, and video/film. All students received four periods per week of visual arts; 6th and seventh graders received introduction to video making in their tech classes twice per week.  6th grade received at least one session with LCI artists, where they spend 3 hours prepping to see an arts event (being steeped in the art genre as it is integrated into a content area) and then another 3 hours post event, debriefing and completing a project based upon the event; thus receiving an integrated comprehensive art experience
Q47_1: School consolidating with another middle school.  We will be closed as of June 26, 2018

Q46_1:
Art Studio: Students are introduced to a variety of art materials and technique - the focus is on creating art, observing art, talking about art and writing about art. Students become familiar with various artists and art movements from around the world and throughout history,they work independently and in groups to create art projects that incorporate a wide array of artistic concepts and materials. Students work on projects that deepen their knowledge of the basic elements (line, shape, form, color, value, texture, and space) while they develop their own artistic style/voice. Projects are often tied to social studies curricula. 

Dance Studio: Students are introduced to a variety of dance styles/techniques with highly trained professional dancers.  Students work in groups to create dance routines. Dance techniques are taught across the grades and are age/developmentally appropriate. 

Theater Program: Teacher works in classrooms with teachers to support social studies work through drama. 

Music Program: Students are introduced to a variety of music making - vocal, instrumental, and percussive; they become familiar with various artists, styles, and genres from around the world and various time periods. Students work together and alone to create new pieces of music as well as to perform vocal and instrumental music in a variety of genres.

Our arts curriculum is purposefully integrated and scheduled into our school day as an integral part of our social studies core curriculum. It therefore becomes inclusive of all students and addresses each child's intellectual, physical and emotional development. Our arts program provides opportunities for our students to explore and express their creativity through learning activities in music, movement, and visual arts. As a small school with limited funding, we depend on the engagement and financial support of our parent body and community-based organizations. Together we are able to provide a rich and essential arts program that helps our students thrive in a rich creative environment and achieve academic success.

Our mission at the Earth School is to support our students inherent love of learning through a curriculum that is engaging, playful, socially-conscious and rigorous. We are committed to knowing each student through his or her individual strengths and to nurturing the development of the whole child. To this end, students receive arts instruction that is integrated into the main curriculum of their classroom, as well as stand-alone arts instruction in visual arts, dance, music, and theater.

UNHS believes in exposing students to diverse forms of fine arts, media arts, dance, music, and theater. During the school day, every student takes at least one dance, music, and/or visual arts course each semester. Our visual arts program fosters students’ creativity and addresses their social and emotional needs while encouraging thoughtful application of the formal and conceptual aspects of art and art making. Through collaboration on projects such as mural painting and art installations, our students develop artistic and interpersonal skills as they play an active role in beautifying our school and community. Our music program offers music literacy through keyboarding for all students and infuses technology through beat making; jazz and rock bands allow for student choice. Students also take dance classes as a part of their regular coursework, studying various forms of cultural dances and examine the technique, history, influence, and aesthetics of each. For 2018-19, we wish to begin tracking students through sequential arts concentrations and maintain a collaborative community partnership with Abrons Arts Center/Henry Street Settlement.
Q47_1: We have strong after school programming, dance students have the opportunity to engage with the community through many outside of school performances including: Manhattan Borough Arts Festival at the Apollo Theater,  9/11 5k Community Day, NYC's Dance Parade and Dance Fest in Tompkins Square Park.  Dance, Music, and Visual arts all share their work at Abrons center in the Disctrict 1 Arts Festival.

Q46_1: We strive to expose our students to a variety of arts in order to expand their horizons and make them more well rounded individuals. Students express themselves in a myriad of ways; we work on providing them with a variety of opportunities. Currently we provide our students with visual arts, digital photography, dance,  rock band, and theater instruction. Students have the opportunity to try 2 different types of arts classes each year from 6-12th grade, four days a week plus after school classes and clubs. Each year we strive to strengthen the programs currently in place and to expand the variety of choices by doing outreach to outside organizations.

Q32_6: Through my Actor's Union I attend developmental works.
Q46_1: Marta Valle High School believes in the importance of enhancing and educating every student through Music, and Dance, in addition to all academic core areas. All students have the opportunity to take courses in Required Music which meets five days a week. The required classes are prerequisites for the advance classes offered in the arts which include:  Music Audio Engineering, Piano I , Piano II. There is also an after school Dance club, and a Music Performance Club that are offered to the students. There are two major music and dance performance events. Also, included in our performances are group/or solo pianists. Both the Winter Show and the Spring Show involve mostly all the students involved in the arts. There is usually a cast of 25-30 performers. Non performing students take the roles of producer, set designer, program designer, lighting controller, sound mixer/audio, and stage manager. In this coming year,a new expansion of facilities in the MVHS Recording Studio,has begun. All arts instruction is aligned to the New York State Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the arts and offers a pathway for excellence and engagement in the arts for all students. *Please view samples of past and present performances at our school website: music.martavalle.org
Q47_1:
The arts offers our urban population at Marta Valle HS an outlet for emotional and identity expression. The training and rehearsal process offers a step-by-step approach to career readiness in areas such as: vocal singing,dance, audio engineering, music composition, and music production. This gives students the ability to self-actualize and create meaning through music, multi-media additions, dance and other various multiple intelligences.
 We are in the process of completing a professional recording studio, however this year our funding was cut due to the ending of a previous grant. We received funds  for the  purchase of  the necessary music software. However, we now need funds for the refurbishing of old recording booths,and the purchase of new portable recording booths.

Q46_1: Our school is dedicated to exposing students to the many opportunities New York City has to offer in the arts. Every semester we offer ballroom dancing through our physical education classes; Lincoln Center visits to work with our students on a small theatrical performance. We also started an AP Art class for students to attempt to get college credit. Our after school program allows students to explore museums across the city and attend Broadway shows. We offer choir, modern dance, drama and visual arts after school and they perform several times throughout the year. Our goal is to continue our partnerships and allow our students the opportunity to learn about American culture and living through the arts. Additionally, we partner with Magic Box, Abrons Center for the Arts Henry Street Settlement, and Ballet Hispanico. From 2016-2020 we will be in a partnership with Exploring the Arts.

NEST+m is a citywide K-12 G&T screened school. We are a STEM school that is committed to meeting the needs of all learners-this commitment means that we value the arts AND the sciences. To do this, we take every opportunity to promote the arts. We supplement in-school programs and courses with after school arts programming. For 2018-2019 we are hoping to add an additional dance residency for 3rd grade. We look forward to continuing on this mission.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the 3rd Street Music School Settlement
Q46_1: Students who apply and are accepted into our transfer high school will be provided with the necessary arts courses to satisfy New York State Department of Education requirements for high school graduation. Student surveys are utilized to determine the types of Art classes to be offered each semester.  In addition to credit-bearing arts programming during the school day, an Extended School Day/School Violence Prevention grant allows us to offer after-school music programs as well as in-school dance workshops.
Our goals are to augment learning with imaginative problem solving, skill development teamwork, aesthetic education, historical contexts.

At P.S. 1 our art programs are embedded into our school curriculum and content studies. We ensure that every child has the opportunity to be involved in the arts program as a musician, singer, artist, director, stage hand, script writer, ballerina, or choreographer. Our goal is to expose our children to all arts forms as they continue to grow as learners at P.S. 1 and become well -rounded citizens in society.

P.S. 2 believes in the importance of arts education as part of our rigorous and well rounded curriculum. Visual arts and music classes engage students in a wide range of learning. Our visual arts curriculum includes exploration of different art forms while incorporating a study of famous artists. The music curriculum includes instruction in instrumental performance (keyboard, xylophone and recorder) as well as instruction in reading music.  Enrichment periods are scheduled to provide additional opportunities in arts learning. We seek out partnerships to further student arts learning and have recently partnered with NYU Music Mentors to provide additional music lessons. To prepare students for 21st century learning, our students use their individual iPad apps to create iMovies, keynote for presentations as well as pages for poster presentations. These are integrated into all content areas of the curriculum - reading, writing, social studies and science. National Dance Institute continues their 30 year history at P.S. 2 teaching our 5th graders. At P.S.2, we recognize the significant impact of arts learning: promoting academic learning, developing important skills, and building positive self-esteem. It is our goal that all our students receive the highest quality arts education.

There is exceptionally strong school community support for the arts. An integral part of the school's mission is to integrate the arts with the academic curriculum. Many classroom teachers have professional backgrounds or serious amateur involvement in one or more of the arts, and many of our families have professional involvement in the arts as well. We offer visual arts, movement, technology and music programs supported by a combination of Department of Education and PTA funding, as well as a grant from the Rudin Foundation. Our children have in-house movement classes twice a week and in-house art once a week. Our clay and music programs provide extra time in the arts each week. The PTA also funds "artist and scientist in residence" mini-grants to classroom teachers,which permit them to partner with outside arts and cultural organizations to support student learning through the arts within the classroom. We take full advantage of local arts organizations, museums, and theaters through residencies and field trips.

Our young artists are active and exuberant explorers who are increasingly curious about the art world around them. They will discover that ideas can be interpreted in a variety of ways and that creating art supports the development of a variety of skills and a sense of self as an artist. Our students will recognize the cultural, societal, and historical significance of art, connect the visual arts to other disciplines, and apply the skills and knowledge learned in visual arts to interpreting the world. We look forward to working with children and observing their ongoing development as artists in our school community.

Q44_R3: Education In Dance & The Related Arts
Q44_R4: Circle in the Square Theatre School
Q46_1: We are an arts-based school with full-time, certified teachers in the following disciplines: art, dance, music and theater. Every grade partners with an outside organization focused on theater or dance; third, fourth and fifth graders have two artists -in- residency partnerships throughout the school year. Our dance, music and theater teacher also collaborate in designing three productions, one each for second, third and fifth grade, with students from other grades helping with sound management and stage direction.

Q44_R2: Circle in the Square Theatre School
Q44_R5: Society of the 3rd Street Music School Settlement
Q46_1: The art program at PS 33 Chelsea Prep inspires students to explore the different ways that they can visually express themselves in a supportive classroom studio environment. Art lessons are developmentally appropriate experiences that encourage children to reflect and communicate about themselves and the world around them. The philosophy of our visual arts program emphasizes that all our students are potential artists who view the world from their own unique perspectives. Their experiences of living in the world are communicated through explorations with different arts materials in drawing, painting, collage, printmaking, and sculpture. Our program inspires students to explore a variety of processes and techniques for self expression and communication. Children are encouraged to work independently as well as in collaborative group settings at all grade levels. All art lessons are aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts at each benchmark level, the New York State Learning Standards for the Arts and the National Visual Arts Standards. Projects and themes are structured to support the philosophies and perspectives of other disciplines such as math, literacy, science, social studies, language arts and technology.
Q47_1:
PS 33 has students in grades PK-5 and is proud to host a diverse community of learners. We work collaboratively to maintain the remarkable achievement that has become the norm for our students. It is home to a rich, standards based curriculum that fosters analytical thinking, creativity, and independence. We use a wide range of resources to provide an holistic and challenging academic program while fostering a welcoming school community. As evidenced through the data here, the school strives to make many and varied connections for all our students by utilizing the vast array of out of school arts and cultural organizations available to public school students in NYC.
Student artwork, art reproductions, picture books and technology are incorporated to assist in achieving the goals of the art program at our school. The artistic development of each child is a blueprint for how we approach the growth of the individual in the classroom experience.  
The art classroom studio provides children a rare and valuable opportunity to express visually their unique feelings, thoughts, and perspectives. Extended time in a studio environment allows for experiences where students can take the time to experiment and create at a developmentally appropriate pace to their needs.  Children learn best when their learning matters to them – when it’s connected to their lives and experiences – and filled with wonder, joy and fun!

Q46_1: PS 40 is committed to developing a high quality arts program: the integration of the arts into our classroom curriculum is essential. Our full time art and music teachers provide our students with an outstanding and comprehensive program that ranges from multi-media use to choral and instrumental music. Outside organizations, such as National Dance Institute and Marquis Studios, supplement and enrich our in-house art studies. Afterschool opportunities in the arts are also available to students. Children celebrate their work through performances and exhibitions.

Located in the heart of historic Greenwich Village, PS41 both reflects the rich cultural diversity of our neighborhood and dynamically incorporates the resources of our neighborhood into our studies. The arts are well integrated into all curriculum areas. Our building is a vibrant testimony to the creative pulse of our community. We have partnerships with: National Dance Institute, The Highline, The Whitney Museum and Jazz at Lincoln Center. Our after school programs provide instruction in choral music, piano, violin and rythym instruments.

Through immersion and our collaborations with various cultural programs, our students will develop talent and skill in different areas of the arts. The arts are integrated into our interdisciplinary curriculum with a focus on the development of literacy, non-cultural appreciation and integration of the curriculum. The programs of study actively engage children in experiencing the arts, using them and communicating through them. We have collaborations with organizations including Chen Dance Center, The Drawing Center, Dancing Classrooms, Audubon Society, Center of Architecture Foundation, Midori and Friends (Jason Poole, Mexico Beyond Mariachi, Chen Tao, Forest Drums), Faces of Wonder, New Victory Theater, YMCA. All of these organizations provide residencies including professional development for participating staff in addition to parental participation. The cultural arts programs are selected because they are aligned to the core curriculum and support the classroom instruction taking place.

"47" American Sign Language and English High School offers courses, clubs and community opportunities in several arts disciplines; these disciplines include Visual Arts, Theater and Dance. Our American Sign Language Courses and core courses also integrate the Arts. In addition to arts courses, "47" offers Arts and Illustration Clubs, Dance and Step Clubs as well as Music, Photography and Theater Clubs. Our students and faculty perform in an Annual Talent Showcase as well as smaller performances throughout the school year.  Our school also provides visits focused on Arts Enrichment: these include visits with teaching artists, trips to various New York City Art Venues, Broadway Plays, Musicals and Dance Performances.
Q47_1: We focus on Arts which are accessible to the Deaf Community.  While many of our students are hearing, our focus is American Sign Language and several of our students and parents are Deaf or hard of hearing.   This would include captioned performances and shows.

Q39_4: participating in a concert with students
Q46_1: P.S. 51 currently offers a well-rounded, standards-driven arts program that combines the elements of visual art, music, movement, dance, and theater to enhance the overall educational experience of our students. Through extensive horizontal and vertical collaboration among arts and classroom teachers, students are provided with multiple opportunities to share their skills and creative talents with the entire school community through arts shows, instrumental/vocal concerts, and dance performances. Our arts teachers have designed a unique program including special clubs and classes like fashion design, chorus, Orff ensembles, recorder ensembles, guitar, ukulele, violin and cello classes, and music theater in addition to the scaffolded curriculum offered in weekly arts classes. We strive to provide a safe and nurturing environment where students are encouraged to transcend emotional boundaries and explore their creative energies.

The PS 59 community strives continuously to provide a comprehensive arts experience for every student. We continue to foster our mission as part of our ongoing commitment to social emotional learning, student confidence, coordination, skill, and appreciation for the arts by maximizing opportunities for movement and creative expression throughout the day. Each year, teachers and resident artists collaborate and reflect to make purposeful decisions about the arts programs being provided to students. We have been fortunate to expand our offerings to include even more hours devoted to theater and dance while maintaining the breadth and quality of our long term music and studio arts programs. It is quite rewarding to celebrate our eager and talented learners each year through the arts. We are thrilled with our current Arts Partners; including Creative Stages, City Center, Lincoln Center, the NY Philharmonic, and Arts Connection. We will continue to rely on the generous support and commitment of our PTA and the City Council as we face anticipated budgetary challenges.

In grades K-5, the Lower Lab School boasts a full calendar of family-friendly arts events, including those related to academic achievement : (Music Concerts, Sotheby's Art Show). The art specialists follow the NYS Arts Curriculum which includes hands-on exploration of the visual arts. The music specialist follows an exploration of music that involves learning, listening and performing music using violins, cellos and, recorders.

PS 89 is committed to providing an enriched art education program to all students. Children participate in weekly classes in dance, music and visual arts. The arts programs are integrated in the classroom curriculum. Collaboration occurs regularly among the classroom teachers and arts teachers which enriches the units of study for children. We believe that providing children with a well-rounded education includes regular participation in a variety of arts programs. Whenever possible we augment our programs by bringing in arts organizations that represent the rich variety of disciplines within the arts in New York City.

Students study visual arts in grade 6 & 7 with an array of contexts offered (calligraphy, pastels, stills, puppets, water paint, mosaics, etc.). Connections are made to their social studies curriculum such as study of and replication of folk art, weaving, etc. The ceramics class has students creating a variety of both functional and decorative pieces with an after school component that allows students to use a potter's wheel. Orchestral music is offered in all grades to students who select this option. Drama is also offered to grades 6 & 7. There is a full length musical production at the end of the year. All 8th grade students select their electives, allowing them to "major" in the discipline of their choice.

Currently P.S. 111 has a full time music teacher and art teacher for grades Pre-K through 5. This year we have four outside organizations that provide arts programming to our students: Studio in the Schools (Pre-K), Alvin Ailey Dance (Grade 4), Young Storyteller's Theater Program (Grade 5) and Orchestra of St. Lukes (Grades 2-5) which is an after school program that services about 15 students. As a school, our goal is to have a grade specific arts program provided by outside arts organization in addition to our full time music and art teachers. However, this is all contingent on funding.

PS 124 views the arts (visual arts, music, theater and dance) as integral components of a well-rounded curriculum for all elementary students. Arts programs at PS 124 also support and enrich academic learning in order for students to develop reading, writing and oral language skills. Appreciation for various art forms is encouraged as students visit different cultural institutions, as well as participate in hands-on activities taught by New York State certified arts teachers and teaching artists from partner organizations. Meaningful arts education at PS 124 is supported by professional development in order for productive teaching and learning to take place in the classroom. The arts teachers use the various art disciplines to help children develop appreciation for the arts as well as provide them with other avenues to express their understanding of themselves and their world. In addition, the teachers will use their discipline as another means to develop literacy skills. The arts teachers will plan and work with classroom teachers, incorporating the arts into the curriculum. Parents support the arts at PS 124 by attending student performances at our school and chaperoning students to numerous arts events throughout New York City.

Our school provides a very strong enrichment program in arts education. The arts program is a crucial factor in attracting an ever increasing number of applicants to our middle school.  Aproximately 20% of our students applying to specialized arts schools are accepted. It is our goal to increase partnership with visiting artists and cultural institutes in order to broaden their appreciation of the arts, to be able to express themselves creatively and so that our students can learn from the professionals and gain insight into the art profession as a possible career choice.

Q39_4: EXTENSIVE Fundraising to pay for Community Based Organizational Arts Partnerships
Q46_1: We believe that the arts play a vital role in helping to improve our students' academic performance and achievement by providing a variety of venues for them to develop the necessary language and social skills, self-confidence and poise needed to succeed. Students enjoy coming to school so our attendance rate is among the highest in the city. Our comprehensive program includes our in-house music and art programs and an arts residency program for every child from Pre-K through Grade 5. Many of our arts partnership programs offer scholarships to students who show a particular interest or talent in a discipline and also provide opportunities for them to continue after they leave PS 130. In addition to our day school offerings, we also have many free school-sponsored after school programs: a competitive fife and drum corps, a school chorus, a ballroom dance club, and a Chinese lion dance club. Parents actively support our many programs by volunteering and raising funds to pay for partnerships with Community Based Organizations, musical instruments, and equipment.
Q47_1: All of the arts programs listed in the survey have been made possible by the generosity of our parents and our Parents Association. We are a Title I school with a majority of children coming from homes that speak a language other than English. Because the parents see the value and the positive impact that the arts have had on their children's academic performance, they have been tremendously supportive in helping us to raise the funds necessary to continue the programs. As a result, our school has consistently ranked as one of the higher performing schools in New York City.

Q46_1:
The Visual Arts program at MS 131 serves a diverse student body in a 3-year, sequential art curriculum
designed to prepare students for entrance into specialized arts high schools throughout New York City.
Students begin their visual art instruction in the 6th grade, focusing on developing technical and
conceptual skills that later serve as their foundation across various mediums and projects. In the 7th
grade, students build upon their arts skills, expanding and deepening their inquiry into art-making in the
context of art history and careers in the arts. By 8th grade, students continue to develop their art
portfolios which are a collection of the each student’s best artwork. Advanced students who wish to
pursue further study in visual arts in high school and beyond, participate in an intensive after school
workshop to produce high quality works for their high school audition portfolios. Our goal is to create
beautiful and meaningful artwork that each student is proud of. To that end, students share their work
with their community by participating in semi-annual art gallery shows, as well as throughout the year in
classrooms, hallways and even student shows held in some of New York City’s most prestigious art
museums. The Music Program at Sun Yat Sen Middle School 131 focuses on instrumental music. It is a comprehensive program for grades 6 though 8 intended to prepare students for continued study in high school. Previous experience in music is not required, but students must be willing to study music at an in-depth level.D
Q47_1: Dance EDUCATION: dedicated to developing dancers that are interested in developing into exceptional dance artists. The dance curriculum is designed to create strong technical dancers where skill and confidence are acquired along with a passion for ALL the performing arts. Students develop as professional dance artists, critical thinkers, problem solvers, choreographers, teachers, leaders, and individuals. Literacy and technology are used to research and create dance.

Q39_4: Collaborative art projects through CBO groundswell to create a school mural
Q46_1: Visual Arts teacher will provide courses to students at all grade levels. Curriculum is developed with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts. Current units are: Unit :0 Sketchbooks/Elements of Art and Principles of Design Unit 1A: Drawing/Graffiti/Street Art Unit 1B: Drawing Observational Unit 2A:Painting/Color Theory Unit 2B: Painting Observational Unit 3A: Collage elements of Art Unit 3B: Puppets/Shadow Unit 4A: Sewing/Sample patterns Unit 4B: Sewing Animals Unit 5A: Paper Making practice Unit 5B: Paper puppets/Sculptures Unit 6A Sculpture Intro Unit 6B Sculpture forms, newspaper, clay. As a supplement, our school has applied for and received a 5 year Extended School Day/School Violence Prevention grant that is used to fund our partnership with 'Groundswell' and 'Harmony'. 'Groundswell' brings together artists, youth, and community organizations through to use art as a tool for social change and beautify our school space,while 'Harmony' allows us to provide music instruction to our students through trained teachers that guide students from beginner group instruction to final orchestral performance.

At Mather, our arts program in the classroom consists of Decorative Finishing in the Building Arts. Decorative Finishing introduces students to the materials and methods of historic architectural surface finishes, including decorative plaster, painted decorative finishes, faux finishing, and gilding. Students receive hands-on instruction in the techniques of common historic finishes, as well as in their history, context, preservation, and present-day applications. Units include: Introduction to Paint, Color Theory and Application, Surface Preparation and Drawing/Transfer, Faux Finishes, Troweled Plaster Finishes and Gilding. Outside of the classroom, our arts program consists of after school clubs, including: a performing/improv arts club, the musical club "The Matherizers", a singing group, a visual arts club, film club, and yearbook/photo club. We also offer summer opportunities for mural painting and craftsmanship in carpentry.

At PS 150 we are proud of our long-standing commitment to the arts, and of our recent development of theater offerings. The arts play a significant role in daily instruction at PS 150: students receive stand alone instruction as well as arts instruction integrated into our in-depth science and social studies themes. Each year, all our work comes together in our annual arts festival,which includes a visual arts exhibit with work from every student in the school and an original theater piece that incorporates dance, music, theater and content study artwork. The theater piece is performed on the main stage of the Tribeca Performing Arts Center for our families.

Our Specialty classes are taught by full-time certified YCS instructors. Our classes include visual arts, dance, music, band and chorus program; students receive one–two periods a week of each specialty class. Our monthly “Specials” news, included in our newsletter, provides you with information regarding what children are learning in each class and how families can support them at home. In addition to our specialty classes, we offer enrichment opportunities which are provided by Community Based Organizations, (CBO’s). These programs provide our students with the unique opportunities to further promote excellence, self-confidence, creativity, and the development of strong-will, expanding on our students' learning in ways that bring new concepts to light or by using old concepts in new ways. Our goal is to provide all of our students with opportunities to learn more about themselves, their skills, and strengths.

We are proud of the varied arts programs that our students participate in throughout the school year. With the generous assistance of the Parents' Association and the participation of our Arts Committees (comprised of parents and teachers) we hope to be able to continue to offer these wonderful programs in the upcoming school year. PS 158 is committed to providing diverse instruction in the arts.

Q39_4: Parents participated in classroom learning with their child through an arts grant received.
Q46_1: Wagner Middle School offers classes in visual arts, theater arts, band, digital arts, jazz band, and chorus. These programs provide much needed art opportunities for students to participate in exhibits, performances, and trips to many arts-based institutions. Band members participate in band five times a week, and collaborate in concerts, borough-wide band shows and performances at Carnegie Hall. This year, the senior band visited the Coast Guard Academy in New London, CT, attended their concert and had lessons or 'clinic' with the Coast Guard band members and their conductor. A number of 6th-8th grade students have auditioned for and been accepted into Manhattan Borough-Wide and Inner City Band as well as the National Children's Chorus. Non-band students participate in a rotating program of theater and visual arts, following the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and an alignment to the Common Core Standards. Activities in the theatre and visual arts program include but are not limited to: art studio, drama club, museum club, dance performances, digital photography, stop-motion animation (Saturday program for parents and students working/learning together), winter and spring concerts. Some of our students have been accepted into summer art 'intensives' at Frank Sinatra School for the Arts. Wagner proudly puts on a musical for our entire school as well as evening performances for the Wagner community. At Wagner, every student should be equally exposed to the arts as they are to other core subjects to create a well-rounded student.

Q39_4: Participating in District Wide Art Show

Q46_1: Our current arts program provides exposure to and participation in the multiple arts disciplines to strengthen a child’s academic, social, emotional growth and development as an individual. Whenever possible, the arts curriculum is integrated with the academic curriculum.  The technology available to teachers in the building is often integrated into arts instruction.  Computers, ipads, and various software is integrated into music and art instruction.

The goals of the art program is for children to use original ideas while developing art skills and techniques. They will be familiar with a variety of visual art forms and can describe them using the vocabulary of visual arts media . We expect that they will develop an awareness of the expression and communicative power of visual art and express thoughts through a combined use of the visual and performing arts. They will showcase their learning by using various media (drawing, painting, sculpture, collage) to create art work with some of the principals of design.

Students will also work within the ORFF music program in the upper grades and Music and the Brain keyboarding in the lower ones.  The goal is for students  to learn various instruments, as well as note reading to be able to both play and sing in various genres of music.

Q39_4: Assisted in designing and completing school mural.  Assisted with matting, labeling, packing and delivering student art work for Council Member Ben Kallos Art Show. With students designing and printing school programs for multiple student events & performances. Running a lunchtime Maker Space activity in the school yard..  Sponsoring student tee-shirt design contests for various school  events  by awarding prizes and producing t-shirts.
Q46_1:
We are firmly committed to the arts. For the first time this year our Middle School students have worked with our partner Cornell Tech University to pilot a Roosevelt Island virtual oral history mapping project "What is Home? An Oral History Project"   This year we once have We have full-time certified music and studio art teachers, who provide arts instruction across all grades. MS Arts offer a cycle of clubs including film history, 3D Art, Media/Technology, etc., and a full 3 years of music instruction. We use residency programs "Building Green" with the Salvadori Center for Urban Design, Clay 3D Art with Studio in a School, Theater Games, Musical Theater, African Dance & Ballroom Dance with RI Main Street Theater and Dance Alliance.  We have also provided Sing & Dance & Movement w/ Isadora Duncan  to grow our music and dance programs for our youngest students.  Additionally, we celebrated the arts this year with an evening of Family Arts Workshops and Weekend Arts Workshops for students.
It is through the generosity of our PTA we are able to fund these programs.

The Ella Baker School is rich in arts education. The curriculum is project and materials -based so that children become comfortable and familiar with various art mediums. All children receive instruction in dance, theater, visual arts. Children in K-5 have music instruction and children in 6-8 have the opportunity to continue with music instruction if interested. All classes participate in ongoing visits to a wide variety of arts and cultural institutions available in New York City. Our teachers participate in ongoing professional development opportunities throughout the year to strengthen their understanding of arts education, an integral part of interdisciplinary units developed by teachers for use their daily classes.

Arts instruction is a rich and vibrant part of students' learning at PS 234. We offer a full array of vocal music classes (K-3rd grade), as well as instrumental music starting in the fourth grade. Our most significant partnerships with arts cultural organizations in New York City are with National Dance Institute, which works with our fifth graders weekly, and Center for Arts Education, which provides music instruction to our K-3rd grade students. Classroom teachers instruct students in visual art, music and theatrical arts experiences throughout our rich social studies curriculum. Our visual arts teacher, music teachers, and dance teacher collaborate throughout the school year to create amazingly well-crafted arts learning and culminating performances for our students. PS 234 has a long and rich history of valuing the arts in children's learning. This is completely evident as you walk through our school.

At the end of the 8th grade year, all students at Salk will have engaged in a rich art experience by making art, reflecting on the process of making art and understanding the cultural and historical significance of art. We aim to fully utilize our rich cultural institutions, parent community, and teaching artists to enhance the arts experience for our students. Both our theatre and visual art teachers (as well as our extracurricular music, dance, and media teachers) aim to expose students to as many various art media as possible and connect their curricula across subjects by planning with core classroom teachers to provide a rich learning environment that allows students to apply concepts across classes while drawing upon real-life experiences.

Q44_R2: City College Graduate Program in Theater Ed
Q44_R4: City College Graduate Program in Theater Ed

Q46_1: All students at East Side Elementary School receive visual arts instruction twice a week. They also have music and dance once a week.

Q44_R1_C1: Anne Frank Center for Mutual Respect
Q46_1:
Grades K-3 artists learn art techniques and art history through a workshop model. Grades 4-8 artists are learning how to maneuver through a Choice-based art class. Our students take trips to several museums - MoMA, Whitney, Cloisters, the Rubin and the Met. 

We have a rich music program with 2 full time music teachers. All students have music each week. K-2 learn general music using Solfege, and Orff instruments. In grade 3 students learn the recorder. In fourth grade, all students learn an instrument for band. In grades 5-8 students have a choice of band or chorus. 8th graders also have a general music history class in which they also learn to compose using Garage Band and Finale. 

We partner with several organizations for drama. Our K students work with a teaching artist from the Creative Arts Team for interactive story telling. Students in grades 6-7 partner with Lincoln Center Education for theater workshops. Fourth work with Kids Empowerment Academy on public speaking. Fifth graders work with the Anne Frank Center for Mutual Respect and the Eighth graders work with Classic Stage Company.
MECA's Arts program is centered around multimedia design and includes visual arts, media arts and production.

The River School has a full-time music teacher that serves students across all grade levels. Through a grant from Music and the Brain, students learn how to play the keyboard while also learning to sing and play instruments such as the drums, xylophone and recorder. 

Additionally, The River School partners with Studio In A School to provide visual arts education to all students. Each grade level residency helps students to build foundational art skills and develop 21st century skills of communication and problem solving.

UA Maker offers courses in Theater and Visual Art, where students engage in both art-making and critical thinking. The first unit of Visual Art, “Art Begins With a Mystery", provides students with experiences uncovering and expressing ideas through visual imagery. In Theater, students begin by learning about storytelling, uncovering the deep connections between design thinking and artistic creativity. Visual Art offers students the opportunity to develop strategies and techniques for making 2D visual art; including proficiency with line and weight, shape and form, value, color, and perspective. In the later half of the class, students will practice and refine these skills in independent works and explore the social and historical context of various artistic expressions. Theater encourages students to extend their expressive and interpersonal skills, building their work in other classes by developing their confidence and comfort presenting to an audience of their peers. Throughout the latter half of the class, students will explore more sophisticated areas of performance, with options ranging from clowning and comedy to the writing, performance, and analysis of Hip Hop poetry. Students will engage with art and art making both in and out of the classroom. They will be expected to produce exhibitions of their own work as well as portfolios of their growth. They will engage artists, art makers, and art spaces in public and community settings in order to explore careers in the arts.

Q32_6: Both are itinerant teachers who attend PD at their other schools
Q46_1: At I.S.289, the arts program is both embedded in the project based curriculum, and as part of a stand alone comprehensive visual arts and music program. Within the project based curriculum of each core class, students use the digital and visual arts to engage in the culture and texts of the content, as well as to demonstrate understanding of the content. Within the Visual Arts and Music curriculum, the five strands include: the various types of art and music making, developing art and music literacy, making connections to the world and to other disciplines through music and the visual arts, exploring careers in music and the arts, and learning about community and cultural resources.

We provide all grades with the experience of live performance with the support of The Wingspan Theater company.  Every grade experiencing watching and creating theater through improv, theater games, storytelling, creating tableaus, and writing plays.  Our 4th graders participate in NDI and our first graders in a New York City Ballet program.  We provide the 4th and 5th graders with musical instrument instruction from our full-time music teacher and teaching assistant.  Our third graders learn to play the recorder and perform in a concert at the end of the school year at Carnegie Hall.  A variety of performances are scheduled throughout the year for all of the grades and we incorporate visual arts into out daily curriculum.

Essex Street Academy offers 3 electives for students in the Art Department: visual art, theater and music. In the visual arts program students learn the basics in art and theory; students are asked to create a series of work that reflect growth. In the theater program students learn memorization skills, performance tactics and are asked to perform major scenes from a variety of theatrical genres. The after school music program at ESA is a performance-based curriculum that focuses on building foundational skills and nurturing a life-long relationship to music. The students learn and practice vocal and beat-making skills; students are then asked to perform and demonstrate growth by participating in talent shows and an end-of-year art expo. These courses are offered to the entire 11th grade class and end in a Performance Based Assessment Task. All three electives are offered to students in all four grades.

Presently, 10th graders in our school receive Studio Art 1 and 2 for one credit each. The courses are designed to meet the required benchmarks and performance indicators for the NYC Blueprint for the Visual Arts. Additionally, our 9th grade students receive two semesters of Digital Media & Graphic Design in the technology lab for a total of 2 elective credits. 11th-  & 12th grade students have the opportunity to take AP Studio Art and to create and submit a complete portfolio for 2-D Design or Drawing.  Students can also participate in the following extracurricular clubs and activities: art club, guitar club, and drama. We also visit a number of cultural institutions each year, and we assist our students applying to arts programs at various cultural institutions throughout NYC.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: PACE High School provides students with opportunity to experience arts instruction in visual arts, theatre arts, and dance. We also provide access to ceramics and choir. Out vision is to expose students to new experiences to during their academic day and to provide robust extra curricular programs to build their arts background. We continually work with outside organizations to supplement our in school programs.

This year we maintained our Arts teaching staff of two artists-in-residence and 2 certified teachers. Our second artist in residence was able to be here two days per week, full time, to both plan projects with content area teachers and deliver direct instruction to studnets.  As a result, we were able to increase student involvement with the Visual Arts. 

Freshman and sophomores at SDC have the opportunity to take a design seminar; in this class, students learn the elements of design, utilize design thinking, practice drafting, and utilize spatial reasoning while building scale models. Students visit key architectural spots around the city, and many see design themes integrated into their subject classes-past projects have included skyscrapers, museums, schools, and bridges. Juniors and seniors have the option to remain in design classes as well as take advanced elective visual arts classes during the spring semester. We also offered two periods of a sculpture elective with one of our art teachers.

At FHS, there is a strong collaboration with Urban Arts Partnership. Academic teachers, a DOE certified visual art teacher and Urban Arts teaching artists co-plan curricula that integrate art, poetry, photography, music, and drama- all to deepen students’ understanding and provide multiple forms of expression in the classroom. The goals for the Arts Education Program are as follows:(1) Provide all students with an inquiry-based, student-centered, and constructivist approach to arts learning and (2) provide all students with arts-integrated lessons and theme-based art studios. Our seniors participate in our annual 'Choosing to Participate', exhibit which combines intense research on a social justice issue and the creation of an art activism piece displayed at the end of the year celebration. Our partnership has provided opportunity and access for all of our students both academically and artistically.

The Urban Assembly Academy of Government and Law offers students a range of elective courses and arts-related programming throughout their high school career. All students take Studio Art during their sophomore, junior, and/or senior years.  This course introduces students to a variety of art mediums and allows for the exploration of both two-dimensional and three-dimensional art processes.  Students in grades 10-12 are also able to take 3-D Art and Design, which is a course that explores various forms of three-dimensional art and affords students the opportunity to acquire the problem-solving necessary to build a sculpture that is structurally sound. Additionally, these courses are supplemented by an extensive after school program, including an art club open to 9th grade students.

LoMA is dedicated to nurturing the artist in all students. Students take survey classes in music, dance, drama and visual art before committing to a 3 year major in one of the disciplines. The students receive in-house arts instruction and are also exposed to a wide variety of cultural institutions and community partnerships within the arts. In addition to working with full time certified arts teachers, LoMA students work with a wide variety of teaching artists in their arts and academic classes. Students at LoMA regularly attend theater, music and dance performances as well as visit museums and cultural institutions. Our students have numerous opportunities to perform, direct and choreograph, including events such as: our fall drama, spring musical, talent show and majors' performance. Students at LoMA have a wide range of arts experiences incorporated into their daily academic classes. LoMA students also have a wide range of extracurricular arts opportunities from which to choose.

Q44_R5: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: NYC Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies works to provide a comprehensive arts experience connected to all subject areas and in arts-specific courses of study. In sixth grade, students participate in a year-long introduction to visual arts with a focus on drawing, stop-motion animation and visual communication through art. In seventh grade, students take drama; engaging in playwriting, learn acting techniques and have opportunities to perform. The seventh grade course is designed in collaboration with a partnership at The New Victory Theater. In eighth grade, students study visual arts through a survey of fine arts-a partnership with The Whitney Museum helps support this work. Students in eighth grade visit the museum multiple times throughout the year and a museum educator also works with students at the school site. The students also showcase art work at a culminating show in the museum. Arts is integral to the student experience at NYC Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies. We have prioritized arts education - providing nearly double the required amount to our students. We believe that when students are allowed to engage in art making and learning about art, they grow as learners and human beings.

The James Baldwin School infuses the arts into classes of many disciplines, like his"Art and Soul." Although we have not had a school play this year, in all previous years our theater class has produced a school play, often written by the students themselves. In addition, we offer after school opportunities in the arts ranging from visual arts to spoken word. Many of our students participate in arts programs partnered with other organizations across the city.

Our school arts program this year included a focus on Visual Arts,  Photojournalism and Film classes. Our goal this year has been to provide students with introductory knowledge and appreciation for the visual arts and the different aspects of photography and film. Our long-term objective is that these classes will provide them a foundation upon which to build a career interest in the Arts.

Peck Slip students receive theater and instrumental music instruction with resident artists from cultural organizations, and general music, dance and visual arts instruction from school-based certified arts teachers. The arts are also incorporated into the classroom curriculum, used both as a tool for learning social studies and science content and for demonstrating what students have learned. For example, kindergarten students produce up to four drafts of realistic drawings of moths and butterflies to sharpen their ability to observe these insects and note their distinct features, and third graders build a model of a Lenape village to demonstrate their knowledge of this culture. This year, fourth and fifth grade students are collaborating in a cross-curricular original cabaret supporting their instruction about immigration in social studies. They are integrating their skills in art, acting, voice and dancing in a culminating performance.

PS 347 has been very fortunate to receive a grant this year that has enabled us to share an licensed art teacher and a licensed dance teacher with the upper school in our building. Through another grant for ELLS and SWDs in the arts, CMA provided 8 weeks of art instruction to our K-5 students; our teachers are also very active in exposing these students to theater on a monthly basis. The school takes advantage of events by New Victory Theater. The venue provides the opportunity for our students to attend monthly shows at prices that our families can afford.
Q47_1: Many of our students are children of deaf parents, Deaf, or Deaf and Hard of Hearing. Art and dance are another form of communication that allows every child to express themselves with no barriers.

Q46_1: Gramercy Arts High School is a screened audition arts school committed to creating an environment where innovation and adaptability foster a persistent and reflective immersion into the relevant world of art and academics. Gramercy Arts High School achieves college readiness for all students by creating a collaborative learning environment that challenges students with rigorous curriculum that holds them accountable for their learning. We are committed to creating a trusting environment of academic excellence where faculty and students are adaptable, professional, and engage in daily reflection. Through collaborative efforts of both the arts and academics, we strive to establish an environment rooted in professionalism, trust and enthusiasm to develop persistent and empowered global citizens.

At the iSchool, experiences in the arts are offered as both Modules and Core Experiences.  All students are eligible to participate in these courses, which include:

•	Introduction to Drawing
•	Advanced Drawing
•	Introduction to Painting
•	Advanced Painting
•	Sculpture
•	Printmaking
•	Painting NYC
•	Guitar 1 and 2
•	Piano 1 and 2
•	Beatmaking
•	Bash the Trash
•	Some modules have included:

o   Children's Bookmaking: In this module, iSchool students travel to an elementary school and meet with first graders to survey their interests and likes.  After consulting with professional children's book authors and gaining a thorough understanding of the various types of children's books that exist, iSchool students spend the quarter writing, illustrating, and binding a children's book for the child who they met.  At the end of the quarter, the iSchool students bring their finished books back to the elementary school to read their stories.

o    Inside the Music: In this module, students become classical music composers whose pieces are performed by professional musicians at a final concert.  Through this course, students learn music theory and techniques of composition in order to produce and direct the performance of complex pieces.

Students participate in a studio arts based curriculum focused on learning through experimentation with materials and techniques. The curriculum is strongly focused on an inter-disciplinary learning between NYS Common Core ELA Standards as well as NYS Visual Arts Standards (NYC DOE's Blueprint for the arts criteria). The Studio Art curriculum helps to provide a solid arts foundation, through exposure to a variety of artists, and mediums. We promote the integration of the arts into all our subject area curriculums. Our students are exposed to various arts genres during classroom activities, as well as the incorporation of trips to various cultural organizations throughout the school year. We are a school focused on college readiness and our arts program reflects our expectations as well as our goals for our students' futures.
We have a full-time visual arts teacher who is implementing a visual arts curriculum with our 10th grade students.

Emma Lazarus High School is a transfer school that serves over-aged, and under-credited ENL students. Our student body is comprised of new arrivals to the United States with limited English skills-we offer stand-alone ENL courses through an English immersion model. Our students have limited time to learn English and pass Regents; however, we ensure that students meet the city and state requirements for the arts and when possible expose them to additional cultural opportunities throughout New York City. Students have visited museums, attended Broadway shows and visited other cultural institutions. We have solicited the professional services of arts organizations such as the Lincoln Center’s LEAD program, the New York City Horticultural Society, Downtown Children’s Museum, and TADA!. We believe that students learn best through experiential, hands-on and project-based instruction. Moreover, we believe that arts integration is an effective method for students to learn and acquire a new language.  Lastly, we believe in ‘arts for art’s sake’ and therefore, we provide our students with meaningful exposure to the arts across the entire school.

As a growing school, we maintain a commitment to the arts. Our students are currently exposed to a range of arts experiences, including the launch of our full-time music program. As we grow, we will preserve an arts program that supports both the breadth and depth of immersion and emerging expertise. We maintain our commitment to community partners and arts organizations who can help make this work even more robust.

The High School for Environmental Studies provides students with opportunities to engage in the arts for all four years. As a theme-based school which focuses on developing environmental stewards, we are proud to be able to provide our students with a Common Core aligned, well-rounded education that places a strong value on an arts education. In addition to offering our students beginning and advanced courses in chorus, orchestra, band and theater, we also offer ceramics, painting and drawing, as well as dance courses through a partnership with Alvin Ailey. HSES is a culturally rich community that enjoys a great deal of student involvement in our arts program. Our teachers are dedicated to providing our students with meaningful experiences and to exposing them to a wide array of art forms, including environmentally themed arts projects.

The Institute for Collaborative Education (I.C.E.) Arts Education Program is a critical component of our school's curricular vertical planning along the 6th - 12th grade arc. Our students are offered multiple arts opportunities at each grade level: including music, theater, dance, visual, graphic, and mixed media arts in their school day program and through after school activity offerings. All students in each grade participate in at least one arts course each semester. Our focus is on the whole student, and we believe that cognitive, social, and emotional development are each positively impacted by continuing exposure to new experiences in which students are enabled to construct their own knowledge and exercise their higher order thinking skills. The I.C.E. Arts Program is an excellent arena in which this work is undertaken, and I.C.E. students and families have been historically very invested in this aspect of the curriculum.

The mission of PPAS is to provide professional performing arts instruction to all students in grades 6 – 12 in a variety of disciplines, while also providing them with a rigorous academic curriculum that will lead to exceptional higher education choices that include, but are not limited to, top performing arts colleges and conservatories. The performing arts curriculum offers students in grades six through twelve a unique opportunity to study the arts in a professional environment. Professional artists offer training to meet the performing arts learning needs of students who are passionate about the arts and committed to the study of the arts. High School students major in professional studios in dance, drama, musical theater, and vocal music. Middle School students participate in a variety of performing arts classes to increase their exposure to performance elements. These classes include acting, dance, singing and music appreciation. PPAS has a unique programming structure where the school partners with professional arts organizations that provide top quality instruction in professional settings. Student take classes in site-specific high caliber studios, which include off-Broadway theaters, concert halls, and ballet and tap dance studios. Students present concerts, plays, and other productions throughout the school year, both in-house and in premier performance spaces across New York City.

All students take a full year (2 credits) of visual arts in 10th grade, where they explore different mediums, including collage, drawing, painting and murals. They study contemporary artists and explore the issues of identity and self. Students have the option to apply for Honors Art in 11th and 12th grade, where they develop a portfolio for post-secondary arts programs. In partnership with Manhattan Class Company Theater, students explore drama integrated into all English classes, from grades 9-11, with reinterpretations of Shakespeare, spoken word poetry, dramatic interpretation of American novels, and rhetoric. There is also an after school drama program, which puts on our annual school play. There is an after school rock music club and an after school dance club.

Our goals for the Arts Program remain the same as past years: all lab students will be exposed to a variety of art experiences that will allow them to interact with art in a meaningful way and to cultivate a life-long relationship and appreciation for art. To nurture independent, creative thinking, the development of content knowledge, and a deeper appreciation of the visual arts, the art department uses a variety of instructional methods; including the development of a studio-like environment, careful observation and writing about specific works of art, making inferences and interpretations, material explorations, class discussions, creative problem solving, the keeping of journals and sketchbooks, and the exposure of students to a wide variety of visual arts resources available in New York City. With regards to music, the curriculum is designed so that students can derive a meaningful learning experience regardless of prior knowledge and experience in music.

chool of the Future has expanded over the last few years to include a full time Visual Arts teacher, two F-status Drama teachers, and a part time music teacher. Students in both the middle and high school receive arts instruction one to two times per week throughout the school year. Our 9th-12th graders choose their electives while the middle school students have assigned arts classes.

The Museum School offers a 4-year studio art sequence aligned with the New York State Blueprint for the Arts standards. All art courses are interdisciplinary and taught by a fully licensed and certified art teacher. Unique to our school are the "museum module" courses, which allow students to take specialized museum-based courses every week that correlate with in-school Regents-based courses. Our goal is to provide students with as rich an arts education as possible while reinforcing the connections between the arts and the core disciplines. Students frequently visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Japan Society, the Rubin Museum, the Museum of Natural History, the Paley Center for Media, and more! The arts are a highly valued part of the Museum School experience.

A college preparatory/liberal arts program, Eleanor Roosevelt High School provides diverse opportunities for students of all levels, interests, and prior experiences in the arts. In the freshman and sophomore years, students elect from introductory courses in media and technology, music, and visual arts. In the junior and senior years, students have the option to study in depth artistic disciplines in small seminars and advanced placement courses. 2017-2018 offerings included Animation, Audio Science, AP Art History, Ceramics, Concert/Symphonic Band, Digital Photography, Film Lab, Guitar, and Visual Art. Extra-curricular opportunities included Chamber Music Society, Choir, Drama Club, Film Club, Jazz Ensemble, Modern Band and Percussion Club.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
