Q46_1: Millennium High School aims to provide every single student with the skills needed to become visually literate members of society. By providing a rigorous 9th and 10th grade curriculum for every single student we feel confident that we are laying the ground work for continued art research and and learning. Our upper house electives allow students to continue to investigate specific areas of art. Electives offered during the 2017-2018 school year included full-year courses in Mixed Media, Graphic Design, and Photography.

Visual Art and Music are offered to all students in compliance with NYS graduation requirements. The Visual Art program includes studio art and art history, with an introduction to artists and artwork from a global perspective. Students experience creativity as a means of expression through an understanding of the elements and principles of art with culminating exhibitions. The Music program offers students an education in basic music theory, including music/rhythmic notation, melody and harmony. Students apply what they have learned to the piano keyboard and have a chance to perform as a group in percussion ensembles. In addition, HPHS offers classes in theater, dance and medical illustration. Our staff is committed to offering students a variety of experiences in the arts, and off-site visits to museums, events and shows are ongoing throughout the year. Student and staff theater productions and events are developed and produced in-house during the school year. Also available to students are courses in the arts at the college level for college credit through the College Now and College Board programs.

Leadership and Public Service High School offers one of the top Chorus and Visual Arts programs of any non-specialized high school in New York City. Our strongest partnerships are with the Metropolitan Opera Guild, DIFFA, Trinity Church Wall Street and The New Museum. We are also continuing to expand our outside partnerships and affiliations. The Leadership Chorus was chosen to perform at the New York Daily News, the New York State Capitol (on 2 occasions), Hunter College, Gotham Hall, Times Square, and we were selected by NBC/iTheatrics for the NBC SMASH Make-a-Musical program. Our students have opportunities to work in arts based internships at The MoMA and the New Museum as well as participate in competitive scholarships with the Broadway League, Stella Adler, and The Roundabout Theater Company, to name a few. Our arts faculty is highly trained from top conservatories and universities in the US. Each member of our faculty has many years teaching and professional performance experience. This year we have expanded both our Studio Art and Music department to offer new opportunities for our students including: a piano lab, new highly qualified staff member.

Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language opened in 2010 welcoming all categories of English Language learners. At Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language we believe that students excel when given a strong academic education and meaningful support to develop the student entirely which includes art's education. Every student at Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language has an opportunity to take either a music class and a photography elective in High School. Students that excel in music are able to continue developing their music skills throughout their HS education.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our Studio Arts teacher works with our students on a variety of highly engaging projects. He has been able to create student-centered projects that allow the students to express personal thoughts and feelings about important social topics, as well as express their own individuality and creative visions. In addition, in the past two years we created several new art history classes, centering around the history of street art, the history of music, and the use of imagery in politics and media. To supplement our Studio Arts program, we engaged with LEAP outside arts organization, to bring in a professional artist two days a week into our school. As such, all art students participated in a series of painting and printmaking projects that introduced to them the broader professional art world. We are also partnering with Dance Theater Etc. this year to provide an after school dance club. Additionally, our subject teams are committed to exposing students to art in a variety of avenues, and we bring our students to many plays, movies, and museums throughout the year taking advantage of our location in midtown Manhattan. Many of our students take more than the minimum two credits in the arts and our goal is continuous exposure to arts as a vital part of a well rounded education.
We have a band and music classes.
Q47_1: We are a small high school, serving mainly students from a Black and Latino background from across the city.

Q46_1: Ballet Tech's students are enrolled in a full-time pre-professional classical ballet school. Its primary goal is to develop new generations of professional dancers. Our daily dance classes are in the tradition of classical ballet: students take pointe, modern, character, gymnastics, and repertory. Through their studies, students develop a strong understanding of the principles of classical ballet and dance, as well as developing a personal and sophisticated relationship to their artistry (or art). They leave the school armed with the necessary skills to pursue careers in the dance field, or to further their dance studies.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_R2: Stella Adler Studio of Acting - Outreach Division
Q46_1: The arts program at Vanguard High School is a comprehensive approach to visual arts. Vanguard currently has one art instructor, who teaches several sections of painting, sculpture, furniture design and digital photography. The teacher also offers a class called "Philosophy in Art" that provides strong support to the Social Studies department at our school. Additionally, the art teacher works with advanced art students,helping them prepare their portfolios for admissions into art colleges.

The Manhattan International High School is committed to providing a variety of opportunities in the arts to enrich each and every student's educational experience. We have, and will continue to integrate the arts into our curriculum with the strong belief that the arts enhance language development which is critical for our students. Students also have the opportunity to expand their involvement in the arts through elective classes and multiple after-school programs. New learners of English develop linguistic, cognitive and cultural skills for informed participation in our city's diverse and creative society.

The HS of Economics & Finance offers visual art in the 10th grade to all students.  Students can also take 8-week seminars in music, theater, and visual arts through our WISE Institute. In the 12th grade, students take either advanced art or theater in order to fulfill their arts requirement. Our students make dozens of trips to arts-related venues. This year in theater we have seen Phantom of the Opera, Pride and Prejudice, and Wicked. Our Open Door Scholars have seen Mean Girls, Bronx Tale, Waitress, Once on This Island, School of Rock, and Lobby Hero among others.  Classes have visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, the African Burial Ground, Museum of Tolerance, and The Tamiment Library & Robert Wagner Archives. We had had two artist-in-residency programs and in 2018-2019, we will continue our TDF Open Door Scholars program and most of our arts programs.

Unity Center for Urban Technologies promotes student engagement in the Arts through a rigorous visual and media arts curriculum using Photoshop and other applications.  We are teamed up with Young Audiences of New York to provide a teaching artist to enhance our music curriculum.  Our Art program is growing and we are facilitating student growth and understanding of the arts through engaging and interactive classrooms.

UA Gateway is dedicated to providing a focused and relevant arts program tailored to our students’ individual curiosity. Students are surveyed at the beginning of each year to determine interests, informing our programming and partnership decision making. In addition to required art courses, UAG students are exposed to art through our digital arts track and enrichment programs. As a school for technology with a focus on digital design and animation, we are particularly committed to the use of technology in the arts as well as the development of art within technology fields. This year we will continue the collaboration between our technology department and the art department to provide a grounding in digital design and art/illustration to support the student's choice of Technology Pathway at the end of 9th grade (Digital Design and Animation, IT & Systems or Software Engineering). We also have weekly drawing, animation, music/band and photography clubs. Additionally, our students participate in several opportunities to attend Broadway shows and theatre performances.

Q39_4: Meals for student performers during production
Q44_R2: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance
Q44_R4: Paul Taylor's American Modern Dance Theatre
Q45_10: NYC Arts Comprehensive Exam , NYSSMA, and NOCTI Performance Arts Exam
Q46_1: Talent Unlimited High School seeks to educate, empower, and prepare students for work in the professional arts world and beyond. As a Career and Technical Education (CTE) portfolio school, students engage in sequential and scaffolded series of knowledge, skills, and internship experiences. Work-based learning tools are designed to train students in the discipline of the artist while equipping them with a vast array of analytical and creative skills. Talent Unlimited High School believes the goal of training students in the arts transcends the art form itself: we endeavor to prepare our students for the rigors of any professional work environment through disciplined performing arts training coupled with an uncompromising academic education. Our students work closely with various arts organizations and industry professionals, including the American Folk Art Museum, Ballet Hispanico, Circle in the Square, Classic Stage Company, Exploring the Arts, Martha Graham Dance Center, Metropolitan Opera, NYPOPS, Opus Dance Theatre and Community Service, Park Avenue Armory, Pentacle, Paul Taylor Dance center, Theater Development Fund (TDF), and Western Wind Vocal Ensemble. We are also beginning to expand offerings to ensure students are educated as whole artist with depth of understanding in their own art form coupled with breadth in related disciplines. In 2017-2018 we debuted courses opened to students in all studios: AP Music Theory and Theatrical Design. We expanded our partnership with Opus Dance to music and theater students.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Murry Bergtraum High School's arts program is designed to provide a foundation in the understanding of art and satisfies the ART GRADUATION REQUIREMENT. Emphasis is placed on understanding the Elements of Art and Principles of Design as a basis for composition. Students will explore a variety of artists, art processes and materials such as drawing, painting, printmaking, two & three-dimensional design, and digital art. Student artwork will reflect aesthetics & cultural and historical contexts.

The PS 527 visual arts program focuses on experimenting and creating artwork in a wide range of media including painting, drawing, sculpture and printmaking, which aligns with NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exposed to a variety of materials, techniques, artists and cultures. We use sketchbooks for planning, work with peers to give and receive feedback, and share work during frequent class gallery walks. While we value the experience of creating artwork the most, we also celebrate the learning and final product during our elaborate Spring Art Show. The music program at PS 527 provides engaging experiences that are appropriately aligned with NYC Blueprints for the Arts to teach the fundamentals of music. In weekly music classes, children are creating, singing, and/or performing on instruments. Classes also function as choral ensembles that rehearse for and perform multiple concerts annually. Many third-fifth grade students elect to be in the band program, which consists of keyboards, guitars, woodwind, brass and percussion and performs a repertoire that spans from Latin jazz to contemporary pop. Students in grades 2-5 receive music technology training in which they learn to compose and record music using digital audio workstations and notation software. In addition to music and visual arts, all students perform in end-of-year theatrical performances, and Grades 1 and 4 learn dance from NYC Ballet and 92nd St 'Y'. Many arts-based field trips occur throughout the school year for all grades.

As a Title 1 business focus school, we strive to ensure that our students receive quality arts instruction and authentic arts experiences that can fully develop the whole student and prepare him/her for success in college and beyond. We see these arts-based skills as transferable and necessary for our students to compete in today's world. We believe that the arts are an excellent platform for our students to explore and gain an understanding of the world around them and a means for them to become active participants in it.They explore personal, global, political, and social perspectives. Students have used the arts as a lens to examine gender issues, social justice, violence against women, climate change, GMO’s, water and food security, immigration,identity and personal expression. Students train as lighting designers, sound designers, and stage managers for school productions and as a paid internship for our theater rentals. We've expanded our arts programming to include Keyboard and Chorus. We have multiple performances throughout the year to showcase the diverse talents of our students; dance concerts, original theater productions, Black History Month performances, talent shows. Our students have performed on Broadway annually as part of Roundabout Theatre Company's Student Theater Arts Festival. Our dance program continues to thrive. We plan to offer Graphic Design and Theater as part of our curriculum in the coming school year. We see the arts as a catalyst for student engagement and an opportunity for deep learning.
Q47_1: We are a business focus school, so our students take business classes as their elective credits. We expanded our AP courses this year. These courses can cause difficulty in scheduling. We have many students who are Level 1's and Level 2's who need more support and so we had to include support classes in our programming. Our Special Ed and ELL population have also risen.

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R4: Young People's Chorus of New York City

Q46_1: U.S.A. continues to be committed to providing a rich-arts experience for all students. With a full-time music teacher and the investment of an electric piano keyboard lab, 10th-grade students are immersed in a comprehensive arts curriculum based on units and lessons designed around NYC Blueprint for the Arts/Music and Common Core Standards. Music Making, Music Literacy, Music History, Cultural Connections and Life-Long Careers in the Arts were the major themes of study this year. Students had the opportunity and responsibility to become educated readers, writers, performers and appropriate audience members, able to give and receive constructive feedback to each other. The highlights/performances held this year included: A Winter Multi-Cultural Holiday Assembly (December), A "Respect for All" Arts Assembly (February), a Celebrate Women's History Concert / Assembly (March) and culminating Piano Recital (June). All performing arts disciplines were supported and encouraged by U.S.A's Arts Partners and Performing Arts Club. In addition, students attended two Vineyard Theatre plays (Fall and Spring Terms) and participated in Spring Theater Intensives after school program; Battery Dance 42nd Spring Opening at Pace University, as well as an opportunity to participate in a 25 hour Dance and Choreography program known as DANCING TO CONNECT for one week in June. The arts nourish and enrich the lives of students at Union Square Academy For Health Sciences.

We are a small school with a mission of teaching every student a musical instrument. To that end, we organize a sequence for each student to take, selecting guitar, piano or band in their first two years, with frequent opportunities for concerts and performances. Additionally, students may elect to attend Glee Club, Beats, Studio Arts, Filmmaking, Theater Dance and Dance Choreography, as well as other embedded arts options during our week-long Intensive. The arts are a rich and vital part of Harvest's liberal arts education program, creating compelling experiences for inquiry into topics of "moral or aesthetic significance."

Our visual arts program offers students comprehensive art experiences with detailed explorations in the classics such as painting, drawing, collage, sculpture, graphic design, and crafts. In addition to gaining confidence and proficiency working with a variety of mediums, students will learn about the history, analysis, and interpretation of art. Our goal is to have students learn from hands-on projects, as well as taking trips to various cultural institutions around the New York City area.

Students also have access to a full music studio where they can write and record music while working with professionals in the music industry who come in as guest teachers.

We will offer a 2 year visual arts program. All students are required to complete one year of required art and will be able to take a second year of elective classes. Teachers can opt to work with partner organizations, Paley Center for Media, Classic Stage Company, American Globe Theater and Tribeca Films additionally for next year, After school program are provided to enhance the students classroom experience in visual arts, theater arts, dance and music.

AFSE offers an extensive Music program where students learn a variety of musical instruments including guitar, piano, and drums. Music classes at AFSE offer fundamental music theory, learning/playing instruments, and composing music. Students participate in extracurricular sessions, practicing various instruments for talent shows and recitals. AFSE also offers a Tech and Design computer technology course where students design and print using the 3D printer. Students have an opportunity to focus on visual arts using technology.

Urban Academy's Arts program spans the visual arts (painting, drawing, sculpture, digital/black and white photography, and film) to creative writing (plays, playwriting, poetry, and fiction) to performance (acting, spoken word, singing and dancing). Most of our arts classes are taught by full time staff: some are taught by professional artists, a few by students. We take the arts very seriously, and two of our graduation requirements are arts based: Creative Arts ,in which students must develop a portfolio of work over time (which is presented to the school), and Art Criticism, in which students must choose a work of art to research (including interviewing professionals in the field) and present to a classroom of students.

Satellite Academy is utilizing a part-time F-Status art teacher (who was awarded to us through the F-Status Arts Teacher Pilot). Students in visual arts classes explore many different mediums of art including- 
Painted Mandalas on Silk
Painted Silk Scarves
Paper Marbling
Acrylic painting on canvas based on a painting chosen by the student
Papermache puppets
Linoleum cut printing
Painted paper masks
Painting on canvas tote bags
A student group also participated in putting on a musical show. They worked with a staff member after school to prepare for this large-scale show. In the show, students sang and played instruments. Students held two performances- one for the student body during the day and one for families during an evening performance.
Finally a group of student participated in a art/ social commentary project- a component of which involved photography as the students took picture in Harlem. These students were flown to California to display their art work and will have another art exhibition in NYC at the end of May.
Q47_1:
Satellite Academy is a transfer high school serving over-aged and under-credited students. Our school services students with many life difficulties. Virtually all of our students are socioeconomically below the poverty line. 
We focus many of our resources to supporting our students both academically and emotionally. 
Funding is always a challenge. 
We have a F-Status art teacher, who is also training in art therapy, teaching visual arts and have seen success with this program. We wish we could expand it. 
We also have a staff member who worked with students outside of the regular school day to provide music and performance opportunities. This was also a great success.

Q46_1: Our Arts Program at Manhattan Comprehensive has grown tremendously this academic year. In our regular academic program, we offer visual arts, and also an Art club on Saturdays. Every year we also invite two dance organizations to work with our students for two cultural performances (Chinese fan and lion dance, Samba dancing, and Merengue). This year we worked with two additional arts organizations to integrate visual and digital media into our classes. We also worked with another organization to introduce theater to our students.

RRGHST offers Studio Art 1, an introductory course to visual arts focusing on various mediums in the art world to develop imagination, self-expression, and using art as a form of communication. Aligned with the Common Core Standards and the NYC Blue Print for the Arts, this course focuses on team building skills, critical thinking, complex problem solving, writing, self-confidence, literacy, decision-making, and school achievement. This course supports intellectual and educational development along with personal and social development-students will have the opportunity to participate in school-wide art exhibitions. An advanced Studio Art 2 class was added to our course offerings.  When combined with Art History in the junior year, students are being encouraged to graduate with the six-credit art certification distinction.  Our Art History elective includes a minimum of one monthly trip to local museums.  The six-credit sequence is an elective.
Q47_1: Our art program is a critical success in our school due to the effort and enthusiasm of the current art department staff.  Student work is showcased throughout the walls and reflects the pride and effort our community has for our children.

Q46_1: We currently offer visual arts classes. Students are also encouraged to attend arts programming after school hosted by our partner community -based organization, the Hendrick Martin Institute. In addition, we partner with TDF and are often provided opportunities to attend the Public Theater.

We provide a four year program in art that will explore both fine art techniques along with art history and the application of these skills in various art related industries. Our students all learn photography, darkroom techniques, digital photography and study the business of the arts. Students create portfolios over their four year experience including artists' statements and related essays. We aim to provide as varied a program as possible in terms of the many subjects in the arts; including design, illustration, gallery and curatorial techniques. Our close connection with the business, industry and post-secondary education communities ensures that the standards, knowledge and expectations are continually updated and reassessed. This connection also allows for students to have access to unique internship opportunities, special enrichment and on-the-job training opportunities.

Humanities Prep offers a full schedule of visual arts opportunities as well as music. We offer a theater program in partnership with the theater Development Fund and Girl Be Heard. Furthermore, arts are integrated into instruction in as much as possible.

Q39_4: Arranged an arts fair at the school called Fan Faire.
Q45_10: Industry professional assessments of students work.
Q46_1: The High School of Art and Design has been a commercial art high school since 1936.All the arts based curricula are developed with our industry partners and post-secondary educational partners. We prepare students for college and careers in the arts. Our students receive two periods of art instruction daily for all 4 years that they attend our school. Our programs are NYS approved CTE programs. Included are architectural design, cartooning, animation, graphic design, illustration, digital photography, film and video, and fashion design. Students learn the Adobe and AutoCAD software programs and become certified in both programs. Our facilities mirror the state of the art equipment used in industry and students participate in internships available through industry partners and various arts organizations. They compete in art competitions and display their artwork both in school and in outside venues. Graduating students are accepted into major colleges and universities throughout the country. All our majors have their own gallery shows in the Kenny Gallery throughout the year. We also invite industry professionals to address our students and share their expertise with our students during Career Day and in their studios. Our culminating Spring Arts Festival thoroughly highlights student achievement in the arts and is well-attended by the public and students' families. In addition, our fashion students present a fashion show and the film students showcase their work in their Film Festival
Q47_1: The High School of Art and Design is a Career and Technical High school that serves a diverse group of students who come from all the boroughs in NYC. As such, we provide opportunities for the students to participate in related art fairs and gatherings that showcase the career they might be interested in, for example the  cartooning and animation students attend COMICON and MOCCA FEST; the Photo students participate in Photoville; the Illustration and graphic design students attend the Frieze Art fair on a yearly basis. Technology changes so fast and we need professional development for the teachers who teach the digital software programs to stay abreast of what is taking place in industry.Our programming allows all our students two periods of art on a daily basis from freshmen through senior year. In addition, we offer art electives to the seniors.

Q46_1: Over their three years in middle school at LMC our goal is to provide students with a basic orientation of multiple art forms and establish deeper facility and competence in a single art form of their choosing. As 6th graders, our students participate in an arts wheel through which they take 8 weeks of instruction in each of the following art forms: dance, music, digital and visual arts. At the conclusion of their 6th grade year, students participate in a series of auditions and select one of these art forms in which they will specialize over the next two years. Through their three years of middle school our students have multiple opportunities to showcase their artwork: 6th graders demonstrate their work four times throughout the year during morning art exhibitions that are open to families,our 7th and 8th graders share their work twice a year in evening art showcase and performance exhibitions. In all three years of our arts program students perform multiple times for peers, the school community and the public. Performance is a skill and experience that we believe to be a key component of arts instruction in our school.

City Knoll Middle School offers a three year art curriculum for all students. Students learn how to use the elements of art and principles of design throughout their three years through a variety of mediums. Many units of study are interdisciplinary and embed the arts into regular content area classes. In addition, City Knoll has partnered with the Museum of Modern Art to help enhance our art program.

Q44_R3: Circle in the Square Theatre School100
Q46_1: Our objective is to foster an environment where maximum artistic creativity can take place through school instruction by certified arts teachers. Whenever possible, the arts are utilized to reinforce the academic curriculum. Cultural institutions are utilized to enrich and expand musical and visual literacy. Students experience the arts using a variety of materials and techniques. Family participation during trips, attendance at school performances and exhibitions is an essential part of our school culture. Active participation of the Parent Association  help us to raise funds for the arts, write grants and display art. Parents often share their talents in performances for students. Parent involvement is integral to our success- "Gallery Night" is a culminating event in June. Parents, students and staff design activities and place art displays representing every child in the PS 9 community for all to celebrate

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Young People's Chorus of New York City
Q46_1: Our School-wide Arts Instructional Focus: To help students plan and monitor their learning in a way that makes their thinking visible through the arts and directly improves attitude and disposition to impact long-term learning and performance. We engage in strengthening our K-5 curriculum and collaboration to strengthen the Blueprints Strands to culturally connect to our students lives. We also seek to broaden our students creative problem-solving minds through integrated concepts and high interest lessons aligned to strengthen their reading of informational text, writing with a point of view, and deepening their thinking by justifying their thoughts and ideas about their artistic creations. Our professional experiences of using visual art as the seed for developing ideas help to expand reading, writing, listening and speaking about visual art and practicing the studio habits of mind in a more profound way. These habits of mind are evident across content areas, in written artists' statements and connections students make between classroom and arts based learning experiences. Our students also develop leadership skills as active participants in art making, musical, theatrical, and dance performances that engage the entire school community with the goal to plant seeds of inspiration, creativity and future careers in the arts.

Public School 76, Asa Philip Randolph School for the Humanities, is located in the historic South Central Harlem section of Manhattan. Our Pre-K through 8 school serves a population of approximately 531 students from culturally diverse backgrounds. The community is home to many families from different countries like Dominican Republic, the Caribbean Islands, Ghana and other countries in Africa. The school plays a vital role for many students and the families within the community. The arts are essential in enriching the cultural lives of our students;our goal is to extend students' learning beyond the classroom through the use of all available resources within and outside the community to expose and engage our students in all forms of arts education, thus enriching their lives academically and culturally.

PS 84, Lillian Weber School for the Arts, prides itself on providing a high quality arts education for all students. Students leave our school with the ability to read music, count rhythms and play at least one instrument. Our students perform and produce artistic and interpretive programs with the finest artists. They film and edit their own multi- media productions with animation, photography and live action. With the implementation of the NYC Blueprints for the Arts, our student are exposed to a variety of art genres and create their own magic. In addition, our school families understand the value of a rich arts education that is integrated into contact learning, transferable to all disciplines and open ended enough to allow children to collaborate, create and problem solve through performance. The arts allow our students an opportunity to excel and experience success using skills that might otherwise go untapped.

The arts are essential at PS 87 and we strive to maintain a fully integrated, cross-curricular arts program. Our school provides a visual arts program, (K-3), a music program (K-5), a theater program, (2-5) as well as a variety of dance programs (K-5). Our arts programs accommodate the diverse range of learners within the classroom. Our arts specialists collaborate in order to enhance a variety of studio practices,artistic methodologies, and technical skills. These skills are intended to build sequentially from year to year, encouraging students to express their creative voice through a variety of art forms. All the arts programs culminate in a year-end celebration aided by many parent volunteers and attended as a school community.  All arts programs are integrated into our social studies curricula K-5. In addition to the school based arts programs, we have partnerships with the National Dance Institute, Ballet Hispanico of NYC, Dancing Classrooms, and Lincoln Center.
Our school views student engagement as the key to raising achievement. All students are challenged to stretch above their current comfort and ability levels.

Q44_R2: Young People's Chorus of New York City
Q46_1: Sojourner Truth School students receive weekly instruction in the visual arts in grades K-8 as a part of their instructional program, they also participate in Alvin Ailey Dance residencies to study different dance genres with resident dance artists. Students in grades 3-8 participate in the Young People's Chorus and have the opportunity to sing in citywide honors choir performances, while students in grade Pre K -2 also participate in our Harmonize program which integrate music instruction with our social studies curriculum.

PS 163 has an arts program that includes weekly classes throughout the year for grades pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, 1st, and 2nd, and for half the year for grades 3, 4,and 5, with full-time dedicated and certified art and music teachers. In addition, there is a choral group,"The Voices of 163",of mixed grades (2nd – 5th) that presents two concerts during the year for the school and an evening performance for the parents. There are recorder lessons for all third grade students with a culminating performance. There is also a percussion group which practices and performs at school performances. This year, all students in grades 3- 4 partnered with Lincoln Center Film Society Kids. There is a full year of dance for the 4th and 5th grades through the National Dance Institute-the 3rd grade takes dance with several New York cultural organizations offering Chinese and African dance for ten weeks followed by a performance for the school. Kindergarten students prepare and perform in their classroom for individual programs for students and parents. PS 163 also hosts the district wide (District 3) art festival every year at the end of May.
Q47_1: There is no classroom designated to be used as an art room starting this school year. Students are taught in their regular classrooms and the art teacher visits each classroom with a cart. In the past, art classroom was part of a trailer extension of the school building but it was closed due to state regulations.

Q44_R1_C1: Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York
Q46_1:
In Pre-K - 4th grades, students receive 50 minutes per week of visual art, music (guitars and singing), and technology with teachers licensed in each discipline. Art curriculum aligns with Social Studies. Technology incorporates coding; music incorporates guitars; art incorporates ceramics. Additionally, students in grades 3-5 receive biweekly music instruction with the NY Philharmonic.

In 5th-8th grades, students receive 90 minutes per week of visual arts and music with teachers licensed in each discipline. Arts curriculum is a 3-year curriculum. In visual art it includes sculpture and painting. In music it includes keyboarding.

P.S.166, The Richard Rodgers School of the Arts & Technology, provides students with a robust arts program that enriches depth of knowledge and appreciation for the arts. Our comprehensive arts program incorporates Common Core Learning Standards, NY State standards, and are Blueprint aligned. We aim to develop the whole child through a rigorous and enriching program that incorporates music, dance, theater and the visual arts into instruction. Students explore, create, and experience the power of music by investigating historical, societal, and cultural themes. Through instruction, they build technical and expressive skills while learning to choreograph and perform dance styles rooted in the understanding of dance across cultures. Students participate in annual dance and musical performances with opportunities to express themselves in set design, choreography and lyrical writing presented to our community and their families. They explore a vast array of artists, art movements and materials through hands-on project-based learning experiences, culminating in a school-wide art show. Children are provided instruction that is interdisciplinary in linking the arts to literacy and social studies by making connections to local and global communities, and culture. Students discover that ideas can be interpreted in a myriad of ways. We celebrate imagination and growth through the appreciation of the arts. We believe that student learning is not confined by the walls of a classroom.

The Theater Arts Program is based on the Blue Print standards that allow students to explore various forms of the performing arts. Each grade level is taught drama activities and lessons that support the continued development of their social skills and literacy. We have an end of the year school wide performance that showcases the students' talent and ability to work cohesively.

Q44_R4: Sugar Hill Children's Museum of Art & Storytelling
Q46_1: P.S 185 Early Childhood Discovery and Design Magnet School (ECDD) is committed to providing a high quality arts education to every student,offering vocal music, piano keyboard, dance, and visual arts instruction as part of the regular curriculum. In addition, we partner with community arts organizations to expose children to a wide range of performance and visual arts. At ECDD, a strong foundation in arts literacy prepares our students for a lifetime of arts appreciation as well as providing them with rich contexts for problem solving, creativity, collaboration and communication of thoughts and ideas.

The RSMA Community believes that the arts enhances the lives of our students. We work hard to prioritize music, dance, visual arts, film and performing arts at our school, both during the school day and after school. Our students in the lower school have dance and music every week, and our upper school students participate in a comprehensive performing arts program. Through those classes our students are exposed to the arts during the school day, but we find that they want and need more, so we have also expanded our arts programs after school. We offer choir, dance, theater, visual arts and film through our after school program, and our students are so engaged in this work. We continue to look for opportunities to expand our arts program so that we can immerse our students in the arts and tap into their many talents. Every year, more and more of our students are applying and being accepted into high schools that have a focus in the arts such as LaGuardia High School,Talent Unlimited High School,Professional Performing Arts High School, and Grammercy ArtsHigh School

Our students are exposed to a variety of arts education programs over the course of their elementary education through partnerships with National Dance Institue, Wingspan Arts, Lincoln Center Education,  the New York Philharmonic and the Center for Architecture. The students also have weekly classes with highly-qualified, school-based studio art and music teachers. We are happy to take advantage of the many opportunities available to us to visit museum exhibits and attend live performances.

Q39_4: Family Holiday Craft Night, Family Sip and Paint
Q46_1: The P.S. 208 community continues to participate in various arts related events and activities within the 2017-18 schoolyear.  We are in our second year in partnership with Inside Broadway where all classes will be participating in a musical theater production celebrating ‘Greatness Over Time’ which connects with part of our school mantra “…All students can succeed, no exceptions” This culminating performance which is held in May alongside our yearly arts exhibition where students showcase some of their work in the school year. We continue to participate in the District 3 Arts Festival where students will be performing and exhibiting art work.  One of our 5th grade students, Elijah Santiago’s artwork was selected to be part of the Manhattan Borough Arts Festival where his painting, entitled The Mystery, will be shown at the MOMA this year. We continue our Art Club for the second year that includes 4th and 5th grade students who meet once a week after school to work on special projects relating to school events, mural painting, and student choice activities. This year we held two family arts and crafts events to encourage creative and fun activities parents and guardians can participate in with their children, ‘Holiday Family Craft Night’ and ‘Sip and Paint Party’.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: The STEM Institute of Manhattan will continue to provide visual arts and music instuction through art residencies provided by LeAp. In collaboration with this leadership program, STEM students receive regular instruction in visual arts and theatre. Our classroom teachers will continue to integrate art through the content areas so our students will continue to explore, design and showcase their work in our corridors and classrooms.

Study of various artists on going
Museum trips ongoing
Fall - contour portraits of one another
Fall - pick one of works and render it with patterns of dots
Winter - self portraits in the manner of Chuck Close
Spring - Pop Art studying the work of Andy Warhol

Q44_R4: Sugar Hill Children's Museum of Art & Storytelling

Q46_1: The arts program at Dual Language Middle School focuses upon developing students’ literacy in the visual and performing arts. Within the three-year sequence of studio arts classes students participate in the process of artmaking through the exploration of artistic history and the various media, subject matter, and symbolism therein. Students respond critically to a variety of works in the arts and make connections between the art and other subjects as a result of their studies ,developing understanding of and appreciation for the reasons people and cultures construct works of art (both visual and performance), and how the arts shape the diverse cultures of past and present society. During the three-year dance sequence, students explore not only the steps, but also the history and symbolism within dance, from a variety of cultures and time periods including Bharatanatyam, traditional African dance, Chinese Fan Dance, Salsa, Hip-Hop, Jazz, and ballroom dance styles to name a few.

West Side Collaborative Middle School values the arts and incorporates arts into content area curriculum through interdisciplinary projects. We also offer courses in specific art forms. Students are provided with arts experiences that allow them to be creators and performers, exploring a wide range of arts disciplines including visual, film, music, digital, dance and theater arts. In content area and arts courses, students respond to and analyze works of arts. These experiences are enhanced by long term partnerships with art museums and performing arts organizations that broaden our students' awareness of the importance of the arts and their value to society. We are pleased to continue relationships with organizations such as the Whitney Museum of American Art, Wingspan Arts, and The Center For Arts Education to enrich our arts curricula at West Side Collaborative Middle School.

Our current arts programs focuses on providing on our children with many opportunities to participate in the different art genres.  Our goal is to expand their understanding of different cultures through the arts.

Community Action School provides programmed Visual Arts to students in the sixth and seventh grade. Students receive three periods per week and are given instruction in multi-media art including sculpting, drawing, painting, and other art forms. Every student is eligible to participate in after-school art clubs including Chorus and Film where instruction is provided by residents from our partners at Urban Arts. Community Action School intentionally provides art instruction in the after-school program to ensure access to a variety of art forms.

West End Secondary School is committed to providing a comprehensive arts program for all students inclusive of visual arts, dance, and music. Multiple partnerships will enhance our commitment to the arts.

The Maxine Greene High School for Imaginative Inquiry is a learning community in which deep engagement with works of art enhances the imaginative capacity leading to the intellectual rigor of all students. 

This approach to inquiry based learning is rooted in the philosophy of Dr. Maxine Greene which fosters a sense of self-worth, curiosity and empathy.  MGHS empowers this diverse community to work towards a more just, humane and vibrant world.

Teams of teachers currently work on shared inquiry around instructional practice as related to the integration of arts across the curriculum.  As a Focus school with Lincoln Center Education, the principal and a school-based teacher leader identify an Area of Focus and commit teacher time and resources sufficient to conduct Action Research, as well as analyze findings and report results.  Teachers on the team meet throughout the year to create and present substantive findings, plans and recommendations related to the school’s Area of Focus.  The school’s principal and select teachers attend two Cross-School meetings during the schoolyear, one in January and one in June to represent their work and report on their Area of Focus, as well as to share materials. The school identifies one or more Teacher Leaders to take on the logistics of the partnership and the process of conducting Action Research on the topic identified as their Area of Focus.
Q47_1: Teams of teachers currently work on shared inquiry around instructional practice as related to the integration of arts across the curriculum.  As a Focus school with Lincoln Center Education, the principal and a school-based teacher leader identify an Area of Focus and commit teacher time and resources sufficient to conduct Action Research, as well as analyze findings and report results.  Teachers on the team meet throughout the year to create and present substantive findings, plans and recommendations related to the school’s Area of Focus.  The school’s principal and select teachers attend two Cross-School meetings during the schoolyear, one in January and one in June to represent their work and report on their Area of Focus, as well as to share materials. The school identifies one or more Teacher Leaders to take on the logistics of the partnership and the process of conducting Action Research on the topic identified as their Area of Focus. The school makes this role part of the professional workday responsibilities for Teacher Leader and commits per session funds to support it when necessary.

Q46_1: At the Manhattan School for Children, we believe that the arts are vital to our children's education, and that the exploration of the arts nurtures their creativity, imagination and ability to see other points of view as they make personal connections to the world they live in. To foster this vision, the school community has developed a dynamic and well-organized arts program across arts disciplines that is inclusive of our children's backgrounds and of the world's cultures. We are committed to a vision of the school as a community of learners, who are empowered to create their work and share their process. We achieve this vision by the integration of the arts experiences within classroom curriculum and the broad exposure to the arts through our collaborations with neighborhood cultural institutions. Our school is currently in a vertical grade research project with Lincoln Center Institute with the goal of understanding how to implement the capacities for imaginative learning across cohorts.

The philosophy of the art program emphasizes our students as potential artists who view the world from their own unique perspective and experiences. These experiences are communicated through explorations with different materials such as drawing, painting, collage, printmaking and sculpture. Not only do the students begin to express themselves creatively, but they begin to learn the language of art, such as line, shape, color and form. 
All art lessons are aligned with the curriculum and standards set forth by the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, the New York State Learning Standards for the Arts and the National Visual Art Standards. The lessons work to support the standards of other disciplines such as math, literacy, science, social studies and technology. Students are expected to develop their abilities to communicate visually, orally and in written form within the Art Room/Studio. Students begin to play an instrument in grade 2 and by eighth grade have learned to play three instruments.  Students in middle school have dance and photography electives and eighth grade students have a 20 session ballroom dance program.

Our goal is to expose our students to as many genres of art as possible, and engage them in critical conversations about their experiences with art. We have a visual arts teacher that works with our students in Ceramics, and her work is supported by our writing teachers who engage our students in thinking about how their work communicates their intentions as well as an afterschool drama program.

This school year our number of students who partnered with the Theater program at The Brandeis Campus increased from 5 last year to 12. Students from all schools met every week for 3 hours to rehearse a play. The play will be presented in the Black Box theater in May 2018 and all students and staff from the campus will be invited.

Innovation Diploma Plus (IDP) High School offers art courses in Theatre, Mixed Media, and Digital Media. Our courses focus on using an inter-disciplinary approach to shaping critical art spaces that allow students to explore connections between notions of self and community. Within that process, students are able to re-contextualize both narrative and story through their own use of multi-media and performance as well as use art to explore critical issues that are important to them. Each course has three specific performance challenges and one culminating capstone that function as part of a student’s ongoing portfolio. In addition, teachers at IDP collaborate with outside cultural organizations to offer after school programs in Theater, Spoken Word, Creative Writing, and Video Production. During the 2017-2018 school year, IDP produced two full theater productions and one Spoken Word performance. In addition, students were given opportunities to attend cultural arts events, such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Broadway shows. IDP is a member of the Brandeis Arts Collective, which provides after school arts programs, including music, dance, theater, and fine art, to students from attending schools.

Q44_R4: Caribbean Cultural Center - Visual Arts/Visual Arts Research & Res Ctr.
Q46_1: Wadleigh Secondary School for The Performing and Visual Arts offers a comprehensive performing and visual arts education program to students in grades 6 -12. Wadleigh Performing Arts program offers classes in Drama, Vocal Music, Piano and Instrumental music. The Dance program includes tap, modern, jazz, African and other cultural dance forms. The Visual Arts program offers general and advanced classes in painting, drawing and digital photography, including computer graphics. We will add ceramics classes as well as a culinary arts after school club.  We have a film/ video oral history program in partnership with The Apollo Theater Foundation. The school's vision is to emphasize the well balanced student. We have adopted the 'Habits of Heart, Habits of Mind and Habits of Work'. We strive to become the premier arts school in the Harlem community. At Wadleigh, students engage in a rigorous academic curriculum inclusive of advance placement courses, honor classes and college credit courses infused with a strong performing and visual arts program designed to ignite our scholars' imagination, nurture their intellectual curiosity and develop their creative spirit within and beyond our school walls.

The MS 421 arts program has created a three year sequential music and dance program to develop our full scale marching band. Students in 6th grade begin the sequential music program, which includes general music, instrumental music, dance, brass, and rhythm. All curricula follows the principles articulated in the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and instills the "8 habits of studio thinking" in our children's' lives. By 8th grade, students have been exposed to various art forms and built a repertoire of skills that encapsulates these experiences at MS 421.  Each year the marching band participates in several performances on site and off site, such as parades, district performances, and competitions in the city. Our visual arts program is currently in its second year at West Prep.  Students study and apply various mediums throughout the year and develop a strong foundation in drawing, color, value, and composition starting in 6th grade. All art curricula follows the principles articulated in the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and instills the "8 habits of studio thinking" in our children's' lives. Our school hosts at least two showcases each year to highlight the work we are doing within the visual arts and music classes.  Finally this year we have also added Theater programming to all students in the fall culminating with a winter performance and as an elective option open to all students in the Spring also culminating with a performance.
Q47_1: Moreover, integrating the arts with our schools magnet theme, "Youth Voice through Youth Media," will engage our students in more authentic 21st century learning experiences.

Q46_1: PS 452 aims to provide opportunities to leave the classroom for exploratory purposes to museums, landmarks, parks, neighborhoods and cultural institution. We utilize group projects that require the children to plan, research, organize and share. Our goal-oriented units use technology, art, drama and movement to express ideas. Currently we engage our primary grade students in the exploration of the foundations of music and begin to foster their visual artist-self through many mediums. Upper grade students begin to diversify their learning through choral work, differentiated instrumentation, art history, art making, art critique, and advanced visual artistic creation. We believe the arts to be an inclusive and engaging experience for all students, instilling an appreciation for all art forms while fostering their journey to become lifelong fine arts appreciators. During the 2017-2018 school year we engaged residency programs with National Dance Institute, the Salvadori Center, NY Historical Society, and Lincoln Center Film Society Kids. We work in collaboration with cultural institutions such as The American Museum of Natural History, Carnegie Hall, and various other museums and artistic institutions throughout New York City.

The arts curriculum offers different ways of understanding reality and expressing one’s self. Ninth grade students experience the arts rotation, which includes drama, dance, music and visual arts. The 10th, 11th and 12th grade students choose from an array of arts electives, including Digital Film, Digital and Black & White Photography, African Percussion, Choreography, Guitar, Dance Technique, Music Theory, Musical Production, Percussion, Beat-making, and Studio Arts classes in Drawing, Painting, and 3D Art. Advanced or Honors courses are offered in art, dance, drama, film, music, and photography.

Our school enjoys an international reputation as the first and foremost high school dedicated to nurturing students gifted in the arts. Part of our mission is to provide an opportunity for students to pursue conservatory style training. Our state-of-the-art building at Lincoln Center was designed especially for the arts and features world-class facilities including a 1,150-seat concert hall, art, dance, music, recording and theater studios, and an art gallery.

Our school has a passion for the arts and academics. We are dedicated to nuturing students creative talents. Part of our mission is to provide our students with a solid foundation in the arts through a sequence of academic courses, career exploration opportunities and inspiring interactions with fellow students, faculty and professional artists. Students will receive an introduction to fundamental concepts of art;they will explore elements of art and principles of design through studio lessons using problem solving skills in a variety of 2D and 3D media: drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, cardboard and clay. Students will build a foundation of media and technique through lessons engaging observation and imagination. Our art program will expose students to a variety of artists, styles, and vocabulary building dialogue to critically analyze their work and the work of others. Students will be exposed to the visual arts through trips to museums and from our resident artist through our partnership with City Arts.

The High School of Arts and Technology at the MLK Campus is a small school with approximately 490 students. At the High School of Arts and Tech, we use arts and technology as tools to teach, learn and drive the educational process. The students have access to visual art, theater, drama, general music, art history and graphic arts on computers. Our school has its own student art hallway gallery.

Our music and visual arts interaction takes place during the day. We are able to provide and open music and art room during student lunch period. Any student may take advantage of this. We had group of students develop and perform theater pieces as par to the Hamilton School Program. 

Our goal is to increase the number of opportunities students have outside of the regular school day. We also hope to offer students varied media and performance models.

The arts program at Mantattan/Hunter Science High School uses project-based learning to educate students about visual media, culture, history, and mathematics. Educators infuse their curricula with multidisciplinary lessons that offer practical applications for their expressive and creative talents. Our students transform themselves into active participants of their culture. In visual art, students learn a broad range of disciplines including but not limited to sculpture, modeling, drawing, painting, scenic design and a multitude of others. They receive a broad education in the history of the arts featuring notable artists and their styles. In the performing arts, students explore animation, audio sound and sound design, film and TV study, acting, directing, stage combat and theater technology. Our acting and musical units address diction, projection and performance techniques to instill confidence and ownership in our students.

The mission of Kaufman Music Center's Special Music School High School (SMS) is to develop students who have the skills, competencies and knowledge necessary for successful 21st-century music careers. The 21st-century musician can analyze, compose, and perform music at the highest level; has a strong sense of his/her own artistic “voice,” and is fluent in current music technologies. The 21st-century musician possesses the academic knowledge, skills, and habits that are keys to success in a rapidly changing world; he/she is also community-minded, inventive, and resourceful. Founded in 1996 and inspired by the “spetsshkola” system of the former Soviet Union, Special Music School is a unique partnership between the New York City Department of Education and Kaufman Music Center, a not-for-profit cultural organization.

Q44_R3: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: FDA II is a Lincoln Center Education focus school. Here, we value art education and deem it important for each of our scholars to be exposed to dance, music, film/media and the visual arts. Our lessons are aligned to the BluePrint and Common Core standards. At FDA II, scholars perceive the arts through the capacities of aesthetic education as defined by Lincoln Center Education. Scholars explore the arts with the assistance and knowledge of our teachers and visiting artists, as well as getting involved and learning for themselves with hands-on performance tasks.

Mott Hall II considers the arts to be a critical part of our curriculum. All scholars at Mott Hall II take music for three years. The music curriculum is anchored by "Music and the Brain." Additionally, 7th and 8th scholars receive dance instruction from a certified dance teacher. Mott Hall II collaborates with Studio In A School to provide visual arts as part of our after school program. The Society for Educational Arts (SEA) also works with Mott Hall II to provide a 100-hour theater residency that ends with the performance of our annual school musical. Extra art instruction is embedded in the school curriculum and partnerships have been formed with various organizations such as Alvin Ailey and Groove Diplomacy. Finally, Mott Hall II has a school choir and rock band scholars can audition for.

At Public Scool/Middle School 7, our academic program is challenging, rigorous and enriched by integrating the arts. We have a partnership with Hunter College that works with our music teacher in providing violin instruction to our elementary school students.  We also have the 'I Have A Dream' Foundation , an afterschool program  that helps children with homework, provides instructional support, implements art projects,and takes our students on trips. 'Edible School Yard' is a creative garden project that involves our entire school, grades pre-kindergarten to 8. We have  a rooftop garden, where each student  plants, maintain tools, create signs and grow healthy fruits and vegetables. In addition, we have a classroom dedicated to being a kitchen for healthy food preparation. It's an exciting year! The National Dance Institute works with our fourth and fifth grade students once a week and culminates with a gala dance performance for the students and their parents in the school.

Q44_R1_C1: Circle in the Square Theatre School
Q46_1: TAG has been devoted to providing well-rounded Arts education for its students. All of our students, kindergarten through eighth grade receive consistent, high-quality instruction in Music and Visual Arts. We have a dedicated kindergarten through 4th grade music teacher. In 4th grade, students transition to instrumental music through the recorder. By 5th grade, students choose a band instrument and begin their performance instruction. All kindergarten through 8th grade students perform for their classmates as well as parents during formal concerts, multiple times per year. In addition to our music program that takes place during our regular school day, we have an afternoon Latin Jazz Ensemble that rehearses twice a week, after school. They perform multiple times per year, both in school and at community events throughout New York City. Our Visual Arts program is continuing to grow and develop. All of our students, K- 8, receive Art instruction at least once per week. An after school art program is offered to students in creating art work for display. They work in various mediums. Pieces have been displayed at Art Shows both in the school and online, through Artsonia. Our art teacher also does an "Art Lunch," where students can work on projects during their lunch and portfolio development for students applying for specialized high schools.

At River East, we provide a comprehensive arts education program. We partner with several community based organizations to enhance student opportunities in the arts. With this support, we are able to offer full time visual arts instruction, pottery, violin, dance, and chorus as well as a music program in which students participate in a series of interactive concerts that introduce music from various parts of the world.

Roberto Clemente's art program consists of monthly projects. Each unit includes pre and post-assessments-content specific vocabulary is a big part of each unit. These projects further the understanding of all students with different modalities and individual needs. There are many assemblies that showcase student achievements in music and dance. There is a school wide multicultural day where our students explore the culture of various countries and showcase their learning through food, song or dance. Our upperclassmen work closely with artists from the Guggenheim to explore other visual art techniques and take field trips to the museum as part of the program. We have a full time visual arts teacher who is certified in the arts, teaching art history along with art methods and vocabulary. She also identifies connections to science through the arts as well. While teachers are not available for dance, theater and music at PS 38, scholars are exposed to a variety of art form through different resources and programs.
The PS/MS 50 Arts Program is designed to support students in self development through theater arts and performance.

School’s Arts Program Description 2017- 2018 - The PS/MS 57 Arts program includes visual, music, theater and dance components. All students receive arts enrichment in these areas. Prekindergarten has music, role-play, poetry and movement as integral components of everyday. K-8th grades infuse poetry, music & art into CCLS-based lessons which are developed by the teachers and instructional teams. In addition to embedded school-based visual arts instruction, we have an Arts partnership with the 92nd Street 'Y' that provides stimulating student experiences through choral training that culminates in a district-wide showcase with several participating schools. 92nd St.'Y' also engaged students in visual arts, Hip Hop and musical introduction. This year the 'Dancing in the Classrooms' served 5th grade and company served our middle school population. These dance programs culminate in the school's participation in a citywide competition. Afterschool programs such as the YMCA, Roads to Success, and City Year provide arts exposure via varied dance genres such as hip hop and tap; while the staff enhances support of the arts initiative via after-school Chorus, Flag Corps, Step Squad and Classical Music Appreciation for K-8th grade students.

We currently work with three major community based organizations-Turtle Bay Music School, Midori & Friends, and El Museo del Barrio. They provide enriching opportunities to our students in music, theatre, and fine arts education.

Public School 83 believes that integration of the arts into all aspects of the school community is essential to promoting the goals of the Common Core Learning Standards and revised common core aligned curriculum implemented within all classrooms, Pre-K to Grade 5, in our school.  As visitors travel through the hallways of our building and observe the fantastic pieces students have created. 

We strive to create environments where students can learn powerful lessons about resilience, ingenuity, and empathy. Engagement in the arts helps students understand the value of sustained effort over time; increases their ability to approach a problem from a variety of angles; and deepens their interest in and ability to relate to other people – all which are of lifelong importance.

Teaching the creative process is at the heart of all of our arts curriculum. Our teachers lead students towards a deep engagement with the creative process: generating original ideas, testing different approaches, collaborating with peers, incorporating feedback, and building resilience as they move towards creating works of art that can be shared with the larger community.

Finally, the arts create a space where students can connect with others who share their interests and passions. The vulnerability and the honesty required to make meaningful art – and the intensity that comes from preparing to share that artwork with others – creates a unique environment where students can come to a deeper understanding of who they are and what they can accomplish.

Our goal at PS/MS 96 is to continue to provide our students with a complete Arts Program. This will enhance our current curriculum via our teachers and also be supported by many cultural organizations, which will partner with us in the future. Our goal for next year is to continue to provide 3 Arts Disciplines; Visual Arts, Dance and Music as well as to Technology.   We also hope to include some Theater program which we may look for as a residency.  Our students will work with their art teachers who will align projects to their core subjects as well as promoting art outcomes including shows, digital displays, concerts and performances for our greater community. We also look forward to continuing Arts Workshops for parents and their children, broadening our scope as a community school. Through the connection to the arts we look ahead to positive and tangible improvements in learning across all educational disciplines. We also hope our Middle School students can connect arts to relevant cultural and career opportunities, providing opportunities for portfolio specials going forward into the new year.  Exciting additions to our programming will include our continued Verizon Innitiative and our new Maker Space which will allow students to explore their potentials as makers and innovators.  Our goal is to provide all students with exploratory time in this new Maker space.

P.S. 102 is committed to educating the whole child through the use of different disciplines that address the many needs of our students. Students in the visual arts program will gain and extend knowledge of art media and art compositional elements. Students will also explore the content through the use of different materials and techniques. Students in the music program will gain and extend knowledge of music making and music literacy by making connections of common themes from different communities. Our Arts program will focus on the students' prior experiences and align to the scope and sequence of each grade level to enhance learning for all students. Teachers will be encouraged to create student-directed activities that encourage investigation and thought. Teachers will use the Art and Music Blueprint from Studio in a School to help formulate units of study and lessons that are developmentally appropriate for our students. In Visual Arts, students will engage in graphic arts, programing for animation, painting, drawing, and collage. In Music, students will learn to read music and engage in instrumental music via recorders, ukuleles, and samba drums. Students will also engage in choral singing. . All art classes will have a writing component in which they will research a topic from the respective content area. These essays will follow the TC writing format with rubrics and there will be an opportunity for oral presentations.

Q44_R5: Museum of the City of New York
Q46_1:
PS/MS 108 School of Authors currently has two full time Visual Arts Specialists.  Our elementary art teacher PreK-5 is a former MET Astor Educator and has 15 years experience teaching in the NYCDOE.  Our middle school art teacher 6-8 has six years experience teaching art part-time for the NYCDOE and is a published poet and artist.  Both instructors have strong studio backgrounds and experience teaching multiple disciplines and grade levels.  Our arts curriculum is aligned with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts and is rooted in the Studio in a School philosophy of a child centered approach to learning and experimentation as a resource for obtaining knowledge.  Our arts teachers collaborate with classroom teachers to plan trips and make cultural connections in our community.  During the 2017-18 school year we had student worked accepted into the Borough (MoMA) and PS Art City Wide (MET) art exhibits.  

Our school has an artist in residence program with the New York Philharmonic.  We participate in the Very Young Composers program and the recorder program.  These programs are a part of the Young Peoples Concerts series.   

We also work with The Shakespeare Forum in the middle school.  Our sixth graders attend a drama club during lunch and attend classes 2-3 hours a week most of the year.

The arts are considered a vital part of our mission at P.S. 112. It is our goal to provide all of our students with a high quality standards based arts education. We want our students to discover the lifelong enjoyment and wonder of dance, visual arts and drama. Our arts programs provide students with rich learning experiences that strengthen their academic skills, creativity and positively impacts student achievement in reading, writing, math, science and social studies. The arts program at P.S. 112 creates a culture of mutual respect and enhances self esteem.

Our students and teachers experience professional arts concerts and events at 92 St.'Y' and PS 146. Through our partnership, students have been able to take advantage of further arts instruction at 92 St 'Y', and have been offered scholarships there. Our vision for this partnership is to build a course of study consisting of arts disciplines that are related sequentially and make meaningful connections to the Common Core Standards and Blueprint for the Arts. Through this partnership, we are able reach our goal to make sure that reach every child in the school has access to the arts. We consider the arts crucial to the development of our students, both academically and personally, recognizing that effective arts education addresses the diverse ways in which students learn. We are committed to fostering collaborations between classroom teachers and teaching artists using common language and curriculum goals. The 'Y' also provides professional development to our classroom teachers as well as assessment and evaluation of our arts programs. This year, we again are extending our programs through June through an arts extension grant that has greatly helped expand into other arts disciplines for the students. The students will use what they learned in their art classes to create and produce a school-wide performance combing all art disciplines in classes prek-5. We are looking for additional ways to expand our arts programs for the 2018-2019 school year too including the arts in our new 3K programs for September 2018.

Q47_1: The school will assess all funding sources to see if the budget can support a part-time or full time arts teacher.

Q46_1: PS/IS 171 believes that integration of the arts into all aspects of the school community is essential to promoting the goals of the Common Core Learning Standards and revised common core aligned curriculum implemented within all classrooms, Pre-K to Grade 8, in our school. As visitors travel through the hallways of our building, they view the beautiful artwork created by our students. Classroom teachers work collaboratively with our arts providers to design units of study and motivating projects that will enrich student achievement while working to foster student appreciation of the arts. Working with the various arts provider, classroom teachers and specialists are able to infuse music, movement, art and dance into literacy, mathematics, social studies, science and foreign language. Our long term partnerships with cultural and artistic organizations including Studio in a School and the Horticulture Society of New York support and enhance our efforts to promote the arts. We are proud to share that on June 6th, 2018 thirty-two students of our sixth, seventh and eighth grade will participate in the New York State School Music Association (NYSSMA) Festival at NYU University. Two of our students will perform solo pieces at this phenomenal event.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1:
The BBMS community is committed to ensuring that our students are provided with opportunities that include learning through the arts.  We currently have one full time music teacher who participates in "Music in the Brain". This opportunity allows students to cognitively develop skills through the concept of listening to music, playing the keyboard and composing melodies. We have established partnerships with the Society of Educational Arts and CMA. Currently, we have a visual arts program. Visual arts is infused in the social studies curriculum and this year students created community murals. The murals represent who they are in the East Harlem Community.  The artists worked with teachers to integrate the arts in classrooms, using project-based learning to creatively bridge disciplines.  This school year we added a dance program which is led by the Society of Educational Arts. The dance program provided an opportunity for students to learn a number of techniques and dance history.

In addition to our visual arts program with SEA, we also shared our resources with our campus partner PS83. Currently, we are sharing the full time visual arts teacher. Our lower grade students were afforded the opportunity to engage in a year long visual arts program that included developing cognitive skills through the arts. This opportunity has allowed us to ensure that all students across grades K-5 are provided with unique learning opportunities through the arts.
Our plan is to add a full time dance teacher this upcoming academic year.
Q47_1:
Our school cultural is nurturing and positive. When entering our school you will feel the climate change and see positive interactions throughout the school community.
Our population consists of 41% of students classified as English Language Learners. For this reason, we take the time to write grants that will allow us to provide unique learning opportunities to our second language speakers. It is important for our ELLs to be afforded opportunities to develop language and cognitive skills.
Our school supports content learning which allows our students to enhance critical thinking skills. We promote this by ensuring that Science and Social Studies are taught through exploration and investigations.
