We use the FOSS program which has allowed our students to engage in hands on investigations. This learning has contributed to our ability to excel in science. We have participated in the District Wide Science Fair and were awarded first place for academic year 2016-2017 and 2017-2018. Our school is making the necessary changes to ensure progress continues to take place. We are extremely proud of our scholars and will continue working collaboratively to ensure much success for our students.

Q46_1:
The Arts Program at Manhattan East is a comprehensive study designed for both beginners and advanced students. Sixth graders are introduced to Visual Art and Music as part of their required curriculum.

Students in all grades choose from Visual Art, Music, or Dance as part of their "Arts Focus," which meet twice a week for double periods.

Dance is also an option as part of our physical education component.

Q44_R2: Willie Mae Rock Camp for Girls
Q46_1: Arts are integrated into each subject area. JSK also uses outside arts organizations throughout the day to provide a well rounded arts experience. Students travel to cultural institutions frequently and participate in arts programs in the city.

We currently have school-day sequences for Music, Visual Art and Dance for grades 6-12; we prioritize access for all learners, and emphasize performance at venues throughout the city. Our music program is currently focused on ensemble playing, and we are excited to have the only string orchestra in District 4! Scholars learn music theory and composition as well as performance technique under the direction of a Grammy Award winner/teacher. We also offer Latin American Jazz ensemble as a class and after-school program. Our Visual Arts program is a 6-12 sequence focused on developing the fundamentals of visual art, developing scholar talent, and exploring different forms of visual art, all under the instruction of an award winning Art teacher. Additionally, through our partnerships, the students participated of the collaboration between our school and Marquis Studios using two artists in residence. We offer Film Production as an introductory course, we also offer visual art and dance in our after-school program through Union Settlement Community Learning Center. Our Dance department is also a 6-12 sequence focused on developing the fundamentals of dance in different genres from ballet to jazz and hip-hop. The scholars compose and perform their own works throughout the year while making connections with other arts and disciplines outside the arts.

A strong arts education is integral to learning and has a positive impact on overall student achievement and engagement in a wide range of experiences in and out of school.

Mosaic Preparatory Academy's arts program pushes student enthusiasm, discovery and inventiveness for "The Arts" as well as a need for development of cognitive, social, and communication skills. Students intrinsically learn how to innovate, problem solve, think critically and creatively through "The Arts." Our students go on various trips throughout the year to visit museums, theaters, cultural institutions and community organizations.

Renaissance School of the Arts' (RSA) core belief is that Arts education adds immeasurable value to our human existence-it empowers us to dream, enlightens us to our potential, and liberates us to take hold of the unknown. RSA provides students of all learning styles a stimulating and rigorous middle school educational program intertwined with the performing arts as they strive toward academic excellence. During their three years at Renaissance School of the Arts students receive intensive training in their chosen arts field. Upon graduation, our students are ready to audition for performing arts high schools and will have a strong foundation, not only in their specific art form, but in all of the arts. Through our partnerships with Lincoln Center Institute, the 92nd Street Y, Roundabout Theater, Shubert Theater Broadway Junior, and Muralopolis work together to provide core content instruction infused with Common Core Learning Standards and citywide expectations of exposure in the arts

We aim to provide arts through direct instruction of a licensed studio artist, as well as by providing music, dance, and visual arts to each student. We are a technology-based school, providing students the opportunity to create music and film on their computers and utilize online resources to enhance their arts education. Our school is also partnered with The Leadership Program to engage students in kinesthetic activities for socio-emotional growth.

Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics High School offers a robust arts curriculum. We offer both Visual Arts and Music, including an introduction to music theory. Additionally, we offer both Technical Drawing and Photography. The visual art program studies arts through the ages;exploring artistic techniques for drawing, painting and sculpting, and offers many oportunities for students to create their own art. Our technical drawing program introduces students to creating plans that visually communicate how something functions or is to be constructed. We work with Shakespeareforum to provide free after-school drama lessons, culminating in an end of year performance.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: At Park East, we offer both introductory level visual arts classes and an advanced level portfolio class for students who are considering college study or careers in visual art. We have also offered electives in the the arts including Theatre, Performance Poetry, Choir and Introduction to Music.

Central Park East High School offers both Studio Art, Photoshop and Yearbook to students during the school day. We complete the NY State graduation requirements with this program and offer students who excel in the arts many opportunities beyond the mandated credit requirements. We also offer students the opportunity to join the school newspaper, 'The Madison Times', where students gain valuable experience in learning design layout techniques with the In-Design software program. In addition to the art classes offered during the regular school day, Central Park East High School works with Young Audiences through a CASA grant to offer digital film and improv theater residences to students as an extracurricular opportunity. Students who seek admission to colleges that focus on the arts receive assistance with developing portfolios for admission and are offered access to many supplemental after school and summer programs to increase their exposure to the arts. Finally, we continue to collaborate with Urban Arts Partnership and two other nearby high schools to offer Latin Dance, Theater and a DJ Club as additional after-school choices for our students.

Q32_6: Carnegie Hall MEW, 92nd Street Y, Jewish Museum, LAMBDA Literacy, New Visions CLN, NYPL, National Book Award, UFT, League of Women Voters, DMV
Q35_6: Metropolitan Opera, TDF Open Doors, TDF Stage Doors, Hudson Review, Rattlestick Theatre, Manhattan Theatre Club
Q46_1: The comprehensive visual arts and music programs consist of Standards and Blueprint Based curricula that enrich student learning and offer a generous platform in providing personal development in-school and beyond. The additional courses, partnerships, museum, film and theater programs add incomparable enrichment to broaden the academic, creative and professional perspective. These programs enable each student to make connections between cultural, historical and social aspects of the world through their uniquely creative imagery and expressive languages. This year all, arts related courses expanded to include more technology and now use state- of- the- art equipment to enrich the learning experiences. Both the formal arts departments of Art and Music education and enrichment curricula are designed to expand the developing student's capacity to relate to the world of increasing complexity, connection and enjoyment. A variety of career directions are explored, developed and nurtured.

Currently 1/3 of the school is offered Studio Art Year 1, Year 2, and AP art and Independent Art in mixed-grade classes. These courses introduce and develop students visual thinking skills and develop ideas from concept to completion through scaffold projects. The projects develop students ability to work out problems in line, color and 3D media such as: clay, plaster, paper mache & mixed media. Students produce individual and group projects, exhibited around the building year round, as well as entered in exhibitions locally and nationally. Lessons are coordinated across school curricula, and students are encouraged to build a portfolio with school projects, personal work done at home, and apply to after school programs as well as summer museum and arts internships. After schools workshops in visual arts have included building a strip canoe.

Music is also offered to 1/3 of the students in mixed-grade classes through three courses: Beginner, Intermediate, and Band, which performs at school events and basketball games. Students are also provided with individual instruction after school through a 'Go Fund Me' program created by our Music teacher to bring in musicians to teach. After school workshops are offered to students in Latin Dance, Hip-Hop Dance, DJ Music Production, through Urban Arts. Students attend 1 hour classes twice a week over the full academic year, and their work is showcased in school exhibitions and two end-of-semester talent shows.

Isaac Newton Middle School for Math and Science has a full time visual arts teacher. Students interested in applying for Visual Arts High Schools are given assistance and instruction on preparing their portfolios.

Central Park East II values arts education. We partner with  several organizations including Opus 118, About the Swing, 92nd Street Y, Jazz at Lincoln Center and Rosie's Kids to provide quality arts education in a limited space.  As we move to a new building, which will house both our elementary and middle school students we will have space to expand the arts. We are already planning for a certified visual arts teacher, a dance program as well as a arts through technology program.
Q47_1: Due to lack of space we had to close our in-house music program  We are moving to a new space that will facilitate arts programming.  We have already identified a certified visual arts teacher for next year.

Q46_1: PS30 is dedicated to providing students with art experiences and learning.  This school year we continued our partnership with 92 Street Y's Musical Introduction Series Program for our first and second grade students.  Students meet with the Teaching Artist 5 times a year, attend first hand concert performance experiences of in music and culture from around the world, and teachers attend PD about what the children are learning in this program. Opus 118 provides violin instruction twice each week for students from first to fifth grade. Each group receives individualized attention from two experienced OPUS violin instructors.  Opus 118-provides violin instruction each week for students from first to fifth grade. Each group receives individualized attention from two experienced OPUS violin instructors.  LeAp Works work with first to fifth grade ENL/SWD students exploring Social Studies themes through art project-based learning. Performing Arts visit from Inside Broadway and Making Books Sing and trips to ballet performances through Dance Theater of Harlem and American Ballet Theater. PS30 is committed to the continuing support of Arts Education to broaden and deepen students' exposure and deepen their appreciation of the arts aligned with the Arts and Music Blueprint Standards as well as the Common Core Standards.

This school year we were fortunate to have the 92nd Street Y, where the artists worked with our fourth and fifth grade students as they learned about music in different countries around the world. In addition, students attended field trips to the 92nd Street Y. Our students enjoyed engaging singing activities with artists and musicians around the world.

In addition, our school also participated in Doing Arts Together, where our first grade students learned different forms of art, including painting, and using clay.  Doing Arts Together, also offered engaging activities surrounding art, during after school.
Q47_1:
This survey does not reflect the arts instruction that we provide for our pre-kindergarten and kindergarten students.  All of the pre-kindergarten and kindergarten students receive about 40-50 hours of arts instruction per school year in the visual arts, dance and music. Also, arts is integrated in the classroom on these grade levels.

In addition, the school has partnership with The Manhattan School of Music, Teacher's College Columbia University, 92nd Street Y, Museum of Modern Art, Whitney Museum, Guggenheim and The Jewish Museum.

Q46_1: This year we continued with our goal to expose our students to as many aspects of the arts as possible as this is paramount to their holistic development. Understanding and participating with the different art forms (dance, music, visual art) will facilitate and engender understanding and hopefully tolerance of their own as well as other cultures. The integration of the arts in our curriculum will help to develop their creativity in response to the other content areas. Students will gain awareness of the variety of careers available in the arts and this will broaden their career scope, especially for those who demonstrate an affinity for these areas. In addition, the introduction to the arts will allow them to develop an appreciation of them as a source of personal enjoyment and lifelong learning.
Q47_1: Urban elementary school with 95% of students of black or hispanic descent. 90% of students qualify for free or reduced lunch.  School resources are severely limited.  A full body Arts program would be extremely beneficial to student population.

Q46_1: PS/MS 123 is committed to providing quality arts educational programs for our students. We strongly believe that our students' gifts and talents should be nurtured to their fullest potential. It is our intention to provide art integrated experiences to enable our students to participate in various multiple art forms. Emphasis is placed on developing creative and critical thinking skills to address the challenges of the 21st century. Our goal is to design and facilitate student interest and appreciation for the arts. Staff and parents will be provided professional development workshop opportunities to improve and enhance their understanding of the arts. Parents will be provided multiple opportunities to take part in various art form celebrations with their children and teachers. We recognize the importance and therapeutic value of the arts in the lives of our students by permitting them to express their feelings through various art themes. We will continue to select highly-qualified art teachers to provide a standards-based arts curriculum.

In our progressive approach, we believe that education must not be a race for the accumulation of facts, but should be an enriching end in itself. We also believe that education is a joint venture among students, parents/caregivers and teachers. We see the individual child’s curiosity, abilities and learning styles as integral factors in designing, individualizing and assessing each student’s learning. We believe that the arts are an essential part of the curriculum and that it is important for students to express themselves creatively and to use their imaginations freely. We believe that the uniqueness of children is revealed in their very existence and that it is the school’s responsibility to foster their innate sense of the mystery and joy of life. We encourage children to follow their interests, pursue problems in a way that makes sense to them and defend their conclusion by explaining their thinking in a variety of ways. We understand that there are many kinds of intelligence and the traditional academic, cognitive area is one. Equally important areas of intelligence are: intuition, imagination, artistic creativity, physical expression and performance, sensitivity to others, and self-understanding. To neglect any of these areas is to limit students in the development of their full human potential. We engage students with hands-¬on investigations, projects and design challenges across the grades and subject areas inspiring greater interest, depth and understanding.
Q47_1: Over the last three years the school's Title I population has decreased where 67% of students now qualify for free and reduced lunch.  Consequently, the more affluent families have demanded that the school hire a full-times arts instructor which resulted in a visual arts teacher joining the faculty. Additionally, the affluent families were able to use the personal connections with their employers like the New York Philharmonic or different musical companies to enhance learning in our school community.

art, technique and process. 2.Development of observational, social and fine motor skills 3.Self-confidence through artistic expression

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)

Q46_1:
Eagle Academy for Young Men of Harlem during the 2017-2018 school year served grades 6 to 10.  Our highlight event featured Letitia Wright-Shuri from Black Panther on Marvel's Black Panther STEAM Day. Marvel's Black Panther STEAM Day provided hands-on activities including acting and directing and an exclusive by-invitation only Advance Screening of BLACK PANTHER @Magic Johnson Theaters: https://vimeo.com/255755147
We also partnered with The Marching Cobras http://www.marchingcobrasny.org/
Our students performed at venues around the country. One highlight was our MLK Jr. Drum Major speech tribute video at https://vimeo.com/251081128
Our scholars collaborated with Impact Repertory Theater on original plays/poems and attended several Apollo Theater events including The Roots and Fruits of the Blues: https://vimeo.com/267017998 
In addition, we were awarded a grant through the Office of Arts and Special Projects for 10 acoustic guitars and our scholars are sure to create something special.
At Eagle Harlem, we offer a Modern Jazz Music Program led by Mr. Ekshtut, an accomplished musician with a Bachelor's of Music (Jazz Performance) and a Master's of Music Education from New York University. For 2018-2019, we plan to create a "music major" and "non-major" specialty tracks for Grades 9-11 - "majors" specialize in music theory/band/production while "non-majors" choose instrument lab or music production for 1 semester each. Budget permitting, we plan an honors band for advanced students and a state of the Art Music Technology Lab.

Q47_1: We are an elementary PreK-5 school located in central Harlem. We believe that the arts are essential in enriching the academic, social and cultural lives of our students. Due to our limited resources, we are unable to provide a rich Arts program which includes music and dance, but we currently have a full-time visual arts teacher who provides direct instruction to students in K-5; students in Pre-K receive arts instruction from their classroom teacher. The goals of the art program will be to use all available resources within the community to expose and engage our students in all forms of arts education to extend their learning beyond the classroom, thus enriching their academic and cultural experiences. In order to ensure that our students become literate in the arts, we have established ongoing partnerships with various cultural institutions, including the Apollo Theater, The American Ballet Theater and Broadway Beats, to name a few. Our partnership with these organizations enable our students and staff to fully engage in various art forms which taps students' unidentified talents and interests. Full Arts integration will enrich students learning. Our goal continues to be in encouraging our school-based arts teachers to expand learning opportunities for our students.

Q46_1: We currently have a UASGC Robotics team, we also offer AutoDESK (Photoshop, AutoCAD). We also have the Apollo and Caribbean Cultural Center come and visit the students after school and provide one-on-one instruction.

Q44_R2: City College Graduate Program in Theater Ed
Q44_R4: National Dance InstituteCity College Graduate Program in Theater Ed
Q46_1: PS 161 has a small group of full time fine arts teachers. Our two Music teachers offer instruction in general music and music technology as well as strings, chorus and guitar, serving all 9 grades in our K-8 schools. We put on two major music performances; a Winter and Spring concert. Our art teacher teaches 2nd-8th grade. We have a full-time Drama and Dance teacher who works with grades K-4,as well as our afterschool middle-school drama club and middle school electives. Our students do theater in collaboration with our City College Theater partnership. The highlight of the year is our annual middle- school fall musical, which has become a cherished tradition. Our fall production of "Annie" featured 40 student performers, elaborate design, and a packed house of 400 community members. Our drama club attended a performance of "The Tempest" with the EMIT theater company We participate in dance with several dance residencies including NDI and Reach Educational Solutions. Our elective model for the arts in the middle-school has been transformative to our arts culture. For the last 4 years, 1 in 10 of our 8th graders has gone on to matriculate at a selective fine arts High School. Our middle-school debate team won the City and State Championship.
Q47_1: PS 161 is a K-8 school in West Harlem with a predominantly Dominican population.  96% of our students are poverty-level, 25% of our students are students with disabilities, and 27% are English-Language learners.

Q46_1: Following our school's motto of 'Mind, Body Success', the P.S. 175 Arts program focuses on teaching to the whole child by incorporating multiple intelligences within the arts instruction. The goal of the Arts program at P.S. 175 is to provide an interdisciplinary standards-based arts program through which our students will be provided ample exposure to dance, music production (instrumental and choral), visual arts, and theatre. Engagement in these disciplines will enhance cultural awareness, promote positive socialization skills, boost self-esteem and positively impact students' capacity in areas such as math, literacy, and science. Through participation in these arts programs, students will recognize and engage in the vibrant historical and artistic community of Harlem. They will also learn about cultural diversity through exposure to music and dance from around the world. Students will have an opportunity to create their own projects in our music and dance studios. Consequently, students will think and behave like artists.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: P.S. 194M scholars participate in the following Arts programs: Visual Arts and Integrated Arts. Both of the aforementioned programs are aligned with The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts to provide a standards-based, rigorous approach to teaching the arts, as well as the Common Core and NYS Standards, as applicable. Our Visual Arts program takes a holistic approach to developing the whole artist, where scholars are exposed to Art History and the technical skills required to develop their artistry. Integrated Arts incorporates music, dance, and theater, which afford scholars the opportunity to develop each discipline in a unique way. Additionally, our scholars’ learning is enhanced by field trips, interdisciplinary projects, and service learning activities. Scholars participate in whole-school and grade-level performances where they showcase their creative talents in music, dance, and theater, as well as feature their work in art exhibitions. Our Arts programs help foster a wide range of discovery and critical thinking activities, and are designed to promote and foster scholars’ creativity, discovery, exploration, and expression.

At PS 197M, Art is an integral part of our instructional program. Students in all grades from Pre-Kindergarten through Grade 5 receive a range of art instruction. One of the highlights of our Art program is our partnership with Time-In Art. Students in Kindergarten, Second, Third, and Fourth Grade receive direct instruction each week, for both interpreting the visual arts of others, as well as how to create their own works of art with emphasis on techniques. Through this program, students have had the opportunity to attend various art galas, operas, and culturally themed events in many of New York City's esteemed museums. For the 20182019school year, we intend to increase our performance arts offerings for our students. One highlight will be our new Ballet Program, in which students in grades 2-4 will have a unique opportunity to develop their potential with formal instruction

Q39_4: Workshops by Studio in a School
Q46_1: Our school had the privilege of continuing our visual arts partnership with the Studio In A School program, which provides visual arts instruction for our students and professional development for our teachers. As a result, we have an abundance of art displayed throughout the school, with an increased love and respect for visual arts by students, staff, and the entire school community. For the year 2018-2019, we will continue to provide dance, music, and theater instruction via our Leadership Program collaboration, our full time staff Music/Choral teacher, and/or licensed full time staff arts instructors.
Visual arts program the provides students with arts experiences in all aspects of visual arts.

The Mott Hall High School school community will exhaust all available resources to accomplish the goals of providing our students with the most enriching Arts programs possible. The school will continue to integrate the core values of our mission statement and school goals, and instructional focus aligned with the Danielson framework. The Arts Program will continue to implement the Common Core Music curriculum and the Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. MHHS community will ensure students are exposed to and use a variety of media subjects, symbols and themes in order to ensure students create works of art. Mott Hall High School Arts program recognizes an effective and high-quality arts education can be a powerful catalyst for a successful education. Students will utilize the principles of art to create their own personal styles and express their ideas through various means, allowing them to find various ways to express themselves. Students will develop techniques that will reflect their personal styles to illustrate and inform different opinions,recognizing and embracing the social, cultural, and historical significance of art. Mott Hall High School will provide students opportunities to work individually, as well as in groups, at building schools and community organizations to develop students' art appreciation. Mott Hall High School will forge partnerships with local institutions, such as the Schomburg Library, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and others to bring art enrichment to the students.

Our goal is to foster an environment where artistic creativity is nurtured and developed. It is our goal for students to recognize the cultural, societal and significance of the arts,thus becoming lifelong learners and advocates of the arts.Through our Arts program, students are allowed to see themselves as true artists and performers.We believe our Arts programs help students to develop critical thinking skills which allows them to view the world through multiple lenses. As a school community we visit the cultural institutions of NYC. Our arts infused program is aligned with the NYS Common Core Standards and The NYC Blueprint.

Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science and Engineering focuses on visual arts in middle school in its curricular sequence,
providing a three-year sequence of visual arts instruction that includes elements of theory, introduction to arts genres, methods and tools. Students create a wide variety of visual arts projects, exercising creativity and applying their growing understanding of form, color and shading to a more sophisticated level as they grow through the three years of arts instruction. In high school, students receive instruction in music. CSS also offers a wide range of extra-curricular arts offerings, ranging from dance to theater to choral and instrumental music, which allows students to choose an arts area to explore in depth and/or experiment with various disciplines.

Q44_R1_C1: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance
Q44_R2: Paul Taylor's American Modern Dance Theatre
Q46_1: The Urban Assembly School for the Performing Arts (UASPA) sustains a challenging college preparatory curriculum that infuses the performing arts into all aspects of the academic experience. We know that instruction in the arts enhances the academic performance of many hard to reach students. We present our students with a conservatory level of study, and weigh offerings in the performing arts equally with our academics. During first semester of freshman year, students gain instruction in four areas of the performing arts: Dance, Theater, Technical Theater and Vocal Arts. At the end of first semester of freshmen year, students declare and audition for a performing arts major, which remains their focus throughout their high school career. During that time students have double periods of conservatory study in their major as well as an internship or apprenticeship with a professional artist/arts organization.

At New Design Middle School we believe in the idea of providing our students with a variety of arts experiences.  This year we will be providing our students with a music residency provided by Midori Freinds.  This residency will consist of a full demonstration of the selected instruments, as well as a discussion of the various components necessary for student success.

The Teachers College Community School's (TCCS) overall arts goal is to provide all of our students with a well rounded, high quality arts education which includes Dance, Drama, Visual Arts, and Music. We are proud to note that our school's Arts program encompasses all grades, including pre-kindergarten. Our school has forged strong collaborations with Teachers College, Columbia University. Our students have performed in music recitals and school-wide concerts, their artwork curated for exhibit on-site and displayed at Teachers College. Visiting artists have performed at our school. We have had a successful collaboration with Studio in the Arts.  All children deserve to explore the stimulating and exciting world of the arts, and to see the world through a different lens. This year we embarked on an in house theater program for grades 2-6 and our inaugural middle school class is embarking on the use of technology in arts.  TCCS has made a strong commitment to provide a diverse and valuable arts education for our students.
Thurgood Marshall Academy offers Music courses and Visual Arts courses to students in grades 6-12 taught , and, the Young Peoples Chorus of NY provide theater, dance and choral instruction.

Arts programs at our school are in the shape of 45 minute electives offered twice a school year.   The classes are flexible and assignments change based on student prior experience.  The teachers have developed a four semester sequence that they hope to implement if student interest and availability to teach the class supports the needs and structures of the semesters.   We additionally have a Digital photogralhy class that is offered one semester per year.

For the second year,our renewed vision for the entire Duke Ellington School community is to create an enduring and creative platform for all scholars to become visionary leaders that foster 'Ellington P.R.I.D.E' by way of the performance arts. This year we brought in a dance teacher fulltime, continued Music and hired a theater teacher full time. The entire Arts cluster team led their respective scholars in monthly culminating showcase performances that exemplified the PBIS virtues of the month. By modeling and teaching Positivity, Respect, Integrity, Determination and Excellence via the performance arts platform, we as a school community aspire to provide opportunities for students to participate in a myriad of artistic endeavors so that they may become well rounded individuals who have an appreciation and a love for the arts. Our partnerships with Turn 2 Us, Lotus Dance residency, Midori & Friends, the Shubert Theatre/Arts Connections grant and Arts Connection for ELL/SWD grant,allowed us to expand the minds of the children and connect the arts with their education. Furthermore, the award-winning Ellington Poet Society Spoken Word Club at the school has become a staple in the community for Theater Performance Arts with culminating performance at the Apollo as part of the Manhattan borough Arts Festival for the second year in a row.

P.S. 5: The Ellen Lurie School was the winner of the prestigious Leonore Annenberg School Fund for Children Grant. In partnership with the Center for Arts Education, the grant allowed for the planning and implementation of extensive music-integrated curricula. Our goal is to encourage our students to use their imaginations to solve problems by nourishing their creative skills. We believe the arts provide entry points into Common Core Learning Standards-aligned curriculum for students and are a vehicle for students to build self-confidence by feeling successful in the classroom and can be a catalyst for increased student motivation and achievement. We are committed to hiring certified arts teachers to lead our arts programming, with a focus on visual arts. We strive to meet the NYS instructional time requirements. In order to allow learning within all four arts disciplines, we partner with cultural organizations, including the Center for Arts Education and Shen Wei Dance Arts. Through these partnerships, students not only reap the benefits of an enriched curriculum, but teachers also have the opportunity to grow professionally through planning and delivering instruction in cooperation with teaching artists, thereby expanding their capacity to integrate the arts throughout the school day for our students. P.S. 5 expands our arts offerings after school with two select choral groups, drumming ensemble, ELL visual arts / social studies program and a family arts program.

P.S. 8M aims to make Arts education a significant part of our students’ experience alongside rigorous academic standards and instruction. P.S. 8M encourages its students to participate in arts education through its programming in art, music, dance, and arts-related classroom projects to support language development and literacy. 

Our newest initiative, in partnership with The Children's Aid Society, engages parents to learn about and participate in the process of nurturing the innate connections between the arts and childhood development.  

Currently, we offer classes in art and literacy, dance, general music, instrumental and vocal music instruction to students at all levels in grades pre-K through 5th. We produce a fully staged and costumed musical theater production with 3rd-5th graders each year.  After-school activities include Modern Band; in which we explore a wide range of musical genres, including Latin, Rock, and Popular music. We maintain instrument grant-based programming and equipment through Music and the Brain and Little Kids Rock. In-house performances include monthly interactive jazz combos with The Jazz Foundation of America, and yearly performances with the American Classical Orchestra. Dance and movement are an important part of our arts curriculum with support from the Arnhold Organization in partnership with Together in Dance.

PS/IS has a strong music and art program where students are encouraged to explore new ideas, materials, ways of thinking and looking at the world. Music and art use integration with the classroom learning to help make strong cross- curricular connections. Students art work is hung around the school as well as showcased in city wide art shows. Students perform for fellow classmates and parents several times a year with small and large ensembles. Our school partners with several arts and cultural organizations here in New York City to enrich the students' experiences and learning.

Q44_R3: Sugar Hill Children's Museum of Art & Storytelling
Q46_1: Our goal at The Wright Brothers School is to provide well-rounded arts instruction to our students. To accomplish our goal, we have created a diverse arts program that serves as a creative forum for our students to support their individuality and cultures. Students participate in our visual arts instructional program and our residential Music-art program, Arts Horizon, that supported literacy through the arts. Our partnerships include The Guggenheim Museum, The Society of Educational Arts and the Sugar Hill Museum. We extend our students' appreciation of the arts through trips to the Guggenheim art museum, New Victory Theater, and Sugar Hill Museum. Our annual multicultural celebration in June will highlight the various cultures represented in our school community, through research projects, exhibits and performances. Parents participate in art workshops and collaborate with their children whenever possible.

In the Visual Art class, students participate in an arts curriculum that helps them understand how material, technique and process are used to create works of art. Students learn through object-based inquiry and discussions in the classroom and during museum visits which deepens critical-thinking skills and enhances classroom curriculum. Resources such as art making supplies and electronic devices like iPads with museum apps, help students become familiar with a variety of different art forms and hone their ability to observe and discuss their own artworks and the works of art of others. The program is enhanced with regular museum visits and a year-round calendar of exhibitions showcasing students' work. In Theater, Pre-K and K students activate and use their imagination through creative drama activities and storytelling. First graders explore ensemble acting and memorization techniques through participatory stories from different cultures. Second graders develop the actors' instruments: voice, body and mind, while participating in play productions. Third and fourth graders engage in complex acting settings such as full-length rehearsals or scene work to explore theater making processes through various roles: actor, director, designer, spectator and critic. Dual language students in fourth grade are trained in Jacques Lecoq’s Pantomime for Actors Technique, which prepare them for the Experimental Theater course in fifth grade. Other fifth grade classes focus on acting or playwriting, with a specific theme or historic period.
Q47_1:
PS 48’s Arts Education Mission Statement

Arts education at PS 48M plays a fundamental role in the individual and social-emotional developmental stages of children. We believe the arts develop self-expression; expand a child’s imagination, creativity, critical thinking, awareness and sensibility for other subjects, disciplines, traditions and cultures; foster global capacities; and improve academic achievement. Our arts education sequential learning focuses on a four-stage cycle: experiencing and understanding art-making processes, developing art-making skills as well as key character values, creating art works, and reflecting and responding to artists, their own work, and  the work of others. Through our program, led and taught by qualified arts teachers and supported by long-lasting partnerships with arts and cultural organizations, we strive to enrich the school environment by embedding arts and culture into the core curriculum.

Q46_1: I.S. 52 offers many programs in Music and Art: students receive two-to-three periods of art per week in their concentrated area, this includes Band, Guitar, Recorder, African Drumming, and Fine Art. Students participate in several performance venues around New York City as well as several performances throughout the school year within the school and local community. Presently we have the only marching band in District 06 in Manhattan.

We continue working with Little Kids Rock where students learn to play instruments and express thoughts and feelings on social issues through songs and poetry. Our affiliation with Rosie’s Theater Kids will continue next year-this program is a fusion of music and dance education for our fifth grade students. The students have the opportunity to attend a Broadway show and participate in a culminating performance. We have been working this year with The Leadership After School Enrichment Program. Through them our students have participated in Visual Arts, Dance, and Music programs. We will continue working with them next year.

There are four components to Dos Puentes Arts Program: Visual Art, Music,  Dance and Theatre. Visual Art is provided by Studio in a School, and serves all our students weekly: children work with a teaching artist in Spanish to learn sculpture, drawing, painting, and printing. This is extended into the classroom during our daily 'Explorations' period. Children also receive Music classes weekly: they learn to sing, play the drum, and use other percussion instruments. Second graders learn ukulele and third graders learned recorder. There are at least two musical/ dance performances a year, and we have a full-time dance teacher who serves all our students. Students learn creative movement, cultural dances, and how to collaborate around a presentation in Spanish. As a dual language Spanish/English school, language and culture are reinforced through the arts, both in the classroom and in each specialty areas. All classrooms also participate in our New Victory Theater partnership, attending performances at the midtown theater. We are also fortunate that our after-school program provides other enrichment opportunities : Chorus, 'Just Dance', Latin Dance, Choral and Instrumental Music.

Our school is committed more than ever to foster a community of learners enriched with meaningful experiences in the arts. As a Magnet School of Arts and Science Exploration we value the transferable skills attained through the fine arts settings.  Our curriculum is invaded with creative activities, artistic and scholarly explorations, and critical analysis.  We provide engagement opportunities for students, faculty, and staff expanding collaborations with arts partnerships. Our goal is to cultivate an environment that encompasses the full landscape of learning.

The P. S. 128M Arts Program consists of a Visual Arts, Dance, and Music teacher, all of whom are licensed and provide critical insights for our students. Students are taught to make social, cultural, and historical connections through dance, music, and art-they learn to connect creatively to other disciplines and to technology, becoming life-long learners and advocates for the arts. Students are actively engaged with cultural institutions, schools, community-based organizations, libraries, and artists that contribute to the cultural and economic strength of New York City, so they can apply the knowledge and skills they have learned to assist them in interpreting the world around them.

The goal of P.S. 132's Arts Program is to integrate the arts into all content areas as well as to develop appreciation for the various art forms. We have partnered with the Music and the Brain and Music Memory programs as a means of exposing our students to music theory starting at the kindergarten level. Currently our kindergarten through second grade students receive two periods of keyboard instruction each week. This practice has helped to develop the students' musical abilities as well as their fine motor skills. Our 3rd - 5th graders receive one period of music instruction per week. Starting in third grade, music instruction is connected to the content being covered in the units of studies by the classroom teachers. The other forms of art are addressed by the classroom teachers, Visual Arts teacher, and cultural/ arts organizations during the school day and after school. Community Word Project provides theater arts to third grade students. Urban Arts Partnership provides visual arts to third grade students and one fourth grade class.

Our 2017-2018 school's Arts curriculum is based on the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts. We provide an Arts Literacy Program (ALP) that offers our students an intra-curricular arts-based program that is instructed by the Visual Arts specialist referencing Social Studies and ELA curriculum. It is a multi-unit rotating program which affords our students the opportunity to study arts history and compare and analyze different world cultures.

Q44_R4: Foundation for the Revival of Classical Culture
Q46_1:
PS 152M has a long history of involvement in the arts.  We believe in enriching our student’s educational experience by exposing our students to the arts.  The arts are proven to instill self-confidence, discipline and focus skills in students.

At PS 152M, we have two dedicated in-house arts teachers who teach art and theatre arts full time.  We have designated a rooms where we house our art studio and theatre studio.

As a Magnet School, we have designed an afterschool program which are primarily technology focused but we have visual art and theatre clubs.
	
At our school, we display student artwork all throughout our building.  Our 4th and 5th grade students participate in the American Ballroom Theatre (Dancing Classrooms) and Drum Café Programs. The culminating activity of American Ballroom Theatre program is the city-wide dance competition in which our team has placed in first place at the city-wide Rainbow Competition.

As a Children’s Aid Society (CAS) Community School, students enrolled in the CAS After-School Program participate in arts clubs such as drama, folkloric dance, art Lovers, handicrafts, and chorus, and have “Expos” at least two times a year.  Our goals for Arts programming include visits to museums and having our students exposed to the arts through musical and theater performances and cultural events.
Q48_2: School Business Manager/ Data Manager/ STARS Programmer

Q46_1: We received a grant for ARTS and English Language Learners and Students with Disabilities. We partnered with Studio in School to provide our students with opportunities to learn art with science. We covered topics such as nutrition, animal adaptions and puppetry. In addition, we continue to work with the Morgan Library which provided a summer institute for teachers and two workshops for students. We applied to have a partnership with the MET, which will focus on building professional learning communities. We also have a partnership with Dancing Classrooms to provide ballroom dancing to our 5th grade students. Furthermore, we hired a part-time music teacher and our Parent Association is helping us fund the program. All our students receive quality visual arts instruction from our full-time art teacher. We have a strong commitment to the arts and we believe that the arts are an integral part of a well-rounded education. We feel that developing arts' literacy, vocabulary, and skills support learning across the curriculum. We hope to instill in our students a lifelong appreciation for the arts.

Art programming in its various forms at PS/IS 187 is a year-round process that promotes and fosters creativity, individuality while showcasing student talents and abilities. Our students embrace the opportunity to learn and become well-rounded individuals by learning from not only our skilled faculty but from many outside providers such as City Kids, YANY, and Art Hoppers as well. As we look towards the upcoming school year, we look to focus on the following goals: Instrumental Music: Continue to advance ability to play instruments by teaching the students music theory, appreciation, and presentation. Students in grades 5-6 will show their growth by performing for an audience of their peers and parents/guardians, while students in grades 7-8 may chose to perform in the annual talent show. Vocal Music: Continue to create unique and original content that aligns to curriculum and addresses the social and emotional needs of students in grades K-4. Students in the elementary school will have the opportunity to perform, while students in grades 5-8 may continue to build their vocal abilities by participating in the Intermediate School Choir. Visual Art: Continue to introduce Art to students in grades K-8 by allowing them to express themselves through painting, sculpting and collage building. Through a series of cycles, students in grades K-4 continue to build on their knowledge and skillset by working with outside providers.

In order to provide our students with a strong foundation in the arts all students participate in Music and Art instruction. These programs support and enhance the classroom learning environment by aligning the New York State Music and Art Standards, New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Music and Visual Arts to the Common Core curricula. We believe that music and art enriches and enhances individual learning, and promotes school-wide progress in the basic skills of thinking, listening, speaking, reading and writing, while supporting our students' social-emotional growth.  Our Music program offers instruction in general music, steel drum band, string ensemble, recorder ensemble, and chorus. This year our school received a generous grant to implement and maintain a music education program and curriculum on the model developed by Music and the Brain (MATB).  All of our Kindergarten and First grade students participate in MATB classes for two periods per week with a MATB trained and licensed music teacher providing instruction using keyboards.   Our Visual Arts program integrates Common Core content, enriching concept and knowledge, and exposing students to various forms of art mediums and experimentation. We continue to provide our students in grades 3-5 with the opportunity to participate in our after school sketch club; with the goal of enhancing students' observation skills and develop their drawing abilities.

Q44_R1_C1: Sugar Hill Children's Museum of Art & Storytelling
Q46_1:
Varied mediums of arts instruction (Music, Dance, Theater, and Visual Arts), are introduced to our Pre-Kindergarten students and is taught by the Pre-K classroom teachers. This year, students in one of our Pre-K classes Kindergarten were provided with direct instruction in the visual arts, during the instructional school day, through a residency program with The Sugar Hill Children's Museum.
First and second grade students were provided with direct instruction in the visual arts through an after-school residency program with Creative Art Works (CAW).
Third, fourth, and fifth grade students were provided with direct instruction in theater, dance, and movement through an after-school residency program with Lincoln Center Education.

All PK - gr. 5 students also have opportunities and experiences to participate in school concerts (usually involving music/singing and dance).

The Arts hold a prominent place at Hamilton Grange Middle School, and for that reason we are committed to making the visual and digital arts as well as music, dance and theater part of our regular school day and afterschool programming. Our commitment to the arts is twofold: (1), we want students to find their passion while here at Hamilton Grange, and through it build the discipline and work ethic necessary to be successful in whatever endeavor they choose. (2), we know that training in the arts is beneficial to the whole child-for instance, sustained learning in music and theater correlates strongly with higher achievement in both math and reading, art studies and activities help keep high-risk dropout students to stay in school, new brain research shows that not only does music improve skills in math and reading, but it promotes creativity, social development, personality adjustment, and self-worth. Students who study art are 4 times more likely to be recognized for academic achievement and 3 times more likely to be awarded for school attendance. We look forward to working with you!

PS/IS 210, The Twenty-First Century Academy for Community Leadership, offers a rich and dynamic arts program that emphasizes Music, Visual Art, and Theater/Dance. Students in grades PreK-8 have weekly visual arts, music, and theater/dance classes. Middle-school students have additional opportunities for arts instruction during elective periods. The school maintains relationships with the Dance Theater of Harlem, the Theater Development Fund, the Museum of Modern Art, the Cloisters Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Whitney Museum. Music offerings include Piano, Drumming, Recorder, Xylophone, and Chorus. Art offerings include Drawing, Painting, Ceramics (with a kiln in the school art department), and other media. Theater students study Playwriting, Acting, Dance, Technical Theater, and present staged productions. Field trips to museums and other cultural organizations frequently supplement classroom instruction. Many opportunities for sharing arts experiences with the school and community exist, such as concerts, graduation ceremonies and art displays in the school's hallways and display cases.

Our Theater program continued this year with the support of a substitute teaching artist. Students studied seminal dramatic texts, engaged with professional actors on site and in theater talkbacks, as well as  engaged in viewing two professional performances: one Broadway and one Off Broadway play. The capstone assessments took the form of original written and/or performed pieces.

Our school's mission is to develop future leaders by providing a world-class STEAM (science, technology, English, arts and mathematics) education that prepares students for college and higher learning. Our education is rigorous and provides enriching learning experiences in and out of school.  Our mission is supported by an arts program that includes: visual art, music, dance, vocal and orchestra. In our visual arts program, students can communicate at a foundational level. This includes knowledge and skills in the use of basic vocabularies, materials, tools, techniques, and intellectual methods of the discipline. Our goal is that our students can communicate proficiently in at least one art form, including the ability to define and solve artistic problems with insight, reason, and technical proficiency.

Music/Orchestra Goals

1. To acquire skills in listening, describing, reading, performing, and creating in order to promote aesthetic response. 
2. To acquire and apply musical knowledge. 
3. To take the initiative to select, understand, and appreciate music as an art form. 
4. To gain insights into many cultures and eras. 
5. To develop the ability to make qualitative judgments relative to music.

Our Dance Program is designed to provide students with movement skills that will increase their flexibility, strength, and aerobic endurance. Emphasis is placed on learning the fundamental skills required for dance training while enjoying the physical benefits. In addition, students will have have many performing opportunities.

The Arts are prominently featured at The Paula Hedbavny School-PS/MS 278. Through visual arts classes,students study fine art and basic elements of art. Art classes are supplemented after school by The Creative Arts Workshop. Our General Music Program offers drum, guitar, recorder and wood instrument instruction using curricula and methodology from Center for Arts Education and the 92nd Street Y.  4th and 5th graders may join the band and students may also join the chorus. Through our partnership with the 92nd Street Y we have hip hop classes for grades k-5 and a music series for grades 1,2,and 3.  Four of our classes partner with the Salvadori Center, which enables students to learn core subjects through the study of architecture.  Our school also has a School-Wide Enrichment Model program where students join faculty-led enrichment clusters,which meet weekly during the school day . Many of our enrichment clusters have artistic components to them,such as musical theater,vocal training and fashion design.

All students in grades 6-12 have access to the arts. Grade 6 students take 5 periods of art instruction each week, while Grade 7 students are programmed for 5 periods of music per week. Students in Grade 8 are programmed for either Art or Music. Students in Grade 9 take either photography or drawing as their first college course through our partnership with City College of New York,(CUNY). 10th grade student take FIWQS, a CCNY college course that links a writing class with either music, dance or visual art. Students in 10th grade may also choose to continue taking drawing or photography. Students who take courses at CCNY may also select courses such as: Theater Arts, Stage Combat, Ballet, Tai Chi. Also, at the high school level, students may opt to take Capoiera as a physical education class. Students also participate in music and theater arts through our partnership with Julliard, Carnegie Hall and Theater Development Fund.

A child educated at Muscota is provided instruction and active engagement in all areas of human development. Along with academic
achievement and building successful social relationships, all children have regular experiences in 4 arts disciplines: visual arts, drama, dance and music. The arts are not just additional subjects for the child "to learn" but rather important avenues of expression of how a child understands the larger world. Arts, at the service of other studies, highlights and reinforces work in other subjects: the mural of the community for social studies integration, writing plays for literacy, and constructing a model house for math and measurement skills. All Muscota students receive weekly classes in each arts discipline. There are regular presentations of student work in the arts as well as more formal performances and exhibits. Each teacher of the arts has an active parent committee that organizes fund raising, field trips
and other parents to serve in the role of teacher.

The M.S. 319 Arts Program offers Visual Art. The Visual Arts program is a sequential, three-year art curriculum (including drawing, painting, mixed-media and architecture) that is materials-based and developmentally appropriate. In response to Common Core Learning Standards, students are offered art classes that are geared towards preparing them for arts-related careers. Classes culminate with an art exhibition at the end of the year for the school community.

Our 2017-2018 school year saw us make a transition in arts programming.  Our Theater Arts program ended while we reinstated our partnership with Creative Art Works.  Creative Art Works offered after school classes in Sneaker Design and Urban Design. Also, we continued our relationship with Alvin Ailey Dance Theater.  Alvin Ailey taught after school Afro-Cuban dance workshops.

New partners joined us in 2018.  The Gibney Dance program worked intensively with a small group of students during the spring.  We also worked with the Sugar Hill Art Museum to collaboratively produce a mural.

Within the school day schedule, a proportion of our students received  arts instruction.  In this class, students studied the technique of a well known artist then produced a piece based on the artist's technique. In addition, one of our teachers piloted a weekly class focused on music theory and percussion.  The instruments used in this class were donated to the school.  

Our goals are to continue to strengthen the three year sequence of Arts courses as well as build stronger arts partnerships. Finally, we will build "rigor" in the Arts by developing more comprehensive arts assessments such as rubrics, peer assessments, timely teacher feedback to students, and performances.
Q47_1:
CMSP 328 is located in the community of Washington Heights and draws students from here as well as Inwood, Harlem, and Bronx communities. These communities have undergone demographic shifts that mirror changes that are occurring in New York City generally. CMSP 328’s student population is diverse by every measure:
Our current enrollment is approximately 250 students from the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Columbia, Ecuador, Mexico, Haiti, Guyana, and the United States. Our largest language group is represented by speakers of Spanish with over 100 students. A notable demographic shift is the increase in the number of Arabic speaking students from countries like Yemen (we currently have 11 Arabic speaking students). Another represented language group speaks Haitian-Creole. According to our School Performance Dashboard, our demographic statistics are: 1% Asian, 13% Black, 84% Hispanic, and 1% Other.  Our percentage of students who are considered ELLs is over 60% while almost 40% of our students have IEPs.

Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R5: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
In order to be college/career ready, the arts are an incredibly important part of a CHAH student's growth and trajectory from grades 6-12. Students in our middle school are exposed to each of the arts we offer: dance, music and visual arts. At the end of middle school, students choose a specialty, such as- dance performance, dance concepts, band, chorus, art studio, etc. Students also have the opportunity to take AP Studio Art as upper-class men/women. 

While funding across the city is being cut and the arts are being marginalized, CHAH has invested in a brand new dance studio, in addition to the existing, fully equipped, state of the art visual arts studios and music rooms. Students have full access to imaging, audio and digital media software on various platforms. Most importantly, CHAH has three full time arts teachers who embody the soul of our arts programs by working with community institutions to bring art alive for our students.

Our community strongly believes in a well rounded student that can speak to all the arts, and can demonstrate their mastery in public performances and expositions. We strongly believe in the arts being a shared, public experience.

Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning School (WHEELS) prepares all students for success in college and careers. WHEELS serves Pre-K through 3rd grade and 6th through 12th grade students, and the arts play an integral role in the school curriculum. WHEELS offers daily classes as well as after-school programs in Dance, Theater, Visual Art, and Music. The school currently has two 3rd grade bands, one 6th-7th grade band, one 8th-12th grade band, general music classes for students in 2nd, 3rd, 6th and 7th grades, visual art classes for all students in kindergarten, 1st, 2nd, 6th, 7th, 10th, and 12th grades, movement/dance classes for all Pre-K through 1st grade students, and drama and musical theater courses for high school students.
Q47_1: The arts report at http://schools.nyc.gov/documents/ArtsReport/2016-17/ArtsReport_M348.pdf contains an error. It says we had no full-time certified music teachers for the 2016-2017 school year. However, Graham Johnson is a certified music teacher and he taught music full time at WHEELS during the 2016-2017 school year, as he does this school year.
Q48_2: Music Teacher and Arts Education Liaison

Q46_1: Our students in grade 8 receive Fine Arts instruction two periods per week provided by a certified art teacher on our staff. Students in grades 6 -8 participate 2 hours per week in a Theater Arts class provided by artists in residence of the People's Theatre Project during the SONYC (School's Out NYC) after school program. Every 8th grade student receives 10 hours per year of Ballroom Dance from an artist in residence of the American Ballroom Dance Theater and 12 students continue regular Ballroom Dance practice as a competing dance team. In addition, our 8thj grade students receive Arts programs as part of our regular enrichment period curricula one period a week for the entire year. In these enrichment clubs, students are learning visual arts and photography. All 6th grade students participate in a series of opera classes provided by our school principal which include attendance at five final dress rehearsals at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center.
Q47_1: We serve the second highest percent of low income ELLs in NYC DOE K-8 schools.  As a small newcomers school, we have a limited budget for the arts and appreciate tremendously the financial support we receive from the Office of Arts of the DOE.  Thank you!

Q44_R3: Sugar Hill Children's Museum of Art & Storytelling
Q46_1: All students study Music two times a week and Dance two times a week throughout the year with full-time certified Music and Dance teachers. Select classes study Dance or Music three times a week. The Music program has a long standing relationship with Little Kids Rock and Carnegie Hall Link Up and offers classroom instruction in Recorder, Guitar, Keyboard, Drums, Auxiliary Percussion, Music Appreciation, beginning Sight Reading and Voice in a variety of genres. Schoolwide weekly sing-a-longs build community and offer opportunities to feature select students. 5th grade musicians also performed in “Pack the Palace” 2018. Through fundraising, new drums and recorders were purchased in 2018. Dance students learn about dance concepts through a creative movement curriculum and are expected to use these concepts to create their own dances. Additionally, students study various genres such as Modern, African, Ballroom and Pre-Ballet. There are multiple opportunities for students to perform dance throughout the school year. Our school is a recipient of the 2016-17 ArtsSpace Grant which provided sprung-wood floors, mirrors and barres in the dance room. In 2016 and 2018, dance students performed in the Manhattan Borough Arts Festival. Limon4kids Artist in Residence program occurs every January. In March, the Paul Taylor American Modern Dance (PTAMD) “Tier 3: Arnhold Dance Education and Audience Initiative provides free tickets to HHS families for the PTAMD Lincoln Center season.

At The High School for Excellence and Innovation we offer a variety of art programs from Studio Art to Advanced Art to our students that are aligned with the New York State standards. Students that are interested in pursing an art career beyond High School have the opportunity to create a portfolio for college entry

The College Academy elevates students creatively and intellectually to express their ideas in visual and musical form and to perceive not only historical contexts but also how it relates to the dynamics of culture in community based art. The College Academy’s visual art courses range from art foundations, intermediate level drawing and painting as well as advanced level studio art. In art foundations, students learn how to establish the elements and principles of design and apply basic level drawing and design skills from a large scope of art genres. In drawing and painting students are encouraged to use symbolic themes within their work to create deeper meaning.. In advanced art, the goal is to prepare students to work professionally for future study of art after high school and to develop their own artistic voice. Students of all grade levels receive additional support at the art club offered twice a week. The College Academy’s music department is a campus-wide music program has begun in earnest with the establishment of the George Washington Band. Students learn the fundamentals of music performance through playing a wind instrument with a large group of other musicians. Students learn basic music theory and performance techniques in a collaborative environment, and perform as a group 3-5 times a year. Our ultimate goal at GW is to build a large, thriving music program with a variety of course selections and performance opportunities, and to create life-long enthusiasts, composers and performers of music.

Q44_R1_C1: Opus Dance Theatre & Community Services, Inc.
Q46_1: At the High School for Health Careers and Sciences, we offer a rigorous arts program. Currently we offer Studio in Arts and Graphic Design as well as AP Studio Art 2D. In our Studio Arts Class, students are given a foundation in the elements and principles of art. Students view, discuss and create paintings, drawings and mixed media art works. In Graphic Design, students are exposed to a Adobe System programs: PS6 and Illustrator, as well as IMovie. In the AP Studio Art 2D course, the students develop their own portfolios with any medium or tools they choose. In the Concert Band classes, students are provided opportunities to learn foundation skills in instrumental music with brass instruments. In addition, students are given the opportunity to explore the arts in museums, film, view Broadway and Off-Broadway shows and to visit colleges with art programs.

Our goals remain as stated in the description 2016-2017. The Music program continues the membership to the Little Kids Rock organization and monthly professional development sessions are attended by the music teacher. PreK- Grades 1 participate in ORFF based song games and instrument work . Grades 2 &3 participate in a ukulele curriculum and the Grades 4/5 classes participate in Modern Band.  Grades 2-5 attended three in-house jazz Presentations by Jazz in at Lincoln Center.  Grades 4/5 completed an inhouse workshop with members of the metropolitan opera chorus and the Met Opera chorus singers presented an opera ambush in our weekly community sing.  An off-site opera was attended by  the Choir 3. The K/1 classes attended two presentations by classical music ensemble.  Two music concerts have been staged in the evening, and the samba band participated in a community arts festival in the United Palace theatre.  The visual arts program is provided by a teacher from the Scribble Workshop.
Q47_1: Our School is a dual language inclusive program.  We identify a minimum 10% if seats for children affected by incarceration and all classrooms are ICT.  We have an extended day arts based a\Afterschool program that is served by staff from within the school and additional staff from the community.  Our Afterschool program is band, samba, dance and visual arts adn is taught entirely in Spanish.

Q46_1: Our school's mission is to prepare our students to become life-long learners by providing an enriched environment that promotes academic rigor through a standards-based curriculum while fostering a love, respect, and an appreciation for the arts. All of our students actively participate in a Visual Arts and Dance program during the school day. In addition, there are numerous opportunities to participate in Dance, Music, and the Arts during our afte school hours through our rich collaborations with the Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre and Urban Arts Partnership

We offer the Music and Art courses that are required for graduation. We also augment our arts programming through our after school programs. Sound Business Institute is our CBO, and they run after school Dance and Step club at our school. This year, the Atlantic Theater Company worked with our students 2 days a week for 6 weeks. Students engaged in a literacy project and re-wrote a portion of a play. Also, Creative Art Works offers a credited art class after school for our students.

Gregorio Luperón High School for Science and Mathematics opened in 1994 as the first school in Washington Heights to serve newly arrived immigrant Latino students. GLHS provides the avenue that enables students to explore the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics throughout four years of high school. We prepare our students to achieve high standards of scholarship and equip them with the necessary skills to be successful in their college and professional careers. We enforce strong community ties that allow our students to become successful leaders with integrity, solidarity and excellence. Our music teacher is part of a community based organization called The Washington Heights Community Conservatory of Fine Arts which prepares children from the community to become masters of the arts and be part of an orchestra.  We serve students in music classes, orchestra/band classes, and A.P. Music classes.  They also receive services from experts in the music fields and private music lessons on a daily basis, even on Saturdays.

Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our school offers Arts education in four main areas: Dance, Drama, Music, and Visual Arts. As in previous years, we have continued to expand our Arts programs, thus increasing the number of students participating and being serviced at our school. We have also expanded our Bronx Arts Ensemble (BAE) program to include two additional performance where our students perform with professional musicians at the school.  In addition this year the Little Orchestra Society will work with kindergarten as well as second grade students.

At PS / MS5x, students are artists and musicians.  Students create and perform while adopting real life art making practices.  They expand their expressive capabilities, gain domain specific vocabulary and make connections between the art they make, the art made by others and the world around them.

School’s Arts Program Description 2017-2018
(To be published in Arts Report)
We offer a rigorous art program designed after top NYC arts schools. The students participate in a studio arts type curriculum based strongly on NYC Common Core Standards as well as NY State and the NYC DOE's Blueprint arts criteria. The Arts curriculum implemented not only by the arts teachers but also by the classroom teachers helps provide a solid arts foundation. We promote the integration of the arts into our curriculum in all subject areas including Math and Science. Our students are exposed to various arts genres during classroom activities, residencies, and through the incorporation of trips to various cultural organizations. We are a school focused on college readiness and our arts program reflects our expectations as well as our goals for our students' futures.

The Wilton School continues to engage students and integrate the Arts into content areas. Our Arts Program consists of a Glee Club, upper-grades Dance Group and African Drumming. We also partner with New Victory Theater & Studio-in-a-School for visual arts and dance to support our English language learners. Students are able to cultivate a deeper understanding of different cultures as they explore world music and other expressions of performing arts. We believe the Arts to be at the core of our curriculum, enhancing the potential of contiguous exploration of various mediums of self expression. As a school community, our staff bands together in support of the arts. Due to budget constraints, several teachers volunteer their time to conduct various art programs before and after school. We look forward in securing any grant monies available to expand our current art program to include visual art and musical programs for all students. We believe that the Arts help students to make basic connections between curriculum and practical text-to-self applications. Our past partnership with the Morgan Library’s Book Project continues to inspire our upper grade students in the production of their own personal narratives in the literary genre of the illuminated manuscripts. Students learn how primary colors for the manuscripts were obtained (maintained in an ink garden) and how we can duplicate similar methods today to obtain our own colors for illustrating. We believe heavily in the arts and seek monies to invest in other programs.
Q47_1:
We service the poorest congressional district in the nation. Situated in the heart of the South Bronx neighborhood of Mott Haven our overall population is predominantly comprised of English language learners. We have observed that our Arts clubs have decreased the rate of violent incidents in the school to a bare minimum. We desperately need the Arts. Through the Arts students are able to make basic text-to-self connections that assure their academic success and save lives.

In continuance of our embrace and provision of arts related programs and services to our student body we also have teachers trained and implementing the Visual Thinking Strategies program. PS 30 continues to engage the entire student body via during a weekly Club Hour program featuring Visual Arts, Glee, Performing Arts, Book Making, Photography, Cheerleading and Dance programs. Teachers on every grade also prepare programs for monthly thematic assemblies via musical, choral and dramatic performances. The Arts continue to be at the center of our core curriculum. We will continue to form partnerships with cultural and community organizations that specialize in bringing the arts in their varying forms to all of our students as well as securing private funding to ensure the continuation of many of our programs.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Anne Frank Center for Mutual Respect
Q46_1: Our goal for the 2017-18 school year is to help our students become critical thinkers by using the Arts in their academic and daily lives, making them college and career ready for the 21st century. The Arts integrate and support all the core subject areas such as Math, Reading, Social Studies and Science. We also used the Arts to improve student motivation, self-esteem, cognitive skills and verbal skills through the different programs that we have in our school, such as: the Education Through Music, Anne Frank Center, and through our teachers who follow the Blueprint for the Arts. Our newest art program,The Visual Thinking Strategies, is designed to expose students to different art works-the students connect to that work and express their opinions and build social awareness. Our goal for the upcoming school year is to enhance and support our students' and teachers' knowledge of the arts.

P.S. 49 is committed to providing a rigorous, well rounded, quality education for all students. The Arts are an integral part of accomplishing that mission. A comprehensive education draws upon the expertise of both Arts specialists and classroom teachers. It is our belief that the integration of arts throughout the curriculum areas serves to enhance and reinforce student learning as well as support the Common Core State Standards. It enables students to better organize, retain and explain information as well as understand the relationship between concepts and skills across curriculum areas. P.S. 49 is using Standards-based curriculum to provide a comprehensive approach in educating students to critically evaluate the world and reflect on the common bonds between literature, the arts and sciences.

Our school's Arts Program is aligned with the requirements dictated by the Blueprint for the Arts, Danielson’s Framework for Teaching, English Language Arts, and the Mathematical Common Core Standards.
