Our goals are to create high standards for each student in our school and create a school environment that strongly supports the arts as an essential substance for child development. We provide rigorous Standard-based arts instruction that will contribute to our students’ college readiness. Our students are introduced to and given all the tools necessary to perform on a keyboard, read notes, and learn about the history of music in America and around the World. Students’ work is featured in our concerts and recitals throughout the school year, where they are encouraged to perform using multiple forms of art such as Theater, Drama and Dance. We will continue working closely with our nonprofit organization partners such as: African Drums, Music and the Brain and the Afro-Latin Jazz Academy.  We are currently seeking additional partnership with Bronx Assemble to further enrich the lives of our students through dramatic play in the arts.

At M.S. 151, the students will: (1)develop an appreciation of the arts and gain confidence in creative self-expression; (2) acquire knowledge of global cultures and be exposed to diverse art forms; (3) develop an understanding of the creative process through experiential inquiry-based learning (4) be given the opportunity to participate/engage in meaningful art experiences; (5) be able to analyze and interpret art using specific language/vocabulary; (6) create works of art on an appropriate level of artistic proficiency ;(7) become cognizant of career opportunities that are art-related. All these are in keeping with all the Learning Standards for the Arts on the Intermediate Level and the NYC Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts that provide a Standards-based, rigorous approach to teaching the Arts. The school's Art program is also in alignment to The National Core Arts Standards to enable arts providers to establish best practices across the education field that will best serve students while complementing national and state standards for education. They are also in alignment with one of the school's goals, which is to integrate discussion and literacy into all disciplines, including the arts, and to integrate the arts into all other disciplines.
Q47_1: At M.S. we educate all students with no screening process for admission in the arts and academics. We believe that when students are given the opportunity for creative expression, increased student achievement follows.

Q46_1: The Arts at P.S. 154x currently consists of a full-time visual arts teacher and a full-time dance teacher. Both teachers are certified and teach a full program. During our Expanded Day programming, students also receive theatre and music instruction. Our Arts programs work together to provide two performances a year which incorporate Set Design, Dance and musical theatre. This year's musicals were Moana and Grease.  This year we engaged in our fourth year of a four year grant with Studio in a School. The Expanding the Frame (ETF) program serviced our 5th graders during the 2017 - 2018 school year. Through this collaboration, the students received additional integrated arts instruction. Studio in a School also holds 'Community Arts Nights' that engage our parents and community in art-making. For the fourth year in a row, Choate Rosemary Hall visited our school to engage selected classes in Vocal/Orchestral music. The residency ended with a performance by the students for the entire school.  Finally, P.S. 154 engaged in a mural painting project onsite, guided by a local street artist.

The art program at P.S.157 is based on the New York City Department of Education's Blueprint for Curricula in the Arts. Along with a determination to provide every child with a strong academic foundation, it is our belief that students should be nurtured in the Visual and Performing Arts.Therefore, we offer our students Art Appreciation programs in Music as well as Visual Art. We are convinced that our commitment, sincerity of purpose, and dedication to the needs and interest of children( which includes the visual and performing arts), will enable us to provide an atmosphere saturated with enrichment and achievement that will prepare our students for the next steps in their educational and cultural journeys. In 2017-2018, our Arts Program emphasizes enrichment in Music Education for the early grades (PreK-2), and in Visual Arts for the grade 3, 4, and 5. Most of the classroom teachers include visual art in their regular curriculum. We offer pull-out instructions for Strings and Little Kids Rock (5th Grade Rock Band) during the school hours and also we offer after school programs for Chorus(Grade 3,4, 5), HIP Hop Dancing/Ballet and Visual Arts in addition to other programs such as Oratory (Circle of Gold), Basketball.

The 2017-2018 school year found the P.S. 161X arts department diving deeper into cultural relevancy to creating multiple pathways for building intellective capacity to support our dependent learners.  We implemented an arts grant writing campaign that has yeilded funding to provide script-writing and storytelling units to our upper-grade general education and integrated co-teaching classrooms through the Shubert Arts Partnership.  Grant funding also increased wind ensemble instructors, allowing for more targeted instruction and deeper connections between what is happening in the music day program and increasing mastery in after school wind ensemble.  Matching funds through Lincoln Center Education brought a vibrant visual arts and theater program to our dual language 2nd-5th grade students.  The music teacher and LCE teaching artist worked together throughout the year with the students focusing on how the arts can support language acquisition.  Inquiry findings will be shared with all 1st-5th grade teachers in order for them to understand the Aesthetic Education Framework and LCE Capacities that students are using across arts disciplines.  Our music teacher and our students have an established rapport and understanding of rituals and routines that prioritizes students’ well-being and sense of safety.  From PK3 to 5th grade, she stresses the importance of the ensemble for students to have a sense of belonging and realize their sense of agency as stakeholders within the class.
Q48_2: PK3-5th Grade Music Teacher/Arts Education Liaison

Q46_1: PS 179 is a 3K  to Grade 5 school. Our goal for our Arts Program is to provide all students with a variety of arts experiences;these experiences will help students to recognize how the Arts play an integral part in their daily lives. All students visit museums to study exhibits connected to their visual arts curriculum, attend theater, learn about and perform music and choreograph and perform their own dances that are aligned with the Social Studies curriculum

South Bronx Preparatory (SBP) Art Program has an interdisciplinary focus geared toward self discovery and promoting identity awareness. This year, the focus has included implementing Common Core Learning as we continue to build literacy through the Arts. This year SBP partnered with Lincoln Center Education to increase our Arts in the middle school-the results were phenomenal! That partnership helped us boost parental involvement, provide 'Family Nights' at SBP with live performances, boost critical thinking skills and intellectual struggle inside the classrooms, implement a 'Capacity for Imaginative Thinking Focus' and ' Notice Deeply', celebrate student work by strategically showcasing in the hallway, and transition Arts into our History curricula.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: The Laboratory School of Finance and Technology provides quality Arts instruction for all of our student body. We expose our students to at least three Arts disciplines: Theater for 6th grade, Theater for 7th grade and Visual Art for 8th grade. Our teachers continually strive to reinforce literacy skills as well as a true appreciation for the Arts; we believe that the Arts create a path to expression that might not have been an option to every student in our community. To create greater pride in their work, we have art celebrations( such as gallery showings), and culminating performances in Music, Dance and Theater. We are proud to put on an annual production through Broadway Jr. and offer Arts programming during the expanded day as well as in the summer. We also go out to attend performances and bring in performers to encourage young consumers of art.

Our school has a robust Arts Program that is improving rapidly. We have a full time Visual Arts teacher and dance and music through teaching artists from CBOs, additionally we hire a Dance consultant to work with each grade intensively for 6 week intervals. We also have Technology teacher that has a Mixed Media Visual Arts Club in which students create a newspaper, documentaries and public service announcements, the yearbook and more. The sixth grade participates in Visual Arts for one semester and Music for one semester, then they choose a major that they continue with for seventh and eighth grade. Our artists use pencil, charcoal, paints, paper sculpture and clay to create amazing artwork. Our musicians learn keyboards and or guitar in addition to using their voices or learning to play an instrument. Our Chorus was selected as a finalist to sing the "National Anthem" at Madison Square Garden. We also created our own school school borrowing the melody from an established song, but rewriting the words-this is sung at every assembly. Understanding the need for our students to move more, we brought a dancer in to teach our students the magic of motion-they are using 'Body Action, Space, Time and Energy' (BASTE) to choreograph their own dances.

HERO High School offers students a comprehensive range of Arts electives: Visual Arts, Music, and Dance, which incorporate the NYS Learning Standards for the Arts as well as support the socio-emotional growth of our students. Afterschool programs include a Visual Art Club, Chorus, and the Cypher Hip Hop and Spoken Word Club. Ninth grade students wrote and performed an original play at the NYC Student Shakespeare Festival. This endeavor was assisted by the Creative Arts Team (CAT) workshops (comprised of ninth and tenth grade students), which meet twice a week after school at HERO

Q44_R2: Caribbean Cultural Center - Visual Arts/Visual Arts Research & Res Ctr.
Q46_1: The PS 277 school community continues to do our very best to provide our scholars with as many arts-related experiences as we can.  In terms of our in-school instruction, we have a dedicated music instructor whose instruction with our scholars covers: reading music, writing music, playing instruments, singing, and performing. We have several partnerships, one funded by both school funds and grant monies, as well as several which are solely funded by grant monies.  Our grant-based partnerships have  allowed our scholars to work with teaching artists in drama, dance and music.  We are very grateful to  the organizations we have worked with this year, they have afforded our scholars opportunities they would otherwise not have had. As we have stated in prior years, we strongly believe that arts instruction must be an integral component of every child's primary education.

At the South Bronx Academy for Applied Media (SBAAM), we empower scholars by enriching their minds and illuminating their voices.  The arts is an excellent platform to realize this vision.  This academic year, 100% of our scholars receive a full year of Theater instruction.  We are proud of the fact that we have sustained partnerships with several cultural organizations over many years. All of the organizations complement each other and we are able to provide multiple art opportunities for our scholars.  We are looking forward to year three of Broadway Junior with enthusiasm.

With limited funding and resources, the Academy of Public Relations has implemented the following Arts Programs: Spoken Word,Hip-Hop/Step Dance, Video Journalism, and Visual Arts. Our afterschool programs included: Mural Painting, African and Latin Dance, and Drama. Through creative budgeting, we were able to provide Visual Arts and Theater to ALL of our students throughout the school year for the first time in 4 years(!). All subject area teachers are encouraged to incorporate art into their assignments and/or projects when applicable, and the school has purchased the necessary art supplies to support this. Students' artwork is proudly displayed throughout the hallways during the school year. 
Our new residency program includes Bridge Building, Garage Band and Digital Architecture. This was a 10 week program offered to each grade.

Q32_6: Arts and Culture Education Services Fair
Q46_1: At International Community High School, the arts present an additional opportunity for recent immigrant teens to further develop social and academic English language skills.  We partner with Bronx Arts Ensemble to provide the following classes twice a week: Hip Hop, Yoga, Capoeira, Percussion and Karate.  Afro-Caribbean dance is also offered through Bombazo Inc.  A school wide assembly takes placed twice a year in December and June in which we invite families and members of our community at large to see the students put on a performance showcasing all they have learned during the school year.  Our students also participate in a theater class which culminates in a play put on by our students in collaboration with Repertorio Espanol.  In addition, our students also participate in studio arts and mixed media arts classes during the week, and attend special arts events and trips throughout New York City.  A few selected students also attend arts classes (once a week) and silk screening classes (three times a week) offered in conjunction with Aspira through the Yuca Arts program.

M.S. 343 (7X343) has partnered with Creative Connections to provide a comprehensive Arts program both during the school day and two days a week after school; the program consists of Music, Visual Art, and Dance. All three disciplines are taught by professional artists hired by Creative Connections, and two of the artists have worked with the school for over eight years building a strong rapport with both staff and students. Each student will receive a full year in each of the three disciplines: by the time they graduate from 8th grade they will have completed three comprehensive Arts programs. The goal is to create awareness in different disciplines so that our students can make informed decisions about the arts in the future. The Arts program is connected to the work being done in the other Core classes to enhance both the enjoyment and their understanding of needed concepts and ideas.

Q47_1:
Art is a diverse range of human activities in creating visual, auditory or performing artifacts (artworks), expressing the author's imaginative or technical skill, intended to be appreciated for their beauty or emotional power.  

We believe the arts program is critical to a child's academic and personal success. Our Visual Arts specialist works closely with the classroom teachers to design curriculum experiences that support the learning continuum. 

Our visual arts program encompasses: 
High expectations for all students
A myriad of appropriate teaching methods and materials
A supportive, cooperative and nurturing environment
Curriculum guided by students' interests

Q44_R3: Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
Q46_1:
We are planning to apply for several ARTS grant and couple our efforts with several community ARTS providers in an effort to bring artistic diversity to our students in forms that are culturally relevant. Each partnership will also focus on career development so that our students have post-secondary options in their plans. 
As part of an initiative to expose our students to 21st century forms of art, it is crucial to provide many forms of Digital arts opportunities related to film, desktop-publishing, and other forms of arts through the cyber world medium. Much as we did in SY 17/18, we will continue to hold 3 annual ARTS FESTivals (November, March & June)as a showcase opportunity to celebrate student achievement and to cultivate better relationships and communication with families.
Q47_1: We are a transfer school with over-aged and under-credited students. We don't currently have a full time ARTS licensed teacher. Instead, we embarked on ARTS partnerships with many DOE approved community Arts organizations to provide ARTS programming that is diverse, out of the box, connected to career opportunities and engaging.

Q46_1: Students participated in digital media projects where they were able to write and make a movie with their peers. Students also participated in visual arts opportunities.

The Visual Arts Program explores numerous dimensions of the visual arts, examines cultural, historical, and personal reasons for making art, and seeks ways in which the visual arts can be applied to and bring about positive outcomes in the realm of social justice. Students develop skills and techniques relevant to the visual arts and learn how to use a variety of methods and materials;they learn to discuss, analyze and critique art in historical, cultural and personal context. CSSJ has a strong theatre collaboration with Manhattan Theatre Club (MTC) in which our theatre teacher co-plans and co-teaches a Playwriting unit with a theatre educator from MTC. In addition to learning about acting, improvisation and studying plays of different genres, students in this program see a current Broadway show and write their own one-act plays which are performed by professional actors from MTC.

The Arts Program at Mott Haven Village Preparatory High School includes visual arts, music, and theater.  

Visual arts incorporate movements in art history, famous artists from those movements, elements of art, and principles of design. Throughout the units of study, the students complete writing assignments, interpret and analyze artwork, participate in gallery walk activities and self/peer critiques. Our students produce work in areas such as, but not limited to: drawing, painting, and sculpture. 

In music class the students are taught the basics of instruments including guitar, piano, and drums. They are also taught the beginning of music theory. 

Theater 1 and 2 classes teach the basics of theater including performance and parts of stage design. Students learn theater history, play analysis, and musical analysis. There are also units that concentrate on acting such as monologue and scene work. Classes are sometimes held in the auditorium.

All students take Music in 10th grade and are able to take an elective course in Advanced Music. In addition, students are offered Painting, Drawing and Graphic Art classes through CUNY. Students are also offered multiple opportunities to attend Broadway plays and concerts. There are a minimum of 6 performances in our school, including 2 Concerts, 2 Theatre performances and 1 Spoken-word performance. We provide interdisciplinary courses that include Art and Literacy (Yearbook and 'What is Art?'). As a performance-based assessment school, most Core classes also include an art component in the curriculum to ensure that students have various venues of expression and creativity. Additionally, we partner with CUNY to provide an opportunity for our students to learn theater and perform at the Shakespeare Festival.

As a 6th-12th grade secondary early college school, our Arts Program focuses on the Visual and Theater Arts. We have an extensive, award-winning creative writing program that we use to fuel our Drama program. We have many outside agencies providing arts support through in-school and afterschool programs. In addition, our students take college classes in the arts. The emphasis is on pushing students to explore and reach beyond their preconceived limitations.

We currently offer Blueprint Reading and Writing for students enrolled in our construction trades, and have an extensive Architecture Program. Additionally, we provide arts through cabinetry and manual drafting for students who are not in or Carpentry or Architecture programs. We also provide after school clubs, such as Arts Club, Carpentry Club and CAD.

The Visual and Performing Arts Department at BLA II allows students the opportunity to express themselves creatively. Students enrolled in our Visual Arts classes are exposed to a diverse range of subjects: Ceramics, Graphic Design, Murals, and multi-media Sculptures. Students can participate in at least one performance-based show before the end of each school year. These works of art and the stage performance are celebrated by students, their peers, and their families at our school's annual Talent Show, Awards Night (BLA II Bonanza), and project-specific exhibitions. Students may also participate in our Photography and Pottery after school classes provided by our visual arts teacher.

At the Urban Assembly School for Careers in Sports, all of our 9th graders are required to take a Visual Art class where they create paintings, sketches and masks. Our students in grades 9-12 also have the opportunity to participate in other arts-related activities such as Theatre presentations, Spoken-word evenings, and Script and Novel writing.

We offer Visual Art, Film, Dance, Musical Theater, Drama, and Mixed Media courses to students in grades 6-12; our Arts sequence include both introductory and advanced courses. Students in our Arts courses exhibit their work in Art shows, perform in Dance and Music Concerts, host and contribute to gallery exhibitions, publish written works in our literary magazine, and perform in a full theater productions each year.

Health Opportunities High School provides students with the opportunity to take Dance and Art elective classes in their regular schedule. Theater and journalism is given as an elective class and students receive an art credit for these classes. Liberty Partnership, a community-based organization, works with the school to provide our students with the opportunity to participate in Digital Photography and Art Therapy.Students' work are presented at an Art Exhibition at Hostos Community College as well as in our school's lobby area. Students have the opportunity to participate in music by joining the school Chorus are taking chorus during the school day as an elective arts credit. Students from these classes make up the choir and they sing at on and off-site school functions.Each year the school hosts its annual "Fashion, Talent and Lip Sync Show", which have students participating in modeling, dancing,poetry, drama and music. This year students had the opportunity to participate in fashion textile by creating and designing different outfits and accessories such as handbags , hats and accessories. Students participated in Patchwork Creation, Embroidery, Knitting, Painting, Drawing and Design. We are committed to developing students academically by giving them a solid foundation in Arts education, which prepares them for college/career and create a well-rounded individual as well.
Q47_1: We are unfunded and need additional financial assistance to help us provide more art opportunities for our students.

Q44_R4: Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture
Q46_1: Senator John D. Calandra School’s Arts programming is limited, due to budget constraints. In 2017-2018, the full time Visual Arts certified teacher taught 25 classes in grades K- 5 for 45 minutes once a week. Grade 2 received music instruction through ArtsConnection. Inside Broadway provided Theater instruction for students in grades 3. 4th grade students studied Dance with Dancing Classrooms. Students attended trips and participated in after school programs that related to music, theater, visual arts and media. Our goal for the future is to increase our arts programming to create a more well-rounded arts education, if budgeting allows.
Q47_1: Carly Ayala, our community school director, has implemented arts programming during the school day and after school. Grades K-5 received instruction through programming from the Salvadori Center. While the description of the program relates to Math and Science, it had an arts component where students used clay to create sculptures. Our school is currently undergoing expansion. We are looking forward to the installation of a mural by Sandy Litchfield in the main lobby. Since the status of our school is currently not Title 1, we rely on funding from outside sources, especially through our local politicians. While we cannot predict the future, we can hope that once the expansion is open, arts funding may increase.

Q46_1: The Arts Teachers collaborated to develop and to prepare performance programs based on curricular themes. Grade 4 wrote and performed an original drama based on the book, Tiger Rising by Kate DiCamillo. The Kindergarten presented a review of music and art concepts covered in class. Three students displayed their art in public exhibitions; one at the Bronx Borough Festival and two at P.S. Art. The Art teacher and two ENL teachers were awarded an Arts Partnership Grant to fund two sessions of an after school arts club for ENL students with input from the Lehman College Arts Dept. Grades K, 1 and 2 followed the Music and the Brain keyboard curriculum. The fourth and fifth grade choruses performed in concert for their parents and peers. Select fourth graders were guest performers at the MEANYC(Music Educators' Assoc.)Honoree Dinner in mid-April. The Art and Music teachers served as facilitators in planning meetings of professional learning in their respective mediums.

Our goal is to provide a safe haven where budding artists can explore their creativity in various art forms in a creative and innovative environment. We have a Band program for fifth graders and Chorus for 4th and 5th grade. From kindergarten through fifth, every student receives a complete music education, while visual arts education is provided for a portion of the population including Pre-kindergarten. Our music program has ben nationally recognized,and our music teacher has been a semi-finalist for the Grammy Music Educator Award as well as being named one of the 25 "Bronx Influential Women".
Q47_1: Our goal is to provide a safe haven where budding artists can explore their creativity in various art forms in a creative and innovative environment. We have a Band program for fifth graders and Chorus for 4th and 5th grade. From kindergarten through fifth, every student receives a complete music education, while visual arts education is provided for a portion of the population including Pre-kindergarten. Our music program has ben nationally recognized,and our music teacher has been a semi-finalist for the Grammy Music Educator Award as well as being named one of the 25 "Bronx Influential Women".

Q46_1:
During the 2017-2018 school year, we provided two Visual Arts Teachers so that all Pre-K -5 students could participate in Visual Arts. The students produced weekly projects which included: mosaics, watercolors, finger painting, sketches and drawings. 
The Visual Arts teachers worked in collaboration with the classroom teachers to support the curriculums and monthly assemblies. 
STARRS Artist collaborated with the third grade teachers to teach support the dramatization of the Peter Pan Unit. 
Teachers and students from K-5 took part in the New York Historical Society Residences in Art History and Enrichment to enhance the social studies curriculum. Monthly Award assemblies were held and 703 students had the opportunity to perform for their peers, teachers and parents during the school year. The Visual Arts teachers entered four art pieces in the Bronx Art Festival and all were selected and exhibited at Lehman College.  During the yearly "Spring Fling", all "Buddies Not Bullies Partner classes K-5 had the opportunity to participate in: Art:mask-making, Dance, Yoga,  Moving to the Music, Science experiments and Outdoor Races and Games. In addition the  Ned Show presented on Character Education for all students Pre-K-5 and their teachers. The final rotation of the day was A Visual Arts Museum. Students, teachers and  parents were able to view Visual Arts pieces of student art work produced throughout the year from grades Pre-K-5.

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: We provide arts integration within the Pre K - 5 curriculum through Inquiry, Exploration and Discovery. Both classroom teachers and certified Arts teacher provide experiences for students to use the arts as a catalyst for learning. Through collaboration and articulation, teachers create performance tasks culminating in involving multiple-content disciplines and new grants have allowed Arts to positively affect content area in the after school program.  Our many partnerships with other organization have helped us strengthen and maintain our focus on the arts. Organizations include: American Ballroom Dancing, NY Botanical Garden, Young People's Chorus, LeAp, Bronx Arts Ensemble and Ballet Hispanico.
Q47_1: We are a campus school across three buildings.

Q46_1: Our school currently has one part-time Art teacher servicing students from K-5. Our students work on projects that are aligned with the CCLS in collaboration with classroom teachers. Our students have also had Music integrated into the school curriculum through the Education Through Music Program (ETM): students in grades K-5 receive general Music instruction, 5th grade students have the option to participate in small group instrumental lessons and a school Band, 4th and 5th grade students can participate in Chorus. The goal of ETM is to provide students with the opportunity to have music in school as it helps develop a well-rounded student. Grade 4 students participate in Dancing Classrooms, where they learn social etiquette through the following dances: Foxtrot, Tango, Swing, Salsa, and Merengue. Working in partnership with the OST afterschool program, Inside Broadway coordinates a Theater program with an artist in residence.

In our school all Arts are taught through Literacy. PreK-5 are scheduled for Visual Arts. Our school participates in cultural arts field trips and programs such as: Disney on Broadway and Lehman College Art Gallery. Our goal is to improve participation, technical knowledge and appreciation for the arts in every grade level. Our classroom teachers and residence artists complement Arts education by including the arts in special projects and performances throughout the year. Our teachers' lessons are based on the standards set forth by the Blueprint for the Arts and the Common Core Standards. Funding is key in order to maintain and expand these programs. To this effect,PS 75-the School for Research and Discovery, will continue its fundraising efforts to support our students' exposure to the arts outside of our school.

Arts programming is offered to all of our students. Many different periods of Art History are covered, as well as famous artists and their works. West African Art has been incorporated with a literacy component.

At the Isaac Clason School, we recognize the importance of integrating Arts instruction into all curriculum areas in order to motivate students to take greater ownership of their learning. Many of our students participate in our Spring Musical and our Spring Choral Concert. This year, we continued to participate in Little Kids Rock program which donated instruments to play modern Band music. We also received a grant from CASA/ Inside Broadway which allowed many children to perform and learn from an artist-in-residence; it also provided the school two opportunities to attend a Broadway show.

Q44_R2: Music for Many IncBravo Broadway Dance
Q46_1: P.S. 119's goal is to provide Arts instruction that facilitates self-expression and builds community spirit. Students are offered opportunities in all of the arts during our regular school day, weekday, and after school programs (Next Jump and Bekin). We also have engage in the arts in our morning and Saturday ENL programs. We have one dedicated Music and one Theatre Arts teacher on staff. They are complemented by Resident Artists in Dance, Music, and Visual Arts.We have supplementary funds through Project Boost to attend field trips to art institutions that provide varied learning opportunities to all students at PS 119. Smartboards enable teachers to integrate the arts and technology.  We celebrate our diverse cultures through the Performing and Visual Arts with annual festivities such as: Holiday Music Concerts; Art Shows; and Talent Shows . Our Science Fair showcases student work demonstrating a rigorous integration of Science, Technology,Social Studies and Visual Arts. Social Studies instruction includes an appreciation of the Arts in each of the civilizations and cultures studied  Relationships with Dancing Classrooms, Smartworks, Music for Many, and New York Historical Society have evolved over the years to permeate teaching practices.
Q47_1: Our Annual International Festival features student performers in music and dance performing traditional songs and dances from Central and South America, the Caribbean, Bangladesh and Pakistan, and Yemen and Algeria.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Henry Hudson Intermediate School 125’s Visual Arts Course is designed to introduce the students to the basic elements and principles of design. Students will have an opportunity to develop their own creative potential through thoughtfully designed projects.They will be given Art History and cultural instruction, including demonstrations and projects using various media to enhance aesthetic growth. The projects students undertake will provide a comprehensive series of experiences aimed at developing technical skills, fortifying an understanding of design, developing appropriate and fundamental Art vocabulary and encouraging individual artistic expression. The goal for each art student is to create their best work and develop a true appreciation for the arts. When creating the interdisciplinary lessons, the following NYS Art Standards and the NYC DOE Arts Education Blueprint, ELA and Math CCLS were incorporated into the units to provide support to these departments.

The Arts contribute to our quality education; it is an instrumental component that enriches the schools academic curriculum. Here at P.S. 130, arts experiences are embedded into lessons presented by ALL our educators. Our Visual Arts Teacher regularly services 24 classes and on occasion, five additional ones. Our intention for next years Arts program is to continue the work begun this year and expand by collaborating with in-house cultural partnerships and organizations. Additionally, we would like to further encourage and expose our students and extended families to our cities great visual, music, theater, and dance resources in the arts.

At IS 131, we have continued with our vision for the Arts by establishing a three year program for our Arts majors; Dance, Instrumental, and Fine Arts. All students select an Arts major as 6th graders and continue with their chosen major through the 8th grade. Our students are offered an intensive program that develops their art skills, introduces them to Art History and fosters a lifelong appreciation for the arts throughout each discipline. Our staff members are available to work with any student who decides to apply to a High School that specializes in the arts by offering assistance with auditions and/or portfolios. Our halls are festooned with the artwork of our students and we conduct concerts throughout the year celebrating our dance and instrumental programs. This year we have established partnerships with Broadway Jr., The Joyce Theater, and the New York Historical Society as a means of providing our students with other venues to experience the Arts in their lives as well as beyond the classroom. At Albert Einstein Intermediate School 131, "We Celebrate the ARTS!!!

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q44_R2: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q44_R3: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: PS 138 has in class art lesson which incorporates the 4r's curriculum and common core curriculum.  The Society of the Educational Arts has been working with our school community through funding from the NYC Council members and Artcounts grants.  Classroom  teachers have participated in various performances in the classroom, school community and local Senior Citizen center.

Although our diverse Arts experience at P.S.140 is designed, with the aid of the Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts as a guide to be rigorous, it also enables each child to understand, appreciate and enjoy the arts in a non-threatening environment. We are unwaveringly encouraging our students to take risks and to believe in themselves as the tools to reach their full potential. 

Being cognizant that the route to success is multi-faceted, we try to immerse our students in meaningful art experiences by infusing other disciplines into art lessons, exposing them to our Artist in residence, providing museum trip, displaying the works of ‘Old Masters’ in our hallways, and inviting parents to participate in our in-house art exhibitions and theatrical performances. They also take ownership of our art endeavors by playing significant roles, via in-house art competitions, in designing programs and posters/flyers, decorating for in-house events, and assisting in curating in-house exhibitions, all of which we plan on increasing.
 
It is our resolute belief that this holistic approach, by addressing their physical, intellectual, emotional and social well-being, will enhance their academic abilities and increase their level of exploration and discovery as they climb the educational ladder and beyond. Moreover, it is instrumental in highlighting the various art-related opportunities available, and also to foster a lasting appreciation for the arts, whether as an artist, future audience member, or a patron.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
The Evergreen School's Arts program is an integrated curriculum component in the daily life of our students. The curriculum is broken down into units by grade level; these units are based on the standards and benchmarks provided by the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. Additionally, all Arts teachers are integrating the Core Curriculum Standards as well as New York State Arts Standards. Instrumental Band is taught by a certified teacher. We value the Arts in our school and believe that we are privileged to have these wonderful programs. We also have a very significant Visual Arts program provided by LeAp that services the entire school.
In the future, the school seeks to develop a film studies program.
Q47_1: The students are attuned to their artistic development..The Evergreen Arts led by the administration seeks to model arts conservatory education within the context of an elementary schedule.

Q44_R3: Mount Vernon Hotel Museum and Garden
Q46_1: Our school strives to provide high quality, comprehensive, sequential skills-based direct instruction to all K-5 students in the Arts that enhances students' academic growth and general development. The school's Arts Programs address the five strands of Arts learning: Arts Making, Literacy in the Arts, Making Connections, Community and Cultural Resources, and Careers and Lifelong Learning. Instructional content is grade-specific and developmentally appropriate. The school has long lasting relationships with external Arts organizations who help support the school's goal to provide students with a wide and deep arts education. Students are provided with multiple opportunities to perform and display their artistic talents for the school community during the school year.

The arts program at the Bronx Studio School for Writers and Artists is one that is designed to expose students to a broad range of art disciplines. Students have the opportunity to engage in Visual Arts, which includes Mixed Media and 3D Sculpture; Dance, Afro-Latin Jazz, and Theater, which includes Costume Design, Intro to Theater, and Moving Image. Students also audition for the annual fall drama production and spring musical that engages students in all areas of theater, including acting, set design, stage management, and lighting. The year ends with a culminating ArtsFest where the entire school community celebrates the many areas of the arts by hosting teacher and student led workshops, which includes an improve showcase, sneaker painting workshop, t-shirt making, and a wide variety of other activities. 
Our goal for next year is to expand the arts program into the afterschool space where students can specialize in their area of interest. 
Another goal is to expand the arts into the middle school so that students will be able to specialize at an earlier age and become more competitive by the time they reach high school in order to advance to local and national competitions.

This school year we were able to continue our music instruction on a full time basis. The goal for the 2018-2019 school year is to include arts instruction (i.e. visual arts, drama).  We are also looking to re-introduce the Music Unites Guitar and Choir Programs to the students.
Q47_1: NA

Q46_1: Renaissance High School offers courses in Vocal music, Instrumental music, Theater and Visual Arts. RHS produces a variety of shows from plays to cabaret to fully staged musicals. RHS has a Beginning, Advanced and Jazz Band, a Beginning and Advanced Choir, and an Advanced Acting ensemble known as the Renaissance Players, all of whom perform at the Winter and Spring Concerts as well as many events throughout the local community and the greater New York City area.  The Visual Arts program showcases work through semi-annual galleries, at the concerts and other events in the NYC area.
Q47_1: There are currently no audition requirements to apply for the school or any of the classes in the Arts program.  Students fill out a survey to list their preferences between art disciplines before the new semester begins.

Q46_1: Our school continues to provide Visual Arts to students in grades K-5 by a licensed fine arts teacher. In addition students in grades 3-5 get a variety of Arts applications via our SEM Renzulli Cluster program. We have a full time Music teacher providing instruction in grades K-5. We have an Instrumental Band program for grades 4-5 and Recorders for grade 3. Inside Broadway is a professional theater company that works with grades PreK-5; each grade performs a culminating production based on a Broadway theme. Students learn the elements of Theater (Choreography, Voice, Drama) to give them a good foundation of how a Broadway production is put together. Every year the 4th and 5th graders go to a Broadway Show and also tour behind the scenes!  Finally, all our classroom teachers involve their students in the Arts through monthly grade-wide assembly performances. Culminating projects often include visual, musical or video 'share-outs' related to the topic of study. Students and teachers proudly display their work on bulletin boards throughout the building.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: MILLENNIUM ART ACADEMY HIGH SCHOOL offers Required Art Studio in both the 9th and 10th grade.The Studio courses follow a sequence beginning with Art Foundation; more advanced work is taught in the upper grades in line with other disciplines such as ELA and Global Studies. Upper grades are offered elective Art Portfolio, Honors Art, or AP Studio Art 2-D. , in which they excel in individual projects and develop their own personal style. We offer multiple CBO-sponsored after school clubs in the arts (visual art, theater, dance) for up to 6 hours per week. Students in the clubs engage in restorative justice practices in the curriculum.  Our students enter various city and community competitions, attend Arts programs outside the building as well, studying Photography, Film and other art forms. Our students receive scholarships to attend these programs.  Competitions we have won include National Scholastic Regional Gold and Silver Keys and Honorable Mentions, DOE PS Art, Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking Competition, DOE Bronx Borough Arts Festival, our local Congressional Art Competition, and Arts Connection.  Our students' artwork hangs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the US Capitol in Washington, DC, and other venues.
Q48_2: Arts Education Liason; Art Department chair; Visual Art Teacher; Peer Collaborative Teacher

Q46_1: Pelham Lab High School offers an interdisciplinary program in the Arts with an emphasis on Vocal Music. Vocal music is connected with the ELA curriculum and includes focused courses in vocal performance as well as piano.

The Arts program at HLR provides each student with an overview of Visual Arts and Instrumental music (Drums), including concept, technique, history, materials, and understanding of how artists and society have used art to express ideas, opinions and experiences. Students also gain an understanding of their own artworks, reviewing works by their peers and understanding historical cultural and social movements. Students will use both Digital Computer/Cameras, and traditional art-making methods such as Painting, Drawing,and Sculpture).  Students learned how to play the drums using various techniques often seen in a marching band.

In the 2017-2018 school year, P.S. 333X provided visual arts instruction with a full-time, certified arts teacher once a week to 25 of its Pre_Kindergarten through 5th grade students.  Visual arts instruction was aligned with the Department of Educations Blueprint for the Arts.  To fill gaps in art education fourth grade students received dance instruction in ballroom dancing with a teaching artist and our third through fifth graders had the opportunity to participate in musical theater instruction through our partnership with Disney Musicals in schools.  The culminating event will be a performance of the musical Aladdin.

Our classroom teachers are encouraged to and enjoy taking students on field trips to concerts, plays, and, musicals in order to enrich arts-based learning.  Our student community is comprised of students of various cultural backgrounds, ELLs, bilingual learners, and students who receive Hearing Education Services.  All students are included in arts education activities and we look forward to using our programs with arts partners to further our goals of creating a truly inclusive community.
We currently have one certified music teacher.  We are actively searching for an art teacher.

Schuylerville Preparatory High School has two visual arts teachers. We offer two mandatory courses: Studio Art and Art Portfolio. In addition to required courses, students also have a plethora of electives from which to choose, such as Upcycling, Art & Design, Art & Craft, and Mixed Media. Additionally, our art scholars apply their knowledge and skill set in a most practical way by designing murals and beautifying our school.
All students at The Bronx River High School are programmed for a rigorous, year-long Visual Arts sequence.

Students are exposed to Ballroom Dancing in the 6th grade and Latin Dance in the 7th grade (for one quarter, as part of their physical education). Students in 9th grade also spend one quarter with Latin Dance as part of their physical education program. We have a Cheer Stunt Team and an afterschool Dance Club provided through our Dance teacher. Through an Arts Matters Grant we were able to bring on a Theater and Dance teacher shared with another school so that we could offer all 4 Arts disciplines. Students spend 1 quarter in each of the 4 Arts disciplines (Art, Music, Dance and Theater)in the 6th grade and in the 8th grade.  In 7th grade they are exposed to one quarter each of 2 out of the 4 arts disciplines. Some students in grade 9 get their 2 arts credits, majority get at least 1 of 2 in the 10th grade. Students get their second arts credit in the 10th or 12th grades. Within scheduling constraints -students in grade 9 get art and music, 10 and 12 which one depends on which class they are in with limited choice in 12th grade
Q47_1: There is a semester 3/2, 2/3 rotation for the shared Dance and Theater teacher with another school.  The Art and music teachers are here full time.  Given the reduced days the Dance and Theatre are here, it limits how we can give those arts and where they can fit in the class schedule. So each class grade 6 and 8 each rotate for 1 quarter into each discipline for a 2x per week class.  7th grade only does 2/4 for one semester bc they need to take health in the spring term. The outside Dance provider is here 2x per week for grades 6,7 and 9 and each class on the grade rotates for 1 quarter into the class given with the PE teacher as part of their PE program.  Grade 10 gets health in the fall so in the spring they can get some arts electives.  12th graders can choose Arts electives versus other electives since they have the flexibility in the 12th grade.

Q46_1: During their middle school years scholars will have a host of opportunities in the Arts. All sixth graders will receive a full year of Visual Arts and will work with such outside partners as LeAp and Lincoln Center. Seventh graders will receive Music and Theater instruction. Q46_1: All students at Bronx Community High School are required to take two Arts classes during the course of their high school education in order to graduate. The courses focus on the NYC Standards, the Blueprint for the Arts and CCLS. In the Visual Arts, these include Art Making,Historical/Cultural Context of the Arts, Literacy in the Arts and Career and Lifelong Learning in the Arts. There is an emphasis on art making and the exploration of materials in each class. During class, students work towards mastery of media and a strong conceptual base for the value of Arts in education and as a vehicle for student voice in a community. In Dance, these courses include developing Dance literacy, making connections by working with community and cultural resources, and exploring careers and lifelong learning. Several times per year students are provided the opportunity to visit cultural organizations around the city and, when possible, outside artists/professionals are brought in to classes to teach and discuss careers in the arts. We offer our students a variety of courses such as Urban Art, Design it Yourself (DIY), Printmaking, 3-D Design, Art & Design, and Art for Change.

Our art teacher has been able to successfully expand the art program through a design class. She would like to have a teaching program dedicated solely to art and so would I, but funding does not currently allow for that in a small school.
Q47_1: We are a small Transfer School serving students who are overage and under-credited. Our students have dropped out or dis-engaged from their traditional high school and we offer an alternative means to get an education and reach graduation as a college and career ready young person.

This year freshman and seniors took a full year of art
We have a visual arts program that includes traditional Fine Arts as well as a heavy focus on Digital Media Arts.

Our Arts Program aims to give students exposure to Dance and the Visual Arts through student interest-based concentrations. We aim for students to experience a multi-year program in the various genres of Dance and diverse styles of Visual Arts. This includes experience through direct instruction in their concentration area, performance and observation in various venues. Q46_1:
The Museum’s Little Friends of the High Bridge program educates children from K to 3rd grade along with their teachers and families in Highbridge about the significance and life of the historic High Bridge and encourages them to visit and enjoy the bridge now that it’s open.

Little Friends is designed to connect the people of Highbridge to the bridge for which their community is named and to the two parks that are joined by the bridge. It encourages teachers to use the story of the High Bridge as a tool to teach history and STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math). Programming focuses on teaching local Highbridge children about the history, significance, and the beauty of the High Bridge, as well as introducing the local flora and fauna that can be found along the nearby Harlem River and the importance of water to all who use the river. The overall goal of the program is to foster a love and appreciation for this natural resource in hopes that children will be inspired to become stewards of their environment.

Teachers and Writers Collaborative
Mission: Teachers and Writers Collaborative partners with New York City schools and community-based organizations to offer dynamic creative writing programs led by professional writers.

We have a Digital Narrative Program which offers students the experience of turning their own poems, short stories or other pieces into an original video game.

In our effort to bring to our students a visual arts program that is culturally reflective of our global diversity, our school's art teacher is expected to expose students to a wide array of artistic endeavors. This would stylistically include portraiture, perspective, still life, and realism/abstraction. With all of this, cohesiveness in forming links to curricular units of academic study to art history must be achieved, thereby allowing for students to ground their artistic endeavors through historical perspectives, using art vocabulary that is relevant to specific periods.
It is our mission to create a studio that embraces and nurtures the creative mind.

P.S.35X is a staunch supporter and proponent of Arts instruction. We believe: "The Arts have a power to deepen and extend our understanding of ourselves and the world" (Carr 2005). Educational research indicates studying the arts cultivates essential qualities students need to succeed in the 21st century. The Arts promote creativity, cooperation, communication, cultural understanding and problem-solving. Learning in the Arts nurtures active engagement, disciplined and sustained attention, persistence and risk taking. Arts education also increases attendance and educational aspirations. Our commitment to college and career readiness includes instruction in the Arts: Dance, Theatre, Music, Art, and Visual/Graphic Art (Technology). Students in grades K-2 receive Arts and Theatre instruction across all areas, and culminating projects are the expectation to show what students have learned.

Our goal is to provide all children with a well-rounded education. That entitlement requires introduction to, understanding of, and appreciation for the Arts. The Arts are an avenue to understanding our history and ourselves. Our goal is to increase the exposure of our students to the Arts, giving students performance opportunities which will lead to increased listening, speaking, and motor skills. Additionally, by providing students with these experiences, they are also given the opportunity to nurture the talent they discover within themselves.

P.S.053 emphases music and visual arts for select classes on Grades Pre-kindergarten through fifth. Throughout the school year, many of our students learn how to play various musical instruments and those who participate in the visual arts program develop artistic skills in that discipline. The school's arts program cultivate our students creativity and prepare them to be critical thinkers.

We have the following Arts programs in our school: Bronx Children's Museum,SCAN of New York, Dance and Visual Arts, New York Pops, Vocal, Drama, Renaissance and Disney Musicals. Our Step team, is four time Bronx Champions. We are currently working on the Aladdin Kids show.

We believe in the Arts across the curriculum at Public School 58; our students have the opportunity to participate in Visual Arts, Dance,Theater and Vocal Music. We believe in encouraging the talents of the whole child and celebrating the Arts in performance, Art shows, and competitions. We collaborate with The New York Twirling Organization, Bronx Arts Ensemble, Groundswell Mural Artists and MET to support our students.

One of the biggest goals of the Visual Art program at our school is to make connections between the Visual Arts and other academic areas for interdisciplinary learning. In addition, we strive to give students the knowledge and skills they need to use the Arts as a way to interpret and portray the world around them. Our music program  provides sequential music instruction for students working towards Music Literacy. Our lower grades (PK-1) focus on song games, the singing voice, and rudimentary musical literacy skills. Grades 2 and 3 sing and also receive basic piano keyboard instruction. Grades 4 and 5 sing and receive basic guitar instruction. Grades 3-5 learn basic vocal technique and vocal health as part of their curriculum. We also have an advanced keyboard club for select third graders and an advanced guitar ensemble for select fourth and fifth graders. We put on six concerts per school year and provide music for assemblies and other special occasions. We are a Little Kids Rock school.

Q46_1: Involvement in the Arts is associated with gains in academics; Arts learning can also improve motivation, concentration, confidence, and teamwork. Our Bronx Arts Education program enables our children to have a more level playing field with children who have had enrichment experiences in the Arts. Comprehensive, innovative Arts initiatives continue to take root in our school. P.S. 73 fosters the use of the Arts as a learning tool by incorporating arts into our daily programs, creating a school environment rich in arts, culture, and hands-on arts instruction. Through various grants, our students have been afforded the opportunity to learn how to play Recorder and Guitar. Our third year music instructor continues to provide us with innovative ideas to strengthen and increase the growth of music education. The after school program(SCAN), has supported us in financing a Drama Club. Our revitalized ‘state of the art’ auditorium has been put to good use re-establishing school concerts. Next year (2018/19) we hope to continue our relationship with Jazz at Lincoln Center from previous school years and also  take 4th and 5th grade students to participate in arts education events sponsored by the MET and El Museo del Barrio. Finally, we are planning to put on a school musical.

Our goal is to involve our students in a variety of creative, artistic, and imaginative experiences which will enhance self-esteem, problem-solving skills, aptitude, concentration, and listening skills. We try to develop in our students an understanding and appreciation of an arts through participation in an Art residency program. We provide the instrument for the integration of the Arts with the Core Curriculum.

P.S.109 believes it is important to cultivate students' interests and talents in the arts. Therefore, with two full-time Visual Arts teaches as well as 2 full time performing arts teachers.  Students are immersed in the arts across grade levels from PreKindergarten through 5th grade.  This year P.S.109 will have its Annual Art Show with 100% student participation-there will be an evening showing for parents and local community members as well.  The Art teachers at P.S.109 have been involved in several Professional Development workshops this year, including inquiry work that explores how formative assessment increases learning in the arts.  This year, our 5th grade students were involved in all aspects of the production, Wiz, Jr.  They auditioned, rehearsed, took an active role in building the set and creation of props.

Our Art Appreciation program addresses Arts Standards aligned with New York State performance indicators; units of study are developed and implemented using the Department of Education's Blueprint for the Arts. Classroom teachers focus on providing a well-balanced art program using a variety of media through project based learning. This program enhances content area initiatives, especially in the reading and writing programs, through grade level unit planning. A Music teacher supports the music program for all students. The classroom teachers provide both Art History and Visual Art programs for all our students. Art and Dance clubs provide enrichment opportunities as well. Theater programs allow students to express themselves in the form of Drama in their classrooms and in monthly assemblies and during school wide celebrations including but not limited to Holidays and Multicultural Celebration. Readers Theater enhances our literacy curriculum.

P.S.114 envisions providing the students, parents and staff with opportunities to participate in Drama, Music, Art and cultural activities that are age and grade appropriate. We hope to continue getting the services of outside professional artists who will conduct hands-on workshops and on- stage performances for the students. Finances have become a huge barrier-we hope that our goals become reality with funding for the Arts. We envision having celebrations in which the community is invited, showcasing Visual and Performing Arts such as stage performances and Arts Fairs. The students can display their creativity through video, computer, musical and artistic displays. We would like to encourage love for all the Arts and bring out the talent within our students. This year we were successful in having more parent-engagement activities which brought our families together to celebrate the Arts. Next year we hope to extend this more, bringing additional members of our community into our school.
 We are a Title 1 school in the South Bronx.Many of our learners do not have any experience with  the Arts and so an Arts Education is very important in our school.Although the students live in an area surrounded by cultural facilities many have never experienced them. We like to bring out the creativity and passion for the Arts in all of our learners. We have many ELL as well as SWD learners and the Arts is a Universal Language that all can understand.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)

Q46_1: Our school has studied and implemented the Schoolwide Enrichment Model for the past eight years, sending teachers to study the model at Professional Development sessions during the year and at the Summer Confratute session sponsored by the University of Connecticut. As part of our implementation of this model, our students and teachers have enrichment clusters incorporated into their weekly program; these clusters are organized into cycles that rotate every 10-12 weeks throughout the year, and all of our students have the opportunity to register for the cluster of their choice. Our enrichment clusters are devoted to skills such as Culinary Arts, Theater, Chorus, Rock Band, Recorder, and Website Design. In addition to our co-curricular enrichment clusters, our students also have opportunities to participate in Arts programs after school. These offerings include MH3 Rock Band, Dance Team, Chorus, and Sports.

We seek to provide students with a foundation in the Arts that will spark an interest that can be nurtured in their junior and senior years. We endeavor to expose our students to the rich cultural offerings of New York City as we foster their creativity. We leverage their natural love for creative expression to expose them to varied art forms. We are sure that with these in and out of school experiences, the love for and of the arts will be rooted in our students' hearts for years to come.

At P.S.163, we continue to implement the Blueprint for the Arts Curriculum for Visual Arts. We are also very fortunate to have a continued residency with Arts for All, where the students are exposed to Theater, Visual Arts, and Dance. This year we will spend a day at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the students will view, discuss and analyze several paintings and sculptures. We also were able to hire a full time music and visual arts teachers.  The students are responding well to the new experiences and the expansion of the Arts program in our school.

P.S.170 is proud to say that we have been able to offer our students access to exceptional instruction in all Arts through a combination of school-based Arts educators and a partnership with Marquis Studios. All of our students' Arts experience is comprised of both skills-based instruction and a connection to the discipline's cultural background and vocabulary. Instruction across all disciplines is aligned with or surpasses benchmarks outlined in the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Students have additional access to arts programs provided by our school's Arts specialists in a variety of arts-based afterschool programs (not discussed in this survey) It is our goal that our students continue to find success and grow both as performers and artists , pursuing the Arts well after they leave our school as artists, advocates, or appreciators. We hope to provide these opportunities through the continuation of our current programs in the upcoming school year.
Q47_1:
Our school is an early childhood school (K-2) located in the Bronx.  We have 4 classes per grade with 1 class per grade being bilingual and 1 being ICT.  Since our school is so small, all classes are able to participate in all arts programs offered. 
We are fortunate to have a very close relationship with Marquis Studios and their support in locating and helping to secure grant money has helped us to provide the well-rounded arts experience that our students need and deserve.

Q46_1: We have continued our plan to expand arts education in the Shakespeare School. To realize the plans' goals, each teacher incorporates the arts into their day-to-day curriculum. Equitable arts opportunities for students take place daily, as the culture of the Shakespeare School continues to be strengthened and supported school-wide. In order to support this vision, we have identified and developed an art studio, a classroom solely purposed with being the space to provide visual arts instruction from our visual arts licensed teacher. In addition to the day-to-day incorporation of the arts, we also have two Project Arts after school programs.  One is theater based and the other is visual arts based.  Our efforts toward a stronger arts education here at P.S. 199 is with the hope to spark policy, future action plans and budget recommendations for implementing a sequential and standards - based curriculum in the Arts outlined at EVERY grade level. This process has fostered further community awareness and hopes to provide the structure and catalyst for sustainable relationships between the Shakespeare School and key arts stakeholders. This concept is founded in the idea that every member of the community has an important piece of the larger puzzle, offering valuable resources that will contribute to the greater good - the future Arts education, awareness and experience of the scholars at the Shakespeare School!

P.S 204 seeks to ensure that students receive a well-rounded education which includes instruction across the arts. We partner with cultural organizations to provide standards-based instruction in the arts, as well as maintain a full time music teacher position. The Music teacher provides instruction to all of the students in the school. Students sing, dance, move, and play along with traditional songs from many cultures. The program also includes instruction on a variety of instruments (guitar, piano, drums, and recorders). Dancing Classrooms provides instruction in Ballroom Dancing to students in grades 4 and 5; and the school also has a partnership with Ailey dance. Studio-in-a-School provides visual arts instruction for all students. Residencies include instruction in two and three dimensional media and students explore the creative process using a variety of media. Art exhibitions allow students to present their work to the public. A Disney Musical Grant offers students the opportunity to participate in producing a Disney Musical Theater piece. This year the students performed "The Aristocats." In previous years, the students have put on performances of Willy Wonka, The Lion King, Aladdin, and Jungle Book.  Marquis Studios provides a parent-child program for students in the primary grades. Students learned the art of Circus Performance, Bookmaking, and Collage. Our children regularly participate in field trips to New York's world-renowned museums.

We provide Visual Arts and Music to students in grades K-8. The teachers are bilingual and instructs in both English and Spanish to align the NYCDOE curriculum and our mission as a Dual Language School. In addition, the classroom teachers provide Art and Music instruction during the day.

Our goal for Arts education at PS236 is to provide a wide range of experiences that will expose our young learners to the many ways to enjoy the Arts. Through our in-house Music program we develop appreciation for many genres of music and provide opportunities for our students to perform and showcase their developing talent. All classes receive instruction in Vocal music and many begin to explore Instrumental music through the use of recorder. Our Choir and African Drum Band meet after school and perform in many venues throughout the city. We host several artist residencies throughout the year that provide experiences in the visual and performing arts. Children have opportunities to experiment with different artistic media and to express themselves through Drama and Storytelling. Classroom teachers integrate Visual Art into all areas of the curriculum, using the Blueprint for the Arts to guide their selection of materials and artistic method. We believe early exposure develops a lifelong appreciation for art.

Our Arts program is an integral part of our students academic program. During the school day, all students enroll in arts-based electives including Instrumental Music, Visual Arts, Dance, Computer Design, Crafts, and Woodworking. All of our freshmen take a Fundamentals of Art course and attend two art-based field trips in their first year of high school.  Three fourths of our sophomores take a Beginner's Photography class while a quarter of the cohort moved on to an Advanced Photography course. 
 Upperclassmen have access to more advanced courses like Pottery and Advanced Painting.  After school, there are a series of arts-based programs open to all students, including Dance, Visual Arts, 3-D Printing, and Music. During the summer, we run "Camp AMS," an all-day program combining academics and arts. This camp is open to all middle school students, including those mandated for summer school. Throughout the year, all of our Arts programs include performances and displays, and students invite the community to share and celebrate their acquired artistic skills.
Q48_2: Assistant Principal & Supervisor of the Arts

Q46_1: The Visual Arts program at Mott Hall Bronx High School is designed to prepare students for the International Baccalaureate program. Students are engaged in creating an art exhibition in their senior year that is a culmination of their work over their time in the program. We also offer BEAT Global afterschool for students interested in music production, beat-making, rapping, and/or poetry. BEAT teaches music production skills using iPads and beat-making software. Students create beats, write lyrics, and put together tracks. All of the instructors are real artists who are passionate about teaching students.

The BCSM Theatre department currently offers two levels of theatre: Introduction to Theater and Theatre Performance. The work in these courses requires personal motivation, passion for exploration, risk-taking, and most importantly, an openness to new ideas, thoughts, and feelings. Students will enhance and develop performance skills in improvisation, theatre games, spoken word, physical theatre and vocal work; they will increase their abilities as imaginative and analytical actors by interpreting the texts of dramatic works. Additionally, students will gain new performance skills needed to help build characer in monologues and scenes. These classes will prove an enjoyable outlet for self-expression, group interaction, and an opportunity to explore personal meaning and identity. After school, the Department produces two full scale Musical Theatre productions each year. Students audition and are chosen to sing, dance and act among their fellow ensemble members. Technical theatre work is also offered, where students may help design, build and paint the sets. Every Fall and Spring, the Theatre Department partners with the Theatre Development Funds' Stage Door Program. Through this program, students collaborate with a TDF teaching artist and attend a Broadway show for free.
Q47_1: Due to generous support from PDT Partners we were able to incorporate an Arts Night at BCSM in 2018 that we look to continue for 2019.  The Arts Night included music, photography, visual arts, dance, poetry  and the performing arts.

Q46_1: We will continue expanding our arts offering at our school. So far during the current academic year we have hired licensed visual art, and music teachers for both upper and lower grades, totaling four teachers. We will add percussion, string and keyboarding during the next academic year.

For the 2017-2018 school year, P.S.294's goal was to integrate Art into the regular school day. Through community arts partnerships, every student at our school was able to experience the Arts and the thrill of performing for their peers and family. Teachers receive Professional Development in Art, Music, Dance, and Theater so that they can support the work of our Arts partners, as well as adopt practices to implement into their own daily lessons. Parents have also been able to participate in arts-related family activities coordinated by our Parent Coordinator in collaboration with our community arts partners. Our partnership with Ballroom Dancing allows direct instruction to our students.

Our school's goal is to focus on project based-learning and Arts projects that go through panels and round-tables, where students defend their work and then prepare it for public presentation. In addition, 3 of our students participated in the NY Historical Shoe Design Competition, 2 of our students participated in the Bronx Arts Festival Exhibition, 1 of our students was a finalist at the 2018 Congressional Art Competition and 4 of our students participated in the 2018 P.S. Art Festival. On June 3rd 3 of our students will be awarded the following Schools Art League's Medals: Alexander Medal, St. Gaudens Medal and the Haney Medal.

C.I.S 303 offers 45 minute Visual Arts classes on a daily basis to 6th, 7th, and 8th grade student for the duration of one marking period per year. The Visual Arts program follows the benchmarks outlined by the Blueprint for the Visual Arts, along with guidelines from the Danielson's Framework for Teaching. Classes are designed to develop drawing, observational and analytical skills through exploration of the Elements of Art and Design in varied media. Units begin with introductory techniques and concepts and progress to complex final group and individual hands-on projects. In addition, set design production offers students the opportunity to delve in careers in the Arts through participation in Disney in Schools programming. The overall goal of the Art program is to teach skills that enable students to make connections across content areas and engage in self-expression. Students demonstrating strong artistic potential and interest are encouraged to pursue portfolio preparation for specialized high schools and are supported by participating in extension Art classes and enrolling in the MS Arts Audition Boot Camp provided by Lincoln Center for the Arts.

Q45_10: Music teacher just came back from leave
Q46_1: Music

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R5: Museum of the City of New York
Q46_1: We currently offer Documentary Film Making as an Arts in our school. Students have been exposed to the filming and editing required to make films. They have conducted action research for their films and will be presenting them at the end of the year.
Q47_1: Our Visual Arts teacher left prior to the 2017-2018 school year and we have been looking for a teacher to replace ever since.

Q46_1: We're closing. It is sad.

Our primary goal within our Arts Education curriculum is to enhance our students overall educational experience. We at CMSP 327 want our students to perform well academically and actively participate in all aspects of our school life. We are keenly aware of how music, art, dance, and film impact the educational and personal growth of each of our students. We have worked with the Arts Matter program for the past few years to increase our Arts offerings, and we have a continued partnership with Dreamyard, which is providing extra-curricular enrichment for both middle and high school.  we have a full time Dance teacher, and have a part time theatre teacher. We have expanded out arts offerings with a part time visual arts teacher in our middle school and are looking to build off that to offer more visual art electives for our high school students.

DreamYard Preparatory High School offers a variety of arts disciplines and experiences to all students throughout their high school careers. Students take an Arts Elective Course in one of four areas: Visual Art, Theater, Music, and Dance in their 9th and 10th Grade Years and choose to major in one of these disciplines in their junior and senior years. This means that all students receive at least 90 minutes of art each semester. Additionally, DreamYard Prep provides in-depth after-school opportunities for students to engage in high quality arts experiences. These include: our annual musical, mural club, dance after-school, and Mouse Squad. Students can also take classes in Music Production, Video Game Design, Fashion Design, Digital Photography, and Poetry.

Students in middle and high school grades were able to take one to two semesters of Visual Arts. Students worked on standards-aligned visual arts assignments to build their secondary school arts portfolios. Third year(or more) students are able to design independent study courses in Visual Arts according to interest and school capacity. Students in middle and high school also received a semester of Music - both Instrumental and Vocal. They performed at four school assemblies and for some of our community Arts partners.
Q47_1: We are a unique transfer middle/high school combination that serves a 100% population of over-aged, disconnected youth.

Q46_1: Our mission is to ensure that students are equipped with the academic and socio-emotional skills necessary to enter competitive high schools. Arts education will develop our students' academic and socio-emotional skill set by providing them a means of expression. Currently, we offer our students daily access to Phys. Ed, and the ability to participate in one of the following enrichment activities: Dance, Visual Arts ( computer-based or painting/drawing ) music, and Theater.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Students have the opportunity to major in Media and Communications which will allow them to experiment and create digital art works.
