Our students continue visiting museums and attending art-related productions such as movies and theater. Additionally, students take Music History and Theory, as well as, Music Production courses. These experiences support their learning and appreciation for the arts.

Our school adheres to the New York State Education Department mandates for all high school diplomas that require students to earn a half unit of study in Art and another half unit of study in Music. All middle school students and upperclassmen in high school earn their Art and Music Appreciation credits through seminar-style courses that culminate in a term project, after meeting the necessary amount of classroom hours.

Grant Avenue Elementary School is committed to the Arts as a critical way in which our students learn more about the world and more about themselves. Our students experience quality Visual Arts, Dance, and Music instruction throughout the school year with our specialty teachers. Students receive additional arts instruction from cultural organizations across the city including Studio in a School, Story Pirates, and Musica Viva NY, thanks in large part to our partnership with Change for Kids. We pride ourselves on engaging with parents through the arts, and together we celebrate our talented students and showcase their work at annual musical performance events (concerts, dance recitals, and a 5th grade musical) and posted displays of student artwork throughout the year.

Mott Hall scholars receive both visual and performing arts classes in each year of the MYP International Baccalaureate programme. Heightened awareness of creative thinking helps our scholars to develop their self-reflection skills in all classes and become more self-regulated learners. At Mott Hall, students have the opportunity to learn through art making and art history. Through the arts, students create, perform, and present in ways that engage and convey feelings, experiences and ideas. It is through these creative thinking practices that students can learn new skills and master skills they have already developed through their own personal artistic practice.
Q47_1: In the International Baccalaureate Program, students are required to receive a total of 50 hours of arts programming per year. This time must be spent equally between a visual arts discipline and a performing arts discipline. Due to volume of students and staffing, Mott Hall students receive a full year of arts programming but it is split into semesters; one semester of visual arts and one semester of performing arts.

Q46_1: At The Bronx School for Law Government and Justice, we believe in the importance of the Arts for our students. We also believe in tapping into students' interests, creativity and abilities. In support of these beliefs and in addition to our school themed electives, we offer arts focused afterschool programs. Our afterschool programs include theater and fine arts workshops, as well as opportunities to see on and off- Broadway performances and visit Art museums. Each year, our students choose from a range of electives in the arts based on their interests. Because Art is both product and performance based, students participating in arts courses and arts workshops share their talent and learning by performing in and out of school.

We do not have a current arts department this school year. However, we mask our arts program with various partnerships such as Sparkhouse that focuses on writing through poetry. In addition, our after school activities such as Opening Act, Yearbook, Bronxworks support our arts program. We also create various school wide performances quarterly. We are currently doing a play on the life and times of Frederick Douglass and we also have had various exhibits in collaboration with family night events to support our scholars progress.
This year we have a Dance Club to engage students after school.  We also added a Computer Arts course for students to develop their digital arts skills.
Q47_1: We have limited space in our building but do our best to provide arts-related content courses, in recognition of the fact that the arts are important for students' overall development as well-rounded individuals (and despite the fact that the arts are considered secondary or tertiary to the core content areas).

Q39_4: Former teacher and community have donated costumes
Q46_1: The High School for Violin & Dance's mission is to "give students the opportunity to perform and shine in the classroom, on stage, and in life- we want to prepare students to be caring leaders in society". At HSVD, students and staff work together to provide opportunities that meet the needs of every learner. One of the major ways in which our school has grown in regards to the Arts has been through continued expansion of our offerings to students. Our Music department offers a full Orchestra program, where students have a choice of Violin, Viola, Cello, or String Bass. Some of the Music Department's goals for next year include having our music students perform both solo and in ensembles at the New York State School Music Association competition. We won the silver for the 3rd time.  We continue to offer a Visual Arts component; students have learned sublimation and heat transfer with vinyl, leading to the creation of: T-shirts, pants, sweaters, mugs, plaques and other items as well. We continue to build relationships with cultural organizations such as Alvin Ailey, and Dance Theater of Harlem. This year we have also partnered with Hamilton, where students studied the time period and created their own performances. Project I.AM continues to be an important part of our school, where students create and deliver individual and group performances before a live panel of judges who provide feedback based on a school-wide performance rubric. Students receive feedback and are then expected to revise their performances accordingly.
Q47_1:
Our students come to HSVD with no prior experience in music or dance.  Since we are not an audition school, our students are learning the very basics of their craft.  The Orchestra program begins with the very basics of playing a string instrument. Our students are so dedicated to their learning their craft; so much so, that they have won the silver in the NYSSMA competition; they won this year, 2018, 2017, and 2015.  They've competed three times and won the silver each time.  In dance, students are learning ballet, jazz, hip hop and the dance terminology.  As they progress through the years, they learn how to choreograph their own dances and perform these choreographed dances at the end of each academic year.  
While our students excel in the arts, they also come from backgrounds that require them to have adult responsibilities at a young age.  Many of our students need to work after school, take care of their siblings, and complete other adult responsibilities.  Some of our students live in shelters with their families or on their own.  With this said, sometimes its difficult for some of them to progress in the arts due to lack of rehearsal on their own  time because of their circumstances; however while in school, they give their very best.

Q46_1: Students are exposed to the Arts in a variety of ways at PS/MS 3. They participate in developmentally appropriate arts instruction in areas including, but not limited to the following: dance, music, theatre and visual arts. Our grade 5-8 students receive additional instruction and support in the Arts through SOBRO, our CBO. We look forward to increasing student participation in the arts for the 2018-2019 school year.

Q39_4: Participate in after school theater program
Q46_1: The Milton Fein School -P.S.7 is a school where we take great pride and pleasure in incorporating the arts into our curriculum.  During the school day all students are given the opportunity to experience dance, music, visual art and drama on a rotational basis.  In addition we partner with several community based organizations which help to enhance our mission to develop the intellectual and social/emotional growth of our students.  We strongly believe that the arts help to strengthen our positive school culture.  Finally we are very proud that we give our students the opportunity to experience the joy of the arts by providing trips to Broadway shows and Alvin Ailey dance performances.

Our current Arts Program is comprised of Music Appreciation, unique Dance Experiences and Visual Arts for all participating students in grades K-5. For the 2018-2019 school year, our goal is to enrich our Arts programs by collaborating with community based organizations to include residencies that offer Theater and Dance.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
At the Ryer Avenue Elementary School, we endeavor to expose students to a variety of art forms and styles across the art disciplines. The dance teacher engaged students in ballet and modern dance styles. The music teacher offers music across cultures, Latin music, Gospel and Jazz are some of what it students learned about in music. Some of visual arts offerings to students included drawing, painting, sculpting with clay and print making. 
       The joy of it all is watching what the students learn across the disciplines come together on stage. Twice a year, collaborate efforts produces a dance musical with scenery. The dance teacher picks a story that her students reimagine in dance. The music teacher finds accompanying music to be played by students on recorder, piano (keyboard) and sung by chorus. After reading and discussing the text for our production the fifth grade students designs and creates the set for the show. It's a fun way to teach students that the arts work together and to expose them to different jobs that are offered in the arts.
       We will continue to teach our students and expose the to the vast world that are has to offer them. The Arts Blue Prints and Common Core Standards have been a great guide. Continued professional development in diversifying the use of these tools to reach our students in the arts is a goal we will continue to strive for to offer our students our best.

The goal of PS/MS 15 is to expose, nurture and enhance the cultural experiences for all students through a variety of art disciplines. Additionally, we offer a variety of afterschool club activities for middle school students to further enhance their arts education experiences. Menu items include Dance, Visual Arts, Film, Chorus, Knitting and Cooking

The art curriculum consists of actively engaging the students in the performing art for dance, music, and theatre, and visual arts through on-site staff members and cultural institutions.  The goal is for the students to become knowledgeable about the different art curriculums by critically analyzing the arts by connecting their work to the work of others. PS/MS 20 works with the students in the Junior Chorus to develop the students' personal and the cultural knowledge of the arts through learning performance to build their vocal techniques. Students have the opportunity to learn the recorder, keyboard, and percussion.

We have two full time ARTS teachers, one in Dance and one in Visual Art.  This year we also had Music enrichment for all students through a Cultural Arts Organization, Education through Music. The music teacher taught all grades, while the dance teacher taught 2nd-5th grades, and the visual art teacher taught PK-1st, and 3rd Grade. Curriculum developed for these programs is based on the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. The two school based teachers attended Teacher Effectiveness, State Standards Training, and Citywide Professional Development. Teachers strive for every child to participate fully in the Arts. They try to give every opportunity possible to the students.
Q47_1: Our school is a Title 1, high needs school. About 21% of our students are ENLs, 28% are SWD, and 33% live in shelters.

Q46_1: We currently have an Arts Leadership Team comprised of students, teachers, and administrators. The Team works towards our Arts Mission Statement and goals set earlier in the year. They organize programs, events and opportunities for both students and teachers around the Arts. We highlight teacher strengths in the Arts, even if they are not certified as arts teachers. Teachers take these strengths and create programs during and after school, in addition to sharing in teacher teams to build capacity in the arts. Our school environment consists of an Art gallery, "The Belmont Art Gallery', located in a hallway/bridge where all grades and programs are represented. Hallways, bulletin boards, and classrooms also come alive with Arts. We have developed strong collaborations with our Arts partners, particularly DreamYard, who have assisted in deepening the work around the arts disciplines.

At PS 33 we take the arts very seriously. We know that the arts provide students with  many different opportunities in the world and in education. In our school we have educators instructing our students in music, dance and visual arts. In our music program we have avery longstanding relationship with Music and The Brain where are students are taught how to play the keyboard primarily in grades k-2. Our Music program also includes The Little Kids Rock program  which we use primarily to instruct students  to play the guitar in the upper grades. Our visual arts program has been a mainstay at the school and our students are instructed in several different mediums in all grades. Our Dance program is instructed across all the grades through an in house teacher where students get a very rich instruction in dance form and technique. Our school also benefits greatly from our long standing relationship with The DreamYard Project. This year they have supported us through in class residencies, teacher professional development and a very enriching after-school program. In consort all of these different arts programs are used in our school to make it a very culturally inclusive environment and our students are not only scholars but young artist.

We provided Visual Arts instruction in grades K-5, and 7, until mid year when our certified arts teacher, and arts coordinator retired. We provide Drama instruction to grades K-5. We dance and sing in our classrooms and at assemblies, shows and our dance festival. We expose our students to cultural events outside our school including plays, recitals, art museums, and films.

for the current school year  we have a licensed visual arts teacher servicing students in various classes in grades 6-8 including ENL and SWD students 
in addition we received a CASA grant from councilman ritchie torres.  creative art works has worked with us in the after school program since october.  by june there will be 3 cycles of work with 3 exhibits.  students use technology to enhance the work.
we also paid for a dance residency which culminated in december 2017.  we worked with  marquis studios.  6 of our 6th grade classes were involved in this in house residency

Q39_4: Participated in Arts and Parents Grant
Q46_1: PS 46, The Edgar Allan Poe Literacy Development School houses students from Kindergarten - Fifth grade. All students receive Arts instruction integrated into the Literacy curriculum. Arts instruction is implemented in the classroom daily by certified classroom teachers; in addition, PS 46 has a full time certified art teacher. This teacher is certified to teach Fine Arts and services students located at our MS 45 annex. Our schools belief is rooted in the idea of developing the whole child, therefore Arts residencies are conducted annually with a resident instructor. Currently our residencies are run through the following organizations: Arts Horizons, DreamYard, and Dancing Classroom Ballroom Dance. Residencies last anywhere from 10-14 weeks in duration and are being conducted in the discipline of Music, Dance, and Theater. Dance includes ballroom, World and African Dance. Students learn the Recorder, Storytelling, Drumming and Poetry. As a result, students' educational experiences are enhanced and enriched. Each class participates in a culminating event that strengthens the home-school connection.

At the Bronx New School, the Fine Arts are a vital part of the comprehensive education plan for every student. We believe every student should have access to quality materials and instruction in all arts areas, including music, theater, dance, and visual arts. Students learn skills in each of the arts areas in accordance with the NYCDOE's Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and New York State Arts Standards. Students learn how to make connections between the arts, academic subjects, and technology while expressing their creativity and critical thinking skills. They engage with many arts experiences throughout New York City, including live performances and art museum visits. Students also have the opportunity to show their growing artistic skills with performances and exhibitions for our school community during the school year.

PS 54 provides Visual Arts, Theater, Poetry, Music and Dance instruction to all of our students. We celebrate this every year with visual arts exhibitions, dance recitals, poetry slams, and theatrical performances with our entire school community. This year we increased our opportunities to work with the DreamYard Project with the focus on visual arts and dance.  We have also begun working with Little Orchestra designed to engage 2nd grade students in music education.  Visiting artists have been working directly with selected classes and with parent groups as part of community outreach in the Arts and have also been conducting afterschool programs. Our students have will be exhibiting artwork in the 2017 Bronx Borough-Wide Annual Visual Arts Festival and the DreamYard Visual Arts Festival at Lehman College, where they will exhibit artwork at the Lehman College Art Gallery. We have a second grade teacher who provides Music instruction- he also conducts a student Rock Band as well as directing a theatrical performance in the spring. Connections are continuously made with the Common Core subjects to support Learning through the Arts.
Q47_1: Public School 54 is known as The Academy of Creative Minds.  We make it our mission to prepare our students for the 21st Century through the use of technology in the classrooms for purposes of instruction and assessment.  As a school community, we are engaging our students in the Cloud 9/PBIS program to improve our school community through it's teaching.  In this, our students participate in the practice of citizenship through respect, responsibility, perseverance and compassion for all.  We set high expectations for all of our students with the belief that they can and will achieve their goals academically and socially.  We are working with various organizations to build on our students use of creativity through the arts to expand their understanding of the various disciplines in art while also making those connections to other subject areas such as literacy, math and social studies.  Our science teacher has a Sustainability Club to teach students about environmental studies to make them aware of these issues affecting our environment and what we can do to correct them. In addition, our teachers work each day to expand upon their best practices with the assistance of Teacher's College and the Universal Design for Learning Guidelines to provide students, through our instruction, multiple means of engagement, representation, action and expression to reach students with various learning needs.

Q46_1: All students in grades K, 1 and 2 participate in a choral program and students in grades 1 and 2 learn to play the recorder. All students in grades 3,4 and 5 participate in a Choral program through The Metropolitan Opera Guild/Urban Voices. All students in grades 4 and 5 learn to play the Violin. Instrumental instruction in grades 4 and 5 are given by resident artist through the Bronx Arts Ensemble. Students participate in Visual Arts , Theater and Dance in the classroom, instructed by a classroom teacher.

Students will receive Art and Music through various programs, trips and before and afterschool groups. All lessons are aligned with the New York State and NYC Blueprint Standards as well as incorporating ELA Common Core, Math, Science and Social Studies as interdisciplinary lessons. Students are able to express themselves and learn visually and vocally to enhance their skills and self- esteem as young students.  We have partnered with Education through Music and have a full time teacher instructing music in all PreK-5 Classrooms.

At P.S.77 we are committed to providing students with a high quality education. In the 2017-2018 school year we were able to expand our arts programs. In addition to having a full time music teacher working with all students from PK-3rd grade and benefiting from partnerships with organizations such as Dream Yard and Studio in a School, this year we were able to offer additional enrichment opportunities. 
This year more families were able to participate in the Studio in a School Family Workshops offered on Saturdays. The program ended with a beautiful art exhibit which everyone enjoyed. 
Seeing the enthusiasm and artistic talents grow with time, we have begun offering after school enrichment arts programs. This structure provides opportunities for more students to engage in dance, music and visual arts. 
Another way our arts program has expanded is by taking advantage of opportunities to attend events outside of the school as well. This year our students in Kindergarten- Third grade attended 1-2 performances offered by the Arts on Stage NY organization. 
We will continue to expand upon these opportunities each year in hopes of nurturing an appreciation for the arts in all of our students.

We believe that the Arts are an integral component of our students' academic and social-emotional development. Through the Arts our students develop 21st century skills such as: problem solving, collaboration, creative thinking, perseverance, and communication skills. We currently offer a comprehensive Arts program comprised of Visual Arts, Music, and Theater. Our daytime Arts program is complimented by a large selection of afterschool arts activities. We have partnered with community based organizations to provide both the students and community-at-large with heightened Arts experiences. Our students take part in a minimum of 3 arts performances per year. These events allow students to display their talents and engage our parents, families and community members. In the coming year(s) we are looking to expand our Arts through Technology. This will include Music/Sound Engineering, Computer Graphics, Web Design, Robotics, and 3D Design. These offerings will provide students with skills to prepare them for college and the current/projected career landscape. We are committed to holistic development of our students, and the Arts is one of the critical components.

Public School 85 is a community committed to integrating diverse art forms across the curriculum to enable its members to reach their full potential. Through the Arts, our community will foster life-long learners with a sense of pride and self motivation. The Arts will be a vehicle to further our understanding of ourselves and the world around us.

The objectives and goal for the P.S. 86 Visual and Performing Arts for 2017-2018 are similar to the expectations for 2016-2017: to provide students with the tools necessary to understand and internalize the elements of art. Living with the elements of art gives students freedom to acquire self-esteem and self-mastery furthering creative momentum. Through direct involvement in an integrated Arts curriculum, students make connections with their daily lives, i.e., Math and Art, Science and Art, History and Art. Self-direction within art classes allows students to express themselves while building problem-solving skills and developing techniques used in making art: descriptive language, analysis of purpose, interpreting feelings, evaluation of art projects. Collaboration with various New York City world-class cultural organizations provides an opportunity for students to build a global arts foundation. P.S. 86 has worked with the Guggenheim "Learning Through Art" since 1997, accruing twenty-one years of exhilarating art making. (Our students art work is exhibited in The Guggenheim every May.) The P.S. 86 vendors list reflects the enriching quality of vendors who integrate the Arts, life styles and cultures of students, teachers and parents. Parents, families and friends are enthusiastic supporters of the visual and performing arts presented by the P.S. 86 school community throughout the year.
Q47_1: In the spring of 2017 P.S. 86 implemented a new program for Special Education called "Fly High". The program targeted Special Education classes: kindergarten through third grade. (The program was based on acquiring self-esteem and mastery not only in the classroom, but in alternative spaces such as gallery studio workshops and museums.) Organized through arts residencies, activities were coordinated with the 86 curriculum. Professionals in the Special Needs spectrum were invited to observe and conduct classes for these students. This year, in the Fall of 2017, the Special Education classes in grades four through six, were invited to complete the cycle with residencies conducted at the Lehman College Art Gallery. The "Fly High" program is regarded as a success with classroom teachers and students looking forward to the continuation of the program in 2018 and 2019.
Q48_2: Art teacher, visual and performing arts coordinator, P.S. 86

Q46_1: P.S. 91 has two certified Music teachers who provide Choral and General Music instruction. All students in grades kindergarten through fifth grade receive Music instruction at least one period per week. We have a certified Visual Arts teachers who provide Visual Art instruction for most students in grades K-5 for at least one period per week. Additionally, we have staff members from "Materials for the Arts" who work with classroom teachers and students on end projects, teaching Art through Social Studies content to students in grades K-5. We also have weekly Music/Orchestra, Visual Arts and Dance programs which take place after school. The school has two culminating assemblies, once in the Winter and the other in the late Spring where students perform in each of their respective disciplines. Also, once a year we have an "Art Gallery" display on our first floor where students showcase their Visual Arts.The displays are received well by parents, teachers and students. Teachers in all grades have three five-minute Dance/Movement/Theater breaks every day.
Q47_1: P.S. 91 is an elementary school in the University Heights section of the Bronx serving 766 students in grades K-5. It is presently a school in good standing in terms of NYSED accountability. We have General Education, Special Education (ICT and Self-Contained), ENL, and Bilingual classroom settings. We also offer support services that include ENL support, counseling, SETSS, occupational therapy, physical therapy, as well as mono- and bilingual speech therapy. Teacher attendance rate is 98% and student attendance is 94%. Meridith Nasjletti has been principal at this school for 7 years.

Q39_4: School sponsored Saturday Family Arts Workshops
Q46_1: During the 2017-2018 school year, we at P.S.94 believe we are giving our students another way of learning and expressing themselves, allowing them to explore new ideas and develop their imagination through Arts education. We have seen the programs in the Arts at PS 94 provide our students with skills in cooperative decision-making and leadership. It has also helped in the social and emotional development of the child, which can lead to an increase in academic achievement as well as overall school success. We have a variety of Arts partners (Lehman College Art Gallery, Studio in a School) and in-house clubs that supplement our Arts program with residencies designed to expose our children to music, theater, dance and the visual arts. It is our obligation as educators to support our students by every means possible. We will continue our Arts partnerships and engage all our learners through the Arts.
Q47_1: PS 94 the Kings College School is a kindergarten through fifth-grade school located in the Norwood section of the Bronx. We serve a unique and multicultural community. The school is situated in the hub of the Montefiore Hospital complex, the Jerome Avenue marketplace, the historically noted Gun Hill Road, Varick House Museum, and the Woodlawn Cemetery. Families from many parts of the world serve to create a distinctively rich educational and cultural community. The school student population comprises 67% Hispanic, 18% Black, 10% Asian, and 3% White. We engage in several collaborations within our school community including affiliations with Montefiore Hospital, NYC Learning Leaders Program, Moshulu Montefiore Community Center, Lehman College Art Gallery, Studio in a School, Boy Scouts, etc. PS 94 hopes to continue the arts-centered learning style which boosts achievement for our students. This can have a far-reaching effect that extends to its surrounding community.

Q46_1:
PS/MS 95 arts program is designed to expose students to various arts forms with the intent to empower creativity and socio-cultural
awareness.

The MS 118 Arts Team has followed through on our Family Arts Engagement Grant. We have had six wonderful events that have enhanced our school's relationship with the Arts.

Some highlights from our individual programs have been exploring the significance of violence in the media though theatre, exploration of impressionist painters and having students emulate their work, two ceramic pieces were accepted into the Bronx Borough Arts Festival and with the addition of our new Music teacher, several chorus groups have been established. 

Additionally, several students have been accepted to performing arts high schools, which has been of high importance to our team this year.

The RKA 10x141 Arts department has worked hard to strike a balanced approach in our middle school Arts curriculum. As students move from sixth grade to seventh, we encourage them to commit to a two-year sequence in either Visual Arts, Band or Chorus during grades 7-8. Yet, as sixth graders, they experience two half-year Arts classes so that they can make a more informed choice about the longer commitment. We are blessed with truly gifted Arts teachers who provide rich classroom instruction; these teachers also provide authentic performance experiences at our Winterfest Arts Festival and our Springfest Arts Festival. In high school there are opportunities for Advanced Ceramics in our AP Ceramics class, in addition to high school Core Art classes. We also offer a Rock Band class, Painting through History, and Ceramics electives. We are proud of the array of Arts experiences available to our students in grades 6-12

At Public School 159, we believe that Art is an integral part of the teaching and learning process. Art enables students to express their personal experiences in ways that are concrete and compelling, even when they are unable to articulate the events in words. Children love to make direct physical contact with their universe. Teaching and learning about Art allows children to develop cognitive and psychomotor skills and an appreciation for Art. Our integration of the Arts has offered our students different didactic art opportunities and learning experiences. We have also created an Arts Integration teacher who reinforces content areas through the use of Visual Arts.

P.S. 205 will continue to implement the Common Core Learning Standards and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, integrating them across the curriculum. Our interdisciplinary approach promotes student progress, improves instructional practices and leads to teacher sustainability in the Arts. In addition to our Fine Arts Curriculum (K-5), we have an additional full time cluster speciality Art teacher to service our students. Our ongoing partnership with Young Audiences enriches and deepens our instructional program by providing quality Professional Development for staff through in-class models and workshops by teaching artists both during the school day and as part of our after-school programming.  This year we became a Community School and have partnered with 21st Century to enrich our opportunities for students and families.

Teachers incorporate Art in their daily lesson plans- in addition, all children receive at least one class of Art per week by a licensed art teacher. Student art work is exhibited throughout the building. Children receive at least one period of Music per week by a licensed music teacher. Students perform two concerts for the school community and parents. Students use photography and slide shows to memorialize special events throughout the year. In order to increase the visibility of Art in our school, we have initiated an enrichment program to create murals around our school and make Art more accessible to all our students. In addition Kindergarten students have participated in a Residency program with Studio in School, as well as a participated in the Music in the Brain program. Grade One students attended a Theater performance of Junie B. Jones

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: The students at P.S. 209 are exposed to various artists and mediums that are aligned to the NYC DOE Blueprint for the Arts. Our students have opportunities to participate in Visual Art exhibits, as well as take part in Dance, Music, and Theater productions during our Fall, Winter, and Spring performances. They also have an opportunity to share their artwork and performances with their families during our quarterly culminating task celebrations. Our students receive instruction in Visual Arts, Dance, Theater and Music from outside artists as well as their classroom teachers/school based staff. These Arts residencies were initiated to provide students with additional opportunities to further their artistic capabilities. P.S. 209 Project Arts Committee also plans school-wide and grade specific field trips to cultural institutions including museums, botanical gardens and zoos throughout New York City to enable students to make meaningful connections.

As a school of Technology and Engineering, our students explore creativity through the use of technology. Within our Core subjects, we increase cultural exposure to the Arts within the general curricula. Our Core subjects have planned field trips to museums, theaters, and concerts. This year, Bronx Engineering and Technology was able to offer Art and Creative Writing as electives. Finally, all BETA students explore the Arts through their engineering courses supported by the Project Lead The Way curriculum. Additionally, sixty-five students are in the Academy of Computer Science and explore the Arts through Graphic Design and Computer curricula.

DANCE: Modern Dance and Ballet classes develop alignment awareness and strength. Through composition class students are encouraged to find their own voice as young artists.

DRAMA: Students are introduced to Acting techniques, Scene Study, Voice and Diction, Movement, Theatre History, Audition Technique, Script Analysis, Lighting Design, and Stagecraft as well as Acting Techniques for Musical Theatre productions and smaller studio settings.

VISUAL ARTS: Students develop their artistic skills through Still Life Drawing, Perspective Drawing, Portraiture, Figure Drawing, and abstract compositions using a variety of drawing, painting, and digital design media. Students develop self-confidence as they build valuable artistic, literacy and technical skills.

VOCAL: Students achieve mastery reading, performing and responding to music in subjective, aesthetic, analytic and evaluative ways. The high school choral music program incorporates the National and State standards for Music, the NYC Blueprint and elements from the Common Core curriculum. TAPCo. choral students participate and perform in a variety of vocal competitions and public venues throughout New York City.

P.S. 226X - The Nadia J. Pagan School, is a school where children come first! Our focus is building future leaders who encompass college and career readiness, a well rounded education through the Arts, and a strong foundation of 21st century skills. We are most proud of our Arts programs where students are exposed to Music, Art, and Dance. We offer a variety of cultural programs to our students that include: Chinese Dance, hip hop, Yoga, Music on Wheels, and other programs that broaden the horizons of our children. In conjunction with our partnership organizations, we house our own enrichment programs such as Student Council, Peer-to-Peer, Chess, Basketball, Photography, Cooking, Ballet, and DJ Spin Club.  Parents are so supportive of our school initiatives that are in place and our attendance rates exhibit the love that students have for coming to our school.

Jonas Bronck Academy's philosophy is to build up the entire scholar.  Scholars have been challenged to take their education to a metacognitive level. The Arts is a major part of that vision implementing the Blueprint Strands in Dance and Art. We have a full-time Dance program in place along with Dancing Classroom (8th Graders only). Our vision is to prepare our scholars in all facets of Dance, building movement and vocabulary skills as well as creating, performing and responding to Dance. The program was further enriched by a Dance Theatre of Harlem partnership which played an integral part in the implementation and connection of the Arts to a vision of college and career readiness path for the scholars. This was made possible with the assist of the Arnhold New Dance Teacher program. The Arts curricula will continue to build on itself as the foundation of Fine Arts are explored, making connections in Art and its practices to many master artists through modern art movements of the newly developed Warwick House of Street Art. LeAp is still a valuable part of the extra-curriculum vein of the school. They add Multi-Media, Cosmetology, Robotics, Fashion, Arts & Crafts, even Cooking. Many scholars are venturing into their own creativity and making life long connections. Next year's goals include a Theatre component which will add to the already rich opportunities we offer our scholars.

At The Marie Curie School For Medicine, Nursing and Health Professions, teachers endeavor to instill in the students an appreciation of the arts, as well as increase their understanding of the arts in history and the real world through hands on activities. As part of our program, the students learn about visual arts and music therapy and careers that might allow them to incorporate their love of the arts with their interest in health. Our English and Social Studies departments works with several cultural arts institutions to integrate theater and visual arts, photography, music, drama and dance into the  curriculum. They provide professional development sessions, both on and off-site to explain, demonstrate and model techniques for incorporating the arts into our academic programs to increase cultural awareness and raise student achievement by providing engaging artistic activities into their planning.

Our school offers a sequential Arts program for high school students. In grades 6-8 each student has the opportunity to take both Visual Arts and Music. At the end of 9th grade, high school students select either a Visual Arts track or a Music track. In grades 10-12, Visual Arts students take elective courses in Creative Crafts, 2D and 3D Design and have the opportunity to take Advanced Placement Studio Art in their senior year. 10th-12th grade Music students take survey courses, including Voice Training, Percussion, Guitar and Keyboard. We have increased our Arts programming with the Lehman College Art Gallery and a variety of Arts institutions throughout the city. Our vision is to continue to expand our Arts program and provide students not only with traditional hands-on arts opportunities, but with critical thinking skills in the Arts that will prepare them for the global 21st century.

We strive to offer a wide array of artistic opportunities to our students. We believe that Arts education is an integral part of the middle school experience because of the opportunities it provides to expand student engagement and encourage creativity in expression. Currently, we offer instruction in Band, Dance, Piano, Strings, and Visual Arts. To offer this range of artistic options, we actively seek to bring in cultural organizations to supplement and expand our own in-school offerings. One of our greatest partnerships is with the Park Avenue Armory which through its residency programs and student and teacher workshops has afforded our students an extraordinary level of enrichment. All our work around the Arts culminates in large-scale school performances held three times a year. These performances bring together the various artistic disciplines in a celebration of the Arts.  For instance, a poignant performance held each February is in honor of Black History Month, where our school community is able to see the fullest integration of the Arts and core subjects such as ELA and Social Studies. As a school community dedicated to increasing the exposure and learning our students gain from the arts, we look forward to future expansion and opportunities for our students to connect to and through the arts.

Q44_R4: National Museum of the American Indian
Q46_1:
In keeping with our school's mission to make all children successful learners, and in our ongoing efforts to become fully compliant with city and state arts standards, our visual arts program is especially strong. Using a variety of assessments including self-made sketchbooks to record progress, exhibits, peer conferencing and NYC Blueprint-aligned curriculum, students are immersed in the language of visual art, in art making, and in making connections from art to other knowledge including science, math and social studies. 

Traditional media including painting, drawing and sculpture are taught as well as bookmaking, puppetry, arts of other cultures and careers in the arts. 

The unique power of the arts to foster social and emotional growth is recognized and drawn upon by all staff at our school. Music, drama and dance are loved and celebrated. The arts keep children in school, and our staff's development in these areas has grown exponentially. Field trips to cultural institutions in the borough and throughout the city is extensive and carefully thought through.  

Our arts program empowers students to experience the arts as a constructive expression of human emotions and as unique intellectual disciplines.
Visual Arts and Drama

Art and Design play an increasingly important role in BASE's curriculum. In 10th grade all students take a year-long Fine Arts course that includes Theory as well as Drawing, Painting and Multi-Media work. The course also includes a full unit in Digital Design using state-of-the-art design software. Design work also plays an important role in the software engineering work students do at BASE. They learn to use Design Thinking to solve complex problems, a multi-step process that includes thinking like a designer to ensure solutions are creative and targeted to user needs.

Kingsbridge International High School has an expanding Visual Arts program, including drawing, ceramics, mosaics, and cartooning. Students have an opportunity to work with the Thrive Collection, taking one vision and turning that into a mural on the school building walls. Art clubs are also an opportunity for students to build on their skills and interest in visual art using non-traditional materials to create works that match their interests.

PS/MS 280 is a K-8 school with a total student population of 910. We have a full time certified Art teacher for grades 6-8, a second full time teacher to teach Art and Music to our K-2 students, and 3 teachers who each teach Art part-time to our grade 3-5 students. It is our goal for all students to be enriched in the Arts as much as possible: classroom teachers' support include all aspects of Art, Dance, Theater, Music and Visual Arts in their lessons by creating thematic units. Throughout the school year, all grades go on several field trips to enhance this curriculum.

We have a lot of art-related events, such as performances from Manhattan School of Music, visits to Columbia Journalism studios, field trips for films and to museums, and opportunities to participate in programs such as The Possibility Project.  We offer more hands on experiences to our student body, including crocheting, and "Soda and Painting" events, as talent shows.

PS 291 is an environment which is child centered and nurturing, recognizing the cultural diversity of our community. In partnership with our students, parents, staff, and community, there is the belief that all students can meet high standards of excellence and challenge. We believe that the role of the school and the home is to provide a climate that enhances the students’ cognitive, creative, and social growth, thereby increasing the child’s potential for success. Plans for the cultural arts initiative build upon the concepts that P.S. 291 has nurtured in our school: to support and sustain standards-based programming embedded in curriculum, supporting literacy and providing opportunities for our students to creatively express themselves using the four arts disciplines -- music, dance, visual arts, and theater. The visual and performing arts have played an important part in our school community for years. Art instruction is aligned with the art standards.

Our Visual Art and Dance teachers offer sequential art instruction to all students in grades K-5. Students are also given in-school art residencies in Visual Arts, Creative Dance, Ballroom Dancing and theater. We offer interdisciplinary connections to help build on the students learning inside the classroom. Our Visual Arts teacher  and Dance teacher develops integrated Arts units that are designed to enhance the New Arts Standards and align to the New York City Arts Blueprints. Through creating, performing, responding and connecting, students are able to develop their art skills and imaginations. Students learn to understand how others express themselves through Music, Dance and Visual Arts. Our students learn to share ideas and emotions and learn how to turn those into images, sounds, and actions. As our students create artistically through the Arts, they become more imaginative and strengthen their problem-solving skills.

P.S. 307's goal remains to infuse the 4 Art strands into Core subjects and to instill an appreciation for the Arts throughout our school community. Our Arts program continues to be enriched by both a CASA Grant (thanks to Councilman Cabrera) and a SPARK Educational Grant from The New Victory Theater.  These 2 grants have given all our students the opportunity to participate in 14 week arts residencies.  For the 2017-18 school year, the CASA grant gave our K-2nd graders the opportunity to participate in dance residencies with teaching artists from The Town Hall and our 5th graders the opportunity to work with a theater artist and create their own scripts.  CASA Grant residencies all culminated with performances for families. 3rd and 4th graders worked with 2 New Victory theater teaching artists for 14 weeks and attended 3 performances at The New Victory Theater.  For the 5th year, we had a Musical Theater Revue, consisting of 3rd, 4th and 5th graders who auditioned to become cast members.  They worked with both a theater and music teaching artist and culminated their residency with 3 performances (2 for their peers and 1 for their families). For the 9th consecutive year we held 2 Saturday Family Arts' Institutes; one for K-2nd grade & one for 3rd – 5th grade.  This year’s art projects centered on S.T.E.A.M. projects (Science Technology Engineering Art Math)such as lighthouses, merry-go-rounds, bridges and electric robots.
Q47_1: We are a small non-DOE building that is over-utilized.  We have no space for dance practices and only one gym and no yard which creates scheduling conflicts.

Q46_1: The Bronx Dance Academy provides

P.S. 310 goal is to provide an Arts curriculm aligned with the BluePrint for the Arts, and supports the Common Core Learning Standards We believe Arts instruction enhance academic performance,and teachers are aware of the value of the integration of Dance, Music and Visual Arts in the content area.
Q47_1: P.S. 310 Complex is divided into four mini schools. One of the mini schools is the Achieving Reading Together Through the Arts Academy. The integration of the arts is the academy's focus. Students in grades 3-5 have the opportunity to major in dance, visual arts, music or theatre arts. At the end of the year, the academy presents their version of a Broadway show. The entire school and the community are invited to this arts celebration.

Q46_1: Students at the Lab School will demonstrate independence and develop content knowledge through creative expression in the Arts. This will be measured by assessing growth in Music composition and performance. •Twice a week, students in grades K-8 will be offered Music instruction by full-time certified teacher. Twice a week, students in grade K-8 will be provided with a music curriculum that is aligned with New York State Standards and the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts by a full-time certified Music teacher •	We offer weekly 45-minute small group instruction in Music for selected students. Selected students in grades 5-8 will have the opportunity to participate in the after school enrichment Music program. Selected classes will receive instruction in various art forms from cultural arts organizations. At least 4 performance opportunities:  2 Cultural Arts Presentations, Kindergarten and 8th grade Graduation will be given by the end of the year.

The Arts program exposes young people to the many facets of the arts; it is our goal that all of our students will stimulate their creative thinking and use the knowledge and skills to enhance their problem solving abilities. It is our intention that this exposure will provide enrichment and a lifetime of arts enjoyment and appreciation.

We believe in providing Arts opportunities throughout the school day to expose all students to many art forms. We also believe in offering many after school activities for students who are interested to expand their opportunities to experience the Arts. We offer many extra-curricular arts opportunities including; Music, Visual Arts, Digital Media and Dance. Students have an opportunity to work with resident artists and attend many arts-related field trips. On Saturdays we host the Fred Dolan Art Academy which provides visual arts instruction and college preparedness support to Middle and High School students who are serious about visual arts.

P.S. 340 continues to provide quality Visual Arts instruction to our students. Our Visual Arts teacher continued to support the content area curriculum through the Arts. Our Social Studies and Art teacher continued their initiative of incorporating both content area curriculum using the valuable tools they learned at workshops last year. This year we partnered with the Lehman Collage Arts Department to incorporate our immigration curriculum with our visual arts curriculum.  Students had the experience of learning social studies content through different mixed media as well as take multiple gallery tours. During the year, we also had a genre of arts programs through our relationship with Marquis Studios.  These programs have exposed our students to different mediums such as architecture, film making drumming and puppetry.  This opportunity allowed our students to see how art is intertwined into many different aspects of learning and their world. We will continue our relationship with Dancing Classrooms to help students achieve social awareness and build relationships with their peers. We will also continue having Theater Movies which provides our students with an outlet to express their emotions and build self-esteem.Our goal is to continue providing positive rewarding experiences through the Arts that will provide students with the skills and knowledge they need to be well-rounded individuals who make sound aesthetic choices.

This year the school provided a variety of opportunities to engage students in the Arts. Grades 6-8 students received visual art instruction twice or three times a week, while students in grades 9-12 had the opportunity to attend one of the three art studio courses (an entry-level studio art 1 and 2, drawing and painting and AP Art in drawing), five times a week. In addition, all students were offered an opportunity to participate in an after school dance program. This year the school also provided a variety of opportunities to engage students in the arts, participating in our annual talent show as well as outings to museums, films, plays and Broadway musicals. Furthermore, the high school art teacher also runs an after school Art club, and organized a three-visit partnership with the Museum of Modern Art. High school students also visited the Bronx Art Museum and the MET Museum. The middle school participated in visits to the MET and Lehman College Art Gallery, and four middle school classes received a series of nine workshops through the Lehman College Art Gallery residency.The school year will end celebrating the year with our our school-wide arts exhibition, which will be in displayed throughout the hallways in mid-June.

We continued our collaboration with Alvin Ailey Dance in grades 2-5, including African and Jazz. AmPark provided Art and Music to students at every grade level. We have a Music room equipped with instruments, and an Art room equipped with arts materials. Our 1-3 grade students attended three outside theater performances and partnered with New Victory Theaters. Our Art program allows children to work with a large range of materials and media, and develop skills and knowledge of art concepts. Much of the work is in collaboration with classroom teachers, and expands on the themes being learned in students' classrooms. In Music, children learn an expansive repertoire of songs. They explore notation, beat, and rhythm using their voices as well as instruments. There are several presentations throughout the year for families.  our fifth grade students began a new partnership with the Bronx Documentary Center that allowed them to explore photography.

Our school currently has full-time staff to provide Visual Arts and Music throughout the four-year sequence, as well as a part-time bandleader.  Our music curriculum focuses on the cultural aspects and relevance of the arts, including social justice impacts, the ethnomusicological history of world music, and the ways in which social changes have impacted the evolution of music.

We have an Art/Math program that teaches mathematical concepts to children through the visual arts. Where possible, the students use vocabulary and expressions related to mathematics. The children use art materials and resources and analyze art. They explore how artists are inspired and how culture influences Art.

In 2017-2018, MS363 will offer a Visual Arts program to all 6th grade students and a Music program to all 7th grade students. 8th grade students will receive Music and Art. The focus of each program will be for students to use the Arts to relate to everyday problem-solving and to make connections to the social and emotional issues they are faced with. Students will use different expressive techniques to become better learners and leaders.

While IN-Tech Academy is known as a technology school offering many Advanced Placement courses, we are also a school that is proud of our arts programs. We have a high school drama production in the fall and a middle school musical in the spring. We have visual art displays in our courtyard and in the hallway leading to the auditorium, which is visible from the street outside our building. We have band performances in the winter and spring. Our facilities include three kilns, several pottery wheels, a band room and a room designed as a dance studio. We also take students on trips to see Broadway shows and the STREB Lab for Action Mechanics. This year STREB performers worked directly with a group of middle and high school students. More could be added, but suffice it to say that the arts are as much a consideration at IN-Tech Academy as technology and AP courses. We work with the whole scholar.
Currently, due to a lack of funding, PS 382 does not have a viable arts program.

Q44_R2: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation

Q46_1: We presently offer Visual Arts and Orchestra. Our goal is to provide our diverse population with opportunities to explore the different art forms, the integration of the Arts using an interdisciplinary approach across content area thus following the Common Core curriculum. It is our plan to offer Digital Arts/ multimedia design and orchestra for the 2018-2019 school year. Our Arts program continues to allow students to develop creatively and challenge their knowledge of style, artistic and cultural contributions to the world of the Arts. We support the individual talents that students posses in Music performance, Music Theory and Visual Arts. We accomplish this through integration of curriculum across the content areas, while maintaining high expectations through standards-based education. Keeping with the Common Core standards, Math and Literacy continue to play an important role. As students use skills in measurement, experimentation, reading comprehension, expand vocabulary and defend opinions through arguments while exposed to a variety of text, visual representations lead student discussion and dialogue as they acquire meaning. We prepare students during the middle school years to be armed with the tools and achievement expectation that will afford them successful paths in high school and college.

The current Arts program at The Angelo Part School continues to grow.  We have added Red Bulll Theater to our list of art based organizations and students in our ELT program experienced Shakespeare through theater and workshops.  Broadway Jr continues and is an integral part of our extended day enrichment program.  We continue to have DreamYard for our students and they write and present poetry for the Spoken Word competitions as well as for their peers.  Our main community based organists, Replications, provides mask making, graffiti art, monologue writing and performing, for our students during Extended Learning Time.  Students, teachers and families visit many cultural organizations throughout New York City, including Bronx Museum of the Arts, MOMA, The Met Museum, as well as Broadway Shows.

An integral part of our educational vision, the Arts program at P.S.396 provides a comprehensive, learner-centered approach to instruction in Music, theater and the fine arts. Our goal is to provide an equitable and accessible arts education for all students. We believe in the importance of recognizing, honoring and supporting students’ different learning styles and in developing questioning and decision-making skills that inspire them to embrace their own authentic voice. Conceptual, critical and creative thinking, social skills and cultural awareness are all aspects of art and music making that are nurtured and encouraged at PS 396. The Music, Art and Theater teachers, along with resident artists, collaborate with classroom teachers to support our inter-disciplinary curriculum and celebrate school events. In addition to our designated program, we enrich the Arts experience for our students with parent and child art workshops, arts residencies, after school enrichment programs, cultural partnerships and museum visits.

Q47_1: We are a Transfer school with a 100%  ENL population with an average age of 17.5.  We have students from a variety of backgrounds and languages and are located in The Bronx.

Q46_1: Students in grades 9-12 receive visual arts instruction in Required Art and Painting courses. Students also have an opportunity to participate in our Expanded School: Studio in a School afterschool program.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_R3: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our school's arts program includes a visual and creative arts elements which focuses on sketch art, pottery, mannequin and marionette making and mural design and painting. Tenth, eleventh, and twelfth grade students have the opportunity to enroll in elective drama, modern art appreciation, and music appreciation and film classes. Additionally, ninth grade English language learners receive dramatic instruction through Lincoln Center Project LEAD. Tenth grade students participate, with an artist in residence, the August Wilson LeAp program which provides them the opportunity to perform at the annual August Wilson Monologue competition. Extra-curricular activities include guitar club, photography club and digital editing. PM school College Now courses include photo and digital music composition as well as a graphic arts classes in conjunction with Bronx Community College. Additionally, New Beginnings Performing Arts Studio provides ninth graders with a residency program in dance. We continue to partner with Theater for a New Audience. Furthermore, this year we have expanded the variety of field trips to include trips to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for ALL 9th graders as well as continued trips to BAM for the annual poetry presentation.

Fordham High School for the Arts is an audition based school offering 6 arts majors: dance, drama, music production & engineering//instrumental, technical theater, visual art and vocal music. Our teachers are artists and educators creating a professional learning environment for our young scholars to be fully and adequately prepared with college and career readiness skills. The Creative Arts Department believes in creating multiple opportunities for students to perform both inside and outside of the school as part of their learning and assessment. Our studios are equipped with current technology and are being continuously updated to ensure 21st Century learning. We have a newly renovated auditorium equipped with state of the art lighting and sound equipment to create professional productions.  Students participate in competitions, showcases, senior exit projects and adjudication events. Each arts studio provides students with the opportunity to graduate withe a Chancellor's Endorsed diploma in their art major. At FHSA, academics and the arts are equally weighed ensuring well-rounded and educated graduates. We offer 7 AP courses, along with opportunities for internships and work-based learning.

Q47_1: The students run the broad spectrum. There are some who have delved in art before while others are just exploring. The students are required to have 1 credit in the Arts in order to fulfill their graduation requirements. Some students are also exploring what they would like to do post-secondary related to the Arts.

Q46_1: We continue to work closely with our art teacher to ensure that he has the resources to develop student skills and to engage them in projects that challenge their abilities in the realm of visual arts. Additionally, we have noted student enthusiasm and requests and have subsequently expanded our art program to include an after school art club. This program allows students to continue working on various class projects after school or to engage themselves in a special project designed for the group by our art teacher. We have installed a Mac lab and have begun the process of introducing students to photography and graphic design skills. We have also created a music program that is conducted twice a week during the students’ lunch period and after school. This program has been expanded to include instruction with musical instruments. Based upon the level of student participation, we hope to continue and to expand this program still further.

We will continue to offer ceramics, fine arts band and general music. We have added painting, figure studies, marching band, modern band. We will be continuing to grow the arts department by adding digital music production/performance. We will continue to grow our theatre department by add new course work on a four year sequence.

Our music department offers a diverse and challenging course of study in music. From performance fundamentals studied freshman year, to conducting, writing, and reading all levels and styles of music, we continue to offer quality music education to each and every student in our school. Included are sequential programs in string orchestra, band, piano, and choir, with multiple ensembles to suit every ability level.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1:
School’s Arts Program Description 2017-2018
The Bronx High School of Science adds a great deal to our STEM education focus with several opportunities for our students to explore the ARTS . It is our mission to provide our students with opportunities for interdisciplinary experiences that combine the unique mix of fine arts, arts, music and drama. Our students have a regular opportunity to perform.  At Science, we enjoyed a high-caliber winter concert and spring concert featuring our Concert Band, Jazz Band, Chorus and Orchestra. These groups are preparing for the spring concert. Our fall play: The Glass Menagerie was a big hit and our spring musical: The Drowsy Chaperone is in rehearsal for a late May performance. S!NG gave a smashing performance of hysterical spoofs written and performed by its many members. Our students have participated in our annual Mask Creation Contest, Japanese Singing Contest and were winners in many photography contests. Many of our artists have been recognized in myriad contests around the city.  Our Art History students are preparing to take the AP exam in May as well.

Through Lincoln Center we are providing our students with experiences in dance, music, theater, visual arts and mixed media. We are integrating the arts through our social studies curriculum.  Our students have visited various art institutions to view the collections relevant to our social studies units with the Lincoln Center Teaching Artists. Students have also seen performances both in school and at Lincoln Center in the above mentioned genres. The entire school had the opportunity to attend performances at Lincoln Center. Our arts committee has planned and implemented a family arts event for our community. The goal of our school is to ensure that the arts are a rountine for students, parents and our entire school community. Lincoln Center has facilitated multiple professional learning activities for all staff members on incorporating art into all content areas.  In addition to Lincoln Center Education, our school has a growing orchestra program. Sixth and seventh graders receive orchestra instruction during the day and we have an elective afterschool Orchestra Club. Members of the club will be going to NYSSMA and will perform three pieces that they have learned. Our orchestra will perform "Pomp and Circumstance" as well as "The Star Spangled Banner" at Graduation. 
We also have a partnership with Dreamyard that provides dance instruction for students.

East Fordham Academy for the Arts provides all students with the opportunity to select from a menu of visual arts, music, theater, and/or dance as an arts elective, and study their chosen art form for three years. Our comprehensive arts programs gives students the opportunity to develop their talents in a variety of dance genres such as, jazz, cultural, ballroom, ballet, and performance dance. Students can also practice chorus, vocals, concert band, sculpting, sketching, painting, set design and mural design. In addition, we have partnerships with various cultural organizations, including Bronx Arts Ensemble, Broadway Jr., Doing Art Together!, and Dancing Classrooms. Through these partnerships, we are able to provide students with direct arts education with experts in various fields. Our arts goal for the 2017-2018 school year is for students to express themselves in various art forms through performances, develop leadership skills by sharing performance and classroom responsibilities, articulate connections between the arts and their own emerging identities as artists, and become informed about the live performances they will attend. Our ultimate goal is to become the model middle school for the arts in New York City.

Audio for Video and Video Production (post-production, editing, writing, split-writing) OR Final Cut Certification Level 2 --Financial Career Management (Computer Technology / Audio Arts /Visual Arts / Production / Engineering / CFM)

The Arts program at Bronx Theatre High School provides students with a well-rounded exposure to various forms of the arts. Students at Bronx Theatre High School are encouraged early on to work with each other as an ensemble, and this is conveyed through performance, set and costume design and visual arts. As students progress through grade levels, they are given numerous opportunities to work with content teachers and Roundabout Theatre Teaching Artists to explore various aspects of the arts including set, sound and lighting design, costume design, and acting. Students who express interest in dance work with our in-house STEP company and choreograph performances. All graduating seniors have the opportunity to celebrate graduation at a Roundabout Theatre Broadway stage. Advanced, and dedicated thespians, who earn 10 or more art/theatre credits (including Advanced Placement Studio Art and Photography/Videography) are eligible to sit for the Comprehensive Theatre Exam in their senior year providing them with an opportunity for an Arts Endorsed Regents upon graduation. Roundabout Theatre Company has been our partnering organization since the opening of the school in 2003 and continues to provide services to our students through in-class residencies and pre/post-show workshops. Studio Art and Advanced Placement Studio Art are offered at the school.  Students complete a sequence of course work and generate a portfolio of various projects including Pop Art, Abstract Drip Art and Multi-Media Collage.

Discovery integrates the arts throughout its socials studies curriculum. In particular, Discovery offers its students an US Art History and Appreciation course as a compliment to the US History course offered at the eleventh-grade level. This course enables students to develop a basic understanding of how to examine art as well as an appreciation for the ways in which historical and cultural periods of American history were manifested in the art that they produced. Students leave the course with a deeper understanding for history and a greater appreciation for the visual arts.

Our School Arts Program offers differentiated access for all students through visual art classes and a guitar club and an after school Theater Program. After two required visual art courses, our students take art electives. We have an Art Club to provide greater access to studio time for each student. Two days a week there is art instruction and five days a week there is guitar instruction during the lunch period. The Parents’ Association also enjoys art-making experiences.
     We aim to nurture a school culture that is supported by commitment to our students’ creativity and their thoughtful, reflective participation in the community. This year, one of our students attended the seven hour Saturday Program of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art and created work along with other top art students in our city that culminated with two gallery exhibitions. Two of our students participated in the Bronx Borough Art Exhibition at Lehman College and students submitted work for the prestigious PS Art Competition.
Our art teacher facilitates the “Arts Mondays” Professional Learning Community for Bronx Secondary school art teachers. Thus, our school administration both supported the Chancellor’s Vision to build highly effective systems for evaluating students’ academic growth and persistence with optimal cognition using Art Studio Habits of Mind as identified by Howard Gardner’s Project Zero. We furthered our partnership with Lehman College Art Gallery which was supported by an Arts and Family Engagement grant.

Our arts program has a number of important goals. We seek, as part of our focus on American studies, to expose students to the careful study of art and music history. We also provide students with the skills necessary to create meaningful works of art on their own. Finally, we place great emphasis on inculcating in our students an interest in seeing and thinking about gallery and museum exhibits, plays, operas, musicals, and other theatrical performances, contemporary film, and modern and classical dance.

Q39_4: Sat Arts program open to parents
Q46_1: Public School 16 provides arts programs in the three disciplines of dance, music, and theater for students in pre-kindergarten through 5th grades. Arts instruction is provided by teaching artists from our established partnerships with the cultural organization of Bronx Arts Ensemble. These programs are supported, in part, by public funds from the NYC Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council. To support and maintain school-wide arts instruction aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts, the teaching artists collaborate and plan with teachers in addition to providing professional development for classroom and cluster teachers during the school day. City Council funding also supports our after school African Dance and Drums Program and Saturday Arts program of Potter, Mosaics, Painting and Jewelry Making. We also offer arts workshops and provide opportunities for parents to participate in arts instruction children during Saturday classes, school trips and other parent engagement activities.
Q47_1: Our Arts program outside of our classroom teachers, is dependent on grants from our City Council. Due to budgetary constraints, we can not provide a full-time Art teacher.

Q46_1: PS 19 has a certified art teacher providing art services to students in grades K-6. For the past 15 years, PS 19 has partnered with Bronx Arts Ensemble to deliver art, music and dance instruction to all our students in grades K-8. PS 19's facilities are limited due to overcrowding and an on-going construction project, but we strive to provide as much arts education as possible. Students who participate in dance and music through programs not offered within our school are given the opportunity to display their talents in our school concerts and shows.

Q47_1: CASA went from Jan. 2018-April 2018

Q46_1: We provide music and dance education through our relationship with the 92nd Street Y. We also offer after school enrichment programs in which students can develop their talents in dance, music, drama, technical and visual arts. We produce an annual student talent show, display student art work throughout the building and expose our students to culturally diversified field trips

This is PS 68's 20th year of collaboration with Education Through Music, Inc. ETM provides a teaching artist for our string orchestra as well as provide professional development and mentor ship to general music teachers. The artist provides instruction twice weekly during and after school hours. Our grade 4 and grade 5 string orchestras are made up of approximately fifty students  who receive instruction on their string instrument of choice. Our music program is comprised of general music, recorder, violin, viola, cello, and bass. General music instruction is provided one to two times weekly for fifty minutes for Pre K-5th grades. We also have a grade 3-5 chorus that meets twice weekly after school. All students perform in at least one concert each semester as well as at festivals, presentations, and graduations. Additionally, after school services in music, dance, drama, and the visual arts are provided by the Phipps Community Development Corporation, which provides instruction to 100 of our students.

As part of our commitment to provide a quality education to all students, we believe in arts education. Our partnership with Education Through Music has given our students the opportunity to have formalized general music instruction in all grades and to participate in various concerts and performances. In addition to formal music instruction, our 5th grade students participate in weekly band lessons as well. Students in grades K-5 also receive visual art instruction by a certified visual art teacher. Additional partnerships with Alvin Ailey Dance Company allow us to expose our students to other art forms. We will continue to make connections between the arts and all disciplines. We will continue with our vision to increase arts education for all students in grades K-5.

For the 2017-2018 school years we have continued our partnership with Notes in Motion providing dance instruction to identified students on grades two and three. Over the past ten years, we have experienced great success through our partnership with Notes in Motion. Each year the cooperating teachers and the dance instructors meet to determine the focus for the year. This allows the teaching artists to connect their lessons to an academic focus area. In addition, this year we have expanded the program to include a Parent Dance Workshop, where parents had the opportunity to learn some of the dance pieces their children learned. 
Our second partnership has been with Inside Broadway: This is a theater residency with identified fourth and fifth grade students. Here students are given the opportunity to create and perform in their very own musical. This residency helps to bolster our students’ confidence level as they perform for their audience. Students and parents are excited about this wonderful opportunity and show their full support at our culminating performance. In addition, six of our third grade students were awarded dance scholarships through Ballet Tech. This year, we hosted three seasonal performances and two performances for our dance and theater residencies. These performances serve as an excellent medium for our parents, teachers and student body to watch our student performers as they showcase their talents and the skills.

Our collaboration with Education Through Music continues to enhance our string instrumental program. The school orchestra has grown from forty-two students in its first year to ninety-two students in our fourth year! This year the orchestra collaborated with One World Middle School in a holiday and spring concert, to the delight of students seeking admission to the school in sixth grade. P.S. 87 will join several schools across the city in an annual performance at Lehman College. Our long term partnership with Studio in a School creates a vibrant visual arts environment.
