Our dance program in K-2 is made possible through a collaboration with Music for Many and it was expanded this year to include kindergarten.  Our Equity Focus this year was around Boys of Color and we introduced an all-boys Hip Hop group in Grade 3/4. Grade 1 performance of Lion King World has become a school tradition. A teacher introduced a new club this year called, “Lights! Camera! Action! Students were introduced to the world of movies and film making.  Students performed all the roles from generating ideas, script writing, storyboarding, acting, directing and many different roles behind the camera.

Public School 96, The Richard Rodgers School, is a diverse school community committed to creating an educational environment of excellence for all participants. Our goal is to have all of our students take an active role in their arts education through hands- on activities and explorations. PS 96 offers arts education in the fields of visual arts, music, dance and theater through granted programs, programs through cultural organizations, and in class instruction. We are proud of the programs that are available to our students including chorus, band, and Dancing Classrooms. Our students receive weekly arts and music education. Many are able to take part in an abundance of after school arts programs including Little Orchestra and a variety of programs through the 21st Century Leadership Grant in dancing, theater and music. Parents and families are connected to their students' arts education through our interactive online art gallery featured on artsonia.com. Parents have also connected to their child's art education through after school engagement opportunities such as work shops and parent nights such as paint nights!

Here at PS 97, the art and music department work hard to integrate the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning and the Common Core Curriculum into our teaching.   With Education Through Music, students in grades 4th and 5th audition to be part of the chorus.   The chorus puts hosts concerts for award ceremonies, graduation ceremonies, and seasonal concerts for the entire school to enjoy.  This Select Chorus also participates at the Lehman College music festival.  Students in 3rd, 4th, and 5th are also apart of the recorder club.  Many students chose to join a club which meets during their recess time. These students can be apart of chorus, recorder group, or a visual arts club.  The 5th grade students also have the opportunity to participate in the percussion ensemble during club hours. The visual arts club creates inspirational posters for the school, dance festival posters for each class in the school, and decorations for school awards assemblies. All students participate in the annual dance festival. Each grade creates a choreographed dance which is performed for the school, parents, and community. In addition to the events that take place during school hours, families participate in Family Art Night. These events take place twice a year and over two hundred people have enjoyed spending time painting and creating art.

The goals of the visual arts and music program are to allow students to experience a robust rewarding and challenging curriculum. Students are introduced to various art forms and music education. Through exploration, students improve in other academic areas. Our main goal is to enrich their arts experiences on a day-to-day basis by allowing them to form connections, make choices, and converse with each other about their work. Building upon and scaffolding with their other subjects in school makes a more rewarding learning experience for our students.

PS 105 continues to be dedicated to providing our students with exposure to a variety of disciplines in the arts. We employ two full-time music teachers, a full-time drama teacher, and a full-time visual arts teacher. We also have a number of affiliations with outside organizations, such as National Dance Institute, Inside Broadway, and Project BOOST.The drama club, chorus and art club attend a yearly trip to Broadway, and have seen such shows as Stomp, Annie, Wicked, and this year, School of Rock.  Specific highlights our arts programs include: Select third Grade students participate in the Inside Broadway Theater program and work toward a culminating end of the year show which is performed for our school community and their parents.NDI provides themed expressive dance workshops for grade 4, also with a culminating activity/performance that took place this May. SWAT is an after school dance program offered through NDI, that provides dance enrichment for selected students of various grade levels; The school chorus and band perform both on and off-site concerts throughout the year. This year the chorus has performed at the Bronx Veteran's Hospital, a tree lighting ceremonies throughout the Bronx; the school drama program performs various shows throughout the year including a Black History Performance for our school community; the school art club creates the setting and backdrops for our school performances. Our Step Team is participating in our district Arts Showcase mid June as well.

The PS 106 school community strives to provide a balanced arts education program which includes music, drama and visual arts. Our teachers are passionate about education and our belief in arts education as a key component in every child's learning. Collaboration among students, staff and parents is the foundation for supporting student learning in all areas. Our arts teachers partner with one another, as well as other teachers, in an effort help students make connections between the arts and across the curriculum. Our common goal is to escalate student participation, heighten best practices in teaching and include parents and community in our partnership for an exemplary arts education program. We also work in collaboration with available artist residency programs to expose our students to as much culture and experience in the arts as possible. This year our residency programs included Dancing Classrooms, Park Avenue Armory, and Disney Kids. This year, in preparation for our production of Aladdin Jr., parents were invited to participate with their children in set and stage prop design during parent involvement time. Each of these experiences allows students to make connections between the arts while applying depth of knowledge in core subjects, including language arts, math and social studies. Together, our teachers are working to help our students to grow creatively and intellectually, while having positive experiences for self-expression.

At the Philip J Abinanti School the arts programs offered provide many opportunities for students to express themselves.  There is one Visual Arts teacher and one Music teacher that service approximately 600 students throughout the academic year.  Each class from Kindergarten through 5th grade engages in a minimum of 45 minutes per week of visual arts education and 45 minutes per week of music education.  
Second grade students have the opportunity to "Build a Musical." A resident from the Inside Broadway organization visits the school two times per week for 2 hours from February to May.  This program was made possible by a generous grant given by Councilman James Vacca. 
Five second grade students traveled to the Ballet Tech School in the city to participate in a 4 month program in which they learned various ballet techniques. 
Through collaboration between the P.T.A. and administrators, all grades are able to participate in assemblies that promote art culture.  For example, Kindergarten through 2nd grade students were given the opportunity to view Chinese acrobats perform and were then engaged in a question and answer session. Additionally, fifth grade students participated in weekly practice for the months of October and November to prepare for P.S.108's annual Veterans Day celebration.  Students were taught choreography and practiced singing songs related to various time periods in our nation's history. Students then performed these learned dances and songs for honored Veterans.

Our grade 2 and 3 classes participated in the 92nd St Y musical introduction series. Students and teachers engaged in four concerts and twelve in-school visits by music teaching artists including two pre-visits and one post-visit per concert. Teachers remained with the class for the entire duration of the session.

Our grade 1 classes participated in the Bilingual Birdies classes. A trained Bilingual
Teaching Musicians utilize guitars and percussion instruments to introduce basic vocabulary through song, dance, and puppetry.

Our school art program will focus more on visual arts, dance and music in the upcoming school year. We are excited with our past partnerships with LEAP, Notes In Motion and Inside Broadway and will extend these through next year.

We offer students a choice of arts electives 2-4 times per week. This year’s arts elective class choices are visual arts, dance, music and theater. Our visual and music arts classes are taught by  full-time certified arts teachers and our dance/theater classes are taught by a teachers who also share other responsibilities. We continue to utilize Musica De Camera as one of the finest arts organizations NYC has in classical music. Our music program is budding every year with performances showcasing the best MS 127 has to offer. Our partnership with our after school program, Sports and Arts in Schools, continues to offer students with additional instruction and exposure in the arts. This year we hosted Annie Jr., which congealed all the arts resources from all departments into the performance. It was a monumental performance which was well attended and supported.

JHS 144 has a tradition of providing students with educational opportunities in the arts. The students at J.H.S. 144 are offered music, visual art and theater. The school employs a full time music and art teacher along with a part time theater teacher. This year the students have been awarded scholarships to arts summer camps, as well as acceptances to many of New York City's arts high schools. Music instruction centers around the J.H.S. 144 Band program where there is an emphasis placed upon instrumental performance and music literacy. The visual art program focuses on art making and is project based. The Arts Department produces two shows a year where the students perform or exhibit work. For the past five school years, J.H.S. 144 has partnered with Lincoln Center Education as part of the "Arts in the Middle" grant. This year, the students traveled to Lincoln Center to attend  performances as well as to art museums to study works with a Lincoln Center teaching artist.

Q39_4: Help with the transportation of equipment to venues
Q46_1: P.S. 153 has a full time music teacher who teaches key boarding to Grades K-2 students, using the Music in the Brain curriculum. In grades 4-5 students are invited to participate in band or chorus which meet afterschool two days per week. We also have a visual arts teacher who teaches classes in Grades K-5. In addition, we partner with organizations such as Dancing Classrooms which provides all fifth grade students instruction in ballroom dancing.  We also partner with Bronx Arts Ensemble who supports our SEM and afterschool instruction. Bronx Arts Ensemble provides African drumming lessons, instrument lessons and dance lessons. Bronx Opera provides theater/music opportunities for students in grades 4 and 5. Classroom teachers are encouraged to use the Blueprints for Arts to incorporate the arts into the content areas. Teachers also plan educational trips to various cultural organizations to expose students to other arts that are aligned to our curriculum.

Because the mission of PS 160 is to provide a standards-based education through high expectations and creativity, it is the goal of the school’s art program to follow NCCAS, NY State, and NYC Blueprint standards in providing sequential music and visual arts instruction from Pre-K to Grade 5. It is also the school’s goal to expose the students, over the course of their years at PS 160, to the other branches of the arts: dance and theater. Furthermore, PS 160 is moving toward a model of education that is cross curricular in all grades.
Q47_1: PS 160X – The Walt Disney Magnet STEAM School – is a Pre-K - 5 elementary school in section 5 of Co-op City in the Bronx. In the fall of 2017, it received a federal STEAM grant. Throughout the year, the curriculum is organized around four main units of study. All subject matter is planned with these units in mind. Students are also involved in completing Project Based Learning based on these units of study.

Q46_1: Students are exposed to a general music program and then they have the option to join the school's orchestra in grade 4. Music is taught both as a subject in its own right and as a means of supporting learning in other areas. Our music program aims to support students' learning and development in music and in all areas, and to build the musical capacity of our students by partnering with middle schools in our zone. The following components are used to reinforce music's role as a core subject: Music instruction for every child that follows a skills-based, comprehensive and sequential curriculum that aligns with state and national arts learning standards and the Common Core. Our visual arts program is designed to provide students the opportunity to create and design artistic projects aligned with the curriculum.

P.S 175 values the arts and provides students multiple opportunities to engage in several arts genres.  We have part-time certified music and drama teachers who work with students on musical and theatrical performance skills.  We also have a visual artist from the Bronx Arts Ensemble that provides students in all grades with visual arts instruction.  Students have attended performances of the American Ballet Theater, New York Philharmonic and Broadway shows.

PS 178X, The Magnet School for Multimedia Arts & Design, is committed to providing a well rounded arts education. The arts are alive, well, and celebrated at PS 178X. All students, K-5, participate in grade-wide assembly presentations. Classroom teachers, with the support of our arts teachers, produce and direct student performances that tap each arts discipline. Art work for the stage is created to set the scene for each assembly to further enhance the audience's experience. PS 178X teachers continue to enhance and infuse arts instruction via an integrated curriculum as per our magnet grant.  Cultural organization partnerships provide professional development for teachers as well as direct instruction for students.  Said collaboration has provided students and teachers with opportunities to fuse cross-curricula knowledge to yield I-stop motion videos featuring themselves as characters in a popular text, visual effect news casting from outer space via the green screen, theatrical on-stage performances of students' creative writing, as well as physical models of the Great Wall of China, LEGO robots, and the replication of worm holes in space.  Our end-term celebrations highlight our arts education program and include music, singing, dance, and public speaking. Our goal is to continue to further develop the teaching and learning of music, visual art, theater, and dance.

The staff, students, parents and community of M.S. 180 are devoted to academic excellence and the cultivation of individual strengths and talents in a safe and supportive environment where individual differences and respect for the rights of others guide school and community behavior. The Arts are a vital component to the educational philosophy design and program at the Dr. Daniel Hale Williams Middle School for the Visual and Performing Arts. The Arts provide the motivation, the challenge, the direction, the recognition, and the self-esteem essential to the emotional, social, and academic success of our students. The school curriculum affords each student the opportunity to achieve and demonstrate high standards in many domains, such as the arts, academics and athletics. Our goal for all students is to prepare them to become productive and responsible members of the culturally diverse global community. Middle School offers the following arts program three (3) times a week for each grade:
Art, Band, Orchestra, Chorus, Theater, Dance, Visual Art, Film & Photography, and Music Technology.

Our schools' arts program provides a variety of opportunities for all members of the school community to be exposed to, appreciate, and participate in the arts. Our arts program continues to show exemplary results year after year. These talents are showcased with several vocal and instrumental themed concerts and assemblies throughout the school year. Our annual Art Expo which is held in May highlights outstanding student art work, from kindergarten through eighth grade. It is an integral part of the school culture, as shown in displays throughout the building. Literacy competencies are also embedded within the arts curriculum to support our students’ growth in the area of English Language Arts

The school's art program seeks to engage students in the visual arts through an interdisciplinary lens that incorporates the school's Health Theme and the Common Core Literacy Standards. For example, elective courses such as the human body support both the visual arts as well as writing across the content areas.
Q47_1: Had an ATR visual arts teacher this year.

Q46_1: The Bronx High School for Writing and Communication Arts offers a wide variety of courses and programs for students in the arts. From creative writing, journalism, and playwriting to drawing, painting, sculpture, drama, film and photography we provide opportunities for students to be involved in the arts in and out of the classroom. We partner with Epic Theatre Ensemble, Exploring the Arts Foundation, Open Door Arts in Education, and Community Word Project to provide arts enrichment in drama, film, writing, visual arts, dance, and stagecraft. Our award-winning lead partner Epic Theatre Ensemble works with us to engage our students in contemporary social justice issues through acting and playwriting. Our ETA grant expands the Epic program with a dynamic film program. Community Word Project teaching artists work with our students to create and perform poetry and  design artwork and paint murals in our school. Our students proudly produce poetry anthologies, short films, a school newspaper and a literary magazine. Through our partnership with DC-TV we have expanded our film-making capacity. We have expanded our partnership with Open Door Arts in Education to bring dance, film and technology into our classrooms. Finally we offer after school drama, anime, and songwriting clubs.

On top of a curricular exploration of studio art and music provided in the 9th and 10th grade, Bronx Lab students will have the opportunity to explore the arts through dance instruction, provided during their lunch hour. Students will learn Hip Hop and International dance styles while the history, culture and contribution of hip hop music and dance which instills messages of strength, self-confidence and positivity. The students will be introduced to the art of storytelling using their dancing to communicate their ideas and feelings to their audience. Through international dance workshops, students will gain a familiarity with, and appreciation of, foreign traditions and cultural diversity. Programs introduce students to the geographic areas where different dance and musical styles evolved, and the ways in which these styles have influenced other international styles. Students will build their knowledge and skills during the course of the semester, culminating in a dance performance at a Town Hall gathering. About Arts Horizons For almost 38 years, Arts Horizons has impacted the lives of more than 9 million children and adults through the power of the arts. They are committed to making the performing, visual, literary and media arts and artistic expression equitable and accessible to diverse people of all ages and abilities. We believe that the arts are fundamental to a child's education, stimulating learning, enriching the teaching process and providing lifelong learning.

The High School of Computers and Technology uses a hands-on technology-based approach to arts education in line with the school's focus.  Students use laptops, make physical crafts such as clocks and string art and learn how to use 3D printers.
This year we were able to offer students Visual Arts and Music Education during the school day to all students. Within our after-school program, students engage in dance, step and drumming.

The theme of our school is health careers; therefore, most of our students take their electives in science and health career courses. Students take art in grades 10, 11, and 12. Since there is very little space in the students' schedule to provide additional classes in the arts, we allow students to have a dance club which is student run. Students have the opportunity to perform in talent shows, Black History Month celebrations, and our multicultural shows. When the budget and programming allows, students are offered a video-making course in grade 11 where the students make their own short videos. Our students may have the opportunity to take trips to museums and watch films in an art class which supports our history classes. 
Due to a grant, Community Word Project has worked with our special eduction, ENL, and general eduction students to create an anthology of poems along with their visual arts creations. Community Word Project then published their poems and artwork in a beautifully bound book. At a PA meeting, students had the opportunity to present their books to their parents and read their poems. During the spring (2017)semester, Community Word Project worked with an art class to paint a mural which is based on themes from their anthologies on a wall within the school.
We added ceramics to our course offering.  We continue to offer Studio Art and Painting.

We have a CTE Graphic Design Program, which leads to a certification in Adobe Illustrator. Students take a 7 course sequence, which consists of the following: 2 courses in Studio Art, 4 courses in Graphic Design and 1 course in Financial Management. In addition, students are offered art electives, such as Illustration, Portfolio and Photography.

Q32_6: Midwest Clinic & The New York State Band Directors Association Region 9 - NYC
Q46_1:
Currently, All students in grades 6-8 are programmed for visual arts or band instruction for the entire school year. Each class is programmed for two periods of art or music instruction per week.  Students are selected for either program based on their ability and preference. In each program teachers ensure to give students in classroom and out of classroom experiences.

In the art classroom students development many forms of visual arts that they can display throughout the school; culminating in the development of an arts portfolio and end of year art exhibit. 

In the band classroom, students work on their individual musical instrument, learning the fundamentals of reading and playing music.  Students prepare in grade 8 for performing art school auditions.  All students prepare for the end of year concert.

Throughout the school year students participate in out of the classroom experiences visiting arts high schools; visiting a local college and attending one of their own musicals;  having college music students perform for them and lead instruction; visit art organizations such as Materials for the Arts; visit local art museums and exhibitions; and attend an open rehearsal of a music entity (specifically  this year the NY Philharmonic).

The Matilda Avenue School is in the third year of existence, servicing approximately one hundred and twenty-five students in kindergarten, first, and second grade. Our arts curriculum includes a partnership with Education Through Music, which provides general music instruction to all of our students for forty-five minutes a week. Students in first grade had the opportunity to work with a teaching artist from Alvin Ailey Dance in a ten week residency that culminated in a dance performance. Students in kindergarten, first, and second grade also received a unit of dance instruction provided by a physical education teacher forty-five minutes three times a week for six weeks during their gym classes. Students also receive visual arts instruction forty-five minutes one time a week provided by a cluster teacher. Classroom teachers incorporate theater into their literacy curriculum within the classroom. As we continue to grow, we hope to be able to offer additional arts instruction.

The Visual Arts program in our school is both engaging and rigorous. Students take ownership of their artwork, developing portfolios throughout the school year. They use rubrics and assessment that provide students with room to make improvements and understand how to create the best work possible. During one semester, 4th and 8th grade students participate in a Dancing Classrooms program, which in an in-house residency teaching students a variety of ballroom dances including salsa, merengue, foxtrot, tango, swing, rumba, and waltz.
Our Music Arts program incorporates singing as well as instruments for 5th through 8th grade. We have upper and lower level bands, who play concerts for our school including parents. Students are required to participate in band lessons during and after school hours. Our Music program also performs concerts in the winter and spring for parents.
Our Arts program works to create well-rounded artists that work to find their niche in the Art world, whether it be performing or visual arts.

Q44_R4: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Bronxdale High School's arts line-up includes a school-specific dance program with a designated dance room. Our dance sequence can lead to an arts endorsement on a diploma. Partnerships with Alvin Ailey. Joyce Theatre, and Ballet Hispanico give students an opportunity to learn about, practice, and see dance performances in varied genres. Students have an opportunity to participate in the campus-wide music program via membership in the Campus band. Students may select this option beginning in ninth grade. Bronxdale has built up a Culinary Academy in an industrial kitchen space so that students may have an opportunity to learn about the culinary arts through a hands-on class that leads to a CTE designation. The program includes work-based learning experience and participation in two large-scale catered events. Bronxdale has a visual arts program that includes graphic/media arts. The arts program begins with an introduction to visual arts and builds up for students who are interested in pursuing visual and graphic arts through opportunities to create public art, participate in arts activities and competitions outside of school, and display artwork throughout the school. Theater is offered throughout ELA and ESL classes, while film is an option as an elective course. Partnerships with cultural organizations and community based organizations have allowed us to provide students with opportunities to learn about film, drama, arts, and dance in the arts-specific classes as well as across content areas.

We offer drawing, video, photography, graphic design, and painting through two visual arts teachers. We have a theater teaching artist who works in collaboration with our ELA teachers and also offers an improv club. We also have a partnership with the Morgan Library and Museum that provides a bookmaking curriculum, teacher professional development, and trips to the museum.
Q47_1: Our school is made up of newcomer English Language Learners.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: We have a theater program integrated in our ENL classes. A teaching artist comes to school to co-plan with the teachers and then work with the students 10 sessions during the fall semester and 10 sessions during the spring semester. In addition, we have a band, vocal, and dance classes after school and on Saturdays taught by certified teachers.
Q47_1: New World High School is a comprehensive high school that serves ELLs.

Q46_1: Students are provided with foundational courses in the arts to enrich their experiences and knowledge pertaining to the discipline. In addition, pending budgetary availability and student interest, we look to offer enrichment clubs pertaining to the arts, like dance, and/or drama.

We continue to work diligently with ETM and our students have continued to grow and excel as musicians. This was our second year with Broadway Jr and our plan is to complete another year for 2018-2019. Our students had the pleasure of performing on Broadway, thanks to Broadway Jr.  The experience was incredible. Opportunities and exposure has proven to be incredible. We are looking forward to another amazing year.

During the 2017-2018 school year, the arts program at Baychester Middle School aims to expose 6th-grade and 7th-grade students to elements of film. Students are encouraged to investigate various artistic movements and theater presentations. Baychester's program will investigate the history of theater while getting hands-on opportunities of self-expression.

The arts program at Pelham Preparatory Academy focuses on visual arts, and music arts. The visuals arts program is charged with producing the majority of the art work displayed throughout the building, including sculptures, murals, and other artistic pieces. The music department exposes students to many levels of the arts including music appreciation classes, and vocal and instrumental classes. Students are also given the opportunity to participate in various campus-wide bands including the beginners, intermediate, and Latin-Jazz bands. These bands perform at sporting events, graduations, concerts, and other campus and community events. In addition, our partnership with Lincoln Center has provided multiple opportunities for our students to explore the performing arts. In addition we have partnered with CUNY - Creative ARTS Team, and the Salvadori Center.

The mission of the High School for Contemporary Arts is to create a caring school community, rich in contemporary arts that will allow each student to pursue personal dreams utilizing specialized talents while meeting and surpassing academic standards. We foster an interdisciplinary approach to learning that will allow students to integrate the knowledge acquired though all disciplines.  Our Arts program is designed to inspire students to create and express themselves in a variety of different art forms in order to promote creativity and a desire for life-long learning.  Our vision is to provide students with a dynamic leaning environment where respect is mutual, ideas are shared and learning is not limited to the classroom.  Our classes ignite the imagination and artistic passion of young people as well as building:
•	Accomplishment through team building
•	Respect for Dance, Music, Theater and Visual Arts
•	Trust through the creative process 
•	Self-awareness and confidence to reach their creative potential
Our Arts programs are aimed to develop our students’ artistic abilities, academic achievement, and cultural empowerment.  Our programs are also committed to the development of creativity and problem-solving skills, improving judgment, and showing children that there are multiple perspectives. We aim to  develop inventiveness in order to help foster innovative thinkers.

BAHS will work with PLTW to embed an art course through our Engineering program. In addition, BAHS works with a variety of educational consultants to provide students with access to a myriad of art forms: dancing, singing and acting. Art programs are created based on student interest during and after the school day. Art programs are designed to include all learners through the lens of character development.

Bronx Park has an interdisciplinary curriculum with a focus on arts inclusion. The arts inclusion means that all summative projects have required elements of the arts blended into the performance. These performances are evaluated by teachers, peers, and individual students based on rubric criteria. There are roughly five major interdisciplinary performances each year. Students have completed two integrated theater projects and three visual arts projects. Students are offered an array of arts electives to choose from, including fashion, drama and theater, visual arts, capoeira, step, digital media, which include movie making and editing, digital graphic design and culinary arts. These electives are extracurricular, run for twenty week semesters, and students receive 120–180 minutes of the arts each week. Within the regular school day students also receive instrumental music, visual arts, and digital arts enrichment courses that run in ten week cycles. This year we have addition a full time visual arts teacher and all students have the opportunity to have art class as well as art club with a certified art teacher.

Pelham Gradens Middle School (PGMS) offers Music, Dance, and  Visual Arts within its curriculum.  The arts program is an extension and enrichment from what students are learning in the classroom.  Arts help to shape a students' overall well-being and academic achievement.  At PGMS, students are exposed to a variety of arts both throughout the school day and extracurricular activities.  For the 2017-2018 school year all students were given the opportunity to perform in the three school plays.  Two plays took place at PGMS auditorium: "Winter in the City" and "A Walk Though Black History."  One play took place at the Cathedral for Greater Faith Church, "A Heavenly Christmas, Leading to the Cross."  Students only had to audition for special roles, however all group pieces were open to everyone.

This year we hired a licensed Arts teacher who offers art family workshops for parent engagement, we increased our Education Through Music residency by 5 days per week, we have Inside Broadway after school program for 4-5th graders, We have a residency with New York City Children's Theater that serves 3rd, 4th grades and families. We have an ongoing partnership with New Victory Theater for field trips, and, we also partner with Cool Culture to provide equitable and free access to cultural organizations
Q47_1: We received a Magnet Grant this year which increased our Arts focus. Next year we hope to have a media arts lab

Q45_10: Reading and Read-aloud; Role Playing; Visualization and Making Predictions; Writing Celebrations; Dance on Stage
Q46_1: At P.S. 6X, we have made a significant effort in providing opportunities to have students move up in reading levels.  We have focused on reading, writing, and verbal expression that allow students to make meaning from text.  Through the 4R’s Program and Teachers College Reading and Writing curricula, students have read, studied the actions of lead and secondary characters, and through visualization and prediction, engaged in role play.  Students have also engaged in Writing Celebrations with classmates and their families.  Dance celebrations aligned with school events have supported student expression and technique.  We strive to ‘be our best,’ ‘love learning,’ and ‘inspire the world.’
Q47_1: PS 6X would welcome additional funding so that we can allocate appropriate resources for arts education.

Q46_1: Classroom teachers provide music, dance, and visual arts for grades k-5. Interdisciplinary thematic units of study, provide opportunities for students to engage in projects that includes art, music and dance. A grant funded a residency program from Flamenco Vivo where our scholars were exposed to Flamenco dancing and the history and culture associated with the dance form for ten weeks that resulted in a culminating performance for general education and special education students in grades K-5.

Q44_R3: I.D.E.A.S. - Interactive Drama for Education and Awareness in the Schools
Q46_1: There are several goals that are incorporated into the arts program at P.S. 47: Goal 1-to provide a variety of art disciplines and create a continuum from k to 5 that will allow children to explore and discover their talents; Goal 2-to develop a lifelong love and appreciation for the art; Goal 3-to infuse the arts into all content areas, allowing teachers to provide differentiation based on individual student modalities and talents. P.S. 47 has adopted the Reggio Emelia philosophy which originated in Southern Italy. This philosophy is basically a "projects approach" to literacy and content area studies. Through the Reggio Emelia philosophy, children work cooperatively to develop art projects and culminating activities that include researching, writing and oral presentations; Goal 4-to align the arts with the New York State Standards for the Arts; creating and performing in the arts; knowing and using arts materials and resources; responding to and analyzing works of art.

Our current arts program is alive and vibrant. PS57 has two full time certified arts teachers, one in music and one in visual arts. Students engage in either music, visual arts or both during the regular school day. Most classes receive two periods of music and one visual arts or two visual arts and one music class. 
  Students also attend after school classes in puppetry, dance, visual arts, circus arts, and drumming through LEAP and Marquis Studios. Children attend class trips to museums, shows and theater.
  PS 57 has both a winter and spring chorus concert. Chorus is a combined group of third to fifth grade students. Lower grades present a winter and spring musical performance with the entire class.       
  Student artwork is displayed throughout the building and in classrooms. There is a genuine pride that students feel about their artwork. Student artwork has been selected for The Bronx Arts Festival Lehman College.  
  Students benefit from attending The Victory Theater, Metropolitan Museum of Art and Lehman College Theater performances.
  PS 57 strives to do all we can with the space and budget allowed our school. Children's artistic talents are recognized and celebrated.

Our school presently does 'arts' during the day school as well as during after-school, through the support of our Community Based Organization, Children's Aid.  Students' art experiences and projects are designed to offer them new lens through which to view the world, foster creativity, and give them channels for self-expression.  On a weekly basis, students are involved in Theater, Music, Visual Arts, Culinary Arts.  Students will, before the end of this year, also embark upon a 'school logo' competition. 
Our students have access to smart boards in every classroom, as well as Ipads, laptops, video equipment and art supplies which the school provides.
It is one of our goals for the upcoming school year to hire an Art teacher who can facilitate this work on a full time basis during the day with all our students. 
Another goal for the upcoming school year is to introduce to our 5th grade students the experience of theatrical performances on 'Broadway' to give them a broader perspective on theater and the art of acting before a live audience.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: C.S. 67 strives to incorporate arts into every day instruction in all subject areas. We encourage students to utilize visual thinking strategies and express themselves through the arts. Teachers also incorporate "move to improve" into their daily lessons. At C.S. 67, students are encouraged to analyze art, and create their own forms of art using their creativity and the knowledge they have gained. Teachers model how to reflect on artwork and students also reflect and assess their own art work. Teachers provide constructive feedback using a "glow", "grow" and "how to", so students continuously progress in the arts. We have continued our partnership with SEA which provides programs such as mask-masking and puppet-making activities. Our arts program continues to use the k-5 blue prints and Common Core Learning Standards to drive instruction. Teachers work collaboratively to ensure that the arts is part of our students' everyday lives.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: Community School 92 offers Visual Arts and Music instruction to the majority of the students enrolled including Prekindergarten. Our visual arts and music programs follow the guidelines offer by the Blueprint. The arts specialists collaborate with classroom teachers to produce projects, performances, and to align their lessons with  classroom curriculum. Arts specialists modify activities to engage all students including students with disabilities, and English Language learners. Assemblies and visual arts exhibitions are produced three times a year. We participate in arts and music contests. Our students leave our school with a deep appreciation for the arts and express interest in continuing their arts education in the future years.

Q39_4: adult learning arts class through CBO
Q46_1: Our arts program is provided through artist residency with Community Word Project.  Students create visual and written works around social justice themes that culminate in a publication and performance.
Q47_1: We are looking to staff a fulltime art teacher for the 2018-2019 school year.  Additionally, we plan to continue our relationship with Community Word Project and are hopeful that we will be able to expand the program to service more students.

Q46_1: Every student in grades 6, 7, and 8 are provided with instruction in music and visual arts aligned with the New York State Standards and the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. In our visual arts program, students learn to use a variety of art media and techniques, including digital media, along with studying many artists and their work. Students learn to critique their own work and the work of other students. Students who are interested in applying to art high schools participate in a rigorous afterschool program designed to improve their portfolios, teach them how to interview and present their work. In our general music program, students learn about key moments in music history, and a basic knowledge of music theory and notation. Students also have opportunities to compose music using technology. They learn how to play the guitar in the guitar lab. Our music teacher works with 8th graders during their lunch period to help them prepare for auditions to high schools for music. We collaborate with our school-based organization, Learning through an Expanded Arts Program (LeAp), for several after school arts programs. Our music teacher runs a modern band program, including guitar, bass, drums, keyboards and vocals. This guitar ensemble has performed at district events and most school events. Two of our paraprofessionals conduct the drama program through LeAp and have performed plays for the parents, staff, and students. Dance and visual arts is also offered through LeAp.

Q45_10: video portfolios of the students' progress
Q46_1: ESMT IS 190 is a middle school serving roughly 300 students.  Our student body currently takes  art education classes twice a week throughout all 3 years.  They have Visual Arts, Theatre and Musical Theatre, depending upon their grade. Interdisciplinary education is the bedrock of our arts program. Art's endless possibilities create differentiation that builds strong personal connections to content in other classes.  One example is how our Special Education Social Studies classes are taught in conjunction with arts education classes. When the 6th grade began a unit on early human civilization, they studied cave paintings in art.  They investigated the messages on cave walls and developed their own cave paintings making paint from vegetables, grass and dirt.  They designed one cave painting for Early Man and one for Future Man.  Each painting's message was developed from their knowledge of SS content and aligned with their RACE paragraphs about the birth of civilization. Students also performed improv as different tribes and monologues as Early Man. A student said "It's kind of cool, it's like I'm history."  This is a key goal at IS 190, teaching our young minds to recognize and develop their natural curiosity, imagination and innovative thought processes. Building a personal bridge to understanding is necessary for lasting comprehension. Growth of self confidence and character are also at the bedrock of our program. Establishing environments where students feel safe and respected builds life long trust and confidence.
Q47_1: We are a small Title 1 school that has very very limited funding for Arts Education.  We are in a growth period for arts education, yet lack the funding to give the students the experience of producing a complete musical or play with costumes, sets lights etc. We strive to enrich our students' experiences in the arts.  In a community where access to after school and weekend dance, music or art programs is limited or financially untenable, our program strives to provide students with an introduction. Not only to the concepts of art, but to recognize that everybody has an inner artist (no matter how badly they think they draw!)  With an outlet for creativity, kids who think they're "stupid"  blossom.  Our students are often afraid to say what they think. Through art we see them gain confidence and connect to their thoughts, eventually sharing. Access to art allows them to like themselves. They learn how to communicate respectfully, listen to each other and respect differences.  Although Manhattan, with many of the finest museums and theatres in the world is only a 45 minute subway ride away, it may as well be Texas. Having funding which would make museums and theatre a regular part of their lives would open up a new world to our students. It could possibly begin a life of regular visits to NYC's fine arts venues. We're in need of funding, enough to help our students develop a more varied and deeper experience with art both inside and outside our walls.
Q48_2: Arts Education Liaison, Theatre Arts Teacher

Q46_1: P.S 195 offers a diverse Arts Program to include Fine Arts, Visual Arts, Drama and Music. Students learn the elements that make up each of these disciplines and are exposed to various forms of arts performances. Higher order thinking skills are supported through these project based disciplines.

CS 211 believes strongly in the transformative effect that art has on children’s lives. As you walk through the halls of our school, you are greeted by beautiful student art. We offer a comprehensive visual arts curriculum pre-k-8th grade. Students at CS 211 participate in a variety of performing arts residencies. Grades k-2 participate in an early childhood movement residency where students learn about music and dance. In the 3rd and 5th grades, students engage in Alvin Ailey and Flamenco workshops. Not only do the students learn the dance form but also see professional dance performances. In the 5th and 8th grades, students participate in a long in-depth ballroom dance residency culminating with a dance gala. Our dance team has won several dance awards. Our 7th grade students, take part in a musical theater residency. Students learn the music and dance from a current theater production and then create and perform their own original theater pieces. CS 211 middle school has an active marching band. The band practices often and participates in various parades in New York City and neighboring towns. 
 This year CS 211 offered an art program for our Ell’s to increase language acquisition. CS 211 hosts several family art workshops for students and parents to learn together. CS 211 holds an annual visual art show representing all pre-k-8 students. The art show is not only a display of exemplary work but also an opportunity for families to make art together. In addition the student performed in three arts recitals.

School's Art Program description: The goals of the Arts Program at our school is to help students express their voice and unique backgrounds through art. Our goal for next year is to incorporate the theme of peace in the students art pieces and within the annual school's art exhibition. This past school year, students created lighthouses as a symbol that every child has a light that they shine on the world around them.

The arts program at PS 214 evolves around three components; music, dance and visual arts. These programs are introduced during the
early childhood and elementary schools and mastered in the middle school. Students are given opportunities to submit pieces of work in the Bronx Arts Festival and PS Art, as well as opportunities to apply for ballet programs at Lincoln Center.

We continue our partnership with Disney Musical in Schools for grades 3-5 and this year partnered with the Shubert Foundation and Broadway Jr. in grades 6-8. Through these partnerships we were able to produce two musical performances at our school.

Our annual 214 Idol show provides students the opportunity to showcase singing and dancing. We have also added a 214's Got Talent show where students in the elementary school can showcase singing, dancing and theatrical talents.

Our school is committed to all of our students being engaged in an arts program and will continue to create more artistic expressions opportunities in years to come.

We have made huge strides in restoring the "performing" and "arts" to the School of Performing Arts. This school year there are teachers who provide full-time instruction in dance, music, and visual arts. Through our partnerships we have been able to bring in Alvin Ailey Dance and Renaissance Youth Center who provide vocal instruction in the form a chorus and band during the school day. Students are learning to play the drums, guitar, and keyboards--together. In a short time the chorus and band have performed twice in school and once at an outside venue. Our plans are to grow the arts program each year as we have over the last two years.

Graphic Design - Students are introduced to key aspects and skills of graphic design. Exploration of visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, image  and type design.

Illustration I & II- Students explore a variety of media. essential components include and are not limited to exhibition, design and fabrication, drawing, painting, analysis, and critiques of original works of art.

Sculpture - Class is geared toward 10th -12th grade students with basic understanding of elements and principles of art and design. The class is geared towards and relies on a small class size due to the nature of materials. Students explore a variety of 3 dimensional materials including but not limited to, wire, plaster, clay, and glass. Students are introduced to basic forms of creating 3d works of art using materials they might not have had access to in a larger class setting.

Dance/Performing Arts - Students explore dance movement and concentrate on improvisational techniques and acting skills and choreography. Students will demonstrate proficiency in characterization, memorization and concentration, invent original body movement in response to music, and  poetry. We will examine monologues, speeches and scenes to distinguish a range of movement to express feelings, characteristics, and sensation. 

Acting - Students will learn necessary elements of concentration in improvisation, scene work and performances, analyze, interpret, memorize and perform a scripted scene.

At Explorations we will like to increase our students’ exposure to the arts. We want provide our students with opportunities for exposure to concerts, dance performance, films, theater performance and artwork exhibits. We hired a music teacher for next year and plan to create an afterschool music program music. We would like to enhance our students’ education by offering multiple clubs such as music, step dance class, playwriting drama and poetry. In addition, we will incorporate three in school performance for the year that include music, theater and dance. We will continue to provide our students exposure to different arts programs such as “El Repertorio Espanol,” Lincoln Center Institute and Roundabout Theater. By doing this, we will provide instruction infused with Common Core Learning Standards and citywide expectations in the arts.

Bronx Latin's vision is for a comprehensive music program in which students cultivate a knowledge and appreciation of music. We believe that an arts education is fundamental to the development of each individual and that the arts provide unique opportunities for cultural exchange and community understanding. Students will learn to read sheet music and play a range of percussion, brass, string and woodwind instruments, including keyboard, full drum set, Congo drums, flute, recorder, trumpet, trombone, tuba, guitar (electric and acoustic) and voice and others. To enhance the arts program in the coming year, students will engage in a technology course incorporating elements of fine arts and photo editing in order to support artistic expression and 21st Century skills. Students also engage in a visual arts program in 8th, 10th, and 12th grades where students have different projects every year, culminating in final projects.

We have Classes in Visual Arts, Dance, Theater, Instrumental and theory music as well as Music Appreciation.
We will establish a Band next year as well as plays .
The Dance program has 2 shows every year and we will be adding music to the show .
We hope to make the arts a bigger emphasis with more funds next year .

Our arts program is comprised of artisitic experiences at all grade levels in both the visual and performing arts. Our goal is to expose students to a variety of arts disciplines and experiences as a point of entry for a variety of student learners. 

Our program has expanded this year to include two full time visual art teachers offering weekly lessons in both two and three dimensional art that include drawing studies, drawing techniques and graphic design projects across all three grade levels.

All students participate in enrichment twice a week during Choice Class periods as part of our Extended Learning Time program. This year we increased art-based offerings by incorporating dance and chorus instruction at all grade levels for the entire year along with periodic dance workshops for self-selecting students. This has also created opportunity for student self-expression in culminating performing arts showcases. 

We partner monthly with assembly providers who infuse the performing arts through, music, song, dance, and rap into a social emotional message while also introducing students to art-based careers and pathways. We also have arts-based curricula that is integrated into subjects across the content areas. 

As a summation of our arts program, our annual school-wide celebration, the Community School Forum, featured an explicit arts- based theme that engaged students, families and community members in student performances, mural making, gallery walk, and live art expo.

The arts program here at The Fairmont Neighborhood School has devoted serious dedication towards bringing in outside resources to our students this school year. We have continued partnerships with existing cultural arts organizations, as well as formed new relationships and partnerships with other arts grants, to enhance both arts instructional time for students, and professional development for designated arts teachers in our building. Students have continued their studies with music, visual arts, and musical theater. Incorporating, storytelling, acting, and choreography has been a significant element that has now been added to our arts curriculum. Because of this added components, students have another means to express themselves through various performance activities that musical theater can include. Overall, students have arts engagements that consist of singing, dancing, acting, instrument-playing, and creating art through the use and application of critical skills and tools.
We are currently offering visual arts to all students; music to 6th and 7th grade; drumming to 6th grade and theatre to all students afterschool.
Students in grade 6 & 7 receive music three to four periods per week for the entire school year. Students in grade 8 receive STEAM Design 2 to 3 periods per week for the entire school year.
Q47_1: As you already know funding is always a challenge, however we seek to truly engage our students in the digital arts and making coding a pivotal part of their education in this ever evolving digital world.

Q46_1: Graphic Art: The course has multiple components and is designed to learn art concepts based on typography and other types of textual design forms. It is also a course to expand the learner’s knowledge of art by contributing ideas, creating art hands-on and the development of one’s own sense and understanding of its meaning. Art & Design: This will exemplify an art studio setting where the learner will be responsible for developing their art projects and the processes involved. Art ideas and concepts will be explored but with the learners designing their own ideas and determining the outcome. Visual Art: This will be based on learning how to develop art as an art-making community. Explorations of art-making will be independent but group based. In this course, the learner will learn concepts of art that focuses on learning about what it means to develop art and create art as a network of artists. Grading will be based on the following criteria:  Class work /Class projects (Product/Project-Based, Independent, collaborative)  In-class projects done individually and/or with peers if project requires it.  Written reflection or written assignment which aligns with project requirement. ? Portfolio Development / Discussion & Presentation Bronx Arts Ensemble provided Spoken Word and Visual Art courses to our student population. Regents Prep with Urban Arts incorporated Rap Music to study for Global History and US History.

The students at Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation are able to explore a variety of art forms, materials and techniques, and sources for inspiration such as observation, memory, and imagination. Students look at, discuss and write about art from different perspectives, as well as their own art and art of peers. The students are able create their interpretation of the world through art, theater and music.

Elements of Art Sculptures:  Students started off the year learning about the 7 elements of art.  They then had to create a 6” square representing line, shape, color, value, texture & space.  They put those squares onto cardboard and created the 7th element of form out of them.  

Candido Bido: 6D & 7D then moved onto a project about Dominican artist Candido Bido.  They studied his portraits and style and were tasked with creating a wax resist painting inspired by his art.  Students were also tasked with identifying his work and citing evidence as to why it was a piece of his or why not.

Self Portraits: 7C & 7B looked at self portraits by famous artists throughout history.  They learned how to draw a face using a geometric based formula that they could then alter.  Once students grasped the formula, they were asked to select one of 3 stylized portrait instructions based on Paul Klee, Chuck Close & Giuseppe Arcimboldo. One students’ Paul Klee portrait was submitted to the NYSATA Legislative Exhibit for March 2018.

Surrealism Rooms: 6B & 6C learned how to create a room using 1-point perspective.  Students then learned about Salvador Dalí and the Surrealism style.  Students were then tasked with drawing in surrealist elements to their room and coloring it in with marker or pencil to have a craftsmanship of a level 4 (out of 4). One students’ piece was sent to the NYSATA Legislative Exhibit for March 2018.

Currently at PAIHS Monroe we have an interdisciplinary visual arts program. The art teacher works closely with major discipline teachers to plan curricula that is project-based to support ELLs in learning English and major concepts they are studying in social studies, English, native language arts, math and science. Students get experience using a wide variety of media, including pencil, charcoal, watercolor, acrylic, clay, and digital art, while learning major content. Next year we hope to include more museum field trips and community art partnerships. In addition, the visual arts teacher is helping more students each year apply to afterschool, weekend and summer programs in the arts

As a alternative transfer high school Arturo A. Schomburg Satellite Academy tries to provide as many academic and artistic opportunities for our students to meet their graduation requirements and become well rounded citizens in society. Though our funding may make it challenging to provide as much arts as we would like, we have been able to work with consultants and our teachers to provide art programs. This year we have been able to offer improvisational theater and dance classes afterschool as well as ceramics and visual art classes during the school day. It is our hope to continue these programs and add more opportunities depending on funding.

Students attend art and music class three times a week with experienced and dedicated arts teachers. Students also learn weekly songs which are sung at the school's sing alongs on Monday mornings. Students participate in capoeira with Abada capoeira and through center times, students work in dramatic play, theater and other art forms. Students attend bi-weekly field trips to various cultural institutions to enrich their understanding of the world around them and the content in which they are studying.

Currently we have a certified visual arts teacher who services the students in our school. She helps the teachers connect visual art to all of the content areas and assists the students with projects. In addition, she facilitates parent workshops twice a month, showing them how visual art connects to what their children are learning in school.  This is our fifth year having school-wide enrichment clubs once a week. Every Tuesday, students participate in clubs that are arts based. In addition, our students in grades 3-5 are provided with dance, theater and chorus after school for three days a week. We have a partnership with Studio in a School this year for our fourth and fifth graders and a partnership with the NYC Ballet which services our third and fourth graders.
Q47_1: We will be writing grants to hopefully bring in more arts experiences for our students.  If funds are available to bring the arts into our school, we will definitely utilize them to enhance the education of our students.

Q46_1: We are the first and only high school in the nation to offer all students a four year curriculum in narrative filmmaking. The goal of our film program is to prepare students for success in competitive colleges and aspirational 21st century careers. Our curriculum focuses on the habits of the mind of filmmakers, including visual thinking, critical literacy, storytelling, and collaboration, which is the synthesis of all skills (technical, artistic, business). This goes to creating something original and representative based on the creator's unique perspective.

The Art Program at Bronx Career and College Preparatory High School was developed based on student's skill sets and interest. The students in grade 10 are given an introductory course to learn basic techniques. Students in their junior year are provided with a course that refines previously learned artistry techniques. Senior year students are selected by the art teacher as demonstrating interest in continuing to develop as artists. These students have developed an art portfolio for entry into college and/or possible career path. Additionally, a film course has been developed in conjunction with the humanities department to support the Global History Curriculum.

Bronx Regional High School is a transfer school that offers studio art and ceramics classes for students seeking to obtain their arts and/or elective credits needed for graduation. But at its core, the program gives students so much more than just credentials. Students develop and build self-esteem and self-efficacy as they learn and master new skills. This is evidenced in the pride that students express as they speak about their work in class critiques and as they offer constructive feedback to their peers. A strong focus on literacy allows students to speak to each other using the language of art as they discuss both their work and the work of others. Further, students can carry their knowledge and engage in the language of art as they move beyond the classroom walls. The vast cultural mecca that is our beloved New York City offers students a wealth of resources to enrich their arts education experiences and support personal growth beyond the scope of the classroom. Students who are identified as having a special love for the visual arts will be encouraged to seek such additional educational and career opportunities. Our goal is to further develop this program so that we can continue to offer students a high quality arts enrichment environment that meets graduation requirements, and more importantly, encourages personal growth in the art room and beyond.

Bronx Envision Academy embraces the arts throughout the curriculum. Students have the opportunity to take up to two arts courses each semester, and we encourage students to explore an arts discipline in depth to prepare for the New York City Commencement Level Arts Examinations. One quarter of graduates from our first three classes graduated with an arts endorsed diploma. Elective offerings include visual art, theater, dance, music, chorus, and creative writing. We also offer summer honors arts courses in visual art and theater and new courses in AP Studio Art 2D Design and AP Art History. Students participate in artist residencies with arts organizations Community Word-Project, and Hawley Hussey Arts. We are also proud partners with the Park Avenue Armory, providing access to high quality arts performances and exhibitions for beginning and advanced students and paid internships for advanced students. Teachers are trained in Visual Thinking Strategies, and students discuss works of art on a regular basis. Because the arts are central to Bronx Envision's core beliefs about how students learn best, BEA has recruited accomplished faculty with strong arts backgrounds. As a result, we offer many arts clubs during and after school. Current offerings include mural-making, anime, comic book club, musical theater, dance company, art, music production and DJing.

Students learn to use iMac software in courses that combine literacy, mathematical reasoning and art. Our course offerings are 1. Digital Storytelling 2. Graphic Design and Media Marketing 3. Videography and the Arts

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
PS 531 is dedicated to providing students access to a range of arts experiences.  All students receive Visual Arts and Music instruction at least once a week from full-time, certified teachers at the school.  

In Visual Arts class, students are exposed to the work of artists to  help them see how different styles have developed over time, then have the opportunity to create their own work in those styles.  Students work in a variety of mediums, from painting to collage to pen and ink.

In music class, students learn about rhythm, scales, and harmony as they sing, dance, and play instruments.  You will see kids playing conga drums, ukuleles, recorders, or just about any other instrument you can think of when you walk into our music room!

In addition to art and music, we offer a wide variety of after school and part time programming.  In our after-school Shakespeare Rock Program, 4th and 5th grade students put on a full scale production of a Shakespeare classic (this year's group is doing Macbeth) and learn to play Bass, Guitar, Keyboard, and Drums.  The program is supported by Dance, Music Theory, and Theater teachers from LEAP, an outside arts organization.

We hope you love arts as much as we do at PS 531!

There are three arts programs at our school. These include a music program, ceramics program, and a theater program which is provided by the 21st Century grant. Each program is done in order to give English Language Learners the ability to express themselves and acquire the English language. The music and ceramics classes are taught by English as a New Language teachers in order to help students develop critical thinking and tier two words that can be used across content. This is done in order to support language but to provide students opportunities to express themselves, their history, and emotions in a healthy way. Students are expected to collaborate with one another in order to create community and team building.
Q47_1: The students at High School of World Cultures are all new arrivals. Therefore, they are learning English for the first time and many students are going to school for the first time in their lives.

Q46_1: Fannie Lou Hamer Freedom High School has a long standing partnership with art educators. The collaboration with the arts introduces a variety of visual art experience to students, enables interdisciplinary exhibitions and encourages educators to use the arts as a tool for learning. Visual arts are woven into curriculum in the school and enables two hundred 9th/10th graders to create artwork that demonstrates their learning and allows them creative expression in their thinking and learning.

A dance club that will provide students with a combination of African, ballet, jazz, and HipHop. Students will be able to use this club to express themselves through the art of movement. In addition, students will be prepared to audition and prepare for various competitions.

At BLS we have one full-time drama teacher who infuses theater, music, dance, and visual arts into her curriculum. Through our partnerships with Studio In a School, Dancing Classrooms, and LEAP we provide various opportunities for students to participate in classes ranging from art to ballroom dancing and music. We also have a theater program that has sixty participants from grades 2nd-5th. Students in 2nd and 3rd grades put together a theater sampler. Students in grades 4 and 5 put on a full show. Students meet throughout the day and after school to work on scripts, dance, vocals, and scenery.  Our monthly assemblies and annual talent showcases, allow students to learn about music and dances from around the world, but also create a platform for them to showcase their own skills.  Our school newspaper is another platform for students to showcase their artistic skills.

We are committed to providing all of our students with sequential standards-based arts education and have earned a well-deserved reputation in NYC for effectively doing that over many years. In addition to full-time staff arts teachers in three strands (music, theater, and visual arts), and teaching artists provided by long-standing partnerships with cultural organizations, we also have a part-time arts coordinator. All classroom teachers and other curricula specialists also provide arts experiences for students. Weekly Town Hall performances provide opportunities for all students to participate in and experience the performing arts. Classes schedule trips to museums, music and theater performances and dance concerts. Annual student performances commemorate The Day of the African Child and Juneteenth. We have an annual musical theater performance, exhibit student art at MoCADA, are home to The Shadowbox Theatre (which provides free performances for our students and NYSCA-funded puppetry workshops), were an Arts Achieve School and have music and visual arts after school programs. One visual arts after school program is a City Council-funded Creative After School Adventure (CASA) with the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts (MoCADA).

The lower school (K-5) has a robust specialty program, including full-time dance, music, theater arts and visual arts teachers. There are multiple school-based extracurricular options for music including the concert band and Glee Club, for theater including a Jr. Theater Club, and multiple visual arts opportunities. The student Green Team collaborated with student artists to create a mural to beautify our recycling area.  
The upper school (6-8)  has a full-time visual arts teacher and a part-time theater arts teacher who is on-site three days/week. School-based extracurricular options include a musical theater club, photography club and rock band.

Our school's arts rogram is multi-layered, multi-disciplined and provides our students with the abilities to be competitive with their peers throughout NYC. Each year, it is our goal to align all of our subject areas in an effort to provide our students with seamless learning and inquiry. Our students are exposed to varied forms of art; including visual arts, theater, dance, and music. Our in-house art teachers, along with our art consultants are innovative and seek to stay current with the trends and new discoveries within their disciplines. We take much thought and pride in how we align each grade with the arts. Each of our grades is assigned an art form according to their social studies curriculum. Our artists and classroom teachers collaboratively study the units and decide what the essential question and year's focus would be for the students across each grade. We provide our students with authentic art instruction which allows them to truly understand the art form that is being studied. Our students are provided with many opportunities to engage in trips, which enhance their art awareness and make their learning real and alive. Our students are also provided with many opportunities to study the varied forms of arts, collaborate with their peers and their teachers, and then present their Type III products. They engage in varied in-house art exhibitions, as well as exhibitions outside of the school on stage, in museums, and at dance competitions. We tap into our students' talents and teach them to be confident artists.
Q47_1: Public School 9 is a Whole Child school that uses the five tenets of Healthy Safe Engaged Support and Challenged to govern our diverse school community.  In an effort to prepare our children for their future in the 21st century we have rebranded our school to promote STEAM. We believe that our students should be given an opportunity to be exposed to more Science Technology Engineering Arts and Mathematics.  We believe that providing our a strong, organic curriculum that is strong in the sciences as well as the arts would help them see the world in totality. We focus heavily on social and emotional supports for our children and their families. We encourage student and family voice and promote many avenues for parental involvement. We believe in tapping into the talents of both the students and the adults in our school community.

Q44_R2: Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Our arts program goals are as follows: to enhance use of ongoing authentic assessment (including projects, observations, student portfolios, exhibitions and performance); to provide meaningful feedback to track student progress in the arts; to expose more students to art museums, concerts and theatrical performances throughout the school year and to continue to enhance our end of year curriculum showcases, which incorporate the arts and all content areas.

The Clinton Hill School strives to provide each student with an arts education that will develop creative ability and nurture a life long appreciation for the various art forms. Teachers engage students in project based educational experiences that integrate the arts across all subject areas and disciplines while addressing the academic and social needs of our diverse student population. Through our partnerships with many cultural organizations, the students are exposed to a variety of art forms, artists and techniques. These various art forms help students develop motor skills, gain exposure to music/theatre using imagination, learning audience skills, movement skills and cooperation. Students showcase their art through concerts, performances, galleries and displays in local businesses.

Q44_R1_C1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q44_R2: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc.(SEA)is a bilingual arts-in-education organization and bilingual theater for young audiences. SEA provides our students with rich learning experiences of dance, theater, and cultural performances that are specially designed for our school community. Individualized programs address students' academic needs, strengthen the arts curriculum, and provide cultural experiences. Students work with SEA's professional dance teaching artist to learn the history of Salsa, Hip-Hop and African dances, as they craft their skills in perfecting partner dance work. Our students present their routines during school-wide cultural performances for the enjoyment of their peers, school staff and parents. Material for the Arts (MFTA) is an in-school residence program which places teaching artists into our classrooms. This program fosters creative ways to reuse materials, to enhance environmental awareness and to incorporate their visual arts and performing arts in all content areas. Instructional Music-In grades 4-5 children play the flute, clarinet, saxophone, trumpet, and trombone. They receive instruction once a week and perform year round. School-Wide Chorus-In grades k-5, students learn basic chorus techniques. Small groups of children help research and choose music that the chorus performs. Music selected, teaches students social studies, history, math and science through the study of music.

The Arts are a vital part of P.S. 46K. Infused throughout the curriculum, the arts provide opportunities for differentiated instruction within various learning modalities. As a neighborhood school within Brooklyn's newly designated "Tech Triangle," we offer an innovative STEAM program, with the arts and design front and center, informing and energizing science and math. Moving forward with an applied learning approach, the arts support and reinforce learning in the Common Core Subjects while developing skills and understandings in the individual arts disciplines. Grade-appropriate lessons are designed to enhance vocabulary and critical thinking skills necessary to prepare students for college and beyond. In addition to an experiential curriculum, students demonstrate mastery of concepts and content as well as processes. We utilize the rich cultural resources of New York City as an extension of classroom activities through trips and assemblies. Collaboration with cultural partners such as the New York Philharmonic provides opportunities for direct instruction to students as well as professional development for classroom teachers. This enhances music, dance and drama instruction.
Q47_1:
