This is our first full year without any magnet funds to sustain our rich programming.  There has been some decline in overall 100% arts programming compliance.   We were able to shore up some programs with limited grants dedicated to in-school, during the school day, arts experiences.

Additionally we are a school with a focus on media arts, which includes film.  This is the first year of the roll our of the BluePrint for the Moving Image.  Most classroom teachers include this arts discipline producing at least one movie a year.  

We estimate that the entire process of producing and screening a film averages about 20 instructional hours a year for each classroom.

Q46_1:
All students engage in the arts on a weekly basis, Pre-K through 5th grade. Through a variety of partnerships and grants, we provide a full range of arts programming at PS 54 during the school day and after school. 

Children engage in music through bucket drumming, Garageband and chorus. Visual arts play a major role throughout the year with partnerships from Studio in a School, Materials for the Arts, Cool Culture and The Leadership Project. Students are given theater and dance experiences through the Metropolitan Opera Guild and the YMCA after school program. 

Classes go on monthly field trips to various art institutions, including the Museum of the Moving Image, The Brooklyn Botanical Garden and many other. Their visits are aligned to their two yearly project-based learning units.

PS 56 emphasized the education of the whole child, with a specific emphasis on creating engaging arts experiences. Our school promotes experiences in a variety of genres, such as dance, visual arts, music and theater. We have been able this year to initiate partnerships with organizations, such as Little Orchestra Society, Bronx Arts Ensemble, Dancing Classrooms, and Studio in a School to ensure that all of our students experience dance, visual arts, music instruction, and performance throughout the year. Additionally, our full time dance instructor has introduced our students to a variety of genres, such as modern dance, traditional dance, tap, and others. Not only do our students experience these themselves, but often through these partnerships they are able to see professional artists and musicians perform at such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Brooklyn Museum, and Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College. We strongly feel that these experiences enhance the students educational experience overall and improve their progress not only in arts classes but other academic areas as well.

The Charles A. Dorsey School provides comprehensive Common Core aligned cultural arts experiences for our scholars. Through the arts, students acquire tools to engage with a range of source materials and learn to draw on research to investigate their own families and cultural traditions in order to express ideas about the world.

We continue to participate in the Noel Pointer Violin Program, Disney Musical in Schools and we have our own woodshop program.  Additionally, we have Music and the Brain. This year we started a small band as a result of some added instruments.

The Academy of Performing Arts (APA) provides the opportunity for students to pursue training in classical ballet, contemporary dance, and vocal music. The Academy places special emphasis on preparing the young artist for high schools that offer specialized performing arts programs. APA has partnered with several arts groups, organizations and foundations such as Mark Morris Dance Group, Arts Alive, Dance Africa, American Ballet Theater and Creative Outlet, as well as individual artists such as ballet dancer, Misty Copeland and Alvin Ailey dancer, Jeroboam Bozeman. Students are featured in our annual Winterfest and Springfest concerts, which showcase all of the art disciplines. Our vocal students have performed at several events hosted by local politicians over the years. Both our dance and vocal students have competed at arts contests sponsored by local community organizations. The School of Fine Arts and Design (FAD) integrates technology into the arts through the graphic design course in Grade 8. Those students participate in the production of the school yearbook.

P.S. 133 is committed to quality education in the performing and visual arts. Every student from Pre-Kindergarten through 5th grade receive a diverse education in the arts based on the New York State Standards and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Through our music program, students are able to differentiate, interpret and analyze musical experiences and make valuable links to language, math and history. Students are able to analyze musical, concepts, genres and performers. They also learn to play several instruments including the violin and piano. In our drama program, students develop social and emotional skills, as well as creative thinking skills. They develop performance skills focused on using the body, voice and imagination. They have the opportunity to perform already published work as well as to create their own original work. The STUDIO visual arts program is a dedicated art studio where the students are encouraged to experiment with various types of medium and orally communicate their understanding of the visual arts. In addition, classroom teachers learn how to extend art into their instructional practices. Drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, sculpture, 2-D applied design, and media tech are integrated into classroom content. Our cultural partners provide new and exciting opportunities for our students to express themselves, in addition to providing opportunities to interact with artists and arts venues in our community.

Studio in a school is a 5 year residency that includes teacher professional development, and parent engagement.
The program is inquiry based.  Each class lesson is based on a three-part lesson where each class begins with a demonstration (and objectives are stated), then the work time (which is the heart of the class) and a reflection where the objectives are reinforced and the kids understand and reflect what they have done.  There are concrete goals (what the children's fingers are doing, like cutting shapes) and then there are greater key ideas (animals are made up of simpler comprehensible shapes). In kindergarten, students will be able to cut and place shapes.  By 2nd grade, they should be able to arrange them meaningfully, and understand spatial relations like overlapping.  By 5th grade, they should be able to plan and execute collage designs whether abstract or figurative.  By the end of the 5 year residency  students will have been exposed to all visual art media.
Q47_1: The last two years our students have been excited about the residency visual arts program, however, they are still underserved in other Art disciplines such as: dance, theater, and music which would provide them with a well rounded cultural experience.

Q46_1: Our arts program is a four year sequence in the high school designed to incorporate state standards (CCSS) as well as components of the NYC Blueprint to aid in the structuring of curriculum, activities, and the exposure to various art forms, festivals, adjudications, and the many resources that NYC offers to supplement arts classroom instruction. These art forms include, Vocal and Instrumental Music, Dance, Theater, Fine Arts, and additionally with support from Arts Connections (Warner Brothers), Studio Recording. Student get the opportunity to work in the many areas of behind the scene skills around the arts such as lighting, sound, and stage design. The middle school students receive arts instruction weekly with the state mandated time requirements. During such times, the student as six graders are afforded the opportunity to change disciplines by grade 7 to ensure that the student has made an informed decision. Our ultimate goal is to engage our students in a rigorous arts curriculum that prepares them academically and socially for success in college and the world of work and to develop their civic engagement at both the school and community level.
Q47_1:
The Dr. Susan S. McKinney Secondary School of the Arts is a 6-12 performing and visual arts Title I school located in the Fort Green /Farragut section of Brooklyn in Community School District 13. Our school serves a diverse population through a comprehensive range of academic and supportive curricula. Our school offers a nurturing and supportive academic learning environment for all of the students.

Our school day operates from 8:00 am until 6:00 pm Monday – Friday for extended day and evening classes and from 9:00am – 1:00 pm on selected Saturdays where students receive classes in literacy, science and social studies instruction, regent’s preparation, as well as instruction in the performing arts. 
We have a full performing and visual arts high school, which has a full dance studio, vocal music room, instrumental music room, black box theater, state of the art recording studio housed in the Arts wing. Our auditorium has undergone a complete renovation by the Bette Midler Foundation in 2015-2016 making it both aesthetical and functional.
McKinney is also a registered College Board school.  Our students participate in Advanced Placement courses offering them the opportunity to acquire college credits and experience college rigor necessary for the transition from high school to college.
Having to have been a Nationally Certified AVID School, we continue to use strategies for students of color who also are among the 1st in their families to go to college.  This program uses specific strategies to encourage an early interventio

Q46_1:
Our Arts Program has helped changed the lives of many students. Thanks to funding received from the VH1 Save the Music Foundation
and the Middle School Initiative Afterschool Grant, we have just completed year 4 of our new and improved Arts Education Program. VH1 Save the Music Foundation provided us with band instruments and other resources necessary to establish a music program. Every single child in the building learns to play an instrument. Students are learning to play one of the following instruments- flute, clarinet,
saxophone, trumpet, trombone, drums, violin, viola or cello. To ensure the sustainability of the program, VH1 Save the Music also provides
us with partnerships and mentorship opportunities. The supported provided by VH1 Save the Music has been tremendous and has also resulted in our chorus being featured on Gloria Estefan's original song ³America´which was apart of the soundtrack for 2015 Macy's Fourth of July Fireworks show. The funding received from the Middle School Initiative Grant was use to launch a free afterschool
program centered around the arts. Our afterschool provider is ArtsConnection. This organization has created a program designed to link learning and the arts. Over the past 4 years, they have worked on exposing our students to wide array of art disciplines- dance, music, visual arts, drama and moving images. ArtsConnection has also successfully infused opportunities for students to develop social
emotional skills around leadership, citizenship, discipline and building community.
Q47_1: Over the past few years, the population of students performing at a Level 1 and Level 2 has increased drastically. As a result, we have a greater amount of students with significant academic needs. Many of our students require extended day supports in addition to traditional supports rendered during the regular school day. A large majority of our students are considered at-risk due to their academic, social, economic and/or housing status. We have a special education population of 35%

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R3: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: At P.S. 270 we believe the arts are an essential part of education for all students. We engage our students both inside and outside of the classroom. Our current arts program seeks to provide a comprehensive arts education that draws upon the expertise of teaching artists, classroom teachers, and our community's cultural resources. Our full-time visual arts program provides students with the opportunity to explore various media such as painting, drawing, collage, recycling, and pottery. Our students participate in monthly and holiday assemblies that help to develop and showcase their skills in acting, singing, and dancing. Our new partnership with LEAP has enabled us to offer all K-5 students a rich after school program offering visual arts, dance, movement, music, drama, and STEM five days a week.
Q47_1: As a small school with a limited budget, we have to be creative with our arts programming.  The bulk of our performing arts offerings happen through an after school grant that will serve our students for the next five years.

We currently serve a gentrifying community. The enrollment at the school is very low and the  funding is low because of this. The art funding for supplies this year was different and much needed. Low number of students impact the ability to hire dedicated art teaching staff. We use a lot of digital media for the visual and media arts in classrooms with the teachers.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R3: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
The students at PS 305 participated In the LEAPS after school program which provided the following cultural and performing arts educational experiences:
Dance
Theater
Music/Vocal
Visual Arts
Poetry

The “Music and the Brain” keyboard lab and a wide assortment of classroom instruments is part of the general music curriculum at P.S. 307. Classes at P.S. 307 has music at least once a week in a dedicated music classroom. Pre-K classes learn movement, rhythmic notation, and begin to learn to play a variety of different instruments. Kindergarten through Grade 2 builds on those instrumentation skills, with a primary focus on the keyboard. Grades 3-5 audition for choir and perform in various ensembles. Cumulatively, a student who has completed the Music Program Experience at P.S. 307 will be capable of playing a number of instruments, have a firm grasp on rhythmic notation concepts, and have gained performance experience. The visual art program at P.S. 307 gives students the opportunity to explore various art media and methods, and to learn about art traditions and artists from diverse cultures and time periods. Instruction is designed to push students further to use their knowledge of materials and methods to explore experiences and ideas through art making and visually communicate to the viewer.  The art curriculum is extremely varied in terms of media and method, using pencil, charcoal, oil pastels, paint, paper, cardboard, wood, fabric, clay, and found objects. Methods such as drawing, painting, 3D construction, sculpting, collage, mosaics, and printmaking are used.  Art instruction at P.S. 307 strives to teach students that they are all highly creative and capable of making great artwork.
Q47_1: P.S. 307 is a Magnet School for STEM Studies. In addition to offering visual art and music to our students, we also engage our students in Engineering Adventures and Computer Science Instruction. Our school population is comprised of general education students, students with IEPs and students on the autism spectrum.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Twice a week, 6th Grades students explore all art strands (Visual Art, Vocal, Drama and Dance). In 7th and 8th Grade, students are assigned to an art strand major, where they focus on that major for two years, meeting twice a week for double periods.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: All of UAMA’s arts programs are built around core outcomes. At UAMA, every student will: • Build a functioning arts vocabulary • Understand the historical development of the arts • Value the arts as a mode of personal expression • Produce art that explores bigger social issues and themes • Defend their work both written and verbally • Connect with career and higher education opportunities in the field. UAMA integrates visual, literary and musical arts into the academic school day. While we have full-time music and visual arts teachers, there are plenty of opportunities to allow for students to engage with the creative arts in other content specifc classrooms with arts integrated units. Students also participate in Extended Studio art classes taught by professional artists once a week in an extended school day. Students have the opportunity to connect with professional internships and undertake independent projects under the guidance of an Extended Studio Teacher and art teacher. Students share their work in class critiques and share-outs and around the school in displays. Field trips, events, and visiting artists further enrich students’ experience and allow them to consider how their academic and arts experiences can translate into careers and life-long interests. UAMA also provides enrichment and internship programs that extend beyond the school day. These take place both at UAMA (through our Extended Studio after-school program) and off-site, through our partnerships.

Students engage in theater arts programming from grades 6 -8.  Grade 6 focuses on improv, narrative elements and characterization.  Grade 7 focuses on public speaking, debate, group skits.  Grade 8 focuses on PSAs and other means of exploring the use of theater to understand the self, the other and to impact the community.

Every BCAM student takes Studio Art in their 9th grade year, Photography in 10th Grade Filmmaking in their 11th grade year, and in 12th grade students complete a year-long competitive art college portfolio course. Additionally, students are required to take a variety of elective arts seminars in all grades, and we offer seven rigorous semester-long afterschool arts academies that are enrolled by student application/audition: Printmaking, Fashion Design, Photography, Theater, Filmmaking, Mural Painting, Modern Dance, and Music Production. BCAM’s goals and priorities for meeting the New York State Education Department (NYSED) instructional requirements for the arts include expanding our curricular offerings to include a four-year visual art scope and sequence for our students. This will increase our ability to provide rigorous instruction that meets NYSED visual arts commencement standards 1c (demonstrate an increasing level of competence in using the elements and principles of art to create art works for public exhibition), 2c (take advantage of community opportunities and cultural institutions to learn from professional artists, look at original art, and increase their understanding of art), and 2d (understand the variety of careers related to the visual arts and the skills necessary to pursue some of them). Specifically, our priority is providing differentiated lessons in rigorous art classes that emphasize skill building, artifact production, and presentation and exhibition of artwork.
The arts program at Science Skills is designed to provide all students with exposure to all aspects of the arts to develop their appreciation, knowledge and skills in the arts.

At SLJ, we believe that a rigorous education includes the arts. Through a variety of arts experiences and partnership opportunities, we make the arts a powerful partner in learning. In 10th and 12th grade, students are exposed to a variety of arts through connections made in content classes and outside arts partnerships. In 9th and 11th grade, students are given exposure to over 20 arts providers for after school and enrichment opportunities. Approximately fifty students across the school participate in off-site enrichment programming in the arts.

The art department at Arts and Letters is committed to cultivating creative confidence in our students through a rich program in visual arts, movement, creative writing, music and theater. From k- 8 students experience an in-depth investigation in the arts. Students create art through inquiry, with a strong focus on revision and reflection. Two times a year students exhibit and perform their work in our bi-annual Art Expo; it is an event drawing hundreds of people and a chance for students to present their work publicly. We believe giving students a rigorous arts education allows students to discover their own interests, develop their voice and expand their critical thinking skills. The arts are a vital part of children’s growth, not only as learners, but as whole people. What is a Culture of Creative Confidence? • A belief in ones abilities and ideas and the abilities and ideas of those around them. • A growth mindset (rather than fixed) that allows for development, evolution, improvement and advancement. • A personal outlook that includes an understanding of the importance of creative thinking and the process that is involved. • An ability to receive and give critique without complaint or insecurity.

Students are offered visual arts during the school day. In visual arts classes, students used digital and other art media, which include written descriptions and student-produced art. Each unit culminates with the students' presenting their work, including an explanation of their artistic choices. All students provide feedback to their peers throughout the year, both written and verbal. Students are given additional opportunities to participate in arts-related classwork and field trips. Students in senior English classes benefit from working with teaching artists from TDF who provide instruction in theater and performance art and accompany students on trips to see plays studied in class. Our freshman, will continue to participate in theatrical spoken word through the Brooklyn Arts Museum (BAM). Next year, we are partnered with Sing for Hope and will be offering music programming for students. We would like to offer music production/chorus and dance.

The goal of our arts programming at UAI is to provide students with exposure to a wide variety of art forms and depth of understanding through visual art, based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Furthermore, our program works with core content teachers to develop units that complement each other. Unfortunately, we do not have the funds for more arts like dance and music at our school.

Q44_R1_C10: program was originally scheduled for after school, this was in conflict with student obligations, and so participation was low. Would engage provider if was able to schedule during the school day
Q46_1: The Visual Arts program at Brooklyn Academy High School is focused on encouraging creativity and personal expression, developing decision-making and critical thinking skills, and increasing communication and listening skills. Through Studio Art, Introduction to Design, and Contemporary Arts Survey classes, students find their voices to express meaning from experiences in their everyday lives. Students regularly participate in discussions about art in a social context, thus allowing for a dialogue that inspires visual awareness. The use of collaborative and cooperative work provides experiences to express ideas and problem solving skills that lead to a well-rounded student.
Q47_1: Brooklyn Academy High School is a Transfer High School located in the BedStuy section of Brooklyn. In keeping with the mission of NYC DOE Transfer schools, we have a relatively small student population, as we service students who are "at-risk", and are mainly over age, and under credited.

Q46_1: Westinghouse High School will continue to provide various and engaging arts opportunities to our students and their families, such as Jazz, HipHop classes, theatrical events, spoken word and drama workshops. Our goal for the 2017-2018 school year is to increase and enhance our current arts program by providing a variety of artistic opportunities to engage the whole school community.

Brooklyn High School for Leadership and Community Service is a transfer school, and as such, a large part of our mission is to re-engage students. This year we continue to use the arts as an effective reengagement tool and have a full time visual arts teacher, as well as two part-time art therapists. Additionally, students have had the opportunity to participate in our film program that includes an artist in residence from Education Video Center who team teaches our Documentary Film class throughout the year. As our film program and partnership with EVC continues to flourish, our students will be afforded the opportunity to have their student films viewed at the Youth Powered Video Film Festival at the AMC Loews Theater in June. We also collaborated with the arts organization Dance Theater Etcetera in April and held a three day school wide Poetry Slam with professional poets who also facilitated poetry workshops with all of our students to celebrate poetry month. Additionally, we had a Teaching Artist teach four animation through applications workshops, and our art teacher partnered with the organization Arts Against Violence who facilitated four workshops through our art classes. Our visual arts teacher also coordinated a trip in which students attended F.I.T's Portfolio Day at the Javits Center. All in all we offered many opportunities to engage students through the arts. Looking ahead to the 2018-2019 school year, we will continue to utilize the arts to inspire students as we hope to expand upon our arts programming.

This year our goal was to maintain our strong theater partnerships. We maintained the Bric visual arts and film opportunities and dance program within our after school programming. We offer and intensive Shakespeare study to all students once a year in partnership with Lincoln Center Theater, and all students have the opportunity to view the play. Through our partnerships with the Strike Anywhere,and the Irondale Theater Ensemble we expanded our theater programming to include having students develop original monologues based on their personal stories and present them formally.  Our grade 6 students shared their work at the Irondale Theater Ensemble space and the grades 7 & 8 presented in our newly refurbished auditorium.  We also extended this work to families at a special event hosted by the Irondale Theater Ensemble.

This year we did not win any grants for art an our budget doesn't allow us to hire an artist. Our music teacher puts on show with students 3 times a year. All students receive music class 2 to 3 periods a week.

Arts education is a very important component of the curriculum at PS 17. Our music and art teachers work with every student pre-k through Grade 5 all year providing valuable enrichment to the lives of each child attending our school. The Williamsburg Movement and Art Center provides dance and creative movement classes to every class in our school. Our students are encouraged to visit locations where art and music are celebrated through class trips and classroom experiences. We hope to see more arts providers coming to PS 17 for the 2018-2019 school year

The arts program at PS 18 consists of visual arts and drama/vocal music for all students in pre k-5th grades. Students are also exposed to cultural trips and performances throughout the year. Hosh Kids  provide HipHop dance and yoga to all students in pre-k-5th grades during the school day. Kindergarten works with the Galli Theater to see performances in German and participate in drama workshops after each performance. P.S. 18 is in the process of building relationships with other cultural institutions to increase our students' exposure to the arts.

At PS 23 we are committed to providing our students access to a wide variety of arts programming. This year we focused on dance, theater, music, digital film and visual arts. Through a grant through from the Wallentas Foundation we were able to provide all students in pre-k, kindergarten, and first grade students with a rich dance program.  Students in second and fifth grade participated in musical theater. Our second graders were part of an audience in four different concerts.  Our third and fourth grade students were engaged in visual and digital art.  This partnership was with the 92nd St. Y.  Finally, students in grades two through five were involved in a guitar club which took place after school. Our arts classroom is equipped to provide visual art instruction to all classes. It is our goal to continue these programs obviously pending the funding.
Q47_1: We are currently functioning as a STEM school.  My vision is to have a STEAM education program for our students.  A little over 30% of our school population is composed of students with special needs.  The arts is an avenue for students to express themselves.  If provided with more funding, we could have an arts education teacher to support our students.

Q46_1: This year, our PTA actively engaged ongoing fund raising throughout the year to support the arts at PS 31. This enabled us to expand our arts program to include Eckford Art Visual Arts Program, WMAAC, early childhood dance and movement, ballroom dance programs, square dancing, a resident artist from the 92nd St.Y, pre-k, Little Kids Rock, assemblies and an early childhood theater program. The Common Core Standards were infused throughout the various art programs. The students also went on a vast array of field trips exploring the arts.

P.S. 34 provides a rich art education to all its students. Kindergarten-fifth grade students participate in weekly art classes. They study various art media as well as the history of art. In addition, we have partnerships with BRIC and Eckford Street Studio to supplement instruction in the visual arts. Our schoolwide art show is held at the Brooklyn Expo Center, a local event space. In addition, students participate in an Art Parade where they present projects based on artists studied in class that year. P.S. 34 is currently in the fourth year of a Disney grant. This year, the students from 3rd, 4th and 5th grades performed Jungle Book. Second and third grade students present one act plays under the guidance of Kevin Ray from Everybody Act. Grade 5 students participate in Dancing Classrooms, a ballroom dancing program. Grades 1-4 study dance with the Williamsburg Movement and Art Center. P.S. 34 is currently in their 13th year of a partnership with Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. Students in Kindergarten, first, third and fourth grades receive music instruction through this program. Pre-Kindergarten through second grade also study music with the Key of Be program. Ms Goslar, a parent and founder of Key of Be conducts a lunchtime chorus for third, fourth and fifth grade students, as well. The chorus performs for the school community several times a year.

Q39_4: Participating in arts programming for parents
Q46_1: We have an extensive arts program at MS 50 that combines in-school arts curricula (music, band, visual arts provided by two full time licensed art/music teahers, our Integrated Arts Program (IAP) that partners community school teaching artists with content area teachers (ELA, Social Studies, ENL) to integrate theater, visual arts, music and dance into our content area curricula, and diverse arts programming as part of our Expanded Learning Time (ELT). El Puente’s IAP includes a codified professional development/training curriculum to support teachers to work with teaching artists to create integrated lesson plans and theme-based projects that will enrich the math curriculum. MS 50 has also partnered wtih El Puente to engage its resident mural group, Los Muralistas de El Puente, to create community murals on MS50’s large exterior wall on Roebling Street, as well as on several interior school walls. Los Muralistas will not just to create the mural for the school, but will facilitate an interdisciplinary mural painting initiative. Students will gather oral histories in social studies, design mural proposals in ELA, study scaling in math, and analyze effects of erosion on different paints/surfaces in science. Our community mural painting project, for example, will have an important math application as students will be asked to use transferring, graphing, and scaling to in bringing the mural from design to larger than life reality.

At P.S. 59, arts instruction is provided across all grades during the school day for a minimum of once weekly as well as a comprehensive after-school enrichment offering. The emphasis for our students is on applied projects and experiences in the arts disciplines. For example, in music our students were learning the building blocks and elements of music-reinforced learning concepts of rhythm, beat, and the beginnings of musical notation. Our 5th grade students were involved in a digital music recording project where they were given an opportunity and the guidance to compose their own song. Their classroom activities included writing lyrics, creating melodies, and arranging their composition in order to complete a culminating performance project during P.S. 59s graduation ceremony. In theater/dramatic arts, our students are involved in all aspects of our annual Disney Jr. theater production. This year our students also starred in their own music video debuting our school song. Our Visual arts and dance instruction during the year are offered by Community Based Organizations as partners and help to round out our arts education  offering
Q47_1: We are a Title 1 school in need of more funding in order to provide  in depth comprehensive arts education to our students. Although we believe arts education is important, the funding that we currently receive is allotted to academic programming, where we also have a critical need.

Q44_R5: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our school offers a challenging arts program to students in grades 6-12. Students in all grades receive the opportunity for arts instruction in instrumental music, theater arts, animation and/or visual arts. Students in grades 6 and 7 take one semester of each arts course before settling on an area of focus for 8th grade which will expose them to all of the art forms. High school students are provided with a choice regarding their arts program and are able to choose from a variety of disciplines. Within their major, students dive deep into different forms of coursework and are expected to be a part of our school's performances, concerts, gallery exhibitions, and arts-based internships. Partnerships with BRIC, NYU Steinhardt, Little Kids Rock and NURTUREart provide students with professional arts opportunities.

PS 84's arts program is a very comprehensive one, following the Blueprint for the Arts. The arts are integrated in all the content areas using a variety of media and techniques. We are very fortunate to be a part of a community that is enriched with a variety of artists, galleries and studios. Our continuous collaboration with various arts residencies have enriched the arts educations of all our students.

In our dedication and pursuit of "Growing Hearts and Minds," our students' participation in and exploration of multiple art forms bring us closer to fulfilling our mission. Students at PS 110 experience all four art disciplines by the time they graduate from fifth grade: visual arts, music, theater and dance. Our visual arts teacher works with grades kindergarten through fifth to create art pieces incorporating techniques in drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, and sculpture. Learning music through song and keyboard, begins in the early childhood grades. Resident artists provide opportunities for our students to explore their creative talents and abilities through cultural dance, musical theatre and movement, ballroom dancing, and production of Shakespearean plays. In addition to practical educational applications, experiencing the arts allows our children to grow socially, emotionally, and physically.

Creativity flows at PS 120 Magnet School of Architecture, Engineering and Design. Through the arts, within our building, all students engage in a rigorous, rich and exciting hands-on curriculum centered around architecture, engineering and design, while fostering a love of education. PS 120 has many residency programs focusing on various arts disciplines. Throughout our school year, each grade focuses a variety of cultures and countries through the lens of science and social studies. In June we have a culminating festival where the students display all their work. In the art room, using the Blueprint for the Arts as our guide, the children study artists and their works, indigenous crafts, native clothing as well as sites and architecture associated with their curriculum. Trips at PS 120 are curriculum based to enhance the subject area about which the students are learning. Our new Magnet grant will afford our students new learning experiences with art and technology to think outside the box and to become global citizens. The learning comes alive through visual arts, music, theater, dance and design. Step into PS 120 at any time and a warm and visually inviting atmosphere will welcome you.

John Ericsson Middle School 126 School for Environmental Engineering offers a robust and diverse arts education program. Visual Arts teachers continue to find a variety of ways to align their instruction to the Common Core Learning Standards that focus on active learning and higher level thinking. JEMS offers advanced visual arts classes that challenge students to develop skills in drawing, painting, collage, and sculpture while exploring the history and analysis of art through various cultural contexts. This year, we facilitated parent workshops, hosted visiting artists, and collaborated with a local Arts organization to create a large-scale, student designed mural. As a Leader in Me School, our students work diligently and use synergy to showcase their talents to bring our Community School together. We look forward to implementing an artist residency program that will provide targeted enrichment through the arts for our ELL and SPED students during the 2018-2019 school year.

We believe that instruction in the arts is integral to the education of every child. We have a fully equipped art studio with a full-time visual arts teacher. There is a fully equipped music studio with keyboards. A full time music teacher facilitates Music and the Brain curriculum to grades pre-k-3. Selected second – fifth grade students participate in our school band. We have a brand new sprung dance floor in our performing arts space. All students receive dance instruction once a week which includes a twelve week grade specific residency. All teachers are trained in teaching the Blueprint for the Arts. Each grade attends arts related field trips throughout the year. Grades pre-kindergarten – fifth are involved with 2 or more arts based residencies in theater, dance and music. Students have performed American Folk dance, African dance, Jazz dance, ballet and creative movement. This year we launched our Design Lab where students will have an architecture residency with the Salvadori Center.

At PS 147, the arts support other subjects, such as literacy, science, social studies, and math. We have a full-time certified music teacher on staff and utilize the talents of various outside teaching artists to provide visual arts instruction to students in prekindergarten through fifth grade. In addition to our music program and in-school teaching artist residencies, students attend numerous off-site field trips which provide authentic arts learning experiences in all genres of the arts. Community Arts Partnerships have been steadily growing. We are particularly proud of the active role our parents, many of them artists themselves, have taken in increasing our students' exposure to the creative and performing arts. All classroom teachers have been trained in Visual Thinking Strategies and Arts instruction is aligned with New York State Arts Standards, as well as the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts.

Q39_4: after school art program for adults

Q46_1: Our goal at Public School 250 is to continue to have a comprehensive arts education program that is interdisciplinary and aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts. Our Magnet theme of Communications and Multimedia Arts will continue to be embedded throughout the school curriculum. We recognize the importance that the arts play in developing students who are creative, critical thinkers and students who can solve real world problems in order to express themselves in different ways. At PS 250, the arts disciplines are incorporated into the school curriculum as a means of encouraging culturally sensitive diversity, and community involvement. We pride ourselves in keeping the arts at the forefront of our students' educational experiences.

Q44_R1_C1: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: We offer a broad range of arts experiences as part of our comprehenisve curriculum. We currently offer courses in concert band, jazz band, guitar, modern dance, theater, songwriting, photography,sound engineering, digital film, ceramics and visual arts.
Q47_1: We are a Title 1 middle school who service the students who reside in the Williamsburg, Greenpoint, Bushwick and Bedford Stuyvesant communities. Our goal is to ensure all students have access to all of the Arts programs we offer. Many of the students who partake in these programs apply and gain entrance into many of the performance arts high schools.

Q46_1: PS 380 implements visual arts and music and movement programs that incorporates activities aligned to the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts and the New York State Learning Standards. Our visual arts teacher introduces students to a variety of techniques and modalities, and encourages all students to enjoy and appreciate fine arts. Students' artwork decorates the corridors of our school, enriching and enhancing our learning community. Art is also integrated within many curricula areas across all grades by integrating and investigating various art forms. The music and movement program is designed to support the social studies curriculum by highlighting the rhythms and songs of particular cultures and geographical areas. Our children participate in a winter and spring music gala and other cultural celebrations that showcase their vocal and dance talents.

At Brooklyn Arbor Elementary, we infuse art and music into the curriculum wherever possible. We believe that the arts play an integral role in child development and foster the creativity and critical thinking skills necessary for a happy and productive life. Our school offers instruction with both a full time licensed art and music teacher, as well as a plethora of enrichment activities pertaining to the visual and performing arts. Next year we plan on expanding musical performance opportunities for our students. Classroom teachers often include music and movement in their activities, and also engage students in visual arts projects pertaining to their units of study. We also have a unique parent-led initiative, the Materials Depot. In the Depot we organize recyclables as well as donated items. Throughout the day, teachers can browse through the meticulously organized bins and load up on inspiration and supplies. This system promotes our school's mission of environmental consciousness and sustainability.

Art History I and II are one-semester full-time courses, required in 9th and 10th grades. They provide an understanding of the formal and contextual methods of analyzing works in art history. They chronologically introduce major themes, movements, and issues in art history from prehistoric times through abstract expressionism. Assessments include Socratic Seminar, analyzing works of art, short and extended essays. Beginning in the 2018-19 school year, 9th grade will take one semester of Foundations in Visual Art, a course which will cover studio practices and foundational skills in 2-d artmaking.

IB Visual Arts is a two-year full-time course, offered in 11th and 12th grades. Discipuli investigate and analyze works of art by various artists while developing a portfolio. Discipuli utilize a visual arts journal to explore and develop ideas. Assessments throughout the year include interviews in which students present their portfolio and visual arts journal. 

IB Theatre is a two-year full-time course, which is offered to 11th and 12th grades. Discipuli explore theatre history, theory and practice through the lens of a scholar, a historian, an audience member and a practitioner. Assessments include Socratic Seminar, intensive process journals, directors notebooks, research presentations, and collaborative projects.

After school, students engage in studio arts, Stoked, theatre, music and dance enrichment programs at Brooklyn Latin. Public performances are exhibited at least twice a year for these programs.
Q47_1:
Modeled after the prestigious Boston Latin School and founded in 2006, The Brooklyn Latin School (TBLS) provides a classical liberal arts education, including the study of Latin, in a discip curriculum provides the groundwork for an understanding of the foundation of our society, while also developing the leadership capacity of our students to become leaders in their communit based on the New York City SHSAT (specialized high school admissions test).
The Brooklyn Latin School offers an all “honors” curriculum taught by an accomplished staff. All courses presented on the student’s transcript represent challenging academic experiences t courses offered at other schools. All students are required to adhere to our core curriculum, with four years of Latin, English, History, mathematics, science, and at least two years of a world students can expect a strong—and continuing—emphasis on structured writing and public speaking, as well as an overarching practice of the kind of analytical thinking that will ensure all T the rigors of college work.
The Brooklyn Latin School is an International Baccalaureate (IB) School. Under the IB Diploma Programme, all 11th and 12th grade TBLS students engage in a rigorous two­year course of eligible to receive an IB diploma, which is widely recognized and respected by prestigious universities.

Q46_1: Williamsburg HS for Art and Tech  provides students with arts based opportunities, both in and outside of the classroom. We firmly believe that arts education provides students with an opportunity to think critically, and to also find a voice to express themselves. With strategic planning and partnerships, we have a visual arts teacher and theatre teacher available to our students. We also have fostered partnerships with community based organizations, that have provided our students with drama opportunities, as well as opportunities to create art within the greater Williamsburg community.

The performing arts department at PROGRESS is one of the biggest and best in NYC. We have four full concert bands, three jazz bands, four piano classes, and numerous chamber groups such as guitar ensemble (modern band) and clarinet choir. A spring musical is held each year. Students have the option of majoring in music. The instrumental, theater and modern band programs draw from all three schools in the campus and allow students to perform at their ability level regardless of age or experience. All musical ensembles compete annually at the NYSSMA festival where they have received Gold and Gold with Distinction awards. Our visual arts department offers students instruction in the foundations of drawing and painting, stage design, graphic arts and sculpture. Advanced students may move on to studio art classes, and A.P. studio art. The Campus is host to the All City High School Marching Band and the All City High School Concert Band, in which many Grand Street Campus Students participate. The campus also hosts the Brooklyn Wind Symphony, Grand Street Community Band and Kings County Concert Band whose performances are free to students and their families.

For the school year 2017-2018, East Williamsburg Scholars Academy offers music, visual arts, theater, guitar and percussion courses for all students. The Grand Street Campus collaboratively provides the music program for all three schools. Its music program is one of the finest not only on the city level but the state level as well. The program consists of four full concert bands, three jazz bands, as well as classes in guitar and music appreciation. The campus put on a spring musical open to students from all three schools. Students may take a four year major in music. The Grand Street bands have won awards on both the city and state level. In addition, the school, in collaboration with the Urban Arts Partnership, provides dance and percussion classes for all students. Urban Arts Partnership advances the intellectual, social and artistic development of under-served public school students through arts-integrated education.

The performing arts department at EBT is one of the biggest and best in NYC. We have four full concert bands, two jazz bands, music theater, and numerous chamber groups such as guitar ensemble and Latin jazz band. Students have the option of majoring in music. Over 600 students receive music instruction each day. The instrumental, theater and general music programs draw from all three schools in the campus and allow students to perform at their ability level regardless of age or experience. All musical ensembles compete annually at the NYSSMA festival where they have received Gold and Gold with Distinction awards. In addition to our performing groups, students may take classes in technical theater, which prepares students for jobs in the entertainment industry, focusing on stage direction, lighting and sound. Our visual arts department offers students instruction in the foundations of drawing and painting. Advanced students may move on to studio art classes, and AP art history. Students are given the opportunity to participate in the All City High School Concert Band and Marching Band, both of which are hosted at the Grand Street Campus.

The Brooklyn Preparatory High School Arts Program offers students a variety of courses to explore their interest in art and develop skills in the area of their choice. During the first semester of 9th grade, students choose to take an introductory course in either Multimedia Arts or Music Appreciation. Each subsequent semester, students may elect to take additional art courses, such as Comic Illustration, Fine Arts, Photography, Printmaking, Latin Dance, Chorus, Keyboard, HipHop & Spoken Word and Band and Drums. Students who wish to delve deeper in a particular area may apply to take Photography 2, Advanced Fine Arts, Masters of Music, and AP Studio Art.

The Williamsburg High School for Architecture and Design (WHSAD) is a 9-12 college preparatory school committed to developing students as imaginative critical thinkers. Our curricula builds a foundation of visual knowledge, skills and literacy for creative problem solving, as students are exposed to design and architecture in stand-alone courses as well as having these studies infused into their core academic courses. WHSAD promotes academic achievement through the integration of a student’s career interests and aptitude to classroom learning and to the world in which we live. Partnered with the World Monuments Fund and the Park Avenue Armory, WHSAD offers students a unique and engaging four year course sequence with a focus in architectural drafting, design principles, and historic preservation. WHSAD students can earn a Career and Technical Education (CTE) endorsed diploma in Architectural Drafting and Design, and up to six college credits upon graduation from our program. All of our students are given the opportunity to participate in paid internships with industry partners.

Williamsburg Prep’s current art program focuses on arts exposure for the 9th grade and more advanced introductory  art classes for upper classmen.  In the future our goal is to offer more advanced art classes to upper grade levels who have attended art classes in 9th grade and show interest and perform with higher art skill levels.  9th grade students currently attend studio art, dance, and theater or creative writing. Juniors and Seniors are offered drawing, intro to painting, counter culture, and computer graphics. Students not in art classes can attend afterschool art club, theater club, and/or dance club. Students have opportunities to showcase their work through art displays in the hallways and talent shows and theater partnerships.

Middle School 577 provides direct arts instruction to the entire student community. All students receive instruction in a variety of disciplines including visual arts, dance and music. Our school goal is to provide students with the opportunity to engage in and seek out and explore their talents and interests in the art field. All students are provided with a three year sequence in music and visual arts. We also offer students the opportunity to engage in clubs specializing in music, dance and art. Our 8th grade students engage in a ten week residency with the American Ballroom Theatre. During the program students are taught the art of ballroom dancing by a licensed dance instructor. Our 6th and 7th grade social studies curriculum infuses project based learning through our residency with Studio in the School to showcase how students can use their knowledge of the content and make their thinking visible. We are fortunate to have dedicated staff members who are able to use their resources to provide our students with a high level of arts education. Moving forward, we hope to seek new opportunities in which our students may engage.

Sixth grade students will analyze their community as urban planners, engineers, and architects. Students will use the influence of their community to inspire their creativity while creating their projects.  Through the artistic process, students will explore many different concepts of these professions. In the seventh grade, students will explore technology in a new and exciting way.  We will be looking at the development of tools and inventions, and how they aid our everyday lives.  Students will explore older technologies as well as creating their own inventions. The eighth grade curriculum is heavily focused on multimedia in the form of advertising.  Advertising consists of effective communication towards a target audience.  Students will learn how to isolate a specific audience and learn how to translate their message both through the use of visuals and supporting text.
Q47_1: Our school will be beginning our third year as a magnet school.  Our magnet themes are multimedia, technology, and urban planning.

Q45_10: ACA Adobe Certified Exam results in PHotoshuo
Q46_1:
This academic year, Automotive High School launched the CTE Digital Art & Design Program. This is the first year the program is officially running. We are in the process of NY State Approval.

Our Digital Art & Design Program offers:
Grade 9
Studio Art 1 & 2

Grade 10
Digital Photography and Imaging 1 & 2

Grade 11
Digital Art and Design 1 & 2

Grade 12
*Career and Financial Management

Grade 12
Advanced Digital Art 1 & 2

Grade 12
Portfolio Development

Students will receive an ACA (Adobe Certified Associate) Certificate of endorsement after successfully passing the Adobe Photoshop assessment.
Q47_1: In addition to the CTE Digital Art & Design Program, Automotive High School also offers a rigorous Studio Art coursework.

Q44_R3: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance

Q46_1: El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice strives to provide all students with rich, inspiring, and culturally relevant engagement in the performing and visual arts. Classes include visual arts, Latin percussion, dance, drama, instrumental music, theater tech/production, and quilting classes taught by our staff artists and teaching artists from our community arts partner, El Puente. Teaching artists also partner with classroom teachers to integrate the arts into academic classes to create student centered learning that supports different learning modalities. We schedule regular cultural celebrations that allow our students to collaborate with their peers in producing  explorations and expressions that reflect a mastery of both the arts and issues they explore through their classes. We provide our students with on-going opportunities and mentoring in the arts, (both in-school and with outside arts institutions), that allow them to develop mastery over their four years at the academy and a life-long love and appreciation of the arts.

Q44_R3: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R5: Snug Harbor Cultural Center & Botanical Garden
Q46_1: P.S. 1 has a strong commitment to the Arts. This year, we added an additional Dance teacher to our Arts Department. Our Arts Department now consists of two Visual Arts teachers, two Dance teachers, two Music teachers, and one Theater teacher. Our Arts Department shares the principal's vision and goal that Arts education is integral to the development of the whole child, and especially important in supporting the learning of our sizable population of English Language Learners, students with special needs, and low-income students. The Arts Department uses the blueprints to guide their instruction, scaffolding to meet the needs of our ELLs, students with special needs, and Title I students. Our strong commitment to the Arts is further evident through our connections with cultural organizations. This year we had residency programs through partnerships with the Brooklyn Museum, LEAP, Making Books Sing & The Dramatists Guild Foundation. Furthermore, we've formed after-school partnerships with the Community Word Project & Brooklyn Youth Chorus. Our Arts Department also forms clubs both after and during school in areas such as film, piano, musical theater and stop-motion. In addition, we hold many arts fairs, and performances throughout the school-year to bring our arts to our parents and community. Our strong commitment to the arts supports all of our learners, helps them be well-rounded members of their community, and prepares them for both college and career.
Q47_1: Our school is made up of 40-50% English Language Learners, 15-20% Students with Special Needs, and over 90% students who receive free-lunch.

Q46_1: It is our goal to educate the whole child, and it is for that reason that we have full-time Art Teacher, Music Teacher and Theater Arts Teacher. We have also pursued and received grants that support the arts in our school. Through collaborations with teaching artists and partnerships with art institutions like The Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Opera Guild, The National Dance Institute, every child experiences a variety of music/theater based arts activities. All students, including those with special needs, are exposed to opera, Broadway musicals, and visual arts projects.

PS 15, The Patrick F Daly Magnet School of the Arts, is a STEAM school with a focus on project based learning.  Our units of study are interdisciplinary and the arts are infused throughout the curriculum.  It is our goal for students to see and explore themselves as artists.  We reserve time for the arts not only through our units of study but in direct service in the areas of music and visual arts on staff as well as every class in the building receiving at least one residency with a teaching artist and community organization in the area of theater, digital arts, visual arts, movement and/or music. We believe the arts is a vital and vibrant component to any school community and we are fortunate to offer our students the opportunity to explore, perform and create every day.

During the 2017-2018 school year students continued to become more involved with the arts. We continued our affiliation with the Metropolitan Opera Guild which afforded our fifth grades classes to make two visits. We continued our work with Studio in a School. One PreK class and three kindergarten classes worked with a teaching artist to receive collage, painting and other visual arts instruction. We entered year 2 of the Disney Musical in Schools grant which enabled us to perform Aladdin for three nights to our families and school community. We continued our collaboration with Arts Connection. Because we were recipients of the SWD/ELL grant for the 2017-2018 school year, we were able to provide visual arts, music and dance instruction to all kindergarten students with Arts Connection. Arts Connection also worked with first grade students on puppetry and second grade students on dance. Students in kindergarten, second, third and fourth grades worked with teaching artists from New Victory Theater, integrating theater into classrooms. They also attended performances there. Continuing our collaboration with Brooklyn Arts Exchange, teaching artists worked with second, third and fifth grades, incorporating dance and movement. S'Cool Sounds provided music instruction to third, fourth and fifth grades. Thanks to funding from our Councilmember, we had Brooklyn Arts Council work with 40 students afterschool on puppetry and dance. We look forward to continuing to grow arts instruction for all of our students.

Our active PTA arts committee oversees arts events in our school and, in collaboration with the PS29 Administration, helps identify, research and make recommendations for arts collaborations with world-class cultural organizations. This past year our collaborations included: Brooklyn/Queens Conservatory of Music (BQCM)optional band for 4th and 5th grade students, American Ballroom Theater’s Dancing Classrooms, Brooklyn Academy of Music, African Dance, a music residency, STREB, and educational partnership with Bent on Learning, Yoga and Let's Play Chess. Our goal as an arts committee and school is for all students at PS 29 to have a well-rounded arts education. The PTA has made the arts a priority in their annual budget, which will allow the school to participate in these various programs for the 2018-2019 school year.

P.S. 32 provides each student with an arts education that will develop creative ability and nurture a lifelong appreciation for the various art forms, while meeting benchmark arts standards. We address academic and social needs of our diverse student population. P.S. 32 will continue to offer a challenging visual arts and creative dance program as well as an in depth keyboarding, ukulele, and choral music program. P.S. 32 plans to continue the relationship with all current cultural arts partners (Rioult, Arts Connection, Metropolitan Opera, and others) and has begun new collaborations with community based art programs such as Artichoke Dance Company and Brooklyn Arts Exchange. Students from pre-k through 5th Grade make connections between what they learn in school and the cultural world around them by attending arts events around the city.

Our goal at P.S. 38 is to infuse the arts into everyday curriculum. Students receive instruction in the arts at every grade level. From keyboard instruction to dance, students have exposure to every type of art form. Our focus continues to be various dance forms, steel pan, violin, percussions and piano instruction. Our STEM lab has now been open for a year. This has enabled our staff to enhance our visual and audio arts program. Our STEM team works diligently to connect technology to the visual arts. We have an extensive steel pan orchestra. Students in grades 3-5 pride themselves with mastering different arrangements, which can be quite complex. Our hallways come alive with music. At P.S.38 we feel the arts are essential to learning. Studying the arts gives students a window into the rich and interesting world around them, teaching them about their own history and culture, as well as that of other people. It cultivates self-expression, imagination and creativity as well as critical-thinking and problem solving skills.

Our school continues to have a full time visual arts teacher who works weekly with all students in grades pre-k-5. All of our students receive additional arts education through extensive arts in school residencies in music, dance, and theater. Arts education is further supported through field trips.

Q44_R3: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: William Alexander Middle School 51 has a robust Arts curriculum.   Every student chooses a specialty (Dance, Drama, Vocal, Instrumental, Photography or Studio Art) when they enter the school in grade 6 and remain in the program for three years.  The students receive an in-depth education in the Art of his/her choice.

PS 94 offers Theater, Dance and Ballroom, Visual Arts, Chorus and Music. These programs consist of high levels of engagement through enjoyable and challenging learning experiences that are constructed around students' interests, learning styles and preferred modes of expression. All students receive instruction that is developmentally appropriate and aligned to the NYS learning standards in the arts. The curriculum allows for instruction to develop a student's ability to express themselves, build skills and knowledge in a variety of forms and provide a sense of belonging in the school community. In addition, our after-school programs are driven by three goals developing talents, providing a broad range of enrichment experiences, and providing follow up opportunities for all students based on their strengths and interests. Our after-school programs consist of: chorus, violin, guitar, flutes, drums, dance, ballroom dancing and theater. We have partnerships with the Brooklyn Arts Council, where students K-2 participate in storytelling through puppetry, murals and mosaics, and African dance. The Brooklyn Youth Chorus for students 3-5 thrives on developing singers and vocal ensembles re-envisioning choral music performance through voice training and music study with performance experiences. Dancing Classrooms, who support our students to develop and cultivate essential life skills and behaviors such as respect, teamwork and discipline through the art of social dance.

Q44_R5: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance
Q46_1: PS 107 has a rich and varied arts program that includes weekly instruction with instructors who are highly effective in their disciplines: visual arts and music. Our students also enjoy many PTA-funded arts residencies. We feel strongly that arts education is essential for all children in that it provides multiple opportunities for high levels of critical thinking and discourse. Each grade participates in a variety of arts-related field trips. These experiences, in addition to our arts programming and residencies, provide students with valuable experiences and an understanding of the arts as an important creative outlet. Our students are able to develop a deeper understanding of these arts disciplines, while at the same time making rich and lasting connections to literacy, math, social studies and science.

We provide arts to our students using residencies.  Our students receive instruction for teaching artists at Studio in a School, LEAP, BAM, and several other institutions.  The instruction is based on needs and interests of our students.  We plan to continue these programs in the upcoming school year as we continue to grow to fifth grade.

Q44_R3: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
In the 2017-2018 school year, P.S. 124's music and visual arts program will continue to offer sequential, skills-based learning with rich experiences in making music and art, and opportunities for performance and exhibition of students's achievements. Teaching and learning is aligned with New York City's Arts Education Blueprint. Lessons in music and visual arts will address the Common Core Standards; build
content knowledge; comprehend and critique artwork and musical performances; value evidence; use technology capably; come to understand other perspectives and cultures. Visual arts learning focuses on creating  art with different artist's materials, while discussing and comparing different art forms and artists. This includes  2 and 3-dimensional work.   First through fifth grade students all make trips to museums and galleries. Music learning focuses specifically on the students as producers of music, using wind instruments, acoustic guitars and percussion, with a lot of movement activities. All children achieve basic music literacy based on the pentatonic scale and solfège singing.
Grade 1 students participate in theater and learn theater skills, such as, stage presence, projecting voice and listening for cues. All arts instruction integrates teaching practices that support the Common Core State Standards.  This year Community School has provided a visual artist residency program for the kindergarten students.  A grant from the Brooklyn Borough President provided Garage Band and an animation residency.

PS 131 has always been dedicated to including the arts in the education of our children. Our goal is to provide our students a means to express their creative side in the various art media, especially as an outlet for our ENL population and students with disabilities. We strongly feel this will provide a well rounded education needed to be college ready.

At Charles O. Dewey, students have their normal Common Core curriculum infused with technology , career readiness and the Seven Habits from the "Leader in Me" program. We are very successful with several shows through out the year, where we showcase mutlimedia artwork and performances created from our student body, and through our partnerships that was formed with NurtureArt, Aperture, Residency Unlimited, NYSSAA, Groundswell, Leader in Me Foundation, and our in-house CBO Center for Family Life. Through these collaborations, students have participated in art internships around mural execution and curating, art seminars, and workshops that connect them to artists in their community. Opportunities for creativity are limitless through a wide range of extracurricular activities and project-based learning in all content areas using STREAM (science, tech, reading, engineering, art and math).

Arts is embedded into the curriculum at Brooklyn New School PS 146. Students receive classes with a music and art teacher and instruction provided by teaching artists from the Brooklyn Arts Exchange. As well, third grade students participate in an African dance residency through the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In addition, both the visual arts and performance arts are developed through the social studies curriculum within the classroom. In our third fourth and fifth grades, students participate in arts workshops where they create models of crafts from other cultures. Open ended inquiry allows students to use the arts for exploration. In this way, students apply the skills learned in the art, music and theater classes to develop their own creations, whether these be skits, shadow puppet theatre, models of buildings, or other visual and musical expressions.

Our cluster teachers include one visual art teacher and one theater arts teacher. Every class in grades K-5 receives one period of instruction in each discipline. We also have a music program that is funded by the PTA. Students in every class receive instruction one period a week from our music teacher.

The Sunset Park School is a Title I elementary school with a diverse population of 1,497 students. Our unique school  offers students with daily opportunities to partake in the arts and value our own and other cultures. Our largely ELL population, enjoy the arts regularly with our eight in-house art specialists, exposing them to a robust Blueprint based arts program. Students regularly engage in sequential CCSS aligned curriculum. Students' exemplary work is showcased in exhibits and in-house displays and in citywide festivals. Students are challenged and empowered through productive struggle and gain autonomy to produce creative individual and group projects. P.S. 169 offers students grades K-5 a robust, engaging and empowering after-school enrichment program that meets once or twice a week for two hours each. These clubs offer chorus, visual art, mastering playing musical instruments such as violin, guitar, drums, band, drama, cooking and more. In addition, students engage in skits through the art of improvisation, share their visual art accomplishments and play musical instruments during our in-house monthly, shared assemblies collaborated by the art department. Students frequently go on trips to cultural institutions and benefit from hands-on experiences to theater and dance performances and visual art exhibits. Through the social-emotional approach students experience the arts and grow as artists as well as empowered individuals who appreciate the value of the arts.

P.S. 172 offers a comprehensive foundation in the arts. In dance class, students learn creative movement, cultural, and traditional dance technique. They work with the elements of dance, improvising, choreographing, performing, and critiquing as their skills grow. Through their time in dance class, students learn historic and current dances from around the world and hone their ability to create their own choreographic work and be discerning audience members. Art class begins with a visual or tactile exploration for motivation or the introduction of an artist or skill technique. Students partake in a wide range of art-making processes and experiment with various media and techniques as they learn about art and artists from an historical and contemporary perspective. In music class, students experience a wide variety of musical genres, instruments, songs, and composers. They develop musical skills and concepts needed to succeed in any general music setting. Instruction draws on musical learning methods including the Orff Shulwork, Kodaly, and Dalcroze methods in order to allow students to explore their voices, strengthen ear training, and develop the confidence they need to succeed in any musical setting. Through their studies in all arts disciplines, students learn problem-solving, expression, vocabulary, social skills, self-confidence and creativity. Social studies and classroom vocabulary curricula are integrated into arts lessons to further support student learning.

Our Title 1 and 3 school has over 1,200 students. They all receive visual arts at least once a week. Many also receive music and dance. We have three visual arts teachers, one dance and one music. We provide many arts residencies. Each winter we perform The Nutcracker in which over 100 children from K to 5th grade perform, design sets, make costumes, perform as stage and lighting technicians and design the program. The Nutcracker also has many of our special needs children performing in the show.This project has not only created a bonding with students in multiple grades and abilities, but with the teachers as well. They pitch in to help with everything, especially performance night. The arts is very helpful as a vocabulary builder for our large ESL population. We have twenty-six languages represented in our school. The arts gives children the confidence needed to tackle academic subjects, and gives beauty to their lives through the visual arts, music, drama and dance. Parents often ask "What is the value of an arts education?" We tell them that the arts is the only subject where the correct answer is not in the back of the book. You learn that the world is not just black and white and that your answer to an artistic solution is just as valid as everyone else. They learn about their own culture and others' through art projects.
Q47_1:
For our students who arrive daily from foreign countries the arts might be their only success for the week. In music and art you can participate without knowledge of language.
This success will hopefully carry over into the classroom to help them feel confident to tackle other subjects.
The arts get students excited about coming to school to finish a new art project, or finish learning a new song.
The arts can make people feel good about themselves.

Q46_1: These are the types of arts experiences that should be available for all PS 261 students in each grade, every year: 1. Core Arts discipline instruction in visual art, music, dance and theater every year for every student with a full-time certified teacher providing a year-long curriculum. 2. Arts integration experiences that bring in interdisciplinary arts across the curriculum in connection with learning in all subject areas. 3. Arts enrichment classes, performances, or residencies that add to or supplement instruction in the arts and arts integration. 4. City, community, and/or neighborhood-based arts experiences like field trips and other real world experiences outside of school.

PS 295 is a community that embraces diversity by nurturing strengths and talents of every child. We strive to educate the whole child while supporting them to be successful both socially and academically. In recognizing that all children learn in different ways, we believe that an arts integrated curriculum cultivates a more meaningful discovery of self, while enhancing prior knowledge and supporting content and language development. It is our hope to encourage a strong respect and appreciation for the arts. Our professional development program provides ongoing learning and leadership opportunities for all members, while offering students an exemple for becoming lifelong learners and leaders of the future.

We believe that all children should have an opportunity to participate in a variety of kinds of art instruction.  All of our students have music and visual arts provided by arts specialists.  In addition, we have many arts residencies for our students in grades 2-5.  Classroom teachers value the arts and there are many opportunities throughout the week for children to do art in the classroom. Social studies is an area where art is fully integrated, so, for example, as our third grades study the rain forest they make papier mache animals, murals, and perform plays.   Our fifth graders participate in an enrichment cycle where they can choose from a variety of options, including many arts choices such as performing Shakespeare, digital photography, garage band, jewelry making, and more.  Trips are an important part of our curriculum across the grades, and in all grades children go to art museums (Brooklyn Museum of Art, MOMA, the Met, and more), other museums (NY Historical Society, Museum of Natural History) and theater and dance performances.

The visual arts program involved 80% of the school population and culminated in many student gallery shows in diverse media within the school. These have included digital photography, watercolor painting and clay sculpture. Creative self-expression and developing technical skills are emphasized. An art history course was added to the school curriculum and students in the class visited the Whitney Museum of American Art. The music program continues to emphasize student composition through its songwriting course, as well as introducing novice students to playing a variety of popular musical instruments.

Students admitted to Digital Arts and Cinema Technology High School choose between the two arts tracks: Digital Arts or Cinema Production.
