They will then embark on a four-year intensive study and production course sequence. In each track, students will learn fundamental and complex concepts/skills necessary in the respective fields, while simultaneously being provided the time, support and reflection to develop their artistic body of work. The respective programs have developed partnerships enabling seniors to participate in internships before graduation. All students will graduate with a minimum of eight credits in the arts.

This school year we added a full time certified music teacher.  We continue to have a full time visual arts teacher.  All students in the school have had a full year of instruction in visual art, vocal music, instrumental music and music composition.  Our pottery program will be incorporated into the school day in the upcoming school year.  We continue to be part of the Broadway, Jr. program, which has grown each year and currently serves 45 students.
Q47_1: MS 442 is a small middle school in District 15.  The school has 4 6th grade ICT classes, 3 7th grade and 3 8th grade ICT classes.  There are currently three ASD/Nest classes (one per grade). For 2018-2019, we will have 4 6th grade ICT classes (2 of which are ASD/Nest classes, 4 7th grade ICT classes (1 ASD/Nest) and 3 8th grade (1 ASD/Nest).

Q46_1: Since its inception, the school has offered electives and concentrated instruction in the arts disciplines of visual art, dance, instrumental music, theatre, and graphic arts/technology component. Our unique vision is to allow our students to excel both artistically and academically in a positive, nurturing, and literate environment. We provide an arts education that develops the creative potential of each student. Our arts program is designed to not only develop the talent and knowledge of our students but to also ignite their artistic passions. We believe that children who study and practice the arts enhance their intellect, learn self-discipline and realize the global implications of creativity and culture.

Dance students study Jazz, Contemporary Choreography and World Dance. Students learn and demonstrate choreography as well as choreograph in groups with their peers. 

Music students learn to play an orchestral instrument and work together in small and large ensembles. Students study music notation, music theory, music history, composition, improvisation, and a wide variety of musical genres from around the world. 

Theater students engage in improvisation, scene study, monologue study, playwriting, and play making, and design, and will read and perform the works of contemporary and classic playwrights. 

Visual art students use art elements, skills, techniques, and processes to structure visual art works in the media of drawing, painting, sculpture, printmaking, photography, illustration, and design with an emphasis on developing well-rounded visual art portfolios. Students use processes of critical analysis to support personal judgments of visual art works to better understand the range of artistic traditions of different cultures, time periods and art movements.

Brooklyn Collaborative is a NYC Outward Bound School. We use the EL Education model, which has its roots in Outward Bound. We are a diverse and respectful community committed to developing students and staff who are kind, openminded, persistent, responsible, collaborative and courageous. 

We offer various arts classes for grades 6-12 that include case studies on current events, world cultures, and social justice issues. Grades 6, 7, and 8 have a strong foundation in general music, beginning instrumental studies, theater and movement, and visual art. As students continue their studies in the arts in our upper grades, the classes become more specific. Some courses that are offered include Modern Rock Band, Evolution of Music, ASL Theater, Art History, Studio Art, and Art and Self. As a department, we align our curriculum to state standards as well as the NYC Blueprints for the Arts. With a focus on mastery based grading, we implement many formative assessments as students create high quality work. 

Our partnerships include New Victory Theater, Little Kids Rock, The Rock and Roll Forever Foundation, Acme Hall Studios, Groundswell, Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Brooklyn Arts Exchange.
Q48_1: Christine Favara, Jill Mee, Kori Rushton
Q48_2: arts liaison/music teacher, art teacher, theater teacher

Q46_1: The Secondary School for Journalism offers a digital arts program that includes the following courses: Studio Art, Introduction to Graphic Design, and Digital Media. Through our partnerships, students participated in arts activities with BRIC.

We currently have one full-time dance teacher, one full-time visual arts teacher, and one full time design teacher. . In the high school, we have a Culinary Arts CTE program. Through the Empire Grant we have a partnership with The Leadership Program and are able to provide several arts programs, including a murals program, theater and drama, a capoiera class, and a fashion design class. These activities take place two-three times a week during our after-school program. Through additional funding, we are also able to provide a music studio program and various French bilingual classes, including culinary, media arts, photography, and soccer.

Arts is a vehicle for expression of ideas that serves to enhance educational, academic, and social experience of children at the school. Children benefit from regular and structured arts programs, each and every day. Art develops intelligence, competencies, and skills that have a direct link to academic performance. Our goal is to allow students to experience a rich and diverse arts program. As we grow to scale, we envision regular participation in all art disciplines for all students. Currently, we have a full- time visual arts provider to deliver art lessons in school and a full-time dance teacher providing dance lessons. Students were able to showcase their arts education to teachers, families, and classmates through a combined visual and performing arts event that included an arts auction, workshops, and a dance performance. Our 1st-4th graders received Theater lessons through Center for Arts Education (CAE). CAE also provided dance residencies for PreK-2nd grade. Students also have opportunities to visit cultural organizations and arts venues on school trips to experience the arts outside of school. In addition, we currently have a partnership with Creative Music Program to ensure our students receive music instruction; we hope to continue this partnership next school year.

The Cobble Hill School of American Studies offers robust opportunities in the arts, including dedicated dance/fitness classes, Studio Art 1 and 2 as well as electives in visual arts,and  a full year afterschool improvisation Theatre Program which culminates in an annual off Broadway production through  Opening Act. We also offer a full year STEP/Dance afterschool program through the Leadership Program.  Annually, several classes perform at the CUNY Shakespeare festival. This year we introduced Inside Broadway to our 9th graders where they learned acting techniques used in Broadway throughout the Spring.

West Brooklyn Community High School aspires to engage and motivate overage under-credited high school aged youth. All our programming, including our arts program, is designed with our student population in mind. We plan on continuing our current offerings as well as continuing to survey our students throughout the year and enhancing what we already offer. Mission: We are a community of educators working together collaboratively to provide quality instruction and social emotional support to overage, under-credited , formerly-truant students in order to prepare them for high school graduation, and ultimately, for college and/or career. West Brooklyn Community High School, a partnership between the NYC Department of Education and Good Shepherd Services provides an accelerated, rigorous learning environment. At West Brooklyn Community High School students, their families, and staff work in collaboration to create a physically, emotionally, and socially safe community. At West Brooklyn Community High School, young people recommit to improve their attendance, accumulate credits, develop a life after West Brooklyn plan, and graduate with concrete next steps. Vision: We continually co-create a community filled with intellectual curiosity, high engagement, laughter, and camaraderie. Our students experience academic success in all forms, high expectations in the classrooms, and an excitement for learning.

We currently provide visual arts and dance through DOE personnel. We also provide drama and theater through one outside organization, Enact Inc., which provide in-classroom workshops to our students on a weekly basis. In addition, our students are invited to films and performances a number of times during the year to enhance art instruction and exposure. Our students are excelling in visual arts. For three years in a row, we will have a representative in the annual Borough of Brooklyn Festival of the Arts. The dance teacher has created an Advance Dance Troop which performs around the City to diverse audiences at different venues.

Q44_R4: Circle in the Square Theatre School
Q44_R5: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Brooklyn High School of the Arts, is now a district 15 school in downtown Brooklyn and is the only fully screened arts school in Brooklyn It boasts one of the most accomplished performing and fine arts programs in the City of New York. Our vocal/instrumental music program ranks among the finest in New York, and achieves top scores while performing at the highest level at state and city-wide competitions annually. Our fine arts program routinely wins major competitions, and has been featured in galleries across the country. It is a pipeline to major art universities here in New York and nationally. Our dance program,features the finest instructors in NYC and has our dance students accomplishing tremendous levels of performance. The spring dance concerts have become highlights to our school year. Our drama department featured a spectacular musical theater production of "Into the woods" and also produced a successful production of "Is He Dead". We are one of only four schools featured in the Schubert Theater Festival on Broadway two of the last three years.  We are one of ten "Exploring the Arts/Tony Bennett" partner schools. ETA provides us with many opportunities for real world internships in the arts for our students. In short, if you are interested in studying the arts in high school, and preparing for a major college conservatory or liberal arts college degree, Brooklyn Arts is the school for you!

Students are taking a full three year, six credit sequence in the arts that includes visual arts, dance, instrumental music and multi-media art. Students in the afterschool program can audition for visual arts, dance, choral and theater troupes as well as photography club.

This year our arts program included Visual Arts I and II, Theater I and II, Photography, and Portfolio Arts. Our theatre arts teacher facilitated several successful community-building events, including two musicals and improv shows. All 9th grade students took a required visual arts course in which they acquired academic vocabulary for analyzing historic works of art, their peers' and their own art. They used a range of media, including mixed-media drawing/painting/collage, digital photography, and stop-motion animation to create visually and conceptually compelling works of art that fulfill aesthetic, expressive, narrative, and/or political art purposes. Students had the opportunity to engage in supplementary arts experiences through our afterschool program, which includes Dance, Music and Audi-Visual Clubs. Students participated in Animation and Film programs through BRIC arts and Reel Works residencies funded by the CASA grant. We hope to be able to offer more rigorous arts electives moving forward in a greater range of media, including graphic design, music production, and film editing. Student photography was exhibited in a Gowanus Arts Studio, and at a coffee shop in Park Slope, and we will be showcasing senior art at a gallery in June.

We offered Dance, Theatre, and Visual Arts. 
We also offered film and photography. 
We have Jazz from Lincoln center onsite twice per year.
our students have worked with Redhook labs to showcase their talents if Fashion, Film & Photography.
Students went to the theatre to see Hamilton as well as Sponge Bob!

In 6th Grade visual arts, we focus on content and form, approaching the elements of design with hands-on projects. Through research and presentations the students receive an introduction to art history by learning, understanding and recognizing the work and styles of at least fifty classical and contemporary artists. 7th Grade drama: Through the study of physical theater (tableaux and movement), self-written monologue performance, Shakespearean plays, directing, and improvisation, students build theatrical skills applicable to everyday life. They are exposed to a variety of dramatic activities to influence self-expression, character development, and ensemble building as they sharpen their analytical and performance skills. 8th graders music: 8th graders spend time doing analytical and comparative listening to music of various eras/genres and learn about group singing, arrangement and rehearsal technique, songwriting, piano, and music technology. After school activities include choir, rock band, and in collaboration with the drama department, a staged musical.

Q44_R1_C10: As long as funding is available
Q46_1: Public School 5 is a Title 1 School. We have a 90% free lunch population and 30% of our population lives in transitional housing situations. Due to our reducing register, our budget will not allow for paid yearlong residencies. We have hired a great dance teacher who services all of grades at a very reduced salary. We have received grants from Brooklyn Arts Council and Materials for the Arts to provide music and visual arts. Due to budgetary constraints, we rely on grants to provide the arts. We have received many educational arts programs from our community congresswomen and assemblymen. Our staff is very creative. They have talents that provide for instruction during culminating events, such as projects and our themed presentations. We rely on the wealth of the skills of our staff to provide that enrichment for our students.  In collaboration with community organizations Art, Dance and Music had been provided on a 6-8 week trial basis.  Attendance has strong for the activities.  We are anticipating financing to aid in the cost of these activities for the upcoming school year.

The Crispus Attucks Young, Gifted and Talented Arts Studio is dedicated to developing observation skills, technical ability and creating finished art work to encourage self-confidence, knowledge, and enthusiasm. Our program is designed to enrich students through the visual and performance arts. The arts curriculum is directly aligned with the Common Core learning standards for visual and performance arts. Our goal for this year was to spark students’ thinking and creativity by providing a comprehensive and engaging program. Students learn a variety of techniques along with a firm foundation in the basic elements of art. They explore the important role the elements play in the creation of artwork throughout history. Students are inspired using a comprehensive range of visual works of art which reflect how the elements of line, shape, value, color, and texture work together to make art. Through drawing, painting, collage and other media, students were able to understand all of the components that produce art in its many forms. Students equally understand how the arts contribute to the community in which they live, which in turn enables them to discover new ways to express themselves.

Public School 25 - The Eubie Blake School offers a rigorous and varied arts program to all our students pre-k-5th grade, including students with disabilities and English Language Learners. A variety of sections are offered to engage our students in dance, visual arts, performing arts, music, monthly grade assemblies, drumming and trips to cultural organizations. These programs are provided on-site and off-site by cultural organizations such as YAFFA, LeAp, Music for Many, Shadow Box Theater, Morgan Library, Band for Today, as well as a certified full-time Visual Arts teacher and a full-time Music teacher. Our program uses a collaborative interdisciplinary approach which is aligned to New York State Standards, the Common Core and the Blueprint for the Arts. Because of our commitment to engaging our students in a sustained rigorous arts curriculum outside of the traditional reading, writing and math curriculum, we have maintained a full-time music teacher and a full-time visual arts teacher and have partnered with various cultural arts organization to enrich the lives of our students and engage them in a love for the aesthetic. The goal of our arts program is to celebrate the arts, enhance our students’ ability to explore non-traditional ways of learning and express themselves in creative and differentiated ways.

Q44_R1_C1: Mark DeGarmo and Dancers / Dynamic Forms
Q46_1: PS 26K engages all our students in quality arts instruction. This past year, every student in our school has received visual arts instruction on a weekly basis, provided by our NY State certified k-12 visual art teacher, based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students explore and express themselves in all required 2-D and 3-D media. A focus on literacy during art classes means that students either discuss, read, or write about art during every lesson. Students engage in meaningful art making, analyze artwork, and assess their own creations. Student choice is an important part of the Teaching For Artistic Behavior initiative where students explore materials, work on individual and group projects, and reflect on the artistic behaviors they employ during art making during discussions and in written reflections. Interdisciplinary projects are a consistent part of arts instruction and have incorporated all other subject areas into the curriculum, including social-emotional development. In addition to our ongoing relationships with Mark DeGarmo Dance and the Met Opera Guild, who provide quality dance and music education to our students, PS 26 has also been able to offer visual and performing arts instruction in our after school. The CASA program provides music instruction in Afro Latin Jazz to our upper grade students. The Leadership Project provides dance, drama, and visual arts instruction to our grade 1 - grade 5 students. Our students also explore the arts outside the school during field trips and during in-school assemblies
Q47_1: P.S. 26 serves the following students: General Education, Special Education (SWD), Gifted and Talented, Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and English as a New Language (ENL). The aforementioned students receive Art instruction.

Q46_1: Our school's Arts program consists of weekly weekly music sessions.  Students work with classroom teachers to participate in class performances 3 times a year.  As part of an afterschool residency, students engage in 14 weeks sessions of dance from different genres.

Stephen Decatur Middle School 35 Arts Program for the 2017-2018 school year has been advanced by the wonderful work of our committed educators in the disciplines of visual arts and dance. Jasmine Jones and Amiyr Barclift have worked diligently in collaboration with our school's instructional focus and various disciplines to incorporate to the arts discipline and various content areas.  The arts program displays their talents twice a year with our Arts in Learning organization in addition to other school events.  Talents are displayed in the fall and spring of each academic year. During the 2017-2018 school year we embarked upon a dance residency with Purelements that focused on the genre of African dance. Our 6th grade students (Howard University) participated in this residency in both the fall and spring.

The arts program continues to enhance our instructional program and we look forward to expanding our programs in the future.

The current arts program at Public School 40 is comprised of a weekly enrichment period in which every child in p-k to 5th grade engages in teacher-led arts activities spanning across genres of music, dance, theater, and visual arts. We also build on our existing program by offering dance to all of our students through a collaboration with a local art program, as we understand that a strong arts program will enhance our children's academic abilities.

We are a school dedicated to bringing out the artist that exists in every student. We offer our students a diverse arts education that includes dance, visual arts and theater. Students who have an interest in attending an arts high school also have the opportunity to engage in mastery classes with a dedicated advisor. Students throughout their three years at our school engage in several arts experiences including visits to cultural organizations, attending Broadway shows and mentoring with a resident artist.

Our arts program includes collaboration with teachers (classroom and cluster) to create theme-based projects and trips and increases the number of trips to cultural institutions based on grade curriculum and arts instruction. We will continue our partnership with BRIC and Ballet Tech. We will continue working with our grant opportunities with Green Weeksville Project. Visual arts instruction for all grades at least once a week will continue.

We provide music instruction through the Noel Pointer Strings Program. We have an F- Status Music teacher who provides instruction to students weekly. Students view and participate in monthly assembly programs written and produced by the teachers. Students in music programs participate in musical concerts as well. We have a community volunteer who provides classroom art instruction to students in grades K-5 which resulted in a school mural creation which hangs in the school's main lobby.  Our students also had the opportunity to play for the new school's Chancellor Carranza when he visited 131 Livingston Street.

Q44_R1_C1: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1:
We had an F-Status teacher but she quit the program. A huge disappointment for our students.
SASF continues to immerse students in dance and creation of all types of beautiful African masks.

Foundation classes in visual art are offered to grades pre-k through 8th grade. Foundation classes in music are offered to students in pre-k through 5th grade. P.S. 308 students are exposed to a wide range of arts focused education in class instruction, enrichment programs and after school initiatives. We also offer learning through the arts programs to k-8, provided by local cultural organizations. In addition, some of our specialized offerings are Steel Pan Band, Instrumental Music, HipHop Dance, theater arts performances, Interpretive Dance, and art and design classes.

Q44_R1_C1: Cumbe: Center for African and Diaspora Dance
Q46_1: Public School 309 is a place where the arts is valued and appreciated.  we believe that every child should have exposure to the Arts to receive a well rounded education.  We have monthly assemblies and quarterly concerts for students to showcase their talents.  Student work is celebrated and prominently displayed throughout the building. All students from pre-kindergarten through fifth grade receive art and music, and we've worked with Town Hall for drama, and Cumber and Yo Re Mi for Dance.  This year, we also partnered with the Noel Pointer Foundation to offer violin to our students, and Signs of The Times, where our students perform musical numbers using American Sign Language. Students learn to become creative thinkers and support their ideas with authentic illustrations. Students learn the craft of performance and presentation. Students will develop the skills and courage to present to an audience that expands school wide and includes parents and teachers.

Our learning community is one that believes in interdisciplinary curriculum development. The goal is to have our students develop both a technical and critical understanding of the arts, and to utilize this understanding in the creation of new works. Our intention is to incorporate both subject-based and outcome-based models as per the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning They learn to define the goals for the content learned, as well as what the goals are for each learner. Our arts program is a year-long collaboration between teachers of various disciplines, guiding student, while exploring intersections between content areas, dramatic presentations, art, stage design/construction, and technology (computer generated graphics, lighting, music, sound, etc.).

At Brooklyn High School for Law and Technology we are trying to include the arts in the two strands of our school, law and technology. Right now we are working to develop a technological based art program for students who are interested in this strand. We have digital art, digital design and digital video to include students that are interested in technology. For the students who are interested in the law program, we are using a more traditional approach, teaching basic arts, arts fundamentals and studio art. At this time we are able to have several art classes that keep our students in touch with the demands of the new technologies in the creation of digital media, as well as using traditional classes for the students who are interested in painting and drawing as expression.

Q39_4: Our Annual Family Community Night at the Whitney Museum
Q46_1: Gotham Professional Arts Academy requires all students to complete a graduation project in the arts in order to meet our school's performance assessment graduation requirements. All students take a required arts foundation course in the 9th grade, then select one of three arts tracks to focus on (visual arts, acting, or art criticism). Students then must pass five sequential art classes in their chosen area of focus. When they are in their fifth (or more) art class, they are eligible to complete the graduation task, which we assess using an arts pbat rubric we have developed. This system encourages rigorous and sustained training in the arts for all our students. Through two grants received this past year (an ESD/SVP grant and an Expanding the Arts grant from the Tony Bennett Foundation), we have expanded our school's arts offerings to include after school classes in dance, music, visual arts, and fashion, and have created a new theater arts track in theater production. Through an ongoing partnership with the Whitney Museum, all our staff received professional development in visual arts criticism from the museum educators at the Whitney Museum.

Q44_R3: Cumbe: Center for African and Diaspora Dance
Q46_1: At Brighter Choice Community School, we believe that exposure to arts education promotes self-directed learning, improves school attendance, and sharpens critical and creative skills. We expose students to visual arts, dance, and music. We believe these disciplines have a huge impact on our mood and emotions. Through our partnerships with The Dwana Smallwood Performing Arts Center, Ifetayo Cultural Arts Center, Cumbe, and Studio-In-A-School, we have seen student visual and analytical skills increase. Additionally, students take ownership of their work and learn from mistakes. We ultimately strive for students to be able to express creativity and make better critical judgments. Our Arts program is a work in progress and continues to build and grow.

The Brooklyn Brownstone School offers both music and visual art to all of its students, two to three times a week. The goals of our arts program promotes serious artistic study, while also making inter-disciplinary connections to core subjects. We have aligned our instructional goals with the Common Core Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. Art education includes working with various kinds of materials, art history, and an afterschool art club for qualified students. The music program includes choral music, music history, music theory and instrumental music. We participate in Little Kids Rock, creating student bands, giving meaningful experience to careers in music and team building. This program includes learning how to play keyboard, music theory for beginners, experiencing variety of musical styles, composing and improvising. Opportunities to see students' artistic talents are available throughout the year. Community meetings with student performances are held twice a month.  Student art is continually posted on the walls of our school. We also partner with Jazz at Lincoln Center "Jazz for Young People", three interactive concerts that are well attended and two in-school student lead talent showcases, as well as monthly musical performances aligned with our character building curriculum, "Heartwood." Musicians and artists visit from the community to provide instruction and information about careers in music. All projects and activities reinforce our commitment to produce critical thinkers and lifelong learners.

Students are enrolled in a visual arts course to earn credits towards graduation. Our students are required to earn two arts credits towards graduation. The pedagogue grades them on assignment completion and also on the students' portfolios being gathered all semester. Students also may participate in 'YRAP: Youth Recording Apprenticeship Program, an afterschool music program. During this program, students write, produce and record songs.  Students also have the opportunity to participate in extra- and co-curricular arts programs, including Film 360 (virtual reality), theater trips, visual arts and mural making.

Q44_R1_C1: Young People's Chorus of New York City
Q46_1:
The Parkside Preparatory Academy marching band participated in a number of events including school graduation, Winter Wonderland Annual Program and the Annual June Showcase, articulation sessions and a performance at the inauguration of Councilman Mathieu Eugene.

The Parkside Preparatory Academy Visual Arts Program is a Discipline Based Art Education (DBAE) Program that integrates the areas of aesthetics, art criticism, art history and art production. All visual arts students were given a rigorous standards-based training in the arts. Students in these classes studied the elements and principles of art through text, video, careers and everyday experiences in order to assist them in understanding how to look at art and the world around them in the eyes of an artist. Students participated in art critiques, which required them to pose questions and find answers. As they learned and practiced the various artistic skills and obtained new knowledge, this year prepared them for future art classes.

In addition, English language arts, math, science, social studies and the performing arts were integrated into the curriculum. Students were given the opportunity to recognize and appreciate the connections that exist among art, dance, music and theatre. 

Art students displayed their work in their year-long Student Art Gallery, an end of the year display, and created props and stage settings for the drama production. Drama students produced a play, Alice in Wonderland and the dance students put on the annual dance recital.

Foundation classes in Visual Art and Music are offered to grades K through 5. The Visual Arts and Music curriculum is aligned to the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Through exploration of painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, sculpture and 2D-design students develop an understanding of the Elements of Art and the Principles of Design as well as the five strands of arts learning. In addition, our music program has a focus on multiple instruments, song studies, beat recognition and drum sequencing.  We also offer learning through theater arts programing connecting historical and cultural concepts covered in the classroom and expressed through performance. In addition, we offer specialized violin and recorder instruction to our kindergarten and 1st grade students. Our 3rd, 4th and 5th grade students travel within the community to take ballet and HipHop dance classes in partnership with the Cynthia King Dance Studio .  In addition our 1st graders participate in a weekly after school Ballet program with Ms. King. Further investigations of dance, theater arts performances, and art and design exploration are incorporated throughout the P.S. 6 arts philosophy. Our goal is to continue to grow the P.S. 6 arts program each year by adding another discipline in order to deepen the imaginative and creative capacities of our students. Our goal is to educate the whole child; the arts are a large contributor to this philosophy.
Q47_1: We are a K-5 elementary school in the heart of East Flatbush, Brooklyn.  We service a large population of ENL and SWD students.  We are a Title 1 school with limited funds for the arts, however we see the impact the arts have on our students creativity and social emotional wellness.  We strive to provide a balanced arts education through school based programming as well as pulling from cultural and art based resources within the community.

Q46_1: P.S. 12 continues to try to provide every student with a variety of arts experiences whether they take place on or off-site during the school day, afterschool, or on the weekend or school holiday. Our goal is to provide every P.S. 12 student with a broad sense of the arts. Many of our students do not leave the community. Therefore, it is imperative to us that every student attends concerts, goes to museums and experiences live theater. It is also important to us that our students be able to create their own art through hands-on experiential sessions and working with actual artists so that they can share their experiences with our students. PS 12's administration and teachers believe that the more enrichment we can bring to our students, the more we follow our vision of educating the whole child. We want our students to experience the world beyond their community, yet realize the possibilities the arts can bring to their world within their homes and their lives.

This year PS 91 engaged in an art residency that incorporated age-appropriate explorations of folktales and mythology and adaptation of those stories.  Puppetry in Practice teaching artists will support student learning of plays and the incorporation of puppetry, music and theater at the school for half of the residency.  For the second half and in response to the Mayor initiative to introduce CUNY colleges to public school students, students will visit Puppetry in Practice at their site on the Brooklyn College campus.  This early introduction to the college vicinity provides early exposure to the college environment.  While at the Puppetry in Practice workshop,  students will complete the culminating activity centered around mask making that will reinforce the Social Studies curriculum for grades 4 and  5 but specifically the Native American culture.

Public School 92 offers direct instruction in the genres of visual arts and music as provided by the two experienced teachers. This is complemented by attendance at off-site cultural institutions (e.g. Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn College Center for the performing Arts, and others) and in-house student performances. Also, this year we were privy to secure a grant from our district elected official and NYCDOE arts department to work with an external partner to enhance the students' passion for African Dance and steel pan. Our goal is to increase opportunities for our students to be participants in and as viewers of various visual arts forms and performance venues. We also strive to incorporate the arts in our regular core content areas, particularly literacy and social studies. For the lower grades, e.g. pre-k & k, the activities are infused in their daily routines and used to enhance their learning experiences. Our teachers provide opportunities for arts related projects, as we maintain gallery type exhibits throughout the school building. This is accentuated during certain time of the year with special events such as Black History or Women's History Month. There is an emphasis on experiencing the arts at community museums and integrating it into the various units of study. At P.S. 92, we believe that the arts is an extension and essential component of a child's educational experience which enhance their learning and overall development.
Q47_1: The parents of most students are from the Caribbean. As a result, they are strong influence to culture of different art forms such as steel pan, soca and reggae music etc. Having a stronger arts program will certainly add value to the students' experiences. However, the level of funding restricts the quality of our program. However, with the little that we do, we do know that it has a grate effect on our families. During any school-based events that involve students' performances, we have the largest turn-out of our parents.

Q46_1:
Pathways in Technology Early College High School (P-TECH) has a rich and vibrant Arts Program. As a S.T.E.A.M. S. (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Math, and Sports) School we aim to provide a well-rounded Arts Education. Our focus for our Visual Arts program is using technology as the medium. This includes a Graphic Design course which uses the Adobe Suite of Graphics Design programs to create a wide variety of Project Based Learning. We have a Web Design Course that blends computer programming with Graphic Design to create rich, engaging, interactive websites

For Enrichment Programs after school we offer Digital Photography, Videography, and Yearbook Design courses.

In addition to the programs  provided directly by our Arts teacher, throughout the 2017-18 year, students had access to a variety of music and Arts programs. Below is a description if the programs as well as our plans for their growth.

Singing and Songwriting  (After school Enrichment)

Students develop their abilities to sing, write original songs and perform with confidence.  In the 2018-19 school year we plan to teach scholars all that is involved in recording music and producing music videos in additional to live performances.

HipHop & Spoken Word (After school Enrichment)

Students learn about and participate in lyrical analysis, poetry / rap cyphers, music recording, music video production and preparation for live stage performances.    In the 2018-19 school year we plan to continue to expand the knowledge and skills of our scholars and provide

The Visual art program at P.S. 138 helps students develop confidence, creativity and literacy through creative projects.The curriculum is align with the standards and benchmarks set forth by NYC DOE blueprint for Visual Art. PS 138, art program goal is to make art the starting point with art making.By connecting art to every subject in the school's curriculum, and by interconnecting a multidisciplinary art program, students not only benefit from the structure of each class, but also from their diversity.The art program is integrating between every subject in other to give student a rich ,well varied, and all-encompass art education. Thought the exploration of a variety media- drawings, collage, painting, and now theater, P.S. 138 is helping students develop an understanding of the principal of art and the elements of design. Students are able to use academic art language to discuss artworks and always cite "visual evidence" to support inferences, claim, and arguments made about a work of art. Goal 1: To increase student's awareness of Visual arts. 1) Introduce different artist, art element, principles of design, and art forms to students. Goal 2: To demonstrate and develop Arts methods that support students achievement. Goal 3:To educate students about art, as well as celebrate student's creativity.This year,P.S. 138 partner with The New Victory theater to enhance art instruction in the middle school. Our Visual art program strives to give all students a well rounded art experience, and encourage them to create a work of art
Q47_1:
P.S 138 is a Pre-k to 8th school located on 760 Prospect place in Brooklyn. The surrounding of the school are rapidly changing with a number of new residential developments under way within a one-kilometre radius of the school.
P.S 138 VISION is to improve teaching and learning so that P.S 138 can become one of the exemplary schools in New York State.
The teachers are highly qualified and experienced, many recognised leaders in their field of expertise. Providing opportunities for students to value add throughout their time at P.S 138 is the driving force behind the school's desire to constantly improve the focus on teaching and learning. Mrs Brutus our art teacher foster an authentic artist's experience for our students through art exhibition. She created a student art show to highlight students art work. The entire school is able to participate in viewing and responding to to the artwork.

Q46_1: This year P.S. 181 hired a full-time theater teacher to provide instruction to those students grades 6-8. Students were introduced to acting techniques, and improvisation. Students have begun to explore the process of putting on staged productions. We currently offer after school theater club. The Theater program works in conjunction with our K-5 Music program, and K-5 Visual Arts program to put together productions for the PS 181 school community.

Exposure to the arts is vital to academic success and cultural fulfillment of our students. The goal of P.S.191's Arts Education Program is to create an environment conductive to engaging students in various disciplines of art through a collaborative process that allows students to infuse their personality, culture and environment through expression. While strengthening the student's creative skills through the study of craft and technique we will engage them in the critical studies of the history of the arts with rigor and curiosity to create unique, challenging and diverse performances to share with our community.The arts are integral components curricular Performance Indicators across all core content areas. Our teachers and paraprofessionals on every grade level work collaboratively with the dance instructors to integrate and align dance studies with the Social Studies curriculum. We will broaden student perspective by working with teachers, professional artists and arts organizations representing diverse, cultural and personal approaches to dance and by seeing performances of widely varied dance styles and genres. A series of assembly performances in music, dance, theater have been the culminating activity for our Arts Program.

Exposing our students to the Arts is important to their overall academic life here at PS 221. While we focus heavily on the content areas it is my core belief that the arts play a major role in our children's lives. This year we offered our children opera lessons and  dance lessons. Our goal for 2018-2019 school year is to is to continue collaborating with Metropolitan Opera to provide music lessons and also bringing on a full time visual arts teacher for our students. We will continue to coordinate trips for all of our students to attend museums, festivals and shows.

Q47_1: we are hoping to include a music program to our arts program in the next school year.

Q46_1: P.S. 249 strives to enrich student learning by aligning the arts curriculum with the national, state, and city standards. We strive to support student independence, content knowledge and the ability to think and speak critically. The young artists at P.S. 249 are encouraged to engage fully in the art-making process, taking creative risks and developing their own voices. Throughout the school year, students have multiple opportunities to display and perform their work as well as share in artful experiences with their families and community. The Arts Teacher Team continues to work collaboratively to make sure lessons are supported by the NYC Blueprints for the Arts and to stand behind the mission of P.S. 249, which is to nurture students as they become college and career ready.

At The George V. Brower School we believe that all students are uniquely gifted.  Our core belief has led us to engage students in a multifaceted curriculum that fosters creativity in drama, performing and visual arts.  We work collaboratively with parents, community organizations and faculty members to design rich and engaging learning opportunities in music, art, drama and dance.  Our arts instructors utilize the Blueprint for the Arts to create rigorous lessons that are intellectually challenging.  As a multi-cultural school with students from many different countries, we construct projects that expose students to a global community.  We believe that exposure to multiculturalism will lead to respect and artistic appreciation of contributions other cultures have made to the global community.  Or school conducts monthly arts celebrations.  Students create artistic presentations through visual art, music, dance and drama.  The George V. Brower School's administrative team and faculty members believe that engaging students in the arts promotes self-esteem and academic achievement.  Our interdisciplinary approach to teaching enables our students to analyze, synthesize and construct their own ideas and work products structured by content based learning.  Moreover, our instructional approach to the arts supports student learning with engagement through multiple learning styles.  Finally, all students have the opportunity to share their unique gifts and talents by participating in the school's multi-faceted arts programs.

P.S. 316 continues to offer a comprehensive visual art and music program. We continue to build upon the previous year's learning to extend and nurture deeper artistic expression. We have a full-time theater teacher who is able to broaden the students' knowledge and experience in dramatic endeavors, including exposure to Shakespeare in the 5th grade. We have added a permanent fourth grade Shakespeare project through CUNY CAT. We were able to link the arts curriculum with common core standards, classroom thematic units, as well as follow the Department of Education for New York City's Blueprint for the Arts. We have broadened our music program to include not only Music in the Brain keyboard program for grades k-5, but also a violin program for grades k-2 and a cello program for grades 3-5 through the Noel Pointer Foundation. We have partnered with CASYM, a Brooklyn Based steel pan group to teach our students and we are also working with Brooklyn Steppers, a drumming teaching organization. We have hired an additional teacher who provides instruction in percussion, guitar, and acapella singing as well as working with our school-wide chorus. We have continued to partner with cultural organizations as well as bring in artists for assemblies and engage in field trips.

Sixth grade explore the world of music through the soprano recorder. They start their instruction to reading standard music notation. Seventh and eighth graders are taught how to play the B-flat clarinet. They play music by reading musical notation. Some of our eighth grade students were accepted into performing arts high schools. Some of our students also were accepted into the Borough Wide Concert Band. All students are taught visual arts by a licensed art teacher. Students studied the elements of arts and the work of famous artists, replicating techniques to demonstrate understanding, knowledge, and appreciation. In addition, all students participating in the Extended Learning Program are given the opportunity to participate in visual art, dance, step, and theater, most of which are taught by teaching artists. By June 2018, more than 85% of the students will achieve a score of 80% as measured by the New York City Blueprint for the Arts.

Our arts program offers students the opportunity to pursue at least two arts-related talents during each school year. Programmed instruction is provided in music and dance and it is offered to grades six-eight. We offer a residency in dance for grades 6-8. Students in all grades can participate in an after-school and Saturday program that includes enrichment in music and dance. Trips are offered to cultural arts events based on our arts program. As a result, all students meet NYSED arts requirements by graduation in the eighth grade.

Q44_R1_C1: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: Currently, our arts program consists of visual arts and dance for all students in grades 6-8. Both programs are offered as part of our regular school curriculum. In the area of dance, students are taught by a certified dance teacher who teaches dance in pop and Hip Hop dance genres. Students showcase their work at school shows and perform at outside concerts including the Brooklyn Borough President's Summer Concert Series. Additionally students receive instruction in visual arts from a certified arts teacher, with literacy connection to that art form, making connections with social, cultural and historical contexts. We also have a thriving steel band after school program for all students and the students have performed at several functions both in and out of school.

Over the years our school has been constantly supported by the Music and the Brain program. This has resulted in most of the school population being exposed to keyboard skills from K-5 grades. For the last semester of this year 5 students began a very basic Brass program, the hope being that it can be expanded to more students in the new year. Parents have been supportive of their children's education in the arts by attending the monthly assembly programs done on a grade level. We all look forward to our Cultural Day called PRIDE where we focus on preserving respect, Integrity,diversity and education in our community. Over the years due to budget constraints we have not been able to hire other Arts teachers to our school. If Arts is to be part of the complete package of educating students in our school for their involvement in their community and the world, then more direct funding has to be made available to make the vision a reality.
This is my last Arts Survey input, I have learned and watched our children's joy in performance and discovery in music. I hope JRS will continue to move ever upward and onward.

College Prep utilizes BRIC Arts Media in-school residency programs to provide quality arts programming to middle and high school students. The BRIC Education team effectively integrates art and media into the core curriculum. Each residency is uniquely designed to meet student needs and learning objectives through:

·Video
·Photography
·Painting & Drawing
·Animation
·Printmaking
·Sculpture
·Mosaic
·Broadcasting

At P.S./M.S. 394, we will strive to expose our youngsters to the work of various artists, and support their own creative development in the arts. We encourage our students to perform at the highest levels, sharing their achievements not only with the school community, but by providing opportunities to arouse and foster a confident spirit within them and help them to develop pleasurable experiences outside of the realm of school life. We are thrilled by the support provided by their parents of the school community via participation in on-site workshops, serving as chaperones for school excursions as well as attending monthly school performances. We invite them to bring cultural agencies to demonstrate their programs, and support parents in their endeavors in the development of these talents. Our partnerships with Lincoln Center for the Arts has served to scaffold the arts experiences at our school. We encourage the students to hone their skills in the arts and to demonstrate their ability within and beyond the school setting, and expose them to all that New York City has to offer.

Our goal is to continue to expose our students to different art forms. Since we do not have a full time art teacher, we brought in several art residencies from Marquis Studio, Music for Many and Purelements to work with our Prek-5th grade students. The residency with Marquis Studio was funded by council member of the 40th district, Matthew Eugene. This program funded an afterschool art program for our 1st and 2nd grade students. Music for Many provide residencies for grade Prek-2 dance and K-5th in art. Purelements provide dance to students from pre-k to 5th grade in the afterschool and Theater to students from grades 3-5.

Arts are embedded in the academic curriculum. Children illustrate their writing, and build models for science and social studies. For this school year 2017-2018. P.S. 398 had  a visual art residency with Studio in a School teachers who serviced students from pre-kindergarten through fifth grade. Students analyze various genres of art. There is a focus on analyzing, interpreting, and creating narratives to reflect on particular art pieces. In addition, selected classes participate in Studio in a School program, whereby, they bring information from units of study. For this school year 2017-2018, a few areas studied were architecture, living things ( animals and bugs),as well as things found in the rainforest.  Students learned the benefits of all living creatures. Students drew, built ,  and painted pictures of living things with various  media such as water color, clay, wood , etc.. Children's art work was displayed in the hallway for all to enjoy and appreciate.

Q47_1: Through the Physical Education program the school will provide various genres of dance such as Ballroom dancing, ballet, modern and Tap. We will continue to seek funding in order to re-engage with the violin program. In addition, we will seek funding to re-engage with keyboarding

Q46_1:
The Academy of Hospitality and Tourism (AOHT) has a unique culinary arts program, where students are taught to express their creativity through food, in preparation, presentation, and taste.  This program consists of a full time certified chef and culinary arts teacher, professional grade kitchen, and adjoining restaurant.  

AOHT also has a full time art therapist, who encourages students to express themselves and their feelings through art.  Students are also supported by a full time restorative justice (RJ) coordinator and RJ program.  

AOHT is located on the Erasmus campus and pools resources to offer a wide variety of extracurricular activities in support of the arts.  This includes teams in dance, cheer leading, and stunt, as well as a band, media studio, art clubs.

Q44_R1_C1: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation

Q46_1: At the International H.S. at Prospect Heights, we believe that education in the arts is essential to a well-rounded education. In addition, we believe that it is in the arts where many students experience joy in school. Students at The International High School at Prospect Heights receive arts education every year. Our school has a full-time visual arts teacher and a full-time music teacher. In addition, through our partnerships with the Theater Development Fund and Lincoln Center, all 10th and 11th graders have received instruction from resident artists in drama, theater and playwriting. Though our program is small, it has had many successes, particularly, in the visual arts where students have won awards and scholarships to programs in colleges such as Cooper Union and Parsons School of Design.

The High School for global citizenship is one of the few schools in the city that offers an animation course as part of its curriculum. With the advent of digital photography and film editing programs  available on most computers, animation is now possible for anyone to create.  In this class, students will engage in various two dimension and three dimensional mixed media animation practices including tradition hand drawn animation, Claymation, wire frame figure animation, and computer based vector animation.  The students will engage the drawing fundamentals, sculpture making, painting, collage, story writing, filmmaking techniques, and mastering computer film editing programs such as I-Movie.  The class will culminate in a completed collaborative animation shorts that will be uploaded to our youtube channel, “the high school for global citizenship animation”.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Our school offers instrumental music and studio art courses. Portfolio development, fashion, sewing, crochet, dance, culinary arts, and individual instrumental lessons are also offered as independent study and extra curricular activities.  The goal of our Arts program is to ensure that all of our students are exposed to the arts and are given opportunities to play an instrument and explore the arts.  Many of our students are creatively talented and it is our goal to give them as many opportunities to develop those talents.  Each year ends with an Arts and Entertainment Show, which showcases our students talents in all areas of the Arts.  We encourage all of our students to be involved in the Arts.  Exposure to the Arts contributes to becoming a well rounded individual.

All students at New Bridges express their creative spirit through art, music or dance class each day. These classes operate on a rotation, to make sure student time spent in each area is equally distributed and not overly affected by the school calendar. In addition to daily classes in the arts, children come together each morning for a community circle called "Bright Start" that infuses music and movement and allows us to begin each day as a whole school community. This year we hosted both a Winter and Spring Arts Festival which drew in hundreds of family members for a night of performance and student artwork on display in our gymnasium, converted for the evening into a gallery. We hosted our third annual "Putting Art on the Map," a visual arts and multicultural celebration. In addition, for our Family Art Night, parents and teachers were invited to explore their own imagination and talents. We believe that the creative spirit of our children cannot only be nurtured during arts as "specials," but should be infused and integrated throughout the school day in each classroom.

Our school provides a comprehensive approach to the arts during our school day and after school. Our programs include: theatre,  chorus, visual arts, arts therapy, music, and music production. Our music program is entirely performance based. Students at YCD have had their work displayed in galleries, government and corporate offices. We also participate in the annual Shakespeare Festival at the Lucille Lortel Theatre.

High School for Service and Learning believes strongly that involvement in the arts is a critical factor in developing our students to become successful and productive citizens of the world. To keep up with the demands of a web based society, we recognize and embrace the value of Visual Literacy as a critical part of being an engaged and informed person able to navigate their way through and contribute to this fast moving economy. Creativity and Critical Problem Solving is a key component in this equation and is taught in the Studio Art Classes as well as in the Academic Classes as well. In addition, ELL classes will be partnering with the Art Program to enhance ELLs and ESLs learning.

STAR Early College School is a 6-12 school that partners with Brooklyn College through the Early College Inititative. We currently have a full-time music teacher and a full-time art teacher. Students participate in band, art club, anime visual arts club, and semi-annual concerts and exhibitions. We also have partnered for the last seven years with the CUNY Creative Arts Team (CAT). CAT uses drama and the arts to help students navigate through the pitfalls of teen life (bullying, dating and relationships, goal setting and college and career readiness). Also students in the upper grades also have the opportunity to interact with the arts because they take college level courses in theater and music on the Brooklyn College Campus. Finally, around eighty students in grades 6-8 benefit from the BCCP Afterschool Arts and Education Program. Students benefit from residency instruction in Media Arts/ Film, Visual Arts, Performing Arts, Dance, Photography and Fashion Design.
Q47_1: STAR Early College School is a 6-12 school that partners with Brooklyn College through the Early College Inititative. We currently have a full-time music teacher and a full-time art teacher. Students participate in band, art club, anime visual arts club, and semi-annual concerts and exhibitions. We also have partnered for the last seven years with the CUNY Creative Arts Team (CAT). CAT uses drama and the arts to help students navigate through the pitfalls of teen life (bullying, dating and relationships, goal setting and college and career readiness). Also students in the upper grades also have the opportunity to interact with the arts because they take college level courses in theater and music on the Brooklyn College Campus. Finally, around eighty students in grades 6-8 benefit from the BCCP Afterschool Arts and Education Program. Students benefit from residency instruction in Media Arts/ Film, Visual Arts, Performing Arts, Dance, Photography and Fashion Design.

Q46_1: The High School for Public Service offers classes in the visual arts, music and drama. Students in the visual arts participate in Foundations, Studio and Painting classes and have the opportunity to explore a wide variety of media. Music students can explore music through Intro to Music (including keyboard and music technology), chorus and band. Drama is also offered during the school day as well as after school opportunities. Our goal at HSPS is to continue to expand both student and parent involvement with all art forms so that students graduate with a greater understanding, appreciation and passion for the arts. We continue to expand out partnerships with community based organizations for both instructional and performance opportunities for out students.

Our school offers a one year visual arts class that follows the NYC Blue Print in Arts curriculum, exposing students to many forms of art making (drawing, painting, printmaking, and digital media). Students explore masterworks of art focusing on particular artists and art historical periods as a way to learn a medium and/or art making skill. All units include skills based exercises and terminate in a final project in which students can show their creativity and mastery of the material which is peer critiqued. At the end of the year, student create a portfolio of their work and reflect on the skills that they have mastered.

Brownsville Academy High School (BAHS) is a specialized transfer high school that serves over-aged and under-credited scholars. The arts program includes dance and the visual arts including, but not limited to, ceramics, applied arts and crafts, drawing, painting, printmaking and sculpture. The goal of the arts department is to provide scholars with a well-rounded program that allows scholars to gain artistic skills and develop an appreciation for the arts. To this end, we have an art gallery where scholar products are always on exhibit in addition to a professional dance studio within our school building. As a result, many of our scholars excel in the arts and some pursue careers in the arts.

Medgar Evers College Preparatory School’s Fine and Performing Arts Department offers a diversified curriculum providing the performing and visual artist in-depth knowledge on refining technique, while discovering the artistry that lies within everyone. The program encourages individuality and creativity, to help students become well-rounded, culturally aware and sensitive to the arts. The program encompasses classes in art, dance, drama and music. OUR MISSION: The mission of the Medgar Evers College Preparatory School Fine and Performing Arts Department is to provide our students with appreciation and experience in the visual and performing arts, offering them an opportunity to learn and advance their skills while developing an understanding of the role of the arts in our society. OUR VISION: The Fine and Performing Arts Department at MECPS is a high quality educational program for students in grades 6-12 that develops the whole person through a curriculum that integrates the performing arts and college preparatory academics. We aim to develop the students academically, artistically and socially so that they leave the school as independent, cooperative, responsible and creative young adults with a lifelong interest and ability in learning and the arts. We believe that these skills and qualities will prepare our students to pursue further educational goals and allow them to contribute to the life and well-being of society as a whole.

Clara Barton's arts programs include courses in visual arts, graphics, ceramics, and music. All Clara Barton students are encouraged and programmed to take one term of Required Art and one term of music. Students are then encouraged to take arts classes such as Ceramics, Graphic Arts, Drawing, or Art Studio. Students artwork is posted throughout the building and in display cases. This year several topics in different disciplines were used and posted to reinforce both the art and the specific topic of a different discipline. Students work was displayed outside of Health career classrooms with work that is relevant to the health careers.  This work reinforces what the schools focus is.  Students work is also celebrated and displayed during special assemblies. Our music classes now include ukuleles, recorders and other instruments due to funds provided by the NYC Department of Education.  Some of our student’s work is submitted to competitions or exhibitions.
Q47_1: Our students take the required Art, and Music classes.  We have many talented students who take our elective classes(ceramics and visual arts)  We are looking to include a chorus elective or other music class.

Q46_1: We believe students have a range of talents and abilities. Our responsibility as educators is to help students discover their talents and create opportunities for them to develop. We offer dance, music, theater and visual arts by licensed professionals weekly. This is in addition to classroom activities planned by their teachers. As a part of our long range plan, we provide additional exposure in a chosen discipline to all of our students beginning in grade 3. Our arts teachers work closely with the classroom teachers to integrate the arts into our units of study. Our International Baccalaureate units highlight the arts from different geographic regions. Every unit culminates in a celebration of what the students have learned, including cultural heritage through the arts.

Brooklyn Institute for Liberal Arts has a strong arts program. We have a full-time visual art, band, chorus and theater teacher and our students are thriving. Because of the continued support from Exploring the Arts (ETA), we were able to expand our arts program and bring in a vocal coach, a guitar coach, a percussionist and a graphic artist to work with the students. This year, we offered visual art classes to all of our students in grades 9-12. Students were exposed to a variety of art media and processes: creating 2D and 3D artworks to express ideas and feelings; developing a proficiency in terminology and techniques related to areas of art; developing the ability to understand and use the elements and principles of art and recognizing art as a means of communication. Students created numerous pieces of art, including self-portraits, which we put on display throughout the school. Our visual arts programs now include Graphic Design, Print-making, and Photoshop. In music classes, students in all grades learned to play a variety of instruments and formed a school band. This band performs at our school concerts and other activities. We also have a chorus and a music production class for students who are interested in creating beats and writing music using technology. We were finally able to get our Steel Pan Band up and running. We were also able to offer theater classes to all 10th and 11th grade classes, and hired an organization called STEM for Dance to enable us to offer an even wider variety of classes to our students.
All 9th grade students receive a full year of art. Students work on interdisciplinary projects that integrate science, social studies, English, mathematics and health science.

At P.S. 770, we embed the arts in many different ways. We have a partnership with Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation and a full time music teacher. In addition, all of our students participate in residencies in visual or performing arts with Marquis Studios (yoga, drumming, and dance). Our 3rd, 4th and  5th graders perform with the Young People's Choir of New York City. We have CASA grants for after school. This year, students in K-2 participated in circus arts and mask making and students in grades 3-5 participated in photography and hip-hop. Additionally, arts are embedded in the academic curriculum. For example, children illustrate their writing, build models for science and social studies, compose maps and create self-portraits. Children also learn songs that are tied to the curriculum. The last interdisciplinary unit is communication, wherein students produce and perform in a school-wide play.We also have a designated arts committee made up of parents and faculty who are charged with finding and writing grants and partnerships to enhance our arts curriculum.

PS./I.S. 66 offers a comprehensive arts program that aligns with the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the Common Core Standards. Formative and summative assessment tools are used by the teachers to analyze student achievement.Our goal is to provide exposure to the arts in the elementary grades and develop a comprehensive sequential arts program for middle school focusing on 2-D and 3-D design. Students in kindergarten through grade three are immersed in the Music and the Brain program, where they learn keyboarding, notation and introduction to music theory. There are two choruses: grade four/five and middle school. The elementary music teacher incorporates movement, percussion and dance  elements as well as piano and choral techniques into the curriculum.The middle school music teacher provides a continuation of the elementary curriculum while adding guitar, bass and drum hit technical skills within several rock band ensemble settings using "Little Kids Rock" materials. School wide visual arts displays highlight student work. Classroom teachers also include art in their curriculum. Students have gone on trips in every grade that include the arts. Art  and music teachers collaborate with each other for shows, concerts, and exhibits. Students have been accepted into art shows and music students perform at nursing homes as part of community outreach. Art and music teachers collaborate with classroom teachers to provide cross-curricular enrichment to deepen students' learning experience.

Our arts program includes two to three weekly hours of visual arts and dance for 6th, 7th, and 8th grade students. Our visual arts curriculum includes painting, drawing, writing and arts research. Our visual arts students will host an arts night exhibition in which their original works will be highlighted. Our culminating arts event will be a talent show. For the 2018-2019 year our goal is to expand the program.

P.S. 115 provides arts instruction in two  arts disciplines: dance and music, utilizing certified arts staff..  We participate in and provide professional development in each art form across curriculum areas that support the Common Core Standards. Students participate in Art, Glee, Recorder, Dance, and Musical Theater clubs.  Studio in the School provided a ceramic residency in the Spring. We have regular school wide performances by our students, with collaborative showcases in the winter and spring. All classrooms across grades produce assembly programs that showcase student talent and highlight grade level curriculum. All classes attend events throughout the city with a variety of cultural organizations. Our art students go out into the community and participate in a wide range of performances and competitions. Grades Pre-K through 2 have a Spring Dance Festival and the entire school has a Spring Carnival in June. Grades 4/ 5 art talents are highlighted with a talent show prior to graduation. STEAM and STREAM classes have been added to our school highlighting the use of arts within content areas. Both programs had their own STEAM/STREAM fair. P.S. 115 also participated in the District 18 Arts Fair in May. There are regular parent workshops that showcase the arts as well as interactive workshops between students and their families.This year we had a Saturday Family Drumming Residency, Saturday Dance Club, and an after school Guitar Residency program for selected students in grades 4/5.

The P.S. 208K school community greatly values its school’s arts programs. These programs are inclusive of parents, teachers, students and our local partners.Students’ exposure to the arts is a critical dimension to their creative and academic development. This year our school had the opportunity to partner with Time In an arts program for the kindergarten, Metropolitan Opera and Dancewave for our second and fourth grade students. Our third grade students had the privilege of learning Indian dance and African Drumming throughout the year. The Brooklyn Arts Council runs an arts driven after school program. When students are provided with these opportunities to explore arts disciplines, they are engaged and encouraged to work more conscientiously in other academic areas. Our students are given the opportunity to explore music, dance, visual arts and theater. Consequently, students express their ideas in positive and creative ways. It is our goal to continue to provide high quality arts education to our students.
The performing arts program focuses on the dramatic arts allowing students to direct their own plays, act, and choreograph dance.
Q47_1: The arts program at our school serves all students including students with disabilities and students that are a part of the ACES program (Academic, Career and Essential Skills). Additionally, our program caters to students of all socioeconomic backgrounds.

Q46_1:
The Langston Hughes School is an elementary school that works to provide students with access to the arts. We have accomplished this goal through the use of staff resources and the services offered by the Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy. Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy has given our students exposure to the cultural arts disciplines of West Africa and America. This year our students have received instruction in African dance and visual arts. Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy has helped our students experience elements of the arts that they may not normally experience.  

We are fortunate to have several gifted artists on staff.  Our certified music teacher is a knowledgeable educator who regularly participates in professional development to enhance her craft. While new to teaching dance in school, our dance teacher is a seasoned educator. She is currently exploring the steps needed to receive certification in dance instruction. Our dance teacher also attended professional development sessions regularly. Under their guidance, students have had the opportunity to create, practice and share their artistry at least twice this year in our annual winter and spring music and dance festivals.

In addition, we have provided arts instruction in a small after-school program that serviced 47 students.  Two of our classroom teachers collaborated with our music and dance teachers to provide instruction in the arts twice a week.  The students studied African, tap and swing dance, guitar, keyboard, vocal music, drum and steel pan.

Over the last 17 years, P.S. 235 - Janice Marie Knight School has developed an arts program that supports and enhances the overall curriculum. The arts programs span across the grades and include all students. Our visual arts and dance teachers organize performances and exhibitions throughout the year. In addition, they continue to work closely with the Community Based Contributors such as National Dance Institute, Theater for a New Audience, and Symphony Space.
Q47_1: P.S. 235 is a large school housed at three different sites, which adds to the challenge of funding and organizing arts programs in all disciplines and all grade levels.

Q44_R5: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: It is our goal to provide a quality arts education to all of our students. To support the arts, we have classroom space dedicated to one visual arts and one music program, each supported by a full-time teacher. We were also able to support our artist-in-residency programs with long term spaces devoted to multiple art forms. Our school auditorium has state of the art sound, lighting and video equipment. Students in grades k-5 have an opportunity to extend their curriculum with an assembly performance during the school year. We have had theater and music residencies to bring expanded opportunities to as many students as funding allows.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: P.S. 268's art program is designed to support our students' creative ways of thinking and provides them with numerous opportunities to express themselves artistically. We continuously strive to make sure that our instructional art program is aligned with the Common Core art standards and grade benchmarks as outlined in the Blue Print for visual arts.

The majority of arts programs provided for our students happen through our afterschool partnership. During the after school hours, students are engaged in dance, step, voice and theater. In addition, Studio In a School provides visual arts instruction to all of our pre-k and kindergarten classes on a weekly basis.

Animation: The making of art through animation, by exploring media and writing techniques—script-writing, drawing, collage, sculpture, applied design, and technology—students develop an understanding of the principles of art and elements of design, deepening their expressive and critical faculties, honing their art skills, and cultivating their imagination.

Music: Students understand the basic elements of music: melody, rhythm and harmony. The students will understand the process of composing music. Musical symbols and their integration into music will relate to the study of creativity. Students will will learn to read and play a simple level of printed music on the piano. Students will learn about the composition of an orchestra, and the various periods in music history.

Art History: This course objective is intended to increase students' awareness of the presence and influence of visual images and objects in their environment. Students will understand how much of their life and societies as a whole are affected by artists and their work.
