The course is based on a broad definition of "arts" and includes the fine arts, popular arts, traditional arts, commercial arts and functional arts.

Brooklyn Generation School students are offered required art courses and several elective courses (Studio Art I & II, Fashion Illustration and Design, Painting and Drawing) that highlight the development of their abilities, to recognize visual arts content, concepts, and skills to create, converse, and understand original works of art. The courses serve as a thematic approach to visual communication and art production, cultural context and art history.

Students become familiar with the principles and elements of design
while completing a variety of assigned projects and experimenting
with different media and processes. In addition to art production, students explore art history, art criticism and aesthetics.Students maintain a portfolio documenting their achievements, signifying the quality, extent of experience, technical skill, application, and development over time.

Brooklyn Theatre Arts High School is a vibrant comprehensive four year college preparatory high school with a focus in theatre arts. All students take a theatre elective course during their education at BTAHS and are exposed to high quality arts programming, trips and experiences. Additionaly, BTA students are eligible to earn a Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma in Theatre upon successful completion of a 10 credit course sequence, senior project and sitting for the Comprehensive Examination in Theatre. BTA has a partnership with Roundabout Theatre Company and strong connections with The Park Avenue Armory, Second Stage Theatre and TDF.
Kurt Hahn offers students Visual Arts and Music course work in the ninth and tenth grades.  Upper class students are able to take both music and arts electives.

Our goal is to offer arts classes to our students in order to fulfill their graduation requirements. It is also our goal to provide our students exposure to the arts, thereby allowing them to discover their talents. With the addition of a music teacher to our staff and our partnership with ETA (Exploring the Arts), we are looking to start a music program for students who want to explore the art form. Over the last few years, several of our students have had their work displayed at various art galleries throughout the city and nominated for prestigious honors. As an inquiry based school, we are fully committed to the idea that building connections between interest and academic rigor through the arts is a tool to propel our students to become greater critical thinkers. In addition, we will also continue to reach out to community based organizations to develop and maintain partnerships to bring more opportunities to our students in the arts.

Q39_4: Participation in our annual Wellness Day activities
Q46_1: The East Flatbush Community Research School is committed to providing students with authentic learning experiences. Our current arts program offers every student two full years of instruction: music appreciation and performance. All of our students are enrolled in our expanded day program which offers our students classes in the following areas: Step Dance, School Musical Production, Sports Programming, Visual Arts, Culinary Art, Music Production, Journalism and Newspaper Design, Robotics Design, and Coding. At the East Flatbush Community Research School, students take a survey three times throughout the school year. This survey allows students to express what their interests are and what types of extra-curricular programming they would like to receive.

The Middle School for Art and Philosophy provides multiple pathways to arts learning including school day arts instruction and extensive after school arts programs including music, dance, drama, and chorus. Our unique Friday schedule provides students with the opportunity to engage in the arts from 12-2:30 pm. During the regular school day, our visual arts teacher utilizes our school's concept based curriculum and instructional model to help students make interdisciplinary connections across classrooms. Teaching artists in residence from Urban Arts Partnership through the 21st Century Grant have infused visual arts into our day program giving us and The Cultural After School Adventures programs (CASA) provide Elders Share the Arts (ESTA) who use history, and culture by using the power of the arts to transmit their stories and life experiences to benefit and support students' critical thinking and literacy skills. instrumental music and song writing, and creative dance programs. Our sports and arts programs regularly tailor its offerings to student interest including drama, multiple forms of dance and visual arts.

The IAM school arts program is embedded into their advertising and media classes. As students move through the sequence of study at IAM, they are exposed to different aspects of the arts. Students work at producing digital art and have been exposed to digital design, digital animation and traditional graphic design. We continue our partnership with Opening Act which began in 2015; through this program our students have performed theatre pieces written and staged by the students in venues in Manhattan.  We expanded our work with the Brooklyn Academy of Music, giving students multiple opportunities to experience BAM's offerings.

The Cultural Academy for the Arts and Sciences (CAAS) offers students visual arts, opportunities for theater and the spoken word, music, and culinary arts. The culinary program, in its second year under Chef Niko, has expanded to include an advanced class. Culinary students cater school events. This year students participated in the annual Brooklyn borough S.T.E.A.M. initiative. The recipient of a 21st Century Grant, CAAS has a full-service after school program, which is run by the Leadership Program, featuring music production, mural painting, karate, culinary arts, and theater arts. In addition to group piano and project-based learning  in visual art and careers in the arts classes, cultural literacy is built into the school day. Students are exposed to theater and dance performances and visit art exhibits, and together with faculty, participate in talent shows at least once each year. Students attend gallery exhibits and enter visual arts competitions, including the Scholastic Art Awards and P.S. Art, and student work is exhibited at Brooklyn Borough Hall,Tweed Court House and other Department of Education venues. Our school continues to emphasize arts in service learning through our various partnerships. Students participated in a variety of residencies and performances at The Brooklyn Academy of Music involving Shakespeare and the spoken word, including storytelling through the Moth. This year students participated in a Brooklyn Academy of Music African dance and culture residency.
Q47_1: New this year at the Cultural Academy for the Arts and Sciences is a full service after school arts enrichment program under the direction of Preston Graham and the Leadership Program. Classes are held for two and a half hours twice weekly and impact up to twenty students per day. Classes include: music production, mural painting, theater arts, culinary, and karate. At the end of each semester, work accomplished by students in these areas is shared with parents and the school community.

Q46_1: We offer an integrated approach to the arts through visual art literacy. Instruction and curriculum are developed by our certified art teacher so that art is integrated to deepen students' understanding and provide multiple forms of expression in the classroom through literacy. The goals for The Arts Education Program are as follows: Provide all students with an inquiry-based, student-centered, and constructivist approach to art expression learning; provide all students with arts-integrated lessons allowing for greater connections between the school's mission and our community service program; equip teachers with creative arts-based pedagogical techniques to meet the holistic needs of students, and align the program with DOE Blue Print for the Art.

Our goal is to provide our students with an enriching arts program. We incorporate technology in our arts classes on a daily basis. Students will be exposed to both the theory and practical application of the arts.  Students will also be given the opportunity to attend arts programs and/or performances outside of school in the near future.

We are a small school with one dedicated visual arts teacher, who conducts five classes per day to provide an opportunity for artistic experiences for our students. During the past two years, in addition to our visual arts classes, we have expanded our program to include such electives as Graphic Arts, Drawing, and Painting. Our visual arts teacher has focused on art history and has incorporated field trips to local museums into his art curriculum. This year we have incorporated the Verizon Innovative Learning program in order to expand our use of technology in art and entrepreneurial learning. This year we also incorporated art into our computer science classes and robotics classes. We plan to expand our Verizon program into more classes next year.

Art is a form of expression and also, an application of creative skill and imagination. The Art Studio is a safe space where students with varied experiences will practice fundamental principles and techniques while, simultaneously developing self-awareness, discipline, and independence by making artistic choices that tap into personal interests. The Arts Curriculum provides diverse pathways of learning in visual form such as drawing and painting, mixed media and photography. Students will observe and learn to comprehend, envision and interpret to reflect, invent and discover to create, and, relate and connect to create.

We have continued our participation in the Arts Matter program and have a part-time visual arts teacher on staff. Students have been receiving visual art for two periods per week. We plan to have a visual arts teacher full time in the 2018-19 school year and expand the program to include digital arts.

At P.S. 7 we strive to give our students the opportunity to exercise their creativity and develop arts literacy through making and discussing art, music, dance and theater.  Our students will develop their communication and problem-solving skills through the arts in a creative supportive community that fosters confidence and self esteem.  Because Common Core promotes the importance of all students studying the arts we incorporate and enhance ELA/ math and content area instruction by connecting a genre or particular text, or a theme of a unit, to works of art, music, dance and theatre. This allows us to utilize the arts as a powerful tool to develop and refrain skills of observation and interpretation that are cornerstone of the Common Core.

At PS13K, we believe in the arts. We provide piano instruction to students through our partnership and grant with the Lang Lang Foundation's "Keys of Inspiration" program. We offer visual art instruction to our students with our certified Art teacher. We offer dance instruction through partnerships with various CBO's. We offer theater through our partnership with the Schubert Theater Arts Partnership.  The Ensemble and monthly assemblies are other entities where students can showcase their talents in the arts. Monthly Assemblies are held with a focus around the Social Studies and Cloud 9 curriculum. During this time, students dance, sing, act and incorporate spoken word.

Cypress Hills Community School (PS/IS 89) is proud to offer a range of arts experiences to all students pre-k-8th grade. Our two in-house teachers (one visual arts and one music) provide students with a well-rounded education in the visual arts and music, including looking at art work, art making, choral and instrumental music. After 16 years of partnerships with Young Audiences New York (YANY), students from prek-5 engage in a twelve week artist residency. In these residencies, teachers and artists partner with each other to provide students with opportunities in dance, film, music and theater. Our parents also have opportunities to engage in arts through these residencies. We continue to be part of a band program through the Brooklyn Queens Conservatory of Music. Furthermore, we continue to build art's partnerships with other organizations such as the Arts in Education organization SEA, Inc. (Society of the Educational Arts) which provided our kindergarten through seventh grade students Latino theater for young audiences performances. In addition, through our expanded education program after-school, students kindergarten through eighth grade select art, music and dance as majors twice a week.

The P.S. 108K’s school community has always supported a comprehensive, enriching arts program that encompasses all disciplines of The Arts: visual, music, dance and theater. It is our philosophy that through The Arts, children develop a variety of channels to express themselves. P.S. 108K is committed to providing a positive learning environment, which integrates the creative abilities of children into the academic curriculum. In order to reach our academic goals, we integrate The Arts into all curriculum areas to provide an education that stimulates our students. We offer all students opportunities to experience a rich Arts environment with instruction in dance, visual arts, music and theater. Through the Arts, our students learn how to be creative, work cooperatively, stay focused and believe in their talents, strengthening their self - esteem. 

Students’ artwork is showcased outside of the school community through state and local art exhibits.  Also, our P.S. 108 Dance Club performs for the District–wide Celebrations.

We host parent Art workshops to increase parent involvement in their child’s educational experience. Our students' portfolios are accessible to parents online through the  Artsonia App and or the website. This allows the parents and students access to our art curriculum and their artwork.

.S. 149-Danny Kaye continues to provide students with high quality arts programs aligned to NYC Blueprints and a Common Core Standards based curriculum. Students are offered extended activities such as visual arts, art club, Dance with Hope, Educational Alchemy Theatre, Steel band, Chorus, Guitar Club, The Little Kids Rock modern band and Keyboard Club. Several of these clubs are led by professionals in the field, while others are facilitated by passionate and talented staff members. Many of these programs are offered as part of our existing day residency programs, while others are afterschool or Saturday programs. Our annual assemblies, concerts and arts festival connect school, families and community in sharing the appreciation of the arts. We have maintained our long standing relationship with key cultural arts organizations such as Neighborhood Music and Arts and Yaffa Cultural Arts annually as well as forming new bonds. Our Out of School Time (OST) community based organization, Gary Klinsky, hosts an annual arts extravaganza for aspiring artists for our PS 149 school community members.

Q39_4: chaperone students on trips, costume design and creation,
Q46_1: Our school is dedicated to arts instruction and explorations in order to support social emotional developmental learning as well as intellectual growth.  Children plan, perform, direct, select and create in each of the arts disciplines.  Teachers form collaborative webs that scaffold arts performances for all students.  We use the arts to explore and understand the variety of cultures that create our unique school community.  The variety of experiences support intellectual challenges and pathways for life long learners.
Q47_1: The talent the staff brings to the table is outstanding for an elementary institution.  Many teachers participate in adult shows that enable them to demonstrate their creativity and interest in the arts for the students.  The teachers build mini cohorts around different art themes that interest them and support students in learning about these forms of art. This helps to create a strong interest in art and a supportive climate throughout the school building. .

Q46_1: The arts program that began this school year consisted of visual arts, modeling/etiquette and musical theatre.

This year P.S. 202 has enhanced the arts program with  a variety of special clubs and events.  The student photography club facilitated by BRIC Arts Media was a culminating activity where the students photographed the community and designed a mural that now hangs in the school hallways.  
 P.S. 202's Art Committee has organized it's first annual art show displaying  student art work developed over the entire school year during art class with our in -school art teacher for grades Pre-Kindergarten through grade 5.  
P.S. 202 also has infused technology in the arts  by partnering with Google for a special day of digital arts in the solar system, with prehistoric animals and inside natural disasters.  
Intervisitations to P.S. 202's  Historical Wax Museum encouraged students to digitally research specific eras in U.S. history.  Students created and designed outfits and information boards and presented to their peers and parents.    We will continue to increase the level of intellectually engaging Art's opportunities for all learners.
Q47_1: P.S. 202 is an elementary public school that services the East New York community with families residing primarily in public housing projects and affordable homes.  P.S. 202 used to service students in grades Pre-Kindergarten through grade 8 however  grades Pre-Kindergarten through grade 5 remain due to truncation and development of various charter schools in the area.  Many of the parents are former students of the school and are proud to have their children attend P.S. 202.  The population of the school is primarily minority students with a vast increase of students of the Arabic ethnicity.  The teachers/paraprofessionals are of diverse cultures and majority of the staff have been employed at P.S. 202 for more than 15 years.

Q46_1:
At P.S 213 the arts department is focusing on artistic development. We have continued to engage our student with Dance and Visual Arts through out the school day . We have enrich our after school program to include Robotics, Steel Band and Karate. Based on the allure of these after school activities .We are planning for 2018-2019 to welcome artist from all disciplines 
 (painting, photography, drawing, video and more)  who are interested in the intersection or art and life and who can lead our students to a deeper understanding and appreciation of the cultures in which we find ourselves.

For the 2017-2018 school year, we maintained the full time musical theater teacher. Piano instruction was also provided to all 2nd to 5th graders, as per the Lang Lang Foundation grant. This year we continued our Chorus for 3rd, 4th and 5th grade students. Our partnership with the Rubin Museum allowed us to provide one 3rd grade class a visual arts residency. For the 2017-2018, students engaged in activities that encourage communication, observation, replication and creation of music, dance and movement within their classes. Our musical theater teacher continued to work with the arts cluster teachers on alignment of curricula to the Blueprints for the Arts, CCLS and Danielson's Framework. This year we were once again awarded the Inside Broadway theater grant for Grade 2. Contingent upon funding for 2018-19 and proof of success, we plan to provide the same programs next year for our students.

The Arts Program at I.S. 218 for 2017-2018 focused on students obtaining mastery of the various skills necessary to succeed in the arts. Facilitators designed projects and performances that showcased student mastery of complex arts skills. Art classes produced artwork that was visually stunning and masterfully executed. The focus was to continue to integrate art and technology in an innovative graphic design curriculum based in our technology lab. Theater and dance classes practiced and performed a variety of high-level performances that showcased their technical abilities. Dance and theater is offered to our 6th, 7th and 8th grade students in a vibrant and approachable curriculum. The focus is on adapting well-known Broadway performances via Broadway Bound Kids to inspire and empower our students through the performing arts. An art organization provided in-class instruction to our grade 6 and grade 7 students as part of their humanities curriculum.
Q47_1: I.S. 218 proudly serves the needs of students in the East New York Community. The student population is culturally diverse with Black, Hispanic, Bengali and Haitian students who find common ground in a safe, nurturing environment. Teachers, administrators and staff strive to be inclusive and dedicated to responding to each student's cultural and educational needs.

Q46_1: P.S. 224's theme this year focused on art history and appreciation. Many of the arts projects were centered around the various artists styles and interpretations. The art teacher supported the vision with culminating arts activities that brought the student interpretation to life. The students were able to create paintings, drawings, and sculptures that reflected on lifelong learning experiences. The projects were then shared with the school community for public viewing.
Due to budgetary constraints, we have not been able to offer arts in our daily schedule for our student population.

P.S. 290 has ongoing art related school-based initiatives. Our goals are to continue our arts programs and create opportunities for additional arts education in all curricular areas to support Common Core State Standards. The school's arts programs will include but will not be limited to the following: Project based, theme based, and performance oriented instruction; arts education in the core curriculum; infusing content based skills into arts education; lessons/objectives or topics that will enable students to meet or exceed grade level and developmentally appropriate benchmarks in the arts; art making, literacy, academic connections, community and cultural resources, and career and lifelong learning into the curriculum; school based art exhibit; partnerships with established arts organizations will continue with emphasis on infusing art into the classrooms and broadening programs to integrate academics and the arts.

Q46_1: At JHS 292 we have licensed visual arts and music teachers who teachers 6th to 8th grade students of all levels, including English Language Learners and Students With Disabilities. We pride ourselves on educating the whole child, and we feel that the arts provide our students with the opportunity to gain self-confidence in their own abilities, which they transfer into the classroom. This is especially true for our students with disabilities. Our students take pride in their performances and in their work. Our dedicated teachers prepare their students from the 6th grade, for auditions in schools for performing arts such as LaGuardia High School.

To supplement the arts program during the day, Jets Academy provides additional instruction the arts for students in grades K through 5.

At the Fresh Creek School we believe in educating the whole child. At the heart of this philosophy is a commitment to providing all of our students with opportunities to develop their many intelligences. To that end, we provide instruction in music and art to every child. This year, using the Orf Method, we focused on developing a percussion and winds program, including training in the use of the recorder, African drums, and xylophone. Students also engaged in vocal training and choral singing. We have Caipoeria instruction as well as African dance and drumming classes for afterschool with clinics for visual arts and music appreciation. For our early childhood learners, we have puppetry to develop their theater skills.

In the 2017-18 school year we were able to continue our arts program through a NYC DOE grant that provided a music residency program, Creative Music Programs-Seth Ginsberg for approximately twelve weeks for students in grades 3-5. In addition, we have continued our dance program with a full time dance teacher providing a dance cluster.

At P.S. 345 we remain dedicated to providing all of our students with the highest quality of Arts education.  Our Arts curriculum is aligned with both the Blue Prints for the Arts and the Common Core State Standards. The Visual Arts continue to be our main art program, providing engaging instruction to all students in pre-kindergarten through grade five.  This school year we were thrilled to add a Music program catering to pre-kindergarten through grade two, in order to promote music appreciation at an early age.  In addition, this year we have also established a school chorus composed of students in grades three to five. Our new Reader's Theater program in kindergarten through grade two has been a great addition, by promoting literacy through the Arts.  We continue to work closely with wonderful cultural organizations, such as Inside Broadway, The Brooklyn Public Library and Shadow Box Theater, in order to support a rich Arts curriculum and Arts appreciation within our school community.  
This school year we were proud to receive the CASA grant which provided us with a fantastic theater residency for students in grades three to five.  We were also awarded a parent engagement arts grant through Shadow Box Theater, where parents and their children learned puppetry and created beautiful puppets as part of a culminating celebration.
To supplement our students' appreciation and knowledge of the Arts, we have also incorporated a plethora of exciting field trips in all Arts genres including theater, dance, visual and film.
Q47_1: Each school year, we strive to build upon and enhance the Arts education our students receive.  We continue to strengthen partnerships with cultural organizations, research and complete grant opportunities, and plan a multitude of exciting arts related field trips to support students exposure to and appreciation of the Arts.  We continually seek to elevate our Arts programming by recruiting teachers who can support all Arts genres and inspire our children to express themselves in a creative manner.  Our hope remains that a greater emphasis will be placed on allocating funds to support Arts programming, so our very deserving and talented children will get an opportunity to benefit from a curriculum that is truly well rounded and student centered.

Q46_1: The following progress are offered to our students: Performing Arts grades K-5, Music grades K-5. In addition we are a Disney Theatrical grant holder and a Music and the Brain school.

The arts have the ability to impact our young people tremendously; besides providing an avenue for students to develop their creativity, the arts possess the power to discipline, empower, and excite our young people. The arts create a feeling of joy and provide many opportunities for students to develop and build their self-image and self-esteem. Currently, our students receive arts instruction in the visual arts, theatre and dance. I.S. 364 utilizes tax levy funds as well as a 21st Century Community Learning Center grant funding to support many of the arts initiatives in our building. In order to facilitate arts instruction, we have augmented our collection of library materials and books. Since personal development plays a key role in the academic success of the students, we will continue to offer personal development through our affiliation with various arts organizations.

The arts, which at AFYW include music, theatre, and visual arts, help to foster students’ self-expression in a safe and caring environment. Our programs help students to solve problems, think critically, engage each other creatively, and feel a sense of accomplishment as individuals and as part of a community. AFYW offers a rich variety of artistic experiences. Students are encouraged to expand their understanding of the arts through music, theater, and/or studiol art. Students develop creativity and innovation, personal style, observational skills and an awareness of multiple perspectives. In the visual arts, students are guided through a program that balances the development of technical skills and ingenuity. Art is offered to students in grades 8-12. Students use a variety of materials to create drawings, paintings, sculptures, and digital designs. The music program encourages students to develop a love and appreciation of music. Music is offered in grades 6-12. Students learn to read music and play instruments. Students participate in the school band where they learn to perform in front of audiences. The theater program encourages students to find their voices. Through instruction and direct experience, students acquire the tools of stagecraft, the confidence to create plays and skits, set designs, and develop acting skills.

Q46_1: At SCCS, we believe children, with access to the arts as a fundamental part of their education, will grow into critical, creative, and compassionate thinkers, and successful leaders of the 21st Century. SCCS integrates the arts into instruction and learning across the curriculum. Our arts-based courses offerings have included theater, Voice-over Recording, Art and Literacy, and our official arts partnerships include BRIC Contemporary Arts and the Shubert Foundation. In addition to formal artist residencies, visiting artists run lunchtime and afterschool sessions, and co-plan arts integration units with our academic teachers in content classrooms. Artists collaborate with teachers daily to provide direct instruction to students, utilizing our auditorium and art studio. Student work is displayed in schoolwide talent shows and exhibitions, and in galleries citywide in conjunction with our partnerships. In addition, we currently have one full-time art teacher and one full-time music teacher on staff who work closely with our student population.

Q46_1: Sequence in performing arts Freshman Year: Introduction to the performing arts. Students will receive a formal introduction to one of our arts disciplines (dance, drama, vocal music and instrumental music), after an initial audition and placement process. Students will select a major in one of these four areas at the end of the freshman year. Sophomore Year: intermediate dance, drama, vocal or instrumental music. Students will begin their sequence of study in the major they selected at the end of 9th grade. Junior year: advanced dance, drama, vocal music or instrumental music. Students will continue their studies in their chosen major. Senior year: Advanced Studio in Dance, Advanced Drama, Advanced Vocal Music, and Advanced Instrumental Music. Students in the advanced studio will be engaged in development of professional portfolios and the creation of original pieces.

Creative arts lay the groundwork for continued exploration in the arts. Students are introduced to the elements and principles of art through a variety of projects. The course is divided into four units of studio art: Drawing, Painting, Printmaking and Sculpture. Throughout the course, students will be engaged in studio practice, reflection and critique.

BGES has an interdisciplinary approach to the Arts, building arts into the literacy, science, and social studies program. The program includes a blend of in-class instruction and opportunities from the classroom teacher in addition to exposure and knowledge building from cultural institutions.

Our goal is to provide exposure and opportunities for all students across the arts including dance, theatre, visual and performing arts to build their knowledge and passion for the discipline.

Due to declining enrollment and the resulting reduced funding, we had to excess our visual arts teacher. We currently rely on our STEAM program to provide art services to our students.  We are still seeking to hire a music teacher to support our extra-curricula vocal, percussion and guitar programs.

In studio art, students are expected to learn a wide range of professional artist’s techniques, methods and materials. Students should be able to meet and exceed standards on the studio art grading rubric.

Q46_1: The foundation of our social/emotional program is Choice Theory. The two needs we recognize as being essential for productive adolescent development are a sense of belonging and power or respect. These needs are fulfilled when students join clubs and develop competencies in the arts. Also, our Media Department offers video production provided by Urban Wall Street, which allows students to share their voice in a dynamic way. We collaborate with CAMBA to provide opportunities for students to learn the skills of choreography and dance, as well as audio/visual competencies.

Studio Art and Art History
    Students were introduced to the Elements of Art and the Principles of Design.
They were made aware of careers in the arts and of how their projects tied in with some of those careers. Students learned how the Arts impacted their lives and how to perceive their environment in new way. We discussed how the  knowledge they gained in class could be beneficial to them in their other curriculums. We also discussed how even if they chose another career path that procedures in they learned such as planning, building, measuring etc. were all basic skills that would need in life.
      All projects included at least one Element of Art (usually more) and learned how the Element(s) were organized by the Principles of Design. Students learned new vocabulary words related to the art making process and art history information relevant to the particular project they were working on.
     Students worked in a variety of mediums, such as drawing, painting, printmaking, clay and sculpture. They were required to write reflections about their artworks upon completion. Students had class critiques where they learned from each other. They learned the steps of art criticism from their text Art Talk by Rosalind Ragans.
      Students learned to observe a work of art and using a chart understand how the artists had used the different principles to organize a given Element of Art.We covered all the Elements of Art and we used all the Principles of Design.

Q46_1: Students at Maxwell CTE High School are given their two terms of required arts credits, ideally in the ninth grade. The art curriculum strives to incorporate interdisciplinary themes, art history and a wide range of studio materials and techniques. Higher level arts-based classes are offered in specialized areas such as fashion illustration, textile design, color theory, typography, photography, web design, mixed media and desktop publishing. Both studio and computer based graphic design courses are taken in sequential order. Currently, students can also fulfill the arts credit by taking music. We offer guitar, chorus, music appreciation, instrumental techniques, and keyboard/piano. Students have the chance to work collaboratively with their peers in the music room for performance ensembles. It is our hope that in the near future, students will elect to pursue careers in the arts. The art/music teachers attempt to tap into the students' creativity to strengthen their problem solving skills. Maxwell has participated in the annual SING competition for the past two years. Students have the opportunity to dance, sing, write, set design, be in the chorus, act, stage/lighting/sound crew. New in the Spring 2018 was a new elective course, dimensional art where students explore found art and problem solve as they create more intense artworks using mediums not usually utilized in the traditional classroom.
Q47_1: We offer two CTE pathways which fall under the ARTS for programming/transcripts.  Communications Media (graphic design) and Apparel Tech Engineering (Fashion Design).  Students who successfully complete these CTE pathways and, pass the three part technical assessment receive a CTE endorsed diploma at graduation.

Students attend off-site arts exhibitions and functions to extend their in-school arts engagement and learning.
We have full time theater in the fall and full time Visual Arts in the spring semester. 8th grade students take half a year of both arts disciplines.

Second and third grade students study theater to develop characters and build cultural awareness. Students in grades 3-5 also have an opportunity to develop their coding skills.

At East New York Middle School of Excellence, our goal is to expose our students to the arts to build awareness of themselves and their culture.   We offered students the opportunity to learn sign language with an infusion of dance and music to encourage them to encourage students to speak "their truth." Most of our field trips are arts-based in which our students are given the opportunity to attend all types of arts performances and events. For example, over the past three years, students have been afforded the opportunity to see operas at the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center. We also attend BAM frequently for a variety of different arts events throughout the year. Additionally, our full-time music teacher engages our students with all forms of music throughout the year from African drumming to pop music.  In November our ENYMSE Band- Little Kids Rock, performed for the District Office Legislative Breakfast. We also played at two Townhall Celebrations to commemorate student achievement on their standardized exams.   In addition,  Little Kids Rock also collaborated with our Sign Language class in a Holiday Show as well as our annual Black History Show—“Woke with Pride”.   To conclude the year, the ENYMSE Band with Little Kids Rock Modern Band performed at one of the most prestigious venues in Manhattan—The Bitter End.

School for Classics offers students a variety of elective classes in theater: Theater History, Improvisation, Film Study and Playwriting. All entering students take Introduction to Theater and Theater History. The Performing Arts Department and Drama Club produce annual performances of their own works as well as those of classic and contemporary playwrights. They also produce Fall and Spring talent shows with opportunities to give students opportunities to showcase performances that include singing, dancing, and musical talents. Field trips to Billie Holiday Theater, Lincoln Center, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art supplement the theater curriculum. Once or twice a year, SFC hosts an arts organization for a school-wide performance. Past examples include Jazz at Lincoln Center and the Martha Graham Company. SFC has partnered with a wide range of arts organizations in the past to support its theater program. We have also partnered with artists from People's Theatre Project, CUNY-CAT, and SASF in select classes and after-school programs.

We had another successful Arts Program this year where we were afforded the grant for our 2nd and 3rd grades SWDs and ELLs to participate in a theater/visual arts program with LEAP. Teachers and students were given the opportunity to receive direct instruction through LEAP's instructional coach. Students were able to enhance their literacy skills through the arts. 
Unfortunately were unable to afford a dance teacher for this school year, however we are hopeful that funding will emerge from some source so our students can experience all 4 genres of the arts during their K-8 years. Our music program is growing as we expand our program to build our band and orchestra ensembles. We have implemented a plan to build capacity and linear progression of skills. Our students performed their first concert this year and we hope to have annual events celebrating the Arts. Our 4th years partnership with Robert Shurbert Arts Center has allowed our students to participate in awesome performances. This year our students performed Beauty and the Beast and it was a smashing success. Our goal remains the same, to provide a comprehensive arts program to all our K-8 students.

IS 62 is comprised of 3 academies, a 6th Grade Exploratory Academy, The Academy for Performing & Visual Arts and The Law & Community Service Academy. Arts instruction is infused throughout the building, with a prominent presence in the Academy of Performing and Visual Arts. IS 62 offers visual arts, band, keyboard, dance and chorus programs in arts-specific rooms, including a state of the art dance studio, a fully stocked art room, a band room with a heavy presence of brass and woodwind instruments and a keyboard room with sixteen hi-tech keyboards and three technology labs. Our school auditorium has been updated with a new sound system, has audio/visual technology access and a baby grand piano. Students in 6th grade participate in a rotation of the arts and a chorus program. Students in the 7th grade are screened and matched with a major arts class for the year. Students in the 8th grade continue with that major arts class for a second year and, in addition, pick up a second arts class as a minor. Each program adheres to the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and the New York State Common Core Learning Standards. It is and has always been our hope that our students have exposure to a variety of cultural activities, experiences and events that provide enrichment and assist in the development and growth of that student holistically.It is our mission that our students gain the inspiration needed to foster their individual creative interests as they become young men and women, through the exposure and mastery of both the arts and a

PS 69 is proud to be named The Vincent D. Grippo School in honor of the late superintendent of Community District 20. In addition to a rigorous academic education, PS69 provides a highly rigorous arts environment. All students experience deep and challenging curricula in visual arts, music, dance and theater programming which is provided by skilled professionals. All curricula is developed in alignment with the Blueprints for the Arts, Common Core Standards and Danielson's Framework. Additionally, PS 69 is pioneering the development and use of formative assessments in the visual arts. Under Chancellor's initiatives, PS69 has been designated for the past three years as a Showcase School for Integrating the Arts for Student Success and this current year as a Showcase School for Partnerships for Arts Enrichment. Visiting educators learned how to naturally infuse literacy in the arts, saw systems and structures that bring arts programming to all students and understood how to use the arts to bolster early language acquisition. Professional Development workshops and Arts Mondays are held at the school and led by citywide staff. Our art studio serves as a laboratory and resource to support the professional growth of colleagues throughout the city. PS69 has also been showcased at the Annual District 20 Performing Arts Showcase and Visual Arts Showcase. Selected student artwork has been recognized at the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival.

Q46_1: P.S. 105 has a strong commitment to arts education and recognizes its potential to enrich every aspect of teaching and learning. Our goals, strategies, and major initiatives center on supplying all of the student population with instruction in visual arts, music, dance and theater, using the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, which is aligned to the Common Core State Standards. All students actively engage in the processes that constitute creation, performance, and participation in the arts. They respond to and analyze the arts with an understanding of the cultural dimensions and contributions of all arts disciplines. The arts instruction is implemented using a comprehensive and sequential standards-based approach, targeting the benchmarks in the blueprints. This allows students to be art makers, have literacy in the arts, make connections, be aware of community and cultural resources and develop into lifelong learners of the arts.

At P.S. 160, 80% of our students speak a language other than English at home, and 68% of our students are English language learners. The arts give our students a voice to express themselves. We have full-time teachers in visual arts, music, and drama, and part-time teachers in violin and dance. Our students also enjoy arts residencies in dance. Our school has several rich afterschool programs that provide instruction in the arts, They include, Art Club, Chinese Dance Club, and Orchestra. Our goal is to provide quality arts education to all students in our school. We also have many daytime, evening and Saturday workshops, festivals and assemblies to expose and engage our students and their families in all art forms. At P.S. 160 we believe in educating the whole child, so we are a great supporter of the arts. We also believe in nurturing the gifted, talented and enthusiastic. Our hope is to continue to grow our arts programs. At P.S. 160, there is something for every student.

Fostering our students’ creativity and talent is a part of P.S./I.S. 163's mission statement and a major component of our students' education. In addition to regularly scheduled music classes, our school has a chorus, a guitar club, a band, and an orchestra. The students who are members of these groups, as well as many others, participate in and perform in our winter concert and our spring arts festival. Our dance program exposes students to various types of dance, classical and contemporary, and presents them with the opportunity to express themselves through movement. Our visual arts program provides students in grades K-8 a well-rounded visual arts experience that covers both art history and hands-on art projects. At P.S./I.S. 163, the arts are an integral part of student learning, as they help students to make connections between subjects and gain a sense of pride and accomplishment by recognizing their creative talents and potential.

The arts program is aligned with the NYC Blueprints for the Arts. The music program serves grades pre-k- through 5 with a combination of general music, vocal, recorder and instrument instruction. The extended day program serves a group of band students two to three times a week depending on whether they are in the beginning or advanced band. All band members are provided with instrumental lessons at least once a week during the school day and all advanced band members attend practice each day during recess. The band performs at school events, concerts and graduation as well as at outside events like the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival and the District 20 Arts Fair. The visual arts program serves pre-k through 5 students. Classroom teachers integrate art instruction into their curriculum daily. This year we partnered with cultural organizations like Rioult, Wingspan, Smartworks, Studio in a School and STEM KIds NYC to offer additional arts residencies to students.  We also have an afterschool program that brings in arts programs from Marquis Studios.

P.S. 170 The Ralph A. Fabrizio School has a diversified group of American students and a large immigrant population from different Asian, Middle Eastern and South American Countries. We strongly believe that the Arts bridge the cultural, religious, gender and racial diversity of our 1030 student population.  We have three certified and licensed teachers for fine arts, vocal and music programs. The goal of our Arts Program is to offer dance, music, theater and visual arts through a variety of programs, student workshops, trips and ART competitions to our K-5 students.  The following programs are offered by our Art cluster teachers: Violin,  Music and the Brain, Recorders, Chorus, Band, Visual Arts classes and an ENL Theatre Arts program whose English as a new language students write, produce and perform original dramatic plays. Students perform at monthly PTA meetings, recorder and violin concerts. Band and chorus students also perform at annual winter and spring concerts.  At our 8th annual Cultural Festival students performed dances, music and songs from American, Arabic, Chinese, Greek, Latino and Russian cultures. Visual Arts, Band and Chorus students participate in local and city-wide contests such as: Fall Window Painting, Fall Poster, Sustainability Calendar, District 20 Visual Arts Showcase, Brooklyn Arts Festival, Music Memory Competition and the Respect for All Contest for which we were honored in 2018. At P.S. 170 we are committed to fostering a lifelong love and appreciation of the arts.

Q48_2: Arts coordinator PS 176, Music Teacher, Band Director

Q46_1: The visual arts program provides instruction to students in Pre-k through grade five according to the Blueprint for the Arts. We provide visual arts instruction and residencies in dance and music instruction; extend learning beyond the classroom with museum visits, theater performances, and other venues that expose students to a lifelong appreciation of the arts. PS 179 provides opportunities for parent engagement in the arts through student performances. PS 179 offers Chorus and Music Memory. After school programs include Art Club, jazz and hip-hop dance, Garage Band, Drama Club, visual arts and Brooklyn Children's Theater after school program.

PS/IS 180, The SEEALL Academy is dedicated to strengthening and expanding the arts learning experience for all of our students. We strive to offer many diverse arts opportunities to our students, tapping into the talents and unique abilities of our entire staff, not just our certified arts teachers. We continue to expand our arts department via hiring, enrichment, and after school activities.

Our present goals for our Art's Programs focus on our visual arts and music program.  We strive to encourage a love and respect for the arts through our teachings, as well as strengthening cross-curriculua connections. Our Visual Arts Program stresses the use of multi-media techniques using a hands-on approach with successful results. The use of journals reinforce the art curriculum through writing. Our music program has presented several school-wide recitals showcasing the children's musical progress. Our music teacher focuses on understanding breath, pitch, rhythm, melody, voice, movement and incorporates this into the daily curriculum. We display our progressions and learningss through music performances and art exhibitions. We are continuing to see positive feedback from our students in terms of self-confidence and experiential learning. In addition our school continues to provide our 5th graders with a 20week Ballroom Dancing Program. We have also enjoyed a visual arts residency for our ICT classes through the Shadow Box Theater.  Imagination Creations conducted a residency in visual arts, for our 1st graders. We were very excited to have recieved a grant for a school mural. Our entire school community was free to participate in our school wide mural being painted in our school yard.  Fifth grade students generated the initial sketches for this project. Our teachers continue to link the arts to their daily teachings in many different ways. Their support & collaboration helps emmerse the arts into daily activites.

This year we have been fortunate enough to offer students in all grades the benefit of performing arts and visual arts instruction as part of their school schedule. Students also have multiple opportunities to take part in Zumba, Bucket Band and Dance classes.  We also offer a period per week of Show Choir where students learn theater-related pieces to perform at a culminating event at the end of the year. There is also an art committee that works with the visual arts teacher. Students have performed at school concerts and assemblies both during the school day and evening and included parental involvement. Through a partnership with the NIA ExpandED, students were able to put on a performance of Beauty and the Beast.  Along with the afterschool arts teacher, students created sets and props for the production.

Q44_R1_C1: Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: The arts program within IS 187 allows students to become fully immersed in all aspects of the arts. The arts programs include and not limited to the band, chorus, visual arts graphic arts and theatre. Students have the ability to take part in our after-school program in which they experience, drama, set design, graphic arts as well as engage in various field trips related to the arts.

Our arts program follows the New York City Blueprint which is grounded in the national and New York State learning strands. These strands guide teachers in addressing specific learning goals for students. They also provide the guidelines for offering a diverse visual art, dance and musical experience. The visual arts program is structured around the Art Making strand of the blueprint. Our artists are given the opportunity to work in different media, including painting, drawing, collage,sculpture and printmaking. Our music program provides our students with many opportunities to express themselves through music. Students in grade 4-8 have the opportunity to participate in the school band or chorus program.

P.S 200's mission is to achieve excellence in all areas of the curriculua. In addition, data is used for analyzing student achievement and focusing instruction. In the disciples of music and visual arts, all students participate in a curriculum that reflects The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts goals. Teachers are receiving professional development for Formative Assessment, Art Mondays, Common Core Standards, and Danielson's Framework. Enrichment programs for the arts include a STEAM curriculum which helps students in 3rd, 4th, and 5th grades integrate technology, science, social studies and art.

Drama: to create a school-wide production incorporating all aspects of theatre including acting, lighting, sound, directing, choreographing and set design. Music: to develop and expand students' vocal and instrumental technique through daily study of scales, technical exercises, vocal warm-ups, and short compositions that facilitate improvement of tone quality, tuning/intonation, rhythmic precision and general concentration. Art: to use differentiation to enhance all projects of art within the Blueprints for the Arts and to incorporate the Common Core Standards using the Universal Design to reflect Blueprints for the Arts.  Annual Chinese New Year Celebration including dance and instrumental music.  Annual Multicultural Fair celebrating different cultures and their customs.

At PS 204, we strive to engage our students in all aspects of the arts: visual arts, dance, theater, and music. Students in K-5 have the opportunity to broaden their skills in our visual arts program where our arts teachers utilize The Blueprints for Teaching and Learning the Arts. Our teachers engage students in various visual arts projects providing them ongoing opportunities to partake in self and peer assessment aligned to the standards. We have three full-time certified music teachers who provide music instruction to students in grades K-5. Our kindergarten students perform in an annual Gift Sharing musical performance. Our 1st and 2nd grade students are provided the opportunity to perform in class concerts with their classes, for their parents, highlighting all they have learned over the course of the school year. Our 3rd graders learn the recorder and take part in a culminating performance. Our 4th graders study various Broadway musicals (Inside Broadway) and perform acts from each of them for our student body and parents. In addition, 4th and 5th grade students have an opportunity to play in our school band and 3rd and 4th graders can participate in our orchestra program. Our 5th grade students can also join our school's chorus and perform at various concerts. All students in grades Pre-k through 5 learn different styles of dance and perform in a school wide dance festival held annually each spring, and our fifth grade students receive instruction by Dancing Classrooms in various styles of ballroom dancing.

Q39_4: Parent participation in facilitating Borough Arts Festival, NYSSMA, Colombus Day Parade, and other outside of school events
Q44_R5: Snug Harbor Cultural Center & Botanical Garden
Q46_1: Our rich and diversified arts department at PS 205 is one that utilizes a myriad of resources and unique performance opportunities throughout the year. Our students are provided with a plethora of opportunities to perform on and off site. The concert band performed at the Columbus Day Parade, and our band/jazz-band was selected to perform at the yearly Borough Wide Arts Festival. Band, piano, and orchestral students performed at our annual STEAM Night NYSSMA recital, providing our student musicians with a valuable chance to perform recitals at the elementary school level. We had 39 of our orchestral, band, and piano students partake in the 2018 NYSSMA Festival. PS 205 was selected to receive an ELL Arts Grant for the 2017-2018 school year in conjunction with Marquis Studio. Our school also received a grant for 16 guitars from the Office of the Arts and Special Projects. In addition to our Grades K-4 dance affiliations with Marquis Studios, our 5th grade continues it’s yearly association with Dancing Classrooms for ballroom dancing. Our Visual Arts Department had two semi-finalists for PS Art, and one of our our student’s work was chosen for the Office of Sustainability Calendar, and continuance of our yearly art-exhibition for STEAM Night. In May, our G&T classes perform a yearly art concert. These accomplishments work towards our objective of creating the most well-rounded, holistic arts education possible, with the objective of high retention rates and providing middle schools with talented musicians and artists.

We use the Blueprint for the Arts, and offer arts to all our students. One addition to our arts program that we are proud of is the expansion of our dramatic arts and dance instruction. We have also increased our outreach to cultural organizations in order to enrich students understanding and appreciation of the arts disciplines. We have nearly 33% English Language Learners. The arts is also a way of engaging our ELL students and motivating them to improve their use of the English language. Through the arts, we celebrate diversity in our school with cultural performances. In addition, the school runs a comprehensive architecture program for 7th graders. With the help of Mr. Ronald Miller, architect and director of Planning Design Construction for Maimonides Medical Center, classes use a lifelike request for proposals to design a building by preparing floor plans, elevation plans, axonometric drawings and a scale model. Ten final teams are chosen to represent the school of design Expo, a special day at the center for Architecture in Manhattan where the teams present their designs to a panel of professional architects. Our school presents an annual festival of the arts allowing students to showcase what they have learned through dramatic performances, musical concerts and exhibition of student art. Parents of performing and exhibiting students are invited to attend. Finally, we have also increased our after school and summer instruction in the arts.

Students as Montauk follow a three year sequential art program in visual arts and take Introduction to Music in the sixth grade. Students also have the opportunity to participate in Chorus, Piano lessons, Dance, and Arts and Crafts in our after school program. Serious music students are offered the opportunity to participate in the district 20 band, while serious visual arts students are offered the opportunity to participate in an after-school portfolio workshop in the seventh grade to prepare for auditions at various city art high schools including LaGuardia, Murrow, Art & Design, Fashion Industries, and Brooklyn High School for the Arts. The visual arts curriculum is scaffolded and rooted in the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. While making art, students develop a language of critique through continual reflection and self and peer assessment practices. Through the analysis and interpretation of masterworks, students relate learning in the arts to learning in other subject areas.

JHS227 is immersed in the arts for the years 2018-19, Edward B. Shallow has a school band, a school orchestra, a string band, a school vocal/chorus, a digital photography class, Sumba Dance incorporated into physical education curriculum, theatre in the form of Inside Broadway and Theatre Moves. In addition, segments in arts are dedicated to Disney Art, graphing, drafting and civil engineering.
We also have partnerships with Rush Philanthropic and Story Studio.  We are recipients of the CASA grant which supplements our theatre program with Inside Broadway.

Q44_R3: National Museum of the American Indian
Q46_1: P.S./I.S. 229K serves children in pre-k through Grade 8. Early childhood students learn about the elements of music that include singing, instruments, and movement, incorporating the Kodaly and other methodologies. Upper grades have an opportunity to join the school band, string orchestra, jazz ensemble, and chorus.  Visual arts students are empowered with experiences that challenge, build knowledge, and skills in the use of the various tools, techniques and intellectual methods of creating art.  Our goal is to provide a sequentially standards-based arts education which builds an appreciation of various cultures, connects to other disciplines through participation in NYC cultural institutions and makes known the varied available careers in the arts.
Q47_1: Due to lack of staffing applications, we were unable to offer our customary Saturday Theatre Program this year.  However, we already have plans underway as to how we will correct that situation, should it occur again, in the new school year.

Q46_1: Instruction in all the arts disciplines is an important part of the culture of PS 247. It is for this reason that we offer the following programs for our K to 5 students: violin instruction; Music and the Brain; Ballroom dancing; NIA after school art; NIA after school theater, NIA after school art; NIA after-school dance; NIA after school band; recorder instruction; piano instruction; chorus; CITE art's program; Marquis Studio arts program and Music and Memory. We are also a community BEACON school so we offer 6 days of instructional arts programs throughout the year. Students in our specialty music programs preform at a winter and spring concert. We continue to follow the NYC blueprint for the arts instruction and have integrated these benchmark expectations into content area instruction, aligning our units of study with the common core learning standards.

I.S. 259 takes pride in providing its students with a varied choice of arts disciplines during the day in order to explore and expand their creative needs and inspire life long arts learners. Students also have the opportunity to pursue a new arts skill during after school programs. After school programs include: Drama Club, dance, keyboard, marching band, concert band, concert string orchestra, scenic design,and Fashion Club. The Concert String Orchestra continues to compete at the NYSSMA festival and has received three gold medals with distinction. One of our most exceptional features is a 400’ mural on our third floor which has been featured on CBS, ABC, and Fox television. This remarkable piece showcases the talents of our students interweaving history, poetry and literature of various periods in collaboration with the 9/11 Tribute Center. The latest installation meshes the arts and science in a salute to the Renaissance.

The arts are part of our name, part of our vision and mission. All of our students receive exposure to a broad range of arts experiences fully integrated into our school curriculum and culture. We partner with cultural organizations to supplement the skills and specialties of our full time faculty. We make strategic decisions to hire staff with a strong passion for and expertise in the arts. Classroom teachers are integral to the success of our arts program as they bring their own passion and arts experiences to the classroom setting. We are confident that this integrated approach allows children to explore and express their creativity across a wide variety of genre.  We are home to a resident adult theater company. These actors work with our students and perform classical theater for them. Our students learn both the performance aspects and technical aspects of the arts, and they have assumed full responsibility for lighting, sound and stage management for our productions. We look forward to watching our children continue to grow and develop as artists.

Art education is essential for a child’s perception and understanding of our world. Opportunities for creative outlets allow students to interpret their perceptions through different art forms. Art education teaches students to respect and appreciate their own interpretations and those of others. We develop basic skills and encourage awareness of and appreciation for different cultural perspectives, intellectual growth, and creative self-expression. Our school’s commitment to arts education is essential for every student's development as well-rounded, creative and productive citizens in the global world. Goals: Students will • develop literacy skills and make connections to content knowledge in other disciplines through arts • develop an appreciation for art and confidence in creative self-expression • have an awareness of global cultures and an exposure to the diversity of art • develop an appropriate level of artistic proficiency in a variety of artistic media

The 2018 cohort marks New Utrecht High School’s fifth graduating class of the Academy of Art & Design. Over the last year we have maintained our expectations of a high level of technical skill with a focus on observational projects and have begun to incorporate imaginative components to portfolio projects. Our students continue to enjoy experiential field trip opportunities throughout the school year. Our 9 art credit initiative implemented last year was successful.  We currently have 20 students eligible for the Visual Arts Commencement Exam, which is 150% higher than the 2016-2017 cohort.  Extra-curricular clubs continue to grow, specifically seen in our Fashion Society with a record of 120 members in its 10th year.  We have consistent contest participation with an increase of scholarships, monetary awards and paid internships. We have added additional choices to the coursework offered such as textile arts focusing on craft-based projects like knitting, photography and an audio/visual collaborative course where students will work in teams to produce their own video productions. We have two art events currently scheduled for next year, one at the end of each semester. We will continue to bolster our course offerings, field trips, and competition/scholarship/internship opportunities for stronger educational outcomes. In 2018-19, we will formulate a strategy for attracting more junior high applications to the Academy of Art & Design, as well as create a structure for recruitment within the building.

A rich arts program with a strong studio and performance component is essential to our students' academic growth. Our studio arts curriculum emphasizes self-reflection and social commentary and includes basic studio art, mixed media, fashion, and design. Our students learn to work in a variety of media including pencil, charcoal, water color, collage, pastel, linoleum and ink print. Students display their work in exhibitions. Courses that provide students with art-technology experience in our newly renovated computer labs include digital photography, graphic design and yearbook. Performance-based courses include chorus, keyboards, drama workshop and musical theater. Student performances take place every year in our newly renovated, state-of-the-art auditorium/theater, where we also screen full-length feature films. We have a long-standing collaboration with BAM and the TDF Open Doors Program and the New York Theater Workshop. Students visit museums and theaters including MOMA, The Met, BAM and the Brooklyn Historical Society. In the last two years, students in our art classes have worked with Thrive Collective, and designed and painted large scale murals at the entrance of the school and in the student cafeteria reflecting the themes of diversity and community.

Q45_10: Students perform annual solo adjudications in theater and Music
Q46_1: Fort Hamilton High School is fortunate to offer a vast array of arts classes. Our visual arts courses include, but are not limited to, creative art, calligraphy, ceramics, drawing, painting, portfolio development and advanced placement studio art. We have an excellent theater department that produces two fully staged shows annually. The last two musical productions were In The Heights and West Side Story. Fort Hamilton High School’s music program is a competitive program that travels and competes across the country. We have consistently received the highest grades at adjudication festivals. Our performing arts program requires an audition and is listed in the H.S. Directory. Seats are limited, but audition pending, talented students from all over New York City can be admitted to our school and be part of our music program, theater program or Joffrey Ballet Dance Academy. Honors level courses are available if students qualify. Students who qualify will take honors level academic classes.

With over 1,100 students, 59% being English Language Learners and 97% of the student population are eligible for free lunch, the school faces many challenges. It is our belief that the arts are a basic and integral part of a high quality education. It is also our belief that every student, regardless of background or economic status, is entitled to this level of education. Every student in our school is provided with arts education as a standard part of our school schedule. Collaboration between teachers and across domains creates a multi-layered, cross-disciplinary program that enables the students to appreciate the interconnectedness of subjects. Science and social studies integration has imbued our arts instruction with a cultural relevance alongside opportunities for experimentation with art forms and techniques.

Q39_4: The school held a parental art class.
Q46_1: FDR offers classes in disciplines including theatre, music, visual arts and film. Students can choose to sample various electives or major in a sequence. Yearly, FDR produces a play, musical, multicultural festival, talent show, and several concerts. Our school is involved with residency partnerships with the best cultural and arts organizations in New York, such as The Theatre Development Fund and Roundabout. Our art rooms include a ceramic studio and photography and computer art labs with state-of-the-art equipment for film and digital photography/restoration. Our music program has a concert band and guitar ensemble. The theatre department offers two tracks, performance or technical. FDR is starting a four year sequence which will end in a specialized arts-endorsed diploma. We are beginning work on a screened program. With its strong multicultural population, our Literacy Arts Program helps ELL students improve language skills through artistic expression. Our goal in to instill a love and appreciation for the arts.

At P.S. 506, assemblies are held monthly and full-length performances are done each winter and spring. Assemblies include, but are not limited to, full-length violin concerts and musicals, themed songs, dances, and skits, and student-created videos that integrate various holidays, historical events, classroom subjects, and leadership principles. Enrichment arts clubs are available to students who show interest in a certain discipline. Visual art contests are held throughout the year to showcase our students’ work. We are in partnership with Disney Theatrics and the full-length Disney musical, Beauty and the Beast, will be shared with our school and community through day time and evening performances in June. Students attend arts-based field trips throughout the year as well. The arts are used to develop literacy through the use of word walls, group discussion, and technology. Arts teachers are given the opportunity to inquire with each other to align curricula and share best practices. All arts programs are aligned with the Blueprint for the Arts. The arts are infused in every classroom and the existence of the arts is truly evident throughout the building through the use of TV screens in the halls highlighting our monthly assemblies, monthly PTA arts shares, and artwork displayed on each floor.

PS 682 is a Schoolwide Enrichment Model School. We conduct three nine-week cycles of enrichment clusters ranging in areas from filmmaking, sports, horticulture and more, based on student interests. TADA! provides our k-5 students the opportunity to dance, sing, and act during the 20 week partnership. Dancing Classrooms for our 4th and 5th grade students brings one cycle of ballroom dance lessons twice a week. We have one full-time music teacher trained in Music and the Brain. The 3-5 students have learned the recorder and our 4th and 5th grade students participate in band. We have a full-time art teacher, for art k-5. We continued Art History for grades 4 and 5. Also we have Town Hall in grades K-3, which is a dance partnership. We have continued an afterschool program that focuses on theater arts, visual arts, athletics, and computers. We are also a TC school that incorporates Art in ELA.

The goal of PS 748 is to integrate visual and performing arts into the curriculum by using an interdisciplinary approach. We were fortunate to have both a full time music and art teacher this school year. Both teachers worked cooperatively with classroom teachers to integrate arts instruction into curriculum maps and create standards based lessons. New this year, we added a full time Theater Teacher beginning in January who worked with classroom teachers to create performances that were curriculum based and presented to parents. At PS 748, we incorporate the Schoolwide Enrichment Model where students get their choice of arts classes including theater, sculpting, dance, and music. In addition, students in grades 4 and 5 participate in academies where the arts are also explored. Students change their selection throughout the year to gain exposure to various disciplines. The Brooklyn School for Global Scholars also believes in building strong relationships with parents. We have an annual winter concert and dance festival each year. We also have a chorus that meets once a week. We hope to continue to build on our arts curriculum in the upcoming year.

District 20 pre-k centers offer instruction in movement and music appreciation, dramatic play and visual arts aligned with the pre- k quality standards and founded on the principles of the pre-k foundation for the Common Core. All children are exposed to a variety of the arts to instill a love of learning through discovery and exploration which in turn stimulates individual creativity.
Q48_2: District Director of Early Childhood Education

Q46_1: P.S. 971 continues to provide an educationally enriched arts program. In our dance, visual arts, music and theater programs, students are able to express their individual creativity while further deepening the connection between performing, visual and musical arts. In addition, to further reinforce the students' understanding of arts, Brooklyn Conservatory of Music returned this year. As a result, this musical program helps students explore musical enrichment through hands-on participation in musical instruments, cultural songs and rhythmic applications. PS 971 students also enjoy in-house performances through Lincoln Center, where they are instructed about the history and evolution of Jazz. In addition, students have opportunities to experience art in technology with our partnerships in Robotics and Coding. Building upon last years success, the coding and robotics program has expanded to include an afterschool component. PS 971 students explore primary sources that include art artifacts for study and reflection. PS 971 students continued their participation in The Morgan Book Project, in which they were able to create handmade books and prepare pigments for painting. Students were also selected and honored as standouts in the 2017-2018 cohort. As a whole, while following the Blue Print for the Arts Standards, students are able to explore the connection with the arts throughout their daily content areas programs.

The Arts Program at P.S.90 offers a vibrant interdisciplinary approach to learning through our music and visual arts classes. All students receive instruction in the Visual Arts from either the school's licensed art teacher or the artist-in-residence. Students participate in boroughwide and citywide contests and have the opportunity to have their work publicly displayed. This year, a second grade student made it to the semi-finalist round of the PS Art competition. We also had a second grade student's artwork displayed at the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival.Several students have had their artwork exhibited throughout the community in places such as a major department store. All students experience a vocal and instrumental music program which includes recorder, violin, keyboard and a complete Orff orchestra. These programs culminate in four concerts and various assemblies throughout the school year. Our school also participates in the Little Kids Rock music program which uses modern band instruments. We also have several arts residencies in place. We are excited to have been designated as a magnet school with a focus on Environmental Studies and Community Wellness. We will continue to incorporate the arts into other disciplines through STEAM (science, technology, engineering, art, math ) and a project based learning approach. Through project based learning, we motivate our students to incorporate many aspects of the arts into their development of problem solving.This approach promotes critical thinking and vigorous learning,

Q32_6: CBO: Arts Connection, Brooklyn Arts Council
Q35_6: CBO: Brooklyn Arts Council, Arts Connection
Q46_1: PS/IS 95 is a pre-k to 8th grade school. We believe in educating the whole child through rigorous academic programs and arts instruction that enriches the lives of our students. We offer dance, music, art, and drama, facilitated by experienced staff members who frequently attend professional development. The arts allow students to expand their academic horizons through a knowledge of cultural appreciation and enlarge their understanding of the world. In our efforts to prepare our students for college and career, the arts program has also been aligned with our social studies curriculum and the Common Core State Standards. Our goals for our arts program are to allow our student population to appreciate the diverse cultural heritages inherent in our school, and to help create a respectful and tolerant learning community.
