We have also sought opportunities with Digital DELLTA through the Brooklyn Arts Council grant funding to bring theater to our school to service all of our English Language Learners in grades 5-7. In addition we applied for and received a CASA Grant for additional visual arts instruction through the Brooklyn Arts Council. Through this program the students have left a legacy for future students by the paintings of murals throughout our school building. We have also engaged parents in the arts by inviting them to workshops that culminated in the painting of murals that are displayed in our multi-purpose room.

Seth Low IS 96 is proud to offer a variety of performing and visual arts to cultivate the talent of our students. All students receive general instruction in both art and music in 7th and 8th grade. In addition students can choose to take part in the following Arts Specialties: Visual Arts including drawing and painting, Orchestra, Band or Drum Corps. Next year we are planning to add theater and vocal to our Arts Menu. In addition we are a Broadway Jr. School and out on a performance every year!

The arts program at Public School 97 provides its students with channels for self-expression and opportunities to enhance self-esteem, all while fostering an appreciation for the arts and encouraging students to become lifelong learners. Our goal is to expose all students to situations and experiences which allow them to explore various techniques in all areas of the arts, because we strongly believe that exposure to the arts increases students' inquiry skills, observational skills, problem solving skills and critical thinking skills. As an all inclusive school, we embrace our multicultural, multilingual PS 97 community and allow opportunities for our students to learn about world cultures, become world citizens and passionate leaders. Through the arts education, we celebrate the voices and cultures of our students, our families, our staff, and our community. At PS 97, every student receives art education through art teachers, NYC Ballet, Inside Broadway, teaching artists, and art clubs. Many of our students continue their art education at Mark Twain Middle school for Gifted and Talented and then at LaGuardia High School.

Q44_R2: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q44_R3: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: The Bay Academy provides rigorous instruction to the arts program and incorporates literacy and critical thinking in all lessons aligned to the Blueprint Standards. The Bay Academy offers talent areas in all three grades such as visual art, vocal music, winds, strings, drama and dance. There are many opportunities after school for students to participate in an arts program. Through collaboration and sharing best practices, teachers are encouraged to create shares lessons that fuse all talent areas. The performing arts classrooms are enriched with ELA Expeditionary Learning Protocols and through observations the performing arts teachers have mastered and balanced the use of creativity and meaningful discussion. The students learn about their craft through non-fiction research, writing projects and performance based assessment. All talent areas summarize their year through a culmination performance.The Bay Academy once again has been the recipients of many elected official based contests such as Respect For All, Assemblyman Cymbrowitz' Holocaust Memorial, as well as Senator Savino's Project Boost and The Ezra Jack Keats Book Making Contest.

Q39_4: creating costumes and props for plays
Q46_1: The goal of PS99 is to raise achievement levels for all students in pre-k-8 through the integration of a rigorous standards based arts program. We incorporate the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts into all curricula areas. Students will develop the skills needed to meet or exceed benchmarks. Students perform in plays and choral presentations in school. Parents come together to create costumes and props to enhance student performances. The community at large is invited and encouraged to be involved. Students in our sixth grade take part in an engaging   STEAM program after school provided by the Brooklyn Arts Council.  All of our 7th and 8th Grade students meet the required number of instructional hours needed for graduation in the arts.

P.S. 100, The Magnet School of Media Arts and Communication believes the arts are an effective medium for forging students, faculty, and families into a school-wide community. We achieve this goal through dance and musical performances, art exhibitions, and partnerships with American Ballroom Theater and the Jewish Association of Services for the Aging. Moreover, our classroom teachers work collaboratively to integrate the arts into our curricula, through Project Based Learning showcases. Each of our arts disciplines is aligned with the Common Core State Standards and the NYC Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Through participation and exposure to the arts, our students are able to develop a self-confidence and sense of self, which supports our vision that at P.S. 100, every child has a voice.

Q47_1: Our school has a very high ENL population. We are providing curriculum heavily immersed in the arts to enrich and enhance their learning experiences and have received grants in the Arts for after-school programs and Saturday programs as well as provide parent-engagement workshops during and after school. We now have two bilingual classes and will continue to add one bilingual class per year for a total of one per grade level. Our bilingual teachers have been providing special instruction with a focus on arts and culture to further learning.

Q46_1:
We have a visual arts and music program with two full time teachers. Our visual arts program exposes students to painting and drawing and art history. In our music program, students learn to read music, play the recorder, drums, guitar and keyboards. 

Through partnerships with cultural institutions and residencies, our program exposes students to a variety of arts disciplines. Our teachers integrate and align our arts program with the New York State Common Core Curriculum and prepare our students for college and career readiness. We strive to ensure that our students take full advantage of NYC's cultural offerings by affording them the opportunity to visit a variety of cultural institutions.

P.S. 128 continues to provide an enriching and diverse arts program for all students. We have two full-time arts teachers and our curriculum is enriched by collaborations with various cultural arts organizations. Not only do we continue to follow the NYC Blueprint for the Arts Instruction, but we have integrated these expectations into our content areas, aligning our units of study with the Common Core Learning Standards. All students receive arts experiences in visual arts, music, dance and theater. Our classroom teachers also collaborate with the arts teachers and supplement the program with grade showcases that are interdisciplinary, and build on student interests and talents. We then integrate the arts in our after school program. We believe that all teachers are teachers of the arts. Arts education allows students to be creative and expressive as we educate the whole child and prepare him/her to become future leaders. The arts are vital to our school, and loved by all students, teachers, administration, and families!

The Students at P.S. 153 share a love for the arts, it's a time for them to unwind from the reading, writing, and math that they do on a daily basis. P.S. 153 currently has a theater, dance and music program.  The theater program give the children an opportunity to come out of their shell through improv,theater games,playwriting and perfromances. Each grade put on a perfromance (monthly). There is also a Musical Production in the evening.  The dance program introduces grades Kindergarten through 5th grade to various elements of dance.  Students are taught dance though body, effort/dynamics, space and relationship. The dance teacher also bought in Alvin Ailey dancers and Hip Hop dancers for the upper grades. In additional there was an opportunity for 75 members of the community to attend a concert at Lincoln Center. The Music program this year was primarily for the Pre-K.  The music teacher goes into the classroom.  Next year the Music program will expand through 5th grade. The goal is to contiune to motivate and reinforce the arts at P.S. 153.

Our arts program continues to grow and flourish. We now have two full-time visual arts teachers, one for grades Pre-K-2 and another for grades 3-5. Our young musicians continue to excel with our instrumental band programs, Cadet Band for novice players and Concert Band for advanced players. Our young singers are part of Chorus and this group includes students from grades 3, 4 and 5. All second grade students learn to play the Recorder and later in the year can audition to be part of the Recorder Band. School leadership is committed to a rich arts education and continues to focus on providing a quality education in the arts for all of our students.

The Michael E. Berdy School for the Arts proudly integrates all art forms into our curriculum. Through Cultural Institutions the students are exposed to different forms art. Students explore visual, multi-media, theatre and music.  In the afterschool program students participate in all a variety of arts.

PS 199 believes the arts provide opportunities for all children to express themselves and develop multiple intelligences and talents. By integrating the arts into other curricula areas, the arts provide a vehicle for developing literacy and critical thinking skills. Our school provides these opportunities to our students both within the school day and in afterschool programs. Through our assembly program, students are exposed to various performance arts and perform in plays and concerts.

Q44_R2: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: Choral music was provided to kindergarten children. Visual arts will be provided to our 1st and 2nd grade children. Every classroom teacher in grades K to 5th grade will provide instruction in either dance/visual arts and theater arts.  Grade K to 5 will be required to perform one assembly program a year.  In grades 6,7 and 8 the ELA teachrs for the grade will work collaboratively with the other content area teachers on the grade to produce two plays in a school year.  The plays can include music and dance as well.

Our school places a very high priority on the quality of the arts imparted to our children. The administration supports every effort to create and maintain the rich and nurturing environment for the arts to blossom. P.S. 212 offers a musical theater program for all grades that includes acting, directing, and design. Puppetry in Practice has supported our arts program by offering a residency to students in various grades. The program incorporated both visual arts and theater in the classroom setting.  We offer a Literacy through Dance program by utilizing a full time dance teacher and program theater and dance clubs for grades 2-5 before, during and after school hours. This year, we have introduced a glee, chorus and cheer club. We also hosted an after school art club which was attended by over 35 students. We have an annual Costume Parade and Dance Festival for the lower grades; a winter concert for all grade levels; a 5th grade musical theater production directed by the theater and dance teacher and complimented by the work of the art club. Our school participates in the Ezra Jack Keats Book Making Competition and our art clubs in grades grades 3, 4 and 5 submit artwork for different contests. Student art pieces are celebrated in a grade level art family fun event. This year, our student art work was selected once again for recognition in the borough arts fair and also to be displayed as part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art showcase.
The goal of P.S. 215's art program is to provide a comprehensive and sequential standards-based art education to all students Pre k-to 5th grade.

For the 2017-2018 Marquis Studios has provided arts instruction for our K-2 students for 10 sessions. In addition, we had the after-school programs where about 100 students in grades 4-5 and 2-3 participated in some art activities. For the after-school programs, we were only able to invite 25 students for each grade.

At PS/IS 226, the students participate in the arts during the school day, in after school programs, and at special performances. Our music program includes general and instrumental classes. Our instrumental program showcases different grade levels on recorder, violin, guitar, keyboard, xylophone, and concert bands. Our visual arts students’ art work is displayed throughout the school using different media and in large scale murals. We have every class perform a class play, which includes singing, dancing, and acting on stage for their peers, family members and the school community. The students perform winter and spring musical concerts on both the elementary and middle school grade levels to demonstrate student achievement in the arts.  Selected students in grades 5-8 take part in Broadway Junior after school theater program provided through Music Theater International.  Our goal is to give every student an opportunity to experience, make connections, and become literate in each of the arts disciplines during their time as a student at PS/IS 226.

The Arts Magnet Program at David A. Boody is a three year sequential program that encompasses strings, winds, dance, theatre, visual art and digital art. Students are immersed in comprehensive arts experiences that include arts making, arts literacy, making connections and performing. The program is aligned with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and prepares students for high school. During this year, we introduced STEAM within our school community.

Q44_R3: National Museum of the American Indian
Q46_1:
PS 238 is a small k-8 school located in Midwood, Brooklyn. The arts programming consists of a full-time certified visual arts teacher, a music teacher/ drama teacher, and a dance teacher. Students in the elementary grades have an opportunity to experience dance, chorus, drama, and visual arts at least one period a week. Students in the middle school have visual arts twice a week.  

The school takes students out of the building to visit museums that are integrated with their social studies, science, and ELA curricula. This year students went to the Whitney Museum, Museum of Modern Art, Rubin Museum, Snug Harbor, The Chinese American Museum, and Brooklyn Navy Yard. In addition they took trips to see the cityscapes where they drew from observation at the Brooklyn Bridge Park and Coney Island. The school also brought in several arts partnerships this year including The Brooklyn Public Library, Museum of Modern Art, Marquis Studios, and Brooklyn Arts Council. This school received ELL partnership grant from DOE Arts. This enabled the school to have a theater program for 12 weeks with 4th and 5th graders. 
The students at PS 238 are growing artistically. This year we had four semi-finalists and one final artist in citywide PS ART show. In addition one student's work is represented in the Brooklyn Borough Arts festival. The school is looking to further strengthen the arts department by developing more arts partnerships in the music and dance disciplines as well continuing to develop the community involvement in the arts.

Mark Twain IS 239 For the Gifted and Talented is an arts-centered school that uses the arts to enhance education across the curriculum. In alignment with the Common Core Standards and the New York City Arts Curriculum Guides (The Blueprints for the Arts), Mark Twain offers comprehensive programs in the four art forms. Screened three-year sequences are offered in Dance; Music (strings, vocal, and winds); Theater; and in the Visual Arts (fine arts and media). Emphasis is placed on literacy in the arts, and cultural/historical connections with related curricula. Students enrolled in a three-year sequence receive intensive instruction throughout their time at Mark Twain, and all students meet or exceed the New York State arts requirements to qualify for graduation in the eighth grade. It is Mark Twain's goal to enable every child to perform at their optimum level in the core curriculum, as well as to participate and appreciate the arts in pursuit of a well-rounded, holistic education.

By June of 2019, students and staff will demonstrate an increased awareness of the arts. Participation in school and class concerts /performances, parent/student workshops and meeting grade appropriate benchmarks in the literacy of the arts strand as measured by The Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Demonstration of mastery will be evidenced both within and beyond the classroom.
Q47_1: As a New York Showcase School we expand the boundaries of our classroom with the support of the residency and in school programs. These programs provide opportunities to develop student voice and agency to our most at risk learners.  As a school whose population boasts some 50 languages from countries across the globe, it is imperative to collaborate with partners who have experienced and appreciate diverse school communities.

Q46_1: Our arts curriculum at I.S.281 Joseph B. Cavallaro is an integral part of a solid educational foundation that builds upon prior arts knowledge and experience and addresses the needs of all learners. We offer a wide range of experiences in dance,music, media, technology and visual arts, wherein students develop the physical, aesthetic and critical thinking skills that enable them to see and respond to the world. Students will experience various disciplines to expand their knowledge and skill and help them to make personal connections with our school and the world around them. Technology and the Fine Arts are infused into curriculum studies throughout our school community. Our staff plan units of study that allow students to experience the arts through a variety of mediums. Ultimately, we seek to nurture an appreciation of the arts within all of our children.

Our school offers courses in the following arts programs: visual arts, music, theatre and dance.  
Our music and drama programs serve as a resource for the development of musical knowledge, musical skills, theatre skills, aesthetic exploration, attitude development and provides for the personal growth of each individual student.  Our students learn theatre skills, music theory, music history and perform in the I.S. 303 jazz band.  The dance curriculum focuses on the study of the Elements of Dance, Ballet, and Tap Dance.  Students learn basic skills and techniques to begin their dance education, as well as dance history and theory.  Students participate in a several dance and theatre productions, both inside and outside of the school.  
We also have arts partnerships with the Center for Arts Engage and Arts Connection.  We offer visual and theatre arts as a way to support our  Language Arts instruction.  Both Arts Engage and Arts Connections initiatives provide a unique opportunity for our school to enrich arts and academic teaching and learning.  The program is infused into the sixth, seventh and eighth grade Language Arts classrooms.

Our goal at the Surfside School is to inspire well-rounded children who have been elevated to a higher level. We believe that by exposing our children to the arts, we provide a positive learning experience that will have lifelong impact. The Surfside School has been recognized, citywide, for its excellence in the arts. In addition to our premier seaside location, we are home to a state of the art dance studio, museum, art studio, well appointed auditorium and two technology labs. Our students are exposed to a myriad of enriching experiences including fine art, ballroom dance, modern, west African and jazz instruction, theater, chorus, violin study, photography and media arts. Our students enjoy frequent opportunities to explore and celebrate their talents. Grade four and five students participate in talent academies aligned to their art discipline of choice. Annually, the dance and art presentations represent the culmination of student enrichment across the various arts disciplines. We believe such experiences allow P.S. 329 students to become empowered, inspired and elevated to their highest level of achievement.

All students at IHSL receive three full years of arts instruction, including visual arts and media arts in the 9th/10th grades as well as multi-media music arts in the 12th grade. All students will have access to additional arts offerings (singing, dance, film/media, photography) through our elective program. Also, the arts program at IHSL has designed innovative, interdisciplinary curricula for ELLs. Additionally, extensive outreach is done to partnership organizations to provide additional opportunities to students, based on need and interest.

Ms. Kreitzer, our school's art teacher is fantastic and talented. Her students have been recognized in contests throughout the city including the 2018 Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival.  Our art room has a state-of-the-art kiln for our ceramics classes (several of our students ceramics projects have been recognized in competitions as well).  

Despite not having a theater program (yet!), we were able to take 80 students to see Hamilton on Broadway this past school year and hope to keep that trend alive and well.

In the 2018-19 school year we will have a 3-D printing lab on multiple floors in the building, a more structured art club that will produce galleries around the building, and a theater club that will put on shows for students and parents alike.

This year, we continued to expand our music program to included advanced piano. Students will be able to concentrate in music appreciation. This year, we included a small visual arts program for students during the day. We have included a coding class that is a pre-requisite to complement our growing computer science program. The in-residency program provided a group of 9th grade students an opportunity to express their artistic talents in visual arts. We hope to expand this program if the funding is provided.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: We are always looking for ways to improve our arts programs. Students in the photography program identify and research trends in photography that make them adaptable to the shifts in the professional industry. We also created a media program. Students use professional video equipment and learn how to broadcast live events. After assessing students to see who had an interest in choral music or in playing an instrument, we created two additional classes in our schedule. We now have a chorus class and a band class. Our theater program is in its fourth year. Our students will be performing a fourth musical at the end of May. This year, we had our second winter festival. Our Theater classes performed along with the band and chorus. We also created a Set Design class in the spring of last year. The students are creating, designing, building and painting the scenery for our spring musical. Our Photography program established a partnership with The Art Deco Society. Through this organization, our Photo students had the opportunity to learn and explore Art Deco designs in and around NYC. We will continue to use student portfolio assessments, sketchbooks, projects and our literacy initiative in the arts classes as a way of assessing knowledge and skills. We have attended professional development this year that addresses how to make our instruction more aligned. We will continue to build on what we have established and hopefully add more productive programs as we move forward.
Q47_1:
Currently we have one screened program for the Arts which is Photography.
We have built a Music, Theater and Arts program in house.  We survey students in the 9th grade to see if they are interested in joining either the Theater, Music (Band or Chorus) or Visual Arts classes and this is how we have been building our program.

Our students are mostly economically disadvantaged. 19% of our population is ENL and 15% are students with disabilities.

Q44_R5: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: The Arts Program at KECSS is designed to expose students to multiple forms of artistic expression, including visual arts, performing arts, and the written and spoken word.  KECSS’s Enrichment Clusters allow students to pursue their diverse artistic interests each year with other students and KECSS facilitators.  These included painting, using mixed media to create visual arts projects, and participating in drama and theater.  7th grade students had performing arts taught weekly. Our teacher delivered a program according to the Statewide Strategic Plan for the Arts, which included planning and implementation to support the advancement and adoption of the New York State P-12 Dance, Music, Theater, Visual and Media Arts Learning Standards.  Our school’s field trips included trips to see two Broadway musicals, a one-woman show, stand-up performances at the Apollo, Urban word performances, and a Radio City Music Hall holiday show.  In addition, our 10th graders participated in a series of performance workshops with the Creative Arts Team and attended a culminating performance by the program.

John Dewey High School continues to offer and expansive array of courses, including ceramics, computer graphics, drawing, painting, photography, dance and theater production. Each strand ( Dance, Fine Arts, and Theater) has a 4 year scope and sequence resulting in the opportunity to take a regents exam and receive an Endorsed Diploma in their strand of study. This is a challenging, but prestigious achievement that the New York City Department of Education now offers. 
This year our theater department did a production of Almost Maine in the Fall and our Spring Musical is Legally Blonde. Legally Blonde is based on the novel by Amanda Brown and the MGM movie starring Reese Witherspoon.
Our Dance program continues to grow and share their work with us. This year in honor of  Woman's History Month they celebrated influential woman in history with dances choreographed by students as well as our teacher Ms. Green. We look forward to our yearly culminating event where all classes showcase their work for the year. 
Our Fine Arts department proudly celebrates our students work at our Annual Art Show where students, teachers and families come to celebrate the artistic growth of our students highlighting our seniors growth over the 4 years at John Dewy High School.
Our Fine and Performing Arts Academy will be entering its third year, and we look forward to increasing its capacity and offerings moving forward.

Q39_4: teachers donate art supplies as well
Q46_1: At L.I.F.E. Academy High School for Film & Music in Brooklyn, we offer a multi-year,sequence in film and visual literacy as well as a revolving track in music (audio) production in support of our mission of engaging diverse learners through a variety of media and inquiry based projects. Film and music literacy are woven through core classes through introducing students to various tools to cultivate, unlock, and express their creativity in multiple modalities. By tapping into their artistic voices, students apply critical thinking skills via projects and peer review and critiques of works in progress. The school maintains a student photography gallery of nearly 50 framed works to evidence concepts learned while emphasizing ownership as well. In support of our arts program, while making connections to art and artists studied in class, we continue to partner with and immerse students in the visual arts through visits to the Whitney Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern Art, The International Center of Photography, Brooklyn Museum, and more. Students are taken on photography and film trips to capture and create work at Central Park, Prospect Park, and the Brooklyn Botanical Garden.  Students participate in Teen Nights at the Whitney Museum & the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Master classes are offered with the community based support of “I Will Graduate” in their music classes and afterschooll through ABC/Disney’s “Get Reel,” program for our second year. For the first year, students worked with Avenue Music Group.

Leaders has a full-time visual arts teacher. She teaches a 9th grade arts class that all students take and an advanced class that students may elect to take. We also offer dance, photography, music, and theater electives throughout the year. We offer an afterschool guitar program and an afterschool band program. Our goals for next year are to enhance the quality of all of these programs and to demonstrate the student achievements through more public art and photography shows and more dance recitals. We also want to launch an after-school theater/musical theater program.  We also hope to have more performances for the students in these programs.

Grady High School has worked diligently over the past several years to increase the arts opportunities available for students. As a CTE school, only required art and music were offered. While students are still only required to take two terms of study in the arts, the certified arts teacher provides instruction in a number of different type of art forms in her classes. It is our consistent goal to enhance our students’ arts experiences through integration of courses that give them the opportunity to develop their own artistic identities while expanding their knowledge of cultural arts.

The arts program at Brooklyn Studio Secondary school is a 6-12 that encompasses dance, instrumental music, and digital arts. 

For instrumental music, students take a comprehensive program in winds, brass and percussion. By their 12th grade, students take part in NYSSMA, and the Music in the Parks program. 

For dance, students learn the foundations of dance composition, technique and choreography. We collaborate with Capezio and Alvin Ailey for professional development, performances and resources. 

Visual Arts in encompassed in our Digital Arts CTE program. Students take classes in Studio Art, Digital Art and Animation.

In our Middle School, students take classes as a "talent" concentration in dance, instrumental music, visual arts, and theatre.

We offer a basic art program via our iLearn Platform that allows at-risk students of not graduating the possibility to fulfill the state mandated graduation requirement. Through other classes that are offered we provide students other opportunities to explore and engage in the arts via museums, school talent showcases, and plays. We have also been fortunate to receive a grant for an arts program to combat violence.

Shell Bank students enjoy Violin through the Midori and Friends Grant.  Students also participate in dance, art and music classes through Marquis Studios.  Elective classes in music, drama, theatre, film, art and dance are also offered all during the school year.

Instruction in the arts is a top priority at P.S. 52, and to that end, our arts department delivers instruction in four key disciplines: visual arts, theatre, music and dance, all provided by licensed arts teachers. This broadens the scope and reach of our arts program by giving every student in the school the opportunity to explore the arts through multiple avenues. We produce musical theatre, dramatic performances, concerts, dance performances, and visual arts and the moving image exhibits throughout the year for the school and the community. We also provide parent workshops in the arts and engage the community in the support and production of arts events. The arts department also works with cultural arts organizations to secure arts grants, arrange field trips and provide artist residencies for our school. Classroom teachers incorporate the arts into all areas of their curriculum and exhibit artwork on a regular basis, and artists are studied in each grade as part of the arts curriculum. P.S. 52 is committed to delivering an inclusive, high quality, interdisciplinary arts education for all of our students.

P.S 109 is servicing grades 4-8 in visual arts. This year P.S 109 provided the students with instruction in painting, drawing, pastel art, mixed-media and sculpture. Cross-curricula information was incorporated into each visual art lesson, and each unit plan was tied to a specific artist and art period. Art Club was offered every day during lunch in order to facilitate the students with high school portfolio preparation, and the development of personal art interest exploration. As a result four students were accepted into the specialized art high school programs of their choice. Students were provided with differentiated visual and physical materials in order to reach their diverse learning styles. Students work was exhibited in the Annual District 22 Art Show. Additionally, students displayed their work in the Annual Brooklyn MLK Arts Competition.  Students entered their work into State Senator Kevin Parker's Annual Earth Day Arts contest and the winning Art work is displayed on the Senator's web page. P.S 109 is currently working with an art partnership called Studio in a School; students are exploring pottery making and clay sculpture design from a teaching artist. With the skills gained through this partnership, next year we would like to incorporate more clay sculpture making into the art curriculum at P.S 109. 
Students in Kindergarten-Grade 2 receive integrated Literacy, Arts and Theater instruction through a residency with Puppetry in Practice.

PS 119, a Title One school, has a strong foundation of Peace Education that defines the culture of the school.  PS 119 is committed to developing the whole child with a focus on the arts. Students are given art and music instruction from pre-k through grade 5. A magnet school, each year students study diverse cultures with a culminating expo demonstrating student learning and achievement. An important part of the school culture is to expose our children to global traditions while promoting peace on earth. Art is seen as a tool for creative expression as well as a pathway for language development and behavior modification. Our arts partners work in concert with the arts educators and classroom teachers to provide the most coherent scaffolding of lessons for making meaning through the arts. Students visit cultural institutions and performances throughout the school year. It is through this far-reaching arts approach that we believe children are motivated to enjoy learning across the curricula as they evolve into their best selves.  

Additionally, our school has a strong foundation of Peace Education that defines the culture of the building.  PS 119, has been recognized by the United Nations for its effort to Promote Peace through Arts Learning.  Our goals are to broaden the resources available to our students, teachers and families in the classrooms and in the arts spaces. We look forward to more collaborations, to further develop dance, theater and STEAM initiatives, introduce new media and to make the world a better place.

At P.S. 134 we strive to incorporate all aspects of the arts instruction into the curriculum. Our goal is to create a climate of appreciation and learning of all art forms by our students. We do this by exposing the students to various arts instruction from kindergarten through Grade 5. We also do this by showcasing the accomplishments of all students in the arts. The students receive instruction in the arts from certified teachers who use the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts to provide developmentally appropriate lessons. These teachers also differentiate instruction for the students to accelerate the learning of all students.

For over thirteen years, our arts program has shown consistent growth. Our pre-k classes have music, dance, and visual art with certified arts teachers and a Studio resident artist. All K-2nd grade classes have general music and keyboarding with Music and the Brain, art, and dance, as well as a theatre residency. 3rd-5th grade have general music and recorder with another certified music teacher, line dancing in physical education, art with a resident artist. 5th Grade has theatre with a resident artist.  K-1st grades have theater with their classroom teachers. A few dozen students have Music Therapy. We have violin for 30 2nd graders, a new orchestra for 20 3rd Graders, and 15 students participate in Bell Choir. 20 students each in 2nd-5th grade participate in dance clubs. Sixty 4th and 5th graders use band instruments from the VH1 Grant. 50 4th and 5th graders share guitars from Little Kids Rock. 60 children are in Chorus. Throughout the year, we receive several instruments and visual arts donations from the community. Studio in a School provides several parent workshops. Several years ago, the Arts Space grant provided risers, stage lights, and microphones. Next year, we hope to have a theatre residency for all students, and we will be adding an art teacher for 3rd-5th. Every child has several opportunities to perform in both dance and music concerts throughout year culminating in two Fine Arts Nights, as well as several Stepping Up Ceremonies. 4th Gr Band participates in MMNY. We will continue to enrich the whole child.
Q47_1:
“We are a Title I school with approximately 75% of our students qualifying for free lunch.  PS 139 is located in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. This is a neighborhood of both single-family homes and large, densely populated apartment houses surrounded by commercial avenues. The neighborhood is economically and culturally diverse. Our families speak approximately 30 languages at home. Our diverse student body represents countries such as: Pakistan, the former Soviet Union, Mexico, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, as well other countries in the Caribbean, South and Central America, Asia, Europe and Africa. We serve approximately 200 English language learners and 170 students with disabilities” (quoted from section 2 of our school CEP plan 2017-2018).  The following is taken from page 12 of our CEP.
--Total Enrollment 975 	--Attendance Rate 94.2% 
--% Limited English Proficient 17.5% 
--%Students with Disabilities 15.0% 
Racial/Ethnic Origin (2016-17) 
--American Indian or Alaska Native 1.1%
--Black or African American 31.4% 
--Hispanic or Latino 38.9% 	
--Asian or Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander 17.5% 
--White 9.2% 	
--Multi-Racial 1.9% 
--(2016-17) ELA Performance at levels 3 & 4 31.6% 
--Mathematics Performance at levels 3 & 4 37.9% 
--Science Performance at levels 3 & 4 (4th Grade) (2015-16) 76.0%

Q46_1: P.S.152's goal is to ensure that instruction in the arts is an integral component of our academic program. Students in our Early Childhood Annex receive specialized instruction in visual arts, dance and music. Students in grades 2-5 are provided with specialized instruction in visual arts, music and dance. P.S.152's students in grades K and 1 participate in a school chorus, and upper grade students have the opportunity to be part of our African Drum Ensemble. Students participate in shows and dance recitals several times a year. Additionally, they attend off-site plays and view films in class.

P.S. 193 offers kinesthetic arts and music programs, exposing pre-k thru grade 5 students to a variety of arts experiences. Students are enriched in the arts through cultural arts organizations by attending dance, music, theater and art exhibits in the community. We plan on increasing our family engagement by offering more family night opportunities.

Q45_10: video analysis, NYC Blueprint for the Arts based checklists developed by teachers
Q46_1: A previous Federal Magnet Grant enabled PS 194 to establish our arts program. Although we are no longer funded by the grant, our certified arts teachers and classroom teachers work collaboratively to provide arts instruction to support units of study aligned with the CCSS & the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and the NYS Arts Standards. With knowledge gained from prior arts residencies (Covenant Ballet Theatre of Brooklyn, Alvin Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Making Books Sing, Education in Dance, Brooklyn Philharmonic and Midori & Friends) our teachers continue to use the arts as a vehicle to enhance the classroom curriculum and produce grade specific performances which include dance, music/singing, speaking and acting. We have continued our connection with Covenant Ballet Theatre and Midori & Friends, as well as making new connections with NY City Center. We are continuing our Composer/Artist of the Month program in which students are exposed to facts and musical excerpts each morning. Also, our certified arts teachers are utilizing specially equipped spaces such as our dance studio, music/art room and auditorium. All of our students are receiving dance & music instruction this year. Students are also participating in our arts related clubs (dance, chorus, arts & crafts, graphic design, scrap booking) and our after-school violin program. The arts are and will continue to be an integral part of PS 194.
Q47_1: At PS 194 all of our students participate in the arts. Our ELL students as well as our students with disabilities are fully integrated into general education classes for arts instruction and participate in all performances. The arts is used as a vehicle to reach all children and provide a safe environment for exploration and success.

Q46_1: P.S. 195 is extremely proud of the arts programs we have developed at our school. We have a visual arts teacher who serves all grade levels. Her program incorporates artist studies and rich interdisciplinary connections to our social studies curriculum. A certified dance teacher provides instruction to all students in the history of dance, choreography, and technique. We have several art exhibits and dance performances throughout the year.
Q47_1: As a non-Title I school, our budget is very limited.  Our dance teacher has secured grants to transform the auditorium into a dance studio (mirrors, barres, new lighting).  Our visual arts teacher holds a Common Branch certification.  However, she is an active participant and leader in a variety of professional learning groups.  I wish that we received more credit for the work that she does in providing our students with a rich visual arts curriculum aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts. We extend an invitation for you to review our students' work at our Art Show (5/16/18).

Q46_1: Our visual arts program includes the study of techniques such as painting, printmaking, collage, sculpture, portrait, Matisse paper cuts, and studying famous artists and their work. Children showcase their work throughout the building and at our semi-annual art fairs. Our visual art is showcased online at http://www.artsonia.com/schools/school.asp?id=79902 Our music department focuses on general music instruction, appreciation, keyboard, theory, reading, percussion and woodwinds. It incorporates music in literacy and social studies instruction. Our instructor works with classroom teachers on various projects throughout the year. Classes perform twice a year in the Winter and Spring Gala. The arts are highly integrated in all subject areas. Our day begins with music and is played during independent activities. Film, visual arts and theater are utilized in all content areas. Our gym program is infused with music and movement. We have monthly assemblies during which classes perform music, dance, theater or a combination of all disciplines. Ample rehearsal time is included in the schedule and all classes participate in performances throughout the year. We offer after school programs in art, movement and music for our entire population. We use Title 1 parent involvement money to fund parent workshops in the visual arts. The focus is for parents to understand the impact of arts on children, academically and socially. Our programs provide all children with opportunities to develop a deep appreciation of art.
Q47_1: Our school has a large ELL population which has grown exponentially over the past few years. We are currently seeking grant opportunities that would allow us to provide more opportunities to hire teaching artist from a large variety of arts partners.

Q46_1: This year we have a full time dance teacher who services fifteen classes. We also have a full time visual arts  teacher who services twelve classes. In addition, we have Marquis Studio to our school.This program is funded by a federal Magnet grant. Marquis Studio provides music lessons,  dance lessons, visual arts and theater to our students. In addition, there is Band for Today which provides keyboarding/piano lessons for some of our students. We have plans to expand our arts program next year with the grants we received. We will be working with other outside art specialists to incorporate more arts in our curriculum.

This school year, with a restrictive budget, the Arts program at P.S.203 is growing and thriving.    We offer our students a balanced Arts Program through the following: Visual Art, Music, Band, and Dance.    Classroom teachers along with our full time music (2), visual art, and dance teachers continue to devote instructional time to the arts.    We are continuously making strides to not only meet, but exceed the expectations as set forth in the Blueprint for the Arts and through the integration of the Common Core Standards.
Our seasonal performances, school based and cultural organization- based assemblies, residencies, annual gala, chorus, band, and annual art festival continue to develop and showcase the talent of our students and staff.    Student performances are among the highlights of the school year and support with parent/ guardian presence.

The arts program at PS/IS 206 includes three certified visual arts teachers, two certified music teachers, one certified drama teacher and one certified dance teacher. In the 2018-19 school year, PS/IS 206 will be adding an additional dance teacher to the Arts Department. The elementary music program at P.S. 206 is a sequenced program that addresses musical feeling, concepts, music literacy, cultural context, and performance. The middle school program includes General Music which builds a foundation of music including the instruments of the orchestra, traditional notation, tablature, Western and World Music History, musical theater and the Little Kids Rock Modern Band Program. Performances are done throughout the school year. The dance program at P.S./I.S. 206 is a creative based program focused on the Elements of Dance and techniques such as ballet, modern, jazz, HipHop, and cultural dance forms. Through the Blueprint for the Arts in Dance, we study various choreographers, and the history of each dance form. Students are creative choreographers through the art of dance-making including a partnership with Alvin Ailey. The PS 206 theatre program is designed to introduce students to theatre as an art for and means of communication, engage their creativity in developing original performance material, and build their skills as theatre artists and lifelong learners. The visual arts program is aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Arts and students explore drawing, painting, sculpture paper-mache, printmaking, sculpture and collage.

Q45_10: Skedula online grading system and Teacher class websites
Q46_1: Our goal is to make our students college and career ready in all subject areas, including the arts. Our students participate in rigorous arts curricula which support the Common Core Learning Standards and College and Career Readiness Skills. In addition, we embrace the Arts Blueprint and arts standards based units of study/lessons which connect the arts to the Common Core subjects. As a former i3 Arts Achieve school, we focus on formative and summative assessment which works to empower students to reflect and directly enhance their art. This process makes experience and performance in the arts more valuable by connecting them to a multitude of resources. Therefore, we believe there to be a significant correlation of arts achievement on improved English Language Arts performance. Additionally, we are furthering our school's curriculum by integrating a S.T.E.A.M approach to teaching across all grade levels. It is our firm belief that this holistic approach to learning will yield students to become well-rounded, with the ability to incorporate the arts seamlessly into their daily lives. In this we foster students to make educated, college and career choices which is rooted in the education they receive at PS 207.
Q47_1: The Fillmore Academy features a very strong visual art and musical arts program. The visual arts program offers a screened Portfolio Development/Advanced Art Skill class. Students create portfolios which enable them to audition for specialized high schools. Our school holds an annual gallery exhibit and we are also a former i3 Arts Achieve school in the Visual Arts. Our music program, a former Juilliard Grant school, offers students a screened instrumental ensemble which includes a specialized Jazz Band. Our music program also offers chorus for both upper elementary and middle school students. Both the choral and band groups present two shows yearly. Furthermore, our music and visual arts programs take part in multiple contests, as well as the District 22 band and visual arts show. Through our after-school program Millennium, we have an elementary and middle school theater program which puts on one to two shows each year. As a direct result of the visual arts, music, and theater programs, many of these students go on to specialized Arts High Schools.

Q46_1: PS 217's goal is to provide all students with sequential instruction in the arts so they meet benchmarks in the arts blueprints. Students experience instruction in visual arts, music/movement and theater/dance. They receive additional instruction through residencies and our extensive after-school program which offers 14 arts related clubs providing 44 additional hours of arts instruction to 257 K-5 students.  Fourth and fifth graders choose an area in the arts they wish to focus on and experience in-depth instruction in our Discovery Zone Program by participating in one of twenty-four different clubs. Instruction takes place during an extended last period on Fridays, adding thirty hours of arts instruction for these students

Classroom and out of classroom teachers engage students in arts instruction in alignment with the Blueprint for the Arts. We are thrilled to offer Dance, Music and Visual Arts instruction to our students through our in-house fully certified staff.  Our Art Team collaborates with classroom teachers integrate the arts into all subjects. 
 
Our students participate in visual arts activities such as painting, drawing, collage, and sculpture. Students learn about famous artists through read aloud, research and class discussions. Classroom teachers creatively connect drama and literacy by designing lessons where the children act out stories and put on plays. In addition, students engage in activities such as performing dance routines and drama skits for the students and parents of P.S. 222 to enjoy. Music and expressive movement are integrated into various curricula areas throughout the day. 

Teachers work collaboratively to produce grade level performances such as songfests and holiday shows. We support our students’ talents and creativity by encouraging them to participate in a variety of contests. Every year our students participate in competitions where they can design books, posters, or create songs for the particular topic of the competition.

The Arts program at Cunningham engages students in a comprehensive study of both performing and visual arts. Our objective is to enhance our students' understanding, appreciation and performance. Throughout our program, students are actively engaged in creation and performance in the Arts through a variety of classes. Our goal is to expose students to: Music, Dance, Theater, Painting, Ceramics, Digital Photography, Multi Media Arts, Textile Design, and to enhance their understanding and appreciation of those arts. We encourage them to respond critically to a variety of works, connecting the individual work to other works and other aspects of human endeavor and thought. Through interdisciplinary lessons, field trips, and visits from various Arts organizations, our students develop an understanding of the personal and cultural forces that shape artistic communication and impact the diverse cultures of the past and present society.

This school and its community is dedicated to providing students with a well-rounded arts education.  We have included Dance, Art and STEAM  into our curriculum and scheduling and supplemented instruction with Music Residencies for every student.  Our "clubs" focus on closing the gap in the arts by offering students a chance in our drama club, yoga club, digital photography, school beautification projects (art based) just to name a few.  The staff seeks opportunities for the students to experience live theater with trips as much as possible.  With very limited funding, we set out to include all four art domains to the best of our abilities.  Our belief is that through the arts, our students are well rounded and culturally enriched, with a view toward making every student College and Career ready.

I.S. 240 Andries Hudde Magnet School of STEM is committed to providing an Arts education to all our students.  We have classes in Visual Arts, String Orchestra and Brass Band.  Each of these offerings has a dedicated room and is taught by teachers licensed in the specific areas.  Our Instrumental Music classes perform at graduation, award ceremonies, and selected students perform with the District 22 Honors' Band.  The students'art work is displayed for parent teacher conferences.  Our Title III Immigrant Grant provided us with five evenings of Painting for our parents, facilitated by our Visual Arts' teacher.

In addition to our school offerings, we work closely with Puppetry in Practice.  They provide residencies for our sixth, seventh and eighth grade classes using Stop Motion Animation.

We also partner with BEAM to create visuals aligned with our Magnet Theme.  Brooklyn College Community Theater  provided shows for our students such as Los Planeros, Lunar New Year and Cinco de Mayo. They also provided a Caribbean Dance Residency.  

Our students went on numerous trips to the Brooklyn Museum, The Museum of Natural History, 911 Museum and the Aerospace Museum.

Our school became a part of the USDOE Magnet Program and has chosen Arts and Sciences as their themes. As such, our school has benefited from adequate funding of Arts programs, enabling our school to support residencies in the performing and visual arts. This  grant has ensured that all of our students benefit  experienced and professional teaching artists. Our in school residencies have provided opportunities for our students to have both in school residencies as well as field trips to a variety of cultural institutions throughout NYC. Our extended day arts program includes, dance, theater, visual arts and music. We look forward to having P.S.245 School of Arts and Sciences continue to grow and expand our arts programs.
Q47_1: The survey does not capture our after school arts programs including, puppetry, theater arts, dance and visual arts. There is no space any more to include the way that the classroom teachers are using these residencies to teach art in the classroom.

Q46_1:
The Paerdergat P.S. 251 School’s Arts programs are continuously making strides to not only meet, but exceed the expectations as set forth in the Blueprint for the Arts, The New York State Learning Standards for the Arts and through the integration of the Common Core Standards.
In order to meet these principles, we have identified the following areas of successes and further growth for our Arts Programs: 1. More Music, Theater and Dance concerts and performances. 2. Parent workshops specializing in continued Arts learning at home. 3. Develop student awareness of artistic options through the strategic use of technology and digital media. 4. Professional Development seminars for staff to support use of technology and the arts in student learning and engagement.
This school year we have worked to enhance our arts programs by incorporating and utilizing technology to enrich and assist creative learning and exploration.  Through collaboration of the technology and arts teachers, students are able to create digital portfolios via Google suites programs.  Our goals for creative technology use is to help increase family and community participation in the arts, cultivate rigorous and meaningful arts experiences while fostering college and career readiness.

We are in our ninth year of partnership with Studio. Our resident artist, through a generous grant, has been working with our ELLs and SWD on various art projects. We are considered a "STEAM" school. Student artwork has been displayed in such venues as: the Asia Society,the Brooklyn Historical Society, Museum of the City of New York, The American Embassy in Tokyo, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. We have also been awarded a Cultural After School Adventures Grant through our local councilman. Through this grant, permanent artwork will be displayed for all to enjoy. Our Art Exposition is our culminating event and takes place in the middle of June for students, staff, and parents. Students in our Chorus, Pre-K, and Kindergarten classes have performed several Holiday shows for our student body and parents alike. All classroom teachers have participated in the Nalini Kids program, which encourages nurturing the whole child, including physical, emotional, and character development. We also enjoy The Shubert theater grant through ArtsConnection. Six third grade students participated in Ballet Tech's beginners program.
We have had Miss USA visit our school and co-teach with several students. Our STEAM team has secured the NASA Education Downlink which promotes Education in Space. Our students will interact live with astronauts on June 21, 2018.

Q44_R3: Education In Dance & The Related Arts
Q46_1: Our Visual Arts program, based on the Blueprint for Visual Arts, includes experiences in all media, extended Art periods, museum trips, quality sketchbooks/journals, thoughtful written reflections, formative assessments and the use of an Art room SmartBoard that brings the art of the world right into our classroom. Students' work is displayed around the school and in the community, often winning awards. Two Visual Art teachers assure every student weekly visual arts experiences in an integrated, scaffolded program. Older students have double Art periods.Our Music program's Junior and Senior Chorus perform in two major concerts and District 22 events. All students seen by our Music specialist learn music notation/recognition, and Choral instruction. 4th and 5th grade 'pull-out' students belong to the Flute Club. Our new Dance Studio gives student dancers the chance to explore creative movement and learn dance notation. Ballet barres and mirrors enhance students' experience. Dance curriculum is based on the Laban Movement Analysis System. All Dance students discuss and write about dance as well as observe and critique each others work. Themes include animals, motif notation, patterns, and storytelling. Dance Club participants choreograph creative dances,while Dance students perform two major concerts during the year and at special events. Free tickets to the American Ballet Theater are given to dance students.

"Art does not solve problems, but makes us aware of their existence," sculptor Magdalena Abakanowicz has said. Arts education, on the other hand, does solve problems. Art is closely linked to almost everything that we as a nation say we want for our children and demand from our schools: academic achievement, social and emotional development, civic engagement, and equitable opportunity.

The P.S. 277 Arts program encompasses a range of all arts disciplines. Each child in the school prepares and participates in a Theater assembly program which includes instruction in Theater, Visual Arts, Dance and Music, culminating in a final performance. Pre-Kindergarten prepares and participates in several small performances which include the Lunar New Year and Mother's Day. In addition to the Theater Arts cluster teacher, the 2017-2018 school year saw the introduction of a Visual Arts cluster teacher, as well as a General Music and Band teacher through the VH1 Save the Music grant.  Several artist residencies and workshops in Dance, Theater and Visual arts are provided to our students through parent-funded cultural arts organizations.  These residencies and workshops are the result of a partnership with Marquis Studios through Parents Association funding and a partnership with the Brooklyn Arts Council through Council funds. These partnerships afford us the opportunity to provide additional Arts instruction for all of our students. Our goal is to continue to develop the quality of Arts instruction in all arts disciplines for all students.  It is our school's philosophy that Arts instruction should be integrated into Literacy, Math, Social Studies and Science for our students.

The Marine Park Junior High Band has enjoyed many years of excellence. Located in Marine Park Brooklyn, students begin their musical day at 7:00 A.M. and often finish late in the evening. Students are taught their instruments beginning in the 6th grade, and by 8th grade have had several opportunities to thrive as young musicians. Marine Park's Music program is comprised of: Beginning Band, Symphonic Band, two Jazz Ensembles (audition only), Marching Band, Mixed Chorus, and Treble Chorus. The Symphonic Band, Jazz Ensemble, Jazz Band and Chorus have earned Gold and Gold with Distinction ratings at NYSSMA Festivals for the last eighteen years. Our Drama students are involved with two major productions each year. Our productions include: "Brighton Beach Memoirs", "Lost in Yonkers", "The Miracle Worker", "Cinderella", "Bye Bye Birdie", "Little Shop of Horrors", "Guys and Dolls", "Fame Jr.", "To Kill A Mockingbird", "Outsiders", "Thoroughly Modern Millie", "The Giver", "The Little Mermaid, Jr", " A Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night", and "Hairspray Jr."  All students of Marine Park are given opportunity to experience the arts in project based enrichment classes.

It is the goal of P.S.312 to provide an Arts education program that enhances the appreciation of the arts, while integrating curriculum-based content areas and embedding the Common Core State Standards. We work towards meeting the Standards for the Arts by involving staff, parents, professional artists, arts organizations, cultural institutions and other community resources. We recognize the importance of the positive impact of the Arts on the healthy development of students, both intellectually and socially. Integration of arts education can effectively engage students in all areas of study, helping to raise student achievement, as well as develop students' creative abilities to foster aesthetic appreciation. In addition to our standard Arts program , we provide an intense weekly study in enrichment clusters for selected students in Chorus, Band,Dance,Theater and Visual Arts, all of which culminate in a project or performance for a targeted audience.

Public School 315 is widely recognized as a school where the successful integration of Arts education , academics and quality teaching are inspiring student achievement. P.S. 315 has built an exemplary curriculum that emphasizes both Arts integration and sequential skills-based instruction in Dance, Music, Visual Arts and Theater. Literacy, Social Studies, Computer Graphics and Science all have art components taught by classroom teachers and academic clusters. The arts specialists all integrate Literacy, Social Studies and Science disciplines into their curriculum. The efforts of the teachers are reinforced by partnerships with a team of pre-eminent cultural institutions. It is the school’s philosophy that through the emergence of the Arts, students will make valuable contributions to the community

P.S. 326 has a wonderful Arts program that exposes our students to all different kinds of art mediums, famous artists and their unique styles. We believe that learning through the arts helps prepare children for life. We strive to develop the childrens' imaginations, foster their skills and teach concepts important for self-expression. Students discover and explore elements of art and principles of design in art works and in their surroundings. Many concepts are tied to units of study. Students are given opportunities to examine works of art, learn about the artist and their particular style of creating these works. Students experiment with all kinds of mediums and materials and create beautiful works of art that are displayed throughout our school. Our program allows students to develop essential knowledge and skills they will use throughout their lives

Every student sixth through eighth grade is given the opportunity to take art classes during the 2017-2018 academic year. Every child receives 1-2 periods of Art instruction per week.
Students receive further Art instruction/Enrichment during our School Wide Enrichment Program. Those students interested in Art portfolios for Art High Schools are given the opportunity to continue their Art work in an Art Club given each day during their lunch time.

Midwood High School strives to offer students hands-on experiences to develop their talents in Art, Music, Media, and Theater. Students are offered both in-school and out of school experiences to broaden their knowledge of art and music. We offer Music Production, Graphic Arts and Media Arts( including Sound Recording and Editing classes) to our Media CTE students to make students aware of career possibilities in film, television, and entertainment. We have a television studio and students can enter their filmwork in citywide and national film festivals. We have two new Mac Labs for Graphic Arts. We place students in internships at museums and art galleries. We offer Band and Chorus classes and have earned Silver Medals for our Symphony and Choral groups, and a Gold Medal for our Wind Ensemble at the 2016 NYSSMA auditions. We have an annual SING that is student-created and run. The Spring production exposes students to live theater. All students have the possibility to create portfolios for colleges and are accepted into any Art or Music class during their free periods to work on their art or participate in an ensemble. Our SWD and ELL students participated in an in-school and afterschool Art workshop this year. Our advanced students painted a mural on the bridge over the Long Island Railroad,through Groundswell; our Councilman provided another grant to paint the other side of the bridge this year.

Once again we have collaborated with Roundabout Theater. Students in ELL, English and Special Education have a visiting artist working with them in their classrooms. Roundabout Theater worked with our students (costumes, sets, lighting and all parts of the performance) during SING. Our Music program has grown to include Strings and Orchestra. We have added more sections of Ceramics this year and created an Advanced Ceramics class.  We also created a Mural Painting class as well. We have also expanded our partnerships to include Reperorio Espanol and 92nd street Y

We offer painting, ceramics, studio art.  Exemplary projects are celebrated each year by being displayed at our annual art exhibit.  For music we offer chorus and jazz band.  Each year our students put on a fall and spring concert.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: The Visual Arts and Music programs at Origins High School develops a young artist's technical abilities and personal vision through the study of a variety of traditional and contemporary media. Creative problem solving, critical thinking and a broad range of experiences build the foundation for deeper understanding, advanced learning, and innovation within the various media. All students take Digital Literacy and Art Foundations during their freshman year. Students will learn how to use technology resources to aid them in organization, projects, formatting documents, and self expression. In Art foundations, students are exposed to a wide variety of techniques and skills which will be developed through a series of planned projects in 2-dimensional mediums such as Collage, Drawing, Painting, Graphic Design, Photography and Animation. Sophomores, juniors and seniors are able to choose from the following courses: Instrumental Music, Guitar, Drawing, Sculpture, Ceramics,both Darkroom and Digital Photography, Graphic Design, Animation and Mixed-Media Sculpture.

We are a transfer school that offers Music classes that teach performance, critiquing, composing, and analyzing music to students of varying musical aptitude and achievement levels. Further, we also offer Visual Art classes that are aligned to the NY State and NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students plan, revise, display and present their work using the formal language of the Visual Arts.

Our young artists enjoy rich Art History lessons through the "Master of the Month."  Each month we learn about a famous artist and explore different techniques.  Children engage in creative hands-on art activities which allow them the freedom to express themselves through painting, drawing, sculpture, and collage.  In addition, we purchased Artist in Residency programs from Puppetry in Practice for music, storytelling and theater using puppets.  
Classroom teachers were encourage to explore the arts through our interdisciplinary core curriculum program.
Q47_1: We are a Pre-Kindergarten program.  The arts are a vital form of expression for our culturally and linguistically diverse student population.  Music, movement and the visual arts are incorporated into our daily routines.

Q46_1:
For  school year 2017-2018 our students f received music education from our in house music cluster teacher. Each class went to music three periods/week for vocal music instruction. Basic  concepts of pitch and rhythm  were also taught. Two school wide concerts were performed by the entire student body.
Students also participated in a 10 week theater education course given by Arts Connection educators which resulted in a  dramatic performance of a children's picture book.
Q47_1: As a brand new school with less than 100 Pre K and Kindergarten students and a limited budget, we are just at the beginning stages of building a vibrant arts program. We are very interested in building our program through grants and fundraising efforts from our dedicated Parent Association.

Q46_1: MS 890 is a place where students' talents are nurtured. In its first year of operation, the school served grade 6, where all students received instruction in general music. In addition, students were able to select from several enrichment opportunities which also counted towards instructional time. These included student chorus, a class entitled "Ten Most Covered Songs in History", and a class entitled "Musical History" in which students analyzed popular Broadway musicals and the historical context when they took place. Through various arts residencies made possible by Arts Matters funding, all students also received exposure to cross-curricular arts instruction. Symphony Space conducted a 6 week residency in which students learned about traditional music from Africa, South and Central America and Asia, which overlapped with their units in Social Studies. Additionally, all students were exposed to traditional Chinese dance through a residency program with Brooklyn Center for Performing Arts. During the NIA After school program, students also have an array of arts opportunities to select from, including visual art, band, keyboard and musical theater.

In our current arts program, students learn about different 
artists and how the life of an artist affects his or her artwork.
Students very often create an original version of the work of a famous artist.( example- "Starry Night" by Vincent Van Gogh)
Students experiment with different kinds of media to create original artwork.a
  Oil pastels, markers,  colored pencils, tempera paints,
and water color paints are used.  Students have the opportunity to
engage in lessons with different art techniques.  The art techniques covered are: drawing, painting, collage, printmaking
covered are: drawing, painting, collage, and sculpture.
Art is used as a means to build the self esteem of students.  Students are praised for their artistic efforts.  The art is displayed for others to critique in a positive way.
  For the 2018-2019 school year, I plan to concentrate on more sketching lessons.  Students will need sketch pads and easels to carry out this plan.  Trips to art museums would enhance our program.

Our school community has continued to support the arts programs. We are providing the students with a culturally rich academic experience. We offer programs in the arts both during school hours and in after-school enrichment. Students are able to prepare for auditions and portfolio presentations for specialized high school admissions. Students are taught music, dance, and visual art as part of the school curriculum. Instrumental, choral music, dance and art are taught in morning, and after-school programs. Students may learn ballet, tap, Hip Hop, jazz, Step, African, Indian Folk Dancing, and creative movement as part of their class curriculum or as an enrichment program. Our music program consists of morning and afternoon small group instrumental lessons and pull-out multi-grade enrichment including: drum kit, woodwind, guitar, keyboard, brass and rock band ensemble. Our visual arts curriculum includes mask-making, watercolor painting, clay projects, paper-mache, and bookmaking. Our after-school program helps students explore stage decoration, portfolio preparation, and develops individual strengths and creativity. Our school has collaborative performances showcasing student achievement.We continually help our students explore new avenues of creativity through grants and special activities .

The Art program at PS/IS 155 helps to broaden the students understanding of various cultures, past and present. This is achieved through the study of Art History and the exploration and use of various techniques and materials, which helps students to become well-rounded individuals who are better equipped to tackle high school and be more prepared for college and career readiness

Q44_R1_C1: Opus Dance Theatre & Community Services, Inc.
Q46_1: Across all grades, our staff collaborates with students, parents and teachers to incorporate the arts into the general curriculum.  For example, in first-grade, the teachers work in partnership with parents, art teachers and other staff members to teach about the African culture.  They also help the students create a play-script around the African culture.  They learn African words or adages; they learn different African dances and hear African stories.   As a culminating activity, students present a play and dance performance for the community and parents to enjoy. Another example of the Arts program is displayed in second grade.  The second-grade students learn about several artists and their paintings. After learning about art history and the different genres, the students are encouraged to create their own paintings.  These paintings are exhibited as a culminating event, where parents and the community can come and participate.  Furthermore, the third graders learn about the Latin culture.  Upon learning about different dances and the cultural history of the dances, the students study the Flamenco dance.  They present a performance for the community displaying what they have learned about this culture.  Fourth and fifth grade participates in our Chess program and the College and Career readiness exercises. Often times our teachers work across grades to ensure that the students are being exposed to and experiencing multiple opportunities to learn about the arts.

Q39_4: Participating in Arts Related Learning Oportunities
Q46_1:
P.S. 165 is a Turnaround Arts School.  Through Turnaround Arts, our teachers have received training in Arts Integration Strategies such as Visual Thinking Skills and Snapshot. Our students have been a part of some exciting experiences such as dancing in the National Turnaround Arts video of "Love Train" with Paula Abdul and going to Washington, D.C. to perform in the Turnaround Arts Talent Show at the Kennedy Center. 

Through Lincoln Center Education, our 165 Family has been exposed to 5 star performances as well as workshops that enhance  LCE's Capacities for Learning.

Making Connections through the Arts grows more and more each year in our school.

Next year, we are looking forward to working with Groundswell and Arts Connection as we increase Arts partnerships within our 165 family.#165isOnTheRise#
Q47_1: Our school is located in Brownsville, Brooklyn which is reported to be one of the poorest neighborhoods in NYC.  Our students lack in exposure to the Arts and in general.  Over time, our school has increased Arts programing and Arts related trips which have had a positive influence on our students.  Slowly but surely, our students are more willing to participate in public speaking and performing as well as becoming more confident in their creations.

Q46_1: PS\IS 184 places a heavy emphasis on the arts as we share a Visual Arts Teacher with a neighboring district school due to funding provided via the ARTS Matter Initiative. We have also been a Broadway Jr participant for the last 3 school years which has bolstered our students exposure to stage performances,collaboration within the school community leading to full fledged productions all of which have been well received by all stakeholders. Via an anti-violence grant we are also able to develop a marching band  dance and step teams who travel throughout the borough performing at various special events. Dance instruction and the marching band experience extends in to the extended day program for our middle school students. Similarly,through the CASA grant our elementary school students are also provided with visual arts, drumming and dance instruction during the extended day. Through these grants and initiatives  as our students transition from one grade to the next by grade 6 they would have been exposed to a wide array of arts specific instruction adding to their academic record of receiving a well rounded education.

Q32_6: Visual Thinking Strategies, Focus Five Theater
Q46_1: PS/IS 284 Arts Programming continued to thrive during the 2017-2018 school year as a designated community school and as a 3rd year Turnaround Arts Grant school. In addition to in school Visual Arts instruction for grades PreK - 2, our  in school Theater instruction expanded to include for grades 3 - 8.  We continued with established arts residencies with: Mark Morris Dance, BRIC,  Arts Connection, and The Brooklyn Jazz Consortium.
