After school arts enrichment and instruction was provided by Brooklyn Community Services in Dance and Visual Arts experiences for our Kindergarten - 5th grader. This year we successfully produced our second Disney, Jr. musical "Aladdin" and sent dancers to the Turnaround Arts annual performance at The John F. Kennedy Center in Washington DC.

PS/IS 323 has a team of actively engaged and dedicated staff members, whose goal it is to provide an appropriate and authentic learning environment for each student in all subjects. Exposing our students to the Arts is a priority at PS/IS 323. Our students experience Musical Theater, Dance and Visual Arts. We strive to meet each childs' individual needs in a challenging and encouraging environment, developing their full potential and personal expressions.

Q44_R1_C1: Opus Dance Theatre & Community Services, Inc.
Q46_1: Arts education continues to be a part of the everyday experience of students at I.S. 392. Our students are provided a well-rounded education that includes a balance of academics and arts both during the day and afterschool. We continue to provide the same emphasis on Arts as we did last year through our residencies for Ceramics and Poetry Writing with resident artists. This year, we provided theater classes twice a week to all 7th graders. Additionally, our 7th graders are working with a theater consultant to hone their skills, this will culminate in a trip to see a Broadway show.  Likewise, as part of a theater partnership, our students have seen well over 10 theater productions on Broadway this year.  Our Visual Arts teacher provided ceramics classes to 6th graders which integrates the Social Studies curriculum on Ancient Civilizations. Students at I.S. 392 this year had the opportunity to audition for a role in our Broadway Jr. production of "Lion King". This is the third year with this program, and our students and staff have been working hard to create a production that will be attended by other various schools, as well as our superintendent and elected officials. Broadway Jr. has allowed our students to sharpen their skills in vocal music and dance over the past three years.  In addition, art students have worked diligently to create the sets for the theatrical productions.  To incorporate art forms of diverse cultural groups, we have added steel pan, stilt walking and costume design in our art offerings.

Our current Arts program consists of full time Dance and Visual Arts programs and a part time Music program. All children have Dance, Visual Arts and/or Music 1-2 times per week. All units are aligned with the NYC Blueprint. Teachers collaborate on 3 school- wide performances per year. Partnerships with organizations such as Mark Morris provided supplemental instruction for Dance and Visual Arts this year.

Our Arts program includes Visual Arts focused on drawing techniques and a visual media arts/design. Students can join our Dance and Visual Arts Clubs after school through Counseling In Schools. We also have an in resident Arts counselor. Students present their work via bi -annual events with an art display and Dance/Talent Show. We have Drumline classes with monthly performances inside and outside the school.

FDA VII offered Drama this year and introduced Spoken Word and Scriptwriting. Students wrote and performed "alternative" productions of plays in class and performed one major play for the community-at-large. Additionally, the culminating Drama program is a SING a competition among grade levels which incorporate Scriptwriting, Digital Media and Drama. The theme for our SING competition is "Movies."

KAPPA V recognizes that each child is an individual, that all children are creative and all children have he ability to succeed.  Success can come in the form of academics, or through artistic talents. Because of this we strive to expose our students to various arts discipline.  When the arts is incorporated into every discipline, students demonstrate a better understanding of the curriculum.  Because we believe this, our students are exposed to visual arts, photography, various forms of dance, musical theatre and this year we are investing and building our musical repertoire to include steel pan. We know that all students are not going to excel academically, so our goal is to tap into the hidden talents of our students while creating the best version of them as middle school  scholars.

Q44_R3: National Museum of the American Indian
Q46_1: It is our belief that an Arts program is an absolute necessity for providing students with room for self-expression, creativity and intellectual sagacity. DANCE: students on all grades receive dance instruction on a regular scheduled basis. THEATER: In partnership with Broadway Jr, students have learned acting and staging practices, have successfully brought their third play to our stage. TECHNOLOGY: Our Arts program was implemented to integrate technology (with the use of digital cameras, lighting equipment, and other accessories), to enhance output and to give students an experience in Video Production. SPORTS and ARTS: Students work with the Sports and Arts and Beacon programs to be further exposed to other aspects of the arts: Music, African Drumming, Step Dancing, Graphic Design, Fashion Design and Modeling, and Chess. TRIPS: Students attend art-focused trips to the theatre, art exhibits, and concerts to expose them to a wide variety of artistic options and expression, thereby gaining relevant information and finding their niche in the art world.

Arts partnerships with cultural institutions are the primary form of arts services offered at Brooklyn Landmark Elementary School. We work with Studio in a School to provide visual arts classes to all scholars, as well as Third Street to provide music classes to scholars, all during the school day. We also provided the opportunity for scholars to participate in Ballet Tech during the school day during the winter months. Five scholars were selected each year for the past two years. 

We offer a variety of after school arts programming, through grant funding. This year we offered after school dance to K-1 and violin to 2-3 with our partners at Third Street, and martial arts for K-3 with our partners at CARE LLC. We also offered scholarships to 5 scholars in 3-4 grades to participate in dance at Dwana Smallwood Performing Arts Studio. We hope to continue and expand after school offerings over the coming years. 

Additionally, Brooklyn Landmark hosts special events that  teaching staff and student leaders facilitate, such as the Fashion & Talent Show, the Lip Sync Battle, and performances by the step team. Scholars also perform at honor society, graduation, "Character Day" and other special events.
Brooklyn Democracy Academy provides students the opportunity to participate in Fashion Design, Art, and Visual Art classes throughout the school year.

This year, our school continued  implementation of the music program (D.R.E.A.M. Factory) funded through the Department of Youth Development and Community Development, which provided our students opportunities to use their talents in the Music and Hip Hop industry. This opened opportunities for our students to make an album of songs geared to various topics such as gun violence, sexual awareness, right decisions, etc. In addition, we have a teaching artist in Dance that work with our students on various dance techniques such as contemporary, hip-hop, modern, etc. This was valuable to our students because it increased the number of students performing in talent shows and events inside and outside of the school building. More importantly, an allocated grant through the DOE for a part-time art teacher to support students who needed art credits to graduate with their high school diploma.

Students engage in a visual arts program aligned with the NYCDOE Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts.  Students research a variety of social justice issues and select a social issue of importance. Students analyze artists who create works of art based on social issues. Students gain ideas based on specific artists and create their own works related to their chosen social justice issue. Students write reflections and engage in self and peer assessments, and engage in student led discussions to increase their academic vocabulary and gain a deeper understanding of the content.

BEES is a small middle school. As such, we use a variety of means to incorporate the Arts into our programming. We have a Visual Arts teacher and all students take her class weekly. This year we partnered with ArtsConnection for 3 separate in-school artist residencies. We hosted ArtsConnection teaching artists in Dance, Visual Arts and Filmaking. All students participated in the residencies. In addition, BEES has committed to have live student performances each month. This year we partnered with Creative Connections for an in school percussion residency. Additionally, we are a New Victory Theater Education partner school. This means BEES students attend a performance once per month at New Victory on 42nd Street.

We offer Dance or Visual Arts to all middle school students.  At the high school level,  Grades 9 -12 students receive partial credit as art or dance are paired with physical education each year.   We offer Spoken Word workshops as a unit within English Language Arts and a Spoken Word Dance Elective.  We are also trying to continue and/or encourage community Arts partnerships.
Q47_1: Many students choose our school because we have a strong focus on art at our school.

Q46_1: The Fine and Performing Arts Department vision is for students to be open-minded, to think critically, and to explore in an environment that fosters a community of learners, with a focus on problem-solving skills, collaborative thinking and developing a lifelong appreciation of the Arts. Our vision connects to the broader scope of the goal of our school community: to talk like scholars, write like experts, think like innovators and live like leaders. Our school offers Arts education in all of the four arts areas: Dance, Drama, Music, and Visual Arts. In addition, we house a Technology course that routinely integrates film/documentary/trailer work. The diverse Fine and Performing Arts Department at our large middle school (over 1775 students!) allows all of our students the ability to experience the arts. Since 2014, we have sought to provide a depth of study in a different art form each year for a majority of our classes, while all of our honors classes have the opportunity to explore a three year sequence for an in-depth approach in one art area. In addition, we are thrilled to have partnered with MTI/Schubert Broadway Jr. School to produce two school musicals: "Fame Jr" and "Hairspray" Moving forward into the 2018-2019 school year, the Fine and Performing Arts Department will be engaging in studies of student assessment, aligning best practices and further defining our collective instructional approach as both a cohesive team with an emphasis on the standards and Blueprint to instill an inspiring love of the arts for all!
Q47_1: IS 5 has a full FPA (Fine and Performing Arts) department that consists of one dance teacher, one drama teacher, two music teachers, three visual arts teachers and one certified educational technology teacher who integrates film/documentary/trailer work in her arc of learning across the school year. All full tine FPA teachers are certified in the arts. We continue to work on systems and structures to integrate further student choice in the art they explore in a given school year. In the 2018-2019 school year, we look forward to embedding culturally relevant and significant arts opportunities for our students.

Q46_1: At P.S. 7Q, it is our goal to provide our students with an enriching, comprehensive Arts education. Our certified Visual Arts teacher and certified music teachers meet with many students on a weekly basis and use the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts as a framework for the development of lessons. Music & the Brain is used to teach music literacy and knowledge of general music concepts. We have again increased family involvement in the arts by inviting families to participate in arts-related experiences with their children such as Visual Arts contests, parades, Art Festivals, mask-making, concerts, and written communication regarding community- based Arts opportunities. The hallways of P.S. 7Q are decorated with authentic, standard-based beautiful artwork created by the students. We strive to involve our students in all Arts disciplines and believe that the Arts are an essential component of a comprehensive education.

At P.S. 12Q, we believe that our role as a school should go beyond teaching the core subjects and that we must emphasize the importance of the arts in the development of every student. Arts education and engagement are embedded into our school’s curriculum throughout every grade and content area. All teachers are encouraged to expand their students’ imaginations by experiencing the excitement of class trips. Our school’s art teacher enhances our social studies and science curriculum by offering our students the opportunity to view the world from different perspectives. Students across fourth and fifth grades participate in our school’s band and our fifth graders learn the importance of working together as a team while singing in our school’s chorus. All of our third graders learn how to play the recorder. At P.S. 12Q, we are committed to celebrating our diverse student population through the arts.

The arts program at PS 13Q is vibrant and includes dance, theater, visual art, and music.  Students are engaged throughout the year in various classes.  For example, our Kindergarten-Grade 2 students were involved with a puppetry and theater residency with the ARTS Connection cultural organization throughout the year and our 4th and 5th grade students were involved with a DELLTA Arts theater residency designed to increase oral language development for English Language Learners.  These residencies included studying video artifacts in practitioner groups and included a mix of planning and video documentation meetings as well as time to prepare and share the puppetry literacy strategies. Our 4th grade students were involved with the American Ballet Theater in the Nutcracker Project and were taught dance by the teaching artist as well as attended the performance of The Nutcracker at Lincoln Center.  Our fifth grade students were involved with the TADA! Theater Alliance and learned various techniques in musical theater as well as performed in front of their parents and peers.  Our school regularly hosts Art Exhibits showcasing the variety of artwork our students create throughout the year and our theater teacher directs the students in plays and skits throughout the year. PS13Q students performed The Wizard of Oz this year. We also partnered with Inside Broadway and professional Broadway performers came to our school to perform on stage in our auditorium.  Our 4th and 5th grade students were able to see the performance.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Public School 14 The Fairview School has an amazing music program, bolstering large junior and senior bands, junior and senior violin orchestras, guitar lessons for classes of students, and 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade chorus. Grand musical performances are held at the school in the fall and the spring. Our chorus performs annually at the Corona Tree Lighting Ceremony, at Queens Museum art openings, and at our leadership events. In April 2018, our students performed at Carnegie Hall!  Second graders show their work at Queens Museum, as do the CASA students in grades three, four and five. Additionally, all 1,782 students show at least one piece of visual art at our May Leadership Event when our school is transformed into an art gallery. We started our theater program three years ago, and our students were being celebrated at the Queens Borough Arts Fair for two years and counting. Our purpose for bringing in theater classes was to support all students, with a focus on Special Education and ELL students, in engaging in purposeful conversational English. The program has grown far beyond our expectations as our very talented theater teachers are bringing out the best in our very talented students. In the fall of 2017, we brought in a Flamenco residency to begin to build out the fourth pillar of our arts program.  Look forward to beautiful work from our students in 2018-19!

Public School 16, Queens, strives to align its curriculum with the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, implement school-wide enrichment and accelerate learning for each student in music, visual arts, dance and theater. Our school strives to enrich the curriculum through morning arts programs, day school arts programming, monthly field trips, residencies and implementation of enrichment clusters in the arts during the day and in an after-school rotating program. Our school hopes to sustain partnerships with cultural organizations in the arts including the Artworks, Carnegie Hall, Julliard School, Dancing Classrooms, Queens Botanical Garden, Martha Graham Dance Ensemble and Carlota Santana Dance Company. Our school will continue to seek and forge new alliances to further enhance arts programming.

PS 19Q is committed to providing students with quality arts instruction by expanding partnerships with cultural arts organizations to enhance our curriculum during and after the school day. Thanks to these partnerships, our students receive direct instruction from teaching artists in visual Arts, theatre, music and dance. Additionally, teachers receive professional development to support the alignment of arts instruction and literacy. In addition, to our certified Visual Arts and Music teachers, we have partnerships with the ArtsConnection, the New York Historical Society, the New York Philharmonic, and the TownHall Foundation. Our students enjoy a variety of arts-related field trips, taking advantage of NYC's rich cultural institutions, such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the MoMa. This year we again provided dance residencies in Hip-Hop dance and Ballet to our first and second graders. 
PS 19Q maximizes resources to bring in quality arts programming in-school and after-school. Our after-school programs include: a Flamenco dance residency with Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana, Purfek Academy's Music Engineering program, and the Afro-Latin Jazz Alliance's instrumental music program.

P.S. 28 provides students from diverse backgrounds and abilities with a comprehensive arts program. Our goal is to expose students to theatre, dance, music and visual arts to support the development of their artistic and creative minds. Music comes alive with students singing and performing in spring concerts. Classroom teachers provide opportunities for students to participate in dance in their classrooms. Puppetry in Practice provides students with an art/theatre experience. Pre-kindergarten and Kindergarten students create puppets that come alive to tell a story. First grade students learn how to turn an ordinary marble notebook into an animated journal. Second grade students participate in a stop motion animation residency to explore science or social studies themes. First Grade students participate in a residency with an artist from the Queens Museum to explore the Tiffany exhibit, showing students a connection between the past and present. In addition to a full visual arts program, which includes an annual art show, our students work has been showcased at the Metropolitan Museum  of Art, Queens Museum and Queens Borough Arts Festival. Classroom teachers provide students many opportunities to use their imagination and creativity to explore the arts in all subject areas.

In the 2017-18 school year, PS/IS 49 has continued its strong focus on the arts.  We have added an elementary school drama teacher and continue to offer music and visual art at the elementary level. Our middle school students are offered drama, music, and visual art. We also have an after school drama club for 6th - 8th grade students.  The Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey will perform for our middle school students.  We also worked with the Arthur Miller Fellowship program which provided support for our drama teacher and provided middle school students with the opportunity to create their own stories with an organization called The Story Pirates.  We held our annual spring music and arts festival which exhibited our students' talents as well as our annual holiday concert.  We also received a CASA grant through City Council's office which allowed students the opportunity to work with artists from Studio in a School after school.  After school programs were offered to ENL students as well as 7th and 8th grade students to work on their portfolios for high school.

Public School 58Q strives to provide all students with the chance to participate in visual arts, music, theater, and dance programs in compliance with the 186 plus hours of arts instruction required per year for grades one through three and over 93 hours required for grades four through six. Students in grade pre-K through six received music and visual arts instruction on a weekly basis from both full-time school-based arts teachers and their classroom teachers, who further enhanced their classes’ arts curriculum through dance and drama lessons. Students presented their culminating projects in visual arts, music, dance, and drama for their parents in our Museum of Student Arts showcase in June and on bulletin boards throughout the year. Our auditorium was the site of 10 concerts that highlighted our music students' work, along with music and visual arts-themed assemblies promoting principles of student empowerment as outlined in Stephen Covey’s “The Leader In Me” program. Public School 58 follows the Music and the Brain program, which incorporates music history and keyboard use as a tool for reading music. For Public School 58's foreign language program in Italian, students celebrated Italy’s heritage by singing traditional songs, creating colorful Carnevale crowns, and attending plays based on Italian culture. Students in grades 3 and 6 also explored Italy’s culinary arts by attending pizza-making workshops.

Q32_6: State Education Department, Albany writing Theater Standards
Q46_1: Leonardo Da Vinci, IS61, has offered a complete performing and fine arts program, which includes Theater, Music (Band and Strings), Visual Art, Film, and Dance for the past eight years. Students rank their top three choices for in-school arts options and are matched to a desired arts group. Our sixth, seventh and eighth grade programs in the arts are a full-year sequenced class that allows our students to grow in their chosen arts discipline. In addition to having semester performances that showcase content skills, as expressed in the Blueprint for the Arts, we also incorporate performances that revolve around culture and school spirit. Our arts curriculum is aligned with the Common Core Standards and explores the arts through English language arts, math, social studies, and science. In the last three years, we have partnered with several arts organizations to provide our students a connection to artists, performances, and art work throughout the scholastic year. We also offer our students multiple performance opportunities outside of the classroom through school musicals, dance teams, music, film, and art clubs.
Q47_1:
Our school has a 2,300 student body.  Our goal has been to provide arts education to all our students.  We manage to reach our goal by having 7 arts teachers on our staff and students receiving Arts education twice a week.
We are working on having students have a three year comprehensive sequential program in the art of their choice.

Q39_4: The PTA has funded additional arts classes in Breakdancing and Computer Animation.
Q46_1: At PS 68 we strive to educate the whole child.  Our goal is to equip our students with the ability to express themselves through art, to enhance their lives by the arts and to gain a valuable appreciation of the arts, as a vital component of their learning. We continue to maintain an enthusiastic music and theater performance tradition which is showcased in our weekly assembly programs. We have an annual dance festival each year.  The MUSIC and THE BRAIN program is taught to all Kindergarten, First and Second graders through piano keyboard classes.  "Early-Bird Chorus" is offered for Fourth and Fifth graders. The Chorus collaborates with our local Intermediate School in a yearly Winter Concert. Continuing partnerships are maintained with Studio in a School and Arts Connection which culminate in a musical theater production as well as a school-wide arts exhibit and celebration. Enrichment classes are offered in all grades with students choosing classes such as Music Appreciation, drama, painting, dance and story theater.  Our PTA has funded special programs, this year, in Computer Animation and Break dancing. As well as 5 sessions from a Studio in  a School Resident for our 5th graders.  This year we partnered with Greater Ridgewood Youth Organization who sponsored a Paint Night Event which included parents and students.

Q32_6: Midori, Little Kids Rock & Music and the Brain

Q46_1: At Intermediate School 73 we agree that the arts are extremely important in our students' growth. Our goals are to not only give our students what is required by New York State but also to give them what they need to succeed in our ever-changing society. Our belief is that arts education enhances the intellectual and emotional lives of children by stimulating their imagination, improving communication skills, including analysis and critical thinking and strengthening visual literacy. It promotes emotional intelligence and builds character; encouraging multicultural awareness and acceptance. It instills self-discipline, inspires respect for craftsmanship and gives families an opportunity to share, explore, and celebrate ideas and feelings that children may not be able to put into words. In 2016, our teachers began implementing our Arts Elements Curriculum allowing sixth grade students to circulate through each of the available arts disciplines including visual arts, music, dance and drama. Students received instruction in each course for one semester. We placed seventh and eighth grade students in a class aligned to their area of interest as determined by the Student Arts Survey, enabling them to continue to pursue their area of interest for seventh and eighth grade arts instruction. We believe that our interest-based arts program will inspire students and allow them to creatively express their ideas, leading to increased student performance and achievement.

Q44_R3: National Museum of the American Indian
Q46_1: At Intermediate/Middle School 77, we value arts education.  Our students participate in multiple trips to arts high schools and arts exhibits. We enter art contests and win.  Our Band director, in collaboration with the teaching artist, recruits neighboring elementary school students by going on tour with the after-school band.  Through our partnership with Arts Horizons we offer monthly assemblies for all students. Multiple residencies with Arts Horizons, Arts Connection and LeAp supplement our art program and through a grant, students have been offered various arts enrichment programs of their choice. The students involved in these programs have displayed their artwork and various other projects in a culminating gallery exhibition and performance. Our chorus gets invited to perform with St. Francis Prep at the Hallelujah concert every year.  Parents are always invited and welcomed to support and participate at these events.

Our goal is to continue to provide students with an extensive exposure to as many arts experiences as possible. Besides our visual arts and dance programs currently in our school, we have continued our daily and monthly arts celebrations. Our daily Village News musical announcements continue to be a huge hit with our students. The children choose a meaningful song and have Words of Wisdom for it, lead the announcements of the morning. We start each day with a song, smile and reminder to, "treat people the way we want to be treated". We continue to add several school wide celebrations - We had a school wide harvest celebration incorporating a lip sync performance - We celebrated the music of Motown for part of our Black History Month Curriculum.  We created displays and had a school wide celebration for Lunar New Year, including a parade with a student made giant dragon leading the way.  Cultural celebration, dance performances and a school-wide art exhibit filled the gym again this year - Lastly, we also expanded on our parent engagement and had a paint night for parents and students - it was a huge hit and we plan to have more next year.

Our partnership with Learning Through Art, an artist-residency program, cultivates students' 21st Century learning skills: creativity, innovation, critical thinking, problem solving, collaboration and communication. Lessons are designing with a focus on sustained, process-oriented art projects that support learning across the curriculum. Through the program, experienced teaching-artists collaborate with our classroom teachers to develop and facilitate art projects integrated with the school curriculum. During the twenty week in-school residencies, participating students examine, discuss, and create works of art. Students participate in three visits to the Guggenheim Museum throughout the course of the residency. Through these visits students are immersed in an environment rich with the works of master artists, where they engage in art inquiry, develop new insights into art and think critically about art and ideas. Public School 88 was also awarded a Disney Grant allowing us to partner with Disney artists in working towards putting on a spring production of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". Students will perform the production in the school for students and family members. Additionally, council member Crowley awarded our school a CASA grant for our 1st and 2nd grade students.
Q47_1: Public School 88 had hired a certified art teacher who was developing our students' appreciation of the arts through various experiences.  However, due to budget cuts in October, we had to excess this teacher and cut the program.

Q46_1: Public School 89's art program strives to enrich our students through the arts. Our goal is to help children learn to express themselves in varied ways, which may include creating art, talking about art, sharing their unique abilities and potentially develop a lifelong awareness and participation in the arts. Through sensitive adult guidance, children are aided in mastering pivotal moves in the artistic process, the creation of ideas for personal expression, the discovery of visual qualities to express ideas and feelings, and the use of media to convey an expressive intent. A strong sense of pride is created in our students through our continued concentration on the cultural diversity of our student population. Through the varied art mediums, students are taught about different cultures by learning native songs and dances as well as art history.

Our goals for the coming school year are to continue to integrate the arts curriculum into our common core curriculum.  We have added a new cultural arts organization, Dancing Classrooms, to our repertoire.  Our fifth grade students had an amazing time learning different styles of dance.  We feel that their lives have definitely been enriched through this experience.  We would like to continue our relationship with Arts Connection for the upcoming school year as well.  We will be reapplying for grants in music and theater. We will continue to encourage teachers to take field trips to the various cultural institutions that New York City has to offer.  This will continue to enrich our curriculum and instructional programs.

At IntermediateSchool 93 we offer a twice-a-week, full year talent program. We offer sixth, seventh, and eighth grade students the opportunity to take a three year sequence in Visual Art, Drama, and Music. Students may choose different classes each year including the aforementioned courses as well as LEGO Robotics and STEM. This year students have had the opportunity to work with Midori and Friends who offer volin lessons through a 4 year grant with this organization. In addition, students were also offered a residency program through Dellta Arts in Dance. Our school and teachers facilitate arts related activities in most disciplines. Each year our clubs and classes perform several theatrical productions, many concerts as well as an annual art exhibit. The school provides opportunities for students and families to engage in trips, after-school and weekend activities, such as visiting some of the museums our great city has to offer. We look forward to continuously making our art program bigger and stronger as we have proven to do so in recent years.

Our goal as a school is to continue to have certified arts teachers servicing all of our students in the arts, while aligning curriculum to the Blueprint for the Arts, the New York State Standards, and the Common Core Curriculum. We hope to provide an arts program that will enrich and enhance learning across the disciplines. We will continue to devote designated rooms for our arts teachers. In the past five years we have also implemented an after school theater program and our school has put on a large scale musical theater production every year. For the past three years we have had a school wide Art Expo where we showcased artwork from third through eighth grade.  We continue to put on a Winter Concert showcasing the talents of our talented chorus and band, as well as a "Battle of the Bands" run by our middle school music teacher in an after-school program. In addition this year we will be adding a talent show for grade five through eight. Students' work have been entered in multiple contests and successfully exhibited. Some of these competitions include the Queens Borough Art Fair, P.S. Art, the UFT Raw Materials. We continue implementation STEAM in K-2, and our science teachers incorporated art into their curriculum. We added a dance teacher and theater teacher, who are classroom teachers, to work part-time with younger grades.  This year we brought the Ping Chong + Company to the building and had incredibly successful results with the students who found their inner voice and shared their personal stories with their peers

At Public School 110Q we value the arts. In our sixth year, a full time music teacher continues to work with our children. Throughout the year the teacher has been using the Orff Schulwerk approach to teaching music through imitation, experimentation, and personal expression. Children receive music instruction up to two times per week; they put on two concerts during the school year. To complement our music program, the CASA program has provided after-school music programs in the spring for students in the first grade. We are also working to incorporate art into the curriculum via our STEM classes, which are currently offered to 2nd - 5th graders.  This year 5th graders also learned about ballroom dancing. They put on two concerts for their families to demonstrate what they learned.

PS/IS 113Q has a full time certified arts teacher that services grade 6 and 7.  In addition to our certified art teacher, general education teachers are encouraged to incorporate visual arts into their everyday lessons.  Our music program provides students in elementary and middle school with instruction in literacy through music.  The music program also includes thematic based concerts for all elementary levels and preparation for graduations and special ceremonies.  Grades 3-8 are also invited to participate in Glee Club and members perform at key events throughout the year.  PS/IS 113 also has a contacted certified dance teacher that works with all of our classes in grades K-5.  The culminating performance each year for this program is the dance festival.  The dance festival spans over three days in early spring and allows students to showcase their theme based dances in front of family and friends.  The CASA program provides our school with a drama and performing arts experience. This program exposes children to the theater arts and gives them an opportunity to dance, sing, role play and create the physical backdrop for the performance.

Public School/Intermediate School 119 offers a variety of performing arts to our students. We presently have a number of orchestras, multiple level bands, guitar ensemble, Music and the Brain for our elementary students, chorus, chamber winds, and visual arts for the majority of our students. The arts program is designed to connect with the other content areas and to meet National Standards for the Arts and implement the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Parents and the community enjoy our vast amounts of shows and performances throughout the year.

Intermediate School 125Q offers an enriched and comprehensive unified arts curriculum to all of its students. We have dedicated classrooms and studios for dance, orchestra, band, visual arts, chorus and theater. All seven unified arts teachers are licensed and teach full time programs in their subject area. Teachers attend professional development sessions in the building as well as those offered by the DOE. All unified arts teachers collaborate on a weekly basis and hold arts workshops together with the students each term. Students are given the opportunity to select specific classes in the arts and are able to continue that course work from grade 6-8. Students may switch course work with the approval of their teacher, parents and department supervisor. Students in the arts maintain learning goals that are created and maintained through individual conferencing between teacher and student. All students taking dance, chorus, theater, band and orchestra are given the opportunity to perform in front of the school community on three separate evenings. These performances take place in December and May. Students may audition for the annual school musical which is performed in May.

The arts program is aligned with the New York State literacy standards as well as the Blueprint for Teaching & Learning in New York State. Students work with a wide range of strategies to create traditional and contemporary works of art in a creative setting. Projects are completed in units, where students build upon prior learned skills in art, music, and theater.

Public School 143Q is dedicated to immersing each and every child in the arts. Our certified visual arts, music and dance teachers, along with our drama teacher, meet weekly with many students and use the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts as a framework for the development of lessons. Our arts clubs, including Glee Club, Dance Club, Music Club, and Drama Club encourage our students to explore and share their talents. Our strong partnerships with arts organizations support our vision for the arts. The community gathers to see student performances, which include venues at our own school and at Carnegie Hall. We are continuing to grow our arts program and are committed to supporting our students by providing them with an enriching, comprehensive arts education

Developing awareness and appreciation of the arts for all students continues to be a fundamental goal of our school. Each year, students in many grades participate in an arts residency through various outside agencies. It is our goal to increase the number of students receiving arts instruction, either in classrooms or with an arts cluster teacher. Recognizing that every child has interests and talents, we have instituted a dance classroom for our sixth grade students as well as other classes. Our fifth grade ballroom dance program continues to be a favorite with our teachers and students. In addition, we have partnered with an outside organization to provide subsidized music lessons for students in fourth through sixth grades. We will continue to seek support from outside organizations to enhance our arts programs. Through Arts Connection we have been able provide varied arts instruction for our students, including an after school creative movement class.

For the 2017-2018 school year, Public School 199Q has had arts partnerships with The New York City Ballet, Creative Music Programs, and New York City Children's Theatre (Making Books Sing, Inc.). Our partnership with The New York City Ballet provided a dance residency for twenty-five first through fifth grade classes. Creative Music Programs provided arts residencies for eight classes, focusing on music. This school year we continued our partnership with New York City Children's Theater (Making Books Sing) for eight first through fifth grade classes which culminated in a class-share performance. Classes were able to participate in theatrical performances provided by New York City Children's Theater (Making Books Sing, Inc.)and performances by NYC Ballet. Funding supports direct services to students, planning and/or professional development for school staff, materials and supplies, curriculum resources, arts and cultural services, performances, admissions to performances, etc. Our goal is to continue these arts partnerships for the 2018-2019I school year.

At Public School 229, we value arts in education. Throughout the school day, children are immersed in a plethora of education in all of the arts disciplines. We currently have two visual arts teachers and two music teachers. In addition, our regular classroom teachers implement the arts in education throughout the day. Teachers in our building are constantly embarking on innovative projects in the arts such as reader's theater, songs and dances, visual arts projects, and field trips to museums, films, and shows. Outside organizations play an important role in educating our children in the arts as well. We participate in Dancing Classrooms Ballroom Dance, Midori Instrumental Music, Arts Connection BRIDGES Puppetry program, and Ballet Tech. Through these programs we are able to provide the students with valuable arts experiences. All children at Public School. 229 leave our school with a solid foundation in the arts.

We serve newcomer immigrant students with a huge range of languages. Our school engages students in project based learning and mastery-based grading to assess student learning. The International High School for Health Sciences visual arts program offers visual arts courses for 9th and 10th grade students in a variety of media, including painting, drawing, origami, collaborative art making, photography, printmaking and illustration. Eleventh grade students are enrolled in a theatre/drama class. Our program focuses on incorporating visual art making skills and literacy skills to allow students to answer essential questions that develop higher order thinking skills and literacy skills. This year, ninth and tenth grade students engaged in a variety of units focused on community issues, producing a mural of text on image self-portrait and a quilt. The eleventh grade team continued their work with a visiting teaching artist who helped to use a drama curriculum to introduce theatrical concepts, allowing students to write and perform scenes, and role play practical post high school circumstances, such as interviewing skills. The 12th grade brought in a teaching artist to develop a unit on Macbeth to incorporate performances of scenes from the play.

Public School 239 has a comprehensive visual arts and music program. Our music teacher works with a variety of grades, as well as a 4th and 5th grade chorus. Our school chorus participated in a cross-school choral performance in December and have performed for parents and students during and after school. Our visual arts teacher also works across grades and displays student work around the school for all to enjoy. Our technology teacher works with our students on the development of graphic arts skills, photography, and coding in the pilot of a Lego robotics program. Both 4th and 5th grade students participate in theater and art clubs. Our theater club will be performing an end of year show to be shared with the student and parent communities. Our school community continues to perform monthly assemblies to further develop theater skills. Students worked on set development, music and dance performance, as well as writing. Third grade students attended Ballet Tech. Our arts team has created and compiled lessons based on the benchmarks found in the NYC Blueprints for the Arts. Classroom teachers use the lessons to provide our students with readers theater and dance experiences from around the world. Music and Dance are incorporated into our SuperYou character curriculum with culminating performances in June. All of our students have an opportunity to experience and enjoy the arts.

Our arts program strives to challenge students to think critically and creatively in the visual arts. Students are knowledgeable about a variety of art materials as they investigate the relationship between the visual arts and social, political, historical and personal issues. Students keep a portfolio of their work culminating in a year end self-reflection. Students partake in independent field trips to museums and galleries to support classroom learning. Yearbook class has been added as an elective. The goals of the yearbook class is to involve the students to develop and organize a publication that encompasses the representation and accumulation of their experiences throughout their school years. The skills they will acquire include Layout and Design, Photography and Typography as well as to meet deadlines. The students earn an Art Elective credit towards their transcript accumulation.
Q47_1: We are a Business High School with CTE certification.

Q46_1: At High School of Applied Communication all students are encouraged to explore their artistic interests and abilities. Our arts program creates opportunities for students to learn the social, cultural, technological, and historical significance of visual media. Students develop and strengthen their artistic techniques and critical thinking skills to make the arts reverent, both, as a future career and personal enrichment. In studio arts we offer rigorous units in illustration, sculpture, engineering, earthenware, painting, typography, and history though the arts. In digital art we offer web design, graphic design, photo editing, and Microsoft Office Training.

At A.C.E. Academy for Scholars, Public School 290Q, scholars receive the following art offerings: Visual Art, Performing Arts and Arts and Sciences. These courses are supported by the Blueprint for the Arts. Scholars perform in music, dance, and theater. In all subjects, our scholars’ learning is enhanced by field trips, interdisciplinary projects, service learning activities, and professional experiences. Visual arts takes a holistic approach to developing the whole artist where scholars experience exposure to art history and the technical skills to develop their artistic talents. Performing arts incorporates music, dance, and theatre where scholars have the opportunity to develop each discipline in a unique way. Scholars participate in two whole-school performances annually as well as one grade-level performance annually. The Arts and Sciences course at the A.C.E. Academy for Scholars is a unique class modeled after similar ideals of a liberal arts college education. Scholars engage in a wide range of discovery and critical thinking activities, while simultaneously transferring their literacy and numeracy skills. We linked the common process and inquiry skills of the Arts and Sciences and developed a course that allows scholars to create, discover, explore, and express. The Arts and Sciences course at A.C.E. Academy for Scholars is supported by the Blueprint for Visual Arts, created by the New York City Department of Education, driving the arts component.

Civic Leadership Academy currently provides students with visual and performing arts' coursework. Students are enrolled in an Arts' course such as Ceramics, Studio Art, Advanced Studio Art, Dance or Musical Theatre each semester. Students have the opportunity to participate in Arts' based extracurricular activities in the Fall and Spring semesters, including The Art Club and Dance Club. Students are showcased during the annual Winter and Spring Concerts, as well as class specific events during and after school throughout the year.

Q39_4: attending theatre shows with their children outside of school time after an arts teacher received a grant for 30 musical tickets.
Q46_1:
PAIHS has an interdisciplinary, standards aligned, arts program that includes theatre and studio art as well as new offerings this year of digital photography, 3D art, and drawing and painting taught by certified arts teachers. Our staff includes a certified theatre teacher and two certified visual arts teachers.

We have partnerships with Repertorio Espanol, Theatre Development Fund, Flamenco Vivo and Urban Arts which bring in artists to offer classes in Flamenco Guitar, Flamenco Dance and Poetry, African Drumming, Cartooning, DJ technology, Theatre, Dance, and Web Design.

This year, students wrote and produced an original, politically charged, play that was performed at city hall. 
 
Our students' artwork was featured in both the PS Art Show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Queens Borough Visual Arts and Theatre Showcase.
We inaugurated our first annual PAIHS Visual and Performing Showcase this May. 
In addition to our International's Night festival, which featured musical and dance performances by our students.
Our after school offerings include Open Studio hours and Portfolio Club.
PAIHS has a renewed commitment to expanding its art offerings. We hope to have two digital photography sections next year as well as an AP 2D art program to culminate the PAIHS art track for students interested in pursuing art in college or their future careers, or in preparing a portfolio supplement for college. 
We hope to secure funding to maintain and further our arts and technology related electives and technologies
Q47_1:
Our school is a small high school located on a single floor in a four story building that is shared by three other schools. We serve an entirely ENL population of students who have recently emigrated from Spanish speaking countries. Due to limited space, art takes place in general education classrooms, though one room has been designated an art room and all materials are stored there in. We have three glass showcases for permanent art exhibition.

Our arts department leader also facilitates an Arts Monday PD for Queens North.

We were previously a Renewel school but achieved Rise status this academic year. Maintaining our arts program is essential because we believe the arts offer future opportunities for our students and support their literacy skills and affect towards school, in turn, affecting regents scores and graduation rates.

We are developing an arts track where all students in 9 and 10 take studio art and theatre and can continue through the arts track to take more advanced courses in their later grades.
Q48_2: Visual Arts Teacher and Department Leader

Q44_R2: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
Q47_1: At Bard High School Early College Queens students complete the 9th and 10th grade, including participation in an arts each semester, then all students enter college on our campus.  Students take a program of college courses, including more advanced work in the Arts, during their final two years, culminating in both the high school diploma and the AA degree from Bard College.  Our school is in a shared building, but it is well-equipped for the Arts, since it was a designed to house an Arts high school.

Q46_1: Learners and Leaders has a robust arts program. Students work with experts including DOE certified arts teachers and others with high level knowledge and skill in working with students to ensure a high-quality and well rounded experience with arts. Art has a very important role in our lives here at Learners and Leaders. Students participate in a wide variety of art forms. They have the opportunity to learn about and explore important concepts in music, visual arts, dance and technology.

As part of the New York City Arts curricula, scholars will be exposed to multiple forms of art. Scholars are expected to use observations skills to discuss art, integrating the related vocabulary; produce various types of art and the elements of principle and design; write and read about the various arts to reinforce their literacy skills; identify the cultural significance of the arts; make connections with the arts to other content areas; extend learning beyond the classroom by participating in community activities and using cultural resources, such as attending museums and dance performances.

Corona Arts and Sciences Academy aims to provide an Arts educational experience for our students that is both rich in content and practice while being accessible for all students. As our school’s enrollment expands, our Arts programs have kept pace by added new arts teachers and offering new classes to our talent program including classes in ballet, jazz dance and theatre. This year, we continued our sequential arts program in which students are allowed to take an arts sequence, focusing on content that both interests the student and promotes personal student mastery. Our goal is to promote the importance of the arts in the well-rounded students’ pedagogy. The positive life-skills acquired in such courses can be used across the curriculum and outside of the school setting. The results of this sequential programming is evident in our student’s work. Students from the Corona Arts and Sciences Academy have been selected to have their art work displayed at the Queens Museum of Art this year and our 7th grade band received a “Gold” rating at this year’s NYSSMA Major Organizations Festival. 

Our new facility is equipped with two visual arts studio spaces, a band room, a fully functioning dance space, and a multi-purpose Gymatorium with a curtained stage, lighting, and sound system. We have continued to work to expand upon our inaugural curriculum, fostering student voice and creativity through the implementation of lessons geared around arts history, theory, and practice.

The goal of our visual arts program is to teach students the elements of art and the principles of design. Students are encouraged to analyze masterworks, their work, the work of their peers and discuss the elements of art. Curriculum units are focused on line, shape, form, texture, and value. There is a school-wide art show that takes place in the spring. The goal of our dance program is to encourage self expression and creativity through dance performance and dance making. Through dance technique and creative activities, our curriculum teaches students important skills for both dance and life, including problem solving, self discipline, and spatial awareness. Dance enrichment programs are offered after school throughout the school year. Finally, students have the opportunity to showcase their dancing in various assemblies and performances throughout the year Students at Public School 330Q are given the opportunity to learn about the many different aspects of music through performance. Kindergarten and first grade students learn a large repertoire of songs, games, and dances. Students in this age range master skills such as singing, listening and keeping a steady beat. Second graders learn about different styles and cultures in music through the Carnegie Hall Musical Explorers program. Third graders are provided the opportunity to learn the recorder through the Carnegie Hall Link Up curriculum. Fourth and fifth graders learn to play a variety of different band instruments.

As our school is growing, we continue to develop our arts programming. Our partnership with Education Through Music (ETM) continued with a full-time certified music teacher teaching classes to all of our students. Students performed in two choral concerts. Next year, our ETM certified music teacher will join our school faculty and ETM will continue to support the school with professional development and programming. We plan to start an orchestral program with our 4th grade students. All students also participated in art classes with our full-time certified art teacher. Their work was displayed in two school-based art shows. Two of our students had their work selected to be displayed in borough-wide and city-wide art shows. Our third grade students participated in an "Arts and Healthy Living" project led by an artist-in-residence from Studio in a School. We hired a full-time certified theater teacher who implemented our first out-of-classroom theater program. All students took theater classes. Students also attended dance, music and theater performances in school and in venues around the city.

At Newtown HS our students prepare portfolios for college and career readiness in the arts. Students are familiar with the NYS Standards & NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exposed to various art forms, tools & techniques to produce artworks and perform. Students develop observational skills and how to develop and argue an opinion when comparing & contrasting their artwork and the work of others. Students are introduced to professions in the arts and are encouraged to develop their goals towards artistic careers. Newtown HS has art exhibits, concerts and plays within the school. Visual art students have exhibited work at outside as well and have had finalists in competitive exhibits such as PS Art , Ezra Jack Keats book competition and the Borough Fair. Our  guitar students often perform at community venues and accompany the choir. We have received grant money to expanded after school enrichment clubs which range from arts and crafts, film, dancing , and art club studio-time to name a few. We have an annual Sidewalk Art Day and this year we had a Fall into the Arts event, an outdoor display of students' scarecrows for viewing by the community. We have offered Paint Night that is open to students, staff and parents. The painting class did an installation art exhibit of umbrellas and kites.This years play in May is "Once upon a Mattress" " and we also host a Spanish Drama Play. We offered College Now classes through La Guardia Community College in Drawing, Painting and Music appreciation. Next year we will offer AP Art.

Grover Cleveland High School continues to offer a rigorous and engaging arts curriculum aligned with the Common Core Standards and focused on College and Career Readiness. Students in the Academy of the Arts choose a pathway to a concentration in fine arts, commercial arts, music, or drama. New additions to the Arts curriculum include AP Music Theory and College Now Art History (Renaissance to Contemporary). All pathways seek to engage students in art making, performance, portfolio building, and technology. Students in all Small Learning Communities at Grover Cleveland experience foundational courses in art and music.

Our school has a full time art and music teacher. All high school classes receive instruction in our music studio and the art classroom. In addition, students can enroll in LaGuardia Community College arts classes which include visual arts, theater, dance, voice and instrument instruction. We are a small school which traditionally serves a high risk population. Our students have the ability to stay a 5th year to earn an Associate's Degree and/or earn college credits. Approximately 115-120 students enroll in all areas of the arts as well as other college classes.

Students generally study two dimensional art media, including drawing, painting and collage. They broaden their creative horizons, expand their English vocabulary and knowledge of art history while practicing a variety of techniques and styles. Since all of our students are English language learners we place a heavy emphasis on English language development in all of our content area and non-content area courses. Students are required to turn in written critiques/reflections at the end of each unit. They learn to work alongside other young artists in a vibrant, supportive workshop environment while also learning to work independently in pursuit of an individual sense of expression. All students moving from our ninth and tenth grade junior institute to our eleventh and twelfth grade senior institute must present a creative portfolio project before a committee as one of their six graduation portfolio requirements.
Q47_1: The International HS at LaGuardia CC is a multicultural alternative high school for recent arrivals servicing the needs of students with varying degrees of limited English proficiency.  Our mission is to enable each of ur students to develop teh linguistic, cognitive and cultural skills necessary for success in high school, college and beyond.  The International High School gives priority to students of limited English language proficiency who have been in the United States for four years or less at the time of application.  All of our students enter as English language learners.  Our students come from over 50 countries and speak 38 languages.  All teachers provide English and native language development through the content area instructional program.

Q46_1: The High School for Arts and Business has a highly developed art program that has ten credit art sequences for both Fine Arts and Graphic Arts. These sequences culminate in a Chancellor's Endorsed Advanced Regents Diploma. We are also developing a Career and Technical Education Sequence for Graphic Arts. The course offerings are: Studio Art, Foundational Drawing, 3-D Design, Computer Graphics, Digital Filmmaking, Digital Photography, Advanced Painting, Studio Arts, and Commercial Design. There are also college level and Advanced Placement courses in Art History, Drawing and Photography (Articulated Agreement with Queensborough Community College). Our program offers internships from the Center for Arts Education,  Groundswell Inc., The Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Queens Museum. Students participate in arts workshops at Cooper Union, Fashion Institute of Technology, The Harlem School for Arts and The Art Students League. Last year we had an exhibit at the Queenboro Museum. Most of our art students have complete our ten credit sequence and have attained the Chancellors Endorsed Arts Diploma. The music department offers a Beginning and Advanced Band, Beginning and Advanced Chorus as well as Music Theory. Our school has a full concert band set up featuring woodwind, brass and percussion instruments. We have partnerships with the Oratorio Society and The Orchestra of St. Lukes. Students are performing and attaining NYSSMA certification. We have dance instruction and a full dance studio. We host several dance performances.

The goal of Maspeth High School's fine and performing arts programs is to support the school's core values of truth, beauty, and goodness through the promotion and appreciation of multiple art forms. All students at Maspeth High School are encouraged to enroll in a single art discipline over the course of their four year high school career. As freshmen, students choose from the following: theater, ballet, string orchestra, chorus, or visual art. Our arts courses are designed to promote the school's mission to have our students become leaders in all fields of personal endeavors through academia and to be physically, emotionally and intellectually healthy with determination and compassion. We accomplish this through a curriculum which is built upon Common Core and Blueprint for the Arts standards combined with our school's classical values. 

In addition to our daily programs, we offer multiple after-school opportunities for students to become further involved in their chosen art form, or to explore the other disciplines. Students may participate in any of the following after school clubs: Art Club (visual), Argonotes (acapella), Tech Club (theater), Band Club (all instruments), Dance Company (ballet), National Art Honor Society, String Orchestra, and Tri-M Music Honor Society.

We believe that these offerings will help us to achieve our ultimate goal of providing a foundation from which our students will develop a lifelong commitment to the arts.

The general arts education program at Queens Vocational consists of project-based learning activities that focus on the five visual arts benchmarks. These benchmarks are: Art Making, Literacy in the Visual Arts, Making Connections through Visual Arts, Community & Cultural Resources, and Careers & Life-long Learning in the Visual Arts. This program allows students to acquire the credits required of all New York City students to graduate from high school. In addition, Queens Vocational has two four-year Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs. These two programs are graphic arts and cosmetology. Graphic arts focuses on preparing students for work in the field of computer graphics. Students develop a visual/design vocabulary, create designs through the use of different media and processes, and engage in design creation and criticism. This program teaches students how to use Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign and Acrobat.

Q48_2: AP Pupil Personnel Services and Music

Q46_1: Our full-time arts teacher provides students with curriculum and instruction that address a range of media and arts concepts. The teacher leads students in a range of outside-of-school trips and internal projects and exhibits. This year, we expanded our arts programming to include college-level peer critiques, theater and music study and production in english classes, including embedded theater/English instruction and film study in english classes. Students in cross-listed social studies / english classes also developed personal video memoirs relating to immigration.
Q47_1: We serve at-risk youth, ages 16-21; many of our students are parentified, work full-time, or face health and/or legal issues.

Q46_1: The 51st Avenue Academy endeavors to make the arts a special part of the school year. Our visual, and theater art program has proven to be extremely fruitful. Once again students in our school won art and theater competitions enabling them to perform at the Colden Auditorium,The Metropolitan Museum of Art,The Queen's Museum, on-line art shows and much more. Our engaging theater program equips our students to express themselves and learn life's core lessons. Our school scope is to expose our students to the arts, to find ways of expressing their feelings through integration of all the core subjects. Our school environment integrates all the arts, including an after-school program entitled Arts and Literacy. The arts engage students in a variety of modalities that enable them to achieve personal and corporate goals in music, visual art, dance, theater, and more. Our students have been exposed to many forms of art that aid in their achievement in core subjects such as literacy, math, social studies, science, and social skills. Thus far, our students have had the privilege of going on trips to museums, musical forums, theater and dance institutions which have expanded their experiences and personal vision. The art program at Public School 877 has exposed students to many art forms, enabling them to grow in their personal, physical, mental, emotional and artistic development. Our vibrant arts curriculum plays a large part in our students becoming productive members of society and the global community surrounding them.

The foundation of Public School 20's arts program is to provide quality arts instruction, assess students in the arts, build teacher capacity in arts instruction, develop partnerships with arts organizations and promote parental involvement in arts education.

Public School 21 provides a well rounded arts program for all students. Weekly assembly periods are led by teachers who prepare the students for grade wide performances. Our third grade students participate in a comprehensive recorder program where they learn to read music as well as play the instrument. This program gives the students a basic music background before they choose an instrument for our fourth/fifth grade band program. Our arts department has collaborated to produce several showcases throughout the school year, including our school's musical and multicultural night. Art exhibits are on display throughout the school building. During cycles of enrichment classes, students in grades one through five have an opportunity to choose from a wide variety of arts classes throughout the year. Each year our dedication to the arts is further developed through a variety of cultural affiliations. This year we are proud of our partnerships with Ballet Tech, Carnegie Hall, Inside Broadway and Little Kids Rock. All of our arts events are celebrated either grade or school-wide in order to give our families the opportunity to celebrate their children's accomplishments.

The Public School 22 community believes that the arts are integral to successful learning. Three full time arts teachers, music, visual art, & drama, provide our students with a variety of arts experiences. To ensure that every student is involved in the arts, they are scheduled for music, visual arts, and drama a minimum of once every seven days. This seven day cycle allows for the over 800 students to engage in the arts regularly. We also provide after school arts enrichment programs. This year we have had the opportunity to bring in many performances for our students and assembly programs that have allowed the students to interact with the artists. We also work with a cultural organization within our community to provide our students with dance. The students in our school perform in a fall and spring music and dance concert. We have also received a grant titled Disney Musicals in the Schools, which enables a school team of staff and students to learn more about musical theater. There is also an end of the year theatrical performance by the drama club. Our third grade students participated in a digital storytelling residency to help connect both media and literacy. All classes are encouraged to organize class trips to the many cultural organizations the city has to offer as additional enrichment in the arts. We will be looking into partnering with an additional organization for an arts partnership grant for the coming school year. We hope to continue to make the arts an important part of our students lives.

Our goal is to integrate the arts disciplines aligned with the New York City Blueprint in the Arts and the Common Core State Standards in all core content curriculum areas. This will be measured by student performances, projects, journal entries, observations and lesson planning. Our students will explore, engage engage in, and respond critically to the visual, expressive, creative and fine arts. Our classroom teachers design, plan, and implement curriculum using the arts as a vehicle of expression and support to content area work. Our teachers will include working with various media and techniques in the visual arts: Reader's Theater, storytelling and oral presentations, singing through the grades, and creative movement and rhythm for early childhood. Class trips to museums, concerts and theater presentations will be conducted to extend the partnerships with cultural organizations providing our students the opportunities for scaffold learning from dynamic teaching artists in music and singing. In addition, we are the recipient of a CASA grant so that our second and third grade students participate in music activities after-school. We also partner with Brooklyn Conservatory of Music and ESTA for instruction in music, dance and theater. Early exposure and integration of the arts into our curriculum expands our youngest learners' knowledge and enables our children to become more successful in the future.

Dance: 1 )Perform movements/dances that require demonstration of complex steps/patterns as well as an understanding of contextual
meanings. 2)Create dance studies and full choreography based on identified and selected dance vocabulary. 3)Apply a variety of
choreographic processes for a duet/ensemble performances. Music: 1)Sing and/or play recreational instruments accurately, expressively,and with good tone quality/pitch, duration, loudness, technique, and singing diction. 2)Identify and describe the roles, processes and actions needed to produce concerts. Sing or play songs while maintaining tone quality, pitch, rhythm, tempo, and dynamics. Art: 1)Develop various skills of multiple mediums and understand the techniques required to express artistic vision. 2)identify and distinguish between abstract expression and observation-based exercises, accurately depicting objects based on direct observation while further facilitating student creativity. 3)Combine and apply a variety of artistic media.

Public School 29's goals for the arts for the 2017-2018 continues to ensure that all students had a variety of opportunities to experience the different aspects of the arts. This year teachers have focused modeling constructive feedback.  This encouraged and supported their students to be reflective of their practice and identify areas of strength and next steps. Teachers focused on journaling, notebooks, and portfolios.  Arts teachers collaborated in a culminating arts extravaganza. Each child in grades two through five put on a production that integrates theatre, music, dance and art. In collaboration with the parent teacher association, every third grade student received their own recorder and put on a concert for their families. All fourth and fifth grade students have the opportunity to try out for our Public School 29 Chorus, Drama Club, and Dance Company, who perform in different capacities throughout the year. The Dance Company was selected this year to perform Queens Borough Arts Festival at Queens College.Parents are invited into the building for workshops around the arts, to assist in creating scenery for productions and to participate in performances. To further extend our in-school arts program we have welcomed, Poppenhusen and Ballet Tech to work with our students. The fourth grade classes had the opportunity to see "The Blue Man Group" on Broadway. Lastly,  In the 2018-2019 school year we are motivated to continue strengthening our arts practices within our building and to cultivate a learning environment
Q47_1: where all students have the opportunity to express themselves.

Q46_1: We recognize that the study of art enriches students' learning and their lives. Our program enhances students' abilities to express themselves creatively by offering opportunities to participate in a comprehensive integrated arts education. This includes experiences in school, as well as experiences in the community and New York City in general. Our program enables our children to reach the NYS Learning Standards in the Arts. The goals of the program are that children are actively engaged in creating, performing and participating in the arts, make use of available materials and resources, respond thoughtfully to a variety of works, and understand the cultural contributions of the arts.

Q44_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Public School 79Q serves 1,134 pre-kindergarten through grade five students. We have a vast in-house arts program which includes three full time performing arts specialists, one each in dance, music, and theater, plus one visual arts certified specialist. In addition to classroom arts instruction, students are provided with instruction from cultural arts organizations. Dancing Classrooms offers our fourth and fifth graders a residency in ballroom dancing. The Metropolitan Opera Guild at Lincoln Center offers our second and third graders a residency in Urban Voices. Marquis Studio offers our  first grade students a residency in dances from around the world. Lincoln Center for the Arts offered our kindergarten students a residency in music combining folk and rock instruments.

We provide a child-centered arts enriched environment for every student. We partner with arts organizations and cultural institutions. Our arts program includes the visual arts, vocal and instrumental music, dance, and theater/drama. In our art studio students use their imagination and problem-solving skills. They learn about master artists, different art media, the elements of art and composition. Children learn to play instruments including recorders and electronic keyboards. Parents are invited to school-wide multicultural events, recitals, holiday performances, publishing celebrations, etc., and are active participants in our community 'art-reach' events. 5th graders have the opportunity to join arts based clubs/troupes including dance, theater, art and glee. 3rd and 4th graders have the opportunity to join the Jr. glee club. In order to ensure equity in opportunity,  all of our clubs are held during the school day. Weekly assembly programs highlight the drama, dancing, singing, and visual arts skills of each class. Student dancers perform at many events. Music in the Air, a tradition for over 40 years, is a community event. It is a four night event where every student performs.

Public School 120 has a choral music program as well as instruction from a licensed visual arts teacher. Students in PreK and Kindergarten receive music and arts instruction five times a week. Through this combination, all of our students receive music and/or arts instruction throughout their week. This year, as in past years, students in Grades 3-5 participated in a year-long residency with New York Philharmonic teaching artists. They traveled to David Geffen Hall for a concert, watched chamber music concerts in school, and composed culminating pieces that are performed for their families in June. Students at PS 120 are also exposed to a variety of arts residencies, including Material for the Arts, Shadowbox Theater, Bricks/Chinese For Kids, Indian Dance, and the New York City Children's Theater. We are proud that every single student is exposed to the arts. Many of our children have grown socially and emotionally through these programs. In addition, the arts have increased our students' language acquisition as well as supported their writing skills. We hope to continue these successes next year and beyond.

Public School 129 has always been, and continues to be, an advocate for the arts. Over the past several years we have added a full time drama teacher so that we now have all arts disciplines in our school. Our goal is to hire more full time arts teachers to service our students. We plan to continue our very successful relationship with Dancing Classrooms. The program has become an integral part of the fifth grade experience. It is our hope that we will be able to expand our arts offerings next year.
