The P.S.130 art program consists of a music program offering chorus and recorder instruction as well as visual arts instruction provided by teaching artists from Guggenheim Museum and Studio in a School. In addition, we have a full time visual arts teacher who through the works of the world's greatest artists inspires the creativity and imagination of young students by following the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. We participate in an after school theater program from Queens Theater in the Park. The P.S. 130 arts partnership collaborations offer students and the school community the opportunity to explore, experience and engage deeply in units of study in dance, theater, music and visual arts. Our primary goal is to encourage and support the imaginations of young students.

We believe that instruction in the arts is essential in providing a well-rounded curriculum for our students. Since children learn in different ways, it is essential to support their learning styles and intelligences using various methods. We have found that the arts can make the difference between a child's success or failure in school. Our goal is to expose our young learners to multiple forms of art so they may experiment and find those that interest them. We continue to expand on these experiences for our young learners and look forward to growing this initiative by partnering with more organizations and providing our students with more enrichment program opportunities.

Q39_4: The LEAP Saturday Parent/Child Mask Making Program
Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our aim at Public School 163 is to develop students academically, artistically and socially so that they leave this school as independent, cooperative, responsible and creative children with a lifelong interest in the arts. Our visual arts program benefits students in many ways. Beyond the tremendous value of learning artistic expression, they learn to visualize and complete creative projects. We added dance to our cluster programs this year, to have the students experience varying styles that identifies the uniqueness of each one. Through our arts education residencies the students are making connections between visual art concepts and other curriculum areas. The Indian Dance residency taught the students the traditions and culture of South Asia. Through our residency, Luann Adams Story Telling, our students were exposed to folktales and fables through a theatrical approach. Inside Broadway allowed the students to feel the background experience of preparing for a Broadway play. Each of these residencies also included performances that families attended to reinforce the love of the arts at home. We believe that this exposure will prepare our students to pursue goals in arts education and allow them to be well rounded citizens that will contribute to the life and well being of society as a whole.
Q47_1: We have a Mandarin dual language program in grades K-5. All 14 classes have a Lunar New Year performance, which include traditional Chinese songs and dance routines. They perform for students and parents of the community.

Q46_1: Our school offers all inclusive opportunities in arts education. We offer extensive programs in visual arts, theater, dance, moving image/video arts. All students receive a comprehensive arts education which begins in pre-kindergarten and continues through eighth grade. We are committed to the philosophy that the arts provide vehicles for strengthening basic skills, heightening language development, academic motivation and achievement. The arts allow a wide range of students the opportunity to experience success and develop a feeling of self worth.
Q47_1: We are a title 1 school located in the heart of queens. It is an involved community with lots of engagement in our arts programs. We host two annual arts events for the school community to be apart of. In addition to this, a large portion of our graduating students go on to attend specialized arts high schools as they move forward in their education.

Q46_1: The goal of arts instruction at Public School 165Q is to engage every student in expressive arts-making activities. Our accelerated arts programs provide numerous opportunities for students to achieve artistic excellence. Curricula in dance, vocal music, visual art, band and string orchestra are based upon the New York State Learning Standards for the Arts and are aligned with the NYC Blueprints for the Arts, for grades Pk through 5. All students receive arts instruction as well as opportunities to participate in formal and informal performances. Music, dance, and visual art are differentiated, according to their respective learners in a variety of class settings including: ASD Nest, Integrated Co-teaching, Self-Contained Special Education, General Education, and Gifted & Talented. Music, dance, and visual art programs offer sequential multi-year instruction for all students, as well as an accelerated performance program for students in the PS 165Q Gifted and Talented Program. The school community's strong tradition of a dedicated commitment to the arts and supportive family involvement nurtures the education of the whole child.

P.S. 169 is dedicated to creating a nurturing and intellectually enriched environment, which develops each child's unique capabilities. The arts can be used as a vehicle to foster creativity as well as parent and community involvement. Our dedication is evident by the presence of a full-time music and visual arts teacher, dedicated music and arts rooms, and our partnership with Together in Dance. All students in grades Pre-K through fifth grade create visual art, which is exhibited throughout our school and at our annual art show. As a school-wide enrichment school, all students in grades 1 through 5 are given an opportunity to choose areas of interest to study weekly.

The Public School 184Q arts program includes visual arts and dance for all students in grades kindergarten through five. This year we continued our Dancing Classrooms Ballroom residency for our fifth grade students and they loved learning how to rhumba, tango, swing dance and more! Grades kindergarten through four students reaped the benefits of a City Center Artist in Residency dance program. Students learned about the basics of movement and space and were given the opportunity to work together to create their own dances. This year, the theme was Dance through the Decades. Each grade learned all about dance in a specific decade. All students in grades kindergarten through five also received weekly visual arts instruction aligned with the Blueprint for the Arts. Projects are designed to build on student interests and skill level. All of our students are provided with opportunities to share their artistic pieces with the community on a regular basis. This year we were also able to hire a part time music teacher for part of the year to give our students exposure to music instruction. We believe that the academic performance and overall success of our students is enhanced by the presence of the arts. The dance, music, and art instruction is tied to content area learning, thus reinforcing academic knowledge. It enhances both fine and gross motor skills and coordination. It also builds a sense of confidence and provides students with knowledge specific to the art forms.
Q47_1: As a small, non-title I school, we struggle to pay for arts programming. We rely on PTA donations, arts fundraising, city council/senator grants, and private donations to enrich our arts programming.

Q46_1: All of our sixth-grade and seventh-grade students are enrolled in fine arts courses for two to five periods per week.  The courses include band, strings, chorus, and visual arts.  The instructors include five full-time music/visual arts teachers. Select sixth-grade classes also study the arts and culture of the Silk Road (Silk Road Connect) during their ELA or social studies classes. Sixth through eighth-grade students have the opportunity to study the arts during our extended day program, as well as in our comprehensive after-school program sponsored by the Child Center of NY Arts. Offerings in the after-school program include dance, musical theater, chamber orchestra, jazz band and art portfolio. During the school day, students participate in dance and visual arts residencies through Arts Connection. We recently received a grant from ArtsSpace to update one art classroom and to create another one. This has greatly enhanced our visual arts programming.  Our goal is to offer our students a comprehensive, sequential, and rigorous fine arts curriculum which fosters an appreciation for the arts, as well as develops the necessary skills for placement in high school art programs and expanding future career choices.

Daniel Carter Beard Junior High School 189Q arts education program provides students with opportunities to employ literacy in visual art, music, and theater that are aligned with the New York State Learning Standards. Students actively participate in skills-based instruction in the arts and develop connections between the arts and the core curriculum. Within the arts program, students receive direct instruction in visual arts, choral music, and theater, including musical theater. We have begun to lay groundwork for a graphic arts pathway with the introduction of Stop Motion Animation and video editing.  This has been greatly aided by the addition of instructional technology hardware and software made possible through a Reso A Grant.

Students are also exposed to instruction in the arts through residencies provided by local cultural organizations. Our goal is to continue the comprehensive art program allowing students to further develop their skills in visual arts, vocal music, and in theater based projects, including musical theater.  This year, in addition to our residency programs with Arts Connection and Flushing Town Hall, we hosted a music artist in residence through Artist Year.

As a 21st Century Community School, we also had the opportunity this year to expand our after school arts offerings in dance and Stop Motion Animation.

Students at Public School 193 have the opportunity to experience the arts in a variety of settings. The art and music program afford children the freedom to explore various media supported with classroom instruction. Through our partnership with City Center, our students participated in a dance residency based on the work of Alvin Ailey. This residency culminates in shared sessions to which parents are invited. NYC Children's Theater allows children to to engage in interactive workshops designed to promote respectful and positive behavior.  Students participate in singing, dancing, and theater with Inside Broadway which is funded by City Council. The culminating performance will be shared with the entire school. Selected grades participate in enrichment clubs of their choice involving the arts such as chorus, cheerleading, etc. Select classes have participated in Circus Arts to learn not only circus arts, but to explore their creative expression and build confidence.  Other classes participated in the Percussion Around the World residency which children learned rhythm and beats.  In addition, some classes participated in Construction Kids and learned to use a variety of tools to build bird houses, wooden cars, etc.  Our 5th graders learned Ballroom Dancing and showcased their dancing in a school assembly and competed in the Rainbow Dance Competition.

Junior High School 194 offers arts education to every one of our 1200 students. Arts offerings include dance and an after-school dance team, instrumental music (concert and jazz bands), chorus, fine art, theater, film & media, and photography.  All students are given an opportunity to select an art form and pursue it for a calendar year; in grade six, students have two choices per year. For instrumental music, students are encouraged to participate for a three year program, each year building on the skills of the previous year. Twice yearly, students have an opportunity to showcase their work through film festivals, dance shows, theater productions, art galleries, and concerts. This year we have partnered with arts organizations including Flushing Town Hall, Jazz @ Lincoln Center, City Center, and Magic Box Productions that provide additional enrichment for our students. Our belief is that our diversified arts program promotes engagement and enhances the rigorous learning for all our students.

We value Arts education and its role in a well-rounded education. Budget constraints have historically made it challenging to add full-time Arts-certified teachers, but we take steps to fill those gaps whenever possible. We have one Visual Arts-certified teacher and one Drama cluster teacher. Middle school students have the opportunity to engage in enrichment electives related to the arts. And with our recent grant from the Magnet Schools Assistance Program, we have expanded our growing list of arts partnerships throughout multiple grade levels. Partner arts organizations include: Ballroom Basix, Together in Dance, Marquis Studios, and Studio in a School. We believe that it is possible, and essential, to provide arts education in creative ways. Residencies may not be traditional arts classes, but they can be equally valuable. We are just now beginning a four-year partnership with Roots, Routes, and Rhythms, which will tie the arts to Social Studies in grades 3-8.

Q44_R1_C2: Gina Gibney Dance; Hands are for Holding
Q46_1: Every student at Public School 201 is provided access to performing arts. Through creative and strategic use of resources the school has one full time certified music teacher, and one full time certified dance teacher. Students are afforded the opportunity to learn keyboarding as well as creative dance, social dance, and choreography. Collaboration between PS 201 and the Music and the Brain grant provides students the opportunity to learn music literacy and appreciation through piano keyboard. The American Ballroom Dancing Company further develops music and dance appreciation for students in fourth grade, completing twenty sessions of ballroom dancing that culminates with an assembly for the community and a group of fourth graders attending a local competition. Public School 201 has a collaboration with community organization, the Chinese Advantage, and offers additional in-school enrichment programs including Lion King World, Shakespeare Players, and Sing Me A Story.  The after school Chorus and Stars Dance Company programs give motivated students opportunity to develop their arts skills and perform in the community throughout the year.

PS 209 has a full time certified music teacher who provides instruction to all students.  We use various cultural organizations to provide arts instruction.  Our classroom teachers provide instruction in the visual and performing arts.

Q39_4: Assisted our Art Teacher in our Musical Theater Program
Q46_1: Our goal is to provide students with a meaningful & well-rounded arts based curriculum. Each student participates in a production which ensures they will have an opportunity to dance & perform for an audience. We have a full time visual arts teacher who implements lessons that integrate various content areas. We have a full time music teacher who services every class in the school. We have both a grade 4 and grade 5 chorus and a school band who meet with the music teacher weekly. Students in grade 3 learn about & perform on Djembe drums & other orchestral percussion. Grades four and five learn how to play and perform with recorders, guitars ukuleles, keyboard & other instruments. For a seventh year we have our CCAST (Cadwallader Colden After School Theater) program which enables us to perform an annual musical theater production. This year we performed "Aladdin Kids." Approximately 80 students (performers, art/set design and stage crew) were provided with a twenty week after-school program. This full scale production was presented to family, friends and the community in the spring. This performance assists us in sustaining the CCAST program for the following year. Thirty of our grade two students participated in a CASA grant sponsored by our Councilman's office. The students met for twenty 2.5 hour sessions with a resident from Flushing Town Hall to learn Chinese dance. The program culminates with a performance in June. We will continue to utilize all available resources for a continued comprehensive arts education program.

Arts instruction in theater, music, and art are provided by both classroom teachers and by the art and music teachers. Students also receive arts experiences by participating in events at Queens College, Lincoln Center, The Guggenheim and The Metropolitan Museums of Art, Ballet Tech and more. We also host Ballroom Dancing for select grades! We are especially excited about continuing the K-8 music and instrumental programs, we have created a full time music position for middle school band. We have expanded our instrumental and choral programs, including a new beginner band/orchestra with small group lesson instruction for grades 4-6, choral ensemble opportunities for the same grade levels, and Little Kids Rock modern band instruction for students from elementary to lower middle school. In grades 7 and 8, band is a full time subject. Music at PS/MS 219 is inclusive and differentiated for our student population in opportunities, instruments and ensembles. The addition of an elementary school visual art teacher ensures that every student in grades Pre-K to eight receives arts instruction weekly. We are also proud of our Early Childhood Program where we seamlessly integrate literacy into visual arts, drama, music and movement. Throughout the school, we incorporate movement into everyday academic activities through Move to Improve and Activity Works. For the 2018-2019 school year, we would like to create a drama and/or dance program and bring more performance opportunities for our students in and outside of school.

We strongly believe students involved in the arts make gains in math, reading, cognitive ability, critical thinking, and verbal skills. Our school's theme is "The Arts", therefore careful attention is given to planning lessons and projects to ensure that our magnet theme continues to flourish. We are fortunate to offer our students both performing and visual arts classes during the school day as well as an extensive after-school talent enrichment program

Q44_R1_C1: Anne Frank Center for Mutual Respect
Q46_1: Veritas Academy is a high school which opened in September of 2013. We are a small school which is committed to finding the gifts and talents of all students, in keeping with our Renzulli Schoolwide Enrichment Model. Veritas has on staff one full-time visual arts teacher. We offer students visual art courses as well as arts electives. This school year we were afforded a wonderful opportunity through The Anne Frank Center arts residency program. This organization, with which we have a longstanding collaboration, worked with our students on the themes of self-identification, respect for all and inclusion. Veritas also offers an extracurricular modern dance club and a Latin Dance elective. We look forward to expanding our arts course offerings in the future.

Queens High School for Language Studies is a small high school committed to providing opportunities in the arts for our students. We currently offer a theater class to ninth graders and visual arts to tenth and eleventh graders. Twelfth graders can elect into an advanced visual arts or theater class. In addition, we have a weekly after school Music Club, Photography Club and Improv Club.

Public School 242 actively engages students in creating art in all media and exploring the expressive arts in musical theater, dance, and visual arts. We make school-based connections by teaching students about artists and their lives, discussing art as lifelong learners, and integrating the arts into all curricula areas. We provide students with cultural and historical background through on- and off-site professional performances and trips to museums and cultural institutions. Our strong and ongoing partnership with musical theater teaching artist, Alastair King, provides students and staff with the opportunity to develop as musical theater artists and performers culminating in musical theatre productions on each grade level. Our partnership with Studio-In-A-School provides rich opportunities for students and staff to work with teaching artists to create and display in the visual arts, culminating in grade level art shows for families. We have partnered with Together in Dance to provide our students with creative movement and musical theater opportunities in which they can collaborate in the dance making process and express themselves through the arts. Our collaboration with Cultural After School Adventures (CASA) provides enrichment through a grant funded after school arts program for our first and second grade students which culminates in an exhibition of student artwork at The Latimer House Museum. In these ways we support students, families, and staff members in appreciating the arts and living artistic lives!

TALES continues to integrate the arts into all curriculum areas in the school. Specifically, TALES is viewing the arts as a way to enrich the language acquisition process for its many English language learner students.  Music is used on a daily basis in every classroom as an important instructional tool for the school's young learners. We also have an ESL teacher who teaches language through the mode of music. In addition, we contracted with Studio in a School to provide visual arts instruction to our Pre-Kindergarten through third grade students.  TALES hopes to continue offering specialized arts instruction in order to provide students with a rich, child-centered curriculum that promotes language development and a love for the arts.

The arts program at The Robert F. Kennedy Magnet School of Community Studies includes a general and vocal music program for all of our students. Our school has a show choir and a recorder ensemble that performs both in school and "on the road". Students have the opportunity to take class and grade trips that expose them to music, dance and theater. In addition, eighth graders have an opportunity to take a visual arts course.

Queens School of Inquiry is a sixth through twelfth grade Early College Initiative School. All middle school students receive instruction in art,music, and theater. Students learn the basics in drawing, painting, printmaking, ceramics, art history and art criticism in sixth grade. In music, all students gain basic knowledge in reading and composing music and all students learn to play musical instruments in an orchestra and brass band in seventh grade. In theater, all eighth grade students take the Introduction to Musical Theatre course, where they develop skills in performance, playwriting, and theatrical criticism, which scaffold into the 9th grade acting course. When students enter high school, every freshman student is scheduled for Acting I & II (Acting and Directing, Scene Study and Production) Opportunities are extended to students who wish to enroll in advanced level drama courses, college art courses and/or high school art and music electives. Outside of the school day, Queens School of Inquiry offers MIddle School Musical, tech theater club and SING!. The Queens School of Inquiry arts department programming is expanding. Our current eleventh grade students will be eligible for an advanced endorsed arts diploma designated in theater if they fulfill ten credits in theater related coursework, a three part year long assessment, and an independent student exit project.

Arts are an integral part of our students' educational experience at the Flushing International High School. All of our students take classes in visual arts, media arts, and drama in each of their four years. Students also have multiple opportunities to perform and share their work with members of the larger school community.
Q47_1: All of our students are recent immigrants who are new learners of English. The arts gives them an opportunity to develop their language skills and express their ideas and identities in multiple ways.

Q44_R2: Opus Dance Theatre & Community Services, Inc.
Q44_R3: Opus Dance Theatre & Community Services, Inc.
Q46_1: The Arts Department at the East-West School of International Studies includes dedicated, full-time dance, music and art teachers at both the middle school and high school levels.  Students have the opportunity to experience beginning dance, beginning studio art, chorus and beginning guitar throughout their time at East-West.  Our dance courses address the five strands addressed in the NYC Dance Blueprint for the Arts while exploring the fundamentals of dance through the genres of Japanese cultural dance, Chinese cultural dance, hip-hop, jazz, musical theater and ballroom dancing.   Visual arts classes engage in a variety of art techniques and artists through the use of hands on projects including weaving, original cartoon animations cells, one-point perspective city paintings, surrealist landscape paintings, cartoon sculptures, and realist pencil portraits to name a few.  Chorus students experience music through the lens of a professional musician.  They learn to read basic music notation and interpret markings in vocal music, develop their voices using proper vocal technique, and explore the lives and music of musicians and composers (past and present) in all genres of the music industry.  Students in beginner guitar learn the fundamentals of playing and maintaining the instrument.  The department plans on expanding its offerings to students.  For music, a Musical Theater class open to high school seniors and in visual arts, a Graphic Design class for high school students.

BELL Academy has full time Visual Art and Music teachers on staff. Grades 6 through 8 all receive two periods of Art instruction during the week. Grades 6 and 7 receive two periods of Music instruction during the week, including General music for both grades, instrumental for grade 6 and digital music for grade 7. In addition, BELL also has Enrichment periods two periods a week where students have the option to choose additional Art-related classes such as String Ensemble, Drama, Water Colors, Film, Animating with Code, and Fashion.

Q44_R3: DOE Office of Arts and Special Projects
Q44_R5: Institute for the Study of the Ancient World
Q46_1: The arts at John Bowne High School afford students the opportunity to meet both the N.Y.S. Learning Standards in the Arts, as well as the Common Core Learning Standards. Explicit connections are made between the arts and history, and literacy is reinforced in all arts courses. Courses include illustration and digital media, studio art and drawing, sculpture and crafts, fashion design, graphics, band, chorus, guitar, piano, and strings. John Bowne is proud of its state of the art piano lab. Students participated in both a winter and spring art exhibit and concert and in our third SING performance. John Bowne has a continued partnership with the Queens College Jazz Residency. Our students have the opportunity to perform in the Spring Jazz culminating concert at Queens College and receive feedback from the Queens College music staff. We look forward to the implementation of our new visual arts sequence for Fall 2018. Upon successful completion of the first year Studio Art foundation course, current freshmen will have the opportunity to select the two-dimensional or three-dimensional track. The visual arts sequence will culminate in the NYC Department of Education commencement exam and successful completion of the sequence will result in a Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma in the Arts.
Q48_2: Assistant Principal Physical Education, Music and Art

Q46_1: Flushing High School has a robust and growing arts program in three major arts disciplines: music, visual art, and theater. Students may enroll in a variety of arts classes. Modern band students learn popular music through keyboard, percussion, and guitar, culminating in two major performances. Piano classes are tailored to student ability, which means beginners can learn simple rhythms and advanced students can tackle complex pieces for performance. Choral students learn and perform classical and contemporary pieces while being introduced to music theory. Visual arts students engage in drawing, painting, digital media, and multimedia. Theater students learn acting, playwriting, design, and directing by producing both published and self-written works.

Public School/Intermediate School 499 continues to cultivate an intensive arts education program involving the entire school community. The visual arts teacher aligns lessons with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Planned lessons are thematic and rigorous, as well as standard and content based. Students are encouraged to appreciate and understand how art can become a vehicle for expressing ideas, exploring new experiences and igniting the imagination. Supplementing our art program is our partnership with Lincoln Center. We are a Lincoln Center Education Focus School and as such we boost the study and appreciation for various art forms: visual arts and dance. We infuse aesthetic education philosophies and methodologies throughout our curriculum. Queens College supports our involvement with LCE and our music program.
Queens Academy High School offers a multidimensional, cross curricular arts program in Mixed Media. Art classes are infused with literary elements to assist students in inquiry and argumentation.

We continue to strive to provide our students with a rich arts experience. Through the use of our full-time art teacher, our students develop their creative skills to meet the NYS Arts graduation requirements.
Q47_1: We are a small Transfer High School which serves students that have fallen behind academically.  We continue to find it a challenge to provide our students with additional arts experience because we focus on accelerated credit accumulation to help students get back on track. Also because of our small size, we operate on limited budgetary options. We would welcome opportunities to obtain grants to support art education at our school.

Q46_1: The arts program at Public School 18 is driven by thoughtful, robust and sequential instruction guided by the NYC Department of Education Blueprint for the Arts. Using backwards planning and inquiry-based lessons, creative exploration and expression, students create art to make social, cultural and academic connections to engage in learning beyond the classroom. Students at Public School 18 are encouraged to share in each others diversity, celebrate their individuality, and become life-long learners and visual interpreters. We strive to make the arts an integral part of providing a well-rounded education to all our students.

PS 26 has made strides to incorporate a vast range of artistic influence within all of our classrooms. Our art teachers promote their craft through drama, music, visual art, computer science and STEAM projects. Our teachers are influential to our students in regard to allowing our students to express themselves in other than conventional ways, both in and out of the classroom. We continue to search for materials, projects, and innovative technologies to enhance our existing arts programs.
Q47_1: Our building consists of 714 students. Within the entirety of the building there are four self-contained classrooms, six English as a New Language classrooms, and six Integrated Co-Teaching classrooms.

Q46_1:
Public School 31 is a school that is dedicated to providing an enriching arts program to its students. Our music program includes a full time music teacher. We perform winter and spring concerts. We employ a full-time visual arts teacher who works with each class, incorporating a variety of media into student art. We also have a Winter and Spring Art Show. Public School 31 also consists of an outstanding drama club which meets after-school from January through June culminating in a final performance for our community at large in June. Our fifth graders are part of a ballroom dance arts residency in which the culminating activity is a performance for their parents. Twelve students are chosen to take part in the Colors of the Rainbow ballroom dance competition against other schools around the city.

The arts are incoporated into our daily classroom lives and each class rehearses and performs for their families and peers.  Our halls and our lobby showcase the extraordinary talent of our students and creates a wonderful environment for students and staff alike.

At P.S. 41 we place an extremely high value on arts. We offer a variety of different arts opportunities. All students, K-5, receive one period a week of music instruction by a full time, certified music teacher. Students in grades 4 & 5 can volunteer to participate in our chorus or band, with several performances taking place throughout the year. All students, K-5, receive one period per week of visual arts instruction by a full time, visual arts teacher. Artwork is displayed throughout the building. We are also fortunate to be able to offer theater arts to all of our students. Alastair William King works with children and stages culminating performances, by grade, throughout the year. Additionally, our 5th grade students participate in a semester of ballroom dance lessons with an artist from Dancing Classrooms. At the end of the program, students put on several culminating performances for their parents and all students.

At Public School 46Q, we value the importance of the arts for all of our students. We offer a multifaceted and comprehensive set of experiences in the arts through their integration in all subject areas. The school is decorated with student created art masterpieces. The performing arts are highlighted by the winter and spring concerts. Choral instruction is provided to all students in both lower and upper grades. Children receive a variety of instrumental music instruction with band instruments including piano, string instruments, keyboarding, percussion electric guital and acoustic guitar. Additionally, all third grade students receive recorder instruction. Dance instruction is given to all fifth graders and is also offered to the rest of our student population through various whole class and pull-out activities. Musical theater is offered to all the students at Public School 46Q and each class puts on a musical theater production. Additionally, we seek to provide our teachers with professional development during our arts cycles with teaching artists.

Nathaniel Hawthorne Middle School 74 provides rigorous ARTS instruction in all four art forms. As part of our individualized approach, during the 2017-2018 school year, our students were provided with individual choice. The students could choose from instrumental music, vocal music, graphic art & design, studio art, theatre, or the moving image. We continue to provide additional arts learning through our collaborations with World Dance Theatre (Cultural Dance Project), Arts Horizons, Jose Limon Dance Company, Jazz at Lincoln Center, and the New York Historical Society. Our Dance program was part of Arts Achieve over a seven-year period. The Arts Achieve work created a foundation for our teachers and students to learn how to use peer and self-assessment to drive instruction. Our teacher team has shared these best practices, and this approach has been shared across the arts department. Three of our arts teachers were facilitators this year during Arts Monday professional development, and three of our other arts teachers participated in these professional development opportunities. Their work and research focused on utilizing different types of formative assessment in order to guide instruction. These conversations were a continuation of the Arts Achieve work that was started in our dance program.

Q44_R1_C1: Musical Theater Residency with Alastair King
Q46_1: The arts program is designed to teach students creativity and to introduce as well as continue to expose the children to a variety of art materials. Lessons correspond to the New York City Art Standards and align with the Blueprint for the Visual and Musical Arts. Each grade has its own curriculum and challenging projects that often relate to what they are learning with the classroom teacher. The children are exposed to many different techniques in art and music. In addition, there is an emphasis on formative assessments (both peer and self) as well as summative assessments where the children have time to reflect on their projects.

Public School 98Q provides varied art form instruction to all students. Music is the primary art form students receive throughout the year, spanning instruction from general music to reading music, playing instruments (recorder,guitar,keyboard) and culminating in a fifth grade seminar on music history and the science of music (Music  The Brain). Kindergarten through third grade students learn stage presence and performance as part of music class and participate in an annual spring concert. A chorus, selected by audition, rehearses weekly and performs a culminating concert in the spring. In addition, our fourth and fifth grades were introduced to ballroom dancing this year. PTA funding supplements our arts programming which includes theater performances, Midori workshops & concerts, and a visual arts residency. A CASA grant has allowed for a partnership with Midori & Friends with after school programming in drumming and vocal training, leading to a Spring  performance. Public School 98 also offers an after school program that includes instruction in visual art, theater and music for students interested in going beyond what is offered during the school day. A school-wide vocabulary enrichment initiative has been enhanced by original songs written to incorporate themed "words of the month", which are performed at an annual Vocabulary Day Celebration. The arts instruction at Public School 98 is integrated with other curricular areas that includes literacy, social studies, science, math and technology.

At The James J. Ambrose School we believe that instruction in the arts is essential in providing a well-rounded curriculum and education for our students. It is important to include opportunities for our students to develop their abilities in other areas such as performance in dance, music, and visual arts. Providing students with other avenues to excel is critical, as it allows students to experiment, find new interests, and showcase their talents in many different ways. Our goal is to continuously provide a variety of opportunities for students to engage in these areas. We hope that this exposure leads to a lifelong love and appreciation for learning about the arts.

Our overall goal is to incorporate visual arts, music and dance into everyday learning and provide all students with opportunities to participate in a variety of arts activities. This is accomplished through dedicated periods of instruction provided by our classroom and visual arts teachers, programs involving cultural organizations, artist residencies and field trips. Our philosophy is that the arts are essential to building critical thinking skills, creative and effective problem solving, effective communication and teamwork. For these reasons, instruction and appreciation for the arts are infused in all areas of the curriculum by teachers and support personnel. Art is a universal language and our goal is for each member of our school community to realize the importance of the arts in the development of a well balanced educational program and lifelong learning.

Our arts program is an integral part of achieving our school's mission to prepare students to exhibit their competence as critical thinkers and creative individuals. Our learners will take responsibility and ownership of their learning to successfully contribute as a productive member of society. Without the arts in our school, we would not be able to help develop the whole child. We have incorporated interdisciplinary projects which help our students to excel in school and beyond. Many of our students go on to showcasing their talents in various venues. Throughout the school year our students perform or have their works displayed in places such as Queens College, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, American Ballet Theatre Company, as well as the Little Neck/Douglaston Memorial Day Parade.The collaboration provided by in-residence teaching artists provides the students additional information and experiences. Many of our students who have a passion for the arts are accepted and continue their journey in specialized arts high schools. The arts at Marie Curie help provide students a place for their creative side to come alive. We were pleased to continue providing our students with choices in the following art programs: dance, vocal, orchestra, and visual art and look forward to offering as many experiences with the arts as we can in the future.

The learners of Public School 159Q participate and are exposed to various components of the arts, daily. This includes; theater, dance, music, and visual arts. All classroom teachers use "Go Noodle" with their students. "Go Noodle" integrates music, song, and dance. Every month, students perform the dances they have learned at school day events as well as at monthly evening PTA meetings. Every year, the third grade team learns cultural dances and they put on a Winter performance of the dances for their families and friends to enjoy. Our school has a full-time licensed visual arts teacher who provides instruction in the arts about artists, time periods of art movements and connections between the content areas and the art work students are learning. Students in grades four and five participate in a specialized art club, where students create art portfolios. Our full-time music teacher has designed a program that teaches students about song, reading sheet music, and to play instruments including the keyboard, drums, guitar, electric guitar, and recorder. We have a chorus & band program that performs a concert each year. Each class in our school goes on a minimum of 3 class trips per year to museums and theatrical performances. This school year we received a CASA grant and worked with CUNY Creative Arts program to provide theater instruction to our third, fourth, and fifth graders. In addition, our parent teacher association has provided our students with enriching assembly programs (Lunar New Year, STEAM).

We are grateful to the parent teacher association and council representatives who monetarily support a great number of our arts programs. The Early Stages Program provides visual arts and theatre in grades kindergarten through four, in conjunction with the Ballroom Dancing program in grade five. The Ballroom Dancing residency takes place in the fall for the fifth graders with a culminating day/evening performance for students and parents. These programs help with our efforts to promote building upon multiple intelligences for all our students, which is the essence of our mission statement

Irwin Altman Middle School 172 is committed to providing our students with a quality arts education and assuring that we are following our mission to "make this school the educational center of this community" which is culturally and artistically diverse. As in past years, in Digital Film/Computer Coding we have followed the Common Core grade 6 - 8 Literacy in Science and Technology Subjects Standards to supplement our curriculum focused on Computer Science for All and computer fluency for creating digital media products (animated movies, apps, etc.) The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts has provided a guide for our curriculum development in visual arts, vocal and instrumental music and theatre production. This year, we expanded our commitment to linking the arts and scholarship by establishing a new local chapter of the National Tri-M Music Honor Society with our first cohort of inductees; this was also our first year performing in the NYSSMA Spring Festivals (where we were awarded Silver [Level 2]). Through a NYC ArtsContinuum grant we became a NY City Center partner school and received a Resident Artist to expand our arts offerings to include Dance for some of our 6th graders, provide them with the opportunity to attend a professional arts event (Broadway's "Hey Look Me Over"), and to perform in two in-school dance events; the costumes for which were a product of a Costume Creation workshop series that we established to include our families and interested community members in our flourishing arts program.
Q47_1: MS172 will soon be applying for a one year extension for the NYC Office of the Arts ArtsContinuum grant and intend on working with the arts vendor, NYC City Center, to once again offer dance to 6th graders (particularly from our elementary feeder school partner PS191) and working with our full time teachers of other arts disciplines to incorporate Dance/Movement elements into their curricula for other grades. Similarly, we are hopeful that MS172 will once again be recipients of a Project BOOST grant that we will use to restart the Family Engagement workshop series next year.

Q46_1: We have three major goals in developing the arts at our school. We plan to continue to train classroom teachers to incorporate more arts learning into the content areas. We intend to continue to increase students' awareness and appreciation of the arts, parent involvement and outside partnerships in the arts.

PS/IS 178Q offers arts programs in the following areas: music,visual arts, dance, and digital media/technology. Additionally, we are partners with the prestigious Young People's Chorus of New York City, offering a choral program for students in grades three through eight. We have a successful fifth grade ballroom dance program in partnership with Dancing Classrooms. We have a long standing partnership with the Jewish Museum made possible through CASA and our local Congressman. We also have partnered with Arts Matters in order to provide a robust curriculum of arts instruction for all our students across kindergarten through eighth grade. In our effort to expand programming and highlight the arts by creating new experiences, our students have bridged learning across grades and disciplines and created workshops and presentations for the community. We utilized digital portfolios in the arts and piloted digital assessment software to incorporate 21st century technology for college and career readiness. We have received multiple grants made possible through arts teacher initiatives to continue to support the need to update our studio spaces. Our graduating students have gained acceptance into specialized high schools such as La Guardia, Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, Brooklyn Tech, Queens High School for the Sciences at York College and Townsend Harris.  As we move into the 2018-2019 school year we are anticipating to replace our music program with theater and continue to offer music through our partnership with the 92nd Street Y.
Q47_1: Our school services children in grades PK-8th grade.

Q46_1: By June 2018, pre-k through grade five students will have connected the arts to personal experience, community and society through developing dance, music, visual arts, and theater literacy as measured by the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts theater benchmarks.

Each class receives vocal, music and art instruction during the week and after school by our certified teachers.Talented grade three through five students are in the chorus and present three concerts per year. Students audition, practice and perform each year in our Mayflower Idol show. Every class produces an art, musical or dance production celebrating historical events, cultural events, curriculum units, holiday celebrations or book reviews. Using after school PTA and parent funding, our staff offers various art programs in dance, computer graphics, CODE, arts and crafts among others. Students and parents look forward to many annual events where the children perform: Thanksgiving Day, Grandparent's Day, International Day, Chinese Festival, Colonial/Historical Fair, Carnival Dance Show, Mayflower Idol and our spring and winter concerts. This year we received funding from Senator Avella to provide Architectural/Visual Arts instruction for grades 2 and 3 along with Immigrant Funding for a Saturday "Structural Design Program" for our English Language Learners in grades 3,4 and 5. We also co-wrote a grant with MS 172 to provide 10 sessions of "Jazz Dancing" for our 5th graders culminating with a parent/student trip to see a Jazz performance at City Center. Hopefully through various funding sources we will be able to continue to work with outside cultural organizations.

Our arts program provides instruction to all students in dance, music, theater and visual arts. Our school based programs integrate the arts into core subject curricula through a variety of initiatives. We expose the students to a variety of arts experiences and provide enrichment opportunities through clubs that support college and career readiness. We provide information for students and families about arts opportunities available locally and throughout New York City and are committed to creating community connections through the arts. Our goal is to connect families with their child's education through ongoing opportunities in the arts that support student achievement.

Our school's vocal music program encourages students to participate in an interactive learning experience that promotes self-expression. Students develop an understanding and appreciation of music literacy which supports and enhances the Common Core State Standards. Our music program is defined by students' innate and natural ability as well as interest. We believe that all students not only benefit from a quality music program, but that it also enhances their daily learning experiences. Students enjoy the benefits of a vocal music program that promotes musicality, theory, and performance. Students in kindergarten through fifth grade learn through units of study aligned to the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Music. Our school is also a recipient of the "Music And The Brain" program that includes teacher training, piano books, keyboards, recordings and curriculum materials for classroom piano instruction for students in K-5.

Q44_R1_C1: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
Q46_1: We keep the arts a vital part of our students' education. We have on staff an art teacher to work with the students in all classes, pre-kindergarten through grade five. Two student art shows were produced in the fall and spring. Our entire school community is involved in our International Fair which includes ethnic performances performed by the students. All classes in kindergarten through grade five participate in two six-to-ten week cycles of the school-wide Enrichment Cluster initiative. Every classroom teacher incorporates arts education into their classroom instruction. All kindergarten through grade five students receive weekly music instruction from our music teacher. We were able to hire our current music teacher through our partnership with the organization Education Through Music which affords students an enriching experience with music. Students performed two concerts for the school community to showcase their music instruction and talents.

We are a community-based middle school. All sixth graders go through a full arts instruction assessment in visual, choral, and instrumental, and dance arts. They are assessed for talent and based on that assessment, students and parents are invited to participate in tracked arts talent for seventh and eighth grade. Art talent students are groomed to create arts portfolios in their specific discipline in preparation for auditions in NYC specialized arts programs in high school. Many of our art talent students are chosen to attend prestigious arts schools such as LaGuardia Hig School and Frank Sinatra. Others continue to take arts courses in their local or chosen high schools. Some form of the arts (Dance, Visual Arts, Music Instruction, Filmmaking, Digital Art) is available for seventh and eighth graders outside of the talent track.

PS 221 is fully committed to arts education.  We pride ourselves on sharing unique and meaningful learning experiences. Our visual arts program includes, art history, sketchbooks, school-wide participation in the Square 1 project, and our continuing partnership with NORC/Deepdale Cares.  This year’s community project centered on recycled art, creating classroom and decorative objects from a variety of recycled items.  We are in our third year of our art enrichment, Artify It! Our music program provides musical and instrumental arts education. Our students participate in singing and performing using the Orff approach, and learn to play instruments including the recorder, guitar, ukulele, and drums. We perform school concerts and community outreach, such as the fourth grade holiday concert, third grade recorder concert, & second grade Earth Day sing.  Our dance program includes Dancing Classrooms and our annual Dance Festival. Our theatre experiences included Circus Arts, Marathon Playhouse, Queens Theater, LeAp, and the Queens Museum. We also partner with Journeys into American Indian Territory, and the Art Works Project with visits to The MET. In-house, our annual Renaissance program incorporates a wide variety of enrichment experiences in the arts, such as dance, theater, visual arts, and music. We hold an annual talent show and Family Art Night. This year we introduced Musical Theatre Guild, with students writing and performing an original play.

Our students are engaged in the arts from pre-kindergarten to grade eight. Students are given a variety of opportunities across multiple art disciplines, including visual arts, vocal and instrumental music, and theater. We believe that exposing students to the arts is an essential component of supporting them to have a well-rounded educational experience within our learning environment. Here at Public School/Intermediate School 266, all constituencies are strong advocates for arts education, and work to ensure that all students have access to meaningful learning opportunities that are aligned with the arts and culture.
Q47_1: We utilize our outside dance organizations to prepare our students for a culminating Multicultural Day. We also hold an annual Arts Festival in the Spring in which all of our students display their artistic pieces and musical presentations for parents and friends to view.

Q44_R1_C10: The SWD/ELL grant requires the school to pay $7500. We are not a Title I school and will be a second year new school with limited funding.
Q46_1:
We are going to hire an additional arts teacher if funding is possible, so that additional disciplines are addressed

We would also like to forge with an additional cultural arts organization to create a more robust arts program at this school.
Q47_1: This was indicated in the previous page, but I would like to reiterate that PS 376Q is a brand new school and we are going to expand to the first grade, which will serve Pre-K to 1st grade students in the 2018-2019 school year. We are located in district 26 and have not been designated as Title I school. Thus, we are limited with funding with only 170 incoming students for the next year.

Q46_1: Our music department offers a diversified program to meet the needs and interests of each of our students. Students have the opportunity to be members of the following performing groups: Junior Chorus, Senior Chorus, Beginning Band, Intermediate Band, Advanced Band, Beginning Orchestra, and Advanced Orchestra. In addition, there are courses in Guitar, and Music Appreciation. Students perform at concerts throughout the year as well as participate in several field trips. Students learn music theory, perform in an ensemble, and understand music in relation to history and culture. Develop instructional strategies to ensure that each student reaches their full potential while developing a lifelong appreciation for the arts. WE WILL BE ADDING ADVANCED PLACEMENT music theory for students in  GRADES 10-12.   Performing Arts Program- Students study ballet, modern, and jazz techniques along with choreography. Students also have the opportunity to explore additional forms of dance by attending live performances and participating in school productions. Theatre and Film: The primary goal of this course is to enhance students’ understanding of the art of film. Students will study and become familiar with filmmaking terminology and film history. Through the screening of various films and film clips in class, students will analyze techniques and critique the work of a broad range of directors. All aspects of cinematography will be explored including editing, lighting, camera use, mise-en-scene and production choices.

Our current arts program consists of dance, theater, fine arts, graphic and visual arts, and vocal and orchestral/band performance. Our goals are to sustain a diverse and challenging sequence of courses which will culminate with our arts festival and the regents for our Dance Academy students. This enables our students to participate in authentic arts experiences both in and out of school. We are looking to offer a three year sequence in graphic arts. Our students have many opportunities to perform both in an out of school in dance, instrumental and vocal music.
Q47_1: Our Assistant Principal for art and music, retired about a month ago. The Principal is filling in until new hire in September.

Q44_R4: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: Martin Van Buren has a dynamic arts program which offers many electives and sequences in music and visual arts. The music department offers sequences in piano, band, chorus and musical theater. Senior students are offered Music Production and Composition. In Visual Arts we offer a fine arts sequence as well as sequences in fashion, cartooning and animation, graphic arts, advertising and web design, 3-D design and architecture. We have a chapter of the Tri-M Musical Society and participate in the Grammy Foundation Training Camp each year. Drumline Club and Visual Arts clubs are offered after school. We are proud to say that we have successfully helped our students enter into excellent college arts programs including the Fashion Institute of Technology, Parsons, C W Post, Cooper Union, The Arts Institute, Nassau Community Fashion Program, and Queens College Music program.

Q44_R4: Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York
Q46_1: Bayside High School's music and art programs are congruent with the Bayside mission to graduate students possessing awareness and core competencies needed for success in the employment arena and institutions of higher learning. Both programs provide student-centered, skill-intensive, real-world experience in students’ areas of interest. Rooted in developing core technical skills, our programs also familiarize students with industry-standard equipment and software. Lastly, we introduce students to careers in their chosen art form, as well as expectations of the job market, with special attention to arts careers. We are approved by the NYSED office of CTE for both our screened Art and Music Programs. Accordingly, we actively align our Digital Art & Design Program and our Music Performance & Production Program to meet industry expectations. Both programs culminate in industry-endorsed technical assessment.
Q48_2: Assistant Principal Arts and World Languages

Q46_1: Students in PreK to 2nd grade receive Visual Arts Instruction and Music two times per week from a certified arts teacher. Students in 3rd to 5th grade receive Theater instruction. Students in 6th through 8th grade started off the year receiving Visual Arts Instruction until the teacher left her position. For the second half of the year student in 6th-8th grade received arts instruction for an outside organization, Thrive. Students in the middle school (6th-8th) are also granted the opportunity of participating in a theatrical production through the Broadway Jr. MTI grant.
Q47_1: Unfortunately we lost the middle school art teacher early in the school year. The elementary arts teacher had small groups of arts enrichment for the middle school during extended learning time, where the students made sketchbooks and created work that could become part of a portfolio for a specialized art school. The students were still able to create work and participate in judged contests such at the MLK Art Show in Albany and the Queens Borough Arts Festival.

Q46_1:
Students are offered visual arts and music during the school day. In visual arts classes, students used art media, which include
written descriptions and student-produced art. Each unit culminates with the students' presenting their work, including an explanation of
their artistic choices. Through our
partnership with groups like YMCA, students have been exposed to dance performances and dance recitals. All students provide feedback to their peers throughout the year, both written and verbal. Students are given
additional opportunities to participate in arts-related classwork and field trips.

Our practical vision for arts instruction emcompasses inspiring students, building confidence, and deepening critical thinking skills through the arts. This should include not only history and appreciation but a hands-on component which allows for experiential learning. Our goal is to maximize our students' creative potential.

Q39_4: Participated in cultural arts collaboration with Visual arts teacher to bring Eastern art into the classroom.
Q44_R4: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: This year we encouraged parents to help us integrate their cultural background in our visual arts practices. Parents worked to choose an art project that would represent a style of art from their cultural backgrounds. Students created an image using this drawing style. Teachers and parents collaborated to create a cultural sharing workshop to enhance cultural understanding and promote a sense of community within the school.

Here at MS 53, "The Swagger School," we believe in educating the whole child. Our performing arts program introduces students to historical and language based content while allowing them to explore their sense of self. Our program impacts our students' cognitive growth by increasing cultural awareness, problem solving abilities, recognition of visual language, and higher order thinking skills. Every Wednesday, for approximately two hours, our students participate in one of the following performing arts programs: Drumline, Martial Arts, Dance, Step, Visual Arts, Music, Photography, and Steel Pan. One of our most esteemed programs, Life Changing Music, allows students to explore their creativity through songwriting as well as music and video production. As featured on Fox 5 News "Influential New Yorkers" segment, we take pride in our students and staff having produced several CD's and music videos, including "SWAGGER," "53-Swag," and "Motivate" featuring Dres of Black Sheep. The LCM program has dramatically increased self esteem and collaboration among students as they express themselves through positive musical messages. Additionally, our Urban Arts partnership offers rigorous residency programs in a wide range of art forms, taught by expert teaching artists. All programs use a project based approach for students to develop pre-professional skills and key vocabulary while producing high quality, original artworks. Students also develop an increased awareness of career opportunities in the arts.

The goal of the Public School 56Q arts program is to engage students in an integrated arts experience to enhance children's understanding of the world around them. Through a combination of school-level instruction and cultural partnerships, we will continue to provide children with a rich and meaningful arts educational experience.

Students worked hard this year on achieving our school goals of improving questioning techniques and establishing a culture for arts learning. We have been able to develop questioning techniques for students to gain a deeper understanding of art works and question each other's point of view and thinking. These questions have enabled them to think critically about art which is helping them to become lifelong learners of art. We have established a culture for arts learning which is demonstrated by the children connecting art to real life experiences as well as global issues beyond their background.

Q39_4: Studio in a School Parent workshops
Q46_1: At Public School 62, a Magnet School for Computer Science and Innovation, we encourage our students to be Makers of Apps and Arts. We ensure that all 950 plus students participate in dance, music, theater and visual arts classes during their years at Public School 62. Innovation is integrated across all disciplines and classroom Maker Spaces incorporate concepts with design. Fourth grade students participated in Dancing classrooms and competed in a ballroom competition.  In these classes they are exposed to a wide variety of arts across a variety of genres and cultures. Our dancers practice creative movements, develop motor skills, focus on specific styles of dance and explore a variety of ways to create and manipulate their own movement. Our arts programs provide opportunities for students to become literate in art, make social, cultural and historical connections, and become lifelong learners and advocates for the arts. Additionally, our third, fourth and fifth grades are given the opportunity to participate in an arts club (dance, visual arts, chorus or theater). This year we were awarded a Midori grant in which thirty six students were instructed in guitar. We celebrate the arts throughout the year through shows, exhibits and classroom presentations attended by the whole school community. These performances and presentations are recorded and uploaded to our school website and our Facebook page for viewing.

At Public School 63Q we have established strong partnerships with many arts organizations such as Carnegie Hall, American Ballroom Theater, Music & The Brain and Little Kids Rock. During the 2017-18 school year, we also added Disney Musicals in Schools and the Rubin Museum of Art to our list of arts partners, with a production of “Lion King Kids” and a “Math and Mandalas” residency.  Our current performance groups include chorus, modern band, concert band and violin. Despite being a large school, PS63 ensures that every student has an opportunity to shine onstage with a show by each grade involving every student in K-5.  We feature original artwork by students in our school productions, as well as in outside exhibitions whenever possible. This year we had winners in the following art exhibitions and contests: NYSATA Legislative (exhibited in Albany, N.Y.), Public School Art (exhibited at The Metropolitan Museum of Art), Queens Arts Festival at The Queens Museum of Art, and Ezra Jack Keats bookmaking contest Queens borough winners.  This was also year two of a grant for a music/theater residency to support our English Language Learners. Our music and visual arts departments have been reliably strong, so we continue to seek ways to increase access to programs involving the theater arts and dance. In order to support the school’s 2018-2019 Social Emotional Action Plan and CEP, next year we will seek to incorporate arts activities into our Harmony program for social-emotional wellness and awareness.

Q44_R2: Young People's Chorus of New York City

Q46_1: Art is incorporated in to our curriculum and we have an extra curricular art program.

Our distinctive arts program offers students hands on experiences through a variety of instructional and cultural initiatives. Our partnerships with NaliniKids, Midori Music and Arts Connections expose our students to theater, visual arts, music, and dance. Students learn a variety of artistic processes from inception to presentation. We celebrate the arts throughout the year through shows, exhibits and classroom presentations attended by students, staff, and family members. Arts is an integral part of our curriculum and we are dedicated to creating lifelong learners and advocates for the arts.

This year we won the Disney Musicals in Schools Grant in which 2 teaching artists came to our school once a week for 17 weeks and guided us in the production of the Disney Musical, The Jungle Book. This is a 3 year grant which begins with strongest support in the first year and tapers off with each subsequent year. With their guidance and professional direction, we were able to prepare the students for 4 performances of The Jungle Book.  This afforded students who never sang or danced the opportunity to learn how a performance is produced. It has been extremely gratifying to watch students blossom into their roles.  We provided community outreach opportunities for parents to help with sets and costume decoration.  The students will see the Broadway show Aladdin, compliments of Disney and perform at the Amsterdam theater for their parents as a reward for participating in the Disney Musicals in schools program.
  Our school also was given the opportunity to be in a choral program which will perform at the Apollo Theater. A trained vocal teacher auditioned 3,4,and 5th graders and has been teaching them various musical pieces for the performance. The students are enjoying both of these wonderful opportunities.

Public school 96 Queens is an elementary school with 310 students from pre-kindergarten through grade 5. We use an interdisciplinary approach to infuse the four major arts disciplines. Visual art, drama, dance and music have been incorporated into our units of studies. Our visual arts curriculum focuses on various art forms aligned with the Blueprint for the Arts. Students study various composers and our diverse population has afforded us the opportunity to study several cultural dances during our annual dance festival. For the past three years, funding from a private donor has made it possible to secure a residency with Studio In A School. The program provides comprehensive, rich, sequential visual art instruction to all K-5 students. Each grade receives weekly art instruction in a range of media, designed specifically for PS 96Q, in alignment with the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Visual Arts and Common Core. Classes are instructed in collaboration with the classroom teachers and a professional studio visual artist. The program equips students with multiple opportunities to develop the ability to work from observation, memory, and the imagination, to plan, reflect, revise, and to collaborate, to develop ideas from multiple sources and synthesize their ideas to create original works of art that are personally relevant. This school year we have partnered with Music For Many and RIOULT Dance companies to provide dance residences to students in grades 3-5 and K-2 respectively.

Most classes receive both Visual Arts and Dance instruction. We collaborate to enhance, not only our Arts curriculum but also our core curriculum areas of study.  We interconnect all subject areas through the Arts.  We use Science, Social Studies and Math curriculum in our Arts lessons to increase and expand the student's understanding of the material they learn in class.  We have noticed that this method has increased the level of understanding among the students.  The classroom teachers have expressed that they notice this increase also.  We plan trips, school events and use of literature along with music in order to enrich the cultural experience of each student.

We continue to maintain our arts program at PS 100, which consists of three major components that cycle three times a year, covering all of our classes in music, visual arts and drama/theatre. An additional component offers instrumental music instruction and chorus. The students in our instrumental program play recorder, clarinet, saxophone and percussion. The children have competed at NYSMA, performed at Carnegie Hall.

Public School 104 in Far Rockaway Queens provides an enriching art program to students in grades pre-k through 5th grade.  Students in grades pre-k through second grade work towards the second benchmark in New York City Blueprint for the Arts by exploring and manipulating different mediums, creating art inspired by cultures from around the globe.  Students at this level make observations, ask questions and then create an imaginative visual response through play and exploration of materials.  Grades 3rd through 5th work towards benchmark 5 by taking part in art critiques providing a journal response followed by a class discussion of ideas assisting students in making cultural and historical connections.  In addition, students in grades 3 through 5 practice drawing techniques to improve skill level and exercise their imagination.  Students at all grade levels are exposed to artists from the past and the present inspiring them to discover the many career possibilities in the arts.  Instruction is provided in 2 dimensional and 3 dimensional modalities with a focus on the elements and principles of art and design.  The Art instructors of P.S. 104 teach parallel to classroom teachers to reinforce learning in the subjects of: english language arts, social studies, math and science. An art show is presented in May displaying student work from the school year help to develop and refine the quality of work and increase student interest in developing as an artist.

Our arts program runs with One music teacher and one visual arts teacher, serving students from pre-k to eighth grade. Depending upon the classes, students receive art education one to two times a week in both disciplines. The arts program follows the NYC Blueprint Benchmarks for the Visual Arts and Music, making interdisciplinary connections with the social studies and science curriculum. Lessons are planned incorporating Common Core Standards for Math and ELA. . Outside the school, music and visual art teachers participate in various professional development workshops related to their own discipline. The school also offers one period per cycle, for art, chorus and band that runs over 2 semesters for grades seven and eight

All students at Lighthouse Elementary-27Q106 receive music instruction at least once a week throughout the school year. We meet the New York State Learning Standards in the Arts as measured by unit tests in the arts, written responses , musical performances and art displays. Music and Dance Artist Year provider work together with classroom teachers to enhance core knowledge and to support students in the expressive arts. Students have the opportunity to not only create melodies and perform in concerts, but will also learn to play the recorder, percussion instruments and steel drums. Students have the opportunity to participate in a winter concert, spring concert, the Black History Month Show, and the Say No To Violence Assembly. Fifth graders will participate in a graduation show/assembly. In partnership with Education Through Music, staff members will participate in professional development training in-house. The music teacher participates in both in-house professional opportunties and mentorship as well as District 27 Arts professional development.

Public School 108 is proud of our ability to provide each child in the school with an opportunity to explore and experience the arts. Our art teachers are diligent about displaying student artwork so our hallways serve as a gallery showcasing our children's current artistic achievements. Our dance teachers coordinate performances amongst all grades exhibiting students' hard work to entertain fellow pupils, staff and parents. We have supportive parents who continuously participate in school events. This year we were able to hire a teacher for a chorus / theater program. We are continuously exploring other avenues which may provide a multitude of invaluable experiences.

Goals For Arts Education: Students will expand their awareness of the influence the arts have had on the world throughout history. Students will be able to make connections in the arts to other areas of instruction. Students will receive a well-rounded education in the arts. The arts have been considered to be a link to higher-level thinking. We offer instrumental music in grades kindergarten through eight: kindergarten through second grades are introduced to reading and playing keyboards via the "Music and the Brain" program...seguing into the third grade with flutophones and graduating in grades four through eight to the playing of concert band instruments...leading to musical groups as the Concert Band and Marching Band (grades four through eight) and the Jazz Band (grades six through eight). An additional musical group is our fourth through eighth grade our Glee Club. Visual arts instruction is given to a majority of the school.

The visual arts program at Public/Middle School 124 follows the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual arts, created by New York City Department of Education's Office of Arts and Special Projects. Through the five activity strands that compose the Blueprint, students are offered a comprehensive and multifaceted set of visual arts-related experiences. Formative assessment is utilized in the arts classroom to support students and improve performance. Middle school students applying to screened visual arts programs in high schools will participate in a portfolio class to prepare for auditions. Public School/Middle School 124 will continue to enter art competitions such as the Queens Borough Arts Festival, the Ezra Keats Bookmaking Contest, and PS Art. In the graphic arts, students are encouraged to develop an interest in the field of graphic design. They develop their digital manipulation skills by creating a complex piece of artwork using Adobe Photoshop Elements. The program enables students to create, edit, organize, and share images with the use of a computer. In addition, the dance/creative movement at PS/MS 124 emphasizes building a foundation of the dynamics of movement with the incorporation of spatial awareness, use of effort, shapes, and relationships between the dancers. As students move to the middle school level, there is the opportunity to work collaboratively with their peers in dancemaking, aligning the learning process with the Blueprint in Dance.

At Middle School 137, we strive to educate the whole child and have continued to make arts education an integral part of our curriculum and instruction. In order to accomplish this, we realize that a well-rounded education in the arts is a critical component in preparing our students to enter the professional community. Students are exposed to career-building skills in arts-related fields and gain an appreciation of art as a means of expression. By infusing the arts with technology, we provide students with an arts curriculum that is challenging as well as rigorous.
