Students are supported to apply knowledge and skills learned in the arts to make connections to the world around them. Our arts curriculum supports goal setting, prioritizing, and strengthening interpersonal skills by working collaboratively with peers, working independently, and continuing to align and support the Blue Print for Arts, Music and Dance. We put great emphasis on literacy in the arts and these skills support interdisciplinary units of study. This year, we were fortunate to have two of our students selected to participate in the Queens Boro Arts Fair, and an 8th grade student receive the 2018 Dr. Dolores Beckham Arts Award.  For the second consecutive year, we had the extreme pleasure of being the host school for New York State Music Association Adjudication. Our school has previously been rated Gold in both our Instrumental Band and Chorus for the borough of Queens.

Public School 146 is proud to offer classes in the arts to our students in the forms of theater and the visual arts and to expose them to music and dance in their regular classrooms. We have art-based displays throughout the school year and take our students on trips to experience art forms in music, drama, and dance. We participate in citywide art contests offered by the Office of Health and Wellness, NYC Sustainability Council (Energy Saving), and Earth Day celebrations.   Under the guidance of our theater teacher multi-grade students put on yearly musicals. We believe the arts is an integral piece in the mosaic of each student's well-rounded education.

Q44_R2: Dancing Classroom American BallroomJ&F Fund Raising
Q44_R3: Children's Museum of the ArtsLONG ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM
Q46_1: At Public School 155Q, the arts program utilizes the five strands of The Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in the Arts, aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards, as a guide for integrating the arts into the core curriculum. The school's visual and musical arts curriculums provide a variety of modalities for creativity, student learning, and success. Differentiated, and scaffolded instruction is evidenced in student performances, portfolios, and completed work projects. We will continue to improve student achievement in the arts, through the development and implementation of balanced art assessments, formative and summative, that are aligned to high student content and Blueprint based academic achievement standards.

Public School/Middle School 183Q is committed to providing our students with an art enriched program. All grades and classes conduct an assembly which focuses on a theme for the month. Students participate in talent shows, a Christmas show and Black history month performances. They perform plays, sing songs and create their own dances. We encourage teachers and staff member to incorporate the arts throughout all subject areas, such as drawing and music. We have the Enact program that works with our first through fourth grade students on drama. The Thrive program works with our middle school students through visual arts and music and our third grade students participate in dance with Ballroom Basix.

P.S. 197Q engages our scholars in the arts through Dance and Visual Arts. Both are taught with experienced and talented consultants. 

Our Visual Arts consultant comes to us through Smartworks and aligns his instruction through the NYC DOE Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Projects aligned to the curriculum as well as through celebrations such as African American History and Women’s History Month.

The Child Center of New York provides our Dance Consultant. Dance classes involve cultural and current dance moves, strategies, methods and history. Students learn different types of dances through various pieces of music. Dance classes offer the children an engaging and collaborative experience.

The mission of Robert H. Goddard Middle School 202 is to provide our students with a comprehensive education with a particular emphasis on the fine arts. Enabling students to view the world through a holistic lens will prepare them to meet the challenges of college and career as motivated, socially conscious and inspired individuals. Our long term goal is to continuously enhance the arts curriculum by providing instruction, aligned with the Next Generation Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. Additionally, our goal is to enrich our students' lives by exposing them to the arts and having them develop a profound and lifelong appreciation for the arts. This will enable our students to express themselves freely in a variety of creative ways, and thus allow them to develop and showcase their own personal talent.
We would ultimately like to program our students based on their interest and abilities in the Arts for an enrichment track.

Throughout the 2017-2018 school year, the visual and performing arts program was guided by the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning for the Arts.  The goal of each program was to meet the benchmarks of the second, fifth and eighth grade students.  As benchmarks were achieved, students became familiar with visual and musical concepts, art and music history and the elements and principles of fine art and music.  In addition, students were offered opportunities to participate in musical theatre and set design.  We strive to support the Core standards between the arts and the academic subjects for all of our students.

Q32_6: Arthur Miller, Dance Theatre of Harlem, Puppetry in Practice, Roundabout Theatre
Q46_1: Nearing the completion of our first year with a Dance program and a change of direction in our Music and Theatre programs, MS 210Q's vision of the Arts has been solidified.  Our primary goal is to perform at a level which will include our school in conversations that were once exclusive to institutions such as Frank Sinatra, LaGuardia, Art & Design and F.I.T.  The Performing Arts Department has grown exponentially through the guidance of our new teachers and residencies. Representatives from the Arthur Miller Foundation, Puppetry in Practice, Dance Theatre of Harlem and Roundabout Theatre have taught our students strategies to reduce stage fright and public speaking resulting in a noticeable improvement in pride, confidence and academic performance.  The field trip to Broadway (Anastasia) has motivated our performers. It was the first Broadway show for many of our students.  Administration has reserved a portion of what the budget allows however, following our Winter Festival of the Arts parents, local businesses and support groups have made donations ranging from costumes and props to their time.  Unfortunately, good equipment is not inexpensive.  We were able to purchase wireless microphones as our first major investment.  Proceeds from future performances can perhaps assist in our next purchase like floating mirrors, new curtains or an HD camera!  Our music teacher has begun to network in hopes of leasing, buying or fixing our aging instruments.  Years ago, this conversation was never initiated, now we have a wish list.

The main components of P.S. 223's arts program are our full-time visual arts teacher and full-time music teacher. Arts instruction is aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Instruction continues to pursue diverse approaches to the content being taught through various media and repertoire. Student artwork has been showcased throughout the school and featured in our new music and visual arts exhibition room. One of our students proudly participated in the Queens Borough Arts Festival; family and staff attended the opening reception. The chorus continues to engage parents and the school community with their performances. Holiday performances and our dance festival remain highlights for the entire school community.  A group of students also attended dance and music related field trips with our music teacher. In a project organized by the visual arts teacher this year, many of our staff collaborated in a large-scale 40 foot long mural that is now a permanent part of our auditorium space.

At M.S. 226Q we will continue to offer rich art experiences to our students through exposure to diverse activities in photography, music, poetry and dance. Our continued partnerships with Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation and Alvin Ailey Dance Company develop our students’ cultural awareness and create an appreciation of the arts. Through poetry our students are learning to express themselves through written and spoken word. We will also continue our theater program which will give our students an opportunity to dramatize their favorite stories and characters.

Our arts program includes one full time art teacher, two part-time art teachers, and one full time music teacher. We partnered with Midori & Friends, Inc. through a grant from City Councilman Ulrich and was provided with concerts, music residencies, and a CASA grant for an afterschool middle school chorus program. We also partnered with Studio in a School for our first and fifth grade visual arts residencies. ArtsPower, Inc. continues to return every school year with three theatrical performances for our K-2, 3-5, and 6-8 student groups.

Members of the PS 253Q community believe in the benefits and need for Arts education as part of our students instructional development.  We offer of our classes visual arts as well as dance as part of their instructional program.  in addition, we look to receive grants to further implement Art into the lives of our students.  Over the past several years, we have partnered with Marquis Studios to hold art residencies, such as percussion, puppetry, yoga, circus arts and song writing.  As we move forward, we are always looking to bring more arts education into the lives of our students.
Q47_1: Proud to serve the Far Rockaway community, our school is home to a diverse population of students in Pre-K- Grade 5, with the following representation: 61.92% Hispanic, 32.45% Black, 1.49% White, 2.48% Asian, 0.17% Pacific Islander, 0.83% American Indian or Alaskan Native, and 0.66% Multi-Racial. 49.67% Males and 50.33% Females. Within our population, 21.52% are Students with Disabilities (SWDs) and 30.13% are English Language Learners (ELL’s).

Q46_1: Our Arts program follows NYS Learning Standards for the Arts and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exploring five different art making strands in each grade from kindergarten through fifth grade and study several different instruments in music classes. We ensure that our students reach the visual arts benchmarks working onfour to six week unit based projects. By the end of second grade, they demonstrate knowledge of a variety of art materials and tools and create original artwork. By the end of fifth grade, our students work on sequential projects and extend their knowledge of art media. We are also integrating art and music with other disciplines and collaborate with classroom teachers on special projects. In our arts program we support literacy by writing about art and music concepts and interpreting and analyzing works of art. An important component of our art program is regular visits to music concerts, dance and theater performances and art museums, where students experience original works of art and understand their significance within the context of diverse cultures. We also offer several programs for parental involvement in the arts through numerous art workshops and music events.

Frederick Douglass Academy VI offers a required music credit 5 periods a day, Monday through Friday in the form of a non-sequential Modern Band class that focuses on performance and composition. Students, are offered the opportunity to choose a main instrument from the Modern Band idiom (Guitar, Bass, Keyboard, & Drums). 

After school music opportunities include a highly proficient Modern Band ensemble on Friday afternoons, an inter-school band in cooperation with the Academy for Medical Technology on Tuesdays, and a Chorus on Wednesdays.

After school ensembles regularly perform outside of school and at school functions including assemblies, Awards Night, and Graduation.
Q47_1: FDA VI is a small school capped at ~400 students, and a staff in the low 20s. The arts department is made up of one music teacher who is also the Arts Liaison. The required music class is currently one of two elective classes offered (the other a College and Career Readiness class), and students do not have the opportunity to choose their elective credits.

Q46_1: Voyages Prep- South Queens High School has created a project based art program tailored to our young adults. A true collaboration between our art and construction teachers, the Construction Arts Program incorporates a wide range including sculpture, architecture, carpentry, modeling, paint, ink and brush, wood working, and other non traditional elements. Students build various projects throughout each trimester ranging from habitat models, Tim Burtom exhibitions, murals, 3-D houses, Lego sculpture, and models. In addition we are currently building to scale a photography program and a film making/documentary program with Power Tools for Progress and the Office of Post Secondary Planning.
Q47_1: Transfer High School for Over aged and Under Credited young adults

Q46_1: Our visual arts program is offered to both middle and high school students. The art teacher creates interdisciplinary projects with the core subject teachers. In addition, we have choral music, Guitar as well as a concert and marching band. Our choral music teacher is working with the Middle school students to put on a production of Beauty and the Beast , while the other arts classes are working to support this production through the creation of choreography, sets, props and costumes. Our students are not only offered their required arts program, but also an additional choice of elective in dance, chorus, band and visual arts. Electives classes take place three times a week.

Public School 273 serves pre-k through fifth grade students. We believe that providing visual arts and music education is integral to addressing the needs of the whole child. Our visual arts program serves all of our students and is integrated and sequential. In grades pre-k through fifth, our visual arts instruction increases children's awareness of their physical environment, extends and develops the use of the senses and encourages inventive thinking. Our visual arts program supports individual interpretation of ideas and feelings while providing opportunities for experimentation in a variety of media, such as painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, sculpture, 2D/graphic design and digital media. Our art teacher nurtures our children's curiosity by encouraging our students to explore and express their individual interpretations of artwork. In grades pre-k through four, our music teacher implements differentiated instruction and builds upon the strengths of the students. Instrumental music, including keyboarding in collaboration with the Music and the Brain program, is taught in grades kindergarten through second. This year, we received a grant from the Carnegie Hall Weill Music Institute Link Up Program to provide great musical experiences for our grade three students utilizing recorders. Our music teacher has also established a specialized school chorus consisting of fourth grade students.  We have also partnered with ArtistYear to provide ongoing theatre experiences for our students.

Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy Vi offers a comprehensive arts program which focuses in the dramatic arts and instrumental music. All cadets receive both of the these classes, biannually, for their three years at Kappa Vi. We believe in sequential, experiential learning. Students, or cadets, are encouraged by their teachers to engage themselves throughout this curriculum to ensure for a well-rounded education and aid to core-curriculum classes. Drama at Kappa Vi focuses on specific areas. These areas are: creating original student compositions, creating parodies/satires, folklore play-ons, as well as analyzing how art imitates life. Students participate in a large production at the end of each semester where all of these art-forms are highlighted. For all three years, students are broken into groups, where they create and perform on a daily basis. Instrumental music at Kappa Vi allows students to actively participate in a concert band setting. In the sixth grade, students have the choice of picking their own instrument, learning the responsibilities that pertain, and the responsibility of mastering the basics and beyond. With these understandings, students participate in musical units revolving around conflict, love, and motivation. The application of both disciplines and the integration of the arts into all content, allows students to cultivate a passion for the arts in their time at Kappa Vi

The Arts Program at HCMS continues to grow. The Visual Arts program provides direct instruction for 6th and 7th graders, plus an Enrichment Program for students who would like to pursue art on a more personal level.  The Enrichment Class enables students to work from an exploratory perspective by allowing students to create their own art project and work on it over an extended period of time.
With the addition of an new and experienced music teacher, the music program at HCMS is flourishing.  There is currently an advanced chorus, a 6th grade chorus, a 7th grade chorus, a drum/percussion class, guitar class, and an 8th grade band.  Next year, we hope to start a drumline that can grow in the next few years.
Q47_1: HCMS is a Title 1 school that serves 360 students.  HCMS is a fairly new school and  we are still developing out Arts program.

Q46_1:
QIRT offers a comprehensive Studio Production program, with a focus on gaining the skills and confidence to create, produce, and perform music in a studio environment. Students learn multitrack recording and songwriting techniques utilizing Garage band and Logic Pro on Mac workstations. Students learn how to play piano and use MIDI, alongside basic editing, mixing, and mastering. 

Students who achieve mastery at the beginner levels of the music program are eligible to continue on in advanced music classes which further enhance their skills as performers and songwriters.

At P.S. 306Q, we believe that a well-rounded education begins with integrating the arts into the curriculum. All students benefit from the opportunity to learn about and experience the arts. Arts education helps bolster a child’s attitude towards school and in turn makes for a more positive school environment. Next year, we will continue to offer arts education through theater and the visual arts.

We currently offer visual (Studio) and digital arts (Photoshop) to all our students as well as theater and dance. We also offer a college board certified course in AP Studio Art (Drawing) for our advanced art students who want to pursue an arts college/a career in the arts. Every year, we host a major art exhibit where our students showcase their visual and digital artwork to the school community, including parents. Some of our previous graduates have won scholarships in various art competitions. We also have art and yearbook clubs that meet every week after school. Students have the opportunity to engage in theater production twice a semester as well as take dance electives for physical education.

Advanced Drawing 
Advanced Concert Band
Campus Rock Band

The Visual Arts program at EPIC offers classes that help students develop their artistic skills as well as guide them through a journey of self exploration. All students will be engaging in a wide array of artist materials (shading pencils to plaster cloth) to expand their current artistic ability. Here at EPIC we also believe that simply creating art isn't enough, and that our students need to be able to express their personal voice through the visual language of art. We strongly feel that this level of personalized art education paired with highly technical art instruction will provide a strong foundation of artistic exploration for all of our students.

Our school uses both performing and visual arts as a bridge between content and understanding. Classroom teachers design their standards-based curriculum maps with the arts integrated within. All arts-based teachers design their arts based curriculum maps integrated with core subject standards. School based art teachers include visual art, dance, music, STEAM, and theater. We offer art based residencies through Creative Arts Team, Rockaway Waterfront Alliance, The Guggenheim Museum, The New Museum, NYC Ballet, Little Kids Rock and Center for Architecture. We also use the Schoolwide Enrichment Model on Fridays for two periods where students get to choose the cluster they want to study. We do two cycles of enrichment. Cycle I and cycle II last fifteen weeks each. We also have art enrichment after-school programs/clubs in dance, art, band, 3D printing, chess, basketball, soccer, and theater.

Waterside School for Leadership works to integrate our progressive visual arts curriculum into each scholar's educational experience. We believe that the visual arts are a critical and essential part of the education of every young person and we work to provide all scholars with high-quality, studio art experiences fitting to their individual stages of development and background. Studio visual arts courses include drawing, watercolor, manga art, portraiture, photography and painting. Scholars research and emulate various artists and styles over the course of three years. They are encouraged to ask questions with each and every project they create.

Village Academy has continued to strive to integrate the arts into subject areas as well as providing each student with visual arts, music, theater and dance, multiple times a week. Our students continue to participate in recording their own media arts and developing their own original music. Students participate in poetry slams, direct and produce videos, and perform in annual concerts. Currently the students work with Entertainers4Education Alliance, Life Changing Music, and the YMCA. Teachers also support our arts initiatives by providing weekly arts and literacy based electives and attending professional development related to the arts. As a small school we continue to need the support of grants for funding to expose all our students to different forms of arts education where they can continue to express themselves through the arts.

Q45_10: participation and punctuality, blogs and online discussions
Q46_1: Scholars' Academy stays committed to enhancing the effectiveness and scope of existing programs and continues to embrace the numerous technological advances that are offered in our society, through our stream webcasts, links to student-made films, concerts, and performances, as well as exploring virtual art studios and installations. Our student artists work in and respond to a global environment that is culturally diverse, technologically advancing, and multifaceted. Scholars' Academy makes art in the 21st century accessible to all and prepares our art students for success in college and careers.

The music program at Rockaway Park High School for Environmental Sustainability focuses on developing student musicianship utilizing popular music. Students learn traditional music notation, however, emphasis is placed on the development of their auditory senses. Students learn to rely on their ears when making a variety of musical decisions. We offer a two-part guitar course with the added option of learning other modern band instruments (keyboard, bass guitar, or drums). In addition, we’ve also created a modern band program for those students who wish to continue, develop, and explore their musicianship.

The focus of our arts program is to provide our students with opportunities to participate in the various disciplines of art, dance and visual arts, where they learn the content, skill, techniques and processes. By creating a safe and risk free environment students can appreciate and enjoy the arts as well as express themselves through a variety of artistic media. Through the high standards in our art program, students will develop the ability to understand how time, culture and society influence art as well as make interdisciplinary connections.

WAVE Prep is committed to demonstrating WAVE (Worldliness, Accountability, Virtuousness, Excellence) and preparing scholars for college and careers. To support scholars in developing as worldly and virtuous individuals, all scholars engage in a rigorous interdisciplinary curriculum that integrates various forms of art across all content areas. Scholars embrace dance, visual arts and music, and utilize their artistic abilities to demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of academic areas.

At P.S.377, the instructional focus is for students to engage in meaningful discussions, exemplified by responding to and extending each other's thinking. This will deepen and enrich their language development and give them the confidence to apply knowledge to the real world.  It is our belief that participation in all arts disciplines directly supports this focus. Studies measuring creative thinking, critical thinking, problem solving and reasoning all find these functions increase and improve when arts education is integrated into the curriculum. Research on students involved in arts education shows that they learn how to communicate effectively, practice constructive criticism and listen better. P.S. 377 currently has a visual arts program as well as music and movement. As it continues to grow, the school looks forward to further expanding the arts programs.
Q47_1: P.S.377 is currently in it's first year and primarily consists of early childhood, Pre-K and Kindergarten which explains the lack of arts programs at this time. In the coming years the school will be expanding until it becomes a full capacity 3K-Grade 5 school.

Q46_1:
The RHHS visual arts classes explore basic and advanced drawing, the world of ceramics, portfolio design and computer graphics. Through the Design Academy that students may enter in the 10th grade, students take three full years of art courses that prepare them for the NYC Comprehensive exam in the Arts, the completion of a varied portfolio and the potential of a Special Arts Recognition on their diploma.  Artists at Richmond Hill High School exhibit their art at our school-wide arts fair or as winners of citywide art contests.  Past winners have had their artwork put on display in places of distinction throughout the city including The Queens Museum of Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 
The music classes at Richmond Hill High School provide students with the chance to explore music making through classes in percussion and through the use of music composition software.  In the percussion classes, students explore rhythm and ensemble communication in preparation for the 2 concerts the school celebrates each term.  Students of all levels will perform for an audience in their first semester.  The music composition classes ask students to mix and blend sounds to create a theme-based sound.  One project, for example, asks that students compose a new musical theme for known television trailer.  Students become proficient in the professionally recognized Ableton Live music software.

The theater classes at RHHS allow students to experience all aspects of putting on a performance including writing, acting and staging.

The John Adams High School arts program offers students a broad perspective of the arts and deepens their understanding of the opportunities for art-related careers through exposure to art history, contemporary artists and artwork, and music and drama. This program attempts to enable students to realize and achieve their full potential in art. Lessons consist of lectures, demonstrations, slide presentations, studio activities, assigned research and group assessments.

Our school along with the band and art program, has added the Arts in Education Program (I Will Graduate) to our arts program. This program provides instruction in different types of dance, YRAAP, chorus, karate, steel pan, journalism and drumline.

Q39_4: Monthly Parent Workshops embedding the arts across ELA
Q46_1: P.S. 40's Arts program continues to grow like the Little Engine that Could! Our little artists are developing into well rounded individuals.  We are continuing to expose our scholars to a variety of well known artists, like Monet and Matisse; however, we also delve into the cultural influence of art found throughout the world.  From paper mache, to paper towel rolls, our artists have the opportunity to work with many traditional and non traditional art mediums to help express their work.   We are currently working on expanding our arts program to bring in talented teaching artists to help continue to develop our scholars in a variety of art forms.

William Wordsworth School P.S. 48Q is an institution where active, hands on, learning takes place throughout every classroom.  The arts (visual, music, theater and dance) are brought to life by classroom teachers each month, as different grade levels present what they have learned with a performance in the auditorium that encompasses singing, dancing, acting, and set/prop design.  Our staff engages all scholars with the various arts as they firmly believe it plays a vital role in the improvement of a scholars' academic achievements and the development of their social skills. Our scholars' education is extended beyond our doors as they take  field trips to various places where they are embraced by the arts and our doors are always open to the strong partnerships of our visiting artists.
	The visual arts program is offered to all grades levels, pre-K to 5th grade.  Scholars are enriched with rigorous lessons that focus on building art skills and techniques, learning about the art that surrounds them and the vocabulary that is used when speaking about art.  It is important that scholars can not only express themselves through the creation of art but that they can discuss and appreciate their own art, and the art of others, using the language of art.  Honing these skills provides confidence and further engagement which can play an integral role in transforming all classrooms into functioning art spaces.

Q44_R3: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q44_R4: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1:
At the present time Public School 50Q has a full time visual arts, drama and music teacher. This year we've also received several grants;   CASA, Arts and Family Engagement and The Arts for English Language Learners and Students grant.  The grant allowed us to provide direct arts instruction to students in the areas of moving image, visual arts, musical theater and dance during day and afterschool hours. 
We have established partnerships with Alvin Ailey, Marquise Studio, ArtsConnection and Society of the Educational Art. 
 Our primary goal is to promote academic excellence and cultural awareness through a strong arts program. It is our vision to challenge all of our students academically and creatively. Our focus is to mesh our students’ cultural knowledge and background into our arts program; thus allowing our students to develop positive attitudes towards self, others, and the community. Additionally, we would like to increase our association with cultural arts organizations with a focus on dance.
Our Principal, Rina Manjarrez is committed to supporting the teaching of the arts.  Her vision is to instill in our students and community a life-long passion for the performing and visual arts that results in personal and professional artistic pursuits throughout their lifetime.

Public School 54Q continues its ongoing partnership with LeAP and Creative Arts Team-CUNY and anticipates a new partnerships with Arts Horizons and Midori for the upcoming school year. This year we were able to fund a Paraprofessional, currently completing her Visual Arts Degree/State Certification in Visual Arts to work with students across Grades K-5. We were able to support multiple projects through our partnership with Material For The Arts and fundraising. Teacher Cohorts regularly attend MFTA workshops and the school integrates art across content areas thorugh interdisciplinary units. Music and movement is infused throughout our physical education program; classroom activities; monthly assemblies and concerts. PTA executive board and parent volunteers continue to support our movie nights, assemblies and performances. We try to enlist all the in-house talents of our diverse staff and each morning children are welcomed to classical renditions by one of our paraprofessionals on the piano. Student Council regularly consults with the broader student constituency and we continue the tradition of "An Afternoon of Art" each Friday. Councilwoman Koslowitz has generously continued to support our partnership with CAE and we look forward to the same in the upcoming school year. We have a grant team who is working on securing  additional parent engagement opportunities.  We are constantly seeking additional partners to provide additional Art experiences for our students during our After-School Programming.

The P.S. 55Q. school community provides a warm and welcoming climate and culture where students are engaged in the arts through project-based units in grades Pre k through 5th. Their visual arts projects titivates the halls of our school and creativity and expressionism is displayed. In our program, students are engaged in role playing, skit writing and performance of some of our favorite stories. We also use technology to share our understanding of important concepts through the use of computers and art based software such as iMovie. We provide a centers based approach to learning for all students where classroom teachers and teachers of the arts work collaboratively in a projects based learning environment. Students can then make clear connections to the curriculum and generate a strong understanding of the "big ideas" we study. Our communication through the Arts program provides students with the opportunity to engage in visual arts, learn about different types of styles from famous and accomplished artists,art elements and principles through multiple modalities. Our teachers provide all students with the opportunity to write and perform their own pieces of drama. We make continuous effort to expose students to different performances offered in New York City,we invite performance artists and authors into our school to share their craft with students, as well as observing theater based performances as well. We strive to create global learners for the 21st century.
Q47_1: Our students that are in grades Pre-K to 5th,  are a diverse and energetic mix of kids from various ethnic groups that display interest in all aspects of visual arts. Our school community is located in a low socio-economic area of South Richmond Hill, NY. There aren’t any places for kids to experience art. Many of our students are ENL, special needs or new immigrants. The families of these students lack the means to take advantage of the culture in NYC. Many of the parents work more than one job and/or do not speak English. This makes it hard for them to take their children to museums, book signings or meet/greets for authors, theaters and other visual art experiences.  The parents and the students appreciate the culture and experiences that will last a lifetime that is provided by our school community. Our art program supports our new Magnet school title, The Maure Magnet School of Multimedia through Communication Arts and Technology.

Q46_1: Our art program provides instruction in fine arts and performing arts, with opportunities to attend cultural events. Students perform at in-school concerts and assemblies as well as outside of school performances. There is an end of year Arts Concert and Gallery Exhibit. Our students are afforded the opportunity to participate in multiple arts activities before and after-school through partnerships with: Alvin Ailey Ballet, Queens Symphony Orchestra, and Lincoln Jazz Center.

This year our school participated in several art residency programs. We partnered with Alvin Ailey through the CASA Grant to bring an after-school program to our second through fifth grade students. Ailey also provided the community with two assemblies, a family fun night and a the student who participated also performed for the school community.

We also partnered with Marquis Studios for three residencies. Our grade three schools learned dance to the Lion King. Our grade four scholars created visual art based on the Lion King and our fifth grade scholars learned songs from the Lion King. All three grades came together for a culminating performance of the Lion King with standing room only in the audience.

Our second through fifth grade scholars participate in a lunch/recess dance ensemble that has performed at the Universoul Circus and Great Adventures in additional to providing the school community with a winter and spring performance.

The music teacher has a chorus that also performs for the winter and spring concert. In addition to the chorus there is a music club where the scholars learn to play the recorder. Ms. Manigault works with the recorder ensemble daily and every year they play with students from across the city at Carnegie Hall.

Each grade also present an assembly for their peers during the school year.

Q44_R3: Paul Taylor's American Modern Dance Theatre
Q44_R5: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1:
At P.S. 82Q, it is our goal to consistently advance and enhance the level of student participation in the arts and technology. We have a new dance teacher added to our table of organization this school year and have been able to coordinate with different organizations, in an effort to advance the quantity and quality of arts instruction provide to our students. We write grants, reach out to our local politicians and look to resources available in the community to allow the opportunity to expose students to ballet, theater, chorus and other forms of dance. We aim to continue to build relationships with organizations such as Marquis Studios, JCAL and Lincoln Theater, in an effort to further our arts exposure. 
We are fortunate enough to have classroom teachers who are very artistic, and we worked collaboratively as a school to incorporate art into our curriculum. Some of the ways in which we do this is by having monthly themes, door contest and other events which allow students to promote their artistic abilities and enhance the school environment. Our English Language Learners have an art program imbedded into their Saturday program, in which they learn about different artist and then replicate some of their famous pieces. 
The ARTs are important to us at the PS82 school community and we treat as a language, which allows children to express themselves.

Q39_4: Parent Coordinator: Fashion Show, Sewing/arts and crafts for parents.
Q46_1: Public School 86 Queens strives to improve its arts programming each year. Our music teacher is a certified music professional who is trained and knowledgeable in instrumental, chorus, and in the creation of musical scores with the students. Our lessons are interdisciplinary, and our ongoing curriculum writing enables us to improve our shows and assemblies, while supporting the arts. The theater arts teacher encompasses the arts, theater, through literacy. In addition to the students learning and growing, our parent involvement has increased with each passing year through the arts and craft sessions provided by the parent coordinator. We encourage parents to participate in arts/crafts, tutorials, museum trips, and live day and evening performances. Our multicultural fashion show in March, depicts the fashion, art, dance moves, and music of all the countries represented in our community. Our music teacher has immersed our third, fourth and fifth grade students with learning the guitar. Our fifth-grade chorus has performed at The National Choral Festival each year for the past five years.  The second graders participated in a 14-week residency with TADA!  Also, through the Jamaica Arts Center, The CASA grant program was awarded, and 40 ESL students participated in an afterschool Theatre/Visual Arts program. Overall, the students have the opportunity to become inspired while becoming lifelong learners through the arts.

For the 2018/2019 school year, Public School 99 plans to continue to teach, support and experience all four art forms according to the NYS Standards for the Arts and The NYC Blueprint, while emphasizing the Common Core. The arts are integrated into every area of the curriculum. Continued planning, conferencing and reporting by teachers at professional development meetings (e.g. grade conferences, literacy meetings, technology summits) will be continued and encouraged. Support for the arts are evident with our cultural partnerships and our parent involvement programs in the arts. Student work, assemblies, exhibitions, dramatization fairs and trips are integral to educating the whole child. Community connections are also emphasized through newsletters, bulletins and invitations to our school-wide cultural events. Our assessments will be ongoing, collaborative and directed toward enhanced student learning in the arts.

Over the years our school has established professional collaborations with outside organizations. These collaborations provide academic and recreational enrichment for our students, and support our staff and instructional goals. Currently, we are partnered with: Queens College, Jazz Standard, Little Orchestra Society, American Ballroom Dancing and NY Pops. We have done fund-raising with and for: Penny Harvest, City Harvest, and St. Jude’s Hospital. Our parents association has provided several arts residencies for students in kindergarten through sixth grade to enrich the curriculum

The visual arts teachers in our school provide our students with an extensive art education that is aligned with the Common Core Standards, NYS Art Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. The culminating projects are displayed throughout the school building and semi-annually at the Superintendent's office. Some of our students' artwork has been entered into and been selected as semi-finalists and finalists in borough-wide and city-wide art competitions. Classroom teachers support the arts and make connections to the arts within their curriculum. They welcome artist residencies into their classrooms and aid in arts activities/performances. In addition to our daily art program/artist residencies, our school provides several arts related after-school programs. These programs allow students to display artwork and scenery and participate in dramatic performances.

We have a dance program with a full time dance teacher. We also have a visual arts program with a full time visual arts teacher. Our arts program goals are to ensure that exceptional works of art are created and performed. In order to provide more opportunities for participation in arts experiences and to guarantee that arts education is a part of all our students' learning experiences we have a dance, theater, music photography and art club that meet every Friday, during the school day. We also offer after school programs in dance, cheer, yoga, fitness through movement, crafting and chorus. Our chorus sings at various events such as school concerts, basketball games and community events. We have a state of the art dance studio dedicated to our dance program. We have many art residencies, ranging from circus arts/theater, bhangra dance, taiko drumming and latin percussion. We hold parent child arts workshops in hip hop dance, bollywood dance, Taiko drumming and percussion.

We are committed to high standards in arts education. The arts help children learn creativity, confidence, self-expression, thinking skills, and a joy for learning. We provide arts education by following the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts Benchmarks. Our glee club performed in two concerts, kindergarten students presented a choral concert and first grade students performed circus acts. Our second grade participated in Dances around the World and our third grade participated in Hip Hop. Our fourth grade students learned to play recorders and participated in a robotics residency. The fifth grade students studied ballroom dancing and participated in a musical spectacular. Our fourth and fifth grade students competed in Music Memory. The International Festival celebrated the diversity of our school through the performing arts. The Ezra Jack Keats Competition motivated our students to write and illustrate childrens' books. Our art teacher created projects with the students and the technology teacher embedded visual arts with technology content. One visit to our school speaks for itself

School’s Arts Program Description 2017-2018
(To be published in Arts Report)

In the 2017-2018 school year we have provided all students in grades pre-kindergarten through grade five with many opportunities in the arts. All of our students received a class in visual arts and music. Learning experiences included playing instruments such as the recorders and the drums in addition to performing a variety of showcases. The students put on several performances throughout the school year. In our arts class the students are exposed to a variety of materials, techniques, learn about different styles of art and write about their art work using academic vocabulary to enrich their writing pieces. In our continued partnership with Marquis Studio the students used technology to create architectural forms. Our goal for next year is to expand our arts program, integrating the arts with science and social studies through project based learning activities.  This year 1017-2018 we were able to hire a part time music teacher to teach students in grade Three through Five, how to read music and  expand our instrumental music program. Next year we look forward to hiring a dance instructor to support students from different ethnic backgrounds. This teacher would teach students how to share their culture through physical movement.
Q47_1: At P.S. 140 Queens- The Magnet School of Science, Technology and the Arts is composed of approximately 470 students. The students come from various ethnic backgrounds such as  Africans Americans, Hispanic,  and Asians. Recently our school was awarded a Magnet Grant in order to change the demographics of our school. In 2017 the students designed the new playground by drawing and creating scales.Already this year, our students were involved in Project Based Learning  in  which the students are  involved in developing   Projects which will teach and present ways to preserve the new playground.

Q46_1: This school has submitted the following description of its arts program: This school has submitted the following description of its arts program:The arts program at P.S.144 is a comprehensive, sequential program aligned to the New York City Blueprint for the Arts, and reflects all of the major arts disciplines including visual arts, music, theater and dance. We believe that the arts are an integral part of learning and through these interdisciplinary experiences, children develop their creativity, learn problem solving skills and become critical thinkers. The art teacher specialists provide instruction in artmaking and skill development. Our strong collaborations with our cultural organization partners like the Guggenheim Museum and the Queens Museum of Art have helped us build meaningful arts curriculum that is reflected in classroom practice.Through residencies, performances, museum visits and workshops, students, teachers and families are immersed in exciting arts experiences throughout New York City.
Q47_1: As our school population grows, and we look forward to the future expansion of our building now in progress, we hope to build on our existing foundation of quality arts programs. The additional physical space will enable us to offer more exciting programming for students, teachers and families.

Q46_1: At P.S. 160 all students are engaged in a diverse set of experiences in the arts. Students create and conduct their own investigations, analyze data and draw conclusions. Culminating activities mirror productions in theater, dance, architecture, engineering and music. The students are given many opportunities to showcase their artistic talents. The children, along with the visual arts specialist, designed and implemented a museum featuring their artwork in the school cafeteria. With the music specialist, students in first and second grade learned to play the piano, with a culminating recital at the end of second grade. Students in grade three learned to play the recorder while students in grades four and five learned the ukulele through individualized programs that encourage peer instruction. The dance specialist worked with all grades introducing multicultural dance styles. Ongoing relationships with skilled artists and musicians enable students to become artistic and independent critical thinkers. The Magnet Program, through collaborations with organizations such as the Turtle Bay Music School, Dancing Classrooms, Midori, Alvin Ailey’s Arts in Education and Community Programs, taps the rich resources in New York City to bring in-depth experiences that are not available elsewhere. Arts instruction at P.S. 160 is delivered through discrete classes conducted by musicians, dancers and licensed teachers who are specialists in the arts. At the same time, the arts are integrated into thematic units across the curriculum.

The Common Core Learning Standards has changed the way we think about instruction. We now expect students to think critically and develop a deeper understanding of complex topics. Students develop a keener appreciation for unfamiliar topics. Teachers infuse the arts into their instruction, making the subjects more relevant. Through this modality, the children more readily develop an appreciation of abstract concepts and extend their understanding of those previously mastered. With this in mind, we have adjusted our curriculum to include singing, dancing, performing, and the visual arts. Our students have the opportunity to incorporate the arts into other subjects, making topics come alive. They become active learners, ready to engage in activities that support higher order learning. They also cultivate an interest in unfamiliar concepts. They build background knowledge and develop intellectual curiosity. New York City is a treasure for art enthusiasts. Our students venture off school grounds to watch dance and choral presentations.

The arts program at the Metropolitan Expeditionary Learning School (MELS) is comprised of year-long courses in instrumental music (orchestral and rock instruments), and visual arts for all students in sixth and seventh grade. Beginning in eighth grade, students may also elect vocal music and all courses continue in sequence to the AP level. Central to the arts at MELS is an emphasis on the relationship between the arts and the world, characterized by the full integration of the arts into the school’s interdisciplinary, community-action oriented curriculum. In 2016-2017, students participated in a gallery exhibition, the annual fall arts, Coffee House Showcase, Battle of the Bands competition, and an elementary school orchestra tour. Additionally, MELS offers after school programs in rap crew, art portfolio, and jazz ensemble.

At Public School 174, we strive to provide access to a high quality arts program. Our students are learning about all forms of art, artists, and diverse cultures. All are inspired to communicate their own ideas through creating original art. Our students are making connections to concepts in other subjects such as math, science, language arts and social studies. Our students are performing classic as well as original productions through movement, music, and language. They interact with peers, teachers, and professionals in both school and life settings. Our students reflect on all forms of their learning through demonstration, replication, presentation, performance and display.
Q47_1:
Our clusters include: certified visual arts, certified library media, STEM science, performing arts (dance, theater, music) and two physical education teachers (one certified PE.) This enrichment is supplemented by residencies from many of the most prestigious NYC arts agencies.

Teachers write many grants to supplement funding for arts materials and residency fees. Additional support is provided by fundraising from the Parents Association as well as from NYC and NYS Legislative grants.

Our student population is diverse - includes students who are ENL (30%) SE (12%) and G&T (20%.)

Q46_1:
Our Arts program continues to grow and flourish.  During the school day student learning is facilitated by several certified art teachers: visual arts (1), vocal music and performing arts (1), and instrumental music (1). Certified art teachers and classroom teachers collaborate and articulate goals and high expectations for all students.  Students present their talents in the school auditorium during concerts and performances. The Art Gallery is presented in the school gymnasium. Student family members are encouraged to attend.
Various funding sources support in school Arts Residency programs.  Mark DeGarmo Dance Studio facilitated dance for all identified English Language Learners students and Students with Disabilities.  All kindergarten and first grade students participated in New York Pops.  Participation included "Kids in the Balcony" and "Kids in the Stadium" programs. Jazz at Lincoln Center integrated grade four social studies with music.  Dancing Classrooms introduced formal ballroom dancing to all grade five students.  A third grade class participated in the Morgan Library Book Making Project. All third graders participated in the Marquis Studio African Market Place Project. All fourth graders played recorders. Cool Culture Family Program supported adults and children in exploring ninety New York City cultural venues.  A fourth grade class participated in the Rubin Museum Mandala project. In fall 2018 our school will receive a Sing for Hope Piano. Thirty students participated in CASA Musical Theater After School.
Q47_1:
Our school is diverse in student population and staff members who support all students.  Our school does not qualify for Title 1 funds.  

Dance. theater art and museum programs are provided by cultural arts residency program teaching artists.  

Field trip content and concepts are integrated into the curriculum to support multiple entry points for all students.  Field trip admission costs are a burden.  

All students would benefit from centrally funded certified arts teachers along with visual arts, vocal music, dance, theater, and instrumental music residency programs. 

Central funded teachers should also include "Literacy K-2", "Computers for All" and "Algebra for All."

Staff members will continue to apply for Grants and Foundation Programs.

Like literacy and mathematics arts education is vital for all students.

Our role and responsibility as educators is to prepare students to be life long learners who are healthy, happy and productive citizens.

Q46_1: P.S. 182 continued its Project Quest initiative this school year. Students received intense interdisciplinary instruction through art investigation and exploration in the areas of visual arts, music, dance, and theater. Instruction is led by professional artists and classroom teachers and is programmed into extended learning time. This year, approximately 150 third, fourth, and fifth grade classes participated in Quest.

We currently have a full arts program including dance, chorus, band and visual art. Our students participate in the community at local stores during the holidays, local senior centers, local libraries and NYSMA. Our student created art work is displayed in the District 28 office as well as local libraries. Many of our students audition for and are accepted to Specialized Arts High Schools including Frank Sinatra and LaGuardia High School.

We relate art and music to all curriculum areas to align with the new Common Core Learning Standards. It is important for students to have an in-depth understanding of the formal elements of design which will be used in each project they work on. Students will learn to understand new ways of expressing themselves through various cultures and techniques. More importantly, the children should develop a sense of achievement. Achievement instills confidence which raises self esteem.

Our school community is dedicated to the arts as it benefits our students emotionally, socially, and physically. The arts programs develop childrens' creative minds and technical abilities. Through our visual arts program students explore various media such as painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, and 2D/graphic design. They develop an understanding of the elements of art and the principles of design, as well as deepen their expressive and critical skills. Choral and instrumental music allow students to develop critical insights, engage in music learning and making within the school community, becoming lifelong learners and advocates for music. Our dance program teaches students to become literate in dance and connect creatively to other arts and disciplines suc as technology and health. Engagement in dance learning within the school community, helps students become lifelong learners and advocates for dance. The Green Magnet Production Company teaches students to create sustainable lives. They work to beautify our school, reduce our carbon footprint, and look at global and social issues. Our Technology and Moving Image Program teaches students digital citizenship and awareness of their digital footprint. Students learn to engage in this digital age. Performing students participate in two large scale productions each year that showcase their talents and skills. Many of our students go on to arts high schools, and every student becomes thoughtful and engaged participants in the arts throughout their lives.

We encourage our teachers to take their students to visit museums and cultural events throughout the year. We welcome Jazz at Lincoln Center into our school to perform for our students. Outside sources such as Ballet Tech work with our students, introducing them to the joy of dancing and develop an interest to continue in dance. Our school fosters an environment where art is displayed throughout our building. We believe that experiences in the arts promotes cultural awareness.  It also provides an outlet for self expression which our students may other otherwise never be exposed to.

The mission of York Early College Academy (YECA) is to provide a highly supportive and academically challenging learning environment for traditionally under-served, but strongly motivated students who are committed to college and career success. Our vision is to develop the next generation of forward thinking, tenacious leaders who are socially responsive to their communities. As such, we believe that the arts are essential to meeting these goals. 


We offer Music, Art and Drama on both the middle and high school level. Our curriculum emphasizes the freedom to create, discover, self-express, and work in collaboration through direct engagement in arts making. In addition, we seek to explore the full contextual role of the arts as a societal mirror both historically and today. Our ideal is to make participation in the arts a meaning making process that may lead to vibrant life-long cultural participation. 

At YECA our arts programs act as builders of culture and community imbuing our halls with the energy of self-reliance, creativity and discovery that makes the arts so valuable.

The Emerson School Art Program is being reforged to increase the intrinsic motivation of the students in 6th, 7th and 8th grade and the quality of work that they can learn to produce. The main goal of our program is to give the students the basic tools that they need to create great personal works of art and strive to grow as an artist. An important part of this is to keep students interested by molding the projects we do to the interests of the majority of the students, while also keeping the principles of design and basic skills frimley in place. 
Our art program covers the foundation of art with a Drawing unit, Color Unit and a Painting unit. With our drawing unit we go over the basics of line but reach the technique of drawing in 3D.  In our color unit we touch on the basics of color but also dive into the realm of optical illusions. Our Painting unit focuses on learning how paint works together and how to paint in a certain style. After completion, some of the best or most improved art students finish will be hung in the hallway and some will be hung within the main office. 
Fluidity is important in the production of art, the same can be said about the curriculum the students must follow. In order to keep them enthralled with the creation of artwork the curriculum would be well to do to change if necessary or to alter a project to fit the students better. We don't want art to be stale, it needs to be able to meet the needs of its audience and those needs are ever changing and growing in a middle school setting.

The Academy for Excellence through the Arts provides all students, in pre-k through third grade, with a comprehensive visual and performing arts program. Wingspan Arts provides an in-house visual arts residency and all Kindergarten through third grade students participate. Second and third grade students participate in Literacy through Art and Music and, as a culminating event, students and parents participate and perform in a 1920s living museum event. Students participated in a twelve week residency program with the NY Pops and 92nd Street Y. Second grade students also worked with NY Pops for a 20 week residency

Jamaica Children's School is committed to arts education. Every student has visual art twice weekly and music every week. Children have the opportunity to explore a variety of art media including painting and sculpture. Each month they learn about a different artist and analyze their work. In music, children learn about instruments, musicians, and cultural music from around the world. They explore a variety of instruments and learn new songs. Children perform several times a year for their peers and families. Additionally, all students participate in a weekly Community Meeting. During this time, children participate in dance and theater connected to our core values. As we continue to grow and add new grades to our school, we look forward to developing a full performing arts program.

Hillside Arts and Letters Academy is an arts-themed school that integrates arts into all academic classes, and provides a rich variety of arts themed curriculum both during and after school. Students select visual arts, music, or creative writing and are provided with arts instruction every day as ninth and tenth graders. Tenth and eleventh grade students select into arts themed advisories. Students also participate in extracurricular arts instruction, including HALA NOW, and an after-school arts collective run in collaboration with The Queens Museum of Art. Lincoln Center provides the Learning English and Drama program to ELL students. In addition, students also participate in Drama Club, Mural Club and Dance Club. Students at HALA have the opportunity to earn a Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma with Distinction in the Arts.

We focus on music in the form of Introduction to Music and Music History classes. These are required for all students. Additionally, we have ensemble classes based on student interest: Rock Band Ensemble, Jazz Band Ensemble and String Ensemble. Students in each of the ensemble classes perform in culminating concerts at the end of the semester. Additionally, we provide students with photography classes and 3D modeling. This year, we introduced a visual arts class that includes sculpting, drawing and photography through a partnership with Abrons Art Program

During the 2017-2018 school year, our school provided sixth through eighth grade students with a purposeful art education. Students were provided with a full time NYS licensed art teacher and a full-time NYS licensed music teacher. Each student took a visual arts class over the course of this school year. Eighth grade students were provided with music or visual arts for a full year. Students had the opportunity to participate in our Broadway Junior program, allowing them to gain insight and experience within theater. Overall, we hope to continue to grow our arts program in the 2018-2019 school year. We will continue to participate in the Broadway Junior program as well

Q44_R1_C10: Organization brings animals to the classroom
Q46_1: The Ezra Jack Keats Pre-K Centers will continue to provide the students with rich exposure to the arts.  All students receive dance instruction that includes music and movement as well as zumba and yoga.  Seven to eight times per year we host visiting arts organizations to provide shows for our students. Some of the organizations we partner with are Alley Pond Environmental Center, Encore Performances, The Shadow Box Theatre and the Capulli Mexican Dance Troupe.

We have a dual licensed ELA-Theater Arts teacher that teaches 2 sections of Arts/Theater per trimester. She also partnered with the Atlantic Theater Company which provided multiple off-site opportunities.

Public School 349 currently serves students in pre-kindergarten through second grade. Providing various forms of arts instruction to all of our students is an important part of our school educational philosophy. Our music program, Music and the Brain, continues to provide our students with music instruction designed to develop their proficiency in language, reading, math, and cognition. We have partnered with Turtle Bay Music School as well as Marquis Studios to provide our students with residencies in architecture, Brazilian and Colombian rhythm and dance, puppetry, yoga, and collage. As recipients of a federal STEAM Magnet grant, we are in the process of further strengthening our Arts education program in the coming years.

Q44_R4: National Museum of African American History
Q46_1:
Our school now has four school bands: three concert bands (beginner, intermediate, and advanced) and a jazz band. The bands competed in the Six Flags New England Music in the Parks Competition. Students were also exposed to the arts through the improvisation theater class and the photography class. The computer class is related to the arts through its web design component. Students also have the opportunity to participate in the school's cultural show which includes performances in dance, spoken word, vocal music, and instrumental music.
Students also attended several Arts-related field trips in state and out of state.

The arts program fully embraces STEM to STEAM as our model. The objective of the STEAM movement is to transform research policy to place Art and Design at the center of STEM and encourage integration of Art and Design across all subject areas. This goal is achieved through project-based learning throughout the arts program which is integrated with the curriculum of all students grades pre-k through grade five. The arts program also includes chorus to further expand the arts as a foundation in our student learning. Our strong partnership with Marquis Studios supports student engagement in many forms of visual and performing arts, including but not limited to architecture, puppetry, and music
Q47_1: We are a STEM school. We encourage all forms of architecture across every grade. Teacher volunteers run early morning dance and cheer leading clubs for grades 3 through 5. Both are performing groups.

Q46_1:
Our arts offerings at MS 358 consist of Dance and Theater, with additional residencies in Visual Arts and after school programs in Music and Step. 

All 6th graders take Dance, while more serious Dance students can Major in Dance in 7th and 8th Grade. This year, 6th grade students participated in a 15 session Flamenco Residency with Flamenco Vivo, culminating in a performance at our school. Dance Majors attend dance class during the school day, as well as after school. Dance Majors perform in school assemblies, during the Spring Fling Arts festival and in off campus opportunities.

This year Theater was offered for the first time to 8th Graders. Music students are enrolled in the Harmony Program after school and study violin, cello and viola. Harmony students perform in school assemblies as well as at off campus events. The MS 358 Step Team, The Phoenix Steppers, started this year as well. The Phoenix Steppers have performed in the Spring Fling Arts Festival and practice after school. Each grade received a Materials for the Arts residency this year, during which students created art projects that connected to their Project Based Learning Units in their core classes. 

Our vision for the Arts at MS 358 is to expose 100% of our students to all of the arts we have available during 6th grade and offer deeper learning in an art of their choice through Majors for 7th and 8th grades.
Q47_1:
All 6th graders take Dance, while more serious Dance students can Major in Dance in 7th and 8th Grade. This year, 6th grade students participated in a 15 session Flamenco Residency with Flamenco Vivo, culminating in a performance at our school. Dance Majors attend dance class during the school day, as well as after school. Dance Majors perform in school assemblies, during the Spring Fling Arts festival and in off campus opportunities.

This year Theater was offered for the first time to 8th Graders. Music students are enrolled in the Harmony Program after school and study violin, cello and viola. Harmony students perform in school assemblies as well as at off campus events. The MS 358 Step Team, The Phoenix Steppers, started this year as well. The Phoenix Steppers have performed in the Spring Fling Arts Festival and practice after school. Each grade received a Materials for the Arts residency this year, during which students created art projects that connected to their Project Based Learning Units in their core classes. 

This year we inaugurated our first ever Spring Fling Arts Festival. This performance included 90 students and showcased all of the arts in our school including 7th and 8th grade Dance Majors, Phoenix Steppers, The Harmony Orchestra as well as student created acts in singing, dancing and stand up comedy. 

Our Arts goal at MS 358 is to have enough Majors at MS 358 to include every student in the school. Our vision is for all 6th grade students to have the chance to try all of our arts offerings in 6th grade

Q46_1: Forest Hills High School's Academy of Instrumental and Vocal Music and Drama Academy provide students with rigorous conservatory style training and a challenging academic program.  The Academy of Instrumental and Vocal Music provides intensive sequential instruction on all band and orchestral instruments covering music theory, composition, and of course performance practice as well as intensive choral instruction.  Instrumental music students participate in Jazz Band, Beginning Band, Intermediate Band, and Concert Band, Beginning Strings, Intermediate Strings, Symphonic Orchestra, Beginning and Advanced Percussion Ensemble.  Vocal music students participate in Vocal Training, Women's Chorus, and Concert Choir.  Students perform at various events throughout the city including a minimum of the Winter Concert and Spring Arts Festival annually.  The Drama Academy provides students the opportunity to study the dramatic arts through a rigorous and specialized program involving acting, directing, play writing, film making, and play productions.  The Fall and Spring Play Pro theater productions showcase the arts talents of Forest Hills H.S. students.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
Hillcrest High School offers four-year instruction in the Visual, Theater and Musical arts and two of these disciplines culminate in the Regents and/or AP Level classes.  A Variety of levels and electives are offered to the entire student body including string, orchestra, chorus, drum line, fine art, media arts, theater and art history.
Performance and exhibition opportunities include two festivals of the arts, a full production musical and separate senior and junior theater productions at the school. 
Students enter citywide and National Visual and Performing arts contests as part of the school’s programming. There are also multiple partnerships with arts organizations for student courses and internship opportunities throughout their high school career.

All students take art and music for a half year each. Dance is offered within the physical education department and chorus is offered as a club. The art sequence includes required courses in drawing and painting techniques, color theory, and design principles. Students choose from three pathways: Commercial Art, Graphic Communications, and Web Design. Commercial Art students use traditional art media and computer applications, prepare portfolios, take the industry standards-based Skills USA exam, and earn 6 credits from Queensborough Community College. Graphic Communications focuses on the creative use of computer applications, digital photography, and commercial printing, while Web Design focuses on designing for the web, including both hand coding and computer applications. Students take Adobe certification examinations at the end of these sequences. All visual art students have the opportunity to apply for internships and work-based learning opportunities and receive CTE endorsements on their diplomas.

Queens Gateway to Health Sciences Secondary School is a screened school with the emphasis on health careers and the sciences. We have a full-time art teacher providing instruction to students for the required completion of courses in art, which are necessary for graduation.

We offer basic Studio Arts for the required art credit. We also offer a Graphic Design class to students who have passed Studio Arts. This class doubles as a yearbook production class and an advanced art class. Students use skills learned in Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Illustrator to create dynamic layouts in their graphic design projects. These skills enhance our yearbook production.

Q44_R2: Willie Mae Rock Camp for Girls
Q46_1:
Our beginning music course is designed for students experiencing their first vocal/choral class. This level emphasizes fundamental vocal development, music literacy, and the introduction to ensemble singing. The music curriculum addresses the four learning strands. Opportunities are provided for students to explore ways in which the content of the various disciplines, within and outside the arts are interrelated with those of music.

Our studio art course introduces students to the fundamentals of art. Students will be encouraged to explore media and think, talk and write about art. Students will build foundation skills, as well as the beginning of a portfolio, through hands-on practice and assignments. Through a variety lessons students will study line, shape and form, focusing on light, tonal drawing and linear and atmospheric perspective in black and white and color. Students will gain historical and cultural knowledge through their exposure to different artists. Students will learn about art criticism to evaluate self and other’s works.

Q44_R1_C1: Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1:
Performing Arts Program

All students from Pre-K through Grade 5 are involved in our PS15Q Performing Arts, Sports, and Science Programs. These programs are intended to excite the best in our children. We reach out to each child through the identification of their individual gifts and/or talents. We offer students the opportunities to engaged in many activities throughout the school year as well as over the summer. All programs provide students with engaging and meaningful connections to the school day, ensuring that children continue to learn through the Arts. All students participate in the following programs throughout the school year:

* Dance, art, music, theater, and science 2-3 times a week by a specialist.

* Pre-K through Grade 5 performs during monthly assembly programs for their peers, families, and community.

* Two big showcase productions per year which are put on by the Arts Department for the entire school community. Students have opportunities to take part in plays and theater experiences during school as well as after school.

* Talent programs: Additional instruction provided to students interested in the following activities: Dance, Instrumental Music, Chorus, Sports, Art, Coding, Music, Recorders, and Piano lessons.

* STEM Program (Science, technology, engineering, and math)

* Sports Programs: Sports programs take place before, during, and after school hours as well as on weekends. Sports program include: Basketball, soccer, swimming, tennis, flag football, and track

We endeavor to provide our students with experiences to ensure exposure to the arts.  Every student receives instruction in the visual arts.  The culminating activity of the Arts Fair gives the students the opportunity to showcase the work they have completed during the school year.
All classes in grades 1-5 participate in a class play which includes drama, music, and dance.  These performances as well as our annual Dance Festival are highly anticipated by the entire school community.
Our students also attend middle school performances as well as productions by community arts providers. 
Our artist in residence program is dedicated to African Dance and all students in grades 1-5 receive instruction in dance, music, and song.  The residency culminates with a performance to which our entire school community is invited.

Classroom teachers provide arts instruction in their classroom through class participation in school assemblies and presentations such as Singsation and a dance festival. Scholars have been exposed to the visual arts through project-based assignments. Public School 36 third grade students had the opportunity to partner with The New York City Ballet this school year. Our third grade scholars learned the art form of ballet infused with literacy components through the company's Nutcracker Project. Scholars in the First grade are learned weaving concepts as an art form via an art residency. Students in fourth and fifth grade have participated in dance and music clubs. Fourth graders participated in Ballroom dancing classes. Ten scholars in fifth grade participated in an after-school photography club facilitated by The Project Photo Organization. Third grade scholars participated in an after-school art program facilitated by Jamaica Arts Center for Learning.

Public School 37Q, The Cynthia Jenkins School, makes the arts a priority to ensure that students have a nurturing and diverse learning experience. A teacher of visual arts provides instruction to all students in addition to the instruction by classroom teachers to include dance, music and theater.
