The implementation of various art clubs provide enrichment to selected students in second through fifth grade. Field trips and assemblies are used to integrate all four art forms into the students' learning experiences. The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning the Arts is used to guide the implementation of the instructional art program. An interdisciplinary approach to teaching the arts focuses on literacy through social studies connections, self expression and talent development. Students are encouraged to use the arts to understand historical context and study cultural diversity. Students utilize artistic expression and their imagination to practice their skills as speakers, listeners, writers, designers, visual artists, actors, singers, dancers, researchers, critics and collaborators. Parents are invited to participate in art workshops and museum trips. Students' artwork is prominently displayed in hallways and classrooms to celebrate their talents and learning.

Arts education is vitally important to the full development of children. Providing instruction in the arts has many benefits. Arts education can help to improve the students' overall academic performance, as well as develop the skills that are needed for the 21st century: critical thinking, creative problem solving, effective communication, teamwork and more. The arts provide an avenue that allows children to express themselves creatively and lift their self-esteem. Our goal is to help students become more knowledgeable in the four arts disciplines. Through visual arts, music, dance, and theater, students use their imagination make decisions, problem solve, and work cooperatively together in groups. Hands-on learning experiences teach students to make social, cultural and historical connections. By learning to reflect, analyze and evaluate their own, and their classmates' work, those skills are then incorporated into the content areas and the lives of our students.

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: t is the goal of our school to add to our current arts program. We are looking for resources and funding to incorporate dance, music, visual arts and theater.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Artslink up
Q44_R3: Lincoln Center for the Performing Artsmusical explorers
Q46_1: Our visual arts program at Public School 95 Q is focused on literacy-based art experiences aligned with the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Our students develop art skills through exploration of various techniques incorporating the principles and elements of art. Through art critiques, students develop critical thinking skills and speak using the vocabulary of art. The music program in Public School 95 Q is aligned to The Blueprint for the Arts. Our goals for the music program this year was to introduce musical concepts such as rhythm, melody and harmony and have students engaged in practicing and applying the musical concepts by clapping, tapping or singing.

We have continued to offer the students elective dance, band and visual arts classes throughout the grades. Our after school program Centre Stage/Queens Theatre In the Park grant has continued and is ongoing. We would like to have an increase of funds to increase our arts staff and arts programs for the students. An after school instrumental program would be wonderful. Thank you

Public School/Intermediate School 116Q continues to provide students with 2 major art programs. We have a full-time Visual Arts teacher with a dedicated art room. Students in kindergarten through eighth grade receive regular instruction with lessons aligned with the NYC Blueprint. Our art teacher continued attending monthly Arts Mondays Professional Development which focused on writing rubrics for assessment in the Visual Arts. Student work was entered into various contests and exhibition opportunities, through which our students have had the experience of seeing their work on display in a larger community setting. Students won awards through Arts Connection, NYCATA/UFT and the Queens Borough Arts Festival this year, as well as having work exhibited at the annual SQPA/Roy Wilkins Park Exhibit, where they are able to dialog with professional artists from the surrounding community. Due to a federal grant to District 29, our school is also now a part of the Future Arts Initiative, which enhances the incorporation of Contemporary Art forms into visual arts instruction. Our school continues its partnership with Lincoln Center to provide students with engagement in the arts via residencies with teaching artists at our school in music, drama/theater, dance and visual arts. Students see professional performances at Lincoln Center as well as at our school, where families join us to attend family events. This year culminates with our 2nd Annual Spring Art Showcase with Lincoln Center featuring student work and a live concert.

The Multicultural Arts Education Program at the Lorraine Hansberry School continues to flourish, as the young artists learn and apply art making skills while enhancing their work inspired by famous artists from the past and present.  Their engagement and finished products are a testimony to the effects of learning Art History, Art Making and Art Analysis. Art lends itself to generating participation, speaking and listening skills. Also, art enhances focus, concentration, critical thinking and creativity in all students. Our school plans on involving community based organizations, local artists, studios and businesses in participating in enhancing the learning experiences in our school community. Math, science, language arts, social studies and technology are integrated  with the Multicultural Arts Education. The arts such as Dance, Theater, Media, and Visual arts are integrated within the lessons taught by the classroom teachers.

Public School 131 has a strong commitment to arts education and offers many opportunities for its students to experience different arts disciplines. Our arts faculty is fully state certified and provides rigorous, standards-based instruction in conjunction with the Common Core Learning Standards. Providing twenty-five weekly periods of dance instruction, our faculty expanded this year to include a certified dance instructor.  Furthermore, PS131 introduced a hip hop artist in residency program in addition to its already flourishing arts partnerships. Despite functioning at nearly two hundred percent capacity (and currently undergoing renovation), PS131 empowers students to blossom as artists, develop literacy through the arts, cultivate interdisciplinary connections, and grow into adults who pursue the arts as an integral aspect of the human condition.

The Arts program at P.S. 132Q, the Ralph Bunche School strives to provide students with a Common Core aligned and rigorous approach
to Arts education. Instructional outcomes encourage student exploration of the Arts while simultaneously developing their personal skill sets within this area. Various school excursions and activities also strive to further enhance students' art specific abilities. In partnership,these factors serve to help students to develop a lifelong appreciation of the Arts.

This year our art education department has continued to initiate increased  discussion and writing about presented art work as an integral part of lesson planning. Students are encouraged to question, offer encouragement to others, as well as critique their work in a positive manner.
     Students have continued to visit important museums, Grades 2- 
 5 traveling to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The New York Historical Society,as well as The Museum of Modern Art, all providing enriching and cultural experiences that are addressed in lesson planning. Students often recognize work they have seen in these museums in books and internet programs presented.
     Art work has been submitted to a variety of exhibitions, including the PS 2018 Art Show, The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 2018 Annual Art Exhibition, The  Queens Borough Arts Festival, The Disability Pride Parade Visual Art Contest, as well as the 2018 Energy Conservation Program. One fifth grade student was chosen as a semi-finalist for the PS Show, as well as another fifth grader chosen as a finalist for the Queens Museum Exhibition.
     Students continue to develop their artistic skills, utilizing drawing, painting, and sculpture materials. Lesson plans align with the NYC Blueprint for the Visual Arts. Skills continue to develop as students reach benchmarks described within the Blueprint.
     Our school has begun a partnership, working with the NYC Future Arts Initiative.This will continue into the 2018-2019 school year.

PS 135's art program includes instruction in visual arts, drama, dance and music. The arts are integrated into the students day through cluster programs as well as classroom teacher led instruction. Teachers integrate the arts with other subject areas such as English language arts, social studies and science to provide students with learning opportunities that engage all their learning styles. We feel that it is important to expose our students to the world of the creative arts to engage them in learning and help them become a more well rounded individual in life.In addition, this year we have enhanced our Arts programs through various grants. We have a two year dance grant with Marquise Studio where they provide direct instruction to our 2nd and 3rd grade students in Broadway and Bhangra dance styles. We also held a series of parents art workshops where students and their parents worked cooperatively to create a quilt.

Q39_4: Attending Art Classes specifically for parents
Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1:
The Arts Program at PS 136 for the 2017-18 school year has been multi-faceted. We have courses, workshops and activities encompassing the visual arts and performing arts- music, drama and dance. Students in all grades, along with their parents, have an opportunity to participate in a variety of activities.

For the visual arts, we have an Art cluster teacher, who teaches art history along with various styles of sketching, drawing, painting and multimedia works.   Additionally, we have a partnership with the L.E.A.P program, which provides a year long series of workshops for parents and students to teach scrapbooking and quilt making.  

In the performing arts, our dance teacher works with students throughout the year to teach Jazz, African, and Modern dance techniques.   We also have a partnership with Ballet Tech for some of our students to learn ballet techniques. The LEAP program has a drama component as well, and a teacher worked with our students to create a short literacy based play.   We also have residencies with Elite Marching Band and Make Music Count for our students to learn how to play instruments including drums, trumpets, piano and more.   

We also have a PS 136 Show Choir and a partnership with the Jamaica Center for Arts and Learning (JCAL).  They are working with our students to put on a Broadway style short musical to encompass song, dance and drama.

The Arts Program at PS/MS 138Q Sunrise is a growing and changing one that continues to be built. We offer students the opportunity to participate in Dance/Performance Art, Visual Art and Music. Exposure is most important to us as we prepare students for the challenges that they face in the 21st century. We believe that by creating the space for students to choose and decide, we are therefore intentional with our approach for children to access the wide variety of arts.

The Ronald Mc Nair School PS/MS 147Q provides students with an outlet of expression through the arts. The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts is used to guide the implementation of the art instructional program in our school community.  Students in the elementary grades participate in vocal instruction.  Students are able to audition for our Elementary Choir.  Our classroom teachers integrate visual arts throughout units of study in kindergarten through eighth grade.  Visual art instruction is also provided to students in grades five through eighth during art club.  Our theater teacher provides our students in fifth through eighth grade with instruction in theater and set design. Our interdisciplinary approach to teaching the arts is focused on literacy and social studies. Students are encouraged to use the arts to understand historical context and study cultural diversity. Music instruction is provided to our students in sixth through eighth grade. Keyboard and guitar is taught throughout the school year and students have an opportunity to audition for the band which includes drums, wood wind and brass instruments. Our middle school band performs at various school and community events. Students’ artistic talents are celebrated during assembly programs, theater productions, art displays, and district events.

Through a grant given by our local Councilman, we were able to host the DIVAS for Social Justice Program, which is Digital, Interactive, Visual Arts in Sciences. Our classroom teachers incorporated the arts into their curriculum. Our music cluster teacher teaches music appreciation to kindergarten through fifth grade students and works with the chorus. In addition, students visited Carnegie Hall twice this school year, and as a collective, we incorporated theater and art clubs on Friday afternoons. Our goal is to expand our arts program to include dance, more drama, and continue photography.

The ultimate goal of our school arts program is to provide all students with an increased understanding of art history and how art is used to express our feelings and beliefs.  Students will learn to compare diverse art forms and develop a respect for the arts.  In addition students will discover, develop and enhance their personal abilities.

This year at PS 181 our Arts program consisted of children learning  music, visual arts and theater. Our goal here at PS 181 is to introduce and offer public school students the tools to read and play music through classroom keyboard instruction, woodwind and brass instruments.  In addition, to instrument instruction, children also learned to read music, sing and play rhythms using percussion instruments. During our school year we hold several exhibitions where the children are able to perform at assemblies for their peers, parents, family and friends. Each grade also performs an assembly during their assigned month that includes acting, singing and dancing. Our intended goals are to teach our children to develop an appreciation for the arts whether they are taking music, visual arts, media arts, dance and/or theater.
Furthermore, PS 181 has a theater program where the children are taught to sing, act and dance by performing Disney musicals . We are currently in our third year of participating in the Disney Musicals in Schools program. Students learn on stage as well as backstage components of running a full-length production.
Each year moving forward we intend to continue teaching and molding our children here at PS 181 to develop an appreciation and love for all the arts.

The Linden-Renaissance Middle School offers a rich foundation in the arts supported by Black Spectrum Theater. All students enrolled in our school are required to study visual arts and theater. This year grade 6 students focused on dance. Our seventh graders focused on video production in our state-of-the- arts recording studio. Eighth grades select the Arts  The students performed live for their friends, family and community. Our dance have performed citywide and featured in dance competitions.    We support our Arts programs by offering after-school instrumental band, dance club, drama/theater productions, and partnering with the Museum of moving Images specializing in cartooning and animation. All after-school programs have certified arts teachers.

Q39_4: Parents cover the costs for the instrumental music program
Q46_1:
At P.S.195 we have always been committed to offering students a well balanced education in the arts. Early childhood students receive general music instruction by a licensed music teacher. The focus here is on singing, movement, and playing percussion instruments.

Upper elementary students have the opportunity to learn guitar, keyboards, bass, drums or vocals by joining our Little Kids Rock program. Here, students receive small group instruction once per week and perform in several concerts throughout the school year.   

This year all fourth and fifth graders have weekly dance classes with a resident dance specialist from Ifeytayo Cultural Arts Facility. Students will perform what they have learned at our Community Fair On May 19th.    

We also have classes participating in Carnegie Hall's Musical Explorers and Linked-In programs. Here, classroom teachers are trained to teach students to sing and play the recorder. Students are taught a specific repertoire which culminates in an interactive field trip to Carnegie Hall. 

We also offer students Chorus and after school Step Dancing. These students also perform at several concerts throughout the school year.
Q47_1: Since many of our families can't afford private instruction in the arts like their counterparts in the the more affluent suburbs, It is imperative that funding and support for the arts be increased. For most of our students, school based arts programs are the only exposure and training they will receive.

Q46_1: PS/IS 208 have been partnering with Arts Connection for the past eight years.  We began by having Arts Connection Teaching artists lead theater and dance residencies during our arts electives.  Dr. James Philemy believes that the arts are an essential part of middle school education and has set aside time during the school day to make this happen.  Our elective classes include dance, music, art and in the past theater.  This year we used the funding from the ELL/SWD grant to broaden student choice during our electives and included film.  The film class taught our student how to develop, storyboard, film and edit original work.  In the past two years we have begun a musical theater program through an MTI (Music Theater International/Shubert Broadway Jr. grant.  This two year program is designed to assist PS/IS 208 in developing a sustainable, quality theater program.  It engage students in the joyful process of creating musical theater.  It foster a strong educational community as students, staff, and families all "play a role" in the process.  It also encourage the connection of arts programming to curriculum study in all content areas.  Our students performed Fame Jr., Willy Wonka Kids, Shrek Jr. and Hairspray Jr.  These performances allowed our students to tap into their creative side and express themselves in multiple ways.  In addition to acting, singing and dancing, the students created the set design and were in charge of cuing the music for the performances. Arts in schools shapes lives!!

The Susan B. Anthony Academy Arts Program provides vigorous arts learning in visual arts, instrumental music, general music, chorus, dance and digital art through technology and graphic design. Students are given opportunities to participate in various performances and attend trips to art institutions and exhibits during the school year. Our school’s vision is to provide a quality arts program which aligns with the New York City Blueprint for the Arts and the Common Core State Standards. Teacher teams share best practices and incorporate storytelling, history, and technology through the different arts forms. Teachers in the arts department collaborate with their colleagues from other departments to make the arts disciplines an integral and visible part of our school culture.

The Institute for Health Professions at Cambria Heights offers both visual arts and music courses. In art, students examine both health and social issues from current events to create works to bring awareness of these issues to the attention of the public. Through real world applicable projects we create videos, comics, brochures, board games, and street art along with classical artistic skills such as drawing from observation. In music, our students examine the fundamentals of music theory while relating them to their favorite songs. Utilizing these skills students embark on learning how to play the piano while composing their own original song.

The Institute offers avenues for the study of art through our English, science, social studies and mathematics classes at each grade level through our interdisciplinary approach. From using art and engineering to craft their own designed objects in physics to building representation of bridges in geometry students are exposed to a variety of art forms. Artistic expression is also available to students through a variety of clubs, including art, photography, a dance team, and a step team.
Q47_1: The Institute strives to help each student attain an individualized education consistent with the values of leadership, scholarship, and service through building relationships between students, parents, staff, and community partners. Students become artists, historians, scientists, mathematicians, literary scholars, and health care workers by learning to do the work of these disciplines. Collaboration and teamwork are essential elements of an education at The Institute. The faculty works collaboratively to ensure that student needs are being met by constantly learning about the most effective types of instruction and supports to help students meet their learning goals. Students and their families are integral members of The Institute team. Through advisories, students form important relationships with the faculty and play an important role in designing their educational experience.

Q46_1:
This is a full year course that fulfills the New York State Blueprint Visual Arts requirement for graduation. The course is designed as a beginner art class. This class is a pre-requisite for the students wishing to pursue the advanced Art program as well.

Students will be engaged in developing and understanding the basic elements of art such as color, value, space, emphasis, pattern, and shape. They will familiarize themselves with such mediums as drawing, painting, and three dimensional design. The class will explore cross curriculum projects outside of the classroom to help the students understand the topics in other subject areas.

Students develop an appreciation for the history of the Arts through artist from the past, present, and future. The class is equipped with all of the most modern technology to create a great piece of art that the student is comfortable with and confident that it can be put on display around the school, as well as citywide.

We currently have a full time licensed music teacher. Every class receives music instruction at least once a week in the music studio. All students participate in three annually themed arts assemblies. Students also engage in trips that are centered around the arts.

Pathways College Preparatory School in Saint Albans, Queens, offers Dance, Music, and Technology as electives (we currently have a dance vacancy). Electives are programmed for grades 6,7,8,9,11, and 12. 

The schedule is as follows:
Grades 6-8: Elective is held 4x/wk.
Grade 9: Elective is held 3x/wk.
Grades 11 & 12: Elective is held 5x/wk.

All Dance and Music classes are performance-based. Two big concerts are given throughout the year, as well as several smaller performances.

The following curriculum is taught for Music:
Grades 6 & 7: Middle School Choir/Basic Music Literacy
Grades 8 & 9: Percussion
Grades 11 & 12: Modern Band
*recipient of the VH1 Band Grant and ongoing partnership with Little Kids Rock

Dance:
Currently there is a substitute teaching mostly modern technique.

The following curriculum is taught for Music:
Our school is a recipient of an SEP (Software Engineering Program) grant. We have two Mac labs. The students learn block based programming, with emphasis on audio and visual editing.

At Excelsior Preparatory High School we believe that a rich arts program with a strong studio and performance component is essential to the academic growth of our students. One of our goals is to provide each student with a great overall art experience. All bands are proud to play in our school's various assemblies, concerts and contests throughout the year. Our band has also played in concert along with the Five Towns College Concert Band. We are very excited to see the growth of the arts over the last few years, and will continue to strive for growth. Currently we offer studio and media arts courses, Concert Band, and Advanced Band. We hope to incorporate AP Studio art courses in the future.

The arts are an integral part of Public School/Intermediate School 268's curriculum. We strive to fully realize the goals and objectives of the Blueprint for the Arts and enrich the academic program. We meaningfully integrate the arts into all curriculum areas to enhance learning. Students in grades three through five have the opportunity to participate in the Creative Arts Team theater program.  Students in fourth and eighth grade participated in CAE's Arts Engage Initiative. This program uses drama to support the social studies curriculum.  Disney Musical in Schools has assisted us in creating a sustainable theater program. Visual Arts students had their artwork showcased at the Queens Borough Art Show. Students in grades four through eight had the opportunity to be part of the AMP UP NYC and Little Kids Rock Modern Band program. Dance students had the opportunity to perform at Queens Borough Art Show. Students in grades seven and eight are provided with opportunities to specialize in one art form. They are supported in creating portfolios and preparing for auditions if they are applying to a specialized art school.

The Gordon Parks School for Inquisitive Minds Arts Program continues to inspire and encourage excellence. Students in Kindergarten through grade 5 received instruction in at least two separate arts disciplines. Students in grades 6 through 8 receive instruction in 3 separate arts disciplines, allowing them to complete a 3 year sequence of instruction in Dance, Instrumental Music, and Visual Arts. Extracurricular arts programs are available before, during, and after the school day in Dance, Music, Visual Arts, and Theater (through an association with Disney Jr.)

Q47_1:
STUDIO ART

This is a full year course that fulfills the New York State requirement for graduation. 
The course is designed as a beginner art class. This class is a pre-requisite for the students wishing to pursue the advanced Art program as well. 
Students will be engaged in developing and understanding the basic elements of art such as color, value, space, emphasis, pattern, and shape. They will familiarize themselves with such mediums as drawing, painting, printmaking, and watercolors. The class will explore cross curriculum projects outside of the classroom to help the students understand the topics in other subject areas . 
Students develop an appreciation for the history of the Arts through artist from the past, present, and future.  The class is equipped with all of the most modern technology to create a great piece of art that the student is comfortable with and confident that it can be put on display around the school, as well as citywide.

Q46_1: The Preparatory Academy for Writers offers theater arts and audio/video production classes to both high school and middle school students. An audio club, a production club and an acting group are open to all students. Additionally, we have talent shows twice a year. This year, we introduced a moving image/video production program which allows students to collaboratively create short films and participate in all aspects of the production process from pre-production planning to post-production editing. Student films are screened and shared out with the school as part of a showcase. Additionally, students receive Theatre Arts classes twice a week and dance classes three times per week and are given the opportunity to perform these culminating performance projects in school wide events.

Q39_4: Multiple Art  Parent Workshop, Art Exhibits & Displays

Q46_1: Our school is a Career & Technical Education School with a focus on Information Technology and Finance. Our arts courses are technology based. We offer Graphic Design, Web Design and the Adobe Photoshop certification. We also provide arts opportunities through clubs and after-school classes which are supported by The Future Project, a not for profit CBO we work with.

Cambria Heights Academy art teachers propose elective art courses to our student body, and art courses open based on student interest. To date we've offered digital media, digital photo, graphic design, drawing, mixed media, chorus, origami, film, theatre arts, and three dimensional sculpture classes. We are constantly expanding our elective course offerings.

During the first quarter of school, sixth grade students are introduced to the following art forms: dance, music, and visual arts. During this time, the arts department staff holds auditions in which students gain admission into one studio for the duration of their time at school. Each student has studios schedule 4 period a week. Each studio holds a Winter and Spring showcase which displays the student talent and work. Our goal is to provide a comprehensive education the the arts as well as prepare the students for entry into a competitive arts high school.

The current art program at our school provided multiple opportunities for our students to explore their creative talents and express themselves. Our art teacher Mrs. Quinonez works diligently to seek out opportunities for our students in the community and introduces school wide projects that enhances our building's appearance. Students are proud to see their projects and art work adorning the walls as they transition through the building. 
Our music teacher Ms. Horry, has worked with a choir this year to unlock the singing talents of some of our students. Additionally, she was instrumental in getting the Sing for Hope company to donate a piano to our school decorated by the cast of the Broadway show Chicago. Ms. Horry also worked with our 8th graders to write their own song that they will perform during their graduation ceremony. 
Ms. Hunte volunteers her time to train a dance and drama team whose performances have gotten them invited to multiple venues in the district. She worked with other staff members and students to create an original script for Black History Month which was well received by the school community. 
Next year I would like our arts program to continue replicating the great things that they are doing. We plan on incorporating the arts when planning our project based learning units. In addition we would like our students to put on performances using the instruments that they practice on during music class.

P.S. 360Q currently has a full time licensed music teacher. Every class receives music at least twice a week. Students are currently receiving keyboard instruction. All students participate in assemblies throughout the school year. The music program at P.S. 360 is aligned to the NYC DOE Blueprint for the Arts.

At Mathematics, Science Research and Technology High School, the arts program has been integrated into the CORE curriculum. Teachers are planning integrated lessons with the art, Dance, and Music Teacher.  Students are exposed to different forms of arts such as dance, music, visual art, and theater. They visit the American Museum of Natural History, Brooklyn Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern Art and other institutions such as The Brooklyn Academy of Music, Carnegie Hall, Repertorio (Latino Theater) and Manhattan Theater Club. The school has created partnerships with these organizations. In the past, artists had visit classrooms to discuss their art work. Students are continuing making connections with the socio-cultural and historical significance of theater. This year, Mathematics, Science Research and Technology High School's goals are to integrate arts into all content areas and create partnerships with various arts organizations to enrich the culture of our students. Students are able to express themselves through the arts and build skills and knowledge in a variety of forms. The arts enrich our learning community.

Q44_R1_C1: Circle in the Square Theatre School
Q46_1: Our incoming 9th grade students experience all three art forms in their freshmen year and decide on a major and pursue a sequence in that major that culminates in taking the city arts assessment in June for that selected arts major.
Q47_1: N/A

Q39_4: Attend parent workshops and family fun activities
Q46_1: One of our goals for the art programs at Public School 2Q is to create opportunities for students to recognize the social, cultural, and historical significance of art, and connect the arts to other disciplines. In order to do this, students must be taught to refine their observation, develop problem–solving skills, build a more extensive visual vocabulary, read and write about art to reinforce literacy skills and interpret the arts through discussion. This is achieved through a differentiated and multi-sensory approach to learning. Not only do our classroom teachers teach various art forms throughout the year in content areas, we are also fortunate enough to have community-based arts partnerships as well. Another goal at P.S. 2Q is to continue the current partnerships, to expand the programs offered to include more students, and to add more variety to the programs offered. We were very grateful to provide multiple programs to our students this year, including visual arts instruction, dance, music, and dramatic arts. Through these partnerships we hope to offer students exposure to a variety of art forms and media through weekly sessions with resident artists, field trips and school art projects. Finally, we strive for our students to become lifelong learners and advocates for the arts.

Intermediate School 10Q provides a full theater program that instructs the students in the various aspects of theater production; i.e., stage management, costume design, props, scenic design and acting. The visual art classes provide the students with exploration in the areas of two dimensional drawing, sculpting, and drafting. In the chorus class, the students are able to explore the world of music by learning how to read sheet music, and perform using only the strength and tone of their voices. With the addition of guitar classes, and percussion session, our music classes have gained strength and popularity among the students.

Our goal is to use the NYC DOE Blueprint as a guide to reinforce the arts and its cultural significance in the students' everyday lives. Students are exposed to different artistic styles within the fine arts as well as within the folk art traditions. Students are intellectually engaged during arts instruction while mastering art making techniques. Students are motivated to make meaningful connections to other content areas and are being prepared to become college ready and competitive in the world beyond academia.

At Public School 17 we believe that the arts are essential to a child's academic and social-emotional development. Our arts teachers' classes provide children with opportunities to participate in band, keyboarding, recorder lessons, visual arts, and theater performances. Our arts partners include: Alvin Ailey, Music and the Brain, Brikz for Kids, Ailey pond, Rosie Theater Kids, Community Word, Studio in a School, NY Cares, CASA, Flushing Town Hall, Carnegie Hall and Disney Musicals in Schools.

The arts are valued and thriving at PS 69Q, “The School of Cultural & Performing Arts”. Our students are engaged in multiple arts and enrichment activities that reflect our diverse and multicultural school community. Grants with our arts partner City Lore brought residencies in songwriting, African dance, music and visual arts to our students. Two CASA grants afforded students instruction in traditional Mexican dance and musical theater in after-school programs. Music grants enabled student participation in before and after school programs in addition to instruction already offered in guitar, string and wind instruments in Grades 3, 4 and 5. Our choral program continues to flourish, receiving top ratings at local festivals. Artist in Residence programs delivered direct arts instruction to our students while focusing on this year’s magnet theme of Africa and for next year, The Americas.  These residencies and music programs are celebrated, with our students and school community, through assemblies and performances all year long. We are a SEM school engaging in multiple enrichment opportunities through magnet or interest-based enrichment clusters in Grade 2, 4 and 5 while early childhood students receive arts instruction in our EaGLE program. We will continue our rich, successful cultural arts partnerships with City Lore, JALC, Dancing Classrooms, FTH, Inside Broadway and Joyce Theater. At PS 69Q, we believe that arts experiences and arts education are essential to educating the whole student to reach their full potential.
Q47_1: At P.S. 69Q, we strive for an instructionally focused learning environment emphasizing our multicultural and diverse background of 1,046 students who have 24 different home languages and cultures. We are "The School of Cultural and Performing Arts" and endeavor to offer as many arts experiences to our students as possible. We believe that the arts play a vital role in the development of our students not just academically but in their social and emotional growth as well. All students are encouraged to be meaningfully and thoughtfully engaged in academic, artistic, collaborative and socially conscious tasks where every student is accepted and honored for their accomplishments, potential and individuality.  We annually rotate our magnet theme between Asia, Africa and the Americas, integrating these themes throughout our arts curriculum, residency programs, cultural events, multiple school music celebrations and performances while making connections to our students own varied unique cultural experiences. We embrace all opportunities to collaborate with a variety of arts partners that are brought into our school through federal and state grants, the public sector, NYC DOE approved arts partners along with the families and friends of our students and community.

Q46_1: The elementary art program in Public School 70Q provides activities in drawing, painting, art history, sculpture, printmaking and crafts. The program is sequentially developed on disciplined based art education and is aligned with the New York City Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts and the Common Core Standards. Art concepts are taught through activities based on the elements of design: line, shape, form, texture, space, color and value. Art instruction lends itself to integrating with other subject areas. The purposes of these activities are to help students develop awareness of, and appreciation for, the skills in communicating through art, and a feeling of pride and satisfaction in their work. Multicultural art activities are infused into the curriculum. Art in the elementary school gives students the opportunity to develop an interest in art appreciation and to develop critical and creative thinking skills. Our music program, which also follows the standards, provides an opportunity for all students to receive a comprehensive performance-based music education. Through the study of a wide range of music literature students can become intelligent consumers, producers, and/or creators of music. The high level of motivation required for performance courses is an invaluable asset to educational growth. School performances contribute to developing a sense of responsibility in students.
Q48_1: Sophia Mavromatis and Donna c. Geller
Q48_2: Art Teacher and Liaison and Principal

Q46_1: While strive to maximize critical-thinking skills and rigorous academic learning tasks, we equally prioritize access to the arts. In addition to instrumental music (keyboard and recorder) classes during the day, we offer a before-school violin sectional for kindergartners and first-graders, and a wind and percussion ensemble for third-, fourth- and fifth-grade students. We have a full-time staffed certified visual arts teacher who services classes across pre-kindergarten through fifth grades, and has turned our school's main lobby into a revolving art gallery. Additionally, for the second year in a row, we offer an afterschool theater program that stages two productions a year. We are fortunate to offer Arts for All and Ballet Hispanico residency programs to our Kindergarten and 1st-graders. We will continue searching for grants and other means to bring in more and more music, visual arts, theater and dance programs.

Our goal this year has been to continue to educate the whole child and help build well rounded students. Collections of student work show the students' growth as learners. We continue to align our arts programs with the Common Core Curriculum and the standards from the Blueprint for Learning the Arts so that we establish an alignment of arts disciplines with academic disciplines. We are also maintaining our partnerships with Music and the Brain, Little Kids Rock and Studio in a School to help develop higher level cognitive abilities within our students. Through the arts, students develop a balance in a variety of subjects. Our aim is to create students who are better able to express their creativity and be successful in life.

Q44_R2: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q46_1: All of our students participate in visual arts through our STEAM Art/Media program. This program allows children the opportunity to explore and investigate using critical thinking skills across multiple disciplines. Through the STEAM program our teachers incorporate elements of dance, drama, music and visual arts - all these aspects are incorporated into our classrooms. Our STEAM Art/Media program incorporates aspects of our reading/math curriculum and allows students the opportunity to connect elements of art into our core academic program. Our music program consist of the following: our pre-k classes explore voice and keeping the beat through movement and responsive listening. Our kindergarten classes expand on what's taught in Pre-K with an expansion of song and dance. Grades one and two follow the Weill Music Institute’s Musical Explorers curriculum. Grade three, four and five follow the Weill Music Institute’s LinkUp! program. In addition our grade four students participate in a grade four chorus and our grade 5 students participate in a band/chorus program.

At Public School 85, students are engaged in music, theater, visual arts and dance instruction. Students in grades two through five are engaged in a weekly enrichment that includes arts programming such as band and percussion ensemble, dance, theater, photography, scratch, film and jewelry. In addition classroom teachers incorporate art into daily instruction.In Fall 2017 an arts-in-education after school program with Community-Word Project (CWP)  was offered to our students.

Our goal is to continue to incorporate art into other subject areas, such as social studies and science. We encourage creativity in all students. We utilize a STEAM grant to help further incorporate art into our curriculum. The focus is Engineering, Architecture and the Arts. We also provide musical instruction that is branching out to all subject areas, initiated by our two talented music teachers. Music is also valued in our ESL program. One bilingual teacher utilizes a piano in his classroom to further vocabulary instruction. Our after-school program includes morning instruction to band and chorus members. The Arts and Literacy program provides theater (including video), dance, art and music.
Q47_1: na

Q44_R1_C1: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Community School 111Q scholars receive dance instruction in our school dance studio which was constructed in 2006 with funding from the New York City Council. Dance residencies are provided by cultural institutions and community arts foundations such as Alvin Ailey. Visual arts instruction is provided by a full time art teacher to all grades, Pre-K through eight. Art activities are based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and New York State Standards for Visual Arts. Students participate in citywide contests and school exhibitions, such as our annual student art festival held in June. As a Community School we have a number of partnerships with arts and media institutions such as Studio In A School, The Museum of the Moving Image, Community Word Project Broadway Jr. and Lincoln Center Education. Funding for Alvin Ailey is provided by City Council member Jimmy Van Bramer. Scholars Pre-K-8 also receive music instruction by a full time music teacher.This year we are also putting on a spring theater production of Annie Jr. through our partnership with Broadway Junior. Art and music lunchtime clubs also are implemented weekly.
Q47_1:
At Community School 111 Q We also recognize the importance of the Arts in making our scholars “College and Career Ready!” This year our scholars will perform Annie Junior on June 4, 2018 at 5:00pm.  The partnership with Broadway Junior has taught our scholars self-esteem, the power of speech and projection and the necessary social characteristics to be successful in the ever demanding work force. During the play the scholars dazzle us with several choreographed and vocal performances. The depth of their character and commitment to the team is profound. Our music teacher, ENL teacher, librarian, and Art teacher make this miracle a reality for our scholars!

Other performances included the Art and Peace Dance performances through our Collaboration with Alvin Ailey. Many connections are made back to academics through art. Art is valued at our school.

Q46_1: Our goals are to support the academic development of our students through an integrated, comprehensive arts curriculum. Our arts program increases students' content knowledge through the various art forms and boosts students’ self- confidence through their participation in the arts. Our students gain knowledge of different types of media in the visual arts, learn greater self-expression and express their thinking using body movement and language.

Q44_R4: Dancing Classroom American BallroomAmerican Ballroom Theater
Q46_1: Public School 122 believes the arts are an integral component of a child’s education. The arts complement academics in literacy, mathematics, technology, and all other content areas. All students are provided with arts education in various art forms. The arts help develop the whole child and nurture their talents and interests. In grades four through eight, students have the option to participate in Band or Chorus. Our middle school has a talent show to showcase talent in the arts. In addition, students participate in a club of their choice, including dance, music, and fine arts. Parents are partners in the arts and participate in art education workshops and events. Families are invited to attend school concerts, events, Family Night, Hobby Night, Dance Festival, Culture Night, and art trips. Students and families are given free passes to the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City. Students who participate in American Ballroom Theater in fifth grade are given an opportunity to continue dance instruction in Manhattan for a nominal fee. An event was sponsored for cultural organizations to introduce their programs and encourage family participation. Free passes to museums were given to families who attended the workshop. The school participates in Donors Choose and Materials for the Arts in order to obtain materials for art education. Many of our graduating eighth graders with talents and interest in the arts are accepted by specialized arts high schools.

This year at The Albert Shanker School for Visual and Performing Art we continued to offer a robust arts program including visual arts, chorus, technology, drama, and dance. As we do each year, in 2017-2018 we had three performances: a winter concert, performances at graduation along with a talent show and multicultural festival. This year we partnered with community based organizations such as Alvin Ailey, Inside Broadway, Socrates Sculpture Park and The Community Word Project in order to grow and realize our commitment to the arts. Over the course of their three years of study, students receive instruction in each of these disciplines working not only toward proficiency in basic skills but in a meaningful process helping to build life-long learners who are critical, introspective thinkers. Looking forward to the 2018-2019 school year, we are looking to continue to support and grow our art department with partnerships and grants.

Public School/Intermediate School 127Q provides music and visual arts programs to all students from grades Pre-kindergarten through eight. This year we were fortunate to welcome several artistic residencies into our building to provide additional enrichment opportunities. These partnerships included Creative Arts Team, Jazz at Lincoln Center and Louis Armstrong. We also continued partnerships forged in previous school years like the Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana, Ballet Hispanico, and Disney Musicals in Schools. These enrichment opportunities ensure that students across all of the educational settings in the building are afforded the opportunity to be exposed to and interact with the arts!

Q39_4: Parents assisted with costumes for our annual Spring Musical Production. Additionally, the PTA purchased new sound equipment for the spring production.
Q46_1: At Steinway Intermediate School 141, we make every attempt to keep the arts a top priority in our students' education. Our music classes include music theory, music history and piano choral music programs. Our art teachers bring the joy of visual and computer arts to all our students. In fact, computer art allows our students to be creative using software such as Photoshop, Scratch, I-Movie, and other coding software.  As educators, we understand that our students all have individual strengths and talents. It is our goal to always ensure that these strengths and talents are shared and celebrated. As part of our ongoing effort to showcase our students' talents, we have incorporated several stage performances into our school year: Sounds of the Season Holiday Show, Williams Shakespeare Poetry Slam, Spring Arts Showcase, Annual Broadway Jr. Musical, Man in the Mirror: Respect for All Showcase and the Multicultural Dance Festival.  As a result of our students' contributions, the arts program is flourishing within our school community and continues to be celebrated and appreciated.

It is our goal to continue to expose our students to as many areas of the arts as possible. Currently, we have a visual arts, theater and music program which focuses on arts appreciation! We have a partnership with Studio in A School where students are exposed to visual arts through a residency program throughout the school year.

Q44_R2: Society of the Educational Arts, Inc. (SEA)
Q46_1: The mission of Public School 150Q is to provide our students with instruction and hands-on learning activities in all the art disciplines: music, theater, visual art, and dance. We believe that by tapping into our students’ creative and artistic abilities, it will allow them to be critical thinkers and life-long learners.

The Mary D. Carter school continues to build upon its arts program. In addition to the established music program, a visual arts program has completed it's second year. Drawing upon classroom teachers and the resources of artistic organizations, students are given access to a critical aspect of a worldly education. The school intends to maintain their established dedication to the arts and will continue to offer the same or similar programs to future students.

Arts education strengthens our goal for children given the benefits it provides in fostering academic achievement. At Public School 152 the arts are weaved into each daily instructional experience. We provide our students with in-house arts instruction consisting of music, theater, and visual arts provided by licensed teachers on staff, and artists in residence from arts organizations and trips to enhance the Arts experience. In house residencies include 10 - 12-week cycles provided via our partnership with Marquis Studios to children in kindergarten through fifth grade and a second collaboration with Dancing Classrooms offered to our fifth graders. Arts instruction includes movement and expressive theater for all of our students. Additionally, the following arts programs are provided: Percussion to Grade 3, Islamic Arts studies to Grades 4; Visual Arts (Origami) to Grade 4; Photography and Ballroom Dancing to Grade 5. This year we added a script-writing residency after school with funds from CASA grant. Students worked with residents after school to write original plays that were later performed by actors from the Astoria Performing Arts Center for a selected audience. Additionally, during Parent Night in May the parents participate in Parent-child Arts workshops where students use the skills learned with each residency to teach their parents. Events include origami, painting, drawing, tissue paper art and more. 

The Arts will continue to be the forum to build emotional maturity, physical development, and social awareness.

Public School 166Q has aligned the school's curriculum to the Common Core Learning Standards. Teachers craft and modify lessons to fit the needs of their students. The students work on project-based units, in addition to interdisciplinary assignments. This year, our students had the opportunity to  work with many outside companies. New York City Children's Theater worked with certain grades to make popular stories come to life. Selected students participated in the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking Competition, which enabled them to create their own picture books. Studio in a School worked with students to enable them to learn about nutrition, while incorporating visual arts. Art House Astoria worked alongside classroom teachers to deliver in-class music instruction. Town Hall worked with the certain grades to learn ballroom dancing, creative movement, and hip hop routines and to choreograph original moves. We also have an ongoing partnership with Ballet Tech, which students audition for and are selected to participate in an ongoing study of the art of ballet. Lastly, Kidspire works with the younger grades to learn the basics of architectural design. Additionally, our music and art teachers work with the students to put on countless performances and concerts for school and families. The upper grades have the opportunity to participate in chorus, which also contributes to yearly concerts and events. Our music room has keyboards, guitars, and a drum set where children can learn to read, play and improvise music.

As a Magnet School of the Arts, it is incumbent upon us to incorporate the arts into our core academic areas. We presently incorporate the arts into all of our social studies and literacy units. We have also begun infusing the arts into our math units. We have a full time art teacher and a full time music teacher. Students also participate in artist residencies and in-school concerts and shows.

Our students participate in the arts in multiple ways both in and out of school through collaborations with outside organizations as well as museums and other cultural centers. Our students have a deepened awareness and enjoy the opportunity to participate in the arts.

Q39_4: Participating with their children in monthly art activities

Q46_1: Our comprehensive arts program focuses on music, dance, visual arts, and theater instruction. We have licensed music and theater teachers, and a licensed physical education teacher who effectively integrates dance routines into instruction. Classroom teachers incorporate the arts into content area study. Our arts partners include Studio In A School, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and Inside Broadway in order to provide our students multiple opportunities to develop their skill sets in the fine arts.

Students at the Louis Armstrong Middle School are given many opportunities to participate in music and visual arts. All fifth grade students learn the recorder, sing folk songs from around the world, often celebrating their ancestral heritage, and apply movement to their music making. Sixth graders have a number of options that prepare them for continued study in seventh through eighth grade. In general music, students continue using the mallet percussion and drums while learning basic music theory and solfeggio. In the ensembles; chorus, band and orchestra, students learn how to read music and apply musical notation to a number of genres from the Baroque era to popular music. It is the mission of the Arts department to teach students to be life-long learners. Much emphasis is placed upon working towards preparing students for performing arts high schools and to become career-ready in Arts related subjects. In our art classes, we enable students to use a variety of processes to stimulate creative ideas, manipulatives, and self-determined learning. Students explore many mediums including ceramics in preparing their portfolios for specialized high school auditions. Art classes are actively engaged in using self and peer-assessment to promote growth and revision within their projects. Art students adhere to lessons aligned with the NYC Blueprint while exploring contemporary movements in the art world today. Self-contained classes enjoy differentiated art experiences. All students celebrate yearly in the Art Show.

Public School 228's comprehensive arts program includes an integrated arts curriculum for students in pre-k through second grade. Students benefit from daily opportunities to participate in visual art, theater, dance and music experiences. Artist and Composer of the Month programs develop students' cultural literacy. 2017-2018 artist in residence partnerships maximized creative arts experiences for all of our students and enhanced the standards-based Public School 228 arts curriculum.

Our arts program consists of a three year sequence for our students. These arts disciplines include: band, chorus, guitar, and visual arts. Our goal is to design coherent curriculum and instruction which incorporates the Common Core Standards, Civics in the Community and the Blueprint for the Arts.

Public School 234, The School of Performing Arts and Technology is very committed to arts education. The administration and teachers are very supportive of all the arts disciplines. At our school we have teachers that are licensed in theater, music, dance, visual arts and technology. We are proud to note that our students have participated/engaged in nearly 30 performances this year alone. We have utilized grants from DonorsChoose.org to make our performing arts department shine. Our school now boasts a dressing room complete with costumes, wigs, make-up, and more. We have received a moveable spotlight and wireless headset microphones. The confidence of our students has grown tenfold, allowing us to take our performances “on the road”. Part of our initiative has been to share our performances with other schools in our immediate area. These shared performances have increased the camaraderie among our fellow district 30 schools and added to our students’ confidence, which we are always trying to build. We continue partner with various arts organizations including Inside Broadway, Alvin Ailey, NYC Ballet, Ballet Tech, Creative Arts Team and City Harvest. Our goal is to continue to increase our arts program for the 2018-2019 school year.

Intermediate School 235, The Academy for New Americans, is a unique school designed to service students new to the United States in grades six through eight. Students partake in a variety of projects that allow them to acquire English language skills through the arts. Teachers infuse the arts into their lessons by providing students with opportunities to develop their innate talents through class projects and group assignments. This year C.A.S.A. and S.A.S.F. provided visual arts and theatre to our students in after school programs. We also provided visual arts to 85% of the students through an F-Status art teacher. Students also created art pieces that were displayed in a NYC Lunar New Year Scroll that was exhibited at the David Geffen Hall at Lincoln Center. All art projects were displayed during the school's Annual Art Fair. Students wrote and produced a play with C.A.S.A., that was performed at Queens Theater in the Park.
Q47_1:
Due to budget constraints, we are unable to provide a full time art teacher.  Through the generosity of the F-Status Arts Teacher Pilot program we have been able to offer art to more than 80% of our students. It would be ideal, if we could provide our entire student population with an arts class.
Many of our students have artistic talents and abilities. In November 2017 one of our 8th grade students won the Respect for All poster contest in District 30.  She received recognition from the Superintendent and Council Member Daniel Dromm. She was also recognized at the Annual City-wide Respect For All Ceremony.  
The arts are a universal language. Students with limited English skills are able to express themselves freely and without fear. It would be wonderful if we were able to offer it year round.

Q46_1: Energy Tech High School expanded its existing arts program in the 2017-2018 school year, affording students the opportunity to take Studio Art I, Advanced Studio Art, visual arts electives, Theater I, and theater electives. We are currently preparing to add digital arts and new media technology in the coming year. In addition to formal classroom experiences, Energy Tech continues to offer supplemental theater programming both in the English Language Arts coursework and after school through the New York City Shakespeare Festival and the CUNY Creative Arts Team. We have also expanded our after-school offerings to include theater and art clubs, and have offered a number of in-school and after-school Broadway show and museum trips through a variety of school partnerships.

Public School 280Q believes that the arts are a fundamental aspect of education that provides an environment where students can develop their potential as individuals in personal, social, and educational contexts. Through arts education, students are given the opportunity to creatively express themselves, acquire critical thinking skills, explore materials, develop new ways of seeing and interpreting the world, and learn about their artistic and cultural heritage. We offer visual arts education, music education, and technology. Students are given a variety of opportunities to express themselves creatively.

At our school students have multiple opportunities to engage in various art making activities. The sixth and seventh grade students are exposed to music, art and drama. These subjects are taught by certified arts teachers. There is a strong elective culture at school offering classes in film, photography and creative writing to all grades. There is also a strong dance culture at the school though we don't have a certified dance teacher. The high school students are exposed to arts education through electives. They are offered choices in The History of Cinema, Stand-Up Comedy, Musical Theater, Advanced Scene Study, Chorus, Slam Poetry, Filmmaking Costume Design, Eco-Friendly Fashion Show and Multicultural Dance Club.

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Sixth grade students spend half a school year (meeting twice per week) in visual art and half of the year in music. At the end of the year, these students choose to pursue a two year sequence in either visual art or music throughout the seventh and eighth grade. In addition to regularly scheduled music classes, supplemental sectional instruction time is provided for all music students on a weekly rotating basis. Beyond the school day, our spirit band plays at school sporting events and during open houses. Music students are also supported/prepared for specialized music high school auditions and to attend NYSMA evaluation events. Along with regularly scheduled visual art classes, our school offers a portfolio development class for seventh and eighth grade students who intend to apply to a visual arts high school. This class is offered two times per week and also prepares seventh grade students to apply/audition for Summer Arts Institute and Middle School Arts Bootcamp. Similarly, students who intend to apply to performing arts high schools have the option to take a monologue course, also offered two times per week. In addition, Theater is offered after school through our yearly Broadway Junior musical performances. Our school has received funding from Broadway Junior and produced Broadway Junior musicals for four consecutive years (2018 included).

Currently our school uses outside cultural organizations to provide arts programming for all of our students. We are a citywide gifted and talented school, located in one of the most diverse counties in the nation. Our instructional model integrates arts learning with the academic work taking place, as part of each day's schedule, to foster connections and increase understanding. Using their gifts and talents, we teach our students how to develop knowledge and skills for living and be productive in a multicultural, diverse, and global society. We strive to grant our students the opportunity to be exposed to as many arts disciplines as possible and allow each student to personally participate in the creation of at least one performance opportunity per year.  We have added a full time visual art teacher this year and plan on expanding the number of hours she services our students for the 2018-2019 school year.

The Academy for Careers in Television and Film (TvF), opened its doors to its first freshman class in September 2008. Located on the waterfront at the new Hunter’s Point Campus in Queens, TvF serves students in grades nine through twelve. As a CTE high school, all of TvF’s students simultaneously participate in a rigorous academic program while receiving serious professional instruction. In order to ensure that all graduates are prepared for the workplace, TvF is committed to providing our students with the opportunity to work alongside industry professionals in authentic work experiences. To date, our school has provided internships to over 350 of our students in film/video organizations such as WNET, Panavision, KAS Stage Lighting, Gotham Sound, Silvercup Studios, Timberlake Studios, Cinemaworld Studios, Eclectic Props, Eastern Effect, Contesta Rock Hair, Navasync, Bronx Docs, Alien Dawn Productions, and The Good Wife.

The staff at East Elmhurst Community School pride ourselves on providing our students with a strong academic program that is reinforced and enhanced by a rich emphasis on the arts. In addition to integrating arts into the classroom curriculum through lyrics study, classical music study, and painting study, our students receive arts instruction during the school day during music and visual arts classes. Furthermore, we offer a variety of arts based clubs that meet after school and on the weekend for arts enrichment, practice, and exposure. We also host residencies from arts organizations that help deepen student understanding of a variety of art forms and cultures. Our school strives to reflect and improve our arts integration and programs to align to common branch curricula, include community members, and further develop student understanding of visual arts, music, theater, and dance. 

Visual arts classes at our school are student centered and focused on project based learning. The students also learn about artists, art history, and the principles and elements of art and design. Computer Science is also integrated into visual arts classes through coding, stop motion and robotics.

Our Core music program uses multiple approaches to engage students in active music learning. These approaches build musicianship through singing, speech, movement, and instrument playing. Students have the opportunity to improvise, create, explore, label, imitate, and express themselves through music.

Our school arts program offers weekly visual arts and music classes for all students. Through our partnerships with community arts organizations, we also offer partial-year programs in theater and dance. Our arts curriculum is aligned to the New York City Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, and our school's approach to arts learning also reflects our school's three performance outcomes: critical thinking skills, creativity in problem-solving, and communication skills. In the context of arts learning, critical thinking skills are evidenced by the ability to interpret and analyze works of art across a variety of genres, styles, and artistic traditions; creativity in problem solving is evidenced by the ability to create original works of art through the intentional application of emerging artistic skills and concepts; communication skills are evidenced by the ability to present works of art (e.g., in gallery exhibitions or musical performances) and justify artistic decisions orally and in writing. In all arts areas, we are working to promote the development of critical thinking skills, creativity in problem solving, and communication skills through students' learning experiences in the arts.

Art cluster teachers integrate the arts to our Pre-K units of study. Through the arts, students use their five senses to explore collage, paint and create 3D projects. Students have the opportunity to observe, listen, wonder, create, express ideas, and speak with others - foundation skills for reading and writing. This year, our pre-k students had the opportunity to know Mary Cassatt, Vincent Van Gogh, George Seurat, Pablo Picasso, Henry Matisse, and Jacob Lawrence. The arts allows students to create art, learn about the artist's life, culture, and appreciate art. The music clusters also integrate music to the units of study. This year the students were introduced to Strings: ukelele, violin, cello, guitar, mandolin. Woodwinds: basson, clarinet, oboe, flute, bag pipes, dizi. Percussion: djembe, timpani, castanets, drums. The classroom teachers exposed the students to folk songs, nursery rhymes, and holiday favorites. Songs help teach basic skills concepts as well as social skills.

During the 2017-18 school year, William Cullen Bryant High School has made significant strides in advancing and expanding its arts programs. Our music department faculty increased to four full-time teachers and increased its collaboration with outside performance organizations as well as created a new Music Theory class to ready students for conservatory entrance exams. The Bryant Arts program is a recipient of several grants, including a partnership with the American Composer’s Orchestra. We currently have two full-time dance teachers, two full-time theater teachers and three full-time visual arts teachers, including two graphic designers. Our Dance Company trained with the Martha Graham Dance Company and American Ballet Company. This year the Bryant Theater Company was featured on Broadway as one of five NYC public schools in The Shubert Foundation 2018 HS Theater Festival. Over two hundred Bryant students attended the Broadway musical "Hamilton,” and participated in the EduHam student performances. The Jazz band was awarded a gold medal at the 2017 NYSSMA performance and silver for Intermediate Band. In 2017, Bryant started the Tri-M Music National Honor Society. In 2017-2018, 8 Bryant students received TDF’s Open Doors Scholarships and participated in the year-long program. Bryant stages 2 theater productions, 2 music concerts (jazz band, concert band, rock band, concert choir & show choir), a multi-cultural festival (Festival of Nations), a formal art installation showcase and two dance company shows.
Q48_2: Arts Small Learning Community Director/ Arts Liaison

Q46_1: The principal and faculty at Long Island City High School take pride in providing students with creative course sequences in visual arts and music. While most courses are available to all students, some are focused exclusively on students in the Academy of Humanities and Urban Culture SLC. Our school has a long history of partnerships with various cultural institutions of New York City such as The Metropolitan Opera, ABT, Repertorio Espanol, Socrates Sculpture Park, and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Long Island City High School is also one of the five locations for The Metropolitan Opera HD Live in Schools program. The school offers classes in band, string orchestra, chorus, guitar, music history and music theory. Visual art classes include AP Studio Art (Drawing; 2-D, 3-D), Computer Graphics, Architectural Design, Costume and Stage design. Students have an opportunity to graduate with the Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma in the Arts.

Frank Sinatra School of the Arts offers a pre-conservatory course of study in six art forms: dance, fine art, vocal music, instrumental music, drama, film and media. We are housed in a new state of the art building with an eight hundred seat concert hall, two black box theaters and discipline based rehearsal spaces including art studios, an art gallery and a film sound stage. Our students are involved with many of the outstanding arts and cultural institutions that make up the artistic community of New York City.

The arts program presently consists of band, music history, jazz history, studio art, web design, and video production. The goal of the arts program this school year was to encourage students to participate in performing ensembles such as band and participate in NYSSMA contest events. Students who participate in drama club perform at a Shakespeare festival. Students in the visual arts program display their works around the school and at various locations in the local community. The video production program and web design programs are part of the school's CTE program.

The arts program at Newcomers High School provides newly arrived immigrant students, who are all English language learners, with instruction that supports their transition into a new school setting. We have developed an arts program that builds literacy skills, which is essential for our students. We tap into the vast array of cultural resources that make New York City the art center of the world, teaching our students about various art forms in the fields of music, dance, theatre, and the visual arts. Through arts partnerships that support our instructional programs, we expose our students to our city’s rich cultural and artistic scene. Students have the opportunity for advanced study in a particular dance, studio art, music, media production and media analysis. When possible, interdisciplinary links to subjects such as math, science, English, social studies and multimedia technologies are encouraged and established.
Q48_2: ap art music social studies home langauge arts

Q46_1: The Academy offers the following programs in the Arts: Studio Art, College Now Art History, Play writing, Acting, Digital Media, Opera Appreciation and a 20th Century Expression Through the Arts course. In addition we actively seek to integrate the arts into all the curriculum areas. The Theater for a New Audience worked with two ninth grade ESL/ICT classes. Eleventh grade history students participate in the "American Voices" program through the Office of Special Projects. Tenth grade English students participate in interdisciplinary film screenings bridging ELA and history. Eleventh grade English teachers collaborate with the Museum of Modern Art connecting the written word to a variety of artistic mediums through the theme of identity. Twelfth grade students are offered the opportunity to become part of the Center for Arts Education Career Development Program and intern in the arts. Meanwhile the entire student body is provided with artistic and cultural opportunities such as multiple trips to the Metropolitan Opera, the Metropolitan Museum and other NYC art museums. For the second year students took part in the Upright Citizens Brigade/NYCDOE Teen Improv Festival. For the past twenty one years, the Academy has sent a delegation of students to the New York State Theater Education Association's student conference.

The aims of the International Baccalaureate Visual Arts course, at both the higher and standard level, are to enable students to engage in producing, appreciating and evaluating visual art. Participation in the arts builds confidence as students respond visually and creatively to personal and cultural experiences. They develop an understanding of visual arts from local, national and international perspectives, as they investigate past, present and emerging forms of visual arts. Our students develop skills in, and sensitivity to, the creation of works that reflect active and individual involvement. They take responsibility for the direction of their learning through the acquisition of effective working practices.

This year we received about $20,000 in grant money to support our arts programs which was an essential component of our arts instruction.  This funding allowed us to offer our students residency programs around dance, music, theater, and visual arts. These programs culminated in celebrations with families. Parent involvement is key in keeping the arts alive by contributing their knowledge, time, and funding to support the arts in the classroom.  Our after-school enrichment programs supported further instruction through the arts. Programs such as drama, visual arts, music, and dance were offered to all students. Our students' artwork was selected to be featured at the Staten Island Children's Museum.  An Artist Walkway/Gallery is dedicated to showcasing student artwork throughout the school year. In addition to the walkway, our school building celebrates students' artwork on all bulletin boards, hallways, stairways, and the auditorium. Student artwork was selected as winners for contests such as Online Safety, Respect For All, and Sustainability.  Additionally, we participated at the Ecology Fair highlighting student projects at the Staten Island Mall. At Public School 1 our goal is to continue an arts-rich education, exposing students to more arts learning through dance, music, performance and visual arts. Through the hands-on training and learning teachers engaged in with the residencies, we are working toward building capacity within our school to provide our students with ongoing instruction in the arts.

We offer Drama, Band, and Art for all the students in the 3 Academy's(Business, Science, Arts).  Students collaborate together on projects, and performances.  This year our 6th grade Arts academy students have had enrichment arts class 4 days a week. They performed at a holiday showcase this year in December.
