There is a end of the year arts showcase that will be held.

This school year we offered dance, music and visual arts to our students. We believe performing arts and visual arts are essential in a student's education. Our goal is to enhance socialization, academic achievement and boost self-esteem as well as to provide all students with exposure to the Arts. The arts department is aligned with the Common Core Standards as well as the Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exposed to different dance forms, line dance, yoga, cultural dance, ballroom and role play in dance and movement. In visual arts, students learn about master artists and how to use their techniques. In collaboration with several arts residency programs, students have the opportunity to gain valuable skills in music, dance, theater and art literacy while learning to work together as a team and gaining experience in performing live in front of an audience. Students use their voice and instruments during music and have the opportunity to perform at Carnegie Hall. We offer many opportunities to be involved during school and after school in our arts programs. We have performances during the school day as well as in the evenings. The arts department allows students to use creativity, imagination and collaboration to increase confidence, focus and perseverance in each discipline
Q47_1: We are an appeals school that has been underfunded for over 10 years. Funding is our primary challenge.

Q46_1:
We strive to fully integrate the arts into our curriculum so that we can provide all students with instruction in all arts disciplines throughout the course of their elementary education.  Our current Arts program includes three visual art teachers and three performing arts teachers.  These teachers serve all students in grades kindergarten through five.  Through the generosity of our PTA our fifth grade students participated in Dancing Classrooms.

For the 2018-2019 school year we plan to continue our visual arts cluster program and replace performing arts with a dedicated theater program.  In addition to planning for Dancing Classrooms we conducted a fund raising event this year that will enable us to provide art residencies for all classes in grades K-4 giving students the opportunity for art experiences across the disciplines.

All students in grades three through five received band instruction provided by a DOE certified teacher. All students in fourth and fifth grades received ballroom dancing instruction from Dancing Classrooms. All students in grades two and three received Hip Hop dance instruction from Sundog Theatre. All kindergarten through fifth grade students received theater arts instruction from our full-time theater teacher. Our second graders also had an art session with the Little Artist company.  We are continuing to utilize formative assessment strategies and research to further enhance our arts instruction, and to support our school-wide instructional focus. Our students also had the opportunity to participate in our school-wide enrichment program which also includes many forms of the arts.  Each year, we work diligently to provide our students with exposure to various forms of art as we find it integral in ensuring a well-rounded education for our students.

Public School 6, The Allan F. Kivlehan School, serves as a harbinger for artistic expression.  We were selected as an inaugural Carnegie Hall residency school, and have sustained this relationship for more than a decade.  We have integrated other residencies throughout our history, and currently partner with ArtsConnection to provide a supplementary theater program for our students.  We continue to spiral the four arts disciplines throughout the grades.  This is accomplished via a combination of cluster programming, Junior and PBIS assemblies, field trips, visiting cultural institutions, classroom instruction, and the aforementioned residencies.  

This year, we received a NYCDOE Family Engagement grant, which enabled us to integrate parents within the context of our visual arts instruction.  We aspire to expand this program in the future, as indicated in our CEP; we will utilize art as a catalyst for community involvement.  It is our intention to solidify intergenerational bonds with the Kivlehan Chapter of the Korean War Veterans, whose presence is an integral component of our school identity.  We honor them annually during an arts-oriented Flag Day ceremony, where our students explore patriotism, civic responsibility, and the joys of creative expression.  We are inestimably proud of the artistic identity that PS 6 has forged, and will continue to meld arts instruction with multifaceted components of our curricula.

Public School 8 offers all areas of the arts both during the school day and in after-school programs. Included are art and music classes, classroom theater programs, band, chorus, and dance. The students also participated in programs and contests held throughout the year where the arts were integrated. The Energy Efficiency Calendar Contest and social studies projects are just a few. The after-school enrichment program offers a variety of classes, such as scrap booking, Center Stage Performers, Fitnessgram, Little Picasso's, Music to My Ears, and Glee Club. The NY Public Library and Box Out Bullying have also enriched the arts for the students in our school.

At Public School 9, Naples Street Elementary School, students, staff and families will work collaboratively to create meaningful opportunities for all members. Through strong partnerships with community organizations, students will be provided with cultural and artistic curriculum related experiences to enhance the literacy curriculum. Our school is committed to building a strong arts program that, at full capacity, includes dedicated dance, drama, music and visual arts programs. These programs will offer students at various levels, with different learning styles, access to content based curriculum in an exciting way.

PS10 Fort Hill Collaborative Elementary has increased its Arts instruction for the 2017-2018 school year in comparison to our 2016-2017 year. We have added a full time dance teacher that works with  all students at least 2 times per week. Students in third grade have had the opportunity to partner with Disney Musicals in Schools to produce our schools first musical. They were able to perform a piece of this musical on Broadway. Our students also have worked with Illuminart  to create their own original play and perform it for our school community. Through Sun Dog students were able to enrich our schools environment by painting the doors in our hallway with various characters from children's books. In our STEAM Classroom students work collaboratively to create original works of art through the engineering and design process. This year we have introduced our students to new art forms and our goal is to continue this while cultivating a love and appreciation  for the arts.

For the 2017/2018 school year, Public School 11 offered a full-time theater program for all students. Visual arts, music, and theater continued to be infused within the general curriculum. After-school programs, such as the Newspaper Club and dance, were offered and teachers planned field trips that focused on the arts. Special assemblies and nightly performances took place including The Lion King, Silly States, Life Cycles and The Nutrition Show, Veteran's Day, Holiday Extravaganza, Ecology Day, Dance Fete and Annual Fright Fest.  This year, we wrote a grant for students in Grades 2-4 to participate in Choir.  The experience and shows have been breathtaking!

Q44_R5: Snug Harbor Cultural Center & Botanical Garden
Q46_1: The arts soar at Public School 13! Adhering to the NY Art Standards in Visual Arts, our students participate in grade appropriate activities, such as, chalk drawings (grade one), working with pastels (grade two), and sketching with charcoal (grade four). Student work is displayed throughout the lobby for all to enjoy. Students take part in two units of dance with each unit culminating in a performance for parents. Funding from grants, the DOE, and our City Council Member afforded us opportunities to offer five enrichment programs: The Environmental Art Project, facilitated by Universal Temple of the Arts, guided students through the process of transforming recyclables into art; in a partnership with the Alice Austen House, two ten-week after-school Cultural Adventures (CASA) in photography were accorded to interested third and fourth grade students; a Parents as Arts Partners grant through The Center for Arts Education had parents and children creating an ABC quilt; funding from S.I. Foundation allowed the Kindergarten classes to create books; and, mask-making and puppetry residencies were provided by a DOE grant. We received the rights to perform "Aladdin Kids" through a Disney Musicals in Schools grant. This production, containing all theatrical elements, was shown to every student in our school as well as 2 evening performances for family and friends.  Our Aladdin stars closed a DOE Borough Arts Festival at the St. George Theatre! We culminate our school year with a morning of dance and song during our annual Dance Fete.

During the 2017-2018 school year, Public School 16 has continued to increase arts instruction to meet the arts standards. Students are participating in visual arts, dance, music and theater. During the school day we have an existing twenty five period music program in grades two and three, where students learn to play the recorder. We've also provide a five day, twenty five periods visual arts program. The second grade has participated in a fifteen week, two hour per week, theater program provided by Sundog. We have also continued our fifteen week after-school arts program as part of the Violence and Prevention Grant on Friday afternoons for two hours. In grades kindergarten through fifth ENL students were targeted for a theater program provided by IlluminArt during a fifteen week program. Fourth and fifth grade SWD's were also targeted for an after school visual arts program two days a week. We have partnered with Arts Connection and have residencies in drums, Hip-Hop Story Telling, and Hip-Hop dance. In May, all of our students will be performing and participating during Arts Week.

We have two full time art teachers (music and visual arts). In addition to the teachers, we have a residency with a cultural organization, Universal Temple of the Arts, to integrate the arts into the curriculum. Public School 18 teachers align their lessons with the Blueprint for the Arts. Teachers are also responsible for participating in school-wide assemblies, and grade assemblies. School-wide assemblies covered themes such as Hispanic Heritage, Holidays Around the World, and Black History. Grade assemblies vary according to the curriculum in each grade. The arts are an integral part of Public School 18's curriculum.

Q45_10: language development and application of principles learned
Q46_1: Public School 19 understands the value of the arts in educating the whole child. We strive to secure creative methods to provide our students with rich art experiences and opportunities to create while learning. As a culturally diverse school, respect and understanding for other cultures is made more tangible through the relationship we have built with various cultural organizations. Arts educators from these organizations work closely with classroom teachers to connect the arts to the core subjects in a meaningful way. Our students are offered additional arts opportunities through field trips and assembly productions designed by their peers. We are proud of the after-school theater program we have developed with the assistance of Disney Musicals in Schools, which allows seventy five students training in musical theater, culminating in a performance for our community. We are also proud of the School Wide Enrichment programs we were able to offer after school and on Saturdays, which has enabled our ELL students receive direct instruction in theater, music, dance, and visual arts on Saturday mornings. As a school committed to the arts, we work to provide instruction and experiences in the arts in many different ways.

Public School 20 provides all students with the opportunity to engage in visual arts, dance, music and theater during and after school. It is our belief that arts tap into children's strengths and different learning modalities, enhancing learning across all curriculum areas and providing opportunities for enrichment. The arts also provide an opportunity for parents to experience and share in their childrens' learning. Our visual arts cluster services all grades and the year ends with a culminating art fair. Our theater and movement clusters service all grades, and students perform in class and at school-wide assemblies throughout the year. We continue to seek sources of funding through grant writing and when funding is available, residencies in the arts are provided by vendors. Students attend performances and visit museums and cultural institutions throughout the city.
Q47_1: Our partnership with Sundog theater has had a major impact in the language development and confidence level of our ELL population and students with disabilities.

Q46_1: This year we are extremely proud to continue our work with MTI (Musical Theatre International). The students were excited and worked hard work to perform the play, "101 Dalmations." Each production includes visual arts, music, drama, and singing. Utilizing grant funds, the school is continuing its wellness and anti-bullying themes and partners with NYCArtsCypher to implement and create a comic book club reflecting the school's PBIS core values, anti-bullying theme and healthy habits. In May, we continue our traditional May Fete Dance where all classes perform and the 5th grade dances the traditional May Pole and Drill as a Salute to America. Through grant funds awarded by Staten Island Arts, Art Brings Change Grant, a local graphic designer collaborates with our visual arts teacher to teach about art as career. The third grade art students design and create t-shirts to celebrate PBIS and the school community in art class. Through external support, we partner with Education through Music, INC. which provides music instruction to every single student in our school community. We have multiple culminating shows and a select choir.

Q39_4: Parent Coordinator - City excursion with parents
Q46_1: During the 2017 - 2018 academic year, the Arts program at PS 22R includes Music, Visual Arts, and Dance. The goals of the Arts program include multiple opportunities to experience a variety of musical, visual arts, dance, and theater presentations as expressions of voice, culture and points of view. Students also share and learn about their own culture and personal histories through the arts during our 'Culture Day' Celebration. Exposure to the Arts provide students with expanded awareness of multiple interpretations of events/representations and develop appreciation of same. We also have a  Chorus which provides fourth and fifth grade students with the experience of learning two and three part harmony, working within a cooperative group, building relationships, analyzing songs for musical elements as well as meaning and to meet and perform with top performers in the field. Singer/performers such as Leslie Odom of the play Hamilton came to PS 22 to sing with the students. Students have had past performances such as singing at the Oscars, singing at the Presidential Inauguration of President Obama and other experiences. Our young artists have created a gallery presentation that adorns the school hallways and have created poems to accompany their work.  The overarching goal of these programs is to give students a well rounded foundational education which enhances or further develops their academic and personal growth. We hold the Arts in high regard and are committed to providing quality programs to our students.

Public School 23 has been fortunate to expand our band program to include music instruction for second through fifth grade students with the assistance of parent teacher association gifts to the school. In addition, we have a full time art teacher who is teaching social studies through the visual arts. This provides instruction to grades pre-k through five, infusing both the New York City DOE Social Studies Scope and Sequence and the Blueprint for the Arts. We are also continuing our partnership with Richmondtown Historical Society through a CASA Grant. This grant provides students on all grade levels the opportunity to participate in an arts-based program with a historical twist. In addition, with help of a PTA Grant and SI foundation grant we have collaborated with Sundog Theater to provide theater instruction to all students K-5 over 10 sessions per class, with a culminating performance in front of the entire PS 23 community (parents, staff, and students). Sundog Theater also assisted in helping us secure supplementary funds to allow for our 4th grade students to participate in theater instruction about immigration and Ellis Island, which is directly connected to the 4th grade Social Studies Curriculum.

At Intermediate School 24 the Arts Program includes, on all grade levels: Visual Arts, Performing Arts, Instrument Music (Band), Music Appreciation, Graphic Arts, Computer Technology, and Media. Students enjoy a hands-on experience with culminating activities that offer the opportunity to exhibit the skills they have acquired as they reach each benchmark of the New York City Department of Education Blueprint For Teaching And Learning In the Arts. When visiting our school you will find that we have been successful in reaching our past goals in transforming public space (halls, cafeteria, school yard walls, classroom doors) into lasting pieces of student artwork. Both the interior and exterior walls become student canvases, as individual art work is permanently fixed on the walls throughout the campus. 

As part of our goal to maintain our arts education programs, in September 2017 we implemented individualized programming for the incoming sixth grade.  In 2018 we will add a new dance program to be part of the talent selection choices for students. With a wider selection of art programs to choose from, we believe we will provide a stronger possibility of students being placed in an arts education program that best fit their interests. In addition we will continue to collaborate with various cultural organizations to help us strengthen our art curriculum.

Q39_4: researching grants/PTA donation for class visual arts program. 4 sessions each PK-5
Q44_R1_C10: Our school must be selected for the program.
Q46_1: All teachers integrate the arts into all curriculum areas.  All grades are involved with inquiry based instruction.  Arts instruction is an integral part of the curriculum for all grade levels.  This year we actively sought and were awarded grant funds and leveraged school funds to enable us to provide full time art and music programs for all students.  Students in grades 2 and 3 participated in chorus and puppetry programs.  They put on 2 full performances for the entire school.  Students in kindergarten and first grade participated in a dance program that introduced them to various types of dance and movement. Third, fourth and fifth grade also participated in chorus.  Fourth and fifth grade participated in art and displayed their work at an exhibit.

Q44_R1_C1: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: Intermediate School 27 is committed to providing its students with a multi-faceted arts experience. We do this through the study of instrumental music, vocal music, theatre and visual arts. We engage in a multi-disciplinary approach, infusing the Common Core Learning Standards, in all our arts lessons. We require all of our arts students to participate in writing assignments that align themselves with those standards. Throughout the school year, students are involved in various arts activities that include composition, music history, musical theatre, choreography, creation, analysis, and performance.

Q44_R2: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q44_R3: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1:
Our school's Arts program is aligned to the 8th and 9th Grade Social Studies Scope and Sequence.  The students were exposed to some selected time period studied in Social Studies and the how they influence the Arts at the time.  
The unit of study encompass printmaking and drawing.  Additionally, students were introduced to all the fine points of the printmaking process and explored the drawing technique of micrography and 2D Graphic design.

Q32_6: Music and the Brain, America's Young Voices
Q46_1: Each grade experiences the arts as part of a progressive curriculum that transfers easily from grade to grade. For kindergarten and first grade we have the BAM program (Believe, Achieve, Motivate). Each year the students learn music, movement, and art within the context of an accessible theme such as Living Healthy. In the BAM program children are exposed, sometimes for the first time, to different genres of music, group singing, video, dance and other musical activities. In the second and third grade, the classroom teachers relate the visual arts to other curriculum areas and explore songs and music that correlate to topics they are studying. Students also participate in school plays that reinforce music and visual arts, and are introduced to choreographed group dance. Third grade students learn to read music as they play the recorder. In the fourth and fifth grades, children choose an academy that they continue with for the remainder of their time at school. Students in the band or chorus showcase their talents by performing at a variety of events such as Barnes & Noble, the Groundhog Day Ceremony at the Staten Island Zoo, Staten Island Welcomes our Heroes, Make Music New York, American Young Voices, Music in the Park and other performances throughout the year.

Public School 30 has an arts department that includes visual arts and music. All programs service grades Pre-K through fifth, general and special education, and follow the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Connections are made to all subjects, especially literacy, social studies and math as well as learning about the history of each discipline. Our visual arts department has a fully equipped arts studio. Children create drawings, paintings, prints, and sculptures while also learning art history. The year culminates with one in-school art show and displays of student artwork in our school lobby and at the Staten Island Conference House Art Expo. Our school also had three winners in the Staten Island Borough Arts Festival. Individual students and classes participate in various art contests through the year. In music, students play individually and as an ensemble and learn to critique as well as assess self and peer performances. Students learn to connect sounds and symbols and the year culminates with performances. The music department includes instruction in band, jazz band, rock bank, and  recorder as well as Music Memory and rhythm and movement. This is the 9th year that our Music Memory team is competing city-wide. Our jazz band is teaming up with a local high school jazz band to perform at an outdoor venue.

Students at PS 31 are encouraged to explore the arts through classroom instruction as well as attendance at concerts, dance and theater performances and visits to cultural institutions. Through our partnerships with community organizations, we are able to bring the expertise of practicing artists and performers to our school. Most classes are instructed by a visual arts teacher at least once per week. Student art work is regularly displayed in the school building and classes and parents are invited to take "gallery walks" to view the completed pieces. Art instruction is integrated in the core curriculum with co-planning in social studies and science taking place between the visual arts teacher and our general education  teachers. Students respond to the book of the month through visual arts on a school-wide basis. Through our arts partners with grant funding, we have been able to connect our writing curriculum with drama instruction and provide our teachers with professional development in drama, visual arts and music.Our goal is to provide standards-based arts instruction to all students while nourishing their talents and creating a lifelong appreciation for the arts.

At Public School 35, our goal is to afford our children with opportunities to activate their imaginations. Through the implementation of observation, tactile learning and self expression, our students create hands-on art projects which stimulate thoughtful inquiry and careful perception. It is our priority at Public School 35 to instill a love and appreciation of the arts in every student. Through our music/band program, students have been able to reach their full potential at PS 35 and will be prepared to continue to do so as they continue their academic journey.

Public School 36 has an extraordinary, comprehensive arts program. Our four licensed arts specialists share their knowledge and passion through small group and individualized lessons. Our band/music director conducts two bands in addition to teaching the general music curriculum. The theater arts teacher directs two theater companies as well as teaching the general theater curriculum: physical/vocal expression, playwriting, pantomime, scene work and improvisation. Our dance teacher works in a fully equipped dance studio and teaches different forms of dance as well as choreographic elements and the study of human anatomy. The visual arts teacher works in a variety of media, stressing problem solving. We have an Arts Academy for grades four and five that allows students to specialize in an art form. The third graders benefit from a continuing partnership with Learning Leaders that culminates in a visit to the Brooklyn Museum.

Our certified visual arts teacher provides visual arts for all of our students and is an artist by nature who also acts as a District Arts Professional Development Facilitator. Our school has transformed into a museum-like gallery exhibiting a plethora of visual arts and multi media projects throughout our corridors and adorning our walls, all produced by students. Some examples of the variety of art work include but are not limited to: clay, collage, paper mache, stitchery, water color, sculpture, puppetry, print, documentary photography, etc. All of our visual art teacher's work, as well as our art resident's, is aligned to the Blueprint For the Arts and is aligned to our curriculum across all content areas. Although we only have one visual arts teacher, we ensure that our students are provided with every opportunity to explore other art forms such as photography, technology, dance, and theater through experiences with on-site and off-site cultural organizations. We further immerse our students in real world experiences by aligning a variety of field trips to the arts.

At Public School 41 we provide our students with quality arts instruction. Our art program for Pre-k through fifth grade will continue to be taught by our full-time certified visual arts teacher. The teacher will instruct our children in all art media, organize our two annual Art Expos and art gallery, and coordinate participation in notable art contests such as PS Art, the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking contest and the Borough Arts Festival. 

Our music program will continue to be taught by a full-time music teacher and includes the following instruction: the precorder, recorder, violin, general music history, music composition and theory. Additionally, the teacher will oversee third grade chorus, fourth grade band, fifth grade band and fifth grade music enrichment.  

Our classroom teachers also work with students to incorporate the arts into their general education projects while the visual arts units are usually cross-curricular and align with social studies, science or reading and writing units by grade. Our students will continue to have the opportunity to explore dance and theater arts in both their regular school day and after-school programs.

As we continue our focus of increasing the arts within our instructional program, our school leadership, parent teacher association and faculty have been engaged in grant writing to help support and sustain the arts. We have retained grant support for electric pianos for our music/band program as well as grant money for technology and audio equipment for our theater program. The Public School 42 leadership, parent teacher association and faculty are committed to sustaining the arts as well as continue to leverage community recourses to continue growing and enhancing our program.

Public School 44R's arts program was expanded this year to include theater through a partnership with Sundog Theatre, visual arts through a partnership with Marquis Studios, violin through a partnership with the Noel Pointer Foundation, and dance through a partnership with Alvin Ailey. All classroom teachers ensure visual arts are an embedded component in their literacy programs and most classrooms participate in multiple performances involving dance, music and visual arts. We also have a thriving PS 44 Chorus for students in grades three through five. This year we incorporated S.T.E.A.M. (Science Technology Engineering Arts Math) for Pre-Kindergarten through Fifth Grade students as part of a celebration of Black History Month. In the future, Public School 44R will continue to develop a passion for creative learning in each and every child, allowing students to reach their fullest potential. We will continue to cultivate school-wide initiatives around arts education.

The arts curriculum at Public School 45 is aligned with the NYC DOE Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the NYS Arts Standards. In addition, rigorous arts instruction supports Common Core Standards. The students have the opportunity to participate in annual performances in school as well as in the community. They also have the opportunity to work with students from mentoring schools in the community, as well as teaching artists and cultural organizations, in order to create products and performances, collaboratively. The arts are integrated in other subject areas, such as: literacy, science, mathematics and social studies.

The students at P.S. 46 are eager to participate in the arts.  The entire school receives instruction in visual arts that finishes the year with a school-wide show. Our band program continues, with a pull out program for 4th and 5th graders, led by a dedicated volunteer instructor. The band is always happy to participate in assemblies finishes the year with a concert. The classroom teachers add dance, music and theater instruction.  We have theater productions done on each grade level and a whole school dance festival in June. The parents enjoy attending their children's art activities.
    This year we were fortunate to receive grants that enabled us to expand our arts' instruction. Alvin Ailey provided dance instruction, Sundog brought theater instruction, and the Staten Island Museum provided an after school program in the visual arts.

Q45_10: Capstone Expose, Arts Reception/Gallery Presentation Event, Poetry Slam, Music Concerts, Glee Club Concerts
Q46_1: CSIHS greatly values the Arts as a means of expression and as a means to engage students in higher order critical thinking.  The Arts are incorporated into all disciplines, and activities. We work to expand upon our school's int'l vision and mission through applications of the Arts. We offer classes in Visual Art & Digital Photograph, Instrumental Music through Percussion Ensembles, Drum Circle Facilitation, Modern Band Class as well as Vocal Music through our Glee Club.  Students in our Music Program are exposed to performing professionals, which enhances their musical experience.  From time to time, Artists in Residence are brought into classrooms via SKYPE lessons and in person. Through our Sophomore Poetry Project, students wrote, recited and dramatically performed their very own poetry compositions on the stage as part of our Poetry Slam.  Other outlets for artistic expression and performance can be seen in our talent show production, which incorporates music, dance, drama and vocal performances. Through our Senior Capstone Fair, students utilize the Arts to spread global competence and take community action to address a societal or international dilemma.  CSIHS has two major concerts a year, Glee Club concerts, and hosts smaller events, such as our Arts Reception celebrating students’ artistic talents with mini performances and an art expose.  This year students were also given the opportunity to work with a creative writer in residence who worked with students to develop short stories as an extra-curricular activity.

The arts curriculum at Public School/Intermediate School 48 is aligned with the NYC Department Of Education Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the NYS Arts Standards. Through partnerships with a variety of community organizations, students will be provided with cultural and artistic experiences to enhance the literacy curriculum. Our school is committed to providing a strong arts experience for all of our K-8 students.

The 6th, 7th , and 8th grade curriculum maps for the Arts are aligned with the Blueprint for the Arts. Each year students have the opportunity to participate in presentations and performances showcasing their talents.  Additionally, students have the opportunity to attend performances at local High Schools. Through our association with Alice Austen House, all 8th graders are provided with arts experiences that combine theater, dance and photography.  In this program, students learn about local Staten Island History and explore themes related to social/emotional intelligence.
The teachers also support their colleagues, and the school by providing support for Arts events at the school.

Public School 50 provides instruction in visual arts, chorus, and music to the entire student population as part of our regular academic program. Each class attends one period per week of music and art. Both programs showcase student work through performances and a culminating artwork exhibit. In addition to our regular program, Public School 50 has partnerships with two arts-based cultural organizations. Students in grades three through five participate in a long standing partnership with the NY Philharmonic. Teaching artists provide direct instruction on a weekly basis with an emphasis on recorders and musical composition. In addition, students attend two in-school concerts as well as a concert at Lincoln Center. The students perform their own compositions at a culminating performance. NY Philharmonic also provides professional development for classroom teachers.

Additional in-school programs offered at the school are: Band, Jazz Band, Violin, After-School Chorus, a Talent Show and a Storytelling Festival.

After school Arts opportunities in collaboration with Sundog Theater are also offered.  These include Dance & Theater.

P.S. 50 also engages the students/staff in cultural art-related trips and students participate in showcasing their arts accomplishments with the community at the District 31 Borough Arts Showcase, SI Yankee Stadium, etc.

We provide an opportunity for students to be exposed to various arts disciplines both during and after school.  Two of our three Academies are focused on Performing and Visual Arts with a three year sequence set up to build on prior knowledge and skill level.

The arts are celebrated and valued at Public School 52, where we are committed to providing quality instruction in all arts disciplines. We recognize the importance of family involvement and have provided our families with grade specific chorus performances, student performances of theater productions, band concerts, recorder concerts & Ballroom Dance Finale. We offer  arts opportunities through out the day with a full time Music teacher and a part time Visual Arts teacher and additional arts opportunities in our after-school programs as well, which is sponsored by NIA. Our teachers connect the arts to their curriculum in order to make learning more meaningful. Our administration supports the students, teachers, and arts residencies in enriching and extending student learning through the arts.

Arts Education is an important component in the educational program of each of our students at Public School 53. This year we have a full time Visual Arts teacher, as well as a full time Theater Arts teacher. Every student in our school receives instruction in one of the arts disciplines, once per week, while most of our Gifted and Talented students receive instruction in both Visual Arts and Theater Arts. In addition, the majority of our second grade students receive Visual Arts instruction two times per week.  We applied and received an ELLs and SWDs Visual Art Grant through the city.  Four classes encompassing that demographic received photography instruction during the school day culminating in a school wide Photography Gala.   For most of the school year fifth grade band students were provided with music instruction once per week.  Theater Arts students in grades Pre-K through Fifth have performed many times throughout the year, including Holiday Shows, Respect For All productions and a culminating Fifth Grade Musical.  We have continued partnerships, with Dancing Classrooms who provides ballroom dancing to our fifth grade students, and SunDog Theater who provides theater arts to our second grade students. Classroom teachers utilize various programs which infuse arts into curriculum areas, providing diverse opportunities for our students to learn through the arts.

Public School 54 is a Pre-K through 5 school which is dedicated to providing school-wide arts programs which enable our students to express themselves through music, visual arts and theater. Our school includes extracurricular activities in these areas as well. All of our art classes provide opportunities for active participation. The visual arts program follows the NYC DOE Blueprint for Teaching & Learning in Visual Arts. Public School 54’s music program serves pre-kindergarten through fifth grade students. Grades pre-k and kindergarten receive Music and Movement which includes movement activities, small percussion and singing. Grades one through three receive either recorder class, vocal class, or keyboard class depending on scheduling and location. Grades four and five are Modern Band guitar classes. Students in grades Pre k through two are working towards mastering the benchmarks for theater by activating and using their imaginations and exploring the use of the actor’s tools – body, voice and imagination. Using literacy as their source, students participate in group, partner and individual activities which include dramatic play, storytelling, puppetry, music, and dance. All activities are embedded in the ELA Common Core Learning Standards for the appropriate grade level. Students in grades three through five are working towards mastering the fifth grade benchmarks for theater. Students exercise and refine the actor’s instrument—the body, voice an

Q44_R4: Staten Island Institute for Arts & Sciences dba Staten Island Museum
Q46_1: Our goal is to allow every student access to each art discipline, and give them the foundation to explore their interests and strengths. The early childhood classes engage in music appreciation instruction with a certified music teacher. Each teacher in the early childhood grades integrate visual arts across the curriculum. Our drama program services students after school in the creation of a Broadway style play.  Each child performs at one grade assembly. Our second grade students receive recorder instruction in music. Our third graders have chorus and a small group is selected to participate in a violin program. Fourth grade students are selected for violin or band, and perform twice a year.  Our fifth grade students attend ballroom dance with Dancing Classrooms. Students are selected for band and violin. There is a full time visual arts program that services some classes at each grade level. We also offer visual arts, and drama in our after-school program.

We provide an inclusive environment where special needs students are able to showcase their talents, and build upon their unique artistic abilities. Accommodations have been made to meet individual needs, highlight strengths, and work around limitations.  5th grade students performed at the P.S. Family Fun Day.   Students participated in a Halloween Dance Festival and Winter Holiday Musical Review.  Kindergarten students performed an animated-themed Spring Musical performance on stage, while our 3rd and 4th grade students presented a “Broadway Showstoppers” show.  Our 5th graders presented 16 self-directed scenes in “An Evening of Folktales and Fairytales”. We hosted our third Annual Spring Dance Festival in our school yard at the end of May. Stepping Up ceremonies for children in grades pre-k, kindergarten and fifth grade incorporated visual and performing arts elements.  Visual arts classes worked on various contest entries, including the Disability Poster Contest, Earth Day Poster Contest, and also created Senior Residence holiday gifts.  Student artwork was featured in Art shows at the Conference House and Snug Harbor. In addition, P.S.56 hosted two visual art gallery showings for parents.  Plans are already in the works for additional art enrichment opportunities in the coming school year.

Public School 57 will continue to have a full-time dance teacher and a music program for all grades, kindergarten through 5th. Our  partnership with Education through Music will continue into its third year. This will ensure that all of our students have music in their weekly program throughout the entire year and that we will have two certified music teacher on staff. We look forward to starting our second year as Community School through the 21st Century grant that we received.  We will work with our lead CBO the YMCA to enhance all aspect of our school. Hopefully this will allow us to expand our arts programming. Puppetry in Practice and Sun-dog were two artist residencies that we hope to continue to work directly with our students in the visual arts and theater programs.  We also would like to continue our work with the American Ballet Theater so professional dancers can instruct our students again this coming school year.

Public School 58's art program strives to achieve fidelity to the mandated Blueprints for the Arts. We provide learning opportunities across all grade levels to all children in theater, music, visual arts and dance. We believe that learning through the arts is a valuable and necessary part of students' education. Our goal is to continue to provide these opportunities through one full time visual arts teacher as well a full time music/theater teacher. These teachers serve the entire school community. In conjunction with community based organizations, we provide theater residencies to all second grade classes. Culminating performances through the school year celebrate student achievement with the school community. At the end of May, each school year, we celebrate the arts with an Evening of the Arts Performance showcasing the students' achievements in music and dance. In addition, our building displays our students' visual art work done throughout the year to showcase our commitment to the arts.

Q44_R5: Cumbe: Center for African and Diaspora Dance
Q46_1:
P.S. 59 The Harbor View School is located in the historic St. George area of Staten Island. Our school is a choice school providing families around Staten Island (and all of NYC) an opportunity to apply to a school with new ideas around education.

We have formed partnerships with programs such as Historic Richmond Town, Staten Island Children’s Museums, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, The Noble Maritime Collection, Billion Oyster Project and many more to name a few. 

Our commitment to the arts is very evident in the work in which we engaged in and in the partnerships we create. We have our own art and drama teacher. In addition we collaborated with Sundog Theatre, Cumbe African Dance, Salvadori and Illuminart, who provided our students with in-school residencies.

In addition, to best support a curriculum where the instructional focus is based on an inquiry and project-based approach, teachers have blocks of time where they can fully engage in the depth of the work. The afternoon arts block provides students the opportunity to develop an appreciation for the arts, be art literate and connect the arts to the social context in which their grade focuses on (self, neighborhood, etc.. Using the Seven Guiding Principles for the Arts developed by David Coleman, students study current art, art history, how art impacts current society and explore a variety of tools, mediums and genres.

The Arts at P.S. 60 continues to flourish and the proof is in our commitment to instructional practice.We have two licensed visual arts instructors, a licensed music instructor and a licensed dance instructor.Our Arts instructors meet weekly to discuss and plan during professional development activities that align with the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and the National State Standards. Visual arts students learn skills through scaffolded lessons to build on skills.Students use sketchbooks/journals to track their progress. Smartboard technology and iPads enable students to see and research what is occurring in the Art world.Art work is posted on Artsonia, a virtual student art museum.All students are part of a yearly school-based art show.Our updated dance studio has wooden floors, mirrors and a balance bar  to help students improve their craft.The dance program offers students the opportunity to build their technical and expressive skills and develop their artistry.Dance students have performed throughout SI at Cultural Events.All classes receive a structured dance experience to develop physical, cognitive and social skills.Music students play guitar and sing in student centered lessons.The music repertoire covers music from cultural folk songs to modern pop music.The program is outfitted with 2 complete sets of 3/4 and 1/2 size classical guitars.Students can perform with percussion, electric bass and electric guitars.Our newly added Advanced Chorus, after-school Art, Dance and Guitar Clubs reinforce our commitment to the arts.

William A. Morris Intermediate School 61, a designated Magnet School of the Arts in New York City, is a thriving middle school with a teaching and administrative staff committed to nurturing and encouraging the artistic potential of all of our students in grades six through eight. We continue as a School of Arts and Letters through Museum Studies as designated by our previous Federal Magnet Grant through the US Department of Education. We are proud of our reputation as a school which both infuses and enriches arts education for our students during their time at our school. We continue to develop young musicians, singers, actors, dancers, visual artists, and filmmakers, while cultivating a lifelong love of the arts in all of the young men and women who attend our school. Our school continues to teach and encourage immersion in the many different arts disciplines as indicated by the NYC Department of Education Blueprint for the Arts. All of our students benefit from the many different tenets for success in the arts and those in the three-year immersion disciplines for the arts areas: Band, Orchestra, Choir, Drama, Dance, Visual Arts, Photo & Film Journalism, receive an unparalleled experience at the middle school level.

Students in grades pre-k through grade two received visual arts and dance instruction each week by a cluster teacher. The curriculum is aligned to the Common Core Learning Standards as well as the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. During this time students were made aware of the standards, were given opportunities to self-assess, peer-assess and create goals so that they can take ownership of their learning. Students also received visual arts, dance and theater instruction in the classroom. Creative dance movement blends movement, music, improvisation,and basic dance steps while providing an excellent introduction for the future of all dance techniques. What they learn through both classroom and out of classroom instruction is then showcased for parents through annual performances. This year our pre-k sites participated in the NYC Pre-K Create track. Visual arts, dance, theater, and music were incorporated into ongoing instruction to promote student learning in multiple Prekindergarten Foundation for the Common Core domains. Through professional development we learned new ways to design classroom learning centers so that art activities are integrated.  Additionally, we have partnered with our afterschool organization, NYCID, to extend the arts into afterschool hours.  This year students were offered a dance club, a visual arts club and a theater club.  All clubs were determined based upon parent surveys.
Q47_1: Although my Dance Teacher is not certified in dance she is a graduate of Dance Educators of America,has knowledge of the dance blueprint, professional development in the dance blue print,college credits and G Credits in dance and a Zumba Certification.

Q46_1: At Marsh Avenue Expeditionary Learning School, the arts are integrated in every aspect of the students' lives. As well as using the arts to strengthen ELA, we also incorporate them into our expeditions and presentations of learning. Students take great pride in their performances and have made a name for themselves throughout our school community.

The Gaynor McCown EL High School values the influence that arts education has on core academic subjects. Our visual arts teacher provides arts instruction to beginners as well as advanced students. Students performed in our talent show and presented Broadway Babies. We are the only Staten Island school to participate in TDF's Open Doors Theater Scholarship Program, where eight students are selected to work with a mentor/theater professional and see six Broadway performances throughout the year.
Q47_1: We only have a visual arts certified teacher.  We have musicians on staff who host after school clubs, like guitar and chorus.  If we had funding, we would love to have a band program, but that requires not only a music teacher but instruments, which are not RESO A eligible even though they have a shelf life of more than 5 years and are "bricks and mortar."  Assistance with that would be most appreciated!

Q46_1: This year, through our partnership with Studio in a School, students worked in a variety of art media: collage, tempera paint, wood construction and clay sculpture. The kindergarten students were exposed to these materials once a week for 50 minutes. Initially the teaching-artist engaged in a whole-class lesson, then selected a small group to work on the art. The classroom teacher would then take small groups during the week to create the piece of art introduced by the artist. All students were able to produce an art piece in each of the genres.

Our goal for this year 2017-2018, is for students to self reflect on their own work. Each student will be offered an opportunity to self reflect on their work(aligned to exemplars and their own research), thinking about possible next steps they can incorporate for future pieces.

Q39_4: donating time for bake sale fundraising, dance competitions
Q46_1: The Police Officer Rocco Laurie Intermediate School 72 is an ethnically diverse middle school located in Staten Island, N.Y. with a population total of 1,434 students. We have a growing fine arts program that offers instrumental music ( tracked 3 year program), vocal music ( tracked 3 year program), general music and dance.   Students are offered a three-year sequence in music (band and chorus) that follows a curriculum aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. In addition to our successful dance classes, we have implemented a dance team which has performed at several school events, outside dance competitions, and the Borough Arts Festival at the St. George Theater. This year we have also expanded our music program to include an after school jazz band.  These students have played at numerous community events and the Borough Arts Festival as well.

At Future Leaders Elementary School we value arts education.  We have a teacher that is assigned to teach theater on staff.  The students take turns performing at community meetings that are held bi-weekly.  These performances tie in to our Leaders in Me curriculum.  Our students participate in the School Enrichment Model.  There our students have the opportunity to experience other aspects of art education including, photography, drama club, and painting.

Q44_R2: Learning Through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)
Q46_1: Our arts program is dedicated to the visual arts, dance, music and theater. Each program is a three-year sequence and is a comprehensive application of each specific discipline. Our performing arts program offers Major Band A & B, Chorus, Drama, Dance, Video & Stage Production. The collaborative effort allows our students to reach their potential in each area and provides them with multiple venues in order to perform their talents. Holiday shows, concerts, musicals and extra-curricular functions allow our students to showcase their talent. Many of our students audition for schools such as LaGuardia high School and have achieved high levels of success in their secondary and collegiate careers. The visual arts includes Digital Arts & Design, Fine Arts and Graphic Arts & Print Production. Fine Arts allows our students to express their talents using media such as watercolors, pastels, oils and charcoal to generate beautiful pieces of art that adorn our building. The Digital Arts program affords our students with the opportunity to utilize current software applications to generate a wide variety of projects of student interpretations of design. Graphic Design and Print allows our students to work on the design and application of logos and other media displays. Our program is supported by an extremely talented and gifted staff who lend their expertise to our developing artists. The talents of our students are showcased each year in our annual Night of the Arts.

The units of study we implemented this year aligns well with the Common Core Learning Standards as well as the Blueprint for the Arts. We have expanded our arts partnerships to now include theater, music, dance and the visual arts. Our previous residencies with the New York Philharmonic, Sundog, Alice Austin House and Marquis Studios, have opened the doors to the resources that are an integral part of the development of young artists. We have continued with the NY Philharmonic, and added numerous Community School partners that include Lincoln Center, Staten Island Children's Museum, the Staten Island Zoo, Dancing Classrooms, and Y Superstars. We have continued with Steven Covey's Seven Habits, and have incorporated the Leader of the Month assemblies, which highlight the students that exhibit the Leader in Me qualities. This year we have our third arts culminating event, an Art Expo, to coincide with our Leadership Day. In our community school, we collaborate to create activities that ensure family participation. We are excited about our work in helping to design our new playground with the Parks Department. Our objective is to closely listen to the needs and concerns of the school community so as to enhance the ownership of the work we do here at Public School 78. Our partnerships and programming in the arts ensures that every student and family experience all that New York City has to offer.

The Michael J. Petrides School is a seamless pre-kindergarten through twelfth grade school, committed to providing a learning environment that nurtures the whole child; mind, body, and spirit. Teachers, parents, administrators, and support staff collaborate to provide an education that celebrates the diversity of our students and recognizes the individuality and creativity of each child. We are proud of our comprehensive arts program which inspires interest and encourages students to develop their talents in dance, music, theater, and art.

New Dorp High School’s mission is to provide an environment that enables all students to grow academically, intellectually, socially, emotionally, and culturally. We are divided into eight Smaller Learning Communities, one of which is dedicated to the arts. The Academy of Fine & Dramatic Arts (AFADA) supports a complete academic program and includes dedicated staff and space to students who major in fine and performing arts. There are five sequences of electives offered: dance, drama, art, fashion design  and music, which include lessons aligned to the Common Core and Hochman Method writing exercises, as well as collaboration with dedicated staff to support interdisciplinary activities. Students experience a scaffolded sequence of courses for each of the five concentrations. Each contain beginner, intermediate and advanced classes along with options such as stagecraft, film, photo art, art history, portfolio, chorus, band, piano and guitar. Throughout the year, students are afforded a cadre of opportunities outside the classroom. Moving forward, we used our school survey to create new, more rigorous coursework designed to engage students and foster student participation in extracurricular activities. These include a choice between fine art and fashion design sophomore year and AP Drawing senior year.

Port Richmond High School is committed to providing a comprehensive arts education. Our highly qualified arts teachers constantly assess student work throughout the year. We offer many classes for students to begin or continue their study in the arts. The performing arts classes offered at Port Richmond High School are Beginning Band, Concert Band, Symphonic Band, Jazz Band, Big Band, Marching Band, Chorus, Beginning Guitar, Guitar Ensemble, Beginning Strings, Advanced String Orchestra, and Introduction to Theatre.   We offer a sequential Visual Arts program as well.  Classes include Drawing, Studio Art, and Portfolio Development.  We also offer a sequential TV/Media sequence culminating in the production of our weekly TV show Good Morning Port Richmond.  Our Marching Band can be seen in parades throughout New York City as well as up and down the eastern seaboard. We have a SING production in the fall and a musical each spring. In March, 2018 we produced Guys and Dolls.  The students in our Music Department attend music festivals outside the school each year and perform at various school and community functions. Partnerships include Exploring the Arts (Tony Bennett & Susan Benedetto), Carnegie Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, and ABC Grants awarded through Staten Island Council on the Arts.

Q39_4: Title I - Paint classes for parents
Q46_1: Curtis High School is a comprehensive high school located on the north shore of Staten Island near the Staten Island Ferry. Curtis High School provides arts instruction in the 4 four major art forms of dance, theatre, music and visual art. Curtis offers a sequence in Graphic Design and Fine Arts, Jazz Band, Concert Band, Orchestra, Guitar Ensemble, and Chorus. Dance programs are offered in Modern, Ballet, Survey and Choreography. Dance, Art and Theatre all offer International Baccalaureate classes. All students at Curtis High School can pursue a sequence in the arts regardless of which Small Learning Community they belong to.

Q45_10: NYSSMA Adjudication Festival, Advanced Placement Exams in Music Theory & Drawing
Q46_1: Tottenville High School offers a myriad of arts courses to every ninth through twelfth grade student, and is the only Staten Island High School to offer students the option to complete the required coursework to attain a NYCDOE  Chancellor's Endorsed Arts Diploma in Music or Fine Arts.  Course offerings in Fine Arts include: Advanced Placement Drawing, Fashion, Computer Art, Television, Multi-Dimensional Design, Analog & Digital Photography, Advertising, Drawing , Painting, Architecture, Technical & Computer Aided Drawing Lab, Adobe Web Design, Graphic Design, Art Portfolio, Core Art, and Art History. Courses in Performing Arts include: Advanced Placement Music Theory, Symphonic, Concert, Intermediate, Jazz & Beginning Band; Symphony, Intermediate & Beginning Orchestra; Vocal Training, Mixed & Concert Choir, a nationally recognized competitive Marching Band that performs throughout the metropolitan area and Walt Disney World annually, Beginning and Advanced Guitar & Piano Labs, Music History, and extensive after-school Chamber Ensemble opportunities. Every arts student in our large, 4,000-plus school is important. They become integral members of smaller learning communities, creating a family-type experience. Parent support, as well as great rapport between teachers and students, create an enriched, rigorous learning and creative atmosphere.

The Susan E. Wagner High School arts program has a wide array of courses and specialized teachers within each discipline. The music program has performed to critical acclaim throughout New York City and the country at various festivals, competitions and public venues. This April, the music department swept top honors in all instrumental categories at the Heritage Festival Competition in Boston, MA. Music courses include multi-leveled ensembles in chorus, band, and guitar, as well as composition. The Theatrical Arts Institute is a four-year sequential program, which includes courses in acting, directing, stage design, musical theatre, and playwriting. In addition to class work, students are engaged in a number of full-scale productions each year including musicals and dramatic plays. The visual arts program has opportunities for students to study art through a variety of media including painting, drawing, graphic design, and photography. Students regularly contribute artwork to galleries and national competitions each year. The Dance Learning Center offers multi-leveled courses in Ballet, Jazz, Tap, and Modern.
Our technology rich school environment provides the tools necessary to create a cutting edge Graphic Design program.

Ralph McKee Career and Technical Education High School (CTE) has a highly structured sequence of courses for students to receive CTE certification and an academic diploma. All ninth grade students take one year in art. A three-year sequence in the graphic arts and design explores digital applications and software, film and commercial art, and desktop publishing. The course culminates in the industry based Skills USA assessment, and Adobe certifications through the NOCTI exam. All students have the opportunity to apply for internships, work based learning opportunities, Scholars at Work; Summer Youth Employment Program through the community based organization: United Artists Unlimited, and earn a CTE endorsed regents diploma. Through State Senator Savino, the school provided opportunities for an interdisciplinary visit to museums, a 2-day tour of SUNY and private colleges, and trips to see theatrical releases in connection with interdisciplinary units between English and Social Studies. Through Sun Dog Theater, the school provided opportunities for students to engage in music editing and production around social and emotional themes that concern adolescents.

This year, were able to maintain our sequence for theater and music. We instituted student workshops after working with Sundog Theatre, Inc. This year we were not given the grant for a resident visual artist as we had last year.  However, we worked tirelessly to fundraise in order to bring the program back and expand it. This allowed an even greater number of student visual artists to participate in classes for drawing, sketching, and photography under the tutelage of their advisor. Currently the visual arts program is an after-school club, but we have a great deal of talent in our school and would like to introduce the visual arts as a complete school curriculum. We are creative in utilizing our TV studio by allowing students hands-on experience when filming student productions. Core subject teachers continue to work with our TV studio teachers to have student presentations filmed and streamed throughout the building on the hallway televisions to better reach the student body with messages and spirited information. We continue to bring students to the opera, the ballet and Broadway to enhance their relationships with the arts. Each year we try to grow in new directions a bit more, taking full advantage of New York City and its cultural offerings.  Finally, as a  a specialized school that prides itself on a STEAM curriculum and CTE, teachers and students have paired with the CTE department in order to become a greater presence in our school's maker space.  A mural project is currently underway!

By June of 2019, 100% of our students will receive and engage in a comprehensive art, music, dance or dramatic performance education, and will demonstrate common core standards as measured by the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. 
This includes visual art and/or performance arts. K-8  schedules in rotation blocks allows students to receive this education. Students will incorporate learning into stage and school performances for parents/community. Intermediate students will be programmed into a track of art, band, chorus or drama, dependent upon interest/talent.To supplement in-house performing arts instruction, we formed a partnership with CASA, giving students the opportunity to participate in theater and dance. Even though we have no residency this year, our teachers have been trained through past residencies to teach dance to our students and continue to provide for students. As a culmination all students will display their talents through various performances and art exhibits, which will be documented and assessed and will be open to the community.

Q44_R1_C2: Alley Park Queens Festival of Cultures
Q44_R5: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q46_1: Public School/ Intermediate School 45K provides students with the opportunity to learn to play musical instruments, act on stage, sing in a chorus and engage in hands-on arts projects. Funds are set aside to enable all students to participate in cultural activities, such as field trips to the theater, visits to art galleries and engage with on-site artistic consultants. We have purchased keyboards and percussion instruments to enhance the musical capabilities of our students during the school day. Teachers of the arts continue to be provided with professional development training throughout the school year, which enhances their knowledge and our arts programs. For the seventh year, Music and the Brain, in their early childhood keyboard program, has engaged our students in learning literature through song and play,. There is a strong family involvement component in which parents participate in cultural activities and engage in a variety of musical and artistic experiences. Our goal for the school year is to differentiate the arts learning for students of all grades. The Middle School Arts partnership has been extremely beneficial to our sixth through eighth grade students. During elective periods on Friday, students engage in chorus and dance. In preparation for high school, eighth grade students have an opportunity to build art portfolios with a visual arts focus.

The Mayda Cortiella Elementary School envisions all students in our music program meeting the benchmark standards in the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. These goals are integrated into the overall vision and mission statement of our school and provide each student with a balanced education within each grade's curriculum. Our goals next year are to build on a more balanced, project based curriculum that includes Orff-Schulwerk style class ensembles in each grade level. We will also have winter and spring concerts, in which all students will participate and parents are invited. The collegiality of administrators and teachers helps create a unified environment within Public School 75. The outcome of our efforts produces a stimulating learning environment of vibrant, multi-talented, high performing students.

Q44_R3: Paul Taylor's American Modern Dance Theatre
Q46_1: We currently have two certified arts teachers on staff, one in music and one in dance. All students receive an hour of each art form a week and some classes receive additional arts instruction. We have a select group of students who participate in a band and choir facilitated by the music teacher. There are also select students who participate in additional dance and musical theater programming. Students are highly engaged and involved in the annual performances put on by the music and dance programs. This year Public School 86 had two in-school residencies: dance with Movement Research and visual arts with Studio in a School as well as an after school program with Inside Broadway. We also provide our school community with outside school art field trips. Our school is committed to exposing our students, parents, and community to different art forms and experiences.
Q47_1: Through grants, reduced ticket costs, and free arts programming we were able to provide our students with an array of rich art experiences. However, due to reduced funding we were unable to continue working with some of our past art residencies and were unable to attend performances whose tickets were to high.

Q46_1: At Public School 106 we currently offer dance and visual arts in grades pre-kindergarten through fifth. Each student at our school is given the opportunity to partake in our arts program. Our goal is to instill in our students a deep appreciation of the arts. In addition, our students are offered the opportunity to participate in after-school arts activities. Through the after-school program, the students receive a rich array of disciplines which include music, dance, mural design, and video production. Our curricuulm is based on NY state standards and Blueprint benchmarks. Our arts program is supported by parental and community based involvement. We are looking forward to enriching our community through the arts.

Q32_6: Visits to other schools, teachers union of NYC
Q46_1: In 2015 - 2016 Public School 116 - Elizabeth L Farrell made a commitment to expand our arts program and we continued that work last year as well as this school year. We have two licensed art teachers in both visual arts and music, who continue to attend professional development to increase their knowledge in these areas in order to fully incorporate and embed the arts into our curriculum. Our goal of becoming a school of the arts, is partially based on the fact that a strong art curriculum, combined with content area subjects, enhances and improves student learning, and in some cases, has even helped in closing learning gaps; especially for English Language Learners and students with disabilities. This year we discovered that our ELL population is very talented in the area of visual arts and music, and we are proud of their accomplishments in these areas. We use the Blueprints for the Arts to guide our curriculum and instruction. We have dedicated space in our building to accommodate an art room and a music room housed with equipment such as instruments, smartboards, computers, and an abundance of art supplies. Our art teachers meet with teachers across disciplines and grades, to create interdisciplinary lessons. Our grant team  meets weekly to seek out grants and opportunities to provide funding for our arts program. This year we are proud to begin working in the new state of the art visual arts room that was provided to us through a city grant. The students are very excited about working in this new art lab.
Q47_1: The student population of PS 116 - Elizabeth L Farrell consists mostly of English Language Learners and former ELL's.  We have discovered through research, data and our own initiates that these type of students respond well and learn a great deal through the arts.  It is a universal way for them to express their ideas and have their individual talents shine.  This gives them confidence to tackle more challenging work and provides a foundation for which they can build upon. The correlations they make through visual arts and music helps these students with things such as phonics, vocabulary and reading comprehension.

Q46_1:
Public School 145 has a collaborative residency with Studio in a School that has been on-going for the last five years. The artist in residence provides visual arts instruction to the majority of the students in the school throughout the year. Students have shown growth in their artistic techniques in a variety of media such as sculpture, collage, painting and animation. Students' culminating projects show their in-depth thinking and understanding of artistic creativity. 
PS 145 also collaborates with the "Little Kid Rock" program to provide music instruction with string instruments. 
This year, we again received funding to continue an after-school dance and drumming program in collaboration with the Brooklyn Arts Council. This program supports and highlights our multi-cultural appreciation for our students and families.

This is our third year with our music teacher who is continuing the school-day instrumental music program. For kindergarten through second grade, the students have learned keyboard using the Music and the Brain program, and the students in grades three through five have learned guitar and music composition using various music technology programs such as SoundTrap and Chrome Music Lab. This year we have included ukuleles in the music club. This year's visual arts students enjoyed the arts club. In the art club, students have experimented with different painting techniques. The students participated in a three-part educational program with MOMA, which allowed them to refine their critiquing and creating skills. Our 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade students visited the MET. The students participated in contests, such as the Water Contest, Respect Contest, Black History Month, PS 1, and Brooklyn Art Festival. Our students' artwork is published on the internet website Artsonia, which is an online gallery where families can view their child's artwork. This year we commenced after-school programs in collaboration with Bronx Arts Ensemble, ASPIRA and LEAP. Our select students are participating in Theater, Creative Arts and Sculpture, hip-hop and violin.  These select students that participate in the afterschool program will be presenting in their June 8th culminating events along side the entire school of students.

IS 162 has a visual arts program offered during the school day to all 6th and 8th graders. Theater is offered during the school day to all 7th graders. We have an afterschool arts program funded by Empire After-School. Our after school grant funds a visual arts club and a theater musical program that involves, theater/acting, set production, singing/chorus, and dance.

Q47_1: Students in Advanced Art class created large scale paintings and raised money at a silent auction held at our school. This fund raiser raised money to donate to victims of the hurricanes this past fall. Students learn the value of creating art and the impact it could have on the world around them. Students were able to raise $900 to the American Red Cross to be donated to hurricane victims.

Q46_1: The 2017-18 arts program at Public School 274 incorporated music, visual arts, dance and theater instruction for students in pre-k through fifth grade. Our school values creativity, imagination, self expression and the ability to apply knowledge across content areas. Students need these skills more than ever as they prepare for higher education and the work force. Our school cultivates these skills through arts instruction. Public School 274 collaborated with Brooklyn Academy of Music, New Victory Theater, Little Kids Rock, and Disney Musicals in Schools to include music, dance, theater and visual arts to enrich our curriculum. The Music and the Brain program gave kindergarteners and first graders the tools to learn to read music through classroom keyboard lessons.  Students in kindergarten and first grade finished the year with a piano recital for parents and faculty members.  In addition, Visual Thinking Strategy is implemented throughout our building to support our love for visual arts through rich discussion. All classes visit our art studio where the art teacher introduces different artists and their techniques, many times blending in themes that support the units of study in the classrooms. Student art work will be celebrated at a school-wide art exhibition at the end of May. Our after school program with Disney Musicals in schools offered a unique theater experience to students in grades 3-5, culminating in a performance of Lion King Kids at the end of May and a trip to perform one song from the musical on Broadway.

At Intermediate Schools 291K, students in grades six through eight receive visual arts instruction as required by the state and National Standards. Students are introduced to the elements and principles of art through units, in painting, drawing, collage and 2D design.
Q47_1: It would be nice if our school can be allocated more funding for another arts discipline, preferably a dance or music program Teacher. As of now our school has just one certified Teacher in the arts.

Q46_1:
Intermediate School 347 is fully committed to the arts. We have full-time visual arts and dance teachers that provide instruction to students in grades 6, 7 and 8. We currently have a Humanities team which conducts interdisciplinary planning and execution of lessons for our eighth grade students through Visual Arts, Dance, English Language Arts, Social Studies and Foreign Language. We hope to build on the gains and performance made by this teacher team to infuse both math and science as well.  We currently have residencies and partnerships with prestigious organizations such as the Center for Arts Education and the Urban Arts Partnership.
Our school hosts numerous arts exhibitions and shows throughout the year as well as provide off-site family trips to prestigious institutions such as the Lincoln Center for Ballet.  We also provide Arts instruction for our families during numerous workshops.
We hope to extend our residencies so that even more exposure to the arts is offered.

The goal is to create a visual arts program that is aligned to the academic standards outlined by New York State and the Blueprint for the arts. Programs, such as the Salvadori Skyscrapers program, will be offered during to support additional arts learning. Additionally, we have added two 3D printers to provide students with the opportunity to engage in digital arts, and fabricate their designs.

With the changes to our arts programs for the 2017-2018 academic year we were able to reach ch our goals.
