The introduction of Media Arts as a daily class for our students created a new outlet for students to further express themselves. Our pedagogues participated in professional development and peer observations to aligned their work to the CCLS standards and develop their skills further. Through the use of technology in the class rooms the teachers were able to provide a deeper artistic experience for the students. Also our partnership with the Brooklyn Arts Council and the CASA After school program has provided our students with additional opportunities in dance and singing. We will continue to provide professional development and conduct frequent observations with meaningful feedback to ensure our arts instruction is aligned to the Common Core State Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. We will continue to offer professional development in Instructional Technology to incorporate 21st Century skills in instruction and utilizing teacher feedback we will look forward to improvements that can be realized to enrich the student experience in art.

All of our students (pre-K through 8th grade) have participated in Assembly programs for their families that incorporated a music and dance component. All decorative art work for performances is created by teachers, paras and students. 

Our 7th and 8th graders were provided Theater Arts instruction.
Q47_1: Due to our school's budget deficit we had to excess our Music Teacher. Arts Matter was able to bless us with an F-Status Theater Art's Teacher for our 7th and 8th graders. Thanks to Art's Matter our 8th graders will meet their requirement for graduation.

Q46_1: The arts program at Philippa Schyuler Middle School for the Gifted & Talented has been one of our prized jewels for many years! This versatile program offers students the opportunity to study a variety of disciplines. From Modern and World dance to Steel Pan and Major Chorus, our students are immersed in learning activities that afford them the chance to express themselves and showcase their many talents in a multitude of ways. This year, one of our school's goals has been to continue to enrich and expand the performing & visual arts program within our school community. Given this focus, we have boosted our level of performance, and expanded both of our annual winter and spring concerts to encompass more diversity and theatrical elements. We also put together an elaborate production of the theatrical play, Peter & The Starcatcher, with full cast and crew! We have also expanded on our International Day celebrations to include more performance opportunities that highlight a variety of cultures. In addition, we have created partnerships with local arts educational programs to prepare our students with the foundation skills needed to succeed in these realms. Through these comprehensive programs, students learn valuable, life-long skills that are necessary to working in large and diverse groups. Additionally, they broaden the scope of our school community, allowing for teachers, students and parents to come together and acknowledge the hard work and diligence found within our performing and visual arts program.

Students in K-8 grade all received visual arts classes throughout the school year. Our 4th grade students received dance instruction via the Alvin Alley Arts in Residence program. In addition, students in PreK- 3 received music through the "Music in the Brain" program. Through the Arts Matter grant we provided Theater classes to our 6th, 7th and 8th grade students. We also integrated arts into our middle school advisory program. During Advisory middle school students have the opportunity to learn how to play the guitar and drums. For our 3-5 graders we offered after-school dance classes through FYRE Zone, and our middle school students can attend SASF after-school. We also started an Arts and Crafts after-school program on Fridays which is open to all students. 

Our goal for next year is to further integrate Arts in the content areas if we are awarded the LEAP grant. In addition, we are pursuing other ways to bring music into our middle school classrooms.

Visual art at AEL is offered as the vehicle for arts-credit accrual.  At present, four classes of Intro Art are taught, covering the 11th grade and most of the 10th grade (with a few 9th and 12th graders in each heterogeneous class).  Students who show interest, drive and ability are able to take AP Studio Art: Drawing in the following year (this will soon be a two-yr class, once Intro Art is moved fully to 10th Grade); students who are able to produce enough portfolio work will have their works submitted via AP exam.  This year, most of the AP class was seniors with only one year to produce 24 portfolio pieces, and the timeframe was too short for them to fulfill the exam requirements.  

Intro art is widely differentiated to meet the needs of students with very different levels of previous art exposure.  It's mostly project-based as a way of teaching artmaking skills while giving students agency and works they want to invest themselves in.  In the second semester, projects become longer-form and more intense (comics on Bristol, clay sculptures).  

AP art, after a few guided projects early in the year, runs on the Teaching Artistic Behavior model wherein the teacher helps each student create his or her own personally-planned work.  

Next year, I plan on AP class taking field trips to the Museum of Modern Art as a way to find inspiration and stake a personal claim in the arts institutions in NYC (too many students think it's inaccessible).  I hope to find more funding to allow more materials for all of my classes.

Here at EBC, we believe that the arts provide students with a holistic educational experience in which they can express themselves. Students have shown to improve in all academic areas based on the skill that they learn in arts courses; listening, speaking, collaboration, engagement, reading, mathematics, and literacy skills are enhanced.
Q47_1: Our school utilizes multiple forms of art: visual, music, audio, and film. We have dedicated train professional artists that work with students in supporting their artistic expressions. We believe that the arts provide an alternative form of assessment for our students. The arts have been proven to engage our students in a manner that words and numbers cannot.

Q46_1: The visual arts curriculum at the Brooklyn School for Social Justice is a full year, double credited course. The art program is divided into two sections Into to Studio Art and Intro to Design. In Studio Art students learn basic art theory, art making techniques based on contemporary art influences with an emphasis in drawing, painting and 2D art making. In Intro to Design, students explore fashion design, industrial design, advertising and architecture. Students develop experience working in teams to solve art challenges and learn the basic skills of public speaking through classroom presentation. Students are also introduced to art history and build on their knowledge of global history as a support tool for their upcoming regents in June. AP Studio Art Drawing is offered to our excelling artists in eleventh and twelfth grades with the emphasis on portfolio development and college readiness. AP art is offered as both a single or double year program.

Our partnership with Bronx Enselmble has been incredible- students enjoy our resident instructors in learning about visual art, dance, theater and music. Coordination among our staff with the resident artists has allowed for a wonderful multi-year experience where students have grown in their artistic expression. We will continue to partner with LeAp to have our students learn and express themselves in creative ways, both in the classroom and in public performances.

The staff and teachers at Bushwick Leaders’ High School for Academic Excellence provide a focused arts program with specific instructional goals. We expose our students to the world of theater, visual arts, music and dance and provide them with the knowledge and understanding about arts resources, programs, museums and theaters available in the NYC area. The arts help students to become critical thinkers through connections to the content being studied in English language arts, math, social studies and science classes, as aligned to the Common Core Standards.

in addition to having a full time theater and music teacher, we have a part time visual arts teacher.  The Arts Team meets weekly and collaborates in developing three Showcases a year.  Students, staff and families are invited to attend.  In addition, we have joined with P53, the D75 school in the building to work with Marquis Studios.  We applied for the grant, and received it for two years in a row. Finally, our art teachers work diligently to support our students who apply to specialized art high schools.

Our school offers a digital art program focused on instruction in Adobe Suite. The program includes animation, special effects training and skill-building to allow for alternative options for college or art schools. We plan to bring more professional artists into the classroom and increase links with technology. We intend to enhance connections with potential art schools, colleges and universities, to explore careers in the arts, and promote arts and media internships.

Our school has strived aggressively to intensify its arts instructional program. The goal for our arts program is to expand it to include more opportunity in theater, photography and film for all of our students, with an intensification of our visual arts, music and dance instructional hours. We plan to increase and expand our partnership with external cultural arts organizations to provide professional learning for classroom teachers and non-certified teachers of the Arts

We strongly need financial help in space and infrastructure material to be able to provide important instruction in the Arts

This is the first school year since the 80's that we did not have a certified Fine Art teacher.  However, we continued to provide our special needs students with opportunities to experience the arts in many aspects of our curriculum. A few examples are" for black history month, each class created a visual art display reflective of a famous quote.  Various art forms, such as painting, collage, drawing and lettering were utilized.  Our HS program collaborated and developed a quilt the represented African American History rich with color, thoughtfulness and representation.  Asian New year provided students with the opportunties to experiencek the Art, Music and Dance fo the Asian cultures that included practice and presentation of the Lion Dance and it's historical significance.  Our Physical Education staff provided opportinities to learn about Tai Chi and Qi Gong to enable students to better manage their own behaviors and develop a deeper self-management and internal practice, while learning to appreciate this beautiful movement meditation of the asian culture. This year our hearing impaired classes presented songs they learned and prsented to other classes in our program. In science, students created "scrap wood" race cars and raced them while learning about friction, gravity, and motion. Throughout our school year, we ensure that students have the opportunity to experience our world rich in art art, music and dance intertwined within our curriculum.
Q47_1:
We serve students classified as autistic, emotionally disturbed, intellectually disabled and hearing impaired.  Intertwined, within the curriculum, we continually integrate different aspects of the ARTS.  Students are provided with opportunities to visit museums, the botanical garden, puppet shows, and musical shows.  During science for example, we provided our students with the opportunity to create a "scrap wood" car that was then part of a sci-tech derby.  This opportunity of course integrated science knowledge with creativity. 
    Students create art, poetry and utilize music to tell stories or set moods.  If the DOE provided the funds to hire additonal teachers who are certified in fine art and music, our programs would be richer and more rounded for our students.

Q46_1:
Public School 77K is a District 75 school serving students on the autism spectrum from kindergarten through their graduation at age 21. We believe that the arts play a key role in learning and give our students, both verbal and nonverbal communicators, a way to express themselves creatively. Public School 77K has a strong visual arts program, in which students learn skills in drawing, painting, printmaking, sculpture, digital media and animation. Students are also exposed to art in their community through participation in programs at MoMA, the Brooklyn Museum and etc... 
Each year, we highlight their work and invite families to share in their accomplishments in school and local art exhibitions and at an annual student film festival. Our students have also had work selected for the International VSA exhibition at the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., PS Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Times Square Coalition for the Arts, Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival, and have been awarded the city and district awards in the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking Competition. In the performing arts we have a lively music program in which our students study a wide variety of musical genres and explore playing different instruments. We have partnered with cultural organizations including BAM, Music for Many, and Marquis Studios to provide further exploration of music, as well as dance and theatre to give our students the opportunity to express themselves through movement, build peer interactions, and strengthen fine motor skills.

Serving 100% of students with disabilities, we find that participation in various art forms, including visual and performing arts, and music allow our students to be successful. We tap into a talent that is generally not seen in other academic areas. Therefore, we hope to build upon our performing arts program through dance and music, and also expand our offerings to our students with autism. We hope to use this platform as a way to build positive relationships with families while giving our students with abilities a platform to perform.

Q39_4: Bake sale to raise $ for costumes & materials for SWD grant funded plays
Q46_1: Public School 231, in District 75, offers a rigorous arts education program with a full range of creative arts for our student body. Student engagement in music, dance, drama, and the visual arts is designed to develop creative thinking, problem solving, and social competence in support of student IEP goals and personal growth. Instructional plans are aligned with common core standards and the Blueprint for Learning in the Arts with special attention to cross-curricula connections, and school wide Comprehensive Educational Plan goals. Arts lessons build on prior knowledge and are designed to demonstrate growth over time. Each arts teacher provides hands-on experiential learning in large and small groups with a range of differentiated supports to facilitate student success across a varied population of student ages, needs, and abilities. The arts program at 231 includes multisensory experiences guided by teachers and artists in residence that are linked to cultural, historical, and social contexts. Arts exploration provides our students with opportunities to increase personal and community awareness and to develop peer-to-peer interaction. Throughout the year parents are invited to engage with students during various special events designed to enrich student life and nurture a lifelong enjoyment of the arts. Events may include student performances, student art exhibitions and visits to a variety of cultural institutions.

Public School 368K continues to offer visual arts to every student in our program. The arts program spans across grades and supports all students in both alternate and standardized assessments. Additionally, our annual Winterfest and Black History Concert is well attended by parents, the entire school community and our neighboring schools such as P140 and P396.  This year we did a Motown Showcase that was enjoyed by all.  
Our students will be performing at the District 75 Festival of the Arts this year, along with displays of our their visual arts projects in self-portraits and collages.  In the spring of each year, we organize the annual Spring Variety show, where students across all grades participate and exhibit their talents.  Through use of song, instruments, and technology (interactive whiteboard, laptop, music interface) our students have strived, creating their own songs and music. In addition our music teacher has written grants that have enhanced our musical program with new equipment such as keyboards, guitars and speakers.

Q47_1: P369K is District 75 school, serving students from K-12, with a range of disabilities.  For many students with special needs, the arts act as a way to express themselves, build confidence, and develop social skills.

Q46_1: Arts education is infused throughout the curriculum in all grades. The techniques students utilize, and the knowledge they acquire are gained through various multi-media projects in visual arts, music, drama and dance classes. This knowledge has helped them grow in English language arts, math, science and social studies courses.

Our school services a range of students with diverse special needs. Arts education allows the students to learn and explore through a different means and by infusing arts into the everyday curriculum. By infusing a variety of arts into our curriculum, we see students excel and shine. Students are extremely motivated to participate in our arts programs and remain engaged for extended periods of time. We currently have a fine arts, music and this year we added a dance program at one of our sites. It has been a huge success.  The students have performed at school and district sponsored events throughout the year. It has been an excellent addition to our Arts Education program.  Although these are our dedicated arts programs, all classroom teachers use arts education as part of their everyday instruction.

The goal of our program is to support the development of the whole child by engaging children in discovery and expression through the arts. Based on National, State and City Standards, and aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards, our arts programs include instruction in art making, art literacy, critique and analysis, and the study of the arts in history and culture. Arts education at The Children's School often integrates with learning in other disciplines including social studies, science and English language arts. In all units of instruction there is an emphasis on higher order thinking skills. We believe that the arts education enhances our ability to think critically, since the very act of creativity depends the students' ability to solve problems of expression and representation.
Q47_1: We are a unique educational institution, wherein our ICT classes include both District 75 and District 15 students. In our ICT program we have 2 Pre K classes, and 3 classes at each grade level K to 5. We also have a unit for children with autism, where we have 10 classes utilizing the 6:1:1 model. While this survey requests information on our District 75 children only, all of the data for our ICT classes (each class beginning with the letter T) applies to our District 15 children as well.

Q46_1: Students at PS373K The Brooklyn Transition Center have the opportunity to participate in visual art, theater, music, dance, and film/media arts in a variety of settings in our school and local community. Our students regularly visit cultural organizations, museums & galleries, attend lectures and educational films, and participate in hands-on learning experiences. Our school has built a well-rounded arts program that continues to grow and has been largely documented by the students themselves and showcased on the school website. Our school hosts an end of the year culminating arts celebration which highlights work produced in visual arts, culinary arts, film and music classes. Our visual arts teachers have recently begun an art making partnership with ADAPT Community Network, formerly United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, where students are able to assist community members in the production of visual arts. This year, our school's growing musical theater program will be presenting "The Sound of Motown" and student's work will be showcased through their hard work in prop design, chorus, dance, and acting. Our school arts program continues to evolve yearly, as nearly all classroom teachers and service providers are collaborating to incorporate different arts disciplines into their instruction to support our curricula and our young adults' creative endeavors.
Q47_1: We are a D75 high school and all our students are alternative assessment. Our students are diagnosed with moderate to severe disabilities including intellectual disabilities, autism, and emotional behavioral disorders.

Q39_4: We had a make art with your child day. We have had parents accompany class trips. We host family paint night and family dance events.
Q46_1: P 721K Brooklyn OTC, our students are within grades K-2 and 9-12 (up to 21 years old). We offer full-time arts instruction in music, theater, dance and visual art. Dance is provided through an Arts Residency with Youth Step USA. This year we hired a full time certified music teacher. Non-arts teachers use theater, music, movement/dance and visual arts to enhance/expand the curriculum.  We have expanded our use of cultural providers to enhance student access to a variety of art forms. Strong connections to The Metropolitan Museum will continue next year. This year we began a partnership with New Victory Theater and Lincoln Center. We continued our work with Laser painting with Marquis Studios. Community-based learning is part of our curricula, We are working to fully integrate all art forms into our school's sequence and provided in-house professional development programming in art instruction. Our school offers students and their families an opportunity to enjoy paint night, films or participate in a dance at our Family Nights every month throughout the school year. This year we held our 1st Arts and Family Engagement Dayiwth the MET. Our student's artistic achievements have been recognized as the cover of the 2018 VSA calendar, and at Pratt Manhattan Gallery, PS Art, Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival visual and theatre pieces and the District 75 Festival of The Arts.

We at the School for Career Development explore and embrace a variety of art forms and programs that have proven useful to our student population. Our program is unique because it supports our students’ social and emotional learning and incorporates practical skill building. A well-staffed and supportive team of professionals working collaboratively accomplishes this. Students are prepared not only on a social and emotional level, but can graduate from the school with practical, job related skills and experiences. We have utilized the arts as a means of communication and personal expression in working with our student population on the autism spectrum. Our goal is to stress the importance of academics, job skills, and competitive employment. For this, we facilitate specific programs that are aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts
Q47_1: Brooklyn School for Career Development is a special education HS serving students with emotional and intellectual disabilities along with those on the autism spectrum. Arts in the school provide an avenue/platform for the students to develop socially and emotionally, and to also articulate themselves.

Q46_1: Public School 771K is a District 75 special education school across eight sites. The school as a whole, participates in arts through literacy, and the art teachers work closely with classroom teachers to create a curriculum based on units of study. Our school has participated in the Marquis Studios program with outside teachers working with the students in music and dance. The goal of the our art program, is to provide the students with resources and hands-on experience that will help foster their love and understanding of the arts. This goal will hopefully lead the students to discover a lifelong enjoyment and appreciation of the arts. Through these experiences, Public School 771K hopes to provide an environment that will help the students develop in ways that will improve their educational, social and emotional goals, as well as to enhance their skill set.

The Connie Lekas School is committed to providing a rich arts program to help our students reach their goals. This year we worked with Marquis Studios to complete six successful residencies in a variety of disciplines. We continue to support our full time arts teachers as well as non-arts teachers with extensive professional development, including the Inspiring Learners Through Art program. We have an accomplished vocal chorale, and our families and community enjoy gathering for our semi-annual Family Arts Day. This year, we were proud of the accomplishments of our young artists who were chosen to be represented in both the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival and P.S. Art. Additionally, three of our students received awards in the Morgan Book Project at the Morgan Library.
Q47_1: Our school is composed 100 percent of students with disabilities, including multiple disabilities, autism spectrum disorder and students with intellectual disabilities.

Q46_1: Public School 35M is an elementary through high school with students from kindergarten through grade twelve. Our school is dedicated to academic excellence. We offer students multifaceted arts experiences in an environment organized to provide opportunities and supports appropriate to student abilities. Teachers implement the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts Curriculum and The New York State Arts Standards by aligning arts instruction with the Common Core Learning Standards. Assessment is made on individual achievement related to each student’s stage of growth and development. An arts integration model engages students in various arts activities linked to literacy in the arts, making arts connections to other academic areas, utilizing community cultural resources, acquiring knowledge of arts careers and encouraging students to regard arts as a means of expression and a source of lifelong enjoyment. The art program enables each student to develop positive attitudes toward self, others and the environment through creative experiences. Problem solving and creative learning encourage the student to relate visual knowledge to other core subjects and to respond with originality, appreciation, flexibility and imagination.

The Spectrum School is the District 75 School of Visual and Performing Arts. Residencies with ArtsConnection and Marquis Studios build on instruction provided by twelve school-based arts specialists across eight sites, engaging kindergarten through twelfth grade students with special needs in dedicated arts programming for more than 50% of the school week. In class instruction and residencies, students creatively access core content curricula in English language arts, math, social studies and science through the arts. Our nationally-recognized musical theater program, STAARS (Sequential Teaching in Arts, Action Research and Scholarship), based in arts education research, grounded in the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, and NYS Arts Standards, is a sequential arts curriculum through which children learn the social/emotional and communication skills, paired with the academics they need to succeed in school and daily life.

Q44_R1_C10: Offered complementary services in the past
Q46_1: At P226M, we strive to maintain programming in the arts that is sequential, expands the skill base and knowledge of our students, and aligns to the Common Core Learning Standards. We expect students to increase their physical and intellectual proficiency in the arts as they engage in a variety of motivating, hands-on curricular experiences. Our goals in the arts include developing critical thinking skills through in-class creations, paired with writing about the experience and learning about the arts by viewing art in museums, galleries and the theatre. Interaction with the arts develops students’ interest in art-making, theatre, dance and music and promotes higher order thinking skills by making connections to other subject areas.

Our goal is to expose students to the arts and encourage life-long learning. Through visits from our arts partners, students are introduced to and develop an understanding of how the arts reflect diverse cultures of the past and present - through music, movement and visual arts such as painting, sculpture, printmaking and collage. Our collaboration with the arts organizations has led to an important kind of thinking which transfers to all areas for our students. These multisensory means of engagement are aligned with Common Core Learning Standards and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. The arts have positively contributed to the social emotional and academic areas in each classroom. Thus, our students have exhibited increased respect for personal space, taking turns, listening and responding appropriately. Our visual arts units exemplify collaborative teamwork among students. The residencies have made a strong impact on our students by increasing peer to peer respect, building vocabulary and confidence to express themselves in a safe environment. In addition, through dance and rhythm, our students worked through impulse control, sequencing skills, following directions and socialization. The multisensory nature of the arts is vital to our students. We believe in the expressive, creative and therapeutic benefits of engaging through the arts.
Q47_1: Many of the questions related to exact numbers are very difficult to answer ,since our students population is transient and changes on a daily basis. Therefore, it is important to mention that the numbers reflect a snapshot of students, but do not truly reflect the attendance for a full school year. In addition, we do not have students for a full day in many sites so we must integrate the arts into other content areas to address all standards in a short amount of time. we greatly value the arts and appreciate what the arts budget affords for our special students. Although, capturing data is a challenge for a transient group of students , we see firsthand the power and magic that the arts have on our hospitalized students.

Q46_1: Home Instruction Schools is an interim program serving over 3000 students per year who receive instruction until they are ready to return to their school of affiliation. Art and music is taught as a requirement for high school students. Art and music is also used for all of our Alternate Assessment students to develop gross and fine motor skills and is used to differentiate student learning. The arts program is also infused into the curriculum for elementary and middle school students to help enhance their learning in other academic areas.

Our school's mission and vision is to promote independence while providing a smooth transition from school to life in the community and the best post-secondary outcomes for all. Our school stresses the acquisition of basic, functional skills that students generalize in all settings to help them become more independent learners and thinkers. Our teachers incorporate multi-media and visual arts in their instruction, and many of our students' culminating projects integrate the arts. Student involvement in the arts not only enriches their lives, but also supports their academic and social development. During this past year, we have successfully provided our students with arts instruction through our visual arts program, African Drumming through Title III and Theater with Project Arts. Families are engaged in culminating events that include student performance as well as audience participation. Parents and students were involved in weekend programs to various arts institions.

At our school the arts provide students with opportunities to learn about music, visual arts, and film as forms of personal and cultural expression. Students work with classroom teachers to connect the arts to their core content classes, as well as to explore how they relate to career readiness. Our school has a long-standing relationship with community organization, Best Buddies, IncludeNYC, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Zumba, Marquis Studios, and several arts related trips, which allows the school to collaborate with the community and effectively exposes students to the arts across disciplines. Students also participate in community-based arts field trips in each discipline.

While following the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, our goal is to provide a meaningful arts program to all students with disabilities. We strive to achieve this by being committed to the arts by staffing all our sites with full time arts teachers. We also work with a variety of arts organizations to provide professional development for our arts teachers, as well as exposure to the arts for our students, in our culturally rich community. Our students are also exposed to the arts through visits to theaters, museums and concert halls. Additionally, we provide performances on and off site in order to present the student's hard work to their parents and guardians. There is also a great deal of collaboration between the arts teachers and the classroom teachers across all sites.

Visual arts, theater, digital media and music are offered to our students throughout the year. Students in grades 3-5 and 8-12 participate in Little Kids Rock, a nationwide program which uses the “Music as a Second Language” pedagogical approach to involve students in creating music. Students learn guitar, bass, keyboards, and drums while playing contemporary and classic popular music. The emphasis is on getting students playing as quickly as possible and to integrate music theory as needed. This year, performed a H.E.L.P. Concert: Songs of Hope, Empowerment, Love, and Peace, inspired by the youth movements of the 1960s. 

Students also participated in the NYCDOE’s Digital Theatre Program. Through the Office of Arts and Special Project’s partnership with C&T Theatre in England, students used theater techniques to explore contemporary issues and shared their work with students from around NYC and the world. Students in grades 3-5 interviewed members of the community who had migration stories to tell, then they recreated these journeys in video vignettes, and shared their work, along with the work of other NYCDOE students and students from around the globe, on an interactive digital platform created by C&T Theatre, called PushPull.tech. Students also participated in online video chats with students in St. Petersburg, Russia, and Nairobi, Kenya. 

High school students earn credits for music, theater, and art that fulfill requirements for graduation.
Q47_1:
Public School 23Q is a multi-site organization serving students in K-12th grade from all five boroughs. It is our belief that an effective arts program contributes to the emotional and educational well-being of the whole child. Our goal is to provide a basic foundation and appreciation of the arts and to have this foundation support other areas of instructional learning throughout the school day. Through the arts, we are able to reinforce content areas through hands-on project-based learning, increase self-esteem, develop social and self-advocacy skills, and improve team building while addressing the students' individual needs with regard to their various learning styles. 

As part of District 75’s initiative to promote Student Advocacy for students with disabilities, students in PS23Q learned about the history of the disability rights movement and created a plan to advocate for a need they determined needed addressing. High School classes at P23Q are creating a play that will shine a light on the nature of disabilities often overlooked in our society and the source of bullying for young people who live with them. The play, which integrates research, creative writing, and theater skits devised by students, educates others about 12 emotional disorders in an effort to increase understanding about the disorders and to decrease bullying that stems from ignorance. Students will perform the play at assemblies in general education schools in an on-going community service initiative.

Q46_1: Dealing with disabled students the arts benefits our students enabling them to be creative with an abundance of materials and activities.  The arts helps the students to relieve stress and lessens their frustrations throughout the day. They are able to succeed at their own pace as well as allowing them to experience many different genres of art. This year we were able to expand our art program in different disciplines due to many grants we were able to receive. Hopefully the acquisition of future grants will permit us to continue to expose all of our students to the many facets of the arts.

Q47_1:
WE have many sites and a variety of students served at our District 75 school.
The most capable students have emotional issues which interfere with their learning and behavior.  We serve Special PK and deaf and hard of hearing students some with cholera devices.  The gamut is from PK special ed to middle school children, up to eighth grade. Many of our children are lower functioning with or without being on the autistic spectrum.  In our most autistic site we have visual artists and dance artists come and provide services in the classrooms.
We also are sharing space with a general education school (at most sites) and have very limited space.

Q46_1: P233Q serves students in grades K-12 in District 75. Students have one or more of the following disabilities: autism, health impairments, intellectual disabilities, orthopedic disabilities, speech and language impairments, sensory impairments, emotional disabilities, and/or learning disabilities. Curriculum design includes units of study in keeping with the NYSED Standards for the Arts. The established yearlong "arts" curriculum includes units of study for music and the visual arts. To extend learning across content areas, the arts are infused into various core subjects including, ELA, Social Studies, APE and the school wide behavior management program: Power of Choice. At the start of the school year, students are encouraged to try out for different clubs (i.e. art, band, dance, step, theater, etc.). Over the course of the year, classes participate in special assemblies to include a performance by Young Audiences. High school students participated in the District 75 Arts Festival. As several P233Q classes are housed in a community schools, several classes participate in assemblies/clubs with non-disabled peers. Middle and high school students are encouraged to participate in extra-curricula clubs such as: theater, Aimee, chorus, art, and/or dance as a way to build self-esteem and socialize with non-disabled peers. Other student centered "art" opportunities include participation in culminating unit assemblies, talents shows, the creation of  displays, poster campaigns, classroom presentations, and performance videos.

Public School 255Q's arts program supports the school's focus of a multi-sensory approach to learning. Teachers of the arts provide instruction in their disciplines with emphasis on teaching targets related to developing skills. These teaching targets are developed through the use of school-wide assessments. Additionally, teachers of the arts, in collaboration with classroom teachers, select student IEP goals for which they collect data and monitor student progress thus supporting on-going collaboration. This process advances a collective responsibility for implementation of the IEP as a comprehensive plan.
Q47_1: Our school's ongoing collaboration with Marquis Studios and our new partnership with Daniel's music has been wonderful for our students and teachers.  The teaching artists from Marquis Studios of are the highest caliber and understand best practices for students on the autism spectrum.

Q46_1: P256Q remains dedicated to art enhanced experiences for all. Our school's 6, soon to be 7 (D75)sites service students Pre-K through 12, with varying degrees of abilities. We have 3 Elementary,1 M.S,1 H.S and 2 residential M.S./H.S. sites. We serve students who take Standardized as well as Alternate Assessment Tests. We take pride in our Annual NYS Regents Successes as well as our Job Training to Work Program for our Alternate Assessment Graduates. We are unique in serving youth from El Salvador, Nicaragua, Venezuela etc. who have been placed in our care directly from internment camps at the U.S. border. Our St. Johns site has 24 young men in a Close to Home Program, an alternative to incarceration for first time  offenders. This diversity of students, as well as the 40 mile spread of sites make it difficult to offer our student populations qualifying art programs that speak to each of our populations.Resident Artists selected for specific sites work best; we have already scheduled (2) Puppetry Residences for 2018-2019. We have applied and been selected to receive an Arts Grant in collaboration with Arts Connection. We continue to reach out to and search for "Free" services, (Artist Commissioning Program- H.S. to Art School, FREE Internship- 8- week Job Experience Prog., Planned Parenthood, Be an Upstander- LGBT Anti-Bullying Prog., Be Proud, Be Responsible- HIV/AIDS Workshop).Budgetary limitations make it difficult to schedule in-school performances, which would work be best for our students with limited mobility.
Q47_1:
Our school's 6, soon to be 7 sites service a wide range of students with varying degrees of abilities. We have 3 Elementary,1 M.S,1 H.S and 2 residential Middle/High school sites. We serve students who take Standardized Assessments as well as Alternate Assessment Tests. We pride ourselves on our Annual NYS Regents Successes as well as the Success of our Job Training to work Program for our Alternate Assessment Graduates. We are unique in our ability to serve youth from El Salvador, Nicaragua, Venezuela etc. who have been placed in our care directly from internment camps at the U.S. border. Our St. Johns site has 24 young men in a Close to Home Program, an alternative to incarceration for first time  offenders. This diversity of students, as well as the 40 mile spread of our sites makes it difficult to supply our student populations with qualifying art programs that speak to each of our populations. Residencies are best, this year we scheduled 4 residencies, but that does not enable us to reach even 1/2 of the population.
We have been lucky enough to find programs who have supplied theater tickets, guest speakers and programmatic support,(Artist Commissioning Program- H.S. to Art School, FREE Internship - An 8- week Job Experience Program, Planned Parenthood, Be an Upstander- LGBT Anti-Bullying Program, Be Proud, Be Responsible- HIV/AIDS Workshop)
We have conducted a school-wide STEM/Robotic Fair-Science Engineering Program and United We Om provides free Yoga classes throughout the year for our ever-changing population.

Q46_1: The art and music programs for all Public School 277Q sites are aligned with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and instructional targets are based on the five strands. Students are provided the opportunity to explore different periods, artists, media, and techniques in art and music. The arts program is aligned with our ongoing English language arts and social studies curriculum. Musical performances and art exhibits are ongoing through out the year to celebrate student achievement and we implement culminating activities in the areas of art and music.

The John F. Kennedy Jr. School provides services to approximately 490 students with a range of educational, social and physical needs. We have created a program which incorporates the arts in order to maximize our students’ progress towards independence, integration and productivity. Our program incorporates music, dance, visual arts and the performing arts. Our music program provides students with the opportunity to expand their musical abilities and work collaboratively in a chorus. Through dance, motor and movement is addressed. We have visual arts and photography programs that allow our students to express themselves creatively. Annual theater productions and holiday shows give students the chance to demonstrate their theatrical talents. Lastly, we offer concerts and cultural events both during and after school hours that foster an appreciation of the arts for our students and their families.
Q47_1: 100% of our students have IEPs. From our 500 students, only 3 take state tests. Art is a big component in our school. Our students attend music, fine arts and dance classes. We out together two large theatrical performances every year. We have a school band and work closely with Marquis Studios.

Q46_1: The goals of the arts program at the Queens Transition Center are to: a) integrate arts education into the programming of all alternate and standardized assessment students and bridge the arts into the content areas, b) collaborate and create a series of culminating projects and activities aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards and transition goals of all our students, c) foster positive peer interactions to build communication and help increase tolerance of diverse individuals. For the 2017-2018 school, year we strived to integrate a framework that encourages parents, educators, and school communities to work together within the arts to provide better opportunities for college and career readiness and other post-secondary outcomes.

The arts education program at Public School 811Q is multi-faceted. In multi-media classes students used digital cameras to edit and print photos. Students learned how to edit the school's yearbook; delete old photos and upload the digital pictures of new graduates. Students in all grades received visual art instruction and learned new concepts, with hands-on art making and self expression. Students who received dance and music instruction held several performances throughout the year. Students' work was exhibited at the schools' annual Gallery Walk, the District 75 Office and at the Queens Museum of Art which held a residency program at three of our sites. At the Queens High School for Teaching site, students received art instruction in scrapbooking, technology (including photography and video), dance, music and art. Students were also offered the opportunity to join various school clubs: glee, dance, music, girls club and boys club. The arts education goal for our school is to provide the students the resources and tools to enable them to explore and enjoy the various forms of art.
Q47_1: Alternate Assessment District 75 School serving students in Grades K-12+.  Special Education teachers are needed to teach all the arts in order to best adapt work for our students. Our Alternate Assessment ratios are 12:1:4, 6:1:1, 8:1:1 and 12:1:1 in Grades K-12+.

Q44_R1_C10: We like to use different services so we can get different shows.
Q46_1:
This year we used Arts Connection for our elementary and middle school performances and our high school Artist Residency program. By having these programs available to us, over 600 students were given the opportunity to experience the music and culture of several areas of the world they might not otherwise have access to. The visiting Theater artist at our high school has enabled our students to learn and fine tune already learned coping skill, listening skills, coordination and peer interactions.
We so appreciate the valuable experiences these programs give our students.

The art curriculum in our school sets goals for our students. Students will be assigned various projects over the course of the year, exploring and mastering a variety of media, and learning the required skills to accomplish the set tasks. Students will learn and apply various themes, concepts and symbols to communicate ideas through art. Students will use the knowledge and skills gained from previous projects and apply them to the following ones. The student will use problem solving skills, perseverance, effort and patience when approaching each task. Students will complete all assigned work within the time frame.

Our classroom teachers incorporate the arts into their curriculum and provide a multi-sensory approach to teaching our special needs students. This approach lends itself to using the arts as an important teaching tool. Our licensed art teacher provides opportunities for her students to shine, by teaching them how to use their creativity and talents to create works of art that are showcased each year, at various art venues around the city.  We are also fortunate enough to be a partnership school with Marquis Studios. Our students benefit each year from quality arts instruction, in music, the visual arts, and dance. Our staff and students have formed long-term relationships with many master teaching artists from Marquis Studios, who have provided opportunities for both students, through programming, and parents, through parent-child workshops, to embrace the arts and cultivate the talents of our students! Our school is also proud to be a TATI school. With financial and mentoring support from Marquis Studios, teaching artists from The Teaching Artist Training Institute have the opportunity to come to our school to learn about effective methods of working with students on the Autism Spectrum as well as students with other developmental disabilities. Our school has been given the honor this year, of being named the "David Marquis School of the Arts". We will do our best to honor the late David Marquis by continuing to provide quality arts programming for our students.

It continues to be our goal at 75R373 to provide a comprehensive arts curriculum within the framework of Danielson, the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, and aligned with Core Curriculum Learning Standards. Through the arts, we seek to address the varied learning modalities of our special needs students, in both standardized and alternate assessment, making powerful connections across the content areas. Recognizing the power of the arts to support our students' emotional and social growth, as well as academic growth, we continue to support Emotional Literacy in and through the various arts disciplines. To this end, we continuously strive to expand our programs, to partner with cultural organizations and to elevate the rigor of our arts instruction through cohorts and professional development. With an aggressive approach to grant writing, we constantly seek out opportunities for our students and we have been able to supplement our existing programs and to also bring in partner organizations. This past year we were fortunate to have the distinction of being recognized as a highlighted school in the annual Arts in Schools Report.  We hope to continue to live up to that honor and continue to grow.
Q47_1: Our D75 school currently serves students with disabilities in Pre-K through the 8th grade. Our students have multiple diagnoses, including Behaviorally Impaired, Downs Syndrome, and on the Autism Spectrum.  This year we expanded with the addition of a new co-located site at 31R006.  It has been an ongoing struggle to have equity of arts instruction across grades and sites, as we were in 7 buildings for the 2017-2018 academic year.  In September of 2018, we will be adding an 8th site, at 31R061.  As our enrollment continues to grow, we are spread across the length and width of Staten Island, making it difficult, not only financially, but logistically as well, to provide every student with even one art discipline delivered by a cultural partner and/or arts cluster.  Except for 8 classes, the remainder of visual arts is art on a cart, impacting 43 classrooms that are used for arts instruction (the survey caps at 25).  In many cases, due to a lack of art teachers on staff for so many locations, art instruction is delivered by the classroom teachers, for a total of 20 classes.  Additionally, co-locations pose the problem of competition for space for performances, practices and studio arts, etc.  As an example, one of our sites was forced to decline participation with the Disney in Schools program due to an inability to secure time for rehearsal and performance space.  Sadly, these programs, which have such an incredible impact on our students, often must be severely altered or cut due to constraints of space and finances.

Q46_1: Public School 721R is a District 75 school with a main site and six annexes. At all our inclusion sites, we are proud to say that our students are included and succeed in general education classes. The students are part of general education choral and musical shows and their visual arts projects are displayed within the schools. At our main site, we have our own school choir and entertain audiences at various community events. The arts are incorporated in the core curricula for students to make connections with other content areas and our students attend various cultural institutions within New York City. Funds from the Shubert Foundation will support our production of "Lion King Jr." at our school's main site. This year our school continued to work with Lincoln Center Education, which we funded with Project ARTS money and a NYCDOE Arts & Family Engagement grant.  We also received a Signature Bank Grant for a Family Arts Night. We find that our parents are strong advocates for the arts and as a school, we are assertive proposal writers for additional arts funding. We continue to be a Lincoln Center Education "Focus School."  We conduct active research to study the impact of integrating arts instruction with the Lincoln Center Education's capacities (for imaginative thinking) on our students with special needs. We plan on sharing our school team's findings with the school community at large, as well as with Lincoln Center Education, and their other Focus Schools.  We are applying to continue our Focus School work for 2018-19.

Q39_4: Contributing cultural food dishes to support the Flamenco Vivo arts gala/fiesta
Q46_1: P17X is a District 75 school serving students with disabilities and diverse learners with an emphasis on connecting arts learning across the content areas, and between our elementary and middle school sites through Project Arts Funding and Arts Partnership Grant Programs. Our arts partnerships with Inside Broadway, Flamenco Vivo and New Victory Theatre continue to enhance Blueprint based arts programming, increase parental engagement and increase our NYSED hours to meet our special needs students in all arts disciplines. Our students participate in, and have a history of winning arts competitions including PS Art, the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking competition, All Kids Can Create National Exhibit, All You Can Be by former Yankee Curtis Granderson, and the Bronx Borough Arts Festival.

PS168X is a district 75 school serving standardized and alternate assessment students from Pre-K to High School at seven different sites. The arts program at each site is unique, tailored to the student's age, ability, and class ratio. Music and Visual Arts teachers independently plan arts instruction for the students at their respective site. Our high school students receive arts instruction from the host school's teachers thus that information is not reflected in this survey. All of our arts teachers are full-time teachers teaching in their subject area. They include 2 certified music teachers, 2 certified visual arts teachers, 5 special education teachers teaching literacy through the arts and 1 technology teacher teaching art through technology.  Out main site has a dedicated music room, a dedicated visual arts room and a dedicated technology room. The rest of our arts teachers teach in multi-purpose rooms or travel with carts pushing into classrooms. Instruction is aligned with the NYC Blueprint in the appropriate art discipline and supports the Common Core Learning Standard and IEP goals of the students. Classes are differentiated according to interest, age and ability. Each site holds an end of year performance/celebration in auditoriums we share with the other schools at each of our respective sites. Students display they art work and/or perform for their peers and family members.
Q47_1: It is difficult to capture the unique strengths and challenges of the arts programs at each of our sites in a single survey. This information represents an average drawn from all sites that a hypothetical student could receive at PS168X.  In reality there is wide variance in the type and quantity of arts learning opportunities that individual students receive at their respective sites.

Q46_1: Public School 176X is a district 75 program serving students with Autism Spectrum Disorder and other special needs. Through the art forms such as music, modern dance, hip hop, yoga, STEM, ballet, musical theater, band, chorus and visual arts, students enhance their language, self direction, social skills, reading and life skills as well as performance skills. Aside from projects based in literacy, the school has developed several performing arts groups such as a school chorus, keyboard, three drum lines and a dance troupe. We continue to work with the EASE organization through professional development and online services. This year, the school received the Shubert Arts Grant/Marquis Studios/Daniel's Music for theater workshops involving students and their families. Our school participates in a district sponsored yoga program entitled Get Ready to Learn. Public School 176X participates in District 75 arts events. Students participate in monthly assemblies during which they perform or attend performances that help facilitate a positive school culture for students, parents and staff. The school has a collaboration with the Disney Organization, where Disney drama educators worked with students and staff toward a culminating performance of "Mulan." The entire school community was involved with production in some capacity. The arts provide a pathway to learning that connects the Common Core Learning Standards, the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts as well as parent engagement.

The P186X arts program utilizes the NYCDOE Blueprint for the arts curriculum framework. Our students engage in project-based learning activities in the visual arts, as well as cooperative team activities in movement and theater arts. During the 2017/2018 school year, P186X developed and scheduled an Advanced Art class for those identified eighth grade students whose goal was to apply to a specialized art high school and future careers in a general education setting. In the 2018/2019 school year, the school plans to initiate a digital arts program to support our students to foster skills similar to their general education peers.
Q47_1: Our students are classified with either severe psychiatric/behavioral issues and/or severe cognitive developmental delays, P186X's fine motor skills' program is aligned with their academic and social-emotional needs.

Q46_1: Our art program continues to be robust. Public School 188X integrates the arts into our curriculum following the Blueprint for the Arts. We strive to meet the needs of our diverse student population. We have two theater classes at two sites, art and literacy at two sites, and visual arts at three of our sites. Public School 188X offers a dance movement class at two of our sites and continues to explore arts integration. We continue to strive to meet the diverse needs of our students through the arts internally and externally with the help of cultural programs, public performances and art exhibits. We partner with Marquis Art Studio annually and MOMA to support our students' learning. We were the recipient of Broadway Jr grant for our Middles Schoolers along with a mural grant from Councilman Torres' office. Arts Horizon also provided us with a grant for four classes.  Our teachers participate in EASE professional development along with district based professional development. We participate in Materials for the Arts program, providing our teachers with art materials. Our high school inclusion program is partnered with an arts community based organization.  We received honors from the NYCDOE for our arts education program and the Bronx Museum of Art. Our students enjoy and excel in the arts. Public School 188x loves the arts and values arts integration in our curriculum and school community.

Our goal is to provide arts instruction that is appropriate, individualized and thoughtfully designed to address the strengths and needs of all students at P352X. The arts are an integral part of instruction at P352X and are embedded within the curriculum across all subject areas. Teachers of the arts work with classroom teachers and related service providers to support students in improving socialization skills through real world, cross-curricular and collaborative experiences. Students participate in a wide range of authentic art experiences to broaden their understanding of various art forms and related careers. Students can be found creating original works of art, performing traditional song or dance and experimenting with media to create an iMovie. To extend art education beyond the classroom, we take advantage of every opportunity to expose our students to the vast cultural resources that New York City has to offer and we value the partnerships we’ve formed with our community.

Public School 721X The Stephen D McSweeney School has, over the past several years, demonstrated an expanded commitment to the arts. Most of our highlights this year focused on student performances  in music. As part of our celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, our Latin Music Show this past October featured ten different classes performing to a variety of genres.  One class choreographed a merengue dance to a song called "El Farolito" by Juan Luis Guerra.  Another class performed their own exciting version of Marc Anthony's "Vivir Mi Vida", which featured live keyboards, drums and vocals.  A third class also performed a salsa number "La Gozadera" by Gente de Zona, which featured student's dancing with Puerto Rican flags.  A fourth highlight was a bachata song "Culpa al Corazon" by Prince Royce, performed by a class featuring their percussion ensemble.  Our show, Music Through The Years, featured songs from the 1950's to present day including: Elvis, The Temptations, Jackson 5, Prince, Madonna, Queen, and Adele.  One highlight was a student performing solo piano to Michael Jackson's "Billy Jean."  Another highlight of the show was a duo singing Adele's "Someone Like You."  All in all, every student that performed was special and unique.  Two of our students had artwork exhibited and another performed a piano solo in the performance showcase of the Bronx Borough Arts Festival. A dance troupe create by a classroom paraprofessional will be performing at the District 75 Festival for the Arts. We have had numerous performances

This school year, 2017-2018, we decided to use Marquis Studios to develop a drum corp. We believe that having students learn a discipline such as drumming will help them develop better self-esteem, social skills and coordination. Additionally, our fulltime arts teachers helped our students learn about various artists and the art they created, from collages to abstract to impressionism.
Q47_1: Our schools serves students with severe disabilities, including autism, emotional disturbance and intellectual disabilities.

Q46_1: Our art program has continued to strive. Students have been learning about art history from around the world as well as gaining the skill set to produce their own work. This year, some of our kids have excelled with chalk pastels. We will be showcasing a student's exemplary landscape art work in the Festival of the Arts during June.

The PS811X team believes that all students are entitled to appropriate, authentic and stimulating learning experiences that will maximize their quality of life.  Our arts programming celebrates our students' unique talents and provides opportunities to celebrate their individuality. Our young artists have physical disabilities, intellectual disabilities, attention-deficit hyperactivity disorders, learning impairments and autism spectrum disorders.  The arts programming incorporates the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, aligns with New York State Arts Standards, and Common Core Learning Standards.  The curriculum is differentiated to meet the needs of our students' diverse learning styles and ability levels.  We support our students and their journey to gain independence, self-confidence, and daily living skills. 
  Next year we hope to better create a learning environment that addresses the unique needs of our students with multiple disabilities.  We aim to make the art rooms more accessible and less distracting to increase student participation, focus and achievement.  We aim to do this by adding appropriate tables that are adapted for wheelchair users, visual arts storage and other adaptive equipment that are suitable for our students.
